英雄装备自己的物品有很多种：饼干和金钱、一艘载有醉酒船员的船、一顶帐篷、一匹马。通常所有这些东西都是多余的，英雄要求它们只是为了把灰尘扔到眼睛里。例如，我们的调查将证明，从父亲家里拿走的那匹马没有用处，而是被另一匹马取代。但在这些物体中，有一个值得特别关注：俱乐部。这根棍子是铁做的，通常英雄在出发前会要求它：“好心人，给我锻造一根重5普德 41的棍子”（Af.104d）。这是什么俱乐部？为了测试它，英雄将它扔到空中（甚至三次）。因此可以推断它是一根棍子，一件武器。但事实并非如此。首先，有时英雄不使用他从家里带来的俱乐部，叙述者在故事的后面完全忘记了这一点。其次，从比较中可以看出，英雄随身携带的除了铁棍之外，还有铁门 42和铁靴子。 “伊万努斯卡去了铁匠那里，做了三个衣架，煮了三个prophora，然后出发寻找马森卡”（Sm. 35）。飞走之前，菲尼斯特对女孩说：“如果你想找我，就到遥远的国度、遥远的国度来找我。在你再次找到我之前，你会穿坏三双鞋，你会折断三根铁棒，你会啃三把铁prophoras ”（AF.129a）。青蛙女人也说了同样的话：“好吧，伊万王子，到第七个王国来找我，磨破铁靴子，咬三个铁质的Prosphoras ”（Af. 150 b）。

The objects the hero provides himself with are of many kinds: biscuits and money, a ship with a drunken crew, a tent, a horse. Usually all these things are superfluous, the hero asks for them only to throw dust in his eyes. Our investigation will show for example that the horse taken from the paternal home is of no use and is replaced with another. But among these objects there is one that deserves particular attention: the club. This club is made of iron, usually the hero asks for it before setting out on a journey: "Good people, forge me a club that weighs five pud 41 " (Af. 104 d). What kind of club is it? To test it the hero throws it in the air (even three times). One could therefore deduce that it is a club, a weapon. But this is not the case. First of all, sometimes the hero does not use the club he brought from home, the narrator forgets it completely in the continuation of the story. Secondly, it follows from the comparisons that the hero takes with him, along with the iron club, an iron prosphora 42 and iron boots. "Ivanushka went to the blacksmith, forged three crutches, baked three prosphoras , and set out to find Mashenka" (Sm. 35). Before flying away, Finist says to the girl: "If you have a mind to look for me, look for me in the distant lands, in the distant kingdom. You will wear out three pairs of shoes, break three iron rods, gnaw three iron prosphoras before you find me" (Aph. 129 a). The frog-woman says the same: "Well, Prince Ivan, look for me in the seventh kingdom, wear out iron boots, and gnaw three iron prosphoras " (Aph. 150 b).

在杆+面包+靴子的复合体中，很容易缺少一个甚至两个组件。通常我们只处理面包：（“给他烤一条三个布丁”：St.，275），或者只处理鞋类（“让他缝制许多不同的双鞋”：Sad.60），或者，最后我们只有杆子。我们经常发现面包被合理化为饼干、旅行用品等，而棍棒被合理化为魔杖或棍棒；这里我们有一个意义的转换，使杆看起来像武器，但它从来不代表武器的一部分，从下面的例子中很容易看出：“鞋子被沙子磨坏了，帽子被刺穿了”被雨淋湿了，拐杖变得太细了，拿不住了”（Sev.14）。在这里，衣架不再充当武器，保留了其原始功能。或者：“如果你愿意的话，锻造三个铜帽然后出发。”当他刺穿了他的矛，磨损了他的帽子时，他就会找到我”（《诗篇》130）。在这里，狼牙棒变成了一支矛，但变成了英雄靠在上面行走的矛，而他并不将其用作武器。有趣的是，这种三重元素在以女性为主角的童话故事中得到了更好的保留（芬尼斯特等人）。这是因为女性的身材不适合携带武器，因此狼牙棒始终保持其原始外观。

It is easy for one or even two components of the rod + bread + boots complex to be missing. Often we are dealing with only the bread: (« Bake him a loaf of three poods »: St., 275), or only with the footwear (« Have him sew many different pairs of shoes »: Sad. 60), or, finally, we have only the rod. We often find that the bread is rationalized into biscuits, travel provisions, etc., and the rod into a wand or club; here we have a transposition of meaning that makes the rod appear as a weapon, but it never represents the part of a weapon, as is easy to see from the following example: « The shoes wear out because of the sand, the cap gets holes because of the rain, the crutch becomes thinner when held in the hand » (Sev. 14). Here the crutch does not serve as a weapon, and retains its primitive function. Or: "If he wishes, let him have three copper caps forged for himself and then set out. When he has pierced the spears and worn out the caps, then he will find me" (Sm. 130). Here the club is transformed into a spear, but into a spear on which the hero leans to walk, and which he does not use as a weapon. It is interesting to note that this triple element has been better preserved in the fairy tales in which the protagonist is a woman (Finist, and others). This is because the figure of the woman does not lend itself to being armed, and therefore the club is constantly preserved in its primitive aspect.

可见，鞋子、狼牙棒和面包是死者前往另一个世界朝圣时所携带的物品。后来它们变成了铁，象征着旅程的长度。

It can be seen that the shoes, the club and the bread were the objects with which the dead were provided for their pilgrimage to the other world. They became iron later, to symbolize the length of the journey.

查鲁津说：“由于对旅程和来世的表现……人们还发现一些物品被放置在坟墓中，或者与死者一起被烧毁。如果死者必须渡过水面才能到达阴影世界，那么在他的坟墓里放一艘小船是很自然的。如果他必须走很长的距离，他就会得到更坚固的鞋子” 43。

Charuzin says: « As a consequence of the representation of the journey and the afterlife… one also finds objects placed in the grave or that are burned together with the dead. It is quite natural that if the dead person has to cross the water to reach the world of shadows, a small boat is placed in his grave. If he has to walk a long way, he is given more sturdy footwear » 43 .

这种代表已经在北美印第安人中发现。在博阿斯抄写的传说中，英雄想要找到他死去的妻子。 “他向父亲要了五张熊皮，并用它们剪出了一百双鞋” 44。因此，要前往死者的境界，您需要坚固的鞋子。在加利福尼亚州，印第安人总是穿着莫卡辛鞋埋葬45。 “加州原住民为死者配备鞋子，因为通往永恒狩猎地点的道路漫长而艰难” 46。在孟加拉，死者“装备得好像他们必须进行长途旅行” 47。在埃及人中，死者配备了一根棍子和凉鞋48。《亡灵之书》第 125 章的其中一个变体标题如下：“死者在洁净、清洗、穿好衣服、穿白色皮凉鞋后必须背诵这一章…… » 在阿斯塔特的僧侣纸莎草书中，这样描述阿斯塔特（在地狱中）：“你要去哪里，普塔的女儿，愤怒而可怕的女神？你脚上的凉鞋没有磨坏吗？你身上的衣服不是随着你天上人间的离去而撕破的吗？ » 49这些真正的凉鞋，即使也是实心的，也逐渐被象征性地取代。在古希腊墓葬中发现了粘土鞋，有时甚至是两双50。即使在中世纪，这种表现形式仍然存在，并流传到我们这里。在阿勒曼尼古墓中发现了蜡烛、水果、棍子和鞋子51。在洛林的某些地方，死者会得到鞋子，手里会放一根棍子，以迎接即将到来的来世之旅52。在斯堪的纳维亚半岛，死者在埋葬之前会穿上特殊的鞋子。有了这些，死者就可以走上布满荆棘的石路，通向来世53。 Anucin 54说，如果这条路径穿过地球，就会小心地通过给死者穿上鞋子、在他旁边放一根棍子等来促进这条路径的通过。

This representation is already found among the Indians of North America. In the legend transcribed by Boas the hero wants to find his dead wife. "He asked his father for five bearskins and cut out a hundred pairs of shoes from them." 44 Therefore, to go to the realm of the dead, sturdy footwear is needed. In California the Indians were always buried with moccasins . 45 "The natives of California provide their dead with footwear, because the road to the places of the eternal hunt is long and difficult." 46 In Bengal the dead "are equipped as if they were going on a long journey." 47 Among the Egyptians the dead are provided with a staff and sandals . 48 The 125th chapter of the Book of the Dead in one of the variants is entitled as follows: "This chapter must be recited by the dead after he has been cleansed and washed, and dressed and shod in white leather sandals..." In the hieratic papyrus on Astarte it is said of Astarte (who is in the underworld): "Where are you going, daughter of Ptah, furious and terrible goddess? Have not the sandals on your feet worn out? Have not the clothes that covered you been torn, at the departure and arrival that you made in heaven and on earth?" 49 These real sandals, even if solid, are gradually symbolically replaced. In the burials of ancient Greece, clay shoes were found, sometimes even two pairs 50 . This representation continued to live on even in the Middle Ages and has come down to us. In Germanic tombs candles, fruit, rods and shoes were found 51 . In certain places in Lorraine, shoes are put on the deceased and a stick is placed in his hand for the imminent journey to the afterlife 52 . In Scandinavia, special shoes were put on the dead before being buried; with these the deceased would be able to walk along the stony and thorn-covered path that leads to the afterlife 53 . In the case where the path passes through the earth, care is taken to facilitate this passage by putting shoes on the dead, placing a stick beside him, etc., says Anucin 54 .

这些材料足以证明，其中出现的一百双鞋、两双鞋、粘土鞋、特殊鞋，以及特殊的球杆，都已在童话故事中变成了铁鞋，变成了铁鞋。铁衣架，也因为这个原因的误解，把球杆变成了棍棒，也就是变成了武器。

These materials are sufficient to establish that the hundred pairs of shoes, the two pairs, the clay shoes, the special shoes, which appear in them, as well as the special club, were transformed in the fairy tale into iron shoes and an iron crutch, and due to the misunderstanding of this motif the club was transformed into a club, that is, into a weapon.

这些材料（其中许多是萨姆特专门收集的）让我们可以说，铁鞋是英雄前往另一个世界的标志。

These materials (many of which were collected mainly by Samter) allow us to affirm that the iron shoes are a sign of the hero's departure for the other world.

与上述相关的另一个可能出现的问题是英雄的性格问题。他是谁？是一个活人进入了死者的境界，还是一个死人反映了灵魂的游荡？在第一种情况下，英雄可以比作萨满，他跟随死者或病人的灵魂踏上旅程。当英雄赶走公主体内的邪灵时，他的行为与萨满完全一样。在这种情况下，构图就很清楚了：公主被蛇绑架了，国王邀请了一位强大的萨满、巫师、魔术师、祖先，他出发去寻找她。然而，尽管这个陈述包含一些事实，但进一步的分析将表明它过于简单化，并且我们正在处理其他更复杂的表示。

Another problem that may arise in connection with the above is that of the character of the hero. Who is he? A living person who goes to the realm of the dead, or a dead person who reflects the representation of the wanderings of the soul? In the first case the hero could be compared to the shaman who sets out on a journey following the soul of a dead or sick person. When the hero drives away the evil spirit that has taken up residence in the princess, he acts exactly like the shaman. In this case the composition would be clear: the princess is kidnapped by the serpent, the king invites a powerful shaman, a sorcerer, a magician, an ancestor, and he sets out to find her. However, although this statement contains a part of truth, a further analysis will show that it is too simplified and that we are dealing with other, more complex representations.

因此，解决一个问题会产生新的问题。我们通过研究故事随后的核心时刻来等待他们的解决方案。首先我们需要找出英雄在旅途中的终点。

Thus the solution of one problem gives rise to new problems. We await their solution by examining the subsequent central moments of the story. First of all we must find out where the hero ends up during his journey.

第三章 神秘森林

Chapter ThreeThe Mysterious Forest

1.童话故事的进一步构成。仙媒如何获得。

1. Further composition of the fairy tale. How to get the fairy half .

上面我们已经提到，童话故事的情节中包含着一场不幸和主人公的背井离乡。有时，离开家本身就是一种不幸，比如继女被赶走。这种不幸必须克服，一般是通过落入主角手中的魔法手段来实现的。这样一来，正确来说，结果就已经注定了。然而，这只不过是一个苍白而枯燥的方案，在童话故事中覆盖着极其丰富多彩的细节和配件的丰富装饰。丰富性在于创造构图的相同元素的多样性。深入到细节，问题就来了：魔法媒介是如何落入主角手中的？

We have already mentioned above that the plot of the fairy tale contains a misfortune and the hero's departure from home. Sometimes the very circumstance of the departure from home is in itself a misfortune, as for example when the stepdaughter is driven away. This misfortune must be overcome, and this is usually accomplished by means of a magical means that falls into the hands of the hero. By this, the outcome is actually predetermined. However, this is only a pale and dry scheme, which in the fairy tale is covered with rich ornaments of extremely colorful details and accessories. The richness consists in the variety with which one and the same element of the composition is realized. When we come down to the details, the question arises: how does the magical means fall into the hands of the hero?

在童话剧目中，有很多方法可以为英雄提供这种神奇的手段。通常，为此目的引入一个新角色，行动由此进入一个新阶段。这个角色就是捐赠者。

In the repertoire of the fairy tale there are many ways of procuring this magical means for the hero. As a rule a new character is introduced for this purpose, and with this the action enters a new phase. This character is the donor.

捐赠者构成了童话经典的一个特定类别。它的经典形式是女巫。在这方面，有必要提出保留，即学者并不总是被授权相信童话的命名法。

The donor constitutes a specific category of the fairy tale canon. Its classical form is the sorceress. In this regard it is essential to make the reservation that the scholar is not always authorized to trust the nomenclature of the fairy tale.

通常，女巫这个名字被归因于完全不同类别的角色，例如继母。另一方面，典型的女巫被简单地称为“小老太太”、“后院的小老太太”等。有时女巫的角色是由动物（例如熊）或老人等扮演的。

Often the title of witch is attributed to characters of completely different categories, such as the stepmother. On the other hand, the typical witch is simply called the old lady, the old lady from the backyard, etc. Sometimes the role of witch is taken on by animals (e.g. a bear), or by an old man, etc.

2.女巫的类型。

2. Types of witches .

女巫是一个非常难以分析的角色，因为她的形象由一系列细节组成。这些来自各种童话故事的细节有时彼此不对应、不适应、不合并成一个单一的图像。从本质上讲，童话故事呈现了三种不同形式的女巫。例如，英雄最终与女术士在一起；她向她提问，主角（或主角）从她那里得到一匹马，丰富的礼物等等。另一种类型是女巫绑架者，他们偷走孩子并试图烤他们，之后我们就逃脱了并获得了拯救。最后，童话呈现了女巫战士：她飞进英雄们所在的小屋，从他们背上的皮肤上割下带子，等等。每种类型都有其特定的特征，但也有所有类型共有的特征，所有这些都阻碍了研究。

The sorceress is a very difficult character to analyze because her image consists of a series of details. These details, put together from various fairy tales, sometimes do not correspond to each other, do not fit together, do not merge into a single image. In essence, the fairy tale presents three different forms of sorceress. There is, for example, the sorceress-donor to whom the hero ends up; she questions him, from her the protagonist (male or female) receives a horse, rich gifts, etc. Another type is that of the sorceress-kidnapper, who steals children and tries to roast them, after which we have escape and salvation. Finally, the fairy tale presents the sorceress-warrior: she enters flying into the hut where the heroes are, cuts straps from the skin of their backs, etc. Each of these types has its own specific features, but there are also features common to all types, and all of this hinders the investigation.

我们认为，出路并不在于详细描述这三种类型，而是在于详细描述这三种类型。出路可能是另一条：童话故事的整个进程，尤其是开头（前往死者王国）表明女巫可能与死者王国有某种联系。我们将首先区分女术士的特征，根据历史材料，这些特征证实了这一假设。然而，在这一点上，应该指出的是，这样做只是照亮了女巫形象的一个方面，但却是绝对必须审视的方面：我们也是被艺术逻辑所引导到这一点的。故事和史料。

In our opinion, the way out does not consist in describing the three types in detail; the way out may be another: the whole progression of the fairy tale, and especially the beginning (the departure for the kingdom of the dead), shows that the sorceress may have some connection with the kingdom of the dead. We will begin by separating the features of the sorceress which, in the light of the historical materials, confirm this assumption. At this point, however, it must be noted that, in doing so, only one aspect of the image of the sorceress is illuminated, but it is the aspect that absolutely must be examined: we are also led to this by the artistic logic of the tale and the historical materials.

3.入会仪式。

3. The rite of initiation .

因此，我们的材料引导我们解决的问题可以表述如下：女巫的形象和死亡的表现之间存在什么联系？但这样提出的问题并没有穷尽我们的材料。我们稍后会看到，女巫和这一流派的表现之间确实存在密切的联系。假设这种联系被证明；在这种情况下，一个新的问题立即出现：为什么英雄会到达死亡之门？确实，这是由行动的进展所推动的。童话故事的开头向我们呈现的是在死亡表征的基础上出现的。但这并不能解决问题，它只是转移了问题：为什么童话故事本质上反映的是死亡而不是其他的表征？为什么这些表现形式被证明如此顽强地重要并且易于艺术阐述？

The problem to which our materials lead us can therefore be formulated as follows: What connection exists between the image of the sorceress and the representations of death? But the question thus posed does not exhaust our material. We shall see later that there is indeed a close connection between the sorceress and representations of this kind. Let us assume that this connection is proven; then a new question immediately arises: why does the hero come to the gates of death? It is true that this is motivated by the progress of the action. The beginning of the fairy tale appears to us as having arisen on the basis of the representations of death. But this does not solve the problem, it merely shifts: why does the fairy tale essentially reflect the representations of death and not others? Why have these representations in particular proved so tenaciously vital and susceptible to artistic elaboration?

这个问题的答案是通过对一种现象的分析而得到的，这种现象不再仅仅属于世界观念的范围，而且也属于具体的社会生活的范围。童话故事不仅保留了死亡表征的痕迹，还保留了曾经广泛传播的仪式的痕迹，即年轻人进入青春期时的入会仪式（入会仪式、仪式、成人仪式、Pubertätsweihe、Reifezeremonien）。

The answer to this question is given by the analysis of a phenomenon that no longer belongs only to the sphere of the conception of the world, but also to that of concrete social life. The fairy tale has preserved traces not only of representations of death but also of a rite that was once widespread, namely the rite of initiation of young people at the onset of puberty ( initiation, rites de passage, Pubertätsweihe, Reifezeremonien ).

这种仪式与死亡的表征如此紧密地联系在一起，以至于不可能只研究一件事而忽略另一件事。因此，我们不仅必须将童话故事与信仰的材料进行比较，而且还必须将其与相应的社会制度进行比较。

This rite is so closely connected with the representations of death that it is not possible to study the one without the other. We must, therefore, compare the fairy tale not only with the materials of belief, but also with the corresponding social institutions.

至此，我们触及了一个极其重要的新问题。稍后我们将介绍该仪式的特点；现在，考虑到这个问题的重要性，有必要提及他的研究历史。

With this we touch upon a new and extremely important problem. We will give the characteristics of the rite later; for now, considering the essential importance of this problem, it is indispensable to mention the history of its research.

人们已经观察到童话故事反映了成人仪式，但这个问题从未被系统地研究过。弗雷泽在他的《金枝》中提到了这一点，但弗雷泽对童话故事本身不感兴趣：他只是用它作为支持他的理论的论据，根据该理论，在启蒙期间，入会者的灵魂被提取出来，并将其移交给他。到图腾动物。但由于这一说法在历史资料中并不明显，弗雷泽指的是童话故事中的科什切伊。事实上，科什切伊的灵魂保存在他的体外，但弗雷泽没有证明与入会仪式的联系。

It has already been observed that the fairy tale reflects the rites of initiation, but the problem has never been studied systematically. Frazer mentions it in his Golden Bough , but the fairy tale, as such, did not interest Frazer: he uses it only as an argument in favor of his theory, according to which during the initiation the soul of the initiates was extracted and handed over to a totem animal. But since this assertion was not evident from the historical materials, Frazer refers to the Košcej of the fairy tale. Indeed, Košcej's soul is preserved outside of him, but Frazer does not prove the connection with the rites of initiation.

法国学者桑蒂夫斯以不同的方式处理这个问题55。据他说，一些童话故事（《拇指汤姆》、《蓝胡子》、《穿靴子的猫》、《长着一簇毛的里奇托》）可以追溯到入会仪式。但他如何证明这一点呢？他为列出的每种类型提供了一系列变体，然后告诉读者某个童话故事可以追溯到入会仪式。因此，例如，在引用 pp. 235-75 一些欧洲和其他非欧洲的大拇指汤姆类型的童话故事，作者说：“有趣的是，我们童话故事的这种形式提出了启蒙的想法。艰难的事业可以很自然地用启蒙的考验来解释。”他没有给出这个想法的证据，并且仅限于肯定。它还以相同的方式处理其他类型。

The French scholar Saintyves approaches the problem differently . 55 According to him, some fairy tales ( Tom Thumb, Bluebeard, Puss in Boots, Ricket with the Tuft ) date back to initiation rites. But how does he prove this? He reports a series of variants for each of the types listed, then informs the reader that a certain fairy tale dates back to the initiation rite. Thus, for example, after having cited on pp. 235-75 some European and other non-European fairy tales of the Tom Thumb type , the author says: "It is interesting that this form of our fairy tale evokes the idea of ​​initiation. Difficult undertakings are explained quite naturally by the trials of initiation." He gives no proof of this idea and limits himself to the affirmation. He elaborates the other types in the same way.

只有蓝胡子的研究比较仔细，但即使在这里，人种学材料的引用也非常稀疏，而且常常不恰当。这样的程序不能称为研究程序，而桑蒂维斯的书之所以令人感兴趣，只是因为其中提出了问题。

Only Bluebeard is studied a little more closely, but even here the ethnographic material is cited very sparsely and often inappropriately. Such a procedure cannot be called a research procedure, and Saintyves' book is of interest only because the problem is posed in it.

即使在苏联科学界，这个想法也得到了阐明。例如，BV Kazansky 在总结他对《特里斯坦与伊索尔德》的研究时指出，“特里斯坦与伊索尔德”的情结可以追溯到“成人礼和青春期仪式”。这个想法是通过入会仪式的示意性描述来证明的，但这里也没有详细说明与特里斯坦的联系，只是暗示了。我们会看到，学者们绕着问题转，他们本能地感觉到某种联系的存在，但他们不能或不愿意深入研究材料，从本质上建立这种联系。

This idea has also been enunciated in Soviet science. Thus, for example, B. V. Kazansky concludes his study of Tristan and Isolde by noting that the "Tristan and Isolde" complex goes back to the "rites of initiation and puberty." This idea is demonstrated by the schematic characterization of the initiation rites, but here too the connection with Tristan is not elaborated, it is only hinted at. We will see that scholars skirt around the question, they instinctively sense the presence of a connection, but they cannot or do not want to delve into the material and establish this connection in its essence.

这种指责在较小程度上是针对 S. Ia 的研究。卢里埃树林里的房子 56。作者主要依赖舒尔茨，但这还不够。尽管如此，一系列童话现象却得到了完全无可挑剔的解释，更重要的是，独立于其他学者。第一次不是以猜想或肤浅类比的形式，而是以实质性研究的形式开辟了一条道路。然而不幸的是，他背离了童话类型的传统前提。他只考虑了两到三种类型（主要是《睡美人》和《格林十二兄弟》），并把所有其他材料放在一边，因此他无法清楚地看到这一现象的全部内容。这种联系比上述作品中出现的要广泛得多、深刻得多。

This reproach is addressed to a lesser extent to S. Ia. Lurié's study The House in the Woods 56 . The author relies mainly on Schurtz, which cannot be considered sufficient. Nevertheless, a series of phenomena of the fairy tale are explained in a completely unexceptionable way and, what is more, independently of other scholars. For the first time a path is opened not in the form of conjectures or superficial analogies, but of substantial research. Unfortunately, however, he starts from the traditional premises of the types of the fairy tale. He takes into consideration no more than two or three types (essentially Sleeping Beauty and The Twelve Brothers of Grimm), and leaves aside all the other material, so that the full breadth of the phenomenon does not appear clearly to him. The connection is far broader and deeper than it appears in the above-mentioned work.

我们提到的所有著作都只是从描述性的角度来考虑这一现象，与它所赖以存在的社会制度没有任何关系。

All the works we have mentioned consider the phenomenon only from a descriptive perspective, without any relation to the social regime on which it was created.

我们看到这个问题很新而且不明确。我们不能将自己局限于转瞬即逝的表征，但我们必须更仔细地审视事物。

We see that the question is quite new and unclear. We cannot limit ourselves to a cursory characterization, but must examine things a little more closely.

我们必须将童话故事的材料与入会仪式的材料进行比较，为此，我们必须首先描述这一仪式的特征。

We must compare the material of the fairy tale with the material of the initiation rite, and to this end we must first characterize this rite.

此时我们遇到了一个很大的困难。我们不应该对这个仪式进行简单的描述，而应该追溯它的历史，但目前这是不可能的。这是一个纯粹的民族志问题，在民族志中，这个问题只是描述性的。我们有许多单独的迹象、观察、记录；我们也有一些研究，其中这些指标被系统化并简化为一种人工算术平均值57。我们在领土范围内拥有专着58。但这一切并不能令苏联民俗学家满意：没有提出这个仪式的问题本身，也没有阐明对民俗学家极其重要的细节。每个学者都强调某一方面而损害其他方面。因此，我们一开始也被迫将自己限制在这个仪式的示意图上。历史的视角、问题和细节将逐渐显现出来。

Here we encounter a great difficulty. We should not give a simple description of this rite, but trace its history, but this is not possible at present. This is a purely ethnographic problem, and in ethnography the question is presented only descriptively. We have many individual indications, observations, records; we also have some studies in which these indications are systematized and reduced to a kind of artificial arithmetic mean 57 . We have monographs within the territorial boundaries 58 . But all this is not such as to satisfy the Soviet folklorist: the problem of this rite itself is not posed, details extremely important for the folklorist are not illuminated. Each scholar emphasizes one aspect to the detriment of the others. Consequently, we too are forced at first to limit ourselves to the schematic representation of this rite. The historical perspectives, the problems and the details will reveal themselves gradually.

什么是启蒙？它是宗族政权特有的制度之一。当青春期到来时，人们会庆祝这个仪式。有了它，年轻人就被引入部落社区，成为有效的成员并获得结婚的权利。这就是仪式的社​​会功能。它的形式多种多样，我们将停下来结合童话故事的材料来审视它们：它们是由仪式的心理基础决定的：人们相信，在仪式期间，孩子死了，然后复活为一个新人。这就是所谓的暂时死亡。死亡和复活是由描绘孩子被神话动物吞食和吞噬的行为引起的。据想象，他被这种动物吞掉了，在怪物的胃里待了一段时间后，又回到了光明中，也就是说，被吐了出来或吐了出来。为了庆祝这一仪式，有时会建造动物形状的特殊房屋或小屋，门代表动物的下巴，并且在那里也进行割礼。这个仪式总是在森林或灌木丛的深处举行，并被最深的神秘所包围。它还伴随着身体酷刑和残害（截断手指、打碎牙齿等）。另一种形式的暂时死亡包括象征性地焚烧孩子、煮熟他、烤他、把他切成碎片，然后复活他。复活的人被赋予了一个新名字，并且庆祝仪式的品牌和其他标志被印在他的皮肤上。这个男孩或多或少经历了一段漫长而严格的学徒期。他被教导狩猎方法，向他传达宗教性质的秘密，向他传授历史知识、社会习俗的规范和戒律等等。他接受了猎人和社区成员的训练，接受了舞蹈和歌曲的训练，还学习了生活中不可或缺的一切。

What is initiation? It is one of the peculiar institutions of the clan regime. The rite was celebrated at the arrival of puberty. With it the young boy was introduced into the community of the tribe, became an effective member and acquired the right to marry. This is the social function of the rite. Its forms vary, and we will pause to examine them in connection with the material of the fairy tale: they are determined by the mental basis of the rite: it was believed that during the rite the boy died and then resurrected as a new man. This is the so-called temporary death. Death and resurrection were brought about by acts depicting the swallowing and devouring of the boy by fabulous animals. It was imagined that he was swallowed by this animal and, after spending some time in the stomach of the monster, returned to the light, that is to say, was spat out or vomited. For the celebration of this rite, special houses or huts were sometimes built in the shape of an animal, whose jaws were represented by the door, and circumcision was also practiced there. The rite was always celebrated in the depths of the forest or thicket, and was surrounded by the deepest mystery; moreover, it was accompanied by physical torture and mutilation (amputation of a finger, breaking of teeth, etc.). Another form of temporary death consisted in symbolically burning the child, in having him cooked, roasted, cut into pieces and resurrecting him. A new name was imposed on the resurrected child, and marks and other signs of the celebration of the rite were imprinted on his skin. The child underwent a more or less long and severe apprenticeship. He was taught hunting methods, religious secrets were communicated to him, historical knowledge, norms and commandments of social custom, etc. He trained as a hunter and a member of the community, he trained in dances and songs and he also learned everything that was considered essential for life.

这些是仪式的基本特征，以示意图的形式展现出来。我们将一点一点地强调细节。现在让我们特别注意这样一个事实：人们认为入会者应该去死，并且完全相信他会死并复活。对细节的研究将逐渐向我们揭示这一习俗的意义，以及它所追求的目的。我们将会看到，其根源在于经济利益。

These are the fundamental features of the rite, set out in a schematic form. We will bring out the details little by little. For now, let us pay special attention to the fact that it was assumed that the initiate would go to his death and be fully convinced that he would die and be resurrected. The study of the details will gradually reveal to us the meaning of this custom, as well as the purpose it pursued. We will see that its origins were economic interests.

现在让我们回到童话故事。至此，我们已经从故事开始，在揭露了叙事之后，引出了历史材料。这里，为了使阐述更方便、更容易，我们有时会反过来进行。论证的程序不会改变，有时阐述的顺序会改变。

And now let us return to the fairy tale. Up to now we have started from the tale and have adduced the historical material after having exposed the narrative one. Here, to make the exposition more comfortable and easier, we will sometimes proceed inversely. The procedure of the argument does not change, sometimes the order of the exposition changes.

4.森林。

4. The forest .

在“他的腿带他去哪里”的过程中，英雄（或女英雄）最终进入了一片黑暗且难以穿越的森林。森林是女巫不变的附属品。但这还不是全部：即使在女巫失踪的故事中，男女主人公也总是最终进入森林。故事的主人公，无论是小王子，还是被赶出家门的继女，还是逃兵，无一例外地发现自己身处森林，而他的冒险也正是从这里开始。这片森林从未被更准确地描述过。它非常密集、黑暗、神秘，有点传统，并不完全可信。

In going "where his legs will take him" the hero (or heroine) ends up in a dark and impenetrable forest. The forest is a constant accessory of the sorceress. But that's not all: even in stories where the sorceress is missing, the hero or heroine invariably ends up in a forest. The hero of the story, be it the young prince, or the stepdaughter driven out of the house, or the deserting soldier, invariably finds himself in a forest, and it is precisely there that his adventures begin. This forest is never described more precisely. It is very thick, dark, mysterious, a little conventional, not entirely believable.

此时，与森林及其居民的表征相关的名副其实的材料深渊在学者面前展开：为了不迷失方向，必须严格遵守与故事相关的表征。因此，例如，在童话故事中几乎没有森林精灵和仙女的反映。这位仙女在阿法纳西耶夫的作品集中只出现过一次，并且是在补充作品中出现的。森林之灵绝不是其他教派下的女巫以外的任何人。另一方面，童话故事中的森林和在森林中举行的入会仪式中的森林之间的联系更加密切。这是全世界持续不变的特征。在没有森林的地方，男孩们至少被带到一些灌木丛中。

At this point a veritable deluge of materials connected with the representations of the forest and its inhabitants opens up before the scholar: in order not to get lost, it is essential to stick strictly to the representations connected with the tale. Thus, for example, in the fairy tale there is almost no reflection of the woodland spirits and nymphs. The nymph is encountered only once in Afanasiev's collection, and then in an addition. The woodland spirit is never anyone other than the sorceress under another name. All the closer, on the other hand, is the connection between the forest in the fairy tale and the forest that figures in the initiation rites, which were celebrated precisely in a forest. And this is a constant and immutable trait throughout the world. In places where there were no forests, the boys were led at least into a thicket.

入会仪式与森林之间的联系是如此牢固和恒定，以至于在相反的意义上也是如此：英雄每次到达森林都会提出特定主体与入会现象循环之间的联系的问题。当我们在当代童话故事中读到：“父亲带他走进森林，来到一个特别的小屋，他向上帝祈祷了十二年”（ZP 6）或者：“让我们走进森林，那里有一座房子对于我们在那里”（ZP 41）等等，这种联系仍然相当透明并且可以很容易地阐述。然而，必须指出的是，目前故事本身没有其他关于森林的线索可以让我们做出这种近似。但当我们审视这片森林所代表的功能部分时，事情就发生了变化：在童话故事中，它通常构成阻碍英雄前进的障碍。他最终进入的森林是无法穿透的，它就像一张囚禁新来者的网。童话森林的这一功能在扔梳子的另一个主题中清晰可见，梳子变成了森林并阻止了追赶者。然而，在这里，森林阻挡的不是追赶者，而是偶尔的旅行者，无法穿越森林的陌生人。我们稍后会看到女巫给了英雄一匹马，他骑着它飞过森林。马飞得“比寂静的森林还要高”。

The connection between the rite of initiation and the forest is so strong and constant that it is also true in reverse: each arrival of the hero in the forest raises the question of the connection of that given subject with the cycle of initiation phenomena. When we read in the contemporary fairy tale: "The father took him into the forest, into a special hut, and he prayed to God for twelve years" (ZP 6) or: "Let's go into the forest, there is a house for us there" (ZP 41) and so on, the connection is still quite transparent and can be easily elaborated. However, it must be said that for now we do not see in the tale itself any other clues about the forest that would allow us to make this connection. But things change when we examine the functional part represented by this forest: in the fairy tale it generally constitutes a barrier that holds the hero back. The forest into which he ends up is impenetrable, it is a kind of net that imprisons new arrivals. This function of the fairy-tale forest is clearly seen in the other motif of the thrown comb, which transforms itself into a forest and holds back the pursuer. Here, however, the forest does not hold back the pursuer, but the occasional traveler, the stranger who cannot pass through it. We will see later that the sorceress gives the hero a horse on which he flies through the forest. The horse flies "higher than the motionless forest."

在这一点上，我们发现民族志学家对这个问题的研究还不够充分。为什么全世界所有举行这一仪式的地方，总是在森林或灌木丛中庆祝？你可以做出许多推测，例如，森林确保了秘密庆祝仪式的可能性：它隐藏了神秘。坚持材料会更好，材料表明森林包围着另一个世界，通往另一个世界的路穿过森林。美国神话中有一个男人出发寻找死去的妻子的故事。他最终来到了森林，发现自己身处死亡之地59。在美拉尼西亚的神话中，森林之外是太阳的国度60。后来的材料，从仪式与创造它的社会政权一起消亡的时间开始，表明森林包围着另一个世界，通往另一个世界的道路穿过森林。

Here we come up against an insufficient study of the question by ethnographers. Why is it that in the whole world, in all the places where this rite was performed, was it always, invariably, celebrated in a forest or in a thicket? One can make many conjectures, affirming, for example, that the forest ensured the possibility of celebrating the rite secretly: it concealed the mystery. It will be more correct to stick to the materials, and the materials show that the forest surrounds the other world, that the road to the other world passes through the forest. Among the American myths there is the one of the man who sets out in search of his dead wife. He ends up in the forest and discovers that he is in the land of the dead . 59 In the Melanesian myths beyond the forest lies the land of the sun . 60 Later materials, from the time when the rite had already died together with the social regime that had created it, show that the forest surrounds the other world, that the road to the other world passes through the forest.

这一事实即使在古典时期也很明显，并且长期以来一直被观察到。 « 大部分通往地狱的入口都被密不透风的原始森林所包围。这片森林是哈迪斯入口的理想代表中的一个恒定元素» 61 ;奥维德已经在他的《变形记》（IV，431，VII，402）中谈到了这一点。《埃涅阿斯纪》第六卷中描述了埃涅阿斯坠入地狱的情景：

This fact appears clearly even in classical antiquity, and has been observed for a long time. "Most of the entrances to the underworld were surrounded by an impenetrable virgin forest. This forest was a constant element in the ideal representation of the entrance to Hades" 61 ; Ovid already speaks of it in his Metamorphoses (IV, 431, VII, 402). In the sixth book of the Aeneid the descent of Aeneas into the Underworld is described:

Spelunca alta fuit badoque inmanis hiatu,

Spelunca alta fuit vastoque inmanis hiatu,

Scrupea tuta lacu nigro nemorumque tenebris…

Scrupea tuta lacu nigro nemorumque tenebris…

（六、237-38）

(VI, 237-38)

奥维德和维吉尔都向我们展示了对表征的文学反思，但从这些反思中得出了表征的存在。

Both Ovid and Virgil present us with a literary reflection of representations, but from these reflections the existence of representations results.

这些材料使我们能够得出以下结论，目前纯粹是初步的：童话故事中的森林一方面反映了人们对森林作为庆祝仪式的地方的回忆，另一方面反映了作为进入王国的入口死者的。这两种表述是紧密相连的。

These materials allow us to formulate the following conclusion, which is purely preliminary for now: the forest of the fairy tale reflects on the one hand the reminiscence of the forest as a place where the rite was celebrated, and on the other hand as an entrance to the realm of the dead. The two representations are closely linked to each other.

目前，这一联系尚未得到证实。接下来就让我们看看这位英雄会发生什么吧。

For now this connection is not yet proven. Let's see what happens to the hero next.

5.鸡脚上的小茅屋。

5. The hut on chicken legs .

森林作为一个孤立的元素，仍然证明不了什么。但我们从它的居民身上看到它有点不寻常，我们从英雄突然在他面前看到的小小屋里看到了这一点。在走向“他的双腿带他去的地方”时，他偶然抬起头，看到了一个不寻常的景象，他看到了一座鱼尾纹上的小小屋。看来这个小茅屋伊万早就认识了：“我们想进去受邀吃饭。”他一点也不感到惊讶，并且知道该怎么做。

The forest, as a single isolated element, does not yet prove anything. But that it is somewhat out of the ordinary we see from its inhabitants, we see from the little hut that the hero suddenly sees before him. Going "where his legs carry him" he accidentally raises his eyes and sees an unusual sight, he sees a little hut on chicken legs. It seems that this little hut has been known to Ivan for a long time: "We want to go in and be invited to eat." He is not at all surprised and knows how to behave.

一些童话故事告诉我们，这个小小屋是“旋转”的，也就是说，它绕着它的轴旋转。 “在她面前有一个鸡腿上的小小屋，她不断地转动”（Af.129）。 “他站在那里然后转身”（K.7）。这种表述源于对“翻转”一词的错误解释。有些故事规定：必要时，它会转身。然而，它不会自行扭转。英雄必须迫使她转身，为此，必须知道并发音这个词。在这里我们也看到英雄一点也不感到惊讶。他说话很随意，知道自己要说什么。 “根据古老的座右铭，根据护士的说法”：“小屋，小小屋，”伊万吹完气后说道，“把你的背对着树林，正面对着我。”看哪，小茅屋转向伊万，从小窗户里，一位白发小老太太往外看”（Af.75，注）。 « 小屋，小小屋，用你的眼睛转向树林，用门转向我；不想久留，只想睡一晚。让旅行者进入»（K.7）。

Some fairy tales tell us that this little hut "whirls", that is, it rotates on its axis. "In front of it stands a little hut on chicken legs and it turns continually" (Af. 129). "It stands there and turns" (K. 7). This representation comes from an incorrect interpretation of the word "it turns". Some tales specify: when necessary, it turns. However, it does not turn by itself. The hero must force it to turn, and for that purpose one must know and pronounce the word. Here too we see that the hero is not at all surprised. He has a loose tongue and knows what to say. "According to the old motto, according to the saying of the nurse": "Little hut, little hut," said Ivan, after blowing on it, "it turns behind the forest and in front of me." And behold, the little hut turned toward Ivan, and from the little window a little old woman with white hair looks out» (Af. 75, note). «Little hut, little hut, turn toward the forest with your eyes and toward me with the door; I do not want to stay a century, but only to sleep for one night. Let the traveler come in» (K. 7).

这里会发生什么？为什么我们必须把小屋翻过来？为什么你不能直接走进去？常常在伊万的面前有一堵光滑的墙，“没有窗户，没有门”，入口就在对面。 “这个小茅屋既没有门窗，什么也没有”（K.17）。但为什么我们不能绕过小屋并从另一边进入呢？显然这是不可能的。显然，这座小小屋位于伊凡绝对无法跨越的可见或不可见的边界上。这个边界只能由小小屋跨越和通过，并且必须将其转向“以便我可以穿透并进入其中”（Sm.1）。

What is happening here? Why must the hut be turned around? Why can't one simply enter it? Often in front of Ivan there is a smooth wall, "without windows, without doors", the entrance is on the opposite side. "This hut had neither windows nor doors, it had nothing" (K. 17). But why can't one go around the hut and enter from the other side? Obviously this cannot be done. Obviously the hut is located on a visible or invisible border that Ivan absolutely cannot cross. This border can only be crossed by means of and through the hut and it must be turned around "so that I can penetrate and enter" (Sm. 1).

在这一点上，提到一个美国神话中的一个细节很有趣。英雄想要穿过一棵树，但树摆动不让他通过。 « 然后他试图绕过他。但这是不可能的。他必须穿过那棵树。”英雄试图从树下穿过，但树倒塌了。然后他开始奔跑，突然跳到树上，树折断了，同时变成了一根轻飘飘的羽毛，在空中飞翔62。我们会看到，即使我们的英雄也不会步行离开小屋，而是骑马飞走或变成一只鹰。小小屋的开放面朝向遥远的王国，封闭的一面朝向伊凡可以到达的王国。这就是为什么伊万不能绕着小屋走，而必须把它转过来：它是一个哨所。在接受审讯和测试以确定他是否可以继续之前，他不能跨越分界线。说实话，他已经通过了第一个考验：伊万懂得咒语，能够向小屋吹气，把它翻倒。 “小茅屋将正面转向他，门自动打开，窗户也打开”（Af. 81）。 “小屋停了下来，门打开了”（Af. 65）。有时童话故事强调小屋位于边境。 “这片草原的另一边是一片茂密的森林，边缘有一座小茅屋”（Af.80）。 “这里就是那个小小屋，外面没有通道，一片漆黑，你什么也看不见”（Af. 152 b）。有时它位于海边，有时则位于您必须跳过的沟渠旁边。从后来故事的发展我们看到，有时女巫会被她的主人派去守卫边境，他们会因为她让伊凡通过而侮辱她。 “你竟敢让一个恶棍闯入我的领地？” » (Af. 104 b) 或： « 您负责什么？ »（AF.164）。对于“Refanciulla”是否没有人通过的问题，女巫回答说：“没有，我们甚至不让苍蝇通过。”

At this point it is interesting to quote a detail from an American myth. The hero wants to pass through a tree, but the tree sways and does not give him way. "Then he tried to go around it. But it was impossible. He had to go through the tree." The hero tries to pass under the tree, but it lowers. Then he takes a run-up and suddenly throws himself on the tree, which breaks and at the same time transforms into a light feather that flies through the air . 62 We will see that our hero also does not leave the hut on foot, but flies away on horseback or transformed into an eagle. The hut faces the open side towards the remote kingdom, the closed side towards the kingdom accessible to Ivan. And that is why Ivan cannot go around the hut, but must turn it around: it is a guard post. He cannot cross the demarcation line before being subjected to an interrogation and a test that will establish whether he can continue. In fact, he has already passed the first test: Ivan knows the spell and was able to blow on the hut and turn it around. "The hut turned its front towards him, the doors flew open by themselves, the windows opened" (Aph. 81). "The hut stopped, the doors opened" (Aph. 65). Sometimes the tale emphasizes that the hut is located on a border. "Beyond this steppe there is a thick forest, and right on the edge there is a hut" (Aph. 80). "And here is the hut, beyond which there is no passage, it is pitch dark, you can't see anything" (Aph. 152b). Sometimes it is located on the seashore, other times next to a ditch that has to be jumped over. From the further development of the story we see that sometimes the sorceress is appointed to guard the border by those who are its masters, and they insult her because she has let Ivan pass. "How dare you let a scoundrel enter my kingdom?" (Af. 104 b) or: "What are you charged with?" (Af. 164). When the "Refanciulla" asks whether no one has passed, the sorceress replies: "No, we don't let even a fly pass."

从这个例子已经可以看出，魔法媒介的给予者正在守卫死亡王国的入口。从更原始的材料中可以更清楚地看出这一点：“四处游荡了一段时间后，他看到远处有烟雾，当他走近时，他看到草原上有一座房子。”里面住着一只鹈鹕。他问他：你要去哪里？他回答说：我正在寻找我死去的妻子。这是一项艰巨的任务，我的侄子。”鹈鹕说道。 ——只有死者才能轻易找到这条路。生者只有冒着最大的危险才能到达死者的国度。他给了他一种神奇的方法来帮助他完成他的事业，并教他如何使用它» 63。

From this example it is already clear that the giver of the magical means guards the entrance to the realm of death. This is most clearly seen in the most primitive materials: "After wandering for some time, he saw a smoke in the distance and, approaching, he saw a house on the prairie. In it lived a pelican. The pelican asked him: Where are you going? He answered: I am looking for my dead wife. It is a difficult task, my grandson," said the pelican. "Only the dead can find this way with ease. The living can reach the lands of the dead only at the greatest risk. He gave him a magical means to help him in his task and taught him how to use it. " 63

这里我们也有审讯。我们注意到，在这个神话中，捐赠者具有动物的外观：这一观察对我们以后会有用。其他案件属于同一类别。在多尔甘童话故事中，我们读到：“在一个地方，他们（鹅巫师）必须通过一个开口飞向天空。在这个洞口旁边坐着一位老妇人，她一直注视着飞过的鹅。”这位老妪不是别人，正是宇宙的女士。 « 任何人不得沿此方向飞行。宇宙女士不同意它» 64。

Here we also have the interrogation. We note that in this myth the donor has the appearance of an animal: this observation will be useful to us later. Other cases belong to the same category. In a Dolgan fairy tale we read: "At one point they (the goose-shamans) had to fly into the sky through an opening. Beside this opening sat an old woman, and she kept an eye on the geese that were flying by." This old woman is none other than the lady of the universe. "No one is to fly this way. The lady of the universe does not allow it. " 64

我们还注意到，在所有这些情况下，英雄都不是一个死人，而是一个活着的人或一个渴望进入死者王国的萨满。

We also note that in all these cases the hero is not a dead man, but a living man or a shaman, eager to penetrate the realm of the dead.

但在这里我们找不到旋转小屋。为了解释旋转小屋的形象，我们只能记住，在古代斯堪的纳维亚半岛从未制作过朝北的门。这一方被认为是“不幸的”。相反，埃达（ Nastrand ）的死亡之屋有一扇朝北的门。由于门的位置不寻常，我们的小屋也成为了通往另一个世界的入口。死亡之所有一个从死亡侧面的入口。

But here we do not find any revolving huts. To explain the image of the revolving hut we can only recall that in ancient Scandinavia doors were never made to face north. This side was considered "unlucky". On the contrary, the house of death in the Edda ( Nastrand ) has its door to the north. With this unusual location of the door, our hut also turns out to be an entrance to the other world. The house of death has its entrance on the side of death.

在以女性为主角的故事中，小屋呈现出一些特殊性。在去找女巫之前，女孩去拜访了她的姨妈，她警告她在小屋里会发现什么，并教她如何表现以及必须做什么。这位阿姨显然是后面介绍的人物。我们已经看到，英雄总是自己知道他将如何表现以及他将在小屋里做什么。这种认知不是外部动机的，正如我们将看到的，它是内部动机的。艺术本能迫使叙述者证明这种认知是合理的，并介绍辅导员阿姨的性格。阿姨说了这样的话：“那边他们会用桦树枝打你的眼睛，你用丝带把它绑起来；”门会吱吱作响，关上，然后你在他们的脚后跟下面撒一点黄油；狗会想把你撕成碎片，而你却向它们扔面包；会有一只猫会抓伤你的眼睛，你给它一些火腿”（Af. 58 b）。

In stories in which the protagonist is a woman, the hut presents some peculiarities. Before going to the witch, the girl goes to see her aunt, who warns her of what she will find in the hut and teaches her how she must behave and what she must do. This aunt is clearly a character introduced later. We have seen that the hero always knows for himself how he must behave and what he must do in the hut. This knowledge is not externally motivated; as we shall see, it is internally motivated. Artistic instinct forces the narrator to motivate this knowledge and to introduce the character of the aunt-adviser. The aunt says the following: "Down there they will hit you in the eyes with a birch branch, and you must tie it with a ribbon; the doors will creak and bang, and you must throw a little butter under their heels; the dogs will want to tear you to pieces, and you must throw them bread; and there will be a cat that will scratch your eyes, and you give it some ham" (Af. 58 b).

我们先来看看女孩的举动。当她把一块黄油扔到门下时，我们看到了洒的痕迹。在另一篇文本中，这些痕迹显得更加清晰：“她在门上洒了水”（Chud.59）。我们已经看到，英雄也向小屋吹气。如果女孩给守卫小屋入口的动物肉、面包和黄油，那么这些食物就表明了这些细节的晚期农业起源。我们将在另一章中研究对守卫地狱入口的动物（如刻耳柏洛斯和其他动物）的赎罪祭。最后，如果这棵树用丝带系起来，在这里也很容易看到广泛的仪式活动的残余。如果女孩在从小屋返回时而不是在进入小屋时进行这些行为，即使在这一事实中，我们也可以识别出不那么古老的倒置的迹象。

Let us first examine the actions of the girl. When she throws a piece of butter under the door, we see traces of sprinkling. In another text these traces appear more clearly: "She sprinkled the door with water" (Chud. 59). We have already seen that the hero also blows on the hut. If the girl gives meat, bread and butter to the animals that guard the entrance to the hut, these same foods indicate the late agricultural origin of these details. The propitiatory sacrifices to the animals that guard the entrance to Hades (of the type of Cerberus and others) are studied by us in another chapter. And finally, if the tree is tied with a ribbon, here too it is easy to see a residue of widespread ritual acts. And if the girl performs these acts when she returns from the hut and not when she enters it, here too we can detect signs of a less ancient inversion.

为了找到所有这些现象的解释，我们将不得不求助于处于更原始阶段的人们的神话和仪式：在这里我们找不到洒水，也没有面包，没有黄油，也没有树上的丝带。但另一方面，我们看到另一个事实可以解释有关小屋形象的许多事情：在仪式中，两个世界边界上的小屋具有动物的形状，通常在神话中没有小屋，那里有小屋。只是一种动物，即小屋具有明显的动物形态特征。这解释了“鱼尾纹”和许多其他细节。

To find the explanation of all these phenomena we must turn to the myths and rites of peoples who are stadially in a more primitive phase: there we will not find the sprinkling, nor the bread, nor the butter, nor the ribbons on the trees. But on the other hand we see another fact that can explain many things about the image of the hut: in the rite the hut on the border between the two worlds has the shape of an animal, often in the myth there is no hut, there is only an animal, or rather the hut presents markedly zoomorphic features. This explains both the "hen's feet" and many other details.

在美国狩猎神话中，可以注意到，为了进入小屋，必须知道其各部分的名称。在这些神话中，小小屋保留了更清晰的动物形态痕迹，但有时动物会出现在它的位置。北美传说中是这样描述房子的建造的。英雄从太阳降临地球；他是太阳之子。他娶了一个地上的女人并建造了一座房子。里面的前列和后列都是男人。文本还提到了他们的名字，这些名字相当复杂（健谈者、吹牛者等）。其中两根前柱直接支撑着代表蛇的某些纵梁，而后柱的顶部则有一根代表蛇或狼的横梁。这所房子的门在顶部装有铰链，因此任何不尽快进入的人都会被杀死。 « 当他盖完房子后，他举办了一场盛大的宴会，所有的柱子和横梁都变得活跃起来。蛇开始移动舌头，当坏人进入时，站在房子后面（即柱子）的人感觉到了。然后蛇立即杀死了她” 65。

In American hunting myths it can be noted that in order to enter the hut one must know the names of its parts. In those same myths the hut has retained clearer traces of zoomorphism, but sometimes an animal appears in its place. This is how the construction of the house is described in a North American legend. The hero comes down to earth from the sun; he is the son of the sun. He marries an earthly woman and builds a house. In it the front and back columns are men. The text also gives their rather complicated names (the talker, the braggart, etc.). Two of the front columns directly support certain longitudinal beams representing a serpent, while the back columns are surmounted by a transverse beam representing a serpent or a wolf. The door of this house is fixed on hinges that are high up, so that anyone who does not enter quickly enough is killed. "When he had finished the house, he gave a great feast, and all the columns and beams came to life. The snakes began to move their tongues, and the men who were in the back of the house (that is, the pillars) would warn him when a bad person entered. And then the snakes would kill him right away." 65 .

为什么这个材料很重要，它揭示了我们小屋形成的什么历史？这里有两个特点很重要：首先，房子的各个部分代表动物，其次，房子的每个部分都有自己的名字。

Why is this material important, what does it reveal about the history of the formation of our hut? Two details are important here: first, that the parts of the house represent animals, second, that the parts of the house each have their own name.

让我们首先关注名称。要进入小屋，英雄必须知道这个词。有资料表明他一定知道一个名字。例如，回想一下阿里巴巴和四十强盗的童话故事就足够了，在故事中，你需要知道门的名字才能打开。

Let us first dwell on names. To enter the hut the hero must know the word. There are materials which show that he must know a name . It is enough to recall, for example, the tale of Ali Baba and the forty robbers, in which one must know a name in order for the door to open.

这个词的魔法似乎比祭祀的魔法更古老。因此，“背对森林”这个为新来者打开大门的公式必须被认为比另一个“她给了猫一块黄油”更古老。这种文字或名字的魔力在埃及的死者选举权崇拜中得到了特别清晰的保留。图拉耶夫说：“魔法是给予死者的一种通灵手段，它为死者打开了来世之门，并确保了他在来世的存在。” 《亡灵之书》第 127 章说道：“我们不会让你通过，”门闩说道，“除非你告诉我们我们的名字。” “我不会让你过去，”门左边的柱子说道，“除非你告诉我我的名字。”右边的柱子也这么说。死者为门的每个部分命名，这些名称有时相当复杂。 “我不会让你越过我，”门槛上写着，“除非你告诉我我的名字。” “我不会为你开门，”锁说道，“除非你告诉我我的名字。”铰链、门框和地板都需要同样的东西。最后：“你知道我是谁，过来吧。”让我们注意一下，门的所有部分都被仔细地列举出来，没有遗漏。显然，这个仪式被赋予了特殊的意义，命名仪式，即开门仪式。

This magic of words appears to be older than the magic of sacrifices. Therefore the formula "turn your back to the forest," which opens the door to the newcomer, must be considered older than the other "she gave the cat a piece of butter." This magic of words or names has been preserved with particular clarity in the Egyptian cult in suffrage of the dead. "Magic was a means given to the deceased as a viaticum, it opened the doors of the abodes of the afterlife for him and ensured his existence in the afterlife," says Turaev. In the 127th chapter of the Book of the Dead it is said: "We will not let you pass," say the bolts of this door, "until you tell us our name." "I will not let you pass," says the left pillar of the door, "until you tell me my name." The right pillar says the same. The dead man names each part of the door, and these names are sometimes quite complicated. "I will not let you pass through me," says the threshold, "until you tell me my name." "I will not open the door to you," says the lock, "until you tell me my name." The hinges, the doorposts, and the floor demand the same thing. And finally: "You know who I am; come through." Let us note how minutely all the parts of the door are enumerated, so that none are omitted. It is evident that a special meaning was attributed to this rite, to the rite of naming, that is, of the opening of the door.

众所周知，除此之外，祭祀和洒水在埃及农业时期已经广泛存在。

It is known that in addition to this, both sacrifice and sprinkling already figure prominently in Egypt during the agricultural period.

所有这些材料都表明，在最原始的阶段，小茅屋守卫着死亡王国的入口，英雄念出魔法词，让他进入另一个世界，或者做出牺牲。

All these materials show that in the most primitive stages the hut guards the entrance to the realm of the dead and that the hero pronounces the magic word that gives him access to the other world, or performs sacrifices.

问题的第二面是小屋的动物本性。为了理解它，我们需要更仔细地考虑一下仪式。小茅屋或小屋是仪式的一个恒定特征，就像森林一样。这间小屋位于森林深处，一个荒无人烟的隐秘地点。有时它是专门为此目的而构建的，并且经常是由新手自己构建的。除了它位于森林中之外，我们还注意到它的一些典型特征：它经常呈现出动物的外观，更常见的是，只有门具有动物的外观。它也被栅栏包围，栅栏有时带有头骨框架。最后，有时会提到一条通往这座小屋的小路。现在这里有一些证词：“在这里，在入会仪式上，年轻人去了森林小屋，正如他们所相信的那样，他们在那里与灵魂结合” 66。 “小屋所在地周围环绕着高而厚的树篱，只允许某些人留在其中” 67。 « 在班克斯群岛的夸特崇拜中，在一个偏僻的地方，用芦苇栅栏建造了一种围栏，栅栏的两端垂下并形成入口，称为鲨鱼的下颚。在塞拉姆岛上，据说新手会被下巴吞掉。”这里的入口被称为“鳄鱼的下巴”，而谈到入会者时，据说“动物将他们撕成碎片” 68。 « 在森林里一个僻静的地方，距离舞场一百米远的地方有一个pal na bâta。这是我所见过的唯一的同类建筑；……它的四面都被茂密的灌木丛包围着，其中有一条狭窄的小路，狭窄得只能蹲下来通过” 69。这里所说的建筑坐落在雕刻的柱子上。弗罗贝尼乌斯对头骨的问题特别感兴趣，所以这里没有必要报道他的材料。我们引用的案例不仅代表了对房子的描述，而且还表明了它的功能之一：在这里，英雄必须被吞没、吞噬。我们不想详细解释这个仪式，我们将在别处给出（见第七章）。但从她的家和她的言语来看，女巫也是一个男人的吞噬者。 « 那所房子旁边有一片原始森林，森林里的一块空地中间有一座小小屋，小小屋里住着女巫；她不让任何人进来，并且像吃鸡一样吃人。”小屋周围的栅栏是用人骨做的，上面立着长着眼睛的人头骨；关闭门的不是栅栏，而是人的腿；不是把手，而是手；不是锁，而是一张长着锋利牙齿的嘴”（Af. 59）。我们在上面已经看到，小屋的门是咬合的，也就是说，它代表一张嘴或下巴。因此，我们看到这种类型的小屋对应于庆祝割礼和入会仪式的小屋。这座野兽小屋渐渐失去了野兽的面貌。门是表现出更大阻力的元素：它们比其他部分更长时间地保留下巴的外观。 “在科马科夫的房间里，门像下巴一样关上又打开。”或者，房子前面有一只老鹰：“小心！老鹰每次张开嘴，就一个接一个地快速跳进去！ ”或者：“首先你必须穿过大量的老鼠，然后穿过某些蛇。老鼠会想把你撕成碎片，蛇会威胁要吞掉你。即使你很高兴地从他们面前经过，门也会咬你» 70。这让我们很想起童话里阿姨的叮嘱。看来，甚至连鸟腿也只不过是曾经支撑此类建筑的动物形柱的残余物。守卫入口的动物也以同样的方式解释：这里我们处理的是在动物神拟人化过程中观察到的相同现象。曾经是神的一部分的东西后来成为他的属性（宙斯的鹰等）。这里发生了同样的事情：曾经的小屋（动物）变成了它的属性并取代了它，移动到了入口。

The second side of the question is the animal nature of the hut. To understand this, we must look at the rite a little more closely. The hut, or the cottage, is a constant feature of the rite, like the forest. This hut was located in the depths of the forest, in a deserted and secret spot. Sometimes it was built specifically for this purpose and not infrequently by the neophytes themselves. In addition to its location in the forest, we note some typical features in it: it often takes on the appearance of an animal and, more often still, only the door has the appearance of an animal. Furthermore, it is surrounded by a palisade which sometimes has skulls embedded in it. Finally, mention is sometimes made of a path leading to this hut. And now here are some testimonies: "Here, during the rite of initiation, the young men go to the forest hut, where, as they believe, they unite with the spirits . " 66 « The site on which the hut stands is surrounded by a high and thick hedge within which only certain persons are permitted to remain » 67 . « In the Kwat cult of the Banks Islands, in a secluded locality a kind of enclosure is constructed by means of a reed fence, the two ends of which hang down and form the entrance which is called the jaws of the shark. On the island of Ceram it is said that the neophyte is swallowed up in the jaws ». Here the entrance is called the « jaws of the crocodile », and in speaking of the initiates it is said that « the animal tore them to pieces » 68 . « In a secluded spot in the forest, a hundred yards from the place of the dances was the pal na bâta . It is the only building of the kind that I have seen;… on all sides it was surrounded by a thick wood through which ran a narrow path, so narrow that one could only pass by crouching » 69. The building in question here rested on carved columns. Frobenius was particularly interested in the question of skulls, so it is not necessary to report his materials here. The cases we have cited are not only a description of the house, but also indicate one of its functions: here the hero must be swallowed, devoured. We do not want to dwell on the interpretation of this rite, which we will give elsewhere (see chapter VII). But the sorceress, both by her dwelling and by her words, is a devourer of men. "Next to that house there was a virgin forest, and in the forest, in the middle of a clearing, there was a little hut, and in the little hut lived the sorceress; she did not let anyone in and ate people as if they were chickens." The fence around the hut is made of human bones, on top of which stand human skulls with eyes; instead of bars the doors are closed by human legs, instead of handles there are hands, instead of a lock there is a mouth with sharp teeth » (Af. 59). We have already seen above that the door of the hut bites, that is, it represents a mouth or jaws. We see therefore that this type of hut corresponds to the hut in which circumcision and initiation were celebrated. This beast-hut gradually loses its bestial appearance. The doors are the elements that demonstrate the greatest resistance: they retain the appearance of jaws longer than the rest. « In Komakov's room the door closed and opened like a jaw ». Or, in front of the house there is an eagle: « Be on your guard! Every time the eagle opens its beak, jump in quickly, one after the other! » Or: « First you will have to pass through a multitude of mice, and then past certain snakes. The mice will want to tear you to pieces, the snakes will threaten to swallow you. Even if you manage to pass happily in front of them, the door will bite you." 70 This reminds us very much of the aunt's exhortations in our fairy tale. It seems that even the bird's legs are nothing but remnants of the zoomorphic columns that once supported buildings of that kind. The animals that guard the entrance can be explained in the same way: here we are dealing with the same phenomenon that is observed in the process of anthropomorphization of animal deities. What was once a part of the god himself later becomes his attribute (Zeus' eagle, etc.). And the same thing happens here: what was once the hut (an animal) becomes its attribute and replaces it, moves to the entrance.

在解释这个主题时，我们从最近的材料（即童话故事）转向短暂的材料，最后我们指出了仪式。反过来也可以得出结论。这并不是说在这个领域一切都已经清楚或明确且完全阐明。但仍然可以建立一些联系。为举行入会仪式而建造的动物形状的小屋可以被认为是最古老的基础。在这个仪式中，入会者通过小屋下降到死亡的境界，因此它具有通往另一个世界的通道的特征。在神话中，小屋的兽形特征已经消失，但门（以及俄罗斯童话中的柱子）保留了其兽形外观。这种仪式诞生于氏族政权，反映了狩猎固有的利益和表现。随着像埃及这样的国家的崛起，所有启蒙的痕迹都消失了。那里有门，就是通往另一个世界的入口，死人必须知道咒语才能打开它。在这个舞台上出现的洒水和祭祀，也保留在童话故事中。原本作为仪式的必要条件的森林后来也转移到了另一个世界。在我们看来，童话故事是这一发展的最后一个环节。

In presenting this motif we have proceeded from recent material (i.e., the fairy tale) to material of a transitory nature, and we have concluded by indicating the rite. A conclusion can also be formulated by proceeding inversely. It is not to say that in this field everything is already clear or definitively and completely elucidated. But some connections can nevertheless be sensed. The most ancient substratum can be recognized in the fact of the institution of a hut in the form of an animal for the rite of initiation. In this rite the initiate descended into the realm of death through the hut, so that it has the character of a passageway leading to the other world. In the myths the zoomorphic character of the hut has already been lost, but the door (and the columns, in the Russian fairy tale) retain their zoomorphic aspect. This rite originated in the clan regime and reflects interests and ideas inherent in hunting. With the rise of states like Egypt every trace of initiation disappears. There is the door, that is, the entrance to the other world, and the dead man must know the spell to open it. At this stage, sprinkling and sacrifices appear, which are also preserved in the fairy tale. The forest, which was originally a sine qua non of the rite, is also later transferred to the other world. The fairy tale appears to us as the last link in this development.

6.奥伊博！

6. Oh dear!

让我们继续追随我们的英雄吧。小屋翻转了，英雄进入了里面。起初他什么也没看到。但他听到：“Oibo！俄罗斯精神以前从未听说过，从未见过。现在，俄罗斯的烈酒坐在勺子上，自己滚进嘴里”（Af.77）。 « 一个俄罗斯灵魂来到我这里，在森林里！ »（七版）。或者，更简单地说：“哇，那闻起来像俄罗斯骨头！” »（AF.79）。我们需要关注这个细节：这是至关重要的。

We continue to follow our hero. The hut has turned over and the hero enters it. At first he sees nothing. But he hears: "Oh dear! A Russian spirit has never been heard before, never seen before. Now the Russian spirit sits on the spoon, rolling by itself into the mouth" (Aph. 77). "A Russian spirit has come to me, here, in the forest!" (Sev. 7). Or, more briefly: "Oh dear, it smells of Russian bone!" (Aph. 79). This detail must be dwelt upon: it is essential.

我们检查的原因已经是一次调查的对象了。波利夫卡为他奉献了一整本书，其中收集了作者所知道的所有类似感叹的案例。这样的例子很多，但作者并没有得出任何结论。但他无法到达那里，因为他仅限于斯拉夫材料71。

The motif we have examined has already been the subject of investigation once. Polivka devoted an entire book to it, in which are collected all the cases of similar exclamations known to the author. These cases are very numerous, yet the author does not reach any conclusion. And he could not reach one, since he had limited himself to the Slavic material 71 .

但一旦我们转向相对更古老的阶段，我们立刻就找到了我们动机的关键。这些材料表明，阿法纳西耶夫说伊万的气味是男人的气味而不是俄罗斯人的气味并没有错。但他的这个说法是可以澄清的。伊凡身上散发出的气息，不仅仅是男人的气息，而是活生生的人的气息。死者没有气味，因为他们没有实体，而活着的人有气味，死者通过气味认出活着的人。这在北美的传说中看得很清楚。例如，一名男子寻找死去的妻子，并在地下王国中发现了一所房子。房子的主人想把它吞下去，但又说：“太臭了！他没有死！ » 72 .类似的例子还有很多，例如盖顿为美国俄耳甫斯神话所作的著作。在这些神话中，英雄通过他发出的气味被认为还活着。这个神话中说：“在另一边，有他的妻子和许多人。”他的妻子已经死了，但经过一番寻找，他找到了她。她与其他死者一起跳特殊的舞蹈。从它发出的气味中，死者注意到了新的到来。 “每个人都在谈论新来者的难闻气味，因为他还活着。”这是神话73的一贯特征。但这种特征不仅存在于那个神话中，也不仅仅存在于美国人中。在一个非洲传说中，小女孩的母亲去世了，但时不时地来帮助她的女儿挖掘花园。她被认出了，然后她带着女儿离开了。富勒伯恩继续讲述这个故事：“在那里，母亲把女儿藏在小屋的一个封闭的房间里，不准她说话。过了一段时间，亲朋好友来探望，全都是人影。但他们一坐进小屋，就皱起鼻子问道：‘这里有什么？这是什么气味？这里充满了生活的气息。你在这里藏着什么？ ” » 74。在祖鲁人中：“据说，如果一个人死在地球上，他就会去死者那里，他们说：现在不要靠近我们，你仍然有壁炉的味道。他们说：在你冷静下来之前远离我们 » 75。

But as soon as we turn to relatively more ancient stages, we immediately find the key to our motif. This material shows that Afanasyev was not mistaken in asserting that Ivan's smell is the smell of a man and not of a Russian. But this statement of his can be qualified. Ivan gives off a smell which is not simply that of a man, but of a living man. The dead have no smell because they are incorporeal, the living have a smell, the dead recognize the living by their smell. This is seen very clearly in the legends of North America. For example, a man sets out in search of his dead wife and in the underground kingdom comes across a house. The owner of the house wants to swallow him, but says: "He stinks too much! He is not dead!" 72 . One can find a great many similar cases, for example, in Gayton's work on the myth of Orpheus in America. In these myths the hero is recognized as alive by the smell he gives off. "On the other side," it is said in this myth, "there was his wife and many people." His wife is already dead, but after some searching he finds her. She dances a special dance together with other dead people. From the smell she gives off, the dead notice the newcomer. "Everyone talked about the unpleasant smell of the newcomer, because he was alive." This is a constant feature of the myth . 73 But this feature is not only found in this myth and not only among Americans. In an African legend the mother of the little girl dies, but comes every now and then to help her daughter dig the garden. She is recognized, then she goes away and takes her daughter with her. Fülleborn continues the story thus: "Down below the mother hides her daughter in a closed room of the hut and forbids her to speak. After a while relatives and acquaintances come to visit, all shadows. But as soon as they sit down in the hut, they wrinkle their noses and ask: 'What is that? What smell is that?' Here is the smell of life. What do you keep hidden here? ' » 74 . And among the Zulu: « It is said that if a man dies on earth he goes to the dead and they say: For now do not come near us, you still smell of the hearth. They say: stay away from us until you have cooled » 75 .

活人的这种气味对于死人来说是非常厌恶的。显然，生者世界的关系已经反过来转移到了死者世界。生者的气味对死者来说是令人厌恶和可怕的，就像死者的气味对生者来说是令人厌恶和可怕的一样。正如弗雷泽所说，生者冒犯死者是因为他们还活着76。我们在多尔干民间传说中找到了证实：“那个男人被杀了，因为他带着他世界的习惯和语言来到她身边” 77。因此，渴望进入异世界的英雄有时会事先净化自己的气味。 « 两兄弟走进森林，躲了一个月。他们每天都在湖里洗澡，用松树枝把自己洗干净，直到全身干净，不再散发出任何人的气味。然后他们爬上了库勒纳斯山，在那里他们发现了雷神的房子” 78。

This odor of the living is very repugnant to the dead. Apparently the relations of the world of the living have been transferred to the world of the dead in reverse. The odor of the living is repugnant and terrible to the dead, just as the odor of the dead is repugnant and terrible to the living. As Frazer says, the living offend the dead by the fact that they are alive . 76 We find a parallel in Dolgan folklore: "That man was killed because he had come to her with the habits and words of her world." 77 Therefore heroes who wish to enter the other world sometimes cleanse themselves of their odor beforehand. "Two brothers went into the forest and hid there for a month. Every day they bathed in the lake and washed themselves with pine twigs, until they were completely clean and no longer gave off any human odor. Then they climbed Mount Kulenas and found there the house of the thunder god . " 78

这一切都表明，伊凡的气味是一个活人试图进入死者境界的气味。如果说这种气味令女术士感到厌恶，那是因为，一般来说，死者在面对生者时都会感到恐惧和畏惧。任何活着的人都不能跨过奥术门槛。在美国神话中，死者在自己的土地上看到活人时会非常害怕，大喊：“他在这里，他在这里！” » 他们把一个藏在另一个下面，形成一个高高的堆79。有一些报道称，在入会仪式上，新人要洗澡，以摆脱“女人的气味”（这一事实在新几内亚得到了证实）80。在夸夸特尔部落的神话中，正如博阿斯所证明的那样，与仪式密切相关，英雄经常在旅途中洗澡，或者用非常芳香的植物（例如远志）擦拭自己以掩盖他的气味81。

All this shows that Ivan's smell is the smell of a living man who tries to enter the realm of the dead. If this smell is repugnant to the sorceress, it is because, in general, the dead feel fear and dread in front of the living. No living being should cross the arcane threshold. In the American myth, the dead are so frightened at the sight of a living being in their land that they cry out: "There he is, there he is!" and hide one under the other so as to form a tall pile . 79 There are some reports according to which during the initiation rite the neophytes were subjected to a bath to free themselves from "the smell of a woman" (this fact was ascertained in New Guinea) . 80 In the myths of the Kwakiutl tribe, closely connected with the rite, as Boas demonstrated, the hero washes himself often during the journey, or rubs himself with very fragrant plants (for example with milkwort) to cover his smell 81 .

关于这个主题可以引用很多材料，但我们引用的材料已经足以阐明这个主题的含义。

On this subject one could cite a great many materials, but those we adduce are already sufficient to clarify the meaning of this motif.

7.她给了他食物和饮料。

7. She gave him something to eat and drink .

童话故事的经典要求在感叹号“oibò”等处出现。接下来是关于此行目的的问题：“你是在尝试一项壮举，还是在逃避某些事情？” » 此时我们期望英雄说出他打算做什么；但他给出的答案似乎完全出乎意料，而且与女术士的威胁没有任何关系。首先他要食物。 “你有什么好吵的？”首先给我一些喝的、吃的，带我去洗手间，然后向我询问新闻”（Af.60）。而且，非常奇怪的是，听到这个回应，女巫平静了下来：“她给他们喝水和吃东西，并把他们领进浴室”（Af.60）。 “她下楼并深深地鞠了一躬”（Af.77）。

The canon of the fairy tale demands that the exclamation "Oh dear," etc., should be followed by a question about the purpose of the journey: "Are you attempting an enterprise, or are you running away from something?" We expect the hero to tell us what he intends to do at this point; but the answer he gives seems completely unexpected and has no connection with the threats of the witch. First of all he asks for food. "What are you shouting about? First give me something to drink, something to eat, take me to the bath, and then ask me for news" (Aph. 60). And, strangely enough, the witch calms down at this answer: "She gave them something to drink and something to eat, and took them to the bath" (Aph. 60). "She went downstairs and made a profound bow" (Aph. 77).

不仅在与女巫的遭遇中，而且在许多与她相当的角色中，也总是提到提供食物。当小王子进入女巫尚未到达的小屋时，他会找到一张餐桌并独自用餐。小茅屋本身有时被叙述者强迫去履行这个功能：它是“由一团糟支撑起来的”。 “被一张大煎饼盖住”，对应西方儿童童话中的“姜饼屋”：单从外观来看，这座小房子有时被称为吃饭的房子。

The offering of food is always mentioned not only in the encounters with the sorceress, but also with many characters equivalent to her. In the cases in which the little prince enters the hut where the sorceress is not yet present, he finds a table set and feasts alone. The same hut is sometimes forced by the narrator to fulfill this function: it is "propped up with a pie". "covered with a large pancake", which corresponds to the "gingerbread house" of Western children's fairy tales: already from its appearance this house sometimes gives itself away as a house where people eat.

我们注意到，这是女巫的一个持续且典型的特征。它滋养了英雄，让他精神焕发。我们还注意到，他在吃东西之前拒绝说话。 « 我多么愚蠢啊！我在这里质问一个饥饿的人，一个麻木的人！ »（K.9）。这意味着什么？例如，为什么英雄在离开家之前从不吃东西，而只有在到达女巫家时才吃东西？这不是日常生活中的特征，也不是现代现实中的特征，它有其特定的历史。在这里，食物有着特殊的意义。北美印第安人已经处于进化阶段，我们看到一种特殊的食物被提供给希望进入死者王国的人类。例如，在北美的传说中，水王带领某些年轻人进入他的房子。 “但是一位老妇人，一只老鼠，警告年轻人不要吃科莫科亚给他们的东西，否则他们将永远不会回到上面的世界” 82。根据毛利人的信仰，即使跨过生者与死者之间的河流，也有可能回去，但任何尝过灵魂食物的人都永远不会回来83。

We note that this is a constant and typical characteristic of the sorceress. She feeds the hero, she refreshes him. We also note that he refuses to speak until he has had something to eat. "How stupid I am! Here I am questioning a hungry man, a frozen man!" (K. 9). What does this mean? Why does the hero never eat, for example, before leaving home, but only when he reaches the witch? This is not a trait taken from everyday life, nor is it modernly realistic; it has its own history. Here food has a special meaning. Already at the stage of evolution at which the North American Indians found themselves, a special kind of food is offered to the man who wishes to enter the realm of the dead. Thus, for example, in the legends of North America the Lord of the Water leads certain young men to his house. « But an old woman, a mouse, warned the young men not to eat what Komokoa would give them, otherwise they would never return to the world above » 82 . According to Maori belief, it is possible to go back even after crossing the river that separates the living from the dead, but whoever has tasted the food of the spirits will never return 83 .

这些案例绝对清楚地表明，通过参加为死者准备的膳食，新来者肯定会成为死者世界的一部分。因此，禁止生者接触这顿饭。不仅如此，死者对此并不反感，而且还必须参与其中，因为正如食物赋予生者体力和活力一样，死者的食物也赋予他们所需的特殊魔法力量。

These cases demonstrate with absolute clarity that by participating in the meal intended for the dead, the newcomer definitively enters the world of the dead. Hence the prohibition made to the living to touch this meal. The dead do not feel any repugnance for it, not only that, but must participate in it, because just as food gives the living physical strength and vigor, the food of the dead gives them the specific magical strength they need.

通过索取食物，英雄从而表明他并不害怕这种食物，他有权获得它，他是“真实的”。这就是为什么即使是女巫在请她吃饭时也会平静下来。在美国传说中，英雄有时会假装在吃东西，但实际上却把这种危险的食物扔到了地上。我们的英雄不会那样做，他不怕这种食物。在对死者的崇拜达到充分发展的地方，边走边吃的需求得到了明确的表达和详细的保存。埃及给我们提供了一个特别明显的例子。埃及的材料向我们解释了为什么我们必须先吃饭，然后才能说话。食物打开了死者的嘴。只有尝过之后，他才能说话。

By asking for food, the hero shows that he is not afraid of this food, that he has a right to it, that it is "authentic." And that is why the sorceress also calms down when he asks her for food. In the American legend the hero sometimes pretends to eat, but in reality he throws this dangerous food on the ground. Our hero does not act in that way; he is not afraid of this food. Where the cult of the dead has reached its full development, the necessity of eating on the way is clearly expressed and has been preserved in detail. A particularly striking example is offered by Egypt. Egyptian material explains to us why one must first eat and only afterwards can one speak. The food opens the mouth of the dead. Only after having tasted it can he speak.

在埃及的祭祀中，为了安息死者，当死者被带入墓穴时，人们会向死者（即他的木乃伊）提供食物和饮料。这就是所谓的“供桌”。巴奇这样描述仪式：“食物被送到餐桌上，两张祭品桌也被搬进了usekht帐篷或地下室。雕像（即木乃伊）自然不能坐在餐桌旁吃饭；可能有人，也许是牧师，代替坐在桌边开始吃饭。这顿饭包括某种面包和蛋糕以及饮料tchesert；在它结束时，雕像的嘴唇张开，人们相信以木乃伊为代表的死者已经转变成khu，也就是说变成了一个灵魂，并获得了另一个灵魂的所有能力。世界” 84 .这段文字绝对清楚地表明，这顿饭“张开了嘴”，将死者变成了灵魂，取代了之前变成动物的状态。开口仪式是该邪教中最重要的仪式之一。在葬礼文本中，专门有一本题为《开口之书》的书献给她。但这样的例子也可以在《亡灵之书》中找到。我们引用本书第122章的一段话：《向我敞开！ - 你是谁？你要去哪里？你叫什么名字？ — 我是你们中的一员，我的船的名字是：灵魂收集者......我想要一罐牛奶，蛋糕，面包和肉块......我想要这些东西丰富地给我......我想要对我采取行动，以便我能够像班诺鸟一样前进……»

In the Egyptian cult, food and drink were offered to the dead person, that is, to his mummy, when it was carried into the crypt. This was the so-called "offering table." Budge describes the ceremony as follows: "The food was brought to the table, and two tables of offerings were also carried into the usekht tent or into the crypt. The statue (i.e., the mummy) could not, of course, sit at the table to eat; probably someone, perhaps the priest, sat at the table as a substitute and began to eat. The meal consisted of some kind of bread and cakes and the drink tchesert ; at the end of it the lips of the statue were opened and it was believed that the dead person, represented by the mummy, had been transformed into a khu , that is, into a spirit, and had acquired all the faculties of the spirits of the other world." 84 This text shows with absolute clarity that the meal "opens the mouth" and transforms the dead person into a spirit, a substitute for a previous transformation into an animal. The ceremony of the opening of the mouth was one of the most important of the cult. In the funeral texts a special book is dedicated to it, entitled The Book of the Opening of the Mouth . But examples of it can also be found in the Book of the Dead . Let us quote a passage from the 122nd chapter of this book: "Open to me! — Who are you? Where are you going? What is your name? — I am one of you, the name of my boat is: collector of souls… I want to be given jars of milk with cakes, bread and pieces of meat… I want these things to be given to me in abundance… I want to be treated with me in such a way that I can go forward, like the bird Benno… "

这段话表达了两个愿望：“我想吃东西”和“我想变成一只鸟”。但本质上，它是一个单一的愿望，用我们的语言听起来是这样的：我想通过吃东西来变成一只鸟。 《亡灵书》第 106 章更清楚地表达了这个想法：“请赐予我面包，请赐予我肉，以便我可以通过大腿和牺牲的蛋糕来净化自己。”因此，这种食物净化了，净化了尘世的东西，并将人变成了非尘世的生物，飞翔，轻盈，变成了一只鸟。布雷斯特德说：“最后，牧师为死者提供的奇怪的丰盛面包和啤酒不仅‘把他变成了灵魂’并‘准备’了他，而且给了他‘力量’并让他变得‘强大’。如果没有这种力量，死者就会被遗弃。它还必须使他有能力容忍在另一个世界等待他的敌对遭遇” 85。

In this passage two wishes are expressed: "I want to eat" and "I want to become a bird." But in essence it is a single wish which in our language would sound like this: I want to eat in order to become a bird. In the 106th chapter of the Book of the Dead the idea is expressed more clearly: "Give me bread, give me meat, that I may purify myself through the leg and the cakes of sacrifice." So this food purifies, purifies from what is earthly and transforms the man into an unearthly, flying, light creature, into a bird. Breasted says: "Finally, the strange, substantial bread and beer which the priest offers to the dead man, not only "transform" him into a spirit and "prepare" him, but give him "strength" and make him "mighty." Without this strength the dead man would be left to himself. It must also give him the ability to endure the hostile encounters that await him in the other world" 85 .

正如巴奇的调查显示，这个仪式被认为是非常重要的，并且为每个人，甚至是最贫穷的人庆祝，也就是说，它具有民族性，这就是为什么它能够在民间传说中完好无损地保留下来。

As Budge's investigation shows, this ceremony was considered very important and was celebrated for everyone, even the poorest, that is, it had a national character, and for this reason it was able to remain intact in folklore.

我们在巴比伦也发现了类似的东西。在《吉尔伽美什史诗》的第二块石板中，埃巴尼讲述了他如何梦见自己下降或被传送到阴间：“跟我一起下来，跟我一起到黑暗的居所，到伊尔卡拉的居所，到一旦你进入就无法返回的住所……居民无法做出反应的地方。与鸟类相似，它们全身覆盖着羽毛。”接下来发生的事情尚不清楚，但最后是提供食物：“阿普和埃利尔为他提供烤（或煮）肉。他们给他提供蛋糕，给他冷饮，从皮里取水» 86。

Something similar is found in Babylon. In the second tablet of the Epic of Gilgamesh, Eabani narrates how he dreamed that he had descended or been transported to the underworld: "Descend with me, descend with me to the abode of darkness, to the abode of Irkalla, to the abode from which one does not return once entered... to the place whose inhabitants do not know how to answer. Like birds, they are clothed in feathers." What comes next is not clear, but finally here is the offering of food: "Apu and Ellil offer him roasted (or perhaps boiled) meat. They offer him cakes, they give him a cold drink, water from skins . " 86

所以从这个例子中我们也看到，跨过异界的门槛，首先要吃喝。在这里我们还发现最初是吃饱了魔法食物，然后是在领主的家里进行审讯。

So we see here too that, having crossed the threshold of the other world, one must first eat and drink. Here we also find first the eating of the magical food to satiety, then the interrogation in the house of the lord.

在古代伊朗的宗教中，“灵魂到达天堂后，会受到关于它如何到达那里的问题的轰炸。但阿胡拉-马自达禁止我们询问她所走的可怕而可怕的道路，并命令给她天上的食物» 87。因此，在这里（作为明显的合理化），我们禁止提问并初步提供天上的食物。

In the religion of ancient Iran, "the soul, having reached heaven, is bombarded with questions as to how it got there. But Ahura-Mazda forbids questioning it about the terrible and frightening path it has traveled and orders that it be given celestial food." 87 Here too, consequently (as an evident rationalization), we have the prohibition on questioning and the preliminary offering of celestial food.

在古典时期，我们也遇到过同样的表现形式。 « 卡吕普索希望奥德修斯接受她的花蜜和甘露；只有吃过神灵的食物、喝过神灵的饮料的人才能永远掌握在他们的权力之下……” 因此，珀尔塞福涅在吃了石榴后就属于哈迪斯了…… « 在这方面，我们还可以记住莲花：希腊人吃了这种甜食，他忘记了自己的祖国，留在了食莲者的土地上” 88。罗德以类似的方式表达自己：“谁品尝了地下居民的食物，就会落入他们的权力之下” 89。

In classical antiquity we come across the same representation. "Calypso wants Odysseus to accept nectar and ambrosia from her; only he who has eaten the food of the spirits and drunk their drink remains forever in their power..." Thus Persephone belongs to Hades after she has eaten the pomegranate... "One may also recall the lotus in this connection: the Greek who had eaten this sweet food forgot his homeland and remained in the land of the Lotus-eaters." 88 Rohde expresses himself similarly: "He who tastes the food of the underground dwellers falls into their power . " 89

这里提出的所有材料和考虑因素使我们得出这样的结果：女巫向英雄在前往遥远王国的旅途中提供食物的主题是基于向死者提供的神奇食物的表现而形成的。人在来世世界的旅程中。

All the materials and considerations presented here lead us to the conclusion that the motif of the offering of food made by the sorceress to the hero on his journey to the distant realm was formed on the basis of the representation of the magical food administered to the dead man during his journey to the afterlife.

8.瘦骨嶙峋的腿。

8. The bony leg .

这是当英雄出现在小屋中时女巫的第一个举动。

These are the sorceress' first acts upon the hero's appearance in the hut.

现在让我们来看看女巫本人。他的形象是由一系列特殊性组成的，我们首先要单独考察这些特殊性，然后才能从整体上考虑他的形象。作为一个形象，女巫有两个方面：当伊凡进来时，她在小屋里，这是一种女巫；或者她飞来，她是另一种类型的女巫。

Let us now turn to the sorceress herself. Her image is formed by a series of peculiarities which we will first examine individually, and only after that will we consider her figure as a whole. As an image the sorceress presents herself in two aspects: she is in the hut when Ivan enters, and this is one type of sorceress, or she arrives flying, and is a sorceress of another type.

当伊万进入时，在小小屋里发现了捐赠女巫。首先它躺着：它躺在炉子上、长凳上或地板上。此外，它还充满了整个小屋。 “在头的前面，在一个角落里一条腿，在另一个角落里另一条腿”（Af. 58 a）。 “女巫躺在炉子上，瘦骨嶙峋的腿从一个角到另一个角，她的鼻子已经长到天花板了”（Af.77）。但如何理解“鼻子长到天花板”呢？为什么女巫占据了整个小屋？没有任何地方将她描述或提及为女巨人。所以，不是她大，而是小屋小。女术士记得一具尸体，一具装在狭窄棺材里的尸体，或者放在一个特殊笼子里的尸体，有人被埋在那里或被留下等死。这是一个死人。其他学者也认出她身上有一个死人，一具尸体。例如，贡特特在研究了从古代卡吕普索开始的女巫形象后说道：“如果北欧死者地下区域的女神海拉拥有尸体的颜色，这只意味着，女神死亡，她自己就是一具尸体” 90 .

When Ivan enters, the witch-giver finds herself in the hut. First of all, she lies down: she lies on the stove or on the bench, or on the floor. Moreover, she fills the entire hut with herself. "In front of her head, in one corner one leg, in the other corner the other leg" (Aph. 58 a). "On the stove lies the witch, a bony leg from one corner to the other corner, her nose has grown to the ceiling" (Aph. 77). But how are we to understand "the nose has grown to the ceiling"? And why does the witch occupy the entire hut? Nowhere is she described or mentioned as a giantess. Consequently, it is not she who is big, it is the hut that is small. The witch resembles a corpse, a corpse in a narrow coffin or in a special cage where someone is buried or left to die. She is a dead person. Other scholars have also recognized in her a dead person, a corpse. Thus, for example, Güntert, after having studied the image of the sorceress starting from the ancient Calypso, says: «If Hela, Nordic goddess of the subterranean region of the dead, has the color of a corpse, this only means that, goddess of death, she is a corpse herself» 90 .

这位俄罗斯女巫没有表现出任何其他迹象让她相信自己是一具尸体。但女巫作为一种国际现象，在很大程度上具有这些特征。 “腐烂的属性始终是它们所固有的：凹陷的背部、松弛的肌肉、脆弱的骨骼、被蠕虫吞噬的背部”（Giintert）。

The Russian sorceress does not present any other signs that would lead one to believe that she is a corpse. But the sorceress, as an international phenomenon, possesses these characteristics to an eminent degree. "The attribute of decomposition is always inherent in them: a hollow back, flaccid flesh, brittle bones, a back devoured by worms" (Giintert).

如果这个观察是正确的，它可以帮助我们理解女巫的一个不变的特征：骨瘦如柴的腿。

If this observation is correct, it helps us understand a constant feature of the sorceress: her bony legs.

为了理解这个角色，我们必须记住“对尸体的感知”是很久以后的事情。在已经引用的美国材料中，属于进化上更早的时期，死亡王国的守护者总是动物或失明的老妇人，她没有尸体。对作为森林王国女主人的女巫及其动物的分析表明，她的动物外表是她最古老的形态。甚至在俄罗斯童话中有时也会出现这种情况。在 DK Zelenin（ZV 11）收集的 Vjatka 童话故事中，通常充满了极其古老的角色，小屋中女巫的角色是由山羊扮演的。 “山羊躺在地上，脚踩在岸边”，等等。在其他情况下，我们发现女巫对应于熊、喜鹊（Af. 140 a，V）等。但这种动物从来没有骨腿，这不仅在俄罗斯材料中（这可以通过“maga”一词与“脚”押韵这一事实来解释）91，甚至在国际材料中也没有。因此，骨足在某种程度上与女巫的人类外观及其拟人化有关。拥有兽足的人是从动物到人的过渡步骤。女巫从来不会拥有这样的一只脚，但潘神、农牧神和一大群恶灵却拥有这样的脚。精灵、侏儒、恶魔、魔鬼都有动物的脚。他们把这些脚留得像鱼尾纹上的小小屋一样。但与此同时，女巫与死亡的形象如此紧密地联系在一起，以至于这只兽性的脚被骨脚所取代，也就是说被死人或骷髅的脚所取代。骨足与女巫从不走路的事实有关。它飞翔或撒谎，也就是说，它在外表上也表现为一具尸体。或许，这种历史替代解释了负责看守冥界对门的安普萨为何有着多变的外貌，逐渐以“巨兽”、时而牛、时而驴、时而女性的形象出现；作为一个女人，她的一条腿是铁，一条腿是驴粪。通过转变为女人，她保留了她愚蠢本性的某些迹象。最后一条腿是无骨的。在这方面，我们可以记住另一种形式的腿，即腐烂的腿，这也出现在俄罗斯童话故事中：“一条腿长满虫子，另一条腿由粪便制成”（ZV 11）。

To understand this character, one must bear in mind that the "perception of the corpse" is a thing of much later times. In the American materials already cited and belonging to a much earlier evolutionary period, the guardian of the kingdom of the dead is always an animal or an old blind woman, who has nothing of the corpse. The analysis of the sorceress as the mistress of the forest kingdom and its animals shows us that her animal appearance is her most ancient form. It sometimes appears in this way also in Russian fairy tales. In a Vyatka fairy tale, collected by D. K. Zelenin (ZV 11), which generally abounds in extremely archaic characteristics, the role of the sorceress in the hut is played by a goat. "The goat lies on the ground, with its feet on the banks," etc. In other cases we find that the sorceress corresponds to a bear, a magpie (Af. 140 a, V), etc. But this animal never has a bony leg, and this not only in the Russian material (which could be explained by the fact that the word witch rhymes with foot) 91 but not even in the international material. Consequently the bony foot is somehow connected with the human appearance of the witch, with her anthropomorphization. The man with the animal foot is a transitional stage from the animal to the man. The witch never has such a foot, but Pan, the fauns and a whole series of evil spirits do. Elves, gnomes, demons, devils have animal feet. They retain these feet just as they do with the hut on chicken legs. But at the same time the witch is so intimately connected with the image of death that this animal foot is replaced by a bony foot, that is, by the foot of a dead man or a skeleton. The bony foot is connected with the fact that the witch never walks. She flies or lies down, that is to say, she also appears externally as a corpse. Perhaps this historical substitution explains how Empusa, who is in charge of guarding the ante-gates of Hades, has a changeable appearance, and appears now as a "great beast," now as an ox, now as an ass, and now as a woman; as a woman she has one leg of iron and one of ass' dung. In transforming herself into a woman she retains certain signs of her asinine nature. This latter leg is devoid of bones. In this connection, another form of leg may be taken into account, namely the decaying leg, which is also found in the Russian folktale: "One leg is wormy and the other is made of dung" (ZV 11).

然而，必须指出的是，我们提出的解释尽管比 Giintert 所主张的理论更有可能，但仍然存在一些问题。据他说，动物的爪子起源于骨足。他说：“广泛传播的迷信中包含着一种奇怪的表现，根据这种迷信，侏儒、精灵和恶魔都有动物腿，特别是鹅和鸭的腿……我们首先从转化为动物开始是很自然的。”解释了许多传说中的这个奇怪的细节，但我不认为真正的原因是在此找到的。我们知道，恶魔被想象为腐烂的骷髅，因此脚的怪异外观可以从以下方面推导出来：骷髅脚的足迹被认为是鹅或鸭脚的足迹，当这种联系不再被感觉到时，魔鬼脚的传说就此展开” 92 .

However, it must be said that the explanation we have proposed is still a little problematic, even though it is more plausible than the theory advocated by Giintert. According to him, animal paws have their origin in the bony foot. He says: «A strange representation is contained in the widespread superstition according to which gnomes, elves and demons have animal paws, especially those of goose and duck… It is natural that one should start first from the transformation into animals to explain this strange detail of many legends, but I do not believe that the real cause is to be found in this. We know that demons imagine themselves as decaying skeletons and therefore the monstrous appearance of the feet can be derived from the following: the print of a skeleton's foot was considered as the print of a goose's or duck's foot and when this connection ceased to be felt, the legend of the devil's foot developed» 92 .
