这种解释是牵强的，而且在历史上也是不准确的。骨足是从骨骼足印发展而来的说法是不正确的，因为这样的足印在自然界中是观察不到的。它在流行的表述中（在德国的Drudenfuss中）发挥着一定的作用，但这种表述也需要解释。骨足是主要的，动物足是次要的说法并没有得到其阶段发展过程中所采取的材料的证实：动物的死亡形式比骨骼形式更古老。

This explanation is far-fetched and historically incorrect. That the bony foot developed from the footprint of the skeleton is not true, since such a footprint cannot be observed in nature. It plays a certain part in popular representations (in the German Drudenfuss ), but this representation itself requires an explanation. The assertion that the bony foot is primary and the animal foot secondary is not confirmed by the materials taken in their stage of development: the animal countenance of death is older than the skeletal countenance.

9.女巫的失明。

9. The blindness of the witch .

女巫逐渐在我们眼前展现出自己是通往遥远王国入口的守护者，同时也是与动物世界和死亡世界联系在一起的存在。英雄的神秘森林会认出一个活人，不让他过去，警告他面临的危险，等等。等他吃完饭后，他才给他带路。他通过气味认出了伊万还活着。但女术士通过气味感知伊万还有另一个原因。尽管俄罗斯童话中从未表达过这一点，但仍然可以确定她是盲人，她看不到伊万，但通过嗅觉认出了他。除其他外，波特布尼亚已经推测出这种失明。他解释如下：“女巫被描绘成盲人。可以认为，他的失明具有怪物的含义。黑暗、盲目和怪物的表现是相似的，可以相互替代。”他通过对斯拉夫语言中词根lep的分析证明了自己的主张93。波特布尼亚的结论首先是不正确的，因为女巫不仅在俄罗斯人和斯拉夫人中似乎是盲目的。与女巫类似的生物的失明是一种国际现象，如果一个人开始研究他们所命名的现象的名称或单词的词源（这总是危险的，而且通常基本上不准确，因为含义在名称发生变化时发生了变化）仍然），应该对各种语言的失明命名进行比较研究。他们都没有带来“女巫”的绰号。但这样的分析可能表明，失明不仅仅意味着失明。因此，拉丁语caecus不仅意味着主动失明（那些看不见的人），而且可以这么说，也意味着被动失明（看不见，caeca nox）。德国人也可以这样说：ein blindes Fenster。

The sorceress gradually reveals herself to us as the guardian of the entrance to the distant kingdom and, at the same time, as a being connected with the world of animals and the world of the dead. The mysterious forest In the hero she recognizes a living being and does not want to let him pass, warns him of the dangers he faces, etc. Only after he has eaten does she show him the way. She recognizes Ivan as alive by his smell. But there is still another reason why the sorceress perceives Ivan by his smell. Although this is never expressed in the Russian fairy tale, it can nevertheless be established that she is blind, that she does not see Ivan, but recognizes him by his smell. Potebnya, among other things, had already conjectured this blindness. He explains it in the following way: "The sorceress is represented, among other things, as blind. It can be assumed that her blindness has a meaning of monstrosity. The representation of darkness, blindness and monstrosity are similar and can replace each other. ' He proves his assertion by analyzing the root lep in the Slavic languages ​​93 . Potebnja's conclusion is not correct first of all because the sorceress appears blind not only among the Russians or the Slavs. The blindness of beings similar to the sorceress is an international phenomenon, and if one sets out to study the etymology of a name or a word for the phenomenon they name (which is always dangerous and often substantially inaccurate since the meaning changes while the name remains), one should undertake a comparative study of the name for blindness in various languages. None of them leads to the appellation of 'sorceress'. But such an analysis could show that blindness can mean something more than the simple absence of sight. Thus the Latin caecus does not only mean active blindness (of one who does not see), but also, if one may say so, passive blindness (invisible, caeca nox ). The same can be said of the German: ein blindes Fenster .

因此，对“盲目”概念的分析可以引出“隐形”概念。人可能盲目的不是他自己，而是他与某些事物的关系。在“盲目”之下，可以隐藏相互隐形的概念。对于女巫来说，这可能会导致生者世界和死者世界之间关系的转移：生者看不到死者，就像死者看不到生者一样。但是，有人可能会争辩说，在这种情况下，英雄也必须是盲人。事实上，本来应该是这样，实际情况也是如此。我们会看到，当英雄到达女巫身边时，他就变成了瞎子。

Thus the analysis of the concept of blindness could lead to the concept of invisibility. Man can be blind not in himself, but in relation to something. Under "blindness" there can be hidden the concept of a reciprocal invisibility. In relation to the sorceress this could lead to the transfer of the relationship from the world of the living to that of the dead: the living do not see the dead just as the dead do not see the living. But, one could object, in this case the hero would also have to be blind. In fact this is how it should be and in reality it is. We will see that the hero becomes blind when he comes to the sorceress.

但女巫真的是瞎子吗？这不能直接看出，但可以从一些间接症状推测出来。在童话《女巫和希查尔》中，女巫想要绑架希查尔，当朋友和家人、猫和麻雀出去拾柴时，女巫飞向他。首先是数勺子。 “这是猫的勺子，这是麻雀的勺子，这是Źchar的勺子。”后者无法抗拒并尖叫道：“不要碰我的勺子，女巫！ » 女术士抓住了希查尔，把他拖走了。因此，要知道Źchar在哪里，她必须听到他的声音。他没有看，而是听，就像他感觉到陌生人的存在一样。

But is the witch really blind? This cannot be seen directly, but it can be inferred from some indirect symptoms. In the fairy tale The witch and Źichar, the witch wants to kidnap Źichar and flies to him at the moment when his friends and family, the cat and the sparrow, have gone out to fetch firewood. She begins by counting the spoons. "This is a cat's spoon, this is a sparrow's spoon, this is Źichar's spoon." The latter cannot resist and screams: "Don't touch, witch, my spoon!" The witch grabbed Źichar and dragged him away. So in order to know where Źichar is, she has to hear his voice. She doesn't look, but listens, in the same way she smells the presence of a stranger.

在其他童话故事中，女巫是失明的。 « 女孩一睡着，就把沥青倒进眼睛里，并用棉絮蒙住；她带着她的孩子逃跑了”（Chud. 52）。同样，波吕斐摩斯（与女术士关系非常密切）也被奥德修斯弄瞎了；在这个主题的俄语版本（《单片眼镜》）中，眼睛没有被撕下来，而是充满了液体。这种生物只有一只眼睛可以被认为是一种失明。在德国童话故事中，女巫的眼睑发炎，眼睛发红，也就是说，她没有眼球，而是没有眼睛的红色眼窝94。

In other fairy tales the witch is blinded. "As soon as she fell asleep, the girl poured pitch into her eyes, stopped them with cotton wool, took her child, and ran away with him" (Chud. 52). In the same way Polyphemus (who is very closely related to the witch) is blinded by Odysseus; in the Russian versions of this story ( The Monocle ) the eyes are not torn out, but filled with a liquid. The presence of only one eye in beings of this kind may be considered a variety of blindness. In German fairy tales the witch has inflamed eyelids and red eyes, that is to say she has no eyeballs, but red eyeless sockets 94 .

但所有这些论点只是告诉我们女巫可能是盲目的，而不是真正的。另一方面，在狩猎民族的童话故事中，我们看到了与女巫相对应的生物的有效和真实的失明；在这样的童话故事中，这些生物是一种更加鲜活的存在，而不是一种残留的现象。在这些故事中，与女巫类似的老妇人总是或几乎总是实际上是盲人。 “他走近一间完全与世隔绝的小屋，里面有一个盲人女人” 95。奇迹般产生的主人公在离家后遇见了这位老妇人。她询问她的旅行情况。在另一个例子中，英雄潜入海底，看到三个女人正在专心吃饭。 “他意识到他们是盲目的。”他们向他展示了96 号公路。

But all these arguments tell us only of a possible and not actual blindness of the witch. On the other hand, in the fairy tales of the hunting peoples we have the actual and authentic blindness of the beings who correspond to the witch; in these fairy tales these beings are a more lively and not yet residual phenomenon. In them the old women similar to the witch are always or almost always actually blind. "He approached a hut that was completely isolated, in which there was a blind woman." 95 The hero, miraculously generated, meets this old woman after his departure from home. She questions him about his journey. In another case the hero descends to the bottom of the sea and there sees three women busy eating. "He realized that they were blind." They show him the way . 96

如果女巫确实保护王国远离生者，并且英雄返回时使她失明，这意味着女巫看不到来自生者王国的人从她的王国返回。同样，在果戈理·维杰的童话故事中，魔鬼也看不到哥萨克。魔能见生者，如魔中术士，如生术士能见死者，凡人所见不见。他们向其中一位巫师求助，名叫维吉。 （参见 Af. 77、ZV 100）。

If it is true that the sorceress protects the kingdom from the living, and if the hero blinds her upon her return, this means that the sorceress does not see the one who came from the kingdom of the living returning from her kingdom. In exactly the same way, in Gogol's tale, Vij, the devils do not see the Cossack. The devils who can see the living are like sorcerers among devils, just as the living sorcerers see the dead, whom mere mortals do not see. And they call upon one of these sorcerers, namely Vij, for help. (Cf. Af. 77, ZV 100).

但问题还没有解决。

But the problem is not solved yet.

我们上面说过，女巫与入会仪式有一定的联系。这种联系逐渐向我们显现。起始者被带入森林，进入小屋，在那里他被呈现给一个怪物，死亡和动物王国的主宰。新手下降到死亡领域，随后返回“上面的世界”。我们知道他遭受了象征性的失明，其形式与童话故事中女巫和波吕斐摩斯的失明完全一致：他的眼睛被蒙住了。弗罗贝尼乌斯给了我们如下的描述：新手被蒙上眼睛带进小屋。在一个坑里，有人在搅拌浓稠的玉米粥，一种意大利面。已经入门的人中有人抓住新手，将这种混合了胡椒的胶水涂在他的眼睛上。一声可怕的尖叫声响起，小屋外的人拍手赞美神灵97。这绝不是一个独特的案例。 Nevermann 介绍了大洋洲的情况：“休息几天后，新手会被石灰糊覆盖，这样他们就显得完全白色，无法睁开眼睛” 98。这些行为的意义是通过整个仪式的意义来阐明的。白色是死亡和隐形的颜色。同样，暂时失明是离开死亡地带的标志。新手第二次被石灰净化，同时他又可以看见了，这象征着获得了新的视力，就像初学者获得了新的名字一样。这是整个仪式的最后阶段，之后新人就回家了。除了我们上面检查的嘴巴的张开之外，这里还有眼睛的张开。我们知道，包皮环切术也是同时实行的，童话故事中没有保留这种情况，就像它没有保留门牙的折断一样。所有这些行为的比较也使我们能够将包皮环切术解释为一种神奇的开放形式，先于节制，就像睁开眼睛先于人工失明，以及沉默症先于张开嘴唇一样：在此类场合发言的规定已经确立。此后，年轻人就被授予结婚的权利。然而，我们不会处理这些现象，因为它们并没有反映在童话故事中。

We have stated above that the sorceress has some connection with the rite of initiation. This connection is revealed to us gradually. The initiate was led into the forest, introduced into the hut, where he was presented to a monstrous being, lord of death and the kingdom of animals. The neophyte descended into the territory of death, to return later to the "world above." We know that he was subjected to a symbolic blinding, the form of which corresponds exactly to the blinding of the sorceress in the fairy tale and to that of Polyphemus: his eyes were covered. Frobenius gives us the following description: the neophyte is led into the hut with his eyes blindfolded. In a pit someone is stirring a thick polenta, a kind of paste. Some of the already initiated seize the neophyte and smear this glue, in which pepper is also mixed, on his eyes. A terrifying scream resounds and those outside the hut clap their hands and sing a praise to the spirit . 97 This is far from being an isolated case. Nevermann reports from Oceania: "After a few days' rest the neophytes are covered with a paste of lime, so that they appear completely white and cannot open their eyes." 98 The meaning of these acts is made clear by the meaning of the whole rite. White is the color of death and invisibility. Similarly, temporary blindness is a sign of departure for the regions of death. Afterwards the neophyte is cleansed of the lime and with it he regains his sight, which symbolizes the acquisition of new sight, just as the initiate acquires a new name. This is the last phase of the whole ceremony, after which the neophyte returns home. In addition to the opening of the mouth, which we examined above, we have here the opening of the eyes. We know that circumcision was also practiced at the same time, which the fairy tale has not preserved, just as it has not preserved the breaking of the front teeth. The comparison of all these acts allows us to explain circumcision as one of the forms of magical opening, which is preceded by continence just as the opening of the eyes precedes artificial blindness, and as muteness precedes the opening of the lips: the prohibition of speaking on such occasions has been ascertained. After this the young man is granted the right to contract marriage. However, we will not concern ourselves with these phenomena, since they are not reflected in the fairy tale.

对小男孩所做的行为让我们想起童话故事中的英雄对女巫或波吕斐摩斯所做的行为。然而，神话和童话之间存在着普遍的差异。在仪式中，年轻人的眼睛是闭着的，在童话故事中，女巫或与她相对应的角色的眼睛是闭着的。换句话说，神话或童话构成了仪式的精确反转。这种逆转是如何发生的？

The acts that are performed on the young boy remind us of those that the hero of the fairy tale performs on the witch or on Polyphemus. However, there is a fundamental difference between the myth and the fairy tale. In the rite the eyes of the young boy are covered, in the fairy tale they are covered on the witch or on the character corresponding to her. In other words, the myth or the fairy tale constitute a precise inversion of the rite. How did this inversion occur?

这种仪式给儿童和母亲灌输了恐惧和恐惧，但它被认为是必要的，因为那些接受过这种仪式的人被认为拥有某种我们可以称之为对动物的神奇力量；也就是说，这种仪式相当于原始狩猎的方法。但是，随着工具的改进，随着向农业的过渡，随着新的社会秩序的出现，古老的残酷仪式显得毫无用处并受到诅咒，它们的严厉性就转而针对那些执行这些仪式的人。在仪式中，年轻人在森林中被一个折磨他并威胁要吞噬他的生物弄瞎了眼睛，而已经脱离仪式的神话变成了一种抗议手段。稍后我们在分析焚烧原因时会观察到同样的情况：仪式中的年轻人。 “他们被烧死了”，童话里他们是烧死女巫的孩子。

The rite inspired fear and terror in the sons and mothers, but it was considered necessary, because those who had been subjected to it were believed to possess something that we might call a magical power over animals; that is to say, the rite corresponded to the methods of primitive hunting. But when, with the improvement of tools, with the transition to agriculture, with the new social order, the old cruel rites seemed useless and were cursed, their harshness was turned against those who performed them. While in the rite the young man is blinded in the forest by a being who torments him and threatens to devour him, the myth, already detached from the rite, becomes a means of protest. We will observe the same case later when we analyze the motif of burning: in the rite the young men "are burned", in the fairy tale it is the children who burn the witch.

但除了这些颠倒的例子之外，童话故事还保留了一些英雄失明的痕迹。在女巫的小屋里，英雄有时会抱怨自己的眼睛。这种疼痛的根源各不相同。 “首先给我一点水来洗眼睛，给我一些喝的和吃的，然后问我”（Af.171）。 “这让我的眼睛肿了”，另一个故事中的英雄抱怨道（Af. 50）。有人可能会说这是一个纯粹理性的原因。但从曝光的材料来看，事情似乎有所不同。在祖鲁童话中，女​​孩从启蒙回来后说：“我根本看不见” 99。对失明的特殊研究也许可以解释为什么先知和先见（提瑞西亚）、人民的解放者（参孙）、族长（雅各、以撒）和先知（荷马）经常被描绘成失明的。

But in addition to these cases of inversion, the fairy tale has also preserved some traces of the hero's blindness. In the witch's hut the hero sometimes complains about his eyes. The origin of this pain varies. "First give me some water to wash my eyes, give me something to drink and eat, and then question me" (Aph. 171). "It has made my eyes swell," the hero complains in another tale (Aph. 50). One might object that this is a purely rational motive. But in the light of the material presented, things appear differently. In the Zulu tale the girl, returning from initiation, says: "I can't see at all. " 99 A special study of blindness would perhaps explain why prophets and seers (Tiresias), liberators of the people (Samson), patriarchs (Jacob, Isaac) and prophets (Homer) are often represented as blind.

10.森林女士。

10. The Lady of the Forest .

女巫形象的另一个特点是她强烈强调女性的生理特征。性别标记被夸大了：她被描绘成一个胸部非常大的女人。 “乳房悬挂在河岸上”（Onč. 178）。 “魔女魔女，你的鼻子到了天花板，你的胸脯跨过门槛，鼻涕从边缘滴落，你用舌头扫烟灰。”或者“女巫躺在炉子上，瘦骨嶙峋的腿，鼻子直抵天花板，鼻涕从门槛上滴下来，乳房缠在钩子上，磨牙。”或者更清楚地说：“女巫从小屋里跳了出来，她的脚骨瘦如柴，屁股纤维发达，皮肤……肥皂般的”（Onč.8）。

Another peculiarity of the image of the sorceress is her strongly emphasized female physiological character. The sexual characteristics are exaggerated: she is depicted as a woman with very large breasts. "The breasts hang down through the sides" (Onč. 178). "Witch Witch, her nose reaches the ceiling, her breasts go through the threshold, her snot runs over the side, she sweeps the soot with her tongue." Or "on the stove lies the sorceress, with a bony leg, her nose reaches the ceiling, her snot runs over the threshold, her breasts are wrapped around a hook, she sharpens her teeth." Or even more clearly: "From the hut the sorceress jumped out, with a bony foot, with a fibrous ass, with... soapy skin" (Onč. 8).

因此，女巫具备了母性的所有特征。但是，尽管如此，她并不了解婚姻生活。她还是一个老太婆，而且是一个没有丈夫的老太婆。女巫不是人类的母亲，她是动物和森林动物的母亲和情妇。它代表了人们相信女性可以在没有男性参与的情况下受精的阶段。女性器官肥大并不代表任何婚姻功能。也许正是因为这个原因，她始终是个老妇人。尽管他看起来是性的化身，但他并没有过性的生活。她只是一个母亲，但无论现在还是过去，她都不是妻子。确实，她从未被称为动物之母，但另一方面，她对动物行使无限的权力。听听他在俄罗斯北部童话故事中如何召集野兽：“无论你们在哪里，灰狼，都跑向一个地方，滚成一圈，选出你们中最大的一个，谁必须跑在小王子伊万之后»（曾经。3）。在科什切伊的故事中，年轻的女巫派人去见年长的女巫：（c 路上有我的姐姐，也许她会知道，有人可以回答：第一个能回答的是森林集市，第二个是空中的飞鸟，第三是鱼和水蛇；这世界上的一切存在都服从她”（《箴言》93a）。她发出一声大叫，突然，从四面八方，各种野兽蜂拥而至，各种飞鸟飞翔。”（Af.112a）。有时连风都臣服于巫梯，他大声喊道。 ，他用尽全身力气吹口哨，突然狂风大作，整个小屋都摇晃起来”（Af. 152） b) 在另一篇经文中，她被称为风之母（Af. 108 P）。他相当于德国童话故事中扬起雪的霍勒夫人。在爱斯基摩人中，她是水下动物100的情妇。在多尔加尼的民间传说中，它与海洋女士101相匹配。

The sorceress, therefore, is endowed with all the marks of motherhood. But, with all this, she does not know married life. She is always an old woman, and an old woman without a husband. The sorceress is not the mother of men, she is the mother and mistress of animals, and of animals of the forest. She represents the stage in which it was believed that the woman could be impregnated without the participation of man. The hypertrophy of the female organs does not correspond to any conjugal function. Perhaps for this very reason she is always an old woman. Although she appears as the personification of sex, she does not live its life. She is only a mother, but she is not a wife either in the present or in the past. It is true that she is never called the mother of animals, but on the other hand she exercises unlimited power over them. Hear how he calls the beasts together in a fairy tale from Northern Russia: "Wherever you are, grey wolves, run and roll all towards one place, in one circle, choose among you the biggest one, which will run after the little prince Ivan" (Onč. 3). In Košcej's story the younger witch sends someone to the older one: (c Down there on the road is my elder sister, perhaps she will know, there is someone who can answer: the first who can answer is the wild beast of the forest, the second is the bird of the air, the third is the fish and the water serpent; everything that exists in this world is subject to her» (Aph. 93 a). Or: «The old woman came out on the ladder, cried out in a loud voice, and suddenly, from all sides, wild beasts of every kind, birds of every kind flew» (Aph. 112 a). Sometimes even the winds are subject to the witch. «The old woman came out on the ladder, cried out in a loud voice, whistled with all her might; suddenly the impetuous winds rose and began to blow, the whole hut shook!» (Aph. 152 b). In another text she is called the mother of the winds (Af. 108 P). The keys of the sun are kept with her (Sm. 304). The male equivalent of the witch, Morožko (Frost), is the lord of the cold; he corresponds to Frau Holle of the German fairy tale who brings forth snow. Among the Eskimos she is the lady of the underwater animals 100 . In the folklore of the Dolgans she is the lady of the sea 101 .

但是，有人可能会问，母性在哪里？我们必须在这里认识到非常古老的社会关系的痕迹。母亲同时也是一位女士。随着母权制的衰落，女性失去了权威，只剩下母亲作为众多社会职能之一。但在神话中，女性-母亲-女士的情况有所不同：她失去了母性，只保留了其属性并保留了对动物的权力；由于猎人的一生都依赖于动物，因此它也保留着对人类生死存亡的权力。

But, one might ask, where is motherhood? We must recognize here the traces of very ancient social relations. The mother is at the same time the lady. With the decline of the matriarchy, the woman loses her authority, only motherhood remains as one of the many social functions. But in the myth things are different for the woman-mother-lady: she loses motherhood, she retains only its attributes and retains her power over animals; and since the whole life of the hunter depends on animals, she also retains her power over the life and death of man.

事实上，它统治着动物，特别是森林里的动物，这一事实与这个阶段的个人对森林动物和游戏的依赖有关，他将自己的组织归结为部落。换句话说，女巫代表了民族志中以“大师”为名的现象。

The fact that she reigns over animals, and in particular over those of the forest, is connected with the dependence of the individual of this stage on the animals of the forest, on game, to which he attributes his own organization into tribes. In other words, the sorceress represents the phenomenon known in ethnography under the name of "master".

大师的问题极其复杂，还远远没有解决。 « “大师”的代表是如何发展的？为了澄清这个重大而复杂的问题，必须进行专门调查”，泽列宁102说。

The problem of the master is extremely complicated and is far from being worked out. "How did the idea of ​​the 'master' develop? A special investigation is indispensable to elucidate this weighty and complicated problem," says Zelenin 102 .

“情妇”是什么意思？斯滕伯格通过许多例子证明，对动物的崇拜最初是对整个动物属的崇拜，后来它被赋予了该属的代表，该代表变得并仍然是神圣的（熊，埃及蜜蜂等） .) 最后开发了特定物种所有者的拟人化图像，该物种可以具有人类、混合或替代特征。所有物种的生物都服从这个主。不仅动物有领主：还有元素领主、雷霆领主、太阳领主、山脉领主、风领主等等。在这种情况下，氏族的关系被投射到动物身上，并从这些元素领主中发展出后来的个别神灵。

What does "mistress" mean? Sternberg has shown by many examples that animal worship was originally a cult of the entire animal species, that it was later given to a representative of this species, who became and remained sacred (the bear, the Egyptian Apis, etc.), and finally the anthropomorphized image of the master of a given species was developed, who may have human, mixed, or alternate features. All beings of the species are subject to this master. It is not only animals that have a master: there are masters of the elements, of thunder, of the sun, of the mountains, of the winds, etc. In this case the clan relations are projected onto the animals, and from these masters of the elements the individual deities later developed.

现在让我们看看女巫在最原始的文明阶段是如何出现的，以及在这些情况下与她相对应的是什么。

Let us now see how the witch presents herself in the most primitive stages of civilization and what corresponds to her in these cases.

我们已经看到女巫被描绘成一位老妇人。我们还看到她既是一位老妇人又是一只动物（“这个女人是一只鸭子”）。我们对俄罗斯女巫对应动物的案例特别感兴趣。在美国神话中，父母把孩子带到森林里，把他们绑在树上后遗弃在那里。一只狼（故事强调他已经老了）和一只土狼出现了。老狼喊道：“从四面八方到我这里来！ » 进一步说：“狼和郊狼来自地球各地”。老狼命令把孩子们解开。冬天来了，孩子们为自己搭建了一座小屋。姐姐从狼那里收到了实现愿望的礼物。根据他的意愿，一座亭子围绕着成群的鹿、水牛和其他猎物。少女的眼神可以杀死动物。她所要做的就是说一句话，他们的皮肤就会缝合在一起，形成一个帐篷。毯子上有图案，与今天部落中使用的图案相同。她给兄弟俩一只黑豹和一只熊作为帮手103。

We have already seen that the sorceress was represented as an old woman; and we have also seen that she is both an old woman and an animal ("This woman was a duck"). Of special interest to us are those cases in which the Russian sorceress corresponds to an animal. In an American myth, parents lead their children into the forest and leave them there after tying them to a tree. A wolf appears (the story emphasizes that he is old) and a coyote. The old wolf cries: "Come to me from all directions!" And further on: "The wolves and coyotes came from all parts of the earth." The old wolf gives the order to untie the children. When winter comes, the children build a hut. The sister receives from the wolves the gift of granting wishes. At her will, a pavilion surrounds the herds of deer, buffalo and other game. The girl's gaze kills the animals. She only has to say a word and their skins sew themselves together and form a tent. The blankets form designs, the same ones that are in use today among the tribe. She gives the brothers a panther and a bear as helpers 103 .

此案意义极其重大。主人是动物（老狼）；但他不仅仅对狼行使他的权力，他可以将其扩展到猎人所需的所有动物。他不会将这种力量传递给他的兄弟，而是传递给他的妹妹。她是为哥哥提供帮助的女孩。这个案例本身隐藏了类似主题的经济基础，也表明了与图腾崇拜的联系：女孩赋予部落神圣的设计。

This case is extremely significant. The master is an animal (the old wolf); but he does not exercise his power only over wolves, he can extend it to all the animals necessary to the hunter. He transmits this power not to his brother but to his sister. It is the girl who provides helpers for her brother. This case conceals in itself the economic basis of such subjects and also indicates a connection with totemism: the girl gives the tribe the sacred drawings.

类似的例子还可以举出很多，但这不是例子数量的问题，而是现象的本质问题。

One could give many similar examples, but it is not a question of the quantity of examples, but of the essence of the phenomenon.

在继续研究女巫之前，我们必须问自己另一个问题。到目前为止，女巫一直以死者王国入口的守护者的身份出现在我们面前。在这里，她以动物们的女主人的身份出现。这里有一个链接。我们面临着什么情况？面对同一个图像中的两条线条、两种传统？或者这只是一个形象，女巫的形象和女巫守护者的形象之间是否存在因果关系？领主到底为何要守卫异世界的入口？在这里，材料本身也给了我们答案。我们已经知道，在某个阶段，人们相信死亡是转变为动物。但既然死亡是一种动物的转变，那么正是动物之主守护着死亡王国（即动物王国）的入口，并赋予了这种转变，并赋予了对动物的权力；在后来的构想中，他给出了一种神奇的动物。

Before we continue our study of the mistress-sorceress, we must ask ourselves another question. Up to now the sorceress has presented herself to us as the guardian of the entrance to the realm of the dead. Here she appears as the mistress of the animals. There is a connection here. What fact are we faced with? Are we faced with two lines, two traditions in one image? Or is it one image, and is there a causal connection between the image of the mistress-sorceress and that of the guardian-sorceress? Why exactly does the lord guard the entrance to the other world? Here, too, the materials themselves give us the answer. We already know that at a certain stage it was believed that death was a transformation into an animal. But since death is a transformation into an animal, it is precisely the lord of the animals who guards the entrance to the realm of the dead (i.e., the realm of animals) and bestows this transformation, and with it also power over the animals; in a later conception he bestows a magical animal.

例如，在博阿斯收藏的一个非常有趣的传说中，英雄最终进入了狼群。所有的狼、熊和水獭都聚集在一起，向陌生人致以崇高的敬意。 « 然后，突然，狼群带来了一具尸体。他们用狼皮包裹他，把他放在火边，开始围着他跳舞并记下节奏。然后死者站了起来，摇摇晃晃地走着。但随着狼群的歌声，他的动作更加自信，终于开始像狼一样奔跑。然后狼群首领说：“现在你看看死者会发生什么，我们把他们变成狼”。狼们教英雄跳舞。 “当你回家后，教男人们我们的舞蹈。”他们给了他一支仙箭，他所要做的就是瞄准，然后他就可以在不释放箭的情况下杀死游戏” 104。除此之外，这个例子现在开始让我们了解女巫的仙女礼物是什么。

Thus, for example, in a very interesting legend from Boas's collection, the hero finds himself among the wolves. All the wolves, bears and otters are called together and pay great honor to the stranger. "Then, suddenly, the wolves brought in a corpse. They wrapped it in a wolf's skin, placed it by the fire and began to dance around it and mark the time. Then the dead man got up and began to walk unsteadily. But as the wolves sang, he moved more and more confidently and finally began to run just like a wolf. Then the leader of the wolves said: 'Now you see what happens to the dead, we transform them into wolves.' The wolves teach the hero their dance. 'When you return home, teach the men our dance.' They give him a magic arrow, you just have to aim and the game is killed without the arrow being shot . ' 104 By the way, this example begins to make us understand what the witch's fairy gifts are.

上述神话也解释了这种仪式。现在我们明白为什么会走向图腾祖师的死亡境界了。

The above myth also explains the rite. Now we understand why one went to the realm of death to the totemic ancestor-master.

在本段中，我们不会遵循女巫作为女性的形象，我们稍后在研究异装癖时会这样做。重要的是要确定女术士的形象可以追溯到女性血统的图腾祖先。后来，祖先的头衔和相关权力传给了男性。作为祖先，女术士与壁炉息息相关。她“用手接住余烬”（Onč. 178）。 “他躺在炉子上”（AF.77）。 “他用舌头堆积烟灰”（Sm.150）。 “她躺在长凳上，但她的牙齿在炉子上”（Chud.103）。壁炉与男性祖先的崇拜一起出现在历史上。准确来说，它并不是适应女妖，而是适应女祖。壁炉作为男性父权标志被转移到女巫的形象。因此，她被赋予了女性角色的各种属性，与其说与炉灶有关，不如说与厨房有关：拨火棍、手榴弹、炉子上的扫帚；与其他厨房配件（例如研钵、研杵等）的联系由此而来。

We will not follow the image of the sorceress as a woman in this section; we will do so later when we examine transvestism. What is important is to establish that the image of the sorceress goes back to the totemic ancestor in the female line. Later the title of progenitor and the related power pass to a male. As an ancestor the sorceress is linked to the hearth. She "takes the embers with her hands" (Onč. 178). "She lies on the stove" (Af. 77). "She piles up the soot with her tongue" (Sm. 150). "She lies on the bench, but her teeth are on the stove" (Chud. 103). The hearth appears in history together with the cult of the male ancestor. Strictly speaking, it does not fit the female sorceress, but the female progenitor. The hearth as a male patriarchal sign is transferred to the image of the sorceress. Therefore, she is given various feminine attributes connected not so much with the hearth as with the kitchen: the poker, the grenade, the broom for the stove; hence the connection with other kitchen accessories, with the mortar, the pestle, etc.

达到这一点后，我们可以描述此类生物的进一步进化。从给予鹿的狼，经过动物女性，我们直接来到了生殖器官夸张的女神西布莉（Cybele），到与动物相伴的永恒处女阿耳忒弥斯（Artemis），以及森林的居民等等。斯滕伯格在他关于宗教信仰演变的讲座中和弗雷泽在《金枝》中都证明了Cybele起源于狩猎时期。

At this point we could characterize the further evolution of beings of this kind. From the wolf that gives the deer, through the animal-women, we arrive directly at goddesses like Cybele with the exaggeration of her reproductive organs, to Artemis, the eternal virgin accompanied by animals and inhabitant of the woods, etc. That Cybele has her origin in the hunting period has been demonstrated both by Sternberg in his lectures on the evolution of religious beliefs, and by Frazer in The Golden Bough .

后来，随着农业的出现，守护者开始失去与动物世界的联系，她仍然是入口的守护者和帮助者，为通往另一个世界的道路指明道路。我们在埃及死者选举权崇拜中找到了这样的例子：“他带来了两只雌鹰，它们长着长毛，胸部下垂，这些雌鹰在塞赫塞山上被发现。这些鹰用胸脯拍击佩皮国王的嘴唇……死去的佩皮必须说出这些话才能进入受祝福的王国» 105。因此，守卫另一个世界入口的动物女人不仅出现在神话和童话中，而且还直接出现在较不古老的阶段的丧葬崇拜中。

Later, when with the advent of agriculture the guardian begins to lose her connection with the animal world, she continues to remain the guardian of the entrance and the helper who shows the way to the other world. An example of this is found in the Egyptian cult for the dead: "He brought two female eagles with long hair and pendulous breasts, which are on Mount Sechse. These eagles struck the lips of King Pepi with their breasts... The dead Pepi must utter these words in order to enter the kingdom of the blessed." 105 Thus the animal-woman who guards the entrance to the other world is found not only in myths and fairy tales, but also directly in the funeral cult of a less ancient stage.

11.女巫布置的任务。

11. The enterprises imposed by the sorceress .

人们普遍认为女巫是一个通常被分配艰巨任务的角色。这只适用于以女性为主角的童话故事，而且也可以表明这些功绩实质上是后来产生的。强加给男性主角的事迹要少得多，而且数量也不多。通常，礼物紧随对话之后：“除非我帮助你，否则我认为你不会到达那里”，然后他给了他他的马（Aph. 104 d）。 “他喂他，给他喝，并给了他他的金母马”（塞46）。这种例子很多，是一种典型的形式。这时问题就来了：女巫奖励英雄什么？从表面上和艺术上来说，这种奖励是没有动机的。但根据上面引用的材料，我们可以说英雄已经通过了一系列的考验。他知道打开大门的魔法；他知道转动并打开小小屋的咒语，他也知道手势的魔力：他在门上洒水。他给守卫入口的动物带来了赎罪祭。最后，最重要的是，他并不害怕女巫的食物，相反，是他自己要求的，这样他就永远与来世的众生结合在一起了。测试之后是问题，问题之后是奖励。这也解释了英雄表现的自信。眼前的一切并没有什么意外，相反，一切似乎都已经是他所知道的，并且正如他所预料的那样。他对自己有信心，对自己的法宝实力有信心，这并不是出于什么动机。我们很少遇到像阿姨这样的人物，她教女孩如何与女巫相处。英雄已经知道一切，因为他就是英雄。他的英雄主义本身就在于他的魔法科学，在于他的力量。

It is widely believed that the sorceress is a character to whom it is typical to assign difficult tasks. This is true only in fairy tales in which the heroine is a woman, and it can also be shown that these tasks are essentially of later origin. Tasks are imposed on male protagonists much more rarely, and they are not numerous at all. Usually the gift follows immediately after the dialogue: "I don't think you'll succeed unless I help you," and she gives him her horse (Af. 104 d). "She fed him, she gave him drink, and she gave him her golden mare" (Sev. 46). Many examples of this kind could be given, so it is a typical form. At this point one might ask: what does the sorceress reward the hero for? Externally and artistically this reward is not motivated. But in the light of the materials cited above we can say that the hero has already passed a series of tests. He knows the magic that opens doors; He knows the spell that turns and opens the hut, he also knows the magic of gestures: he sprinkled the door with water. He brought a propitiatory sacrifice to the animals that guard the entrance. And finally, what is most important, he was not afraid of the sorceress's food, he even asked for it himself and thus he has forever joined the company of beings from the afterlife. Tests are followed by interrogations, interrogations by reward. And this also explains the hero's self-assurance. There is nothing unexpected in what he sees, on the contrary it seems as if everything had been known to him for a long time and was exactly what he expected. He is sure of himself and of the power of his magical equipment, which is not motivated by anything. Only rarely do we come across characters, like the aunt, who instruct the girl how she should behave with the sorceress. The hero already knows everything, because he is the hero. His heroism itself consists in his magical science, in his strength.

整个证据系统反映了最古老的表征，正如可以降雨或迫使野兽向猎人移动一样，也可以强制进入另一个世界。这根本不关乎美德或纯洁，而是关乎力量。但随着技术的发展，社会生活的进步，某些司法规范和其他关系也随之发展起来，这些规范被引入邪教并开始被称为美德。因此很快，在对死者魔法力量的实验的同时，对死者美德的实验的表现也开始出现。最原始的和后来的表述都反映在埃及《亡灵书》中。后者包括，例如，死者在天平上“称量心脏”的表现，这一表现也进入了童话故事，我们稍后会看到。其特点是用钢笔作为重量，象征着玛特女神，正义与真理的象征。

This whole system of tests reflects the most ancient representations according to which it was possible to bring rain or to force a wild beast to come towards the hunter, so it was also possible to force entry into the other world. It is not a question of virtue or purity at all , it is a question of strength . But as technology developed, as social life progressed, certain norms of legal and other relationships were elaborated, which were introduced into the cult and began to be called virtues. Therefore, very early, alongside the experiment of the dead man's magical power, representations of the experiment of his virtues began to appear. The Egyptian Book of the Dead reflects both the most primitive and the later representations. The latter, for example, includes the representation of the "weighing of the dead man's heart" on the scales, a representation which also entered into the fairy tale, as we shall see later. It is characteristic that a pen is used as a weight, symbol of the goddess Maat, symbol of justice and truth.

这些关于美德控制的表征也成为童话故事的一部分，并被保留在那里，从与祖先崇拜相关的相对原始的美德表征，到与日常生活相关的较近的美德表征，例如例如，正确地弄松羽毛床垫或洗衣服的“美德”。这种对死者魔法力量的控制，以及为进入死者领域提供“帮助者”，成为了美德的实验和奖励。因此，出现了对壮举的强加，这些壮举有时是从另一个动机、从公主的壮举转移而来的，在这种情况下，它们实际上就在自己的位置上并响应了经典：因此，例如，在十二个平等的人中认出某人的壮举个人或看守羊群的人。然而，在女巫所赋予的功绩中，有一些可以追溯到遥远的古代：其中，例如，她对英雄施加的不入睡的条件，即禁止睡眠。

These representations of the control of virtue have also entered the fairy tale and have been preserved there, from the relatively primitive representations of virtues connected with the cult of ancestors to the more recent ones, pertaining to everyday life, such as the "virtue" of properly fluffing a feather mattress or doing the laundry. This control of the magical power of the deceased and the provision of a "helper" for the journey to the realm of the dead have been transformed into the experiment and the reward of virtue. Thus the imposition of deeds arises, which have sometimes been transferred from another motif, from the deeds of the princess, and in this case they are really in their place and correspond to the canon: thus, for example, the deed of recognizing someone among twelve equal individuals, or that of guarding a flock. However, among the tasks assigned by the sorceress there are some that date back to ancient times: among these, for example, the condition that she imposed on the hero not to fall asleep, that is, the prohibition of sleep.

12.通过睡眠测试。

12. The test by sleep .

女巫对英雄的禁止入睡的禁令，通常与获取能自动弹奏的古筝的任务有关。 « 也许我会把它给你（古筝）；但有一个条件：当我同意时，没有人会睡觉”（Af. 123）。 “现在保持安静，不要打瞌睡，否则你不会有自动演奏的七弦琴”（Sm.316）。

The prohibition not to fall asleep, made by the sorceress to the hero, is very often connected with the task of procuring a self-playing lyre. "Perhaps I will give it to you as a gift; but on one condition: that when I tune it, no one sleeps" (Aph. 123). "Now stand still and do not slumber, or you will not have the self-playing lyre" (Sm. 316).

从以上的例子中，人们可能会觉得禁眠与古筝的主题有着紧密的联系。但这不是一种稳定的联系，而是俄罗斯材料的一种特殊倾向，事实上，这种联系在俄罗斯材料中经常遇到。英雄离开后，他的妻子送给他一朵花。 “用这朵花捂住你的耳朵，”他告诉他，“不要害怕！” ——这就是白痴所做的；大师开始弹奏七弦琴，白痴坐在那里睡不着”（Af. 123 P）。在这里，我们不由自主地想起奥德修斯，他捂住耳朵，以免听到警报声。不排除这个类比揭示了塞壬的形象，塞壬用歌声奉承英雄并杀死了他。在女巫的小屋里睡着会立即死亡。 “小心点，”狼说，“别睡觉！”如果你睡着了，我会立即吞掉你”（Af. 123 V/3）。即使在俄罗斯材料中，睡眠禁令也与古筝没有任何关系。森林本身就充满了魔力，让人产生无敌的睡意： « 他们走呀走，来到了一片茂密的森林。他们一进去，就开始沉沉地睡去”（弗 72）。在其他民族中，睡眠的主题与竖琴的主题无关，但总是与女巫的主题相关。 « 在多尔加尼的民间传说中，我们对这一禁令有非常详细的阐述。在那里，英雄与女巫打牌，然后他就睡着了。他两次欺骗她，说他不是在打瞌睡，而是在思考。然而，第三次，他承认自己已经睡着了，女巫想要吞噬他» 106。

From the above examples one might get the impression that the prohibition of sleep is firmly connected with the motif of the zither. But this is not a stable connection, but a tendency peculiar to Russian material, in which, in fact, this connection is encountered with particular frequency. When the hero departs, his wife gives him a flower. "Plug your ears with this flower," she says, "and don't be afraid!" That's what the fool did; the master begins to play the zither, and the fool sits there and sleep does not come upon him" (Af. 123 P). Here one involuntarily recalls Odysseus plugging his ears so as not to hear the sirens. It is not out of the question that this analogy throws light on the image of the sirens who flatter the hero with their singing and kill him. Falling asleep in the witch's hut brings immediate death. "Be careful," says the devouring wolf, "do not sleep! If you fall asleep I will swallow you up at once" (Aph. 123 V/3). Even in Russian material the prohibition of sleep is encountered without any connection with the zither. The forest itself is enchanted and causes an invincible drowsiness: "They walked and walked and came to a very thick forest. As soon as they entered it a powerful sleep began to take possession of them" (Aph. 72). Among other peoples the motif of sleep is not connected with that of the zither, but is always connected with the motif of the sorceress. "In the folklore of the Dolgans we have a very detailed elaboration of this prohibition. There the hero plays cards with the sorceress, and an invincible sleep comes over him. Twice he deceives her by saying that he is not dozing, but thinking; the third time, however, he admits that he has fallen asleep and the witch wants to devour him" 106 .

为了解读这个主题，我们将从报道美国材料开始。在盖顿以丈夫寻找亡妻为主题的作品107中，我们看到鳏夫不能打哈欠，也不能睡觉，因为这两件事可以表明他是一个活着的人。在这里，睡眠与气味具有相同的含义。活着的人可以通过闻气味、打哈欠、睡觉和笑而被认出。死人不会做这些事。因此，负责保护死者王国免受生者侵害的守护者自然会试图从气味、笑声和睡眠中识别新来者的本质，并以此决定他是否有权继续他的旅程。盖顿报道了这一主题的录音之一：“英雄出发寻找他死去的妻子，到达另一个世界的酋长面前，并在宴会结束后向他表达了他的愿望。”他回答说，他不相信自己能找到妻子，因为他必须熬夜。他告诉他，如果他睡着了，即使只是一会儿，他的妻子也不会回到他身边” 108。

To decipher this motif we will begin by reporting the American material. In Gayton's work on the theme of the husband who sets out in search of his dead wife , 107 we see that the widower must not yawn and must not sleep, since these two things would indicate that he is a living man. Here sleep has the same meaning as smell. The living are recognized by their smell, by their yawning, by their sleep and by their laughter. The dead do none of these things. It is therefore natural that the guardian in charge of protecting the realm of the dead from the living should try to recognize the nature of the new arrival by smell, laughter and sleep, and thus decide whether he has the right to continue his journey. Gayton reports one of the recordings of this theme as follows: "The hero sets out in search of his dead wife, arrives in the presence of the Chief of the other world and after the banquet makes known to him his desire." The Chief replied that he did not believe he would find his wife, since he had to stay awake all night. He told him that his wife would not be returned to him if he fell asleep, even for a moment." 108 .

从《吉尔伽美什史诗》中也可以看出睡眠的证据根本不是随机现象。在那里，英雄吉尔伽美什寻找乌特纳皮什蒂姆，以从他那里获得永生（类似于我们童话中的生命之水）。乌特纳皮什蒂姆（Ut-Napishtim）就是我们在童话故事中看到的同一位体验者和给予者。他建议英雄六天六夜不睡觉。但吉尔伽美什厌倦了长途旅行，睡着了。然而，Ut-Napishtim 的妻子同情他，并在他入睡时叫醒了他109。格雷斯曼补充道：“然后她的丈夫建议她为吉尔伽美什烤一些面包，也许是为了旅途。接下来是准备面包的相当神秘的场景，似乎有一些神奇的美德被归因于“ 110。我们已经知道进入死者境界时所吃的食物具有什么力量。从本质上讲，这些案例表明，禁止睡眠与女巫的形象和她所代表的角色完全一致。

That the test of sleep is by no means a casual phenomenon is also evident from the Gilgamesh epic. There the hero Gilgamesh seeks Ut-Napishtim in order to obtain immortality from him (analogy to the water of life in our fairy tale). Ut-Napishtim is the same experimenter and giver that we find in the fairy tales. He suggests to the hero that he should not sleep for six days and six nights. But Gilgamesh, tired from the long journey, falls asleep. However, Ut-Napishtim's wife takes pity on him and wakes him up at the very moment he falls asleep . 109 Gressmann adds: "Then her husband suggests that she bake a loaf of bread for Gilgamesh, perhaps for the journey. There follows the rather mysterious scene of the preparation of the bread, to which, it seems, some magical virtue was attributed." 110 We already know what power was attributed to the food eaten at the entrance to the realm of the dead. In essence, these cases demonstrate that the prohibition of sleep is perfectly consistent with the image of the sorceress and the role she represents.

在有关入会仪式的著作中根本没有提及对睡眠的特别禁止。尽管如此，我们有证据表明存在此类禁令的个别案例。例如，在卡菲尔人中，当男孩年满十四岁时，他们就会对他们进行割礼，并禁止男孩在伤口愈合之前睡觉。在犹太人中，割礼前一天晚上被称为“守夜之夜”，因为人们不应该睡觉，因为 šedim ，即邪灵，试图在割礼前占有孩子111。一般来说，入会仪式鲜为人知。我们知道这是一次死亡和复活，或者说是一次出生。萨姆特收集了大量关于出生、死亡和婚姻期间禁止睡眠的材料；对我们来说，它很重要，因为它间接证实了禁止睡眠与死亡和出生领域（即作为入会仪式基础的领域）之间的联系。

In the works devoted to the rite of initiation there is no mention at all of a special prohibition of sleep. Nevertheless, we possess evidence of individual cases of such a prohibition. Thus, for example, among the Kaffirs, who practice circumcision of boys when they reach the age of fourteen, the youths are forbidden to fall asleep until the wound has healed. Among the Jews the night before circumcision was called the "night of vigil," since one was not allowed to sleep because the šedim , that is, the evil spirits, tried to take possession of the child before the circumcision . 111 In general the rite of initiation is little known. We know that it was a death and a resurrection, or a birth. Samter has collected a very copious amount of material on the prohibition of sleep during birth, death and marriage; For us it is important because it indirectly confirms the connection between the prohibition of sleep and the sphere of death and birth, that is, the sphere which is at the basis of the initiation rite.

13.儿童被赶出家门，带到森林里。

13. Children chased from home and taken into the forest .

到目前为止，我们已经研究了女巫的形象，主要与她作为遥远国度入口守护者的角色有关。我们顺便观察到，这个图像不仅反映了死亡的抽象表现，而且还反映了与之相关的具体仪式。这些仪式有痕迹，但目前是零星的且反映微弱。我们现在必须面对仪式与童话的比较。我们发现的同样相当假设的对应案例迫使我们通过进行更精确和深入的比较来直接处理材料。

So far we have examined the image of the sorceress mainly in connection with her role as guardian of the entrance to the remote realm. We have been able to observe in passing that this image reflects not only abstract representations of death, but also concrete rites that are connected with them. There are traces of these rites, but for now they are sporadic and weakly reflected. We must now tackle the comparison of the rite with the fairy tale. The very hypothetical cases of correspondence that we have found force us to tackle the material directly by proceeding to a more precise and thorough comparison.

在材料的阐述中，我们目前为止是从童话故事开始的。随着英雄的进步，我们检查了他在路上遇到的事情。然而，现在我们将以仪式为基础，并按照仪式所施加的顺序来检查材料。我们将从头到尾跟踪仪式的整个过程，并将其与童话故事中呈现给我们的内容进行比较。这将使我们能够阐明童话故事的一些最初的元素，而这些元素到目前为止我们还没有被搁置。

In presenting the material, we have so far started from the fairy tale. As the hero proceeded, we examined what he encountered on his path. Now, however, we will base ourselves on the rite and examine the material in the sequence imposed by the rite. We will follow the entire course of the rite from beginning to end and compare it with what the fairy tale presents to us. This will enable us to throw light on some initial elements of the fairy tale, which we have left aside until now.

孩子们接受入会仪式的年龄各不相同，但有一种倾向是在青春期之前进行这种仪式：记住，只有孩子最终会进入吞噬女巫的房子。

The age at which children were subjected to the initiation rite varied, but there was a tendency to perform this rite before puberty: let us remember that only children ended up in the house of the witch-devourer.

当决定性的时刻到来时，孩子们不知何故被送到了森林里，在那里他们受到了一个可怕而神秘的存在的欢迎。这种离开的形式各不相同。对于民俗学家来说，三种形式很有趣：孩子们被父母带进森林，或者在森林里上演绑架孩子的故事，或者孩子主动进入森林，没有父母的参与。 。

When the decisive moment came, the children were somehow sent into the forest, where they were welcomed by a terrible and mysterious being. The forms of this departure vary. For the folklorist, three forms are interesting: the children are led into the forest by their parents, or an abduction of the children into the forest is staged, or the child goes into the forest on his own initiative, without the participation of his parents.

在第一种情况下，带领孩子们进入森林的人总是父亲或兄弟。母亲不能执行此行为，因为庆祝仪式的地方禁止妇女进入，违反禁令可能会导致犯罪者立即被杀。 “晚上，每个新手都在父亲或另一个男人的陪同下，被带入茂密的树林，并将科瓦雷放在他们面前。”韦伯斯特是这样描述孩子们前往新几内亚112的。我们必须想象，孩子们并不总是有人陪伴到神圣的地方，有时他们被独自留下，不得不自己找到小屋。我们知道，在童话故事中，被遗弃或迷失在树林里的孩子会爬上树寻找光明。在这些情况下，它们没有找到人类的家，而是最终进入了树林里的小屋，这属于我们研究的类型。

In the first case, the one who leads the children into the forest is always the father or a brother. The mother cannot perform this act, since the very place where the rite was celebrated was forbidden to women and the transgression of the prohibition could lead to the immediate killing of the guilty one. "At nightfall the neophytes, each of whom is accompanied by his father or another man, are led into the thick of the wood and the Kovare is placed before their faces ." This is how Webster describes the departure of the children in New Guinea 112 . We must imagine that the children were not always accompanied to the sacred place, sometimes they were left alone and had to find the hut by themselves. We know that in fairy tales the children abandoned or lost in the wood climb a tree and look for a little light. In these cases they do not find a human dwelling but end up in the little hut in the wood which belongs to the type we studied.

起始者的伴奏是死亡的伴奏。发起者以特殊的方式进行装饰、绘画和穿着。 “当妇女们看到孩子以这种方式装饰时，她们会泪流满面，最亲近的亲戚，父亲和母亲的兄弟也会如此。他们用泥土和灰涂抹自己，以表达他们的痛苦” 113，这就是典型的原始哀悼图景。

The accompaniment of the initiate was an accompaniment to death. The initiate was adorned, painted and dressed in a special way. «When women see a child adorned in this way, they burst into tears, and the closest relatives, the father and the mother's brothers, do the same. They smear themselves with mud and ashes to show their grief» 113 , that is, we have here the typical picture of primitive mourning.

从这个描述中我们可以看出，一部分人，尤其是年轻人自己，认为离开森林是一种不幸。他们还不知道他们将要实现什么崇高的目标。但即使这种离开被认为是陪伴年轻人的敌对行为，这种行为也是舆论所希望的：发起者即将获得巨大的利益。是父亲主动带孩子离开的。但后来，当这种仪式开始衰落时，舆论不得不改变。通过入会行为获得的好处变得难以理解，公众舆论不得不改变并谴责这种可怕的仪式。这就是主题诞生的时刻。只要仪式作为生物存在，就不会有关于它的童话故事。

From this description we see that the departure for the forest was considered by a part of the population and especially by the young men themselves as a misfortune. They do not yet know what sublime benefits they are about to achieve. But even if this departure was considered as a hostile act committed by those who accompanied the young men, this act was desired by public opinion: the initiate was about to achieve great benefits. It was the father who took the initiative to lead the boy away. But later, when the rite began to decline, public opinion had to change. The benefits acquired through the act of initiation became incomprehensible and public opinion had to change and condemn this fearful rite. And this is the moment of the birth of the theme. As long as the rite existed as a living thing, there could be no fairy tales about it.

在童话故事中，带孩子进入树林的行为始终是一种敌对行为，即使那些被赶出家门或带入森林的孩子后来一切顺利。现在让我们看看童话故事中如何展开前往森林的旅程。故事开头的童话家庭有一种二元性。一方面，婴儿被渴望和等待，当他出生时，他被令人感动的关怀包围着：“小儿子开始在尿布中长大，他是一个真正的小草莓！ »（AF.63）。另一方面，家庭中却存在着沉默或明显的敌意。 “我们怎样才能摆脱它呢？” » 是故事的不变公式。这句话是所有家庭成员都可以说的，但只有一个例外：晚辈从来不会对老人说这句话，也就是说，儿子或女儿在谈论自己的父亲或母亲时不会说这句话。 。只有老人想赶走年轻人，摆脱年轻人。这种“摆脱”的愿望有一种主要形式：不受欢迎的男孩（或女孩）（有时甚至是弟弟或妹妹）被赶出家门，或被带走，甚至被送到树林里：“他发疯了，带着他的妹妹并带领她进入森林”（Af. 158 b）。 “来吧，孩子们，我们去森林吧，我会制作木材，你会采摘浆果”（Sm.233）。通常，从一开始，小屋就出现了。 “他带着女儿走进树林，把她留在一间土屋里”（ZV 122）。 “我将带领我的每个孩子进入森林，这样我就会知道他们能够做什么”（Z.St. 249）。在后一种情况下，我们从一开始就看到儿子会在树林里展示或获得某些技能，“有一天，他们要求母亲带弟弟去打猎，他们把他带到森林深处，然后把他遗弃在那里” （AF.120b）。 “他们一到树林里，他就脱掉衣服，命令他坐在橡树洞里，然后就走了，留下他赤身裸体，赤着脚”（《SM》85）。这些例子可以写满几页；你可以创建一个完整的系统，研究哪些对象被绑架​​或驱逐出家门，哪些没有，你可以研究这种驱逐的动机，你可以问自己对象是谁（儿子，女​​儿，年龄等） 。 ETC。）。但就我们的目的而言，这并不是必需的。我们只考虑问题的一方面，问问自己：谁带领孩子们走进树林？

In fairy tales, the act of leading children into the forest is always a hostile act, even if things later go well for the one who has been driven out of the house or led into the forest. Let us now see how the departure for the forest unfolds in fairy tales. The fairy tale family at the beginning of the tale contains a kind of dualism. On the one hand, the child is desired and awaited, and when he is born he is surrounded by touching care: "And the little boy began to grow in his diapers, he was a real little strawberry!" (Af. 63). On the other hand, the presence of a silent or overt hostility can be felt in the family. "How could one get rid of him?" is the constant formula of the tale. These words can be said by all members of the family, but with one exception: a person of the younger generation never says them in reference to an older person, that is, a son or daughter never says them in reference to his or her father or mother. To drive away, to get rid of, is what only the old want with regard to the young. This desire to "get rid of" has a predominant form: the unwanted boy (or girl) (sometimes even a little brother or sister) is thrown out of the house, or taken, or even sent into the woods: "He flew into a rage, seized his sister, and led her into the woods" (Aph. 158b). "Come, children, let us go into the woods, and I will cut wood, and you shall gather berries" (Sm. 233). Often, from the beginning, the hut appears. "He took his daughter into the woods, and left her in an earthen hut" (ZV 122). "I will take each of my children into the woods, and then I will know what they are capable of doing" (Z.St. 249). In the latter case, it is clear from the beginning that in the forest the son will demonstrate or acquire certain abilities. "One day they asked their mother for her younger brother to go hunting, and they took him into the depths of the forest and left him there" (Aph. 120b). "When they came to the forest, she took off his clothes and ordered him to sit in the hollow of an oak tree, and went away, leaving him naked and barefoot" (Sm. 85). One could fill pages with these examples; one could create a whole system, study in which subjects one encounters abduction or expulsion from home and in which not, one could study the motivation for this expulsion, one could ask who is the object of it (the son, the daughter, at what age, etc. etc.). But for our purposes this is not essential. We will only consider one side of the question, asking ourselves: who leads the children into the forest?

我们已经看到驱逐是出于临时的敌意。事实上，主动带走孩子的人是父亲，或者在他不在的情况下，是哥哥、母亲的兄弟等。但父亲对儿子的敌意对于讲故事的人来说是奇怪和不可理解的，这不符合他的家庭理想。为了证明这种敌意是正当的，童话故事沿着两条线索进行：一方面，它诽谤和贬低了儿子：他应该被赶出家门，他是一个懒鬼（“他根本没有做任何事情”） 113 b) 他运气不好，大家都抱怨他愚蠢，是个“可怜虫”。但这些案例相对较少。更多时候，敌意是根据俄罗斯农民从现实中了解到的家庭敌对条件而调整的。当一个新人成为家庭的一员时，敌意就会产生，并加剧这种敌意：通常是第二个妻子，或者当第一张床上有孩子时是丈夫。因此，在童话故事中，继母出现了，她的历史任务就是承担起这种曾经为父亲保留的敌意。她也是将孩子们驱逐到森林中，在那里他们遇到女巫等的主要演员。真正的父母之间产生仇恨的例子非常罕见。 « 当她的儿子出生时，一开始母亲非常爱他，无微不至地照顾他，拥抱他，并尽可能地教育他。父亲更是如此。当他长大后，他学会了读书，他已经十三岁了，那时他的母亲开始不再爱他”（K.19）。同样的事情发生在兄妹和平相处的时候，突然出现了一个嫂子，并成为了姐姐的敌人，哥哥把后者带到了森林里。因此，带走孩子的并不是父母。我不会举出继母和继女之间的敌意的例子，他们是众所周知的。但是，即使在这种情况下，带女儿走进森林的还是父亲，他的形象通常非常悲惨。 “我们的农夫想了又想，带着他的女儿走进了树林”（Af. 58 a）。 « 老人对他的大女儿感到同情，他爱她……但他不知道如何应对。他本人体弱多病，而老妇人脾气暴躁……”（Af. 52 a）。 “老人很伤心，他哭了，但尽管如此，他还是让他的女儿上了雪橇”（Af. 52 b）。人们想知道为什么继母不想亲自带走她的继女或继子。尽管她如此残忍和充满恶意，为什么她不亲自用她的权威之手带领孩子们进入森林呢？从逻辑上讲她可以做到，但从历史上看她不能，因为从历史上看，总是只有父亲、兄弟或叔叔带领孩子们进入森林，从来不是女人。只有男人才能做到这一点，而在童话故事中，男人有时会保留这个角色。

We have already seen that the expulsion is motivated by an enmity created ad hoc. In reality, the one who took the initiative to take the child away was the father or, in his absence, the elder brother, the mother's brother, etc. But the father's enmity towards his son seems strange and incomprehensible to the storyteller; it does not correspond to his family ideals. To justify this enmity, the fairy tale proceeds along two lines: on the one hand, it denigrates and demeans the son: he deserves to be thrown out of the house, he is a lazy person ("he did absolutely nothing" Af. 113 b), he is unlucky, everyone complains about him, he is stupid and a "wretch". But these cases are relatively rare. Much more often, the enmity is adapted to the conditions of family hostility that the Russian peasants knew from reality. The enmity arises when a new person enters the family, the promoter of this enmity: this is usually the second wife, or the husband when there are children from the first marriage. Thus the stepmother appears in the fairy tale, and her historical task is to take upon herself this enmity, which was once reserved for the father. She is also the main actor in the expulsion of the children into the forest, where they meet the witch, etc. Cases of hatred on the part of the real parents are very rare. "When the son was born, at first the mother loved him very much, took great care of him, pampered him and brought him up as well as could be. And the father even more. And when he was quite grown up he learned to read, and he was already thirteen, when the mother began to dislike him any more" (K. 19). The same thing happens when a brother and sister live together in peace, and suddenly a sister-in-law appears on the scene who becomes the enemy of the sister, and the brother leads the latter into the forest. Therefore it is not the parents who take the children away. I will not cite examples of enmity between stepmother and stepdaughter, they are well known. But even then, it is the father who takes the daughter into the forest, and he usually makes a very miserable figure. "Our peasant thought and thought and took his daughter into the forest" (Aph. 58 a). "The old man felt sorry for his eldest daughter, he loved her... but he did not know how to cope. He himself was sickly, and the old woman was a grumbler..." (Aph. 52 a). "The old man was sad, he cried, but nevertheless he put his daughter on the sleigh" (Aph. 52 b). One wonders why the stepmother does not want to take her stepdaughter or stepson away herself. Why, with all her cruelty and spite, does she not lead the children into the forest herself, with her authoritarian hand? Logically speaking, she could do so, but historically she cannot, because historically it is always and only the father or a brother or an uncle who leads the children into the forest, it is never a woman. Only a man can do this, and in fairy tales, man sometimes plays this role.

14.绑架。

14. The kidnapping of the children .

绑架儿童，或者假装绑架儿童，代表了仪式中离开森林的另一种形式。 « 经常会发生这样的情况：一个所谓的魔鬼抓住了这个男孩，并把他带到了格里格里森林；没有人确切知道；但人们感觉到了？114．在这种情况下，母亲们会说是有鬼魂把她们的孩子带走了。 “魔鬼”和“精神”这两个词的使用证明我们在这里处理的是后来的现象或错误的记录。从森林里来接孩子们的人们伪装成动物和鸟类，他们描绘它们、模仿它们。林中响起树蛙的叫声，人们惊慌失措地逃跑。未受割礼的孩子们离开后，据说“马萨巴”吞下了他们，只有在男人们带来了丰富的猪和芋头贡品之后才会将他们带回来 115。这些存在以及与他们相关的神秘仪式给人们带来了巨大的恐惧，以至于在基督教传入和仪式消失之后很长一段时间仍然存在116。对这些生物的恐惧被用作一种教育手段。 “纳瓦霍部落的母亲们没有实施体罚，而是用这些面具的报复来威胁不听话的孩子” 117。这种恐惧和威胁持续了几个世纪，一直延续到今天。即使在古典时期，我们也有此类威胁的例子：绑架儿童的人是“拉米”。这可能是常见的名称，Mormo、Gello、Karko 和 Empusa 都是单一的 Lamie 118。就欧洲而言，曼哈特已经研究了对此类生物的信仰，我们认为没有必要在这里重新列出他的材料并证明这些生物与俄罗斯女巫、儿童绑架者的亲缘关系。

The abduction of children, or the pretence of it, represents another form of departure for the forest in the rite. "It often happens that a so-called devil takes the boy and leads him into the Gri-Gri forest; no one knows exactly; but people intuit it." 114 In such cases the mothers say that a spirit has taken their children away. The use of the words "devil" and "spirit" proves that it is a later phenomenon or a faulty recording. The individuals who came from the forest to take the children were disguised as animals and birds, they represented them, they imitated them. The noise of tree frogs resounded in the forest, the people ran away in fear. After the departure of the uncircumcised boys, it was said that "Marsaba" had swallowed them and would return them only after the men had brought abundant tributes of pigs and taro . 115 These beings and the mysterious ceremonies connected with them inspired such a terror that it lasted long after the introduction of Christianity and the disappearance of the rites . 116 The fear of these beings was exploited as a means of education. "Instead of inflicting corporal punishment, the mothers of the Navajo tribe threaten the disobedient child with the vengeance of these masks." 117 This fear and this threat survived for centuries and has reached our days. Even in classical antiquity we have examples of such threats: the beings who kidnapped children were the "Lamias." This is probably the common name, and Mormo, Gello, Karko and also Empusa are individual Lamias . 118 The belief in such beings has been studied by Mannhardt as far as Europe is concerned, and we do not consider it necessary to re-list his materials here and prove the relationship of these creatures to the Russian child-snatching sorceress.

15.销售承诺。

15. The promise of sales .

除了陪伴他们进入森林或假装被绑架之外，还有另一种将孩子送入森林的方式，但要理解这种形式，必须更精确地解释仪式及其意义。到目前为止我们已经看到，在接受印心之后，孩子可以回家，可以娶妻等等。需要指出的是，入会者构成了一种组织，一般称为“男性社团”，或者按英文术语称为“秘密社团”。 “秘密”这个词并不完全恰当，因为社团的存在并不是秘密；然而，这个协会的内部组织和内部生活对于外行来说是秘密的。这些协会在部落的生活中发挥着重要且多种多样的作用，并且常常享有政治权力。多个社会也可以共存，但等级不同。入会仪式同时也是进入社会的仪式。不仅是进入，从某一层次的社会进入更高层次的过程，都伴随着对这个社会秘密的启蒙。正式地说（但实际上不是），入院是在孩子出生时甚至可能在孩子出生之前进行的。当他出生时，用现代的说法，他就加入了协会。换句话说，这是一种卖婴儿的行为。在这样做的过程中，父亲向协会支付了一定的费用，并在时机成熟时将孩子交给她参加入会仪式。 “从童年起，孩子们就被欢迎进入社会，尽管直到后来他们才接受舞蹈训练并参与其中” 119。舒尔茨的表述更准确：“孩子也可以提前被卖掉，但只有到了规定的年龄才学舞蹈。”同样的情况也发生在进入著名的“Duk-Duk”联赛120时。男孩出生后可以立即出售，但要到十六岁才能进入联盟。俄罗斯童话故事中的这句话正是与此相对应：“如果生了一个儿子或女儿，在十六岁之前他们是你的，但十六岁时他们是我的”（Ź. St.，第247页）。

Besides the escort into the forest or the feigned kidnapping there was still another way of sending children into the woods, but to understand this form it is essential to proceed with greater precision in the exposition of the rite and its meaning. So far we have seen that after undergoing initiation the child returned home, could take a wife, etc. It is necessary to point out that the initiates constituted a kind of organization, generally called "men's society" or, in English terminology, "secret society." The word "secret" is not entirely appropriate, since the existence of the society was not a secret; secret, however, was the internal organization and internal life of this association for the non-initiated. The associations played an important and very varied part in the life of the tribe, and often enjoyed political power. Several societies could coexist, differing in their degree. The rite of initiation was at the same time the rite of admission to the society. Not only admission, but also the passage from a society of a certain degree to that of a higher degree was accompanied by initiation into the secrets of this society. Formally speaking (but not in fact) admission took place at the time of birth and perhaps even before the birth of the child. When he was born, he was - to put it in modern terms - enrolled in the association. In other words, it was a kind of commitment to sell the child. In doing so the father made a certain payment to the association and when the time came he handed the child over to it to undergo the rite of initiation. "Boys are accepted into the society from infancy, although it is only later that they are trained in dancing and take part in it." 119 Schurtz expresses himself more precisely: "Children can also be sold in advance, but they learn the dances only when they have reached the prescribed age." The same thing happens at the time of admission into the famous "Duk-Duk" league . 120 Boys can be sold immediately after birth, but their entry into the league does not occur until they reach the age of sixteen. This is exactly what the phrase from the Russian fairy tale says: "If a son or daughter is born, up to the age of sixteen they are yours, but at sixteen they are mine" (Ź. St., p. 247).

换句话说，上述回应阐明了“告诉我你家里有什么你不知道的东西”这一主题。这个原因可以称为早期销售原因。这是原因的常见模式：这个人在他的房子外面遇到了一些意想不到的不幸。例如，他的船突然停在海里，或者他弯下腰去喝水，一个怪物从水里出来抓住他的胡子，或者有人在森林里迷路，或者在一个不允许的魔法花园里。他知道，有人为他的女儿撕了一朵花，等等。原因有很多，并且对我们的目的而言，对其进行检查并不重要。这是这个主题的第二个时刻：海洋之王、池塘老人、花园主人或魔鬼，对那些发现自己陷入困境的人说：“把你不知道的东西给我不知道在你家。”在不知道自己在做什么的情况下，他向怪物许诺了自己的孩子，并因此救赎了自己，回到家中，在那里他得知自己生了一个儿子。

In other words, the above correspondence throws some light on the motif "give me what you do not know is in your house." This motif may be called the motif of the anticipated sale. And here is the common pattern of the motif: outside his house the man meets with some unexpected misfortune. For example, his boats suddenly stop in the sea, or he bends down to drink and a monster emerges from the water and seizes him by the beard, or someone gets lost in the forest, or in an enchanted garden that does not belong to him someone picks a flower for his daughter, etc. The motives are very numerous and their examination is not essential for our purposes. And here is the second moment of this motif: the king of the sea, the old man of the pond, or the master of the garden, or the devil, say to the man who is in trouble: "Give me what you do not know is in your house." Without knowing what he is doing, he promises his child to the monster and, having thus redeemed himself, returns home, where he learns that a son has been born to him.

这个主题是鲍姆加滕专门研究的主题，但作者被迫得出这样的结论：“其本质和根源还不够明确” 121。但审视一下童话故事中发生的事情，我们会得到以下结论：在孩子出生时，签订了一份合同，根据该合同，孩子将被置于神秘的森林或水生生物的支配之下。让我们更仔细地审视这份合同：它被最深的谜团所包围；物不以名称，子不以名。 “你不知道的东西就在你家里”是一句寓言。这个寓言在一个被一系列非常严格的禁忌包围的秘密组织体系中，是一个完全可信的历史事实。其次，我们有缔约方之一的水生或森林特征。目前我们还无法阐明这位神秘老人的这一特征：当我们看到孩子在类似情况下的结局时，我们就会变得更清楚。最后，合同的第三个也是最重要的情况是合同到期。合同签订后，孩子继续与父亲呆在一起直到一定年龄，只有在“期限”到期时才离开。这个词是什么？老人要求孩子交出有什么好处？他为什么不立即接受？如果我们假设这个“术语”是指青春期，那么一切就变得更清楚了。 “你将生一个儿子，但有一个条件，那就是，当他十七岁的时候，你把他交给我”（圣典99）。有时讲故事的人自己也不太明白这种延迟从何而来，并以自己的方式解释：“让我的儿子满十二岁，让他给我一点快乐”（Sd.11），即叙述者他认为这种拖延是一种居高临下的表现，这对他来说是不可理解的。儿子离开家时会说这样的话，例如： « “再见，爸爸！现在把我送到你答应的地方！保佑我，时机已到。”他的爸爸和妈妈哭着，不想让他走。但最后他们放了他，他就走了”（ZV 118）。 « “爸爸，再见，现在我不再是你的了！ ” “我的孩子，你从哪里开始？ ”儿子说：“我现在要去森林里的怪物那里，它会吞噬我。 （ZP24）。

This motif has been the subject of a special study by Baumgarten, but the author is forced to come to the conclusion that "its essence and its roots are not sufficiently clear." 121 But if we examine what happens in the fairy tale, we have the following: at the birth of the child, a contract is concluded by virtue of which the child is placed at the disposal of a mysterious forest or aquatic being. Let us examine this contract more closely: it is surrounded by the deepest mystery; things are not called by their names, the child is never named. "What you do not know is in your house" is an allegorical expression. This allegory in the system of a secret organization, surrounded by a whole series of very severe taboos, is a completely plausible historical fact. Secondly, we have the aquatic or forest character of one of the contracting parties. For the time being we cannot shed light on this characteristic of the mysterious old man: it will become clearer when we see where the child ends up in similar cases. Finally, the third and most important circumstance of the contract is its expiration. After the contract the child continues to remain with the father until a certain age, and leaves only when the "term" expires. What is this term? What advantage does the old man gain by demanding the delivery of the child, and why did he not take him immediately? Everything becomes clear if we suppose that the "term" is that of puberty. "A son will be born to you, but on one condition, namely that you deliver him to me when he is seventeen years old" (Sd. 99). Sometimes the narrator himself does not quite understand where this delay comes from and interprets it in his own way: "Let my son live to be twelve years old, that he may give me some joy" (Sd. 11), that is, the narrator sees in this delay, incomprehensible to him, a form of condescension. The son leaves home with these words, for example: "Goodbye, father! Now send me where you promised! Bless me, the time has come." The father and mother wept and did not want to let him go. But finally they let him go, and he went away" (ZV 118). ""Farewell, father, now I am no longer yours!" "Where are you going, my son?" And the son said: "I am now going to the monster in the forest who will devour me" ». (ZP24).

有时，离开的人也会离开教父。这是一个非常有趣且在历史上合理的变形，因为洗礼仪式和入会仪式之间存在历史联系。教父取代了古代的老师和向导。 “他命令他们在他的教女长大后把他带到她面前”（《诗篇》73）。在这些情况下，教父有时会试图吃掉他的教女。

Sometimes the departing one goes away from the godfather. This is a very interesting and historically justified distortion, since there is a historical connection between the rite of baptism and that of initiation. The godfather has replaced the teacher and guide of the most ancient times. "And he commanded that his goddaughter should be brought to him when she was grown up" (Sm. 73). In these cases the godfather sometimes tries to eat the goddaughter.

与出售孩子的承诺非常相似的是，将孩子出售，或更准确地说，将孩子交给意外出现的神秘巫师、工匠或魔鬼。稍后我们会更好地辨别这位大师的性格。一个女人有一个傻儿子。一位老人来到她家。 “‘好吧，’他说，‘把它给我，我来训练它。’她就把它给了他”（《诗篇》221）。 “把他交给我，三年后我会教他所有的技巧”（AF.140a）。在这些神秘的大师中，还有“哦”，有时，只要有人惊呼“哦！”，他就会从坟墓中出现。 »。克莱奇默在他身上看到了死亡的使者或化身，这完全符合我们正在处理的一组现象122。 “老头子，你要去哪里，你要带你儿子去哪里？” — 在森林里，我把他留在那里，我们没有什么可吃的了。 —把他交给我，我将训练他三年”（ZV 30）。因此，主人公离开家后，往往会去实习。让我们看看这次实习的内容是什么。

The promise of selling one's son is closely related to the sale, or, more precisely, the handing over of one's son to a mysterious sorcerer, craftsman, or devil, who appears unexpectedly. We shall find out more about the character of this teacher later. A woman has a simple-minded son. An old man comes to her house. "'Well,' she says, 'give him to me, and I will teach him.' And she gave him to him" (Sm. 221). "Give him to me, and in three years I will teach him all wickedness" (Aph. 140 a). Among these mysterious teachers is also "Oh," who sometimes appears from the grave as soon as one exclaims "Oh!" Kretschmer sees in him a messenger or an incarnation of death, which fully corresponds to the group of phenomena we are dealing with . 122 "Where are you going, old man, where are you leading your son?" — In the forest, I will leave him there, we have nothing left to eat. — Give him to me, I will train him for three years » (ZV 30). So the hero, having left home, often happens to do a period of apprenticeship. Let us see what this apprenticeship consists of.

16.敲敲。

16. He hit, he hit .

森林里的孩子们在可怕的精灵的支配下发生了什么？正如我们已经说过的，包皮环切术无处不在，是入会仪式的中心。但包皮环切术只是男孩手术的一小部分。他们在森林里经受着最可怕的考验和折磨。许多旅行者沮丧地描述了从小屋中传出的痛苦叫声123。稍后我们会看到，孩子们实际上必须承受火的作用。另一种形式的酷刑包括去除皮肤，进行深切，目的是留下疤痕。舒尔茨和韦伯斯特都谈到了从颈部开始的背部变薄。 “这一入会的明显标志是从颈部向下的背部皮肤撕裂” 124。有时，带子穿过背部和胸部的皮肤下方，孩子们就被悬挂在其上125。在南美洲，这些仪式以其特别的残酷而闻名。伤口上撒了胡椒粉，正如我们从童话故事126中得知的那样。这些行为还伴随着殴打。在童话故事中，英雄们正是在小屋里，在森林精灵的手中遭受折磨。女巫“抓起一把杵，开始殴打乌西纽斯卡，殴打他，殴打他，直到他被打倒在地。长凳上，将带子割入他背部的皮肤，然后出去”（Af. 81 a）。 « 突然，老人进入研钵，用杵武装自己，抓住可怜的人，把他扔进研钵，压碎，压碎！他从背上撕下一条带子，一直到肩膀，拿起它，用谷壳摩擦它，然后把它扔到地板下……”（Af.79）。

What happened to the children in the forest, at the mercy of the terrible spirit that was to devour them? As we have already said, circumcision is everywhere at the centre of the initiation rite. But circumcision is only a small part of the operations performed on children. In the forest they are subjected to the most terrible trials and tortures. Many travellers describe with horror the cries of pain that come from the hut . 123 We will see later that the children actually had to submit to the action of fire. Another form of torture consisted in removing the skin, in making deep cuts with the aim of producing scars. Both Schurtz and Webster speak of the tearing of the back, starting from the neck. "The visible symbol of this initiation is a tear in the skin of the back from the neck downwards . " 124 Sometimes straps were passed under the skin of the back and chest, from which the children were suspended . 125 In South America these rites were distinguished by their particular cruelty. The wounds were sprinkled with pepper, as we also know from our fairy tale . 126 These acts were accompanied by beatings. In the fairy tale the heroes are tortured precisely in the hut, and precisely by a forest spirit. The witch « grabbed a pestle, began to beat Usyniuśka, beat him, beat him so much that he ended up under the bench, cut straps in the skin of his back, then went out » (Af. 81 a). « Suddenly the old man enters the mortar, arms himself with the pestle, takes hold of the poor man, throws him into the mortar, beats, beats! He tore a strip from his back down to his shoulders, took it, rubbed it with chaff and threw it under the floor… » (Af. 79).

当被问及这种残忍行为有什么意义时，学者们回答说，这些仪式应该让孩子们习惯于对长辈绝对服从，这是一个锻炼未来战士的问题，等等。当地人有时会以减少人口为目的来解释这些行为，因为一定比例的儿童死于这些行为的后果。但所有这些解释似乎都无法令人信服。这种残酷行为可能是为了“影响智力”：因为它们持续了很长一段时间（有时是整整几周），并且伴随着饥饿、口渴、黑暗、恐惧，所以它们一定创造了一种始作俑者认为是死亡的状态。 。它们造成了暂时的疯狂（由于服用了各种有毒饮料），使初学者忘记了一切，并且记忆力下降，这意味着当他回来时，他不再记得自己的名字，不认识他的父母等。也许他也绝对相信那些告诉他他已经死了并作为一个新的、不同的个体复活的人。

When asked what the meaning of such cruelties is, scholars reply that these ceremonies were intended to accustom children to absolute obedience towards their elders, that they were intended to temper future warriors, etc. The natives themselves sometimes explain them with the aim of reducing the population, since a certain percentage of children died as a result of these acts. But all these explanations seem unconvincing. Probably such cruelties were aimed at "striking the intellect": since they lasted a long time (sometimes entire weeks) and were accompanied by hunger, thirst, darkness, fear, they were intended to create a state that the initiate believed to be that of death. They caused a temporary madness (aided by the administration of various poisonous drinks), so that the initiate forgot everything and his memory failed him, to the point that upon his return he no longer remembered his name, did not recognize his parents, etc. and perhaps he even gave absolute belief to those who told him that he had died and returned to life as a new and different individual.

我们稍后会详细讨论暂时死亡和暂时疯狂的现象；它的形式多种多样。让我们添加一个更奇怪的细节。 « 他抓住勇敢的乌西尼亚的肘部并开始殴打他；他把他摔在地上，直到他跌倒在长凳下，弄脏了他的食物，只留下了一个洗碗机”（ZP 22）。舒尔茨和其他作者告诉我们，孩子们会感到厌恶，他们被迫喝老师的尿液等等。127 .他们被锁在一个坑里，里面有水和粪便，上面覆盖着动物粪便128。舒尔茨没有透露细节，但他说“除了他们必须忍受的痛苦之外，他们还应该克服他们的厌恶。” “他把他送到长凳下”的那一刻可能对应于昏厥、陷入黑暗、死亡和黑暗的感觉。

We will deal in detail with the phenomenon of temporary death and temporary madness a little later; its forms are very varied. Let us add one more curious detail. «He took the brave Usynia by the elbow and began to beat him; he threw him on the ground until he ended up under the bench, he soiled his food, he left him only a sort of dishwashing» (ZP 22). Schurtz and other authors tell us that disgust was provoked in the children, they were forced to drink their teacher's urine, etc. 127 . They were locked in a pit with water and manure and covered with animal excrement 128 . Without going into details, Schurtz says that «in addition to the suffering they had to endure, they were required to overcome their disgust». The moment "he sent him under the bench" could correspond to the fainting, to the fall into darkness, to the sensation of death and darkness.

17.疯狂。

17. Madness .

我们将在这里非常简短地讨论疯狂现象，这是这些案例的必然部分。在童话故事中，这个事实几乎没有反映，但重要的是要在一般联系中注意到它，并且在一般民间传说的表现中它解释了一些东西。殴打、饥饿、痛苦、酷刑，甚至有毒或麻醉饮料，新手都陷入了疯狂的状态。舒尔茨认为，疯狂的时刻是精神迁移的时刻，即新手获得某些能力的时刻。弗罗贝尼乌斯也持同样观点。 « 在这里，我们可能面临着一种在几内亚南部比在新几内亚更常见的情况，这必须被理解为痴迷。目前尚不清楚如何实现这种状态。这些人似乎拥有非凡的力量，例如他们能够将树木连根拔起” 129。 “在某些情况下，人们似乎确实相信新受割礼的人被鬼附身并变得愤怒” 130。在萨满教（其与我们的仪式的联系可以构成特别研究的对象）中，我们发现了同样的现象。 « 埋葬萨满必须而且经常会引起幻觉和癫痫发作。这些萨满在布里亚特人中享有特别的尊重和崇拜» 131。最后，希腊罗马古代构成了这种狂喜的广阔表现领域。稍后我们会看到，俄瑞斯忒斯的疯狂无疑与我们感兴趣的情结有关。但在这方面也可以引用其他神圣狂热的案例。童话故事中也会出现疯狂，但很少见。它与人体被切成四等分的景象有关。当我们研究四分的原因时，我们会发现历史证明四分与仪式中的疯狂之间存在联系。在这些情况下，童话故事说：“她似乎已经疯了”（Z. St. 380）。在瓦加特卡省的一个童话故事中，疯狂的主题得到了进一步的发展：“如果你连续听三个小时而不发疯，你就会得到古筝的礼物，它会自动演奏，但如果你去失去你的理智，他们会砍掉你的头……“士兵甚至一刻钟都听不到，失去了理智，也就是说，疯了”（ZV 1）。在所有这些情况下，疯狂都是由森林小屋中的住所引起的，或者是由强盗引起的，或者是由发出琴声的神秘生物引起的，琴的声音使人发疯。现在我们只能局限于这些摘要说明。这个问题可能构成特定调查的对象，但对我们来说，发现这种现象很重要，因为它将帮助我们理解童话故事中迄今为止尚未破译的几种现象。

We shall here deal very briefly with the phenomenon of madness, which is an inevitable part of these cases. In the fairy tale this fact has almost no reflection, but it is important to note it in the general connection, and in folklore manifestations in general it explains something. By beatings, by hunger, by suffering, by torture, or even by poisonous or narcotic drinks, the neophyte was driven into a state of furious madness. Schurtz supposes that the moment of madness was that of the migration of the spirit, that is to say, the moment when the neophyte acquired certain faculties. Frobenius is also of the same opinion. "We are probably dealing here with one of those cases which are met with more often in Southern Guinea than in New Guinea and which must be understood as obsession. It is not yet clear how such a state could be brought about. It seems that these individuals possessed extraordinary strength, for example they were able to uproot trees . " 129 "In some cases it seems to be believed that the newly circumcised man is possessed by a spirit and becomes raving mad." 130 In shamanism (the connection of which with our rite could be the object of a special investigation) we find the same phenomenon. "Buriatic shamans must cause and often do cause in themselves hallucinations and epileptic fits. These shamans enjoy special respect and veneration among the Buryats." 131 And finally, Greco-Roman antiquity constitutes a vast field of manifestation of this ecstasy. That the madness of Orestes is undoubtedly connected with the complex that interests us, we will see later. But other cases of sacred mania can also be cited in this connection. Even in fairy tales madness is encountered, but very rarely; it is connected with the spectacle of dismembered human bodies. When we examine the motif of quartering, we will see that there is a historically proven connection between quartering and ritual madness. In these cases the fairy tale says: "And she came to the point that she seemed to have gone mad" (Z. St. 380). In a tale from the Vyatka province the motif of madness is further developed: "'And if you listen to it for three hours without losing your mind, you will be given a lyre that plays by itself, but if you lose your mind, they will cut off your head…' The soldier could not listen even a quarter of an hour and lost his mind, that is, he went mad" (ZV 1). In all these cases the madness is caused by living in a forest hut, or by a robber or a mysterious being who gives a lyre, the sound of which drives one mad. For now we can limit ourselves to these brief notes. The problem could be the object of a special investigation, but it is important for us to point out the phenomenon because it will help us to understand several phenomena of fairy tales, which have so far remained undeciphered.

18.手指被割伤。

18. The severed finger .

其中一种残害形式在童话故事中得到了特别完整的保留：我们想谈谈被割断的手指。然而，童话故事中没有保留其他形式（例如折断牙齿）。包皮环切术后切除手指。韦伯斯特对此是这样说的：“部分康复后，他们被带到一个蒙面男子面前，他用斧头砍掉了他们的左手小指。我们被告知，有时候选人也会献上同一只手的食指作为补充牺牲” 132。在童话故事中，英雄经常在小屋里失去一根手指，即左手的小指。失去手指通常发生在以下情况： 1）有女巫或与她类似的生物在场。在这种情况下，会割断手指以查明孩子是否足够胖。 2) Licho-monocle (Polyphemus) 存在。在这里，英雄的手指仍然附着在任何物体上。利乔即将到达英雄身边，但他割伤了手指，以此作为代价，他救了自己。 3）在强盗家里。切下的手指就是戒指的价格。还有很多特殊情况。一般来说，可以注意到，有时英雄从他的功绩中回来时没有一根手指。有时，缺少一根手指就是假英雄的标志。作为交换，他用一根手指、一个脚趾和一条用背皮制成的丁字裤，从英雄那里买了他正在寻找的护身符，并冒充自己的护身符，但后来被缺失的手指暴露了。

One form of mutilation has been preserved in the fairy tale with particular completeness: we want to speak of the cut finger. Other forms, however (for example, the breaking of teeth) have not been preserved in the fairy tale. The removal of a finger was practiced after circumcision. Here is what Webster says about it: "After partial healing, they were led into the presence of a masked man, who cut off the little finger of their left hand with a blow of an axe. Sometimes, so we have been told, the candidates also offered as a complementary sacrifice 146 the index finger of the same hand." 132 In the fairy tale it happens very often that the hero loses a finger in the hut, and precisely the little finger of his left hand. The loss of a finger is often encountered in the following situations: 1) The witch or beings similar to her are present. In this case the finger is cut off to find out whether the child is fat enough. 2) Present Licho-one-eyed (Polyphemus). Here the hero's finger remains attached to some object. Licho is about to reach the hero, but he cuts off his finger and at this price is saved. 3) In the house of the robbers. The cut off finger is the price of the ring. There are also many special cases. In general it can be noted that sometimes the hero returns from his exploits without a finger. Sometimes the lack of a finger is the sign of the false hero. In exchange for a finger and a toe and a strap made from the skin of his back he buys from the hero the talisman he was looking for, passes it off as his own, but is later unmasked by the missing fingers.

在维亚特卡童话故事中，山羊对男孩们说：“从每只手上砍下一根手指，我要尝尝你们的味道！ “他把手指伸进东西里，但它们没有烤。 “不，它们还没有胖，还不到烤它们的时候”（ZV 11）。在德国童话中，手指只能被感觉到，而不是被移开，而在俄罗斯童话中，手指被切断。 “她尖叫着：我的好女儿们，我美丽的女儿们，砍掉他的小手指，他的小手指。”手指被割伤了。 “不，妈妈，他并不胖”（Sm.250）。

In a Vyatka fairy tale the goat says to the boys: “Cut off a finger from each hand, I will taste you!” He throws the fingers into the stove, but they do not roast. “No, they are not fat yet, it is not time to roast them yet” (ZV 11). In the German fairy tale the finger is only felt, not removed; in the Russian fairy tale it is cut off. “She cries: My good daughters, my beautiful daughters, cut off his little finger, his little finger.” The finger is cut off. “No, mother, he is not fat” (Sm. 250).

另一种英雄失去手指的情况发生在英雄与波吕斐摩斯或类似生物在一起时。这个细节足以迫使我们将女术士与波吕斐摩斯进行比较。俄罗斯波吕斐摩斯住在森林里，在一个封闭的树篱后面。他的一只眼睛可以比作女巫的失明。如果英雄在逃跑之前用锡闭上眼睛，那么这个事实就可以与女孩用浆糊填满女巫的眼睛相比较。最后，像女巫一样，波吕斐摩斯是动物之主，但与女巫指挥的森林动物不同，波吕斐摩斯饲养绵羊、牛或山羊。在一个版本中，利科（波吕斐摩斯）将英雄和一头牛一起扔出了栅栏，而他抓住了牛。为了让英雄流连忘返，利科向他身后扔了一把金斧头和一条金链（记住波吕斐摩斯也向奥德修斯扔了一块石头）。英雄是一名铁匠，他允许自己受到诱惑。 « 铁匠心里有些羡慕，他想把链条拿走，但又害怕，只用一根手指碰了一下，手指仍然焊接在链条上。铁匠看到情况不妙，就拿出一把小刀，割破了手指，然后回家了”（《SM》212）。同样：“他不顾自己的手，砍掉它就走了”（ZP 13）。

Another situation in which the hero loses a finger occurs when the hero is near Polyphemus or similar beings. This detail alone is enough to force us to make a comparison between the sorceress and Polyphemus. The Russian Polyphemus lives in the forest, in a pen, behind a hedge. His single eye can be compared to the blindness of the sorceress. If before fleeing the hero closes his eyes with tin, this fact can be compared to that of the girl who fills the witch's eyes with paste. And finally, like the sorceress, Polyphemus is the lord of the animals, but unlike the animals of the forest that the sorceress commands, Polyphemus raises sheep, cows or goats. In one version, Licho (Polyphemus) throws the hero over the fence together with an ox to which he clings. To make the hero hesitate, Licho throws him a golden axe and a golden chain (remember that Polyphemus also throws a stone at Odysseus). The hero is a blacksmith, and he lets himself be tempted. "The blacksmith felt a little envious, he wanted to take away the chain, but he was afraid and touched it with only one finger, and the finger remained welded to the chain. The blacksmith sees that the matter is going badly, takes out a penknife, cuts off his finger and goes home" (Sm. 212). Similarly: "He had no regard for his hand, he cut it off and went away" (ZP 13).

事实上，在森林里，不是只有一根手指，而是整只手都被砍掉了，这一事实可能会让我们推测，这就是那个女孩的哥哥在森林里砍掉一只或两只手的主题的起源；她的手后来奇迹般地长回来了。

The fact that instead of just one finger in the forest the whole hand is cut off, may lead us to suppose that this is where the motif of the girl whose brother cuts off one or both hands in the forest originated; her hands then miraculously grow back.

连被拖进树林中央强盗屋里的女孩子也被砍掉了一根手指。 “强盗们用叉子挖出了其中一个人的眼睛，并剥了皮，又砍掉了另一个人带着金戒指的手指”（《SM》344）。在其他情况下，情况恰恰相反，被抓的劫匪失去了一根手指或一只手。 « 事情结束后，他们坐下来吃饭。由于男朋友没有手，所以他戴上了手套，并在里面装满了沙子。”当他们问他为什么戴手套时，他回答说：“所以，我的手有点痛”（SM.127）。通常，手指也会自行脱落，因为它已浸入禁止的容器或锅炉中（Chud.58）。

Even girls dragged into a robbers' house in the middle of the forest have a finger removed. "The robbers gouged out one of them's eyes with a fork and flayed her, and they cut off the other's finger that had a gold ring" (Sm. 344). In other cases the opposite happens, the robber-fiancés are missing a finger or a hand. "When they had finished their business, they sat down to feast. Since the fiancé had no hands, he put on a pair of gloves and stuffed them with sand." When they asked him why he was wearing gloves, he replied: "So, my hands hurt a little" (Sm. 127). Often, too, the finger falls off by itself, because it was immersed in a forbidden vessel or cauldron (Chud. 58).

这时我想到了俄瑞斯忒斯。在梅塞尼，来自梅格洛波利斯的七个体育场，矗立着一座名为 μανίαι 的女神神庙。在那里，奥瑞斯忒斯谋杀了他的母亲，发疯了，一怒之下咬掉了自己的手指。离寺庙不远的地方有一座小山，山顶是由一块石头形成的。这座山被称为δαϰτύλου μνῆμα 133。

At this point Orestes comes to mind. In Messene, seven stadia from Megalopolis, there was a temple of the goddesses called μανίαι. There, after having murdered his mother, Orestes went mad and in a fit of rage bit off one of his fingers. A short distance from the temple there was a hill whose summit was formed by a stone finger. This hill was called δαϰτύλου μνῆμα 133 .

19.死亡的迹象。

19. The signs of death .

此时，这个仪式的意义问题自然而然地出现了。显然，与其说这是一道伤疤，不如说这是一个开始的标志。在童话故事中，有时会切除一根手指或一只手来代替对整个身体的四等分。有时女孩实际上被切成四等分，但手指的移除本身仍然是某种东西。 “他们抓住了她，剥光了她的衣服，把她放在一根木头上，屠杀了她，然后开始摘下她手上的戒指。”戒指不能滑落。 “他拿起斧头，狠狠地一击，手指和戒指一起飞了起来……”（Af.200）。然而，更常见的是，不进行四等分，而是将手指移开来代替。这种替代在童话《马尼娜残废》中出现得特别频繁。 “把你的头放在木块上，我就把它砍下来。” “如果我真的把你的孩子撕成了碎片……那就砍掉我的手臂，直到肘部”（ZV 72）。在另一个版本中，妻子命令丈夫杀死她的妹妹。 “到树林里去收集木材，然后杀掉你的妹妹。”妹妹恳求道：“砍下我的两只手，拿给她。”哥哥答应了，妻子很满意：“太好了！所以你杀了你的妹妹！ »（Z.圣446）134。

At this point the question of the meaning of this rite arises spontaneously. Apparently, it is not so much a scar as a sign of initiation. In the fairy tale, the removal of a finger or a hand sometimes replaces the quartering of the entire body. Sometimes the girl is actually quartered, but the removal of the finger remains a thing in itself. "They took her, stripped her, put her on a block, slaughtered her and then began to take the rings off her hands." One little ring will not let itself be taken off. "He took the axe and struck such a blow that the finger flew together with the little ring..." (Af. 200). More often, however, the quartering is not practiced and the removal of the finger replaces it; this substitution occurs with particular frequency in the fairy tale Crippled Hand . "Put your head on the block, I will cut it off." "If it is true that I have torn your child to pieces... cut off my arms up to the elbow" (ZV 72).
