In another version the wife orders her husband to kill her sister. "Go into the forest and cut wood, and kill your sister." The sister begs: "Cut off my two hands and bring them to her." The brother does so and the wife is satisfied: "Good! So you have killed your sister!" (Z. St. 446) 134 .

但如果是这样的话，男女主人公被送死在森林里的原因就被阐明了，并且要求出示证明死亡已经发生的东西：血淋淋的衣服、眼睛、心脏、肝脏、沾满血的武器等« 你来了，刽子手，我的儿子。把我的儿子带到田里，把他切成小块，然后把沾满他鲜血的剑带给我。” 《刽子手，别把我撕成碎片！砍下我左手小指，抹剑！ »（恰德。41）。有时会露出血淋淋的衣服。 “他杀了一只狗，将衣服浸入狗的血中，然后让女孩离开”（《SM》243）。

But if this is so, the motif of the hero or heroine sent to die in the forest is illuminated, and that of the request to show something that proves that death has taken place: a bloody garment, the eyes, the heart, the liver, the blood-covered weapon, etc. "Here, O executioner, is my son. Lead my son into the fields, cut him into little pieces and bring me my sword dipped in his blood." "Executioner, do not tear me to pieces! Cut off the little finger of my left hand and smear the sword!" (Chud. 41). Sometimes the bloody garment is shown. "He killed a dog, dipped the garment in its blood and let the girl go away" (Sm. 243).

我们已经知道，同修们被杀是假装的。在这种情况下，死亡迹象会向亲属展示。舒尔茨报告说，一支血腥长矛从小屋的屋顶被射出，即相当于童话故事中血腥剑的血腥武器。旁观者因此知道谜团已经完成。有时会展示一件血淋淋的衣服。 “第二天，血淋淋的衣服被展示给妇女们，她们被告知年轻人已经死了，并且永远不会回来” 135。

We already know that the initiates were pretended to be killed. In such cases the signs of death were shown to the relatives. Schurtz reports that a bloody spear was produced through the roof of the hut, that is to say a bloody weapon equivalent to the bloody sword in the fairy tale. The bystanders thus knew that the mystery had been accomplished. Sometimes a bloody garment was shown. "The following day the bloody garments are shown to the women and they are told that the young men are dead and will never return" 135 .

20.暂时死亡。

20. Temporary death .

这里引用的材料让我们关注一个已经提到过的现象，但其含义尚不清楚。我们想提及暂时死亡的现象。

The materials cited here lead us to dwell on a phenomenon already mentioned, but whose meaning is not yet clear. We want to allude to the phenomenon of temporary death.

这种死亡的形式多种多样，但目前对我们来说重要的不是形式，而是事实本身。以下是一些证词：“几乎所有地方的入会仪式都包括对入会者死亡和复活的模仿” 136。 “仪式的主要部分在于使起始者死亡并复活，从而获得魔法力量” 137。 « 当约定的日子到来时，村里的魔术师向孩子们的方向吹响拨浪鼓，孩子们惊愕地倒在地上；然后他们穿上丧服，来到村外一个用栅栏围起来的地方，叫做维拉。当地人相信这些“死者”会分解，巫师会收集骨头并赋予年轻人生命” 138。可以收集许多可以系统化和研究的证词，但这是民族志学者的任务，而不是民俗学家的任务。我们只能注意到这一事实，而无需过多解释。事实上，魔法品质的获得依赖于这种死亡和复活。

The forms of this death are very varied, but for now it is not the form, but the fact itself that counts for us. Here are some testimonies: «Almost everywhere the rite of initiation includes a mimetic representation of the death and resurrection of the initiate» 136 . «The main part of the ceremony consisted in making the initiate die and resurrect him, who thus acquired magical power» 137 . «When the appointed day arrives, the village magician plays the rattle in the direction of the young men, who fall down stunned; then they dress in funeral clothes and are led to a fenced place outside the village, called vela . The natives believe that these “dead” decompose and that the magician-witch doctor collects the bones and restores life to the young men» 138 . One can collect a great many testimonies that can be systematized and studied, but this is the task of the ethnographer and not of the folklorist. We can only state the fact without going into detail to explain it. And the fact is that the acquisition of magical qualities depended on this death and this resurrection.

但如果我们不能对这种现象进行实质性的考察，我们至少可以考察一下童话故事中所反映的死亡和复活的形式。我们会看到这些形式多种多样，而童话故事却以足够的清晰度和准确性保留了它们。

But if we cannot go into the substantial examination of the phenomenon, we can at least examine the forms of death and resurrection, insofar as they are reflected in the fairy tale. We will see that these forms are very varied and that the fairy tale has preserved them with sufficient clarity and exactitude.

在这一点上，我们首先必须指出，死亡在空间中呈现出位移的形式。在本案中也观察到了这一点。说到启蒙者，据说他“死后进入了精神世界” 139。 “据信，在此期间他在地狱”或“他升入天堂” 140。我们将在这里找到英雄旅程的部分解释。

At this point we must first point out that death took the form of displacement in space; this is also observed in this case. Speaking of the initiate, it is said that he "died and went into the world of spirits" 139 . "It is believed that during this time he is in hell" or that he "ascending to heaven" 140 . We will find here a partial explanation of the hero's travels.

关于暂时死亡的材料极其丰富；但是，未经调查就不能妄加推测。然后我们将继续审查个别案例。

The material on temporary death is extremely abundant; however, it is not permissible to formulate conjectures without having investigated it. We will therefore proceed to examine the individual cases.

21.被困住又复活。

21. Quartered and brought back to life .

暂时死亡的一种形式是将尸体切成四等分或切成碎片。我们知道存在以打开或分割身体为目的的仪式，但我们对它们的了解很少。例如，在澳大利亚瓦拉蒙加部落中，小男孩沉浸在睡眠中，祭司们“在他睡觉时杀死他，隐藏尸体，改变他的器官，并给他引入一条小蛇，这条蛇体现了神奇的力量”。院系” 141 .另一个例子是伊伦塔里亚部落，他们的入会仪式是在洞穴中进行的。新手在洞前睡着了；然后，牧师“用一支看不见的长矛刺穿他，长矛从背部穿过颈背，穿过舌头，在舌头上留下一个大开口，然后从嘴里出来”。 （舌头永远受损，这证明了与神灵的联系）。第二次长矛刺穿了耳朵。之后，沉睡的青年被传送到洞穴，在那里“所有的内脏都被篡改并引入了新的内脏……魔法水晶被引入到开放的身体中，之后青年复活了，但他已经脱离了状态”。他的心思”。后来他醒悟过来并认识到自己是一个巫师142。

One form of temporary death consisted in quartering the body or cutting it into pieces. We know of the existence of rites having as their object the opening or quartering of the body, but we have very little information about them. Thus, for example, among the Australian tribe of the Warramunga the young boy is immersed in sleep, and the priests "kill him during sleep, hide the corpse, change his organs, and introduce into him a small snake, which embodies the magical faculties." 141 Another example is offered by the Iruntaria tribe, among whom initiation is practiced in a cave. The initiate falls asleep in front of the cave; then the priest "pierces him with an invisible spear, which enters from behind through the nape of the neck, passes through the tongue where it leaves a large opening, and exits through the mouth." (The tongue remains damaged forever, and this proves the connection with the spirits.) A second thrust of the spear pierces the ears. After this the sleeping youth is carried into the cave, where "all the viscera are tampered with and new ones are introduced... Magic crystals are introduced into the opened body, after which the youth is brought back to life, but he is out of his mind." Afterwards he comes to his senses and he is recognized as a sorcerer 142 .

从这些案例中我们可以看出，用矛刺穿舌头实际上是在练习的，但是打开身体和篡改内脏是在新手处于昏迷状态时练习的，也就是说，很可能不是在练习中。实际练习过，只是唤起了印象。但如何呢？我们并不清楚。最近的案例向我们展示了对另一个人或一只动物的杀戮和肢解，但不是对新手的杀戮和肢解。有迹象表明，在这种情况下，战俘或奴隶被杀害。在某些情况下，对某些图像进行了斩首。以下是一些例子：“奴隶被杀，秘密社团的成员将他分成四份并吃掉” 143。在这种情况下，一名男子实际上被杀了。在夸夸特尔部落中，“头与躯干分离，分离者展示了一个代表头部的雕刻肖像，脸上带着死亡的表情，并抓住了头的头发。在雕刻师的技术允许的范围内，这些头像大致代表了哭泣的人的图像» 144。

In examining these cases, it is clear that the piercing of the tongue by means of a spear was actually practiced, whereas the opening of the body and the tampering with the viscera were practiced while the neophyte was unconscious, that is, probably they were not practiced in fact and were only given the impression of it. But how? We do not know precisely. More recent cases show us the killing and quartering of another man or an animal, but not of the neophyte. There are indications that on such occasions a prisoner of war or a slave was killed. In some cases decapitation was practiced over certain images. Here are some examples: "The slave was killed, the members of the secret society quartered him and ate him." 143 In this case, a man was actually killed. Among the Kwakiutl tribe "the head was severed from the trunk and the one who severed it displayed a carved effigy representing a head with the expression of death on its face, and held the head by the hair. These heads approximately represented images of weeping men, as far as the skill of the carver allowed" 144 .

有材料证明，一开始展示的是四分五裂的尸体，这些尸体被放在年轻人身上，或者他必须爬到尸体下面或从尸体上走过。显然，这是为了象征杀害始作俑者本人。 « 他们必须穿过一个浑身是血的男人，猪的内脏被放在他赤裸的身体上，给人一种内脏从身体里出来的印象。其他人躺在那里，好像他们已经死了一样，真正的责备之一是新入会者对他们的死亡负有责任。”并不是发起者被杀，而是模拟了另一个人代替他被杀。很可能在这场虚构的杀戮之前，一名旁观者被实际杀害，在这些情况下，旁观者被吃掉了。

There is evidence that the initiate was shown dead, quartered bodies, and that these bodies were placed on the youth, or he had to crawl under them or walk through them. Evidently this was intended to symbolize the killing of the initiate himself. "They had to pass through a man smeared with blood, on his naked body pig entrails were placed, to give the impression that the entrails were sticking out of the body. The others lay around as if dead, and one of the real ones reproached the initiates for being guilty of their deaths." It was not the initiate who was killed, but the killing of another man was simulated in his place. It is probable that this fictitious killing was preceded by the real killing of one of the bystanders, who in these cases was eaten.

毫无疑问，在这个仪式中存在食人行为。所有学者都在谈论它，尽管由于显而易见的原因，没有人直接观察过它。

There is no doubt that cannibalism was practiced during this rite. All scholars speak of it, although, for obvious reasons, no one has observed it directly.

人体的四分五裂在许多宗教和神话中都具有重要意义，在童话故事中也具有非常重要的作用。在这部作品中，我们只能提到一些例子，在这些例子中，四分和复活是力量的源泉或神化的条件。

Quartering, the tearing of the human body have a great importance in many religions and in many myths, and they have a very important one also in the fairy tale. In this work we can only mention some cases in which quartering and resurrection are a source of strength or a condition of divinization.

在 NP Dyrenkova 的研究《如何根据图兰尼亚部落的构想获得萨满礼物 》145中，有大量材料的摘录，证明被切成四半、被屠杀、开膛破肚的感觉是魔法科学不可或缺的条件，并且先于这一时刻。一个人成为萨满。在西伯利亚的图兰尼亚部落中，这种分割的形式是完全相同的：它是在幻觉状态下进行的。以下是该材料的一些摘录。雅库特萨满格拉西莫夫向民族志学家 AA Popov 讲述了他如何成为一名萨满。有一天，他在寻找丢失的驯鹿时，看到天上有三只乌鸦，感到背部受到重击，失去了知觉，然后“鬼魂”靠近，开始折磨他。 « 他们用绳子和丁字裤殴打他，爬行动物吮吸他的身体。他们把他浸入血块中，他在血中窒息，他们强迫他吮吸一个可怕的老妇人的乳房，他们挖出他的眼睛，他们刺穿他的耳朵，他们把他的身体撕成碎片，把他放在铁镣里。摇篮”等。146 .根据许多探险家和观察家的回忆录，在雅库提人中，未来的萨满“经历了斩首、分尸和烹煮身体的所有折磨”。 Teleuti 部落的萨满 Koiòn（野兔）在看到幻象后开始变得如此：“一些男人肢解了她的尸体，并将碎片放入锅中煮。然后另外两个人也到了。他们还切开他的肉，掏出内脏，煮熟” 147。在这里，我们看到了萨满开始施展魔法之前的典型景象。人们想知道为什么所有的萨满都会以同样的方式产生幻觉，为什么这些幻象的图像一方面与仪式形式的实践一致，有时甚至到最小的细节（在大锅中做饭等）在美国、非洲、波利尼西亚、澳大利亚，以及在另一方面，童话故事为我们提供了材料？在仪式中，我们有一种古老的形式，与各国人民的经济基础和社会组织紧密相连。图兰尼亚人代表了经济、社会和宗教文化的较不古老的阶段。童话故事中包含的相同材料在一个全新的、不同的社会环境中遭到破坏。值得注意的是，在古典古代国家和古代东方，这一主题存在于宗教中，但已经以不同的形式存在：被撕成碎片的不是萨满，而是神或英雄。最著名的例子就是俄耳甫斯。但埃及的奥西里斯、叙利亚的阿多尼斯、色雷斯的狄俄尼索斯·扎格勒斯、彭透斯等人也都驻扎在这里。他们所有人都“死于暴力，但他们并没有完全死亡：他们复活并成为邪教的对象” 148。在这些古典时期的案例中，我们可以看到斩首、纹身、疯狂、舞蹈、圣所中乐器的存在、明显的尸体与树的联系，所有这些我们稍后都会讨论。

In the study by NP Dyrenkova How the shamanic gift is obtained according to the concept of the Turanian tribes 145 there are excerpts of a vast material which prove that the sensation of being quartered, slaughtered, disemboweled is an indispensable condition for magical science and precedes the moment when a man becomes a shaman. Among the Turanian tribes of Siberia the forms of this quartering are absolutely identical: it is performed in a state of hallucination. And here are some excerpts of this material. The Yakut shaman Gerasimov told the ethnographer AA Popov how he became a shaman. One day while he was looking for his lost reindeer, he saw three ravens in the sky, felt a blow on his back and lost consciousness, then he was approached by the "spirits" who began to torture him. "They beat him with ropes and straps, reptiles sucked his body. They immersed him in clots of blood, he suffocated in blood, they forced him to suck the breast of a horrible old woman, they gouged out his eyes, they drilled out his ears, they cut his body into pieces and placed it in an iron cradle", etc. 146 . According to the memoirs of many explorers and observers, among the Yakuts the future shaman "experiences all the tortures of decapitation, quartering and cooking of his body". The shaman Koion (hare) of the Teleuti tribe began to be such after a vision: "Some men dismembered his body and put the pieces to cook in a cauldron. Then two other men arrived. They also cut up his flesh, disemboweled it, and cooked it". 147. Here we have the typical picture of the shaman's vision before he begins to exercise his magical functions. Why, one wonders, do all shamans hallucinate in the same way, and why do the images of these visions coincide, sometimes even in the minutiae (cooking in the cauldron, etc.), on the one hand with what is practiced in ritual form in America, Africa, Polynesia, Australia, and on the other with the material that the fairy tale offers us? In the ritual we have an older form, firmly connected with the economic basis and the social organization of the respective peoples. The Turanian peoples represent a less ancient stage of economic, social and religious culture. The fairy tale contains the same material in a relict phase in the midst of an entirely new and different social environment. It can be noted that in the states of classical antiquity and the ancient East this motif exists in religion, but already in a different form: it is not the shaman who is torn to pieces, but the god or the hero. The most famous example is that of Orpheus. But also Osiris in Egypt, Adonis in Syria, Dionysus Zagreus in Thrace, Pentheus and others are quartered. All of them "die a violent death, but they do not die completely: they are resurrected and become the object of a cult" 148 . In these cases of classical antiquity we can observe decapitation, tattooing, madness, dances, the presence of musical instruments in the sanctuary, the connection of the apparent corpse with the tree, all things of which we will speak later.

正如雅各比149 所展示的那样，根据阿斯瓦戈什给出的版本，甚至佛陀本人也将自己的身体撕成碎片并重新组装起来。在这种情况下，动机显然是迟到的，这证明佛陀的行为不再被理解：他这样做是为了让他的父亲皈依。

As Jacoby 149 shows , even the Buddha himself cut his body into pieces and put it back together, according to the version given by Asvagosh. In this case the motivation is evidently late, and it proves that Buddha's act was no longer understood: he acts in this way to convert his father.

四分和复活的主题在童话故事中也很流行。有些类型可以根据主体以及与主体有机联系之外的大量个案来建立。

The motif of quartering and revivification is also very popular in fairy tales. Several types can be fixed according to the subject, as well as a large number of individual cases outside the organic connection with a subject.

宿舍存在的主题之一是森林中强盗房子里的女朋友的童话故事；这是蓝胡子故事的一个变体。稍后我们将更详细地研究强盗的房子，现在我们仅限于指出，在蓝胡子类型的童话故事中，女孩在禁止的壁橱里看到了蓝胡子妻子的残破尸体。 “你往里面看时看到了什么？”房间中央有一个大血盆，里面躺着被切成碎片的人体。旁边有一个树桩，一把斧头在上面闪闪发光»（格林）。当巫师发现女孩在禁柜里时，“他把她扔到地上，揪住她的头发，在木块上砍下她的头，把她撕成碎片，血流了一地”（格林，46）。在俄罗斯北部的童话故事中，一个女孩和一个男孩最终来到了强盗的房子里。女孩被邀请进屋：“进来吃午饭”。他们进去，盛了汤，把白面包端上桌，然后是肉：煮熟的人手和脚”（Onč. 45）。匪徒回到家后，“跑进陌生的房间（即外国人的房间），把男孩拖进厨房。他们点燃了炉子，锅里沸腾了。他们把男孩浸入大锅里煮了当晚饭。男孩痛苦地发出一声惨叫，但没叫多久，就死了。他们把它盛在盘子里，然后坐下来吃。他们吃饱了然后就睡觉了”（Onč. 45）。

One of the subjects in which quartering occurs is the fairy tale of the bride in the robbers' cabin in the woods; a variety of this is the fairy tale of Bluebeard. Later on we will study the robbers' cabin in more detail, for now we will limit ourselves to pointing out that in fairy tales of the type of Bluebeard the maiden sees the torn bodies of Bluebeard's wives in the forbidden closet. "What did she see when she looked in there? In the middle of the room was a large bloody basin, and in it lay human bodies cut to pieces; beside it was a block, and on it glittered an axe" (Grimm). When the sorcerer discovered that the maiden had been in the forbidden closet "he threw her to the floor, dragged her by the hair, cut off her head on the block and hacked her to pieces, so that the blood ran down onto the floor" (Grimm, 46). In a North Russian fairy tale, a girl and a boy come to the house of robbers. The girl is invited into the house: "Come in and dine." They came in, ladled out soup, and brought white bread to the table, then meat: boiled human hands and feet" (Onč. 45). When the robbers returned home, "they ran into the strange room (i.e., the strangers' room) and dragged the boy into the kitchen. They lit the stove and the cauldron was boiling. They plunged the boy into the cauldron and boiled him for dinner. The boy uttered a cry of pain, but did not cry out for long, and died. They served him on a platter and sat down to eat; they ate until they were full and then went to sleep" (Onč. 45).

在这种情况下，行动在强盗家里进行对我们来说很重要。在雅库特童话故事中，两个女孩最终住在一间铁屋里，里面住着一位只有一条腿和一只手的老妇人。女孩们听到她在隔壁房间切人肉，她砍下了她们的腿和手，让她们也吃一些。老妇人砍下了其中一个女孩的头，并将其挂在树上。头并没有死，而是哭泣（Z. St. 462）。在这个故事中，有趣的是，女孩们吃被切成四半的受害者的肉。然而，在俄罗斯故事中，我们拒绝品尝此类食物。然而，另一方面，我们发现一个人被撕成碎片并复活，他让英雄喝人血（ZV 20）。这种血液是神奇力量的源泉。 « “我们必须给他力量！ ”然后他从他的肋骨里抽了一瓶血，递给他，说道：“如果你感觉自己还有力气，就给我也留一点，不要全部喝掉。但他喝空了瓶子，却感觉到自己体内有一股不可估量的力量；他没有给勇敢的人留下一滴水。” （ZP 2）。斩首出现在童话故事中，比如《自弹古筝》。 « “你身边有十二个商人吗？ ——是的，他命令把他们关进监狱，并说：“现在坐下来，不要睡着，否则你们就没有自动演奏的七弦琴了”。商人的儿子坐着看着：与他一起到达的商人被一一带走，他们的头被砍下来，他们的尸体被投入监狱，然后他们活着回来”（《SM》310）。

In such cases it is important for us that the operation takes place in the house of the robbers. In a Yakut tale two girls come across an iron hut where there is an old woman with only one leg and one hand. The girls hear her cutting up human flesh in the next room, she cuts off legs and hands and makes them eat some too. The old woman cuts off the head of one of the girls and hangs it on a tree. The head does not die and cries (Z. St. 462). In this tale it is interesting that the girls eat the flesh of quartered victims. In Russian tales, however, we have a refusal to taste such food. On the other hand, we find a man cut to pieces and resurrected, who makes the hero drink human blood (ZV 20). This blood is a source of miraculous strength. «“We must give him strength! „And he drew a bottle of blood from his ribs and gave it to him, saying: “If you feel much strength in yourself, leave me a little too, do not drink it all”. But he emptied the bottle and felt an immeasurable strength in himself; and he did not leave even a drop to the brave man. ” (ZP 2). Beheading is found in fairy tales like The Self-Playing Lyre . ““Have you twelve merchants with you?” — Yes. He ordered them to be locked up in prison and said: “Now sit down and do not sleep, or you will not have the self-playing lyre”. The merchant’s son sits there and sees: the merchants with whom he had arrived are led away one by one, they cut off their heads, they throw their bodies into prison and there they return alive” (Sm. 310).

因此，不同类型的童话故事都呈现出相同的主题：森林小屋里的一个人的住所。

Thus different types of fairy tales present the same motif: the quartering of a man in a forest hut.

另一种与特定主题密切相关的肢解，是由有关无法治愈的治愈的童话故事提供给我们的。这是一个很受欢迎的童话故事，有多种版本。老人最终进入了熔炉，或者遇到了尼古拉斯，尼古拉斯将他切成碎片，使他复活并使他恢复活力（Sm.155和其他）«“躺下，老人，在槽里”，陌生人说。 。老人上床睡觉，陌生人拿起斧子把他砍成碎片。神父带着水来了。陌生人洒在了破碎的身体上，四肢成形了；它再次喷出，形成一具尸体；他第三次喷洒，看到一个年轻人”（《诗篇》270）。这个仪式的意义很明确：四分法创造了新人。

Another type of quartering, this one closely connected with a specific subject, is offered to us by the tales about The Cure That Does Not Heal . This is a popular tale with several variations. The old man ends up in the forge, or meets Nicholas who quarters him, brings him back to life and makes him young again (Sm. 155 and others). " 'Lie down, old man, in the trough,' said the stranger. The old man lay down, the stranger took the axe and chopped him into little pieces. The priest came with water; the stranger sprinkled the torn body, and the limbs were formed; he sprinkled again, and a dead body was formed; he sprinkled a third time, and behold, a young man" (Sm. 270). The meaning of the rite is clear: the quartering created the new man.

但这只是问题的一方面。我们已经看到，在启蒙期间，一条蛇被引入新手的身体，并被引入肠道。这项手术的好处和必要性很快就变得难以理解，因此意义发生了转变：身体被分成四等分，以取出导致疾病的蛇和爬行动物。这个童话故事或这个主题已经由教授在这个主题中进行了研究。托尔斯泰二世收集了所有俄罗斯材料，与古典时期的主题建立了相似之处150。

But this is only one side of the question. We have already seen that during the initiation a serpent was introduced into the body of the neophyte, and it was introduced into the viscera. The benefit and necessity of this operation must soon have become incomprehensible and therefore undergone a transposition of meaning: the body is torn open to extract the serpents and reptiles which are the cause of disease. This fable or this motif has been studied in the context of this subject by Professor II Tolstoy who has collected all the Russian material, establishing parallels with motifs from classical antiquity 150 .

第三种肢解人体的方式是对与英雄结婚的被施了魔法的公主。这种划分并不与任何特定主题永久相关。 « 他拿起斧头，开始将美丽的玛雅砍成碎片……然后他命令他们给他带来一堆火，并将美丽的玛雅扔进火里。各种肮脏的野兽从里面溜出来：蛇、青蛙、蜥蜴、老鼠”（《SM》142）。

A third form of dismemberment of the human body is that practiced on the enchanted princess, who marries the hero. This dismemberment is not firmly tied to any specific subject. «He took the axe and began to cut Mary the Beautiful into pieces… Then he ordered a fire to be brought to him and he threw Mary the Beautiful into it in pieces. And out of it crawled all kinds of unclean beasts: snakes, frogs, lizards, and mice» (Sm. 142).

除了这三种基本形式（强盗之家、关于无法治愈的治愈的童话以及公主的四分院）之外，还有许多个别案例，其中四分院具有情节价值。但我们在这里所概述的仓促的特征已经足以显示童话和仪式之间的联系。不仅事实本身支持这个论点，而且它发生的环境和一些细节，以及这个主题和森林小屋之间的密切联系也支持这个论点。该主题的另一个特点，即蛇的引入或移除，也可以追溯到仪式。最后，四分五裂的人总是复活的情况表明了暂时死亡的特征，旧的复活表明了人的复活或新生，这就是整个仪式的目的。这些不同的方面是如何形成的则是另一回事。在女巫的小屋或强盗的房子里，蛇或恶魔永远不会从尸体上移走。这个问题不能通过对童话故事进行笼统的比较研究来解决，而必须通过对各个主题本身的深入研究来解决。

In addition to these three basic forms (in the robbers' house, tales of the cure that does not heal, and the quartering of the princess), there are many individual cases in which the quartering has an episodic value. But the hasty characterization that we have outlined here is already enough to show the connection between the fairy tale and the rite. In favor of this thesis is not only the fact itself, but also the environment in which it takes place and some details, as well as the intimate connection between this motif and that of the forest hut. Another peculiarity of the motif, namely the introduction or extraction of a snake, can also be traced back to the rite. And finally, the circumstance that the quartered man always comes back to life indicates the character of temporary death, and the rejuvenation of the old man indicates the resurrection or new birth of man, which is the aim of the whole rite. How these various aspects came into being is another matter. In the witch's hut or in the house of robbers, serpents or demons are never extracted from the bodies. The problem cannot be solved by a generic comparative study of the fairy tale, but must be solved by a thorough study of each subject taken separately.

22.女巫的炉子。

22. The witch's stove .

在所引用的案例中，我们注意到，四等分的尸体经常被煮熟。火像四分卫一样恢复活力。

In the cases cited we have had the opportunity to note that quartered bodies are often cooked. Fire rejuvenates as does quartering.

众所周知，在入会仪式中，新手会以各种各样的方式遭受火的攻击。在这里，我们可以追踪这些形式，将它们放在一起比较，审视它们是相互依存还是独立，检查它们的发展，替代形式、弱化形式和象征形式的出现。与此同时，有必要研究所有非常丰富且几乎取之不尽的神话和宗教表现材料，遵循燃烧的神话形式与仪式形式的对应关系，并确定为什么、以什么方式和在哪里发生这种现象。变成它的反面，也就是说我们有了对象的换位：被烧伤的孩子被那些想要烧伤他们的人所取代。这是进行广泛的历史社会调查的材料。在目前的工作中，我们只能建立基本的参考点并指出联系。

It is known that in the rites of initiation the neophytes were subjected to the action of fire in the most varied ways. Here one could follow these forms, compare them together, scrutinize whether they are interdependent or independent, examine their development, the appearance of substitute, attenuated and symbolic forms. Parallel to this one should examine all the very rich and almost inexhaustible material of myths and religious representations, follow the correspondence of the mythical forms of burning with the forms of the rite and establish for what reason, in what way and where the phenomenon is transformed into its opposite, that is to say we have the transposition of the object: the burned children are replaced by those who wanted to burn them. This is material for a vast historical-social investigation. In the present work we can only establish the fundamental points of reference and indicate the connection.

在我们所知的入会仪式的最原始阶段，我们发现入会者会烧、烤或煮自己。斯宾塞和吉伦记录了澳大利亚人的这些仪式。他们描述的仪式持续了很多天，是一种奇观：在其中一个情节中，在土里挖了一个足够长的洞，可以容纳一个人的尸体，这就是“火炉”。其中一名演员被放入空腔中，第二名演员跪在他的脚边，第三名演员跪在他的头旁边。最后两张描绘了阿伦塔人在土炉中烘烤受害者。在回旋镖的帮助下，他们假装给烤肉浇水，并用余烬覆盖尸体；在这样做的过程中，他们完美地模仿了烤肉的滋滋声和噼啪声……然后从黑暗中出现了第四位演员，代表阿尔彻林加时代（即来自遥远的古代）的青蛙图腾人。他迈着蹒跚的步伐，不断地吸气，仿佛能闻到烤肉的味道。但他似乎无法找出这股气味是从哪里来的。

Even in the earliest stages of the initiation rite known to us we find that the initiates burned, roasted or cooked themselves. Spencer and Gillen have recorded these rites among the Australians. The rite they describe lasted for many days and was a kind of spectacle: in one of its episodes a cavity was dug in the earth long enough to contain the body of a man, and this was the "stove." One of the actors was placed in the cavity, the second knelt at his feet and the third at his head. The last two represented Arunta men engaged in roasting a victim in an earthen stove. With the aid of a boomerang they pretended to water the roast and cover the body with embers; in doing this they perfectly imitated the sizzling and crackling of roasting meat… Then out of the darkness emerged a fourth actor representing a man of the frog totem of the Alcheringa times (that is, of remote antiquity). He advanced with uncertain steps, continually inhaling the air, as if he could smell the roasting meat; but he seemed unable to discover where the smell came from.

这是斯宾塞和吉伦的故事。当表演即将结束时，最后一个演员进场。与此同时，起始者已经被烧焦了。远古人类和凡人的本性已不复存在，燃烧后不再有任何气味就证明了这一点。

This is the story of Spencer and Gillen. The last actor enters the scene when the performance is almost over. In the meantime the initiate is already charred. There is no trace of the ancient human and mortal nature, which is manifested by the fact that after the burning there is no longer any smell.

在这种情况下，仪式是象征性地进行的。但也可以以更残酷的形式来庆祝。年轻人不得不在火中停留四五分钟。在上几内亚，入会者被“杀害、烘烤并彻底改变” 151。 《维多利亚》中是这样描述这一仪式的：“从前一天晚上开始燃起的大火，当时已经快要熄灭了，只剩下更多的灰烬和余烬。负鼠皮悬挂在火上，并向其中投入一铲子煤炭和灰烬。年轻人会从皮下穿过，并撒上灰烬和煤炭。”用铲子取煤的人物有一个特定的面额152。从皮下穿过显然是后来穿过动物的形式。在美拉尼西亚，启蒙者被迫穿过一座又长又窄的建筑物，同时他被浇上沸水153。

In this case the rite was practiced figuratively; but it could also be celebrated in a more cruel form. The boy had to remain exposed to the fire for four or five minutes. In Upper Guinea the initiates were "killed, roasted, and completely changed." 151 The rite is described in the Victoria as follows: "The great fire, which had been lit since the previous night, is already dying at this hour, so that it contains only ashes and embers. An opossum skin is suspended above the fire, into which shovelfuls of coals and ashes are thrown. The boys pass under the skin and are covered with ashes and coals." The characters who take the coals with the shovels have a specific name . 152 The passage under the skin is evidently a later form of the passage through an animal. In Melanesia the initiate was made to pass through a long, narrow building, and in the meantime he was doused with boiling water . 153

我们知道，从一开始，这个年轻人就获得了一个新的灵魂，他变成了另一个人；他成为了另一个人。在这里，我们发现自己面对的是火的净化和恢复活力的美德的代表，这种代表后来在基督教的炼狱中持续存在。

We know that through initiation the youth received a new soul, became another man; here we find ourselves before the representation of the purifying and rejuvenating virtue of fire, a representation which subsequently persists in Christian Purgatory.

在大洋洲，“从前一天起就已经点燃了一场大火。男人们命令新手坐在他们旁边，并在年轻人后面排成几排。突然，他们抓住了那些不知情的男孩，把他们放在火边，直到他们身上的头发都被烧焦了。在这次手术中，许多人被烧伤。但他们的抱怨并没有让任何人感到怜悯” 154。在博阿斯关于夸库特尔部落社会组织的著作中，可以找到许多不同的替代燃烧的例子。

In Oceania "a great fire is lit on the eve. The men order the neophytes to sit down beside it, and arrange themselves in compact rows behind the young men. Suddenly they seize the unsuspecting boys and hold them close to the fire until all the hair on their bodies is singed; during this operation many suffer burns. But their complaints move no one to pity" 154 . In Boas's work on the social organization of the Kwakiutl tribe one can find many and varied examples of substitutive burning.

在所有这些情况下，全部或部分燃烧或烘烤都会带来非常大的好处，即与整个仪式通常带来的好处相同，即获得社区有效成员的必要要求。

In all these cases, total or partial burning or roasting brings a very great benefit, the same benefit, that is, brought by the whole rite in general, namely the acquisition of the necessary requisites for an effective member of the community.

我们知道整个仪式代表着堕入地狱。发生在同修身上的事也发生在死者身上。在南太平洋岛屿上，当地人想象“灵魂在土炉中煮沸或烘烤，就像对待猪一样，然后将其放入一篮子椰子叶中，然后将其交付给死者所生的神灵”。生活中受到崇拜。这个食人的神吃了他，然后通过一个无法解释的过程，这个死去和撕裂的人从神的身体中散发出来，变得不朽» 155。

We know that the whole rite represents the descent into hell. What happened to the initiates also happened to the dead. In the islands of the South Pacific the natives imagined that "the soul was boiled or roasted in an earthen stove as was done with pigs, and that it was then placed in a basket of coconut leaves before being handed over to the god whom the deceased had worshipped in life. This cannibalistic deity ate him, then by an inexplicable process the dead and torn man emanated from the body of the deity and became immortal" 155 .

我们不会停留在以丰富材料为代表的原始神话的舞台上，而是直接进入童话故事，首先考察燃烧的好处。在诺夫哥罗德省的童话故事中，男孩被他的“森林祖父”送去上学。男人的女儿们点燃了炉子。 « 然后祖父把男孩扔进炉子里，他挣扎着。爷爷把他从炉子里抱出来，问他：“你知道什么吗？ ——不，我什么都不知道。” （重复操作3次，炉子变成白炽灯）。 “怎么样，你现在学到什么了吗？ “我比你知道的多，爷爷。”男孩回答道。训练结束了，森林的爷爷传话给父亲，让他来接儿子。”从故事的后续来看，男孩似乎已经学会将自己变成动物（Sm.72）。在维亚特卡童话故事中，男孩最终也成为了森林的主人。爸爸来接他回来。 « “不，我还没有还给你。 “我还得把它放在锅里煮。”他点起小火，把锅放在上面，抓起儿子扔了进去。但他毫发无伤地出来了。他又扔了一次，同样的事情发生了。 “结束了吗？ — 不，再一次......够了，你比我知道的更多”（ZV 30）。在这个童话故事中，男孩学会了听懂鸟儿的叫声。在这两种情况下，原始的狩猎基础都得到了保留：那些经过启蒙的人获得了动物的品质。在博尔特-波利夫卡收集的材料中，人们还可以找到其他被烧伤的男孩变成动物的案例。从同样的表现形式中衍生出有关铁匠、基督、魔鬼的传说，他们神奇地将老人变成了年轻人。通过燃烧，他们恢复了青春。

We will not dwell on the stage of primitive myth represented by copious material, but will pass directly to the fairy tale, examining first of all burning as a benefit. In a tale from the Novgorod province the boy is sent to school by the "forest grandfather." The latter's daughters light the stove. "And the grandfather threw the boy into the stove, and he wriggled. The grandfather pulled him out of the stove and asked him: 'Do you know anything? — No, I don't know anything.' (The operation is repeated three times, the stove becomes red hot.) 'Well, have you learned anything now? — I know more than you, grandfather,' answered the boy. The apprenticeship was over, the forest grandfather sent word to his father to come and get his son.' From the continuation of the tale it follows that the boy had learned to transform himself into an animal (Sm. 72). In a tale from Vyatka the boy also ends up at the forest teacher's. The father comes to take him back. " 'No, I won't give him back to you yet. — I still have to boil him in the cauldron. ' He lit a small fire, put the cauldron on it, grabbed his son and threw him in. But he jumped out unharmed. He threw him in again and the same thing happened. 'Is it over? — No, once more... Enough now, you know more than I do. ' " (ZV 30). In this tale the boy learns to understand the cries of birds. In both cases the original hunting basis has been preserved: whoever has passed through initiation acquires the qualities of an animal. In the materials collected by Bolte-Polivka one can find other cases in which the burned boy is transformed into an animal. From this same representation derive the legends about the blacksmith, Christ, the devil, who magically convert old people into young people. By burning, they regain their youth.

然而，除了这种被认为是一种好处的燃烧表现之外，另一种完全相反的表现很快就出现了。现在我们只注意到这一事实，我们将在检查材料后进行解释。

However, alongside this representation of burning as a benefit, another completely opposite one soon appeared. For now, let us only note the fact, which we will explain after examining the materials.

例如，我们在赫维群岛发现了类似的负面关系，人们相信，经过一番冒险之后，灵魂落入了一个名叫米鲁的可怕生物的网中。弗雷泽写道：“最终，网与灵魂一起被拉上岸，灵魂被可怕的女巫米鲁（Miru）半窒息和颤抖地牵引着，米鲁被称为“红色”，因为她的脸反射着始终点亮的火热。它在炉子里烹煮无形的受害者，但首先它给它们喂食，也许还用黑色昆虫、红色蠕虫、螃蟹和鸟类来养肥它们。恢复体力后，灵魂们必须喝一杯由四位美丽的女巫女儿亲手准备的非常浓的卡瓦酒。由于醉人的饮料而失去知觉，灵魂被放入炉子中，没有任何抵抗，他们在那里做饭” 156。

A similar negative relationship is found, for example, in the Hervey Islands, where it was believed that after some adventures the soul fell into the net of a terrible being, called Miru. « Finally - writes Frazer - the net was hauled ashore together with the soul, which was led, half suffocated and trembling, to the hideous witch Miru, known by the name of "Red" because her face reflected the burning heat of the stove always burning in which she cooked her incorporeal victims, but first she fed them and perhaps fattened them with black insects, red worms, crabs and small birds. After having regained their strength, the souls had to drink a cup of very strong kava , prepared by the hands of four beautiful girls, daughters of the witch. Reduced to a state of insensibility by the intoxicating drink, the souls were put into the stove, without offering any resistance, and there they cooked » 156 .

在这个故事中，谁会认不出落入女巫手中的孩子们，女巫把他们养肥吃掉呢？

Who wouldn't recognize in this story the children who ended up in the hands of the witch who fattens them up to eat them?

有趣的是，在这方面，没有人反对焚烧。第一眼让你震惊的是所发生的事情是绝对不可避免的，灵魂致力于这些痛苦。该材料是在赫维群岛记录的，而上述报告的燃烧导致神化的材料是在相对较近的地点（即康科迪亚群岛）收集的。由此可见，在同一领域，我们发现了截然相反的表述。因此，这不是领土原则的问题，而是其他问题：灵魂的命运取决于死者的社会状况。焚烧对于妇女、儿童以及所有自然死亡的人来说都是致命的。他们最终落入红魔米鲁的网中，这意味着最终的死亡、永恒的毁灭。在战斗中阵亡的人，一般来说，战士和领袖都以另一种方式死亡：他们的灵魂通过壁炉升入天界，永远住在那里。

It is interesting to note that no one fights against burning. What is striking at first sight is the absolute inevitability of what happens, the soul is doomed to these pains. This material was recorded in the Hervey Islands, while the material reported above, in which burning leads to deification, was collected in relatively close locations, namely the Concordia Islands. It follows that in the same territory we find diametrically opposed representations. It is not, therefore, a question of the territorial principle, but of something else: the fate of the soul depends on the social condition of the deceased. Burning is fatal for women, for children, for all those who die a natural death. They end up in the nets of Miru the Red, which means definitive death, eternal destruction. Men killed in combat and, in general, warriors and leaders die in another way: through the hearth their souls ascend to the celestial world, to live there eternally.

因此，这种二元论伴随着社会分化的种子而出现。

This dualism therefore appears with the seeds of social differentiation.

我们知道神话是禁忌的神圣故事，我们将在最后一章中更好地看到这一点。但随着工具的进步和魔法的衰落，故事的“亵渎”不断发展，并与这一事实和社会分层相结合，“亵渎”版本占据了主导地位，即否认的版本燃烧的好处，并将其严厉性指向实践者；因此，被扔进火炉的就是他。但与此同时，从仪式中诞生的古老版本仍然被讲述有关君主、领袖、英雄、半神以及后来的诸神。

We know that myths were sacred tales made taboo, and we will see this better in the last chapter. But with the progress of the "profanation" of the tale due to the improvement of the instruments and the decline of magic and in connection with this fact and with the stratification of society, the "profane" version takes over, that is to say the version that denies the benefit of burning and turns its harshness against the one who practices it; it is he, therefore, who is thrown into the stove. But, at the same time, the archaic version born from the rite continues to be told with regard to sovereigns, leaders, heroes, demigods and, later, gods.

从这一点来看，对经典材料的考察是很有趣的。人物是神和英雄。在荷马史诗中，大地、生育和地狱女神德墨忒尔（Demeter）四处寻找女儿，最终来到了塞琉斯（Celeus）的家中。她在那里生活，无人认出，并被聘为小德摩丰的护士。 « 德墨忒尔同意留下来，成为小德摩风的护士。她将孩子抱在她不朽的怀抱里，把他放在她芬芳的胸前；母亲心里欢喜。”于是得墨忒尔抚养了得墨忒耳，孩子像神一样长大，没有吃母乳，也不吃面包；但得墨忒耳每天都会给他涂上圣水，仿佛他真的是众神的后裔，她把他抱在怀里，轻轻地对着他呼吸，晚上，当她单独和孩子在一起时，她偷偷地把他放在中间火，就像一个烙印，因为她的心倾向于这个孩子，她高兴地要给他永生。

In this respect, the examination of classical material is interesting. The characters are gods and heroes. In the Homeric hymn, Demeter, goddess of the earth, fertility and the underworld, wanders in search of her daughter and ends up in the house of Celeus. There she lives unrecognized and is taken as the nurse of the little Demophoon. "Demeter agreed to stay and become the nurse of the little Demophoon. She took the child in her immortal arms and placed him against her fragrant breast; and the mother's heart rejoiced." So Demeter raised Demophoon and the child grew up like a god, was not nursed and did not eat bread; But every day Demeter anointed him with ambrosia, as if he were truly a scion of the gods, breathed gently on him as she held him in her arms, and at night, when she was alone with the child, she secretly placed him in the midst of the fire, like a brand, because her heart was inclined to the child, and she would joyfully grant him immortality.

荷马史诗如此说道。正如我们所说，这里没有燃烧。一天晚上，孩子的母亲监视了德墨忒尔，看到她的孩子在火中，惊恐万状，尖叫起来。女神对她愚蠢的母亲感到愤怒，将他从火焰中救了出来，从而剥夺了他的永生。这个神话的主题与其说是燃烧，不如说是对燃烧的反应。

So says the Homeric hymn. As we have said, there is no burning here. One night the child's mother spies Demeter, sees with terror her child in the fire and screams; the goddess, angry with the foolish mother, snatches him from the flames, thus depriving him of immortality. The subject of the myth is not so much the burning as the reaction to it.

我们在珀琉斯和忒提斯的神话中看到同样的事情。阿喀琉斯的母亲忒提斯在夜间将她的儿子浸入火中，以摧毁并燃烧他父亲珀琉斯的人性，并赋予他神性和不朽。但珀琉斯监视她并抢走了她的儿子157。因此，在古典时期不再实行焚烧，这一主题已经日渐式微。在这方面，它被转移到来世的表现，这非常接近童话故事。虽然神话中的人物是神和半神，但由于凡人的“误解”，后来成为神的人一般不会成为神。这里意义转换的历史过程是非常清晰的。

We see the same thing in the myth of Peleus and Thetis. Thetis, the mother of Achilles, immerses her son in fire at night, in order to destroy and burn the human nature of his father Peleus in him and to confer divinity and immortality on him. But Peleus spies on her and takes her son away from her . 157 Thus, in classical antiquity burning was no longer practiced; this motif was already in decline. In this connection it is transferred to representations of the underworld, which are very close to fairy tales. Although the characters in the myth were gods and demigods, the men who were to become gods generally did not become such through the "misunderstanding" of mere mortals. The historical process of the transposition of meaning is very clear here.

同样，除了古老的燃烧形式（使猎人和军事领袖能够获得必要的能力）之外，童话故事还保留了一个截然相反的概念：燃烧被理解为一种恐怖，人们可以快乐地从中逃脱。我们不会举这方面的例子，它们太众所周知了。

Likewise, the fairy tale has preserved, alongside the archaic forms of burning that gives the hunter and the military leader the necessary faculties, a diametrically opposed concept: burning understood as a horror from which one happily escapes. We will not give examples in this regard, they are too well known.

23.智能科学。

23. Clever science .

如果我们对将童话故事与入会仪式联系起来的联系的观察是正确的，那么它们就揭示了另一个主题，也就是说，故事的巧妙科学以及那些被驱逐或送走的人的整个复杂性他从家乡回到那里，拥有一些艺术、知识或能力。在故事《聪明的科学》中，父母有时出于自愿，有时出于需要而将孩子送去学校。这似乎是一个完全现实的元素，事实上（尤其是在德国童话故事中）英雄有时会以熟练的大师的身份回到家乡；然而，教师的形象、环境、教学方式和技能的获得与19世纪的历史现实无关，而是与非常遥远的过去的历史现实非常相似。

If our observations on the connection between the fairy tale and the rite of initiation are correct, they throw light on another subject, namely, on the tale of "The Clever Science" and on the whole complex in which one who has been expelled or sent away from home returns to it in possession of some art, knowledge or skill. In the tale of " The Clever Science" the parents, sometimes of their own volition and sometimes forced by need, send their son to school. This would seem to be a completely realistic element, and indeed (especially in the German fairy tale) the hero sometimes returns home as a skilled master of a given craft; however, the figure of the teacher, the environment, the manner of teaching and the acquisition of skills have nothing to do with the historical reality of the nineteenth century , but are very similar to the historical reality of a very remote past.

照顾男孩的老师是一位老人，一位巫师，一位森林恶魔，一位圣人。他住在“海那边”。 “海那边有一位大师，教授各种艺术”（Chud.94）。他“在海那边”或“在河那边”，也就是说，在另一个王国，有时在另一个城市。 « 伏尔加河彼岸，一座城市里，有一位老师，教授各种语言和各种手艺，他什么都知道。他教导年轻人、儿童，三年来他把他们从父母身边夺走”（《圣经》第 64 章）。有时，如果有人说“哦！ »（AF. 140 c）。当你坐在原木上时它也会出现。他是“森林的祖父”。从这些例子中我们看到，老师来自森林，住在另一个王国，把孩子从父母身边带走，带他们进入森林三年（或一年，或七年）。

The teacher who takes care of the boy is an old man, a sorcerer, a forest demon, a sage. He lives "beyond the sea." "Beyond the sea there is a teacher who teaches various arts" (Chud. 94). He is "beyond the sea" or "beyond the river," that is, in another kingdom, sometimes in another city. "Beyond the Volga, in a city, there was a teacher who taught various languages ​​and various crafts, he knew how to do everything. He taught young people, boys, he took them from their parents for three years" (Sd. 64). Sometimes he comes out of a tomb if one says "Oh!" (Af. 140 c). He also appears when one sits on a stump. He is "the grandfather of the forest." From these examples we see that the teacher comes from the forest, lives in another kingdom, takes children from their parents and leads them into the forest for three years (or for one, or for seven).

英雄学到了什么？他学习变成动物或学习鸟类的语言。 « 他们把他托付给一位智者，而智者也是一位智者，这样他就可以学习不同的语言，对一切都了解一点：了解鸟儿什么时候歌唱，羊什么时候咩咩叫，总之，这样他就可以学习一切！ »（AF.140d）。他学习了巫师的艺术。 “把他交给我，我会让他成为一名巫师”（ZP 57）。 “他们把他托付给他，以便他能够学习鸟类的语言”（Af. 140 e）。完成训练后，有人这样评价他：“你的儿子擅长科学，他很有能力”（Chud.19）。 “他拥有伟大的仙女美德和伟大的狡猾：他不仅知道已经发生的事情，而且还知道即将发生的事情”（Chud.19）。

What does the hero learn? He learns to transform himself into an animal or he learns the language of birds. "They entrusted him to a wise man who was also a wise man so that he could learn the different languages ​​and learn a little bit of everything: to understand when the bird sings and when the sheep bleats, in a word, so that he could learn everything!" (Af. 140 d). He learns the art of the sorcerer. "Give him to me, I will make him a sorcerer" (ZP 57). "They entrusted him to them so that he could learn the language of birds" (Af. 140 e). After completing his apprenticeship, it is said of him: "Your son is good at science, he is capable" (Chud. 19). "And he possessed great magical virtue and great cunning: he knew not only what had happened but also what was yet to happen" (Chud. 19).

几乎从未提及如何教授教学。上面我们注意到，在一个例子中，英雄被放在大锅里煮，从而获得了他的预言知识（Sm.72）。而主人的家几乎从未被描述过。只有在一个案例中，我们才知道它是“花园中央的一所房子”，里面住着十二个年轻人（Chud. 94；有关房子的主题，请参见第 30 节）。其他地方提到“学校所在的大旅馆”（Sd. 64）。

It is almost never said how the teaching is imparted. We noted above that in one case the hero was put to boil in a cauldron and thus acquired his prophetic knowledge (Sm. 72). Nor is the teacher's dwelling almost never described. In one case only do we learn that it is "a house in the middle of a garden" in which twelve young men live (Chud. 94; for the reason for the house see § 30). Elsewhere it is spoken of "a large inn where school is held" (Sd. 64).

所有这些细节：老师的森林性格、孩子们与父母的分离、教学的巫术性质、转变为动物或理解鸟类语言的能力等等。导致我们也将这组原因与前面的原因所指的同一现象联系起来。

All these details: the sylvan character of the teacher, the detachment of the children from their parents, the witch-like nature of the teaching, the ability to transform into animals or to understand the language of birds, etc. lead us to refer this group of motifs to the same phenomenon to which the previous motifs refer.

入会仪式是一所学校，是真正意义上的教学。入会后，年轻人接受了所有神话传说、部落所有仪式、礼仪和规范的教育。探险家们相信他们被教导了一门神秘的科学，也就是说，他们获得了某些知识：部落的神话实际上是告诉他们的。一位目击者说，“年轻人沉着地坐着，向老人学习；它看起来像一所学校” 158。然而，问题的关键并不在这里。这不是关于知识，而是关于能力，这不是关于了解想象中的自然世界，而是关于影响它。这个问题在童话《狡猾的科学》中得到了明确的体现，正如我们所说，在童话中，英雄学会了变成某种动物，也就是说，他获得了一种技能，而不是知识。

The rite of initiation was a school, a teaching in the true sense of the word. Through initiation the young men were instructed in all the mythical representations, in all the rites, rituals and norms of the tribe. The explorers believe that they were taught a mysterious science, that is, that they acquired certain knowledge: in fact they were told the myths of the tribe. An eyewitness says that "the young men sat composed and learned from the old men; it seemed like a school" 158 . However, this is not the crux of the matter. It is not a question of knowledge, but of ability, it is not a question of knowing the imaginary world of nature, but of influencing it. This aspect of the matter is clearly reflected in the fairy tale The Clever Science , in which, as we have said, the hero learns to transform himself into certain animals, that is, he acquires a skill and not knowledge.

这种教育或培训构成了全世界启蒙教育的一个基本特征。在澳大利亚（新南威尔士州），老人教年轻人“玩当地的游戏，唱部落的歌曲，跳某些妇女和外行人禁止的舞蹈”。年轻人还接受了部落神圣传统及其科学（知识）的教育” 159。在这里我们也可以看到，叙述的时刻在行动的时刻之后退居二线。 « 这些仪式……由对神话和传说的粗俗但往往非常富有表现力的戏剧化组成。蒙面和伪装的演员代表动物或神灵，其故事由神话讲述» 160。在这则新闻中，有一个前提：神话先于戏剧性的行动，即“神话被戏剧化”。在我们看来，情况恰恰相反。戏剧性的动作是首要的，神话是后来发展的。澳大利亚就是一个令人信服的证明，那里有非常复杂和漫长的戏剧性表现，而神话却很短、极其混乱、无定形，而且对于欧洲人来说往往难以理解161。表演和舞蹈不是表演，它们是作用于自然的神奇过程。初学者非常勤奋地练习了很长时间的所有舞蹈和歌曲。哪怕是最轻微的错误都可能是致命的，甚至可能毁掉整个仪式。在这方面，让我们记住，在白俄罗斯童话中，只有在继女为他跳舞后，熊才会解雇她。在博阿斯的作品集中，我们遇到了英雄前往“另一个王国”并带回他教给他的部落的舞蹈的案例。

This education or training is an essential feature of initiation throughout the world. In Australia (New South Wales) the old men taught the young men "to play the local games, to sing the songs of the tribe and to dance certain dances which were forbidden to women and the uninitiated. The young men were also instructed in the sacred traditions of the tribe and in its science ( lore )" 159 . Here too we can see that the moment of narration takes second place to the moment of action. "The rites… consist of a crude but often very expressive dramatization of the myths and legends. The masked and disguised actors represent the animals or divine beings whose story is narrated by the myths" 160 . In this piece of news there is the premise that the myths are prior to the dramatic action, that "the myth is dramatized". It seems to us that just the opposite has happened. The dramatic action is primary, the myth develops later. A convincing proof of this is Australia, where we have very complex and long dramatic representations, while the myths are short, extremely confused, amorphous and often incomprehensible to a European 161 . Representations and dances were not shows, they were a magical procedure for acting on nature. The initiate practiced all the dances and songs very diligently and for a long time. The slightest error could be fatal, could spoil the whole ceremony. Let us recall in this regard that in a White Russian fairy tale the bear dismisses his stepdaughter only after she has danced for him. In Boas's collection we find cases in which the hero leaves for "the other kingdom" and brings back dances that he teaches to his tribe.

小男孩学习秋季、春季和冬季仪式的舞蹈和仪式，目的是增加游戏、求雨、增加收成、驱除疾病等。162 .

The youth learns the dances and ceremonies which are part of the autumn, spring and winter rites, having as their aim the increase of game, the bringing of rain, the improvement of the harvest, the chasing away of diseases, etc. 162 .

森林之主并不教俄罗斯童话故事中的英雄们跳舞，而是赋予他们神奇的能力。然而，舞蹈也是应用这些能力的一种表达或方式。童话里的舞蹈已经消失了；只剩下森林、主人和魔法能力了。然而，在某些其他类型的童话故事中也可以找到舞蹈的痕迹。他们在音乐声中表演，乐器被认为是神圣和禁止的。举行启蒙仪式并且入会者有时会度过一段时间的房子有时被称为“笛子之家” 163。这些笛子的声音被认为是灵魂的声音。记住这个事实，我们就会明白为什么英雄经常在森林小屋里找到自弹琴、风笛、小提琴等。每个人都必须随着这把竖琴的声音起舞，英雄通过这些舞蹈获得力量。当然，他们的性格完全不同：“他们来到了一个地方，那里有一个小茅屋。他们进入了这个小小屋……他看了又看，发现横梁下有一根风笛。他开始吹奏风笛”（ZP 43）。风笛之声唤起精神。

The forest teacher does not teach the heroes of the Russian fairy tale how to dance, but rather how to bestow magical powers. But the dances were also an expression or a way of applying these powers. In the fairy tale the dance has been lost; only the forest, the teacher, and the magical power remain. However, in certain fairy tales of other types one can also find traces of dances. They were performed to music, and musical instruments were considered sacred, forbidden. The house in which the initiation took place and the initiates sometimes spent a certain period was sometimes called the "house of flutes." 163 The sound of these flutes was believed to be the voice of a spirit. If one keeps this fact in mind, one can understand why in the forest hut the hero so often finds the self-playing zither, a bagpipe, violins, etc. Everyone has to dance to the sound of this zither, and the hero gains power over these dances. Of course, their character is completely different: "They came to a place where there was a little hut. They entered this little hut... He looks, looks and notices a bagpipe under the crosspiece. And he began to play the bagpipe" (ZP 43). The sound of the bagpipe evokes the spirit.

在童话《自弹古筝》的一个版本中，古筝是由人的肌腱制成的。 “主人带领他们进入车间，他们立即将一个人放在机器上的十字架上，并开始拔出肌腱”（Sm.4）。众所周知，神圣的乐器是用人骨制成的。但舞蹈也被隐晦地保留在童话故事中。 « 之后尼基塔开始环顾小屋，看到窗户上有一个小口哨，他接过它，把它放在嘴边，开始吹口哨。他环顾四周：多么有趣啊！盲人兄弟跳舞，小屋跳舞，桌子、长凳、盘子，一切都跳舞”（Af. 116 b）。哨声一响，女巫就出现了。 « 快乐之心带着小提琴出去，去森林里和他的兄弟们住在一起。女术士接近快乐心。 “你在做什么，快乐的心？ ——我拉小提琴”。女术士扔掉了水桶并开始跳舞。” （Z.St.269）。在 Vjatka 的故事（ZV 40）中，退役士兵在孤儿家里的一间小牢房里过夜；这是一座装修精美的大房子（稍后会详细介绍）。士兵在房子里过夜。 « 然后恶魔们开始背诵许多喜剧，但在某个时刻他们停了下来。 “来吧，士兵，现在轮到你了，我们不会再知道了。”以“演妖喜剧”来表示狂野的舞蹈，是非常有趣和有意义的。另请注意，英雄也被迫执行某些模仿动作。

In one version of the fairy tale The Self-Playing Lyre, the lyre is made of human sinews. "The master took them into the workshop, where they immediately put a man on a cross over the machine and began to pull out the sinews" (Sm. 4). It is known that sacred instruments were made of human bones. But in the fairy tale, the dances have also been obscurely preserved. "After that, Nikita began to look around the hut and noticed a small whistle on the window, took it, put it to his lips and began to whistle. He looks around: what a funny thing! The blind brother is dancing, the hut is dancing, the table, the benches, the dishes, everything is dancing" (Af. 116 b). At the sound of the whistle, the witch appears. "Happy-heart went out with his violin and went to stay with his brothers in the forest. The witch approaches Happy-heart. "What are you doing, Happy-heart?" — I play the violin. ’ The sorceress threw away the bucket and began to dance. ’ (Z.St. 269). In a story by Vyatka (ZV 40) the discharged soldier spends the night in a small cell in the orphan’s house; it is a large, beautifully decorated house (we will talk about it later). The soldier spends the night in the house. ‘Then the demons began to perform many comedies, but at a certain point they stopped. ‘Come on, soldier, now it’s your turn, we don’t know any more. ’ ” The term ‘performance of comedies of demons’ to indicate the woodland dances is very interesting and significant. It should also be noted that the hero himself is forced to perform certain mimetic actions.

在彼尔姆省的一个童话故事中，一所大房子的秘密衣柜里住着三个女孩。瓦尼乌萨把衣服还给他们。 “他们穿上衣服，抓住他的腰，开始跳卡德里尔舞”（ZP 1）。上面我们已经说过，从女孩们的衣服和翅膀上就可以辨认出图腾面具和服饰。最后，正如 DK Zelenin 指出的那样，宗教仪式常常变成游戏164。也许森林小屋里盲人与熊的游戏反映了在森林里学到的舞蹈。

In a tale from the Perm province, three girls are found in the secret closet of a large house. Vanyusha returns their clothes to them. "They put on the clothes, took him by the waist and began to dance the quadrille" (ZP 1). We have already said above that in the girls' clothes and wings one can detect totemic masks and costumes. Finally, as DK Zelenin points out, religious rites often transform themselves into games 164 . Perhaps the game of blind man's buff with the bear in the forest hut is a reflection of the dances that were learned in the forest.

童话材料和民族志材料的比较表征在这里也呈现出密切的联系。

The comparative characterization of the fairy tale material and the ethnographic material also presents a close connection here.

24.仙女的礼物。

24. The fairy gift .

我们已经看到，童话故事赋予主人公一份童话礼物，通过它他实现了自己的目标。该礼物由一个物体（戒指、魔杖、球等）组成，或者是动物，主要是一匹马。我们还看到了女巫的形象是如何与入会仪式紧密相连的。这些仪式中是否存在与接受礼物的行为相对应的东西？

We have already seen that the fairy tale gives the hero a fairy gift, by means of which he achieves his goals. This gift consists of an object (a ring, a wand, a ball, etc.) or is an animal, predominantly a horse. We also saw how the image of the sorceress is closely connected with the rites of initiation. Is there anything in these rites that corresponds to the act of receiving the gift?

帮助者的问题将在专门的章节中单独讨论。现在我们只讨论与仪式研究相关的助产士分娩时刻。事实证明，在入会仪式中，这样的时刻不仅存在，而且代表了整个仪式的中心点、顶峰。英雄的魔法能力取决于帮助者的购买，英国人种学家将其称为（有点不恰当）守护者精神。对此，韦伯斯特说：“在未受启蒙的妇女和儿童中，人们普遍相信主持入会仪式的老人拥有某些神秘而神奇的物品，向入会者展示这些物品代表了入会仪式的核心和最具特色的部分。仪式本身» 165。以及其他地方：“基本教义是对个人守护神（即帮助者）的信仰，协会成员通过阳具性质的仪式将自己转变为个人守护神” 166。舒尔茨说，整个儿童入会仪式“简化为购买守护神，购买曼尼通” 167。在下一章中，这个问题将成为更详细研究的主题；我们将包括戒指、魔杖、球和其他物体，以及英雄和他的动物助手之间的纽带。这里只要指出辅助守护者与部落图腾有关就足够了。

The question of the helper is treated separately in a special chapter. For the present we shall deal only with the moment of the delivery of the helper in connection with the study of the rite. It appears that in the rites of initiation such a moment not only existed, but represented the central point, the apex of the whole rite. The magical faculties of the hero depended on the acquisition of the helper, whom English ethnographers have called, somewhat improperly, guardian-spirit . In this connection Webster says: «Among uninitiated women and children the belief was universally diffused that the old men who presided over the rite of initiation possessed certain mysterious and magical objects, the revelation of which to the initiates represents the central and most characteristic part of the rite itself» 165 . And elsewhere: "The fundamental doctrine was the belief in a personal guardian spirit (that is, in a helper) into which the members of the association were transformed by means of rites of a phallic character." 166 Schurtz says that the whole rite of initiation of children "is reduced to the purchase of a guardian spirit, the purchase of a Manitou . " 167 In the next chapter this problem will be the object of a more detailed study; we will include the rings, the rods, the balls and other objects, as well as the connection between the hero and his animal helpers. Here it will suffice to point out that the guardian helper was in relation to the totem of the tribe.

25.女巫婆婆。

25. The witch-mother-in-law .

但女巫的形象尚不完全清晰。从我们的阐述中我们看到，我们让女巫更接近执行入会仪式的人或面具。但这里有一个不一致之处。女巫可以是女人，也可以是动物。它的动物外观与我们对这种仪式的了解完美契合。举行仪式的伟大上师和祖先经常描绘一种动物并戴着它的面具。但如果我们谈论他的人类外表，虽然这没有从民族志材料中出现，但他总是以男性的形式出现，从不以女性的形式出现。现在让我们更仔细地考虑一下女巫的形象和仪式。

But the image of the sorceress is not yet entirely clear. From our exposition it is clear that we are comparing the sorceress to the person or mask who performs the rite of initiation. But here there is an incongruity. The sorceress can be a woman or an animal. Her animal appearance ties in perfectly with what we know about this rite. The great master and progenitor who performs the rite often depicted an animal, wore its mask. But if we speak of his human appearance, although this does not result from the ethnographic materials, he always appears as a man and never as a woman. Let us now consider more closely both the figure of the sorceress and the rite.

仪式的目的之一是让年轻人为婚姻做好准备。众所周知，在异族通婚制度中，入会仪式不是由年轻人所属家庭群体的代表进行的，而是由另一个群体，而且正是与第一群体同族通婚的群体的代表进行的，即年轻人要娶妻子的那个人来说。这是澳大利亚的特殊性，有理由相信这是最古老的启蒙形式168。在将女孩嫁给另一个群体的年轻人之前，妻子所在的群体对年轻人进行了割礼和入会。

One of the purposes of the rite was to prepare the young man for marriage. It is known that in exogamy the rite of initiation was not performed by representatives of the family group to which the young man belonged, but by another group, namely the one with which the first group was endogamous, that is, the one from which the young man would take a wife. This is a peculiarity of Australia, and it is reasonable to assume that it is the most ancient form of initiation . 168 Before giving a girl in marriage to a young man of another group, the wife's group subjected the young man to circumcision and initiation.

在维多利亚，马修斯169观察到另一个事实：“帮助者（由年轻人获得）不必属于发起者的亲属关系：他是从参加仪式的部落之一中选出的，并且恰恰是从参加仪式的部落中选出的。”年轻人后来通过婚姻进入了这个家庭。”正如我们稍后将在有关助手的章节中看到的，这个助手是遗传性的。在这里我们看到它是沿着女性血统遗传的。

In Victoria Mathews 169 observed another fact: "The helper (purchased by the youth) need not belong to the kindred of the initiate: he is chosen from one of the tribes convened at the ceremony, namely, that into which the youth subsequently enters by his marriage." As we shall see later in the chapter on helpers, this helper was transmitted hereditarily. Here we see that it was transmitted hereditarily along the female line.

童话故事也保留了这种情况。我们可以观察到以下情况：如果女巫或小屋的另一位捐赠者或居民与其中一位英雄有关系，那么她总是与英雄的妻子或母亲有关系，而不是与英雄本人或他的父亲有关系。在维亚特卡童话故事中，她说：“呃，儿子！你是我的侄子，你的母亲是我的妹妹”（ZV 47）。这里我们不能从字面上理解“小妹妹”。在某些形式的亲属关系系统中，这个词意味着英雄的母亲与女术士属于同一家庭群体。当主人公结婚后，这一点就更明显了。在这种情况下，说“我的女婿（或我的姐夫）来了”，也就是说，女巫是妻子的母亲或姐妹，是她的亲戚，属于同一家。部落如她。 “我的姐夫来了”（ZV 32）。 “这个老妇人是你的岳母”（Sd. 9）。 “啊，他说，你是我的侄子”（Sev.7）。 “你姐夫来了”（K.7）。 “她（公主）是我的侄女”（K.9）等。

The fairy tale has also preserved this situation. We can observe the following: if the witch or another donor or inhabitant of the hut is related to one of the heroes, she is always related to the hero's wife or mother, never to the hero himself or to his father. In a Vyatka fairy tale she says, "Oh, my son! You are my niece, your mother is my little sister" (ZV 47). Here one should not take "little sister" literally. In the system of certain forms of kinship this word means that the hero's mother belongs to the same family group as the witch. This is even more evident when the hero is married. In this case one says, "My son-in-law (or brother-in-law) has arrived," that is, the witch is the wife's mother or sister, is related to her, belongs to the same tribe. "My brother-in-law has arrived" (ZV 32). "This old woman is your mother-in-law" (Sd. 9). "Ah, she says, you are my nephew" (Sev. 7). "Her brother-in-law has arrived" (K. 7). "She (the princess) is my niece" (K. 9), etc.

彼尔姆童话故事（ZP 1）为我们提供了一个非常有趣的案例。故事中，主人公去寻找失踪的妻子，并遇到了女巫：“你住在哪里？ — 我和祖父一起当了七年学生；他让我娶了他最小的女儿。 ——你真是个傻瓜！你和我哥哥住在一起，你娶了我侄女。”这里伟大的大师被指定为女术士的兄弟。当然，这些只是隐含的线索。如果我们所说的婆婆、阿姨、小妹妹指的是主人公，那么主人公从来没有听说过也不知道他住在森林里的婆婆，这是很奇怪的。但如果我们假设婆婆、姐姐等词已经取代了其他形式的亲属关系，而最终住在小茅屋的英雄最终是根据图腾线而不是根据家庭亲属关系进入了他妻子亲戚的房子，这一事实没有什么可以让我们感到惊讶的；事实上，根据韦伯斯特的观察，我们可以理解为什么他在森林里遇到了他妻子的亲戚，而不是他自己的亲戚。

A very interesting case is provided by a Perm fairy tale (ZP 1). In it the hero goes in search of his missing wife and ends up at the sorceress's: "Where have you been living? — I spent seven years as a pupil at the grandfather's; he married me to his youngest daughter. — What a fool you are! You lived at my brother's, you married my niece." Here the great master is designated as the sorceress's brother. Of course, these are only veiled clues. That the hero has never heard of and knows nothing about his mother-in-law who lives in the forest is very strange if by mother-in-law, aunt, little sister is meant what we mean. But if we assume that the words mother-in-law, sister, etc. have replaced other forms of kinship and that the hero who ends up in the hut ends up at the house of his wife's relatives according to the totemic line and not according to family kinship, there is nothing in this fact that should surprise us; Indeed, in light of Webster's observations, we can understand why he encounters his wife's relatives in the forest and not his own.

所有这些材料都解释了英雄与女巫的亲属关系形式，但仍然没有完全解释为什么女巫是女性。然而，他们认为必须从过去的母系关系中寻找解释。我们在上面看到灌顶是通过妻子的血统来完成的。有一些材料表明，灌顶不仅是通过妻子的亲属关系进行的，而且还通过字面意义上的女性进行：灌顶者暂时变成了女人。另一方面，精神向导也可以被理解为女性，我们很快就会看到。

All these materials explain the forms of kinship between the hero and the sorceress, but they do not yet fully explain why the sorceress is a woman. However, they suggest that the explanation must be sought in the matriarchal relationships of the past. We have seen above that initiation was accomplished through the lineage of the wife. There are some materials indicating that initiation was accomplished through the kinship of the wife, and not only that, but also through a woman in the literal sense of the word: the initiate was temporarily transformed into a woman. On the other hand, the spirit guide can also be understood as a woman, as we will see shortly.

26.异装。

26. Cross-dressing .

我们所比较的材料存在不一致之处。从比较的整个过程中我们看到，由于她的品质和功能的复杂性，在童话故事中女巫应该对应于新手发现自己面前的人物或面具。然而，从引用的材料来看，进行仪式的人似乎并不被认为是一名女性，或者实际上是一名女性。在童话故事中，女巫和森林之主是相互等同的：他们要么把孩子们烧死，要么在锅炉里煮。但当女术士执行此操作或尝试执行此操作失败时，就会引起激烈的斗争。然而，当森林的主人这样做时，他的学生就获得了全知。但女巫也是一个有益的存在，稍后我们将了解她的天赋。童话故事揭示了女巫形象和森林巫师形象之间的密切关系。这种关系有历史原因吗？这个童话故事让人觉得仪式中也出现了一位女性。

There is an inconsistency in the materials we have compared. From the whole process of the comparison it is clear that, for the complex of her qualities and functions, in the fairy tale the sorceress should correspond to the figure or mask before which the initiate finds himself. However, from the materials cited it does not appear that the person who performed the rite was believed to be a woman or actually was one. In the fairy tale the sorceress and the master of the forest are a reciprocal equivalent: both burn or cook the children in the cauldron. But when the sorceress performs this operation or tries in vain to perform it, it causes a fierce fight. When, on the other hand, the master of the forest performs it, his pupil acquires omniscience. But the sorceress is also a beneficent being, and we will later become acquainted with her gifts. Between the image of the sorceress and that of the sorcerer of the forest the fairy tale reveals a kinship. Are there historical causes for this kinship? The fairy tale leads one to think that a woman also figured in the rite.

在大多数情况下，记录或描述这一仪式的旅行者或学者根本没有提及主持该仪式的女性。但在某些情况下，我们看到男性伪装成女性参加仪式。根据其他证词，该协会的所有成员都有一个共同的母亲，一位老妇人。让我们回顾一下与此问题相关的一些案例。内弗曼（Nevermann）这样描述荷属新几内亚马林德-阿尼姆部落的仪式的开始：“男人们伪装成老妇人，穿着妇女的围裙，他们的身体被涂上各种颜色，嘴上长着獠牙，表明他们不应该说话，他们接近了maio-anim（即入会者）。它们将自己缠在“祖先”的脖子上，“祖先”开始将它们拖到一个秘密的地方，在那里它们被扔到地上并假装睡觉” 170。如果这不是森林里老妇人绑架事件的模仿，那么这是什么？我们在神话中也发现了同样的对应关系：捐助者是一位女性。多尔西记录了以下故事：一个人梦见他被要求用粘土蒙住头，爬上一座小山，并在那里呆上四天四夜。第五天，他被老鹰包围了。一只大红鹰说道：“我是一个生活在天堂的女人，我降临在人类中间，赋予他们力量。我会派人给你，你必须把我的笔放在一根魔杖上，这对你来说将是一根魔杖。”一头水牛出现在这个人面前，并给了他进一步的指示：“向你出现的鹰统治着所有的动物。”回国后，他成立了“水牛舞者联盟”，并向他的部落传授水牛的舞蹈和歌曲171。

In most cases, travellers or scholars who have recorded or described this rite do not speak at all of women presiding over it. But in some cases we see that men disguised as women participated in the rite. According to other testimonies, all members of the associations had a common mother, an old woman. Let us review some cases that refer to this question. Nevermann describes the beginning of the rite among the Marind-anim tribe in Dutch New Guinea in the following way: «The men, disguised as old women, with women's aprons, with their bodies painted in various colours, with tusks above their mouths to indicate that they were not to speak, approached the maio-anim (that is, the initiators). The latter clung to the necks of the "progenitors" who began to drag them to a secret place, where they were thrown to the ground and pretended to be asleep» 170 . What is this, if not the mimetic representation of the abduction committed by the old woman in the forest? We find this same correspondence also in the myths: the benefactor-donor is a woman. Dorsey recorded the following story: a man dreams that he is invited to cover his head with clay, to climb a hill and stay there for four days and four nights. On the fifth day he is surrounded by eagles. A great red eagle says: "I am a woman who lives in heaven, I come down among men and give them strength. I will send you someone and you must put my feathers on a wand that will be a magic wand for you." A buffalo appears to the man and gives him further instructions: "The eagle that appeared to you rules over all the animals." Back home he founds "the union of dancing buffaloes" and teaches his tribe the dances and songs of the buffalo . 171

在这个反映萨满技能习得的神话中，值得注意的是，在新手面前出现的动物是女性。

In this myth which reflects the acquisition of shamanic gifts, it is to be noted that the animal which appears to the neophyte is a woman.

在这些生物的女性本质以及女术士的女性本质中，人们可以看到母系关系的反映。这些关系与历史上正在发展的男性权威发生冲突。这次碰撞如何解决？当入会仪式存在时，这一过程必定已经完成：仪式实际上是男性社会接受的一个条件。这场冲突通过多种方式解决：监督仪式的人将自己伪装成女性。他是一个男人女人。从这里我们直线来到伪装成女性的诸神和英雄（赫拉克勒斯、阿喀琉斯）以及许多诸神和英雄的雌雄同体。还有另一种出路：仪式是由男性执行的，但在神秘的远处的某个地方，有一位女性，她是协会成员的母亲。这种形式似乎比其他形式更普遍。让我们举一些例子。 « 部落（新波美拉尼亚）的所有面具都有一个共同的母亲。据信，她生活在戴面具者协会的聚会场所，非入会者从未见过她……据说她病了，患有脓肿，因此无法行走” 172。这位神秘母亲的跛行相当于女巫无法行走。在 Duk-Duk 社会中，最重要的精神被称为 Tubuan。 « 她被认为是所有 Duk-Duk 面具（即所有戴面具的人）的女人和母亲。它最初可能是一种鸟精，但这一事实几乎完全从当地人的意识中消失了» 173。内弗曼还指出，聚会上出现了一些奇怪的人物，“他们同时拥有阴茎和乳房，对于不带偏见的观察者来说，他们看起来就像雌雄同体”。但当地人断然拒绝这种解释，并强调他们始终且只代表男性。”最后，发起者本人有时也被认为是女性。有时她的秘密名字是女性名字174。最高程度的启蒙包括转变为女性的能力175。但是，在这里，我们也发现这种向女性的转变发生在森林中。这是一片被诅咒的森林：男人在那里变成女人，因此避免踏足其中，这是禁林的明显雏形176。

In the female nature of such beings as well as in the female nature of the sorceress one can see a reflection of matriarchal relationships. These relationships collide with the historically developing male authority. How is this collision resolved? When the initiation rite existed, this process must have already been completed: the rite is, in fact, a condition of acceptance into male society. The collision is resolved in various ways: the one who supervises the rite dresses up as a woman. He is a man-woman. From here one arrives in a direct line to the gods and heroes dressed up as women (Heracles, Achilles) as well as to the hermaphroditism of many gods and heroes. There is also another way out: the rite is performed by men, but somewhere, in a mysterious distance, there is a woman, mother of the members of the association. This form seems more widespread than the others. Let us give some examples. « All the masks of the tribe (in New Pomerania) have a common mother. She is believed to live in the meeting place of the mask-wearers' society and the uninitiated never see her... It is said of her that she is ill, that she suffers from abscesses and therefore cannot walk." 172 . The lameness of this mysterious mother corresponds to the inability of the sorceress to walk. In the Duk-Duk society the most important spirit is called Tubuan. "She is believed to be a woman and the mother of all the Duk-Duk masks (that is, of all those who wear masks). She was probably originally a bird-spirit, but this fact has almost completely disappeared from the consciousness of the natives." 173 . Nevermann also reports that strange figures appeared at the festivals "who possessed both the phallus and the breasts and appeared to the unprejudiced observer as hermaphrodites. But the natives categorically reject this interpretation and emphasize that they always and only represent men." Finally, the initiate himself is sometimes considered to be a woman. Sometimes her secret name is a feminine name 174 . The highest degree of initiation includes the ability to transform oneself into a woman 175 . But, here too, we find that this transformation into a female being takes place in the forest. It is a cursed forest: men transform themselves into women there and therefore avoid setting foot there, a clear rudiment, this, of the forbidden forest 176 .

上述材料足以让我们相信，OM Freudenberg 的解释“男女异装代表了性别融合的隐喻：女人变成男人，男人变成女人”，从根本上来说是不准确的177。对我们来说，重要的不是异装癖本身，而是澄清女巫的女性本质以及童话故事中男性对应物的存在的一个因素。森林的主人是历史性的，女人、老妇人、母亲、情妇、魔法品质的赋予者是史前的、极其古老的，但从仪式材料中可以找到她的雏形。女术士是女性，就像西伯利亚萨满通常是女性、雌雄同体或具有女性服装特征的男性一样。这里重要的是注意这个链接，从我们选择引用的少数材料中也可以明显看出这个链接。

The above materials are enough to convince us that OM Freudenberg's interpretation, according to which "the male-female disguise represents a metaphor for sexual fusion: the woman becomes a man, the man becomes a woman", is inaccurate in its root 177 . For us, it is not the transvestism as such that is important, but as a factor that clarifies the female nature of the sorceress and the presence of a male equivalent in the fairy tale. The master of the forest is historical, the woman, old, mother, mistress, giver of magical qualities, is prehistoric, extremely archaic, but from the rudiments she can be found in the ritual materials. The sorceress is a woman for the same reason that the Siberian shaman is often a woman, a hermaphrodite or a man with female clothing attributes. What is important here is to note the connection, and this connection is also evident from the few materials we have chosen to cite.

27.结论。

27. Conclusion .

女巫身材的检查结束了。在我们面前，它已经分解为一系列的特殊性和小的个体特征，现在需要重新组合。

The examination of the figure of the sorceress is finished. Before us it has broken down into a series of particularities and small it-s and single traits that we must now recompose.

但此时我们意识到重组它们是不可能的。试图煮或烤孩子的女巫绑架者和审问并奖励英雄的女巫给予者并不构成一个整体。但与此同时，他们并不是两个完全不同的人物，只是通过名字联系在一起。

But at this point we realize that it is not possible to recompose them. The witch-kidnapper who tries to boil or roast the children and the witch-giver who interrogates and rewards the hero do not constitute a whole. But, at the same time, they are not two completely different figures united only by their names.

本质上，从我们的研究中可以看出，女巫绑架者与启蒙情结有关，移交帮助者的行为也与启蒙情结有关。但女巫的属性以及她的一些行为和感叹也与人类到达死亡王国的表现有关。然而，这两种复合体并不完全相互排斥；相反，它们之间有着非常密切的历史关系。

In essence, it emerges from our examination that the sorceress-kidnapper is connected with the initiation complex, to which the act of handing over the helper is also connected. But the attributes of the sorceress and certain of her actions and exclamations are also connected with the representations of man's arrival in the realm of death. However, these two complexes are not totally exclusive; on the contrary, there is a very close historical relationship between them.

孩子们进入森林的旅程就是他们走向死亡的旅程。这就是为什么森林既是绑架儿童的女巫的家，又是地狱的入口。在森林中进行的行为和实际死亡之间没有特别的区别。但仪式失败了，死亡依然存在。仪式的一部分，发生在入会者身上的事情，随后只会发生在死者身上。这不仅解释了为什么这一边和这一边都有森林，而且还解释了这样一个事实：自古以来，死者都会被煮熟和烘烤，就像发生在起始者身上的事情一样，起始者可以闻到气味，就像一个人一样。到达异世界以后就会闻到。

The children's journey into the forest was the journey toward death. This is why the forest appears both as the home of the sorceress who kidnaps children and as the entrance to Hades. No particular distinction was made between the acts that were performed in the forest and actual death. But the rite ceases, death remains. What was part of the rite, what happened to the initiates, later happens only to the dead. And this explains not only why the forest is found both there and here, but also the fact that since ancient times the dead were cooked and roasted, just as happened to the initiates, and the initiate could smell it, just as he who arrives in the other world will later smell it.

但这还不是全部。随着农业和农业宗教的出现，所有的“森林”宗教都变成了真正的恶魔，伟大的魔法师变成了巫师，动物的母亲和情妇变成了女巫，占有孩子并非象征性地吞噬他们。摧毁仪式的生活水平也摧毁了它的创造者和发起者：烧死孩子的女巫又被寓言作家、童话史诗传统的发起者烧死。这个主题在仪式或信仰中是找不到的，但一旦故事开始独立于仪式而流传，就会出现，表明主题不是在创造仪式的生活水平下创造的，而是在随之而来的生活水平下创造的，他把神圣和可怕变成了英雄喜剧的怪诞。

But that is not all. With the appearance of agriculture and agricultural religion, all "wild" religion is transformed into a veritable devilry, the great magician becomes a sorcerer, the mother and mistress of animals becomes a witch who takes possession of children to devour them non-symbolically. The way of life that destroyed the rite also destroyed its creators and initiators: the witch who burned children is in turn burned by the storyteller, initiator of the epic fairy-tale tradition. This motif is not found in rites or beliefs, but appears as soon as the story begins to circulate independently of the rite, demonstrating that the theme was not created under the way of life that had created the rite, but under the one that succeeded it, and transformed the sacred and the terrible into the grotesque heroic-comic.

第四章 大房子

Chapter Four The Big House

一、森林兄弟情谊

I. The Brotherhood of the Forest

1.森林里的房子。

1. The house in the forest .

女巫绝不是童话故事中唯一的捐赠者，因此我们应该回顾一下其他形式的捐赠者；但既然我们已经开始处理入会仪式，我们将首先遵循与该仪式有关的一切，然后我们将检查其他捐赠者。

The witch is by no means the only donor in the fairy tale, and we should therefore pass in review the other forms of donors; but since we have begun to treat of the rite of initiation, we will first follow all that relates to this rite, and then examine the other donors.

到目前为止我们只考虑了仪式行为。但行为本身只是一个阶段；该仪式还包括与新手回家有关的另一个阶段。

So far we have considered only the ritual act. But the act itself is only a phase; the rite includes another phase connected with the neophyte's homecoming.

在启蒙结束时，在不同的民族和不同的地方，发现了三种不同形式的启蒙阶段的延续或中断：已婚; b ) 他继续在森林里的木头或泥土搭建的小屋里生活了数月，有时甚至数年；c ) 他从森林里的小屋搬到了“男人之家”，住了几年。

At the end of the initiation, three different forms of continuation or interruption of the initiation stage have been found among various peoples and in various places: a ) after his wounds had healed, the initiate immediately returned home or went to the place where he would take a wife; b ) he continued to live in the forest, in a hut, made of wood or earth, for a period that lasted months and sometimes even years; c ) from the hut in the forest he moved for a few years to the "house for men".

在启蒙结束和随后在森林中停留之间不可能划出一条确切的界限：这些现象构成了一个复杂的过程。尽管如此，在没有立即回家的情况下，可以区分两个时刻：真正的开始时刻和随后持续到结婚的时期。现在我们将讨论这一时期以及英雄回归的情况。

It is not possible to draw an exact line between the end of the initiation and the subsequent stay in the forest: these phenomena constitute a complex. Nevertheless, in cases where there was no immediate return home, two moments can be distinguished: the actual moment of initiation and the subsequent period which lasted until the marriage. We will now deal with this period and with the circumstances which accompanied the hero's return.

但首先让我们尝试定义“男人的房子”这个词。男子之家是一种特殊的制度，是氏族制度所特有的。随着建立在奴隶制基础上的国家的兴起，这一制度不复存在。它的起源与作为物质生活基本经济形式的狩猎以及作为其意识形态反映的图腾崇拜有关。在农业发达的地方，这种制度仍然存在，但它开始退化，有时甚至呈现出可怕的形式。男性住宅的功能是多重且不稳定的。无论如何，可以说，在某些情况下，一部分男性人口，特别是从青春期到结婚那一刻的年轻人，不再与父母一起生活在家庭中，而是搬进大房子专门为此目的而建造的，通常称为“男人的房子”。 “男人的房子”或“独身者的情况”。在这里，年轻人生活在一种特殊的社区中。

But first let us define the term "men's house." Men's houses are an institution of a special kind, peculiar to the clan system. With the rise of the slave state this institution ceased to exist. Its origin is connected with hunting, as the basic economic form of material life, and with totemism as its ideological reflection. Where agriculture is developing, this institution still exists, but it begins to degenerate and sometimes takes on monstrous forms. The functions of men's houses are manifold and unstable. In any case it can be said that in certain cases a part of the male population, namely young men from puberty to the time when they contract marriage, no longer live in the family with their parents, but move into large houses built for the purpose, commonly called "men's houses." "men's houses" or "bachelor's case." Here the young men live in communities of a special kind.

一般来说，所有入会者都团结在一个协会中，有自己的名称、自己的面具等。协会的职能也非常广泛和多样。通常它对整个部落拥有有效的权力。男人的房子是协会的会议中心：这里举行舞蹈和仪式，有时还保存面具和部落的其他神圣物品。有时，两栋房子坐落在同一块空地上：一小栋（进行包皮环切术的地方）和一大栋。已婚男子一般不住在那里。

Generally all the initiates are gathered in an association having its own name, its own masks, etc. The functions of the association are also very vast and varied. Often it holds the effective power over the whole tribe. The houses for men are the meeting center of the association: here the dances and ceremonies take place, and sometimes the masks and other sacred things of the tribe are kept. Sometimes on the same clearing there are two houses: a small one (where circumcision is performed) and a large one. Generally married men do not live there.

Frobenius、Boas、Schurtz、Loeb、Van-Gennep、Nevermann 等人的研究为我们提供了男性社团的详细描述，或者用英语术语来说，“秘密社团”（见第三章第 4 段）。

The studies of Frobenius, Boas, Schurtz, Loeb, Van-Gennep, Nevermann and others offer us a detailed picture of male associations or, to use the English terminology, of "secret societies" (see chap. III, § 4).

童话故事保留了极其清晰的男性家庭制度的痕迹。离开房子后，英雄经常会在空地或树林中看到他面前的一座特定类型的建筑物，通常简称为“房子”。

The fairy tale has preserved remarkably clear traces of the institution of houses for men. When leaving his house, the hero often sees before him in a clearing or in the woods a building of a particular kind, which is usually called simply "house."

对这座房子的研究表明，就其整体特征而言，它与前面提到的“男人的房子”相对应。现在让我们继续研究童话故事中的所有特点。

The study of this house shows that, in all its characteristics, it corresponds to the above-mentioned "houses for men". And now let us examine all its peculiarities in the fairy tale.

其中有很多东西让英雄感到震惊。首先是它的大小。 « 走啊走，他们到了森林，却迷路了。他们看到远处有光。他们去了那里：那是一座房子，一座非常大的房子”（Chud.12）。 “看哪，他来到一大片空地，看到一座房子，一座很大、很大的房子，是他从未见过的”（《诗篇》27）。 “一座巨大的房子”（Sev. 47）。 « 他们穿过树林。突然，暴风雨袭来，下起了雨和冰雹。逃，逃，他们发现了一座大房子。天快黑了。一个老者走了出来……“你带你的儿子来教书吗？ ……把他交​​给我，这样我就可以教他，我会教他一切”（ZP 303）。在另一个版本中，这位老人已经五百岁了（ZP 1）。我们可以举出很多例子。大房子与茂密森林结合在一起的奇怪现象并没有阻止寓言作家的脚步，就像迄今为止它还没有阻止学者的关注一样。诚然，这座房子的巨大尺寸和它的宏伟，本身并不能证明任何事情。然而，我们首先要注意的是，这些男人的房子因其令人惊讶的规模而引人注目：它们是巨大的建筑，适合村里所有未婚青年的共处。库克在塔希提岛看到一座两百英尺长的房子。住过简陋的家庭小屋后，这样的房子不能不给人留下深刻的印象。

There are many things in it that strike the hero. First of all, its size. «He walks, he walks, they came to the forest, they got lost. In the distance they saw a light. They went there: it was a house, a very large house» (Chud. 12). «And behold, he comes to a large clearing and sees a house, a large, very large house, the likes of which he has never seen» (Sk. 27). «A large, enormous house» (Sev. 47). «They go through the forest. Suddenly a storm arose and it began to rain and hail. He runs, he runs, they found a huge house. It was getting dark. An old man came out… “Have you brought me your son to be trained? … Give him to me, that I may train him, I will teach him everything” » (ZP 303). In another version this old man is five hundred years old (ZP 1). We could cite many more examples. The strangeness of the combination of the great house with the thicket of the forest does not stop the storyteller, just as it has not stopped the attention of the scholar up to now. It is true that the vast dimensions of the house, its grandeur, prove nothing in themselves. However, let us begin by noting that the houses for men were distinguished precisely by their surprising grandeur: they were enormous constructions, adequate for the cohabitation of all the unmarried youth of the village. In Tahiti Cook saw a house two hundred feet long. After the dwelling in the miserable hovel of the family, such a house could not fail to produce a deep impression.

这所房子的另一个特点是它周围有栅栏。 “宫殿周围有一扇铁门”（Af. 121）。 “这座宫殿四周环绕着高高的铁栅栏：勇敢的年轻人无法步行或骑马进入它”（Af. 116 b）。 “他们在我们周围筑起了很高的栅栏，行人和骑士都无法进入”（Af. 107）。事实上，正如舒尔茨指出的那样178，房子周围有栅栏。部落的圣物被保存在里面，并且禁止妇女和非入会者进入，否则将被处以死刑。房子里还保存着头骨（更多细节请参见弗罗贝尼乌斯），头骨也可以固定在栅栏上。 “宫殿周围有一道至少十俄里高的栅栏，每一栅栏上都有一个头被刺穿”（Af. 125 d）。栅栏保护房子不被任何接近的人看到，否则可能会被当场杀死。有时房子周围有活树篱。 « 当庆祝活动举行时，Duk-Duk 成员会比平时更加​​保护自己免受亵渎，并在taraju （聚会场所）周围筑起高墙，并用垫子覆盖。有时，围栏内会种植活树篱” 179。俄罗斯童话没有保留活树篱，但同样的树篱生长在睡美人周围。故事还保留了进入那个地方的禁令。 « 还有一个花园，被铁栅栏围起来，关着，门也锁着。这是一个禁园，父亲和他的儿子住在那里”（《诗篇》182）。

Another peculiarity of the house is that it is surrounded by a fence. "Around the palace there is an iron gate" (Af. 121). "This palace is surrounded all around by a high iron fence: brave young men cannot enter it, neither on foot nor on horseback" (Af. 116 b). "And all around it they have built a very high fence, neither pedestrians nor horsemen can enter it" (Af. 107). In fact, as Schurtz 178 points out , the house is surrounded by a fence. In it the sacred things of the tribe were kept and access was forbidden, on pain of death, to women and non-initiates. In the house they also kept skulls (for further details see Frobenius) which could also be fixed on the fence. "Around the palace there is a fence at least ten versts high, and on each spike a head is impaled" (Af. 125 d). The fence protected the house from the eyes of those who, approaching, might be killed on the spot. Sometimes the house is surrounded by a living hedge. "When there are festivities, the members of the Duk-Duk are even more than usual on their guard against outsiders and place a high wall around the taraju (meeting place) which is covered with mats. Sometimes inside the fence a living hedge is grown" 179 . The Russian fairy tale has not preserved the living hedge, but this same hedge grows around the Sleeping Beauty; and the tale has also preserved the prohibition on entering that place. "And there was a garden, enclosed with an iron fence, closed, and the doors were locked. It was a forbidden garden, and the father lived there with his son" (Sm. 182).

童话故事甚至给我们带来了对这些房屋的异教宗教功能的某些混乱的回忆：“没有神圣的图像，只有发芽的松果”（Sm.135）。

The tale has even brought to us certain confused reminiscences of the pagan religious functions of these houses: "And there are no sacred images, only pine cones that stick out" (Sm. 135).

这所房子的所有其他特点都可以用远离尘世的愿望来解释。它建在柱子上。 “走，走，他们看到一座柱子上的房子，一座巨大的房子”（Onč.45）。男人的房子通常建在柱子上，里面的居民在高处生活和睡觉。童话般的房子常常以高层建筑的形式呈现，但在这种细节之下很容易发现原始的形态。 “他走近大楼，突然发现自己在楼上”（K.24）。 « 他们开始寻找道路，到达了一片草地；这片空地上矗立着一座三层楼的大石头房子。门关着，百叶窗关着，只有一扇窗户开着，梯子靠在上面”（Af. 118 b）。所以你从楼上通过楼梯进入。 “当他到达宫殿时，他试图进入，但他既没有看到门，也没有窗户，什么也没有，他摸索着寻找一个按钮，当他按下按钮时，门就打开了，他发现自己在宫殿的楼上»（K.12）。在这里，英雄走向上层，避开下层。更清楚的是：“他绕着宫殿转了一圈，那里没有门，也没有楼梯。该怎么办？突然，他看到地上有一根长杆，就把它拿起来，举起来，放在阳台上……然后沿着杆爬”（Af. 122 c）。 « 森林中央有一座大房子，全部用板条围起来……这房子没什么了不起的，但令人惊讶的是旁边建了一个亭子，更妙的是它很高，而且装饰得很好......顶部有一个梯子»（悲伤。17）。例如，在下面的例子中，我们发现了柱子的痕迹：“男孩绕着房子转了一圈，既没有找到门，也没有找到窗户，就想回去。”然后，在一根柱子里，他看到一扇几乎看不见的门，他打开它，走了进去”（Z. St. 346）。这些案例展示了内部是如何被渗透的，并强调了隐藏或掩盖所有开口的谨慎态度。现在，据舒尔茨报道，这里是对安第斯岛上一栋男性房屋的描述：“房子矗立在柱子上，其中一些柱子上雕刻着男性和女性人物的形状。甚至作为到达入口的梯子的横梁也代表了一个拥有巨大阴茎的男人。开口被遮盖起来，这样任何女人都不能看到房子里面……从而不会暴露自己的死亡” 180。安德罗斯群岛的房屋描述如下：“柱子上有一块大木板，有一个通向楼上房间的开口，由四个房间组成：吃饭、睡觉、供应和工作” 181。

All the other features of the house can be explained by the desire to withdraw from the world. It is built on columns. "He walked, he walked, they saw a house on columns, a huge house" (Onč. 45). Houses for men were often built on pillars and their inhabitants lived and slept on high. The house in the fairy tale is often presented as a multi-storey building, but underneath this feature it is easy to discover the original form. "He approached the palace and suddenly found himself on the upper floor" (K. 24).
