"They began to look for the way, they came to a grassy clearing; on this clearing stood a large stone house with three floors; the doors were closed, the shutters were closed, only one window was open and a ladder was leaning against it" (Af. 118 b). So one enters from the upper floor by means of the ladder. « When he reached the palace he tried to enter, but he saw no doors, no windows, there was nothing at all, by feeling he found a button, and as soon as he pressed it the door opened and he found himself upstairs in the palace » (K. 12). Here the hero heads for the upper floor, avoiding the lower one. Even more clearly: « He walked around the palace, there was no door, nor any steps leading up to it anywhere. What was he to do? Suddenly he saw a long pole on the ground, he took it, lifted it, leaned it on the balcony… and climbed up the pole » (Af. 122 c). « In the middle of the forest there was a large house, all fenced with slats… There was nothing wonderful about the house, but what was wonderful was a pavilion built next to it, all the more wonderful because it was tall, and also beautifully decorated… There was a little ladder at the top » (Sad. 17). In the following case, for example, we find traces of columns: "The boy walked around the house, found neither doors nor windows and wanted to go back. Then in a small column he saw a barely visible little door, opened it and entered" (Z. St. 346). These cases show how one penetrates into the interior and underline the care with which all the openings were hidden or masked. And now here, reported by Schurtz, is the description of a house for men on the island of Andes: "The house stands on columns, some of which are carved in the form of male and female figures. Even the beam that serves as a ladder to reach the entrance represents a man with a large phallus. The openings are covered so that no woman can look into the interior of the house... and thus not expose herself to death" 180 . The house in the Andros Islands is described as follows: «A large table rests on the columns, with an opening leading to the upper rooms, consisting of four rooms: for eating, for sleeping, for provisions and for working» 181 .

最后一个例子向我们展示了房子的内部结构：它具有由部门或房间组成的特殊性。童话故事为我们保留了这种结构。 « 那所房子里没有人。他在房间里徘徊”，等等。 （ZP 2）。这是一个典型特征：英雄在大厅和房间里漫步。稍后我们会看到为什么没有人在那里找到我们。童话故事中通常提到房间，这表明主人公在其中看到了一些不寻常和非凡的东西。

This last example shows us the internal structure of the house: it has the peculiarity of consisting of departments or rooms. The fairy tale has preserved precisely this structure for us. "There was no one in that house. He wandered through the rooms", etc. (ZP 2). This is a characteristic feature: the hero wanders through the halls and rooms. Why he finds no one there, we will see later. The fact that the fairy tale regularly mentions rooms indicates that the hero sees something unusual and extraordinary in them.

正如舒尔茨指出的那样，这些房屋经常充当外国人的庇护所。童话故事告诉我们这所房子里有一个“奇怪的房间”，即陌生人的房间（Onč.45）。再次“穿过乌拉尔山脉，他遇到了一栋大房子；这所房子里没有人。他在房间里徘徊……他进入了一个特殊的房间，他躺在沙发上休息”（ZP 2）。

As Schurtz notes, these houses often served as shelters for foreign men. The fairy tale tells us of "a strange room" in this house, that is, a room for foreigners (Onč. 45). And again, "Walking through the Urals he came across a large house; there was no one in this house. He wandered through the rooms….. he entered a special room, lay down on the couch to rest" (ZP 2).

有时这些房屋外观宏伟，装饰有雕刻和绘画。因此，发现它们变成“大理石宫殿”也就不足为奇了。

Sometimes these houses had a grandiose appearance, were decorated with carvings and painted. It is not surprising, therefore, to find them transformed into "marble palaces".

在童话故事中，我们经常看到看守房子的动物，大多是蛇和狮子。我们不会在这里深入探讨这个细节，我们可以在遥远王国的描述中找到这一细节。

In fairy tales we often find animals guarding the house, mostly snakes and lions. We will not delve into this detail here, which we will find again in the description of the distant kingdom.

舒尔茨在他的作品中收集了有关男性家庭的材料。尽管外表不同，但它们却呈现出一些我们在童话故事中看到的典型特征。总而言之，我们可以注意到童话故事中反映的房子的以下特征：a）房子矗立在森林的偏远地方；b ) 因其尺寸而引人注目；c）被栅栏包围（有时有头骨）；d ) 建在柱子上；e ) 您从便携式梯子或柱子进入；f ) 入口和其他开口被覆盖和关闭；g ) 它由一些房间组成。

Schurtz has collected in his work the material concerning the houses for men. Although they are different in appearance, they present some typical features, which we find in the fairy tale. Summing up, we can note the following characteristics of the house, reflected in the fairy tale: a ) the house stands in a remote point of the forest; b ) it is distinguished by its size; c ) it is surrounded by a fence (sometimes with skulls); d ) it is built on columns; e ) it is entered by a portable ladder, or by a column; f ) the entrance and the other openings are covered and closed; g ) it consists of some rooms.

在上面列出的几点中，只有第一点会引起质疑。男人的房子并不矗立在森林深处，或者说并不总是矗立在森林深处。这里发生了某种污染，我们现在要处理。

Of the points listed above, only the first can raise doubts. The men's house did not, or did not always, stand in the depths of the forest. Here a kind of contamination occurred, which we will now deal with.

2.大房子和小小屋。

2. The big house and the little hut .

童话故事不仅提到了森林中的“大房子”，还提到了与女巫及其变种类似的小屋。我们在上文中注意到，入会有时会在一间小屋或森林中的一间小屋中进行，之后入会者返回家人或继续住在同一个地方，甚至搬到男人的大房子里。舒尔茨将这两种类型的建筑称为“割礼之家”和“男子之家”。在童话故事中我们发现了三种情况：我们有立即从树林里的小屋回家，但他们总是孩子或女孩，也有留在森林里直到婚礼。英雄在路上并不总是会遇到“大房子”，但他经常为自己建造一间小屋，或者找到一个已经准备好的小屋，他和他的同伴一起在那里住了很长时间，我们稍后会更详细地看到。这里的索引是非常准确的；让我们补充一点，英雄在树林里建造房屋的例子出现在著名的埃及两兄弟故事中。主人公巴塔前往“雪松谷”。我们有一整套关于这个雪松山谷的参考书目（见维肯特夫），但没有人从我们的角度将它与童话故事中的“森林”进行比较。 « 看哪，过了很多天，他亲手在雪松谷里建造了一座塔。它充满了他自己制作的许多美丽的东西，因此房子里充满了它们” 182。此外，这个童话故事还包含暂时的死亡和复活、异装癖、婚姻等主题。

The fairy tale speaks not only of the "big house" in the forest, but also of a hut like that of the witch and its varieties. We have already noted that the initiation sometimes took place in a hut or a cottage in the forest, after which the neophyte returned to his family or continued to live in the same place, or moved into the big house for men. Schurtz calls these two types of buildings the "circumcision house" and the "house for men." In the fairy tale we find all three cases: we have the immediate return home from the hut in the forest, but it always concerns boys or girls, and there is also the stay in the forest until marriage. The hero does not always meet the "big house" on his way, but often he builds a hut for himself or finds one ready, where he lives for a long time, together with his companions, as we will see in more detail later. Here the concordance is very exact; Let us only add that the hero's construction of a house in the forest is found, for example, in the famous Egyptian tale of the two brothers. The hero, Bata, goes to the "valley of the cedars". There is a whole bibliography on this valley of the cedars (see Vikentev), but no one has ever compared it from our point of view with the "forest" of fairy tales. "And behold, after many days he built with his own hands a tower in the valley of the cedars. It was filled with many beautiful things which he had made himself, so that the house would be filled with them" 182 . Furthermore, this tale contains the motifs of temporary death and resurrection, of cross-dressing, of marriage.

当你从小房子搬到大房子时，情况看起来有点不同。这两栋房子经常坐落在同一块空地上183。甚至童话故事有时也会呈现相同的外部布局：“有一次，他在森林里散步，看到一座又大又漂亮的房子，不远处有一座简陋的小屋”（Sm.78）。童话故事中也有主人公先住在小茅屋，然后又住在大茅屋的情况。在彼尔姆省的一个童话故事中，父母将英雄放逐到旧浴室184，以惩罚他的懒惰。 « 他们把 Vanjucha 搬到了浴室。万尼亚开始到森林里去砍柴：他卖木头，买面包。在森林深处的一块空地上，他发现了一所房子：窗户关着，门也关着”（ZP，第 305 页）。如果这是一个独特的案例，人们可以认为浴室是一个纯粹的现实细节，但我们也在其他系列中找到了类似的例子（Sm.229）。在阿法纳西耶夫的一部童话故事中，英雄住在浴室里。 “格鲁洛人开始进入树林工作，这就是他获取食物的方式。”一个晴朗的日子，他离开道路，看到一座三层大石屋等。 （AF. 118 b）。女孩首先住在峡谷底部的一间小屋里，然后住在强盗的大房子里（悲伤。17）。然而，这些案例数量很少。更正确的说法是，作为一个整体，童话故事并没有记录主人公从小房子搬到大房子的过程：它呈现了其中之一或另一个。这两种结构在童话故事中没有明显的功能差异。童话故事将一般位于村庄或村庄附近的“男人的房子”转移到了森林中，并没有将其与“小屋”区分开来。我们将研究森林房屋的生命，无论它是否可以位于“大”或“小”房子中，但是，正如我们已经说过的，我们将首先研究启动后的时刻，而不是启动的行为在如果。这种生活的特征是森林里有一些勇敢的人共存。

The matter looks somewhat different when one passes from the small house to the large one. Often the two houses stood on the same clearing . 183 The fairy tale also sometimes presents the same external arrangement: "Once, walking in the forest, he saw a large and beautiful house and not far from it a simple hut" (Sm. 78). In the fairy tale there is also the case of the hero who lives first in a small hut, then in a large one. In a tale from the province of Perm the parents relegate the hero to the old bathhouse 184 , to punish him for his laziness. "They moved Vanyucha to the bathhouse. Vanya began to go into the forest to chop wood: he sold the wood and bought himself bread. Far away in the forest he found a house in a clearing: the windows were locked and so was the door" (ZP, p. 305). If this were a unique case, the bath might be considered a purely realistic detail, but in other collections we also encounter similar examples (Sm. 229). In a fairy tale by Afanasiev the hero lives in the bath. "The Simpleton began to go into the forest to work and thus procured food for himself." One fine day he turns off the road and sees a large three-story stone house, etc. (Af. 118b). The girl lives first in a hovel at the bottom of a ravine, then in the large robbers' house (Sad. 17). However, these cases are few in number. It would be more correct to say that the fairy tale as a whole does not record the hero's moving from the small house to the large one: it presents either one or the other. The two types of construction do not have any marked functional differences in the fairy tale. The fairy tale has moved the "man's house" that usually stands in or near the village into the forest, and does not distinguish it from the "little hut." We will examine the life of the forest house independently of whether it can be located in the "big" or the "small" house, but, as we have already said, we will first study the moments following the initiation and not the act of initiation itself. The characteristic sign of this life is the cohabitation of some brave men in the forest.

3.设定表。

3. The table set .

现在让我们看看房子里的居民。主人公在其中找到了一张餐桌：“在一个房间里有一张餐桌，桌子上有十二个餐具，十二条面包和尽可能多的瓶酒”（Af. 121 b，V）。英雄在这里看到了一种与他习惯的不同的用餐方式。在这里，每个人都有自己的部分，所有部分都是平等的。新来的人还没有配给，大家都给了他一点。换句话说，这是一顿社区餐。稍后我们会看到，不仅吃饭，而且生活也是共同发生的。尽管背景略有不同，但俾路支故事中的两种餐桌行为方式形成鲜明对比。 « 当你到达国王的住所时，他们首先会迎接你，然后会给你带来七种不同的菜肴：面包、苹果、肉和其他类似的东西。但不要效仿牧童的习惯，他把盘子里的每一道菜都倒空，不要这样做，而是每道菜都吃一点” 185。在牧童之前居住的村庄里的家庭里，“整个盘子”都被清空了。在非洲材料中，我们可以找到父亲偷偷地从孩子们那里吃东西并且比他们吃得更多的主题：“当孩子们和母亲睡觉时，他吃了所有的凝乳” 186。在树林里的房子里，这是不可能的：我们在这里生活在爱和协议中，这里是兄弟们生活的地方。

Let us now look at the inhabitants of the house. In it the hero finds a table set: "In a room there is a table set, on the table there are twelve place settings, twelve loaves of bread and as many bottles of wine" (Aph. 121 b, V). The hero sees here a way of serving the meal different from the one he is accustomed to. Here everyone has his share and all the shares are equal. The newcomer does not yet have his ration, and everyone gives him a little of theirs. In other words, this is the meal of a community. We will see later that not only the meal, but also life takes place in common. The two ways of behaving at the table are clearly contrasted in a Baluchi fairy tale, although the setting is somewhat different. "When you arrive at the king's house, at first they will greet you, then they will bring you seven different dishes: bread, apples, meat, and other things of the sort. But do not behave according to your habits of a shepherd boy, who empties the plate of every dish, do not do that, but eat a little piece of each one" 185 . In the families, in the village where the shepherd boy had lived until then, they emptied "the whole plate". In African materials one can find the motif of the father who eats in secret from his children and eats more than them: "He ate all the curdled milk, while the children and the mother were sleeping" 186 . In the house in the forest this is not possible: here people live in love and harmony, here brothers live.

4.兄弟们。

4. The brothers .

尽管童话故事的传统是重复每一个动作并避免同时代，但兄弟俩总是一起出现在房子里。

Despite the fairy tale tradition that repeats every action and avoids contemporaneity, the brothers always appear together in the house.

这些弟兄的人数从二人到十二人不等，但最多可达二十五人，甚至三十人（ZP 305）。这个小数字不是与房子的巨大相矛盾吗？这里面是不是有什么矛盾呢？男人的家里可能会有更多的客人：年轻人在那里住了几年，每年（或在其他时期结束时）都有新人到来，而那些到了结婚年龄的人则离开了。

The number of these brothers varies from two to twelve, but there can be as many as twenty-five and even thirty (ZP 305). Does not this small number contradict the vastness of the house? Is there not some inconsistency here? In the houses for men the guests could be more numerous: the young men remained there for a few years, every year (or at the end of other periods) new ones arrived and those who had reached the age to take a wife left.

但首先，正如我们所说，兄弟俩不仅住在“大”房子里，而且还住在一间小小屋里。其次，社区内部存在较小的兄弟会。在某些民族中，那些一起受割礼和入会的人被认为彼此关系特别亲密，几乎就像亲戚一样。在澳大利亚人中，这种关系甚至有自己的特定名称。韦伯斯特还指出，同龄人构成了特定的、受限制的群体。 « 这些兄弟会的成员有一条规定，决不能相互作证，如果他们中的任何一个开始在同伴面前单独吃饭，那将是一种极大的冒犯。这里的大学朋友之间的友谊确实比英国的友谊更牢固。”这个联盟的所有成员都称自己为兄弟187。舒尔茨指出，在这些群体中，甚至可以形成更小的群体，由两个人被迫在战斗中互相保护。因此，我们可以假设童话故事并不反映房子的全部生活，而是反映房子内一群人的生活。

But first, as we have said, the brothers live not only in the "big" house, but also in a small hut. Secondly, within the community there are more restricted brotherhoods. Among certain peoples those who have been circumcised and initiated together are regarded as particularly close to each other and almost like relatives. Among the Australians this relationship even has its own name. Webster also points out that peers form special and restricted groups. "The members of these brotherhoods have as a rule never to testify against one another, and it would be a great offence if any of them were to sit down to eat alone in the presence of his companions. Here the friendship is really stronger than in England between university comrades." All the members of this league call themselves brothers . 187 Schurtz points out that within these groups even smaller groups may form, of two individuals obliged to defend each other in combat. We can therefore assume that the fairy tale does not reflect the whole life of the house, but the life of a group within this house.

5.猎人。

5. The hunters .

当主人公到达房子时，他通常会发现房子空无一人，但有时他会遇到一位老太太，甚至一个女孩。我们稍后会谈论女孩，老年妇女实际上可以进入男人的家，因为她们不再被视为妇女188。兄弟们称老妇人为母亲。下面主人公和老太太的对话解释了为什么家里没人。 « “谁住在这里？ ——十二个人，十二个强盗。 - 他们在哪里？ — 他们去打猎了，很快就会回来“”（ZP 61）。年轻人一起出去打猎，天黑后才回来。男人的房子常常只是人们睡觉的地方，白天却空无一人189。由于兄弟俩做任何事都一致，所以可以合理地假设他们也一起去打猎。这种假设与原始狩猎的形式并不冲突。

When the hero arrives at the house he usually finds it deserted, but sometimes he meets an old woman or even a girl. We will talk about girls later, old women could actually have access to men's houses because they were no longer considered women 188 . The brothers call the old women mothers. The following dialogue between the hero and the old woman explains why there is no one in the house. "Who lives here? — Twelve men, twelve robbers. — Where are they? — They have gone hunting, they will be back soon „ » (ZP 61). The young men have gone out hunting together and only return at nightfall. Often the men's house was only a place where people slept, during the day it was deserted 189 . Since the brothers do everything together, it is reasonable to assume that they also go hunting together; this assumption does not conflict with the forms of primitive hunting.

童话里，一进森林（无论是大房子还是小房子），兄弟俩就立即开始打猎。 “英雄们开始住在那片森林里，并开始捕猎候鸟”（Af. 116 c）。 « 他们在这里定居并建造了一座小屋。然后他们开始捕杀各种鸟类和野生动物，并将羽毛和毛皮收集起来”（Z.St.，359）。男性群体完全靠狩猎为生。年轻人只吃野味，有时被禁止食用农产品。舒尔茨将这个细节与农业是由女性从事的这一事实联系起来。有时会产生原始的狩猎垄断：只有那些加入协会的人才有权狩猎190。在格林童话《十二猎人》中，我们遇到了为国王的餐桌提供猎物的猎人社区之一。同样的事情也出现在俄罗斯童话故事中。 « 在某个王国里，曾经住着一位独身未婚的国王，他拥有一整队的猎人；弓箭手去打猎，射杀候鸟，为领主的餐桌提供猎物”（Af. 122 b）。

In the fairy tale, as soon as the brothers settle in the forest (whether in the big or the small house) they immediately begin to hunt. "The heroes began to live in that forest and began to hunt migratory birds" (Af. 116 c). "And here they settled and made a hut. Then they began to kill all kinds of birds and wild animals, and they gathered the feathers and the hair into a pile" (Z.St., 359). The male community lives exclusively from hunting. The young men eat only game, sometimes they are forbidden to consume agricultural products. Schurtz connects this detail with the fact that agriculture was practiced by women. Sometimes an original hunting monopoly is created: only those initiated into the association have the right to hunt . 190 In Grimm's fairy tale The Twelve Hunters we meet one of these hunting communities who provide game for the king's table. The same thing can be found in the Russian fairy tale. "In a certain kingdom there once lived a celibate king, unmarried, and he had a whole battalion of hunters; the archers went hunting, shot migratory birds, and provided game for the lord's table" (Af. 122 b).

6、强盗。

6. The brigands .

但在童话故事中，这个群体常常也从事另一种职业。这些兄弟都是强盗。在这方面，人们可以考虑对一个古老的主题进行简单的变形，以便将其与后来生活的一种习俗进行比较，更准确地说，与不太古老且更容易理解的抢劫现象进行比较。例如，这就是 Lurjé 191 的想法。不过，森林兄弟的打劫也有它的历史年代。新入会者通常被授予对邻近部落和（更常见的）自己部落进行抢劫的权利。 « 年轻人不再受通常规则和法律的约束，他们有权实施过度行为和暴力，特别是盗窃和勒索食物。在Futa-Djallou，新割礼的人有权在一个月内偷窃和吃任何他们想吃的东西，在Dar-Fui，他们在附近的村庄里闲逛并偷家禽。”这不是一个孤立的现象，而是一种特征。 “新手的力量是如此广泛，以至于他们可以侵占属于非入门者的任何东西” 192。这一授权的含义可能在于这样一个概念：儿童战士和猎人的对立必须发展为反对父系家庭、反对妇女和农业。抢劫是新手的特权，而这正是年轻的英雄。

But in the fairy tale this community often also practices another profession. These brothers are brigands. One might think in this regard of a simple deformation of an ancient motif in order to link it to a later custom of life, and more precisely to the less ancient and more comprehensible phenomenon of brigandage. This is what Lurjé, for example, thinks . 191 However, the brigandage of the forest brothers also has its historical seniority. Often the newly initiated were granted the right to practice brigandage both against the neighboring tribe and (much more frequently) against their own tribe. «The young are no longer subject to the usual norms and laws, they have the right to commit excesses and violence, in particular theft and extortion of food supplies. In Futa-Djallou the newly circumcised are allowed to steal and eat whatever they want for a month, in Dar-Fui they wander through the neighbouring villages and steal poultry. This is not an isolated phenomenon, but a characteristic one. "The power of the neophytes is so extensive that they can appropriate anything belonging to an uninitiated person." 192 The meaning of this authorization probably lies in the idea that in the child-warrior and the hunter it is necessary to develop opposition to the paternal home, to women and to agriculture. Brigandage is the prerogative of the neophyte and such is precisely the young hero.

是否可以将童话故事中的森林强盗与近代的掠夺者进行比较？即使在看起来更加真实精致的图案中，有时也会出现极其古老的特殊性。 « 他穿过城市，192 看到一座两层楼的房子，就进去了。他走进屋子，他们坐在桌旁，喝着伏特加”，等等。英雄要求加入帮派。 “如果你不相信我，请看这里，我手上有标记！……”（ZP 17）。我们已经说过，这个标记是入会仪式的特征：它只不过是纹身。勒布特别探讨了品牌和标志的问题。但还有另一条线索证明了这一主题与入会仪式的联系：土匪兄弟通常以人肉为食。在汤中发现的人骨（ZP 71）中，在被截肢和撕裂的手臂中，在腿中，在头部中，在强盗家里放在桌子上吃的尸体中，等等。我们还残留着食人仪式。

Is it possible to compare the forest robbers in the fairy tale with the thieves of the recent past? Even in the motifs that would seem to be the most realistically elaborated, extremely archaic peculiarities sometimes creep in. "He goes through the city, 192 sees a two-story house, goes into it. He enters the house, they are sitting at the table, drinking vodka", etc. The hero asks to join the gang. "If you don't believe me, look here, on my hands is the mark!..." (ZP 17). That the mark is characteristic of the initiation rite has already been said: it is nothing other than the tattoo. The problem of the mark and the signs has been especially explored by Loeb. But there is another clue proving the connection of this motif with the initiation rite: generally the robber brothers feed on human flesh. In the human bones found in the soup (ZP 71), in the amputated and torn arms, in the legs, in the heads, in the corpses placed on the table to be eaten in the house of the robbers, etc. we have a residue of ritual cannibalism.

7.职责分配。

7. The division of duties .

这个兄弟会有自己非常原始的组织：它有一位选举产生的长老。有时童话里称他为“大哥”。有时，离开家后，兄弟们会扔球或射箭，并选举射得最远的人为长辈。在下面的例子中，与树林里的房子有更清晰的关系：“四个勇敢的人出发了。他们来到了围绕着这个领域的石墙和栅栏。 “谁打破了这些门，谁就是老大哥”（ZV 45）。在楚贾科夫，被交给厨师烤的男孩最终成为铁匠的学徒，最后又成为了老人。 “河里的青蛙在呱呱叫，谁让它们停止叫，谁就成为国王”（Chud.80）。在彼尔姆省的一个童话故事中，我们发现： « 喊道：“回来吧，河流！ “（或“弯腰，森林，朝向潮湿的土地”。显然，最熟练和最强壮的人被选中，他们拥有超越自然的神奇力量。这正是启蒙的方面之一：根据当地人的说法，猎人获得了对元素的力量，特别是对“森林生物”的力量，舒尔茨还提到了我们所指出的情况下的长老选举193。

This brotherhood has a very primitive organization: it has an elder, who is elected. Sometimes the fairy tale calls him "the big brother." Sometimes, after leaving the house, the brothers throw a ball or shoot an arrow, and elect the one who shot the farthest as elder. In the following case we find a clearer connection with the house in the forest: "And the four brave men set out. They come to a stone wall and a fence that surrounds this kingdom. 'Whoever breaks down these gates will be the big brother' " (ZV 45). In Chudjakov the boy handed over to the cook to be roasted ends up as a blacksmith's apprentice and ends up among the elders. "Down in the river the frogs are croaking; whoever stops them from croaking will be king" (Chud. 80). In a fairy tale from the province of Perm we find: "Cry: 'Turn back, river! " (or " bend down, forest, towards the damp earth "). Evidently the most skilled and the strongest is elected, the one who possesses a magical power over nature. This is precisely one of the aspects of the initiation: with it the hunter acquires, according to the natives, power over the elements, and in particular over the "creatures of the forest". Schurtz also mentions the election of the elders in the circumstances we have indicated 193 .

在这个社区里也有一定的职责分工。当兄弟俩打猎时，其中一人准备食物。在童话故事中，兄弟俩总是轮流执行这些任务。 “他们在房子里安顿下来，把杜拜内斯留在那里准备早餐”，等等。 « 谁为你准备糊状食物？ »新来的强盗房子（ZV 52）问道。童话故事并没有保留真实的历史情况，根据该情况，整个新附属团体必须为每个人提供食物并保持房屋秩序194。在美国，新成员必须担任两年的奴隶；在亚洲的某些地方，新加入的较低等级被称为“木材运输者”，并且必须执行这项工作三年195。在俄罗斯和德国的童话故事中，最终进入魔鬼之家的士兵（这个原因相当于和森林一起住在森林里）必须在锅炉下生火一定的年限。鲁杰还强调了这种联系，并引用了瑞士童话故事等内容，其中“男孩们发现自己身处树林里的小小屋里，他们的主要任务是确保壁炉里的火不会熄灭”。196

In this community there is also a certain division of duties. While the brothers are hunting, one of them prepares the food. In the fairy tale the brothers always perform these duties in turn. "They settled down in the house and left Dubynez there to prepare breakfast," etc. "Who prepares the mush for you?" asks the newcomer in the robbers' house (ZV 52). The fairy tale has not preserved the real historical situation, according to which the entire group of new members has to cook for everyone and keep the house in order . 194 In America, new members were required to serve as slaves for a period of two years; in certain places in Asia the lower hierarchy of new members was called "wood carriers" and had to carry out this work for three years . 195 In the Russian and German fairy tale, the soldier who ends up in the devil's house (this motif is equivalent to the stay in the forest with the woodsman) has to feed the fire under the boiler for a certain number of years. Lurjé also highlighted this connection, citing, among others, the Swiss fairy tale in which "the main task of the boys who end up in the little hut in the woods is to ensure that the fire in the hearth does not go out". 196

8.小妹妹。

8. The little sister .

到目前为止，我们所讨论的所有内容都具有配件、舞台、静态的特征，而不是动态和动作的特征。这种动态始于一位女性出现在兄弟会中。

All the things we have spoken of so far have the character of accessories, of staging, of statics and not of dynamics and action. This dynamic begins with the appearance of a woman in the brotherhood.

这里我们不去考察女孩是如何来到树林里的房子里的：她被继母赶走了，或者她被请进了房子，或者被强盗绑架了，等等。在女孩到来的可能形式中，我们将只关注绑架的形式。在阿法纳西耶夫的故事中，两个勇敢的人住在森林里：“一个是盲人，另一个是没有腿的。他们感到无聊，并想到无论在哪里，都想从她父母那里偷一个女孩”（Af. 116 a）。被绑架女孩的情况很不错。 « 巨人们把商人的女儿带到了他们在树林中央的小屋，并对她说：“你将像我们真正的姐妹一样，住在我们的房子里，成为我们的家庭主妇;否则，尽管我们一瘸一拐，却没有人为我们准备午餐、洗衬衫。上帝会因此奖励你！ ” 商人的女儿留在了他们身边，他们爱她，他们认为她是真正的姐妹；他们去打猎，而妹妹总是在家，做所有的家务，准备午餐，洗衣服”（Af. 116 a）。仅这个例子就足以确立“小妹妹”的以下特征：她是被绑架的，或者，在其他版本中，她是自愿来到的，或者是偶然发生的；她做家务，受到兄弟们的尊重；像姐妹一样和她的兄弟们住在一起。

We will not examine here the question of how the girl ends up in the house in the forest: she was chased away by her stepmother, or she was invited into the house, or she was kidnapped by robbers, and so on. Among the possible forms of the girl's arrival, we will dwell only on that of abduction. In a story by Afanasiev, two brave men live in the forest: "One was blind, the other had no legs. They were bored and decided to steal a girl from her father and mother, no matter where" (Af. 116 a). The situation of the kidnapped girl is very dignified. "The giants took the merchant's daughter to their hut in the middle of the forest and said to her: 'You will be like a real sister to us, live in our house, be our housewife; otherwise, crippled as we are, we have no one to cook us dinner, to wash our shirts. God will reward you for this!' "And the merchant's daughter remained with them, they loved her, they considered her a real sister; they went hunting and the sister always stayed at home, she took care of all the chores, prepared the dinner, washed the linen" (Af. 116 a). This example alone is enough to establish the following characteristics of the "little sister": she was kidnapped, or, in other versions, she came of her own free will or happened to be there by chance; she takes care of the household chores and is honored by her brothers; she lives with her brothers like a sister.

这三点中，第三点与历史现实不相符，我稍后会重点讨论，前两点完全是历史性的，甚至在细节上也是如此。

Of these three points, the third does not correspond to historical reality and I will dwell on it later, the first two are completely historical, even in the details.

一方面，男家生活的目的是将男孩与女人隔离开来。整个房子以及里面发生的一切都是禁止女性进入的。这种敌对关系被保留下来，例如，在德国童话故事中：“我们发誓，无论我们在哪里找到女孩，紫色的血液都会流淌”（Grimm，N.9，Lurjé，p.168）。这个案例清楚地反映了对妇女的禁令，但从另一个方面也说明了这一点：它指的是在家庭之外的妇女。

On the one hand, life in the men's house is intended to isolate the boys from the women. The entire house and everything that happens in it is forbidden to women. This hostile relationship has been preserved, for example, in the German fairy tale: "We swear that wherever we find a girl, purple blood will flow" (Grimm, No. 9, Lurjé, p. 168). This case is a clear reflection of the prohibitions concerning women, but it is also clear from another aspect: it refers, namely, to women who are outside the house.

男性的房子禁止女性进入，但这种禁止并不具有相反的价值：在男性的房子里，女性不被禁止。这意味着在男人的家里总是有女人（一个或几个）充当兄弟的妻子。正是这一制度的一个显着特征，舒尔茨甚至谈到了男性人口中存在三类群体：住在纳妾状态下的未受教育的年轻男性，以及生活在规范婚姻状态下的已婚男性。197 .韦伯斯特和舒尔茨的研究中可以找到许多这样的例子。 « 住在男人家里的女孩并没有受到任何蔑视。事实上，父母自己鼓励他们进入……这些房子里通常有一名或多名未婚妇女，她们往往是年轻人的临时财产” 198。舒尔茨说，“在博罗罗人中，为了满足年轻人的性需求，一些女孩被暴力地带到男人家里，在那里她们同时充当一些年轻人的情人并接受他们的礼物” 199。

The men's house is forbidden to women, but this prohibition does not have the reverse effect: in the men's house, women are not forbidden. This means that in the men's houses there were always women (one or several) who served as wives for the brothers. This is such a characteristic feature of this system that Schurtz even speaks of the existence of three groups of the male population: the uninitiated, young men living in the men's houses in a state of concubinage, and married men living in the regular marital state 197 . In the studies of Webster and Schurtz one can find many examples of this. «The girls who lived in the men's houses were not the object of any contempt. Indeed, their parents themselves encouraged them to enter them… In these houses one usually finds one or more unmarried women, who are often the temporary property of the young men» 198 . « Among the Bororo - says Schurtz - to satisfy the sexual needs of the young men, some girls are taken by force to the men's house, there they act as lovers of several young men at the same time and receive gifts from them » 199 .

除了绑架和父母的意愿之外，可能还有其他原因迫使女孩或妇女进入男方家。有时她们会抛弃自己的丈夫，这个原因也在童话故事中有所体现。在彼尔姆地区的一个童话故事中，婚礼后的第一个晚上，流行音乐的女儿用皮带打她的丈夫并说道：“我有一个情人，他的脸只适合擦我们脚上的破布;哈克·哈尔科维奇、索伦·索罗尼奇都比你强！丑陋的丈夫怪物！ ”然后她用丝绸腰带给他穿上衣服就离开了。早上朋友们起床了，新娘却不在。”丈夫去找她，他们告诉他：“她来自哈克·哈尔科维奇，来自索伦·索隆西奇；”房子周围有一道栅栏，每根栅栏上都有一个人的头被刺穿”（ZP 20）。在萨马拉的童话故事中，妻子抛弃了丈夫，走进森林，成为强盗首领，但七年后她悔改并回到了丈夫身边（Sd. 107）。

In addition to abduction and the will of the parents, there could be other reasons that forced girls or women to enter the men's house. Sometimes they had abandoned their husbands, and this reason is also reflected in the fairy tale. In a fairy tale from the Perm region, on the first night after the wedding, the pope 's daughter beats her husband with her belt and says: "I have a lover with a face that is only good for wiping our footcloths; Chark Kharkovič, Solon Solonyč is better than you! You ugly monster of a husband!" Then she dressed him up with her silk belt and went away. In the morning the friends get up, but the bride is not there. " The husband goes in search of her and they tell him: "She is at Chark Kharkovič's, at Solon Solontsč's; there is a fence around the house, on every post there is a man's head stuck" (ZP 20). In a Samara fairy tale the wife abandons her husband, goes into the forest and becomes a robber chief, but after seven years she repents and returns to her husband (Sd. 107).

“小妹妹”的光荣处境，以及她必须履行的家务，完全是历史性的。弗雷泽对住在皮利群岛男子家里的女孩说了以下的话：在服务期间，她必须照顾房子的清洁和火灾。男人们对她很好，不会用暴力强迫她答应他们的恩惠200。女孩住在房子旁边的一个单独的房间里。它受到侠义对待。没有一个年轻人敢进他的房间。给她提供了丰富的食物，年轻人也给她提供了奢侈品，给她带来槟榔和烟草。

The honorable position of the "little sister," as well as the domestic duties which she has to perform, are entirely historical. Frazer says the following about the girls who live in the men's houses on the Pelée Islands: while she is in service she has to look after the cleanliness of the house and the fire. The men treat her well and do not force her to grant her favors by force . 200 The girl lives in a separate room adjoining the house. She is treated chivalrously. None of the young men dare enter her room. She is provided with plentiful food, and the young men also procure for her luxury goods, bring her betel nuts and tobacco.

在这一点上，我想提请大家注意另一个细节，这对于解释丘比特和普赛克等童话故事似乎至关重要：膳食是在一个单独的房间里提供的，这样就没有人看到它。稍后我们将不得不详细讨论这一点。女性只在家里呆一段时间，然后就结婚了。如果一个女人愿意一辈子呆在那里，她就不会再受到尊重。

At this point I would like to draw attention to another detail, which seems essential to the explanation of fairy tales such as Cupid and Psyche : the meal is served in such a way that she does not see anyone, it is served in a separate room. We will have to dwell on this point at length later. Women spend only a certain time in homes, then they get married. If a woman preferred to remain there all her life, she would no longer be respected.

从这些材料中我们可以看出，住在男家的女孩根本不是兄弟俩的“小妹妹”。在讨论一个或几个女人与一群男人的婚姻关系的表达形式问题之前，我们先看看童话中的小妹妹是否总是“小妹妹”。

From all these materials it is clear that the girl who lives in the men's house is not at all the "little sister" of the brothers. Before we turn to the problem of the forms in which the conjugal relations of one or more women with the group of men are expressed, let us see whether in the fairy tale the little sister is always only a "little sister."

首先，童话断然否认婚姻关系的存在，这已经足以让我们产生怀疑。我们在童话《镜仙》中读到：“大家看了她，都想娶她为妻；大家看了她，都想娶她为妻；但由于无法达成一致，他们就把她当作妹妹收进了家里，并极大地尊重了她”（Af. 121 a）。在另一个版本中：“如果有人胆敢对他的妹妹下手，他将被毫不留情地用这把军刀砍成碎片”（Af. 121 b）。在这里，这个故事稍微改变了兄弟关系和婚姻关系的分界线。这在维亚特卡童话故事中得到了证实：被赶出家门的继女最终和两个强盗一起进入了森林。他们出去了。 « 他们给她留下了各种食物和各种衣服：“这都是给你的，吃喝，用最好的衣服装饰自己！……”小女孩和他们一起生了一个儿子 » (ZV 116 ）。和他们在一起，而不是只和他们中的一个人在一起。我们稍后再讨论宝宝的事。在一个白俄罗斯童话故事中我们读到：“从前有一个国王和一个王后，他们有一个非常漂亮的女儿，十二个追求者向她求婚，而这些追求者都是强盗”（Af. 200） ）。在这里，十二位新郎而不是一位新郎同时向一位女孩求婚。我们也承认，这些始终是个体特征、个体案例，但这些案例表明，在排除和谴责一妻多夫的后来婚姻形式的影响下，上述限制发生转变的可能性。在法律没有规定配对婚姻的地方，我们的案例以更清晰的形式表达。在蒙古童话中，七个小王子去小树林（沉思森林）“驱除无聊”。在那里，他们遇到了一位美丽非凡的女孩。 « “听听我们的建议。我们是七兄弟，都是国王的儿子，到目前为止我们还没有妻子。做我们的妃子吧！ “女孩同意了，他们住在一起” 201。

First of all, the fairy tale flatly denies the existence of marital relations, and this alone would be enough to make us suspicious. In the fairy tale The Magic Mirror we read: "After looking at her, each one wanted to marry her; but since they could not agree, they took her into their home as a sister and honored her greatly" (Af. 121 a). And in another version: "If anyone dares to lay hands on the little sister, he will be cut to pieces without mercy, with this same sword" (Af. 121 b). Here the tale has slightly shifted the line of demarcation between fraternal and marital relations. This is confirmed in a fairy tale from Vyatka: the stepdaughter, driven out of the house, ends up in the forest with two robbers. They leave. « And they left her all kinds of food and all kinds of clothing: “It is all for you, eat and drink, and adorn yourself with your best clothes!… „ And the little girl bore a son with them » (ZV 116). With them and not with just one of them. We will speak about the child later. In a White Russian fairy tale we read: « Once upon a time there was a king and a queen, they had a very beautiful daughter and she was asked in marriage by twelve suitors, and those suitors were all robbers » (Af. 200). Here a girl is asked in marriage by twelve grooms at the same time and not by just one. Let us admit that these are always individual traits, individual cases, but these cases show the probability of the above-mentioned shifting of the limits under the influence of later forms of marriage that excluded and condemned polyandry. Where marriage in pairs was not the law, our case is expressed in a much clearer form. In a Mongolian fairy tale, seven little princes go into the grove (a rudiment of the forest) to "drive away boredom." There they meet a girl of extraordinary beauty. "Listen to what we propose to you. We are seven brothers, sons of kings, and up to now we have no wife. Be our consort!" The girl agreed and they lived together . 201

除此之外，必须指出的是，不仅有男人的房子，也可能有女人的房子。在这项研究中不可能深入探讨妇女家庭的问题，仅提及这一事实就足够了。舒尔茨认为，这是后来的现象，是对男人房屋的模仿。在彼尔姆童话故事中，三兄弟环游世界，正如女孩最终进入了男人的房子一样，他们最终也进入了女人居住的房子。 « 突然他们发现自己站在一座美丽的房子前面。他们进入这所房子，他们打开门，他们进入宫殿......他们找到白面包，他们找到各种食物。”三个女孩进入房子并了解到以下内容：“今天房子里发生了抢劫，出现了三个年轻人。这三个人当中，有一个非常漂亮。”女孩们向英雄们提问，然后说：“叫我们妻子，我们就叫你们丈夫；”我们会睡在一起，但如果我们说脏话，我们就会遭殃！如果有人说坏话，我们不会把你留在这里，我们会把你赶走！ »（ZP 23）。

It is also important to note that there were not only houses for men, but there could also be houses for women. In this study it is not possible to go into the problem of houses for women, it is enough to mention the fact. Schurtz believes that this is a later phenomenon, an imitation of houses for men. In the Perm fairy tale three brothers wander through the world and just as the girl ends up in a house for men, they end up in a house inhabited by women. "Suddenly they find themselves in front of a beautiful house. They enter this house, they open the door, they penetrate the palace... They find white bread, they find food of all kinds." Three girls enter the house and learn the following: "Today there was a robbery in the house, three young men appeared. Of those three, one was very handsome." The girls question the heroes, then say: "Call us wives and we will call you husbands; we will sleep together but woe betide anyone who speaks ill of us!" If anyone speaks badly, we will not keep you here, we will chase you away! " (ZP 23).

因此我们看到，在童话故事中，性关系并没有完全被兄弟关系所取代。

We see therefore that in the fairy tale sexual relations are not completely supplanted by fraternal ones.

男人家里的婚姻关系有哪些形式？关于这个问题的材料非常稀缺。无论如何，可以注意到这些关系并非无处不在，也不总是相同。妇女可以根据自己的选择或兄弟之一的选择，属于所有人，或属于某些人，或仅属于一个人。它们“是年轻人的临时财产” 202。早期，他们的服务得到了补偿，包括戒指或其他个人使用的物品，或者是兄弟的箭，后来才支付工资。这种集体婚姻往往以个人婚姻结束。 « 她选择一个伴侣或情人，名义上她是情妇；他负责必须收取的工资或补偿；但在某些条件下，她也可以自由地与其他男人结合。”在这种情况下，主动权来自于女性。但也可以从人开始。 « 当女孩服役时，男人有权向女孩求婚，与他结合，这种情况经常发生。如果他的求婚被接受，他会为他的妻子支付兄弟会一定的费用。然而，更常见的是，女孩在服务期结束返回村庄时结婚” 203。

What are the forms of marital relations in men's houses? The materials on this question are very scarce. In any case it can be noted that the relations were not everywhere nor always identical. The women could belong to all, or to some, or to one alone, by their own choice or by the choice of one of the brothers. They "were the temporary property of the young men" 202 . Their services were compensated in the early days with rings or other objects of personal use, or with arrows for the brothers; later a salary was paid. This collective marriage tends to conclude with an individual marriage. "She chooses a companion or a lover of whom she is nominally the lady; he is responsible for the pay or the compensation that she must collect; but under certain conditions she is free to unite with other men as well." In this case the initiative comes from the woman. But it can also come from the man. "The man has the right to propose to the girl, while she is in service, to unite with him, and this happens often. If his proposal is accepted, he pays the brotherhood a certain sum for the wife. More often, however, the girls get married at the end of their period of service, when they return to their village" 203 .

童话故事并没有反映所有这些可能性：一般来说，女孩不属于任何人，或者她属于所有人，但在某些非常罕见的情况下，可以发现她只属于兄弟中的一个。在楚贾科夫（Chudjakov）（34岁）中，女孩嫁给了最晚到来的人。英雄最终进了强盗的房子。 « 你为什么想回家，蒂蒙贾？留在我们身边，我们会娶你，我们会给你我们的妹妹。”在其他情况下，它属于该团伙的头目，他与头目交换十字架。

The fairy tale does not reflect all these possibilities: usually the girl belongs to no one, or to all of them, but in some rather rare cases it can be seen that she belongs to only one of the brothers. In Chudjakov (34) the girl is given in marriage to the last one to arrive. The hero ends up in the house of the robbers. "Why do you want to go back to your home, Timonja? Stay with us, we will marry you, we will give you our sister." In other cases she belongs to the leader of the gang, with whom she exchanges the cross.

俄罗斯童话没有反映她收到的礼物，但此类案例可以在国际材料中收集204。

The Russian fairy tale does not reflect the gifts she receives, but such cases can be collected in international material 204 .

但另一方面，童话却反映出另一种现象：婚姻向个体结合的趋势，以及孩子在这一趋势中所扮演的角色。

On the other hand, however, the fairy tale reflects another phenomenon: the tendency of this marriage to transform into an individual union and the part that children play in this tendency.

9.孩子的出生。

9. The birth of the child .

显然，孩子就是在这种同居中诞生的。各地对孩子的态度也不尽相同。 “这种结合所生的孩子几乎总是被杀害” 205。可以合理地假设，这种情况发生在妇女是共同财产的情况下。但如果两个人的结合已经是在乱交的背景下产生的，父子关系是可以知道的，那么关系也可能会有所不同。 “在许多情况下，孩子并不被认为是不需要的，而是构成了将自由恋爱关系转变为稳定婚姻的动机” 206。

That children were born from such cohabitation is evident. The attitude towards children was not the same everywhere. "Children born from such unions were almost always killed" 205 . It is reasonable to suppose that this occurred in cases where the woman was common property. But where the union of two individuals had already arisen on the basis of promiscuity, where paternity could be known, the relationships could also be different. "In many cases the child was not considered unwanted, but constituted a motive for transforming a free love relationship into a stable marriage" 206 .

童话故事里有孩子出生时出现的并发症的痕迹。在彼尔姆童话故事（ZP 13）中，英雄通过一条穿过森林的小路来到“房子”（“这里是一座房子”）。这所房子里住着一位女战士：“我迷路了，你不想带我到你家做丈夫吗？” » 她同意与他住在一起，并保留他作为她的丈夫，同年他们生了一个儿子。妻子说：“现在，费多尔·布尔马金，你应该像在自己家里一样生活，因为你和我都有了孩子。”但费多尔准备逃跑。他的妻子去“进行屠杀”，而他则乘木筏逃走。 « 孩子开始大声尖叫，在森林里引起回响。她听到婴儿的尖叫声，赶紧回家。他跑过来，抓住孩子，跑到海边，抓住孩子的腿，把他摔成两半。她把这块扔掉，扔给费多尔，他的木筏开始下沉。费多尽其所能地拒绝了这块碎片并继续他的旅程，而她吃了手中剩下的一半。”要素很明确：森林里的房子，这所房子里的同居，孩子的出生，女人希望将结合转变为稳定的婚姻，杀死孩子（被吃掉），尸体被用作让费多回来以及他离开的手段。在上述案例中，丈夫设法逃离了妻子。我们在俄罗斯北部的童话故事中也发现了类似的情况，但这一次是双胞胎出生，之后英雄逃跑了。经过几次冒险之后，他回到家中，发现了他的妻子，她跟着他来到了他在树林里的房子。孩子正是爱情关系转变为婚姻关系的动力（Onč.85）。在上述案例中，与“大房子”的联系是显而易见的。然而，我们看到童话故事并没有整体承认发生在森林小屋里的婚姻。对于童话故事来说，女人只是一个“小妹妹”。可能童话故事中这个角色的某些特征已经转移到了另一个角色，即公主身上。如果是这样的话，水的故事中的公主，生命的公主，也是我们所讨论的现象组的一部分。在其中，英雄与公主一起犯罪，她带着两个孩子去寻找她的丈夫，她找到了他，“他们在婚姻中合法地结合在一起”（Af. 104 h）。不过，这个问题只有在研究了公主的身材后才能最终解决。

In fairy tales, traces of the complications that arise from the birth of a child can be found. In a Perm fairy tale (ZP 13), the hero comes to the "house" by a path through the forest ("And Here Is a House"). In this house lives a warrior heroine: "I have lost my way, won't you take me into your house as a husband?" She agrees to live with him and even to keep him as a husband, and that same year they have a child. His wife says: "Now, Fedor Burmakin, live as is proper, as in your own house, since you and I have a child." But Fedor is preparing to escape. His wife goes off "to make a massacre," and he escapes on a raft. "The child began to scream so loudly that it made the forest resound. She heard the child screaming and hurried home. She came running, grabbed the child, ran to the seashore, took the child by the leg and tore him in two. She threw this piece away, threw it to Fyodor, and her raft began to sink. As best he could, Fyodor pushed this piece away and continued on his journey, and she ate the half that remained in her hand. The elements are clear: the house in the forest, living together in this house, the birth of the child, the woman's desire to convert the union into a stable marriage, the killing of the child (who is eaten), the corpse used as a means to bring Fyodor back, and his departure. In the above-mentioned case the husband manages to escape from his wife. A similar case can be found in a fairy tale from northern Russia, but this time twins are born, after which the hero runs away. After several adventures he returns home and finds his wife, who follows him to his house in the forest. The children are precisely the motive for transforming the love affair into marriage (Onč. 85). In the above-mentioned cases the connection with the "big house" is evident. However, we see that the fairy tale does not recognize the marriage that took place in the house in the forest. In the fairy tale, the woman is only a "little sister." It may be that in the fairy tale some features of this character have been transferred to another character, namely the princess. If this is so, the group of phenomena we have discussed also includes the princess in the tale of the Water of Life . In it, the hero sins with the princess and she takes her two children and goes in search of her husband, finds him "and they were united in lawful marriage" (Af. 104 h). However, the problem can be definitively resolved only after having studied the figure of the princess.

10.棺材里的美女。

10. Beauty in the coffin .

从我们所说的情况来看，很明显，女性只在男性家里度过一段时间。经过或多或少的长期停留后，他们离开并与其中一位“兄弟”或更常见的是与来自他们村庄的一名男子缔结了婚姻。从历史上看，此时应该出现并发症。男方家里所做的一切对女方都是保密的。这里保存着部落的神圣物品，举行仪式舞蹈等。但对于“小姐妹”来说，没有什么秘密。可以让他们离开吗？ « 他们（即单身汉家里的年轻女性）被允许观看和聆听其他女性无法目睹的歌曲和舞蹈» 207。

From what we have said it is already clear that women spent only a certain period of time in the men's houses. After a more or less long stay they left and married one of their "brothers" or, more often, a man from their village. At this point, historically, a complication should have occurred. Everything that was done in the men's house was kept secret from the women; the sacred things of the tribe were kept there, ritual dances were performed, etc. But for the "little sisters" there were no secrets. Could they be allowed to leave without further ado? "They (that is, the young women who are in the bachelors' house) are allowed to see and hear the songs and dances, which the other women are not allowed to attend . " 207

在童话故事中，与圣骑士一起生活在森林中的女孩有时会突然死亡；然后，在死了一段时间后，她又活了过来，并嫁给了小王子。正如我们所看到的，暂时的死亡是入会仪式的特征和持续标志之一。我们可以假设这个女孩在被逐出房子之前接受了入会仪式，我们可以猜测原因：入会保证了房子的秘密将被保存。在这里，童话故事只稍微改变了内部事件的顺序，但没有改变外部事件的顺序。在童话故事中，女孩突然死了，就像突然重生并结婚一样：唯一非历史的事情就是突然性。事实上，正是在她离开家成为新娘的那一刻，才引发了启蒙的需要，即死亡和复活。

In the fairy tale the girl who is with the paladins in the forest sometimes dies suddenly; then, after being dead for a certain time, she comes to life again and marries the young prince. As we have seen, temporary death is one of the characteristic and constant signs of the initiation rite. We can suppose that the girl was subjected to the initiation rite before being dismissed from the house, and we can guess the reasons: the initiation guaranteed that the secrets of the house would be preserved. Here the fairy tale has only slightly changed the internal succession, but not the external succession of events. In the fairy tale the girl dies suddenly and just as suddenly comes to life again and marries: the only thing that is unhistorical is the suddenness. In fact, the moment in which she left the house to marry was precisely that which caused the need for initiation, that is, for death and resurrection.

我们上面谈到了暂时的死亡（III，20）。这里的问题是建立与我们的童话相关的死亡的外部形式。

We have spoken of temporary death above (III, 20). Here we are concerned with establishing the external forms of this death which are related to our fairy tale.

为什么像《魔镜》这样的童话故事里的女孩会死？在 Bolte-Polivka 中发现的材料使我们能够确定导致女孩死亡的三组物体。第一种是由插入皮肤下的物体组成：针、荆棘、碎片，这可以包括插入头发的发夹和梳子。第二组包括摄入的物体：有毒的苹果、梨、葡萄或更罕见的饮料。第三组由穿戴的物品组成：衣服，例如衬衫、连衣裙、袜子、鞋子、皮带，甚至装饰品、戒指、项链、耳环。最后，我们还有女孩变成动物或鸟，然后又变成人类的情况。起死回生的手段很简单：只要从皮肤上拔出针或发夹，摇晃尸体，让毒液出来，脱掉衬衫、戒指等即可。

Why does the girl die in fairy tales like The Magic Mirror ? The materials found in the Bolte-Polivka allow us to identify three groups of objects that cause the girl's death. The first consists of objects that are inserted under the skin: needles, thorns, splinters, and we can include hairpins and combs inserted into the hair. The second group includes ingested objects: poisoned apples, pears, grapes or, more rarely, drinks. The third group consists of objects that are worn: items of clothing such as shirts, dresses, stockings, shoes, belts, or even decorative objects, rings, necklaces, earrings. Finally, we have cases in which the girl transforms into an animal or a bird and then becomes a human again. The means used to bring her back to life are very simple: just remove the needle or hairpin from the skin, just shake the corpse so that the poison comes out, just remove the shirt, the ring, etc.

在入会仪式中造成暂时死亡的程序中，也有上述的那些。其中之一涉及将锋利的物体插入皮肤下。 « 仪式的主要部分是让起始者死亡，从而获得伟大的魔法美德。死亡是通过虚构或神奇地将神圣贝壳引入新手体内而获得的，然后新手通过唱歌复活» 208。这些炮弹射入了新手的体内。对于学者或公正的观察者来说，这场杀戮似乎是“虚构的”或“神奇的”，但对于新手来说却并非如此，他们认为自己真正被杀并复活了。上述案例也不例外。众所周知，几乎全世界的疾病都是由于体内存在异物而导致的，而治愈方法就是由巫师取出异物。在我们的例子中，死亡和复活都归因于这些相同的原因。

Among the procedures used to produce temporary death during the rite of initiation, there are also those mentioned above. One of them consisted in introducing sharp objects under the skin. "The principal part of the ceremony consisted in causing the initiate to die, who thus acquired great magical virtue. Death was obtained by the fictitious or magical introduction of sacred shells into the body of the neophytes, who were then resurrected by means of chants." 208 These shells were shot into the body of the neophytes. The killing appears "fictitious" or "magical" to the scholar or the disinterested observer, but it was not so to the neophyte, who considered himself really killed and resurrected. The above case is not an exception. It is universally known that in almost all the world the disease is attributed to the presence of a foreign object in the body and the cure consists in the extraction of this object by a sorcerer. In our case, death and the return to life are attributed to these same causes.

另一种造成暂时死亡的方法是投毒，这种方法被广泛采用。年轻人愣住了，失去了知觉，过了好一会儿才回过神来，又复活了。例如，在刚果下游，一位祭司兼魔术师接管了入会的指导。他和他的学生一起去了森林，并在那里度过了一段时间。使用麻醉剂，年轻人被催眠并被宣布死亡209。我们不谈论有毒的水果。显然，毒药总是以饮料的形式施用，就像童话故事中一样，然而，饮料的作用通常也转移到水果上。

Another way of causing temporary death was poisoning, which was widely practiced. The young people fell unconscious, lost consciousness, and after a while came to their senses and were resurrected. Thus, for example, in the lower Congo a priest-magician takes charge of the initiation. He goes into the forest with his pupils and spends some time there. By means of a narcotic the young people are put to sleep and pronounced dead . 209 Poisoned fruit is not mentioned. The poison was apparently always administered in the form of a drink, as is also the case in fairy tales, where, however, the effect of the drink is often transferred to the fruit as well.

最后，当女孩穿上衬衫，系上腰带，或者戴上项链等。它部分是关于后来的童话现象，部分是关于葬礼厕所。入会者被迫穿上死者的长袍210，之后他们被认为已经死亡。在不知道穿什么衣服的地方，入会者会被涂上泥土，这意味着他已经死了。为女孩穿的衬衫是死亡的礼服。在萨马拉的童话故事中，女孩被送去“一件死亡衬衫”。女孩“认为最好试穿这件衬衫。”他穿上它，躺下就死了”（《诗篇》17）。

Finally, when the girl wears shirts, belts, or puts on a necklace, etc., it is partly a later, fairy-tale phenomenon, and partly a funeral toilette. The initiates were made to wear the clothes of the dead 210 , after which they were considered dead. In places where the clothing was not known, the initiate was smeared with clay, and this meant that he was dead. The shirt made to wear the girl is the dress of death. In a Samara fairy tale the girl is sent "a shirt for death." The girl "thought it a good idea to try on the shirt. She put it on, lay down and died" (Sd. 17).

显然，棺材是最新的特征。但棺材的起源和演变大体上是可以追溯的。棺材的前身是动物形状的木箱，许多地方都证实了它的存在。例如，舒尔茨谈到带有代表鲨鱼的木制人物的房屋，其中保存着领导人的尸体。这是棺材最古老的形式，这反过来又反映了更原始的表现，根据这种表现，人死后会变成动物或被动物吞噬。随着时间的推移，棺材失去了其动物属性。因此，在《埃及亡灵书》中，我们可以看到石棺或放置木乃伊的底座的代表；它们有动物的腿、头和尾巴。后来，动物属性完全消失，棺材呈现出我们所知道的形状。从这个角度来看，女孩向动物的转变，反之亦然，即她向人类的转变，她被放入棺材中并被活着取出，是同一顺序的现象，但形式不同在不同的时间。

The coffin, of course, is the most recent feature. But the origin and development of the coffin in general can be traced. The predecessors of the coffin are the wooden cases in the form of animals, the existence of which has been ascertained in many places. Schurtz, for example, speaks of houses with wooden figures representing sharks, in which the corpses of the chiefs were kept. This is the oldest form of the coffin, which in turn reflects more primitive representations according to which, at the moment of death, a man would transform into an animal or be devoured by an animal. In the course of time the coffin loses its animal attributes. Thus, in the Egyptian Book of the Dead one can see representations of sarcophagi or pedestals on which the mummy is placed; they have the legs, head and tail of an animal. Later the animal attributes disappear altogether and the coffin takes on the forms known to us. From this point of view, the transformation of the girl into an animal and vice versa, that is, her transformation into a human creature, her deposition in the coffin from which she is extracted alive, are phenomena of the same order, but in different forms depending on the era.

为什么棺材多用玻璃制成？这个问题只能通过将其与“水晶山”、“玻璃山”、“玻璃屋”以及水晶、石英和后来的玻璃在宗教表征中的所有重要性重新联系起来来回答。中世纪及其后时代的魔法水晶。水晶具有特殊的魔法属性，它在入会仪式中具有一定的作用，水晶棺只是更普遍现象的一个特例（见第八章第8节）。

Why is the coffin often made of glass? This question can only be answered by connecting it with the study of the "crystal mountain", the "glass mountain", the "glass house" and all the importance that crystal, quartz and later glass had in religious representations, ending with the magic crystals of the Middle Ages and later times. Crystal was attributed special magical properties, it played a certain role in initiation rites and the crystal coffin is only a particular case of a more general phenomenon (see chap. VIII, § 8).

此时可能会出现另一个问题：为什么棺材里只放了一个女孩？因为童话里没有保存荆棘等的介绍。在年轻人的身体里？但这并不完全准确。在某些情况下，玻璃棺材中装有年轻男子的尸体（Z. St. 339）。 “睡美人”可以与“沉睡的青少年”（Sm. 56）进行对比。毕竟，即使是前往水灵的年轻英雄也“用白衬衫装饰自己，就好像他想让自己在死亡时变得美丽一样”（ZP 8）。但无论如何，我们都面临着一种女性特有的暂时死亡的趋势。民族志材料中没有这种区分的来源。我们必须将这些形式视为童话传统的一种现象，只有对这一主题进行专门研究才能找到其起源和原因。

At this point another question may arise: why is only a girl placed in the coffin? Why has the fairy tale not preserved the introduction of thorns, etc., into the body of the youths? But this is not entirely correct. In some cases the glass coffin contains the body of a young man (Z. St. 339). To the "Sleeping Beauty" one can contrast "sleeping youths" (Sm. 56). After all, even the young hero who went to the Water Spirit "adorned himself with a white shirt, just as if he wanted to make himself beautiful for death" (ZP 8). But, in any case, we are faced with a tendency towards specifically feminine forms of temporary death. In ethnographic materials there are no sources for such a differentiation. We must regard these forms as a phenomenon of fairy-tale tradition, the origin and cause of which can be found only by a special study of this subject.

11.丘比特和普赛克。

11. Love and Psyche .

我们讨论的整组现象非常复杂，毫无疑问，并不是所有的联系都已经被强调；并非一切都已被发现和发现。另一方面，某些类比很可能被证明是错误的。

The whole group of phenomena that we have discussed is very complex, and, undoubtedly, not all the connections have already been brought to light; not everything has been discovered and rediscovered. On the other hand, it is very possible that certain analogies may prove false.

因此，例如，可以提出丘比特和普赛克故事的某些元素与我们正在处理的一组现象之间的联系问题。

Thus, for example, the question can be posed of the connection between certain elements of the tale of Cupid and Psyche and the group of phenomena with which we are dealing.

普赛克在哪里，她与爱的婚姻生活在哪里发生？配件是已知的：宫殿和花园。但俄罗斯民间故事中的普赛克住在森林小屋里，是十二兄弟之一的妻子。在俄罗斯北部的童话故事中，房子的女主人是一位老妇人。女孩回到家，老妇人邀请她躺在窗帘后面。 « 突然我们听到一声枪响、一声雷鸣，十二个年轻人走了进来。老妇人对十二弟说：“别吃饭了，有新娘子要给你。”他和外国女孩（Onč.178，丘比特和普赛克类型）睡觉。当然，有人可以反驳说，这一案件证明不了什么，这里发生了与十二强盗主题的同化。问题也可以这样提出。但另一种方法是可以接受的：普赛克与丘比特的婚姻难道不反映了与“兄弟”的临时婚姻现象，但其他兄弟被省略，临时一妻多夫婚姻被呈现为最近的结合吗？这个猜想被一系列的观察所证实。

Where is Psyche, where does her married life with Cupid take place? The accessories are well known: the palace and the garden. But the Psyche of Russian folk tales lives in the house in the forest and is the wife of one of the twelve brothers. In the fairy tale of northern Russia, the mistress of the house is an old woman. The girl comes to her house, and the old woman invites her to lie down behind a curtain. "Suddenly there is a bang, a clap of thunder, twelve young men enter. The old woman says to the twelfth brother: 'Do not dine, there is a bride for you.' " And he sleeps with the foreign girl (Onč. 178, type Cupid and Psyche ). One can, of course, object that this case proves nothing, that here an assimilation with the motif of the twelve robbers has taken place. The problem can also be posed in this way. But another approach is admissible: could Psyche's marriage to Cupid not reflect the phenomenon of temporary marriage with the "brothers", but the other brothers are omitted and the temporary polyandrous marriage is presented as a union of more recent formation? This conjecture is confirmed by a whole series of observations.

爱的宫殿坐落在森林里并不是俄罗斯童话的独特特征，而是其普遍特征。在汉诺威童话中，女​​孩在城堡里呆了七年，也就是说，她暂时住在那里，必须看管房子，就像我们熟悉的“小妹妹”一样。城堡里的仆人、工人和车夫竞相想和她共度一夜211。

That Love's palace is located in the forest is not a peculiar feature of the Russian fairy tale, it is a universal characteristic. In a Hanoverian fairy tale the girl stays in the castle for seven years, that is, she lives there temporarily and has to look after the house, just like her "little sister" whom we know well. The servants, the workers and the coachman of the castle compete with each other to try to spend a night with her 211 .

但这绝不是这个想法向我们暗示的唯一特征。通常女孩已经被许诺给一个怪物。对预售的研究表明，被出售的人发现自己处于一种与启蒙情结相关的状态。我们已经看到，这个女孩被她的父母卖到了男家，而且是父母自己把她送到了那里。在丘比特和普赛克类型的童话故事中，女孩通常表现出相当弱的抵抗力。而且，在新家，她总会发现已经为她准备好的饭菜，这与上面报道的材料非常相似。 « “别担心，先生，”女儿说，“有上帝的帮助，我在那里也会很开心。带我去找蛇。”她的父亲接了她，把她留在宫里，告别了她，回到了自己的家。这个女孩，一个商人的女儿，在房间里走来走去，到处都是黄金和天鹅绒，但她没有看到任何人，她没有看到一个活生生的灵魂。时间流逝。美女开始感到很饿，心想：“啊，我多么乐意吃一口啊！ „.她还没想完，面前已经摆了一张桌子，桌上摆着食物、饮料和糖果；我们所缺乏的只是鸟奶”（Af. 155）。

But this is by no means the only feature that suggests this thought. Usually the girl has been promised to a monster. The study of the sale in advance shows that the person sold finds himself in a condition connected with the initiation complex. We have already seen that the girl was sold by her parents to the men's house, and that it was the parents themselves who sent her there. In fairy tales of the type of Cupid and Psyche the girl usually offers rather weak resistance. Furthermore, the fact that in her new home she always finds a meal already prepared for her, also comes very close to the materials given above. " 'Do not grieve, habbino,' said the daughter, 'with God's help I shall feel good there too. Lead me to the serpent.' The father took her and left her in the palace, took leave of her and returned to his own home. The girl, daughter of a merchant, wanders through the rooms, everywhere there is gold and velvet, but she sees no one, she sees no living soul. And time passes. The beauty begins to feel very hungry and thinks: "Ah, how I would gladly eat a morsel!". She had not finished thinking when a table was already in front of her, and on the table food and drink and sweets; all that was missing was the bird's milk" (Af. 155).

在这里，我们也很容易认出我们所熟知的“大房子”，尽管这里既没有命名也没有描述它。我们在上面已经看到，在那些房子里，女孩被提供食物，以一种她看不到任何人的方式呈现给她，也就是说，我们发现自己处于一种隐形服务的舞台上。隐形仆人是这些故事的一个永恒特征。在弗雷泽那里，这个问题以一种非常理性主义的方式呈现，但它可能是一个更深层次的东西。我们已经知道，住在房子里被认为是在死亡的王国里。这个领域的特点之一就是隐形。因此出现了“失明”以及新手身上的白色或黑色油漆等。正如我们稍后将看到的，隐形帽子也从这里衍生出来。然而，这种相当传统的隐形被认为与房子里的居民的传统动物外观一样真实。也就是说，我们有一个关于隐形的虚构故事，童话故事将其保留为真正的隐形。

Here, too, we can easily recognize the "big house" so well known to us, although it is neither named nor described here. We have already seen above that in these houses the girl is supplied with food, which is presented to her in such a way that she cannot see anyone; that is, we are faced with a kind of staging of the invisibility of the service. Invisible servants are a constant feature of these stories. In Frazer the matter is presented in a very rationalistic way, but it may be that something much deeper is involved. We already know that the stay in the house was believed to be a stay in the realm of death. One of the peculiarities of this realm is invisibility. Hence the "blindness" and the white or black paint on the bodies of the neophytes, etc. From this also comes, as we shall see later, the hat-that-makes-one-invisible. This rather conventional invisibility was, however, considered to be as real as the conventional animal appearance of the inhabitants of the house. That is, we have a fiction of invisibility that the fairy tale has preserved as real invisibility.

最后，丈夫的兽性和他的突然失踪也不矛盾，反而证实了我们的猜想。 “森林兄弟”具有动物外表绝不是一个例外（见 Af. 120）。入会者和那些住在男人的房子或森林房子里的人常常被认为是动物，并把自己伪装成动物。最后，新郎早上的失踪与房子“白天荒芜”的主题有关。

Finally, the animal nature of the groom and his sudden disappearance do not contradict the above, on the contrary they confirm our conjecture. It is not at all an exceptional case that the "brothers of the forest" have an animal appearance (cf. Af. 120). The initiates and those who lived in the houses for men or in the houses of the forest were often believed to be animals and disguised themselves as such. Finally, the disappearance of the groom in the morning is connected to the motif of the house "deserted during the day".

所有这些主题在其他童话故事中也有出现，并且没有什么特别新的内容。但亲戚来访的原因在这一轮故事中显得更为特殊。在有关仙女新郎的童话故事中，女孩（有时在丈夫的陪伴下）去拜访她的亲戚（格林，88 岁），或者客人从她父亲的家里到来。长期以来，人们一直认为普赛克生活的王国应该被理解为死者的王国。我们已经知道，根据信仰，接受启蒙的年轻人留在了另一个世界。但如果蛇的花园只是来世的国度，亲戚的来访就令人费解了。然而，如果女孩的蛇丈夫的花园和王国以及留在另一边的亲戚和父母的王国都按照我们所指出的意义来理解，那么后者的来访就变得可以理解了。在阿普列乌斯，女孩收到了她姐妹们的拜访。在我们的童话故事中，经常发生相反的情况：女孩去看望她的父母。 “她记得她的小角落”（ZV 13）。 “让我再次见到我的母亲”（Chud. 63）。 “我们去找我的父母吧”（《SM.126》）等等。正如韦氏词典212所指出的，一段时间后，亲属被允许探望入会者。博尔特发现童话故事“失去了其神奇的特征，因为妻子设法说服丈夫去拜访她的父亲”（Bolte-Polivka，I，46，第400页）。也许吧，但在童话故事中，“神奇”和“不神奇”可以同样具有历史意义。

All these motifs are also found in other fairy tales, and there is nothing specifically new in them. But the motif of the visit of the relatives seems more peculiar to this cycle of tales. In the fairy tales about the fairy husband the girl (sometimes accompanied by her husband) goes to visit her relatives (Grimm, 88), or guests come to her from her father's house. It has long been believed that the realm in which Psyche lives is to be understood as the realm of the dead. We already know that, according to belief, young people undergoing initiation sojourned in the other world. But if the serpent's garden were only the realm of the afterlife, the visit of the relatives would be inexplicable. If, on the other hand, the garden and the realm of the girl's serpent husband and the realm of the relatives and parents who have remained on the other side are understood in the sense we have indicated, the visit of the latter becomes understandable. In Apuleius the girl is visited by her sisters. In our fairy tales the opposite often happens: it is the girl who goes to visit her parents. "She remembered her little corner" (ZV 13). "Let me see my mother again" (Chud. 63). "Let us go to my parents" (Sm. 126), etc. As Webster 212 points out , after a certain time relatives were allowed to visit the initiates. Bolte finds that the fairy tale "loses its miraculous character, since the wife succeeds in persuading her husband to pay a visit to her father" (Bolte-Polivka, I, 46, p. 400). This may be the case, but in the fairy tale the "miraculous" and the "non-miraculous" can be equally historical.

12.妻子参加丈夫的婚礼。

12. The wife at her husband's wedding .

在我们所描述的情况下，青年男子和一些女孩可以先后缔结两次婚姻：第一次是“自由”在“大房子”里，是暂时的集体婚姻，第二次是回国后缔结的婚姻。家，是稳定的、有秩序的，家庭由此诞生。

In the situation we have outlined, both young men and some girls could contract two successive marriages: the first was "free" in the "great house", and was a temporary and collective marriage, the second, however, which was contracted after the return home, was stable and regulated and from it the family was born.

可以看出，童话中的主人公有时会结婚两次，或者更准确地说，是准备第二次结婚，忘记了他的第一任妻子。从我们的材料来看，人们可能会问，第一任妻子是否是在外面、在另一个境界认识的，等等。不是男家的临时老婆。主人公回国后即将娶的第二任妻子可能对应于第二次规范婚姻的妻子。在历史现实中，第一任妻子，所有兄弟的妻子，特别是他们每个人的妻子，都被抛弃和遗忘了。回国后，缔结了稳定稳固的婚姻，组建了家庭。这正是英雄一直想做的事。但离婚的妻子“从那个地方”出现，英雄娶了她。

It may be noted that in the fairy tale the hero sometimes marries twice, or, more precisely, he is about to marry for the second time, having forgotten his first wife. From the point of view of our material, one may ask whether the first wife, met outside the home, in another kingdom, etc., is not the temporary wife of the men's house. The second wife that the hero is about to marry after returning home could correspond to the wife of the second, regular marriage. In historical reality the first wife, wife of all the brothers and also of each of them in particular, was abandoned and forgotten. After returning home a stable and solid marriage was concluded, a family was created. This is precisely what the hero always wants to do. But the repudiated wife shows up "from that place" and the hero marries her.

如果这个观察是正确的，如果这里确实有一个历史条件的类比，那就意味着童话反映了一个后来的阶段，即这个体系瓦解的阶段，即与正常秩序发生冲突的阶段。农业制度和其他形式婚姻的需要出现了。

If this observation is correct, if there really is a historically conditioned analogy here, it would mean that the fairy tale reflects a later stage, the stage of the disintegration of this system, the stage in which the conflict with the order proper to the agricultural regime occurs and the need for other forms of marriage arises.

让我们看一下与这个问题相关的一些案例。在童话《海王与智者瓦西里莎》中，英雄被卖给了海王。他去找他，娶了他的女儿，然后带着她回家。瓦西丽莎说：“继续吧，小王子！向你的爸爸和你的妈妈通报我，我会在街上等你，但请记住：亲吻所有人，但不要亲吻你的妹妹，否则你会忘记我的！ »（AF.125a）。此时，一个疑问出现了：是什么迫使瓦西丽莎在街上停下来？故事中没有提到她不能和小王子一起进城的任何障碍。这种奇怪的举动并非出于童话故事，而是出于历史。如果不是停在城门口，两个妻子之间就不会发生冲突，但这种冲突是一个没有被完全遗忘的历史现象。沿途的一站是白色的线，我们的主题被缝在童话故事中。 “不要亲吻你的妹妹”这一禁令我们也很清楚。童话里的“小妹妹”和森林里的房子的“小妹妹”是一样的。 “别吻她”也是一个足够明确的指示。在这个童话故事中，女孩要求英雄不要与其他女人有任何关系。但是，尽管如此，他“亲吻了他的妹妹”，也就是说，进入了另一段婚姻，之后他完全忘记了他的第一任妻子。 “我们的小国王要和一位富有的公主结婚了。”其特点是，儿子被嫁给（而不是自己）嫁给一个“富有的女人”，也就是说，在这里我们发现自己面临着婚姻谈判。这两段婚姻的性质不同。瓦西丽莎被遗忘了。但童话里她总能找到办法出现在婚宴最美丽的时刻。 “突然国王想起了他的妻子，跳了起来”等等。没有人再关心不幸的“女王”，英雄娶了瓦西丽莎。 “显然，新娘很沮丧，客人也很沮丧，但我们无能为力”（K.6）。

Let us examine some cases that relate to this problem. In the fairy tale The Sea King and Vasilissa the Wise the hero is sold to the Sea King. He goes to him, marries his daughter, and then returns home with her. Vasilissa says: "Go on, little prince! Announce me to your father and mother, and I will wait for you here on the road, but remember well: kiss everyone, but do not kiss my little sister, or you will forget me!" (Af. 125 a). At this point a doubt arises: what forces Vasilissa to stop on the road? The tale does not mention any impediment that would prevent her from simply entering the city together with the little prince. This strange gesture is motivated not by fairy tales, but by history. If she had not stopped at the gates of the city, there would have been no conflict between the two wives, but this conflict is a historical phenomenon that has not been entirely forgotten. The stop on the road is the white thread with which our motif is sewn to the fairy tale. The prohibition "Do not kiss your little sister" is also clear to us. The "little sister" in the fairy tale is the same "little sister" from the house in the forest. "Do not kiss her" is also a sufficiently clear indication. In this fairy tale the girl asks the hero not to have anything to do with other women. But, nevertheless, he "kisses his little sister", that is, he concludes another marriage, after which he completely forgets his first wife. "Our little king is married to a rich princess". It is characteristic that the son is given in marriage (and does not marry himself) to a "rich woman", that is, we are here faced with a marriage contract. The two marriages differ in their character. Vasilissa is forgotten. But in the fairy tale she always finds a way to make herself known at the height of the wedding feast. "Suddenly the little king remembered his wife, and jumped up", etc. No one cares about the unfortunate "little queen" anymore and the hero marries Vasilissa. "The bride, of course, was upset, and so were the guests, but there was little that could be done" (K. 6).

也许有人会说，我们对吻的解释是合理的。一些作者提出了不同的解释：他们认为遗忘是从生者领域进入死者领域时记忆的丧失，反之亦然。例如，阿恩就持有这样的观点：“从这个年轻人在亲吻来自这个世界的女孩时忘记了她这一事实就可以看出，女孩是另一个世界的存在的一部分” 213。这样的解释是可能的。我们已经看到如何理解英雄“在另一个世界”的永恒。在《亡灵书》中有为保存记忆而祈祷的内容（第二十二章），这表明存在记忆丧失的表征。但这个吻却与这一切相矛盾。为什么遗忘恰恰是从接吻开始的？在阿恩的解释中，这仍然是模糊的，而如果我们像本章中所做的那样解释吻和小妹妹，问题就会变得更加清晰。

It may be objected that our interpretation of the kiss is rationalized. Several authors advocate a different interpretation: they consider oblivion as the loss of memory at the moment of entering the realm of the living into the realm of the dead, and vice versa. Aarne, for example, is of this opinion: "That the girl belongs to the beings of the other world is seen from the fact that the young man forgets her when he kisses a girl of this world." 213 Such an interpretation is possible. We have seen how the hero's stay "in the other world" can be understood. In the Book of the Dead there are prayers for the preservation of memory (chap. XXII), which indicates the existence of representations of the loss of memory. But the kiss contradicts all this. Why does oblivion begin precisely with the kiss? In Aarne's interpretation this remains obscure, while the question acquires a certain clarity if we interpret the kiss and the little sister as we have done in this chapter.

为了让人们记住她，她做了一个馅饼，馅饼里飞出了两只鸽子。 “他切了馅饼，一只鸽子和一只鸽子飞了出来”（Sev.1）。这些鸽子互相亲吻；鸽子的忠诚让英雄想起了他自己的不忠。 EG Kagarov 在他对婚礼仪式的研究中说道：“一对鸽子的肖像被粘在圆形面包上，“这样我们的孩子就成对了”，或者两只小鸟喙对喙地放在婚礼面包上，这样我们的孩子就可以配对了。夫妻双方可以共同生活。我将这一事实与两个木偶的神奇雕像进行比较，这两个木偶温柔地拥抱彼此，注定要在某些人之间产生爱与和谐（葡萄牙）”。作者将此仪式纳入了联合仪式或统一仪式中214。即使在童话故事中，我们也能看到这种仪式。

The means by which the girl uses to be remembered consists in making a pie, from which two doves fly out. "He cut the pie and out flew a dove and a dove" (Sev. 1). These doves kiss; the loving fidelity of the doves reminds the hero of his own infidelity. In his study of the wedding rite, EG Kagarov says: "On the round loaf of bread is glued the effigy of a pair of doves 'so that our children are paired' or on the wedding loaf are placed two little birds beak to beak so that the spouses live in harmony. I compare this fact with the magic effigy of two puppets that tenderly embrace each other and are destined to give birth to love and harmony between certain people (Portugal)." The author includes this rite among the syndiasmic or unitive rites 214 . Even in fairy tales we have a reflection of this rite.

接吻和遗忘不仅是瓦西里莎和海王童话类型的典型，而且也是其他类型的童话故事的典型。对这些案例的详细研究绝对清楚地揭示了事情的真实状况。根据所引用的材料，所发生情况的口头表达也变得特别清晰。在维亚特卡童话故事中，被卖给魔鬼的英雄娶了他的女儿，然后回到自己的家。 “然后他就失去了结婚的念头，完全忘记了另一个即将生孩子的女人”（ZV 118）。上面我们已经指出了孩子在临时婚姻向稳定婚姻转变过程中所发挥的作用。父母对归来的儿子说：“去找执事的妻子，问你的问题，她有三个女儿；你是怎么想到这么远的地方去寻找新娘的？ »（第 97 条）。 «国王伊凡想到了他的第一任妻子，对国王说：“我不可能带走你的女儿。我已经在乌拉尔有一个妻子“”（荒芜的地方，森林），（ZP 12）等。这就解释了童话故事中经常发生的重婚罪。 « 我想让她成为我的妻子，但我家里已经有了另一个妻子，我该怎么办？ »（K.6）。

Kissing and forgetting are characteristic not only of the tales about Vasilissa and the Sea King, but also of other tales. A detailed study of these cases reveals the true state of affairs with absolute clarity. In the light of the materials cited, the verbal expression of the situation that has arisen also becomes particularly clear. In a tale from Vyatka, the hero who has been sold to the devil marries her daughter and then returns home. "Then he had a fancy to marry, and he completely forgot about the other, who was about to give birth" (ZV 118). We have already noted above the role played by children in the transformation of a temporary marriage into a stable one. The parents say to the returned son: "Go to the deacon's wife, ask your question, she has three daughters; why did you think to seek a bride so far away?" (Sm. 97). « King Ivan thought of his first wife and said to the king: “I cannot take your daughter. I already have a wife in the Urals” » (deserted places, forest), (ZP 12), etc. This explains bigamy, which occurs so often in fairy tales. « I would like her to be my wife, but I already have another one at home, what should I do? » (K. 6).

Finist也属于同一组（Af. 129）。然而，在这个童话故事中，人物的安排略有不同。第一次婚姻——自由婚姻——不是在森林或另一个王国结束，而是在英雄的房子里结束；然后他化身动物前往另一个王国，准备与另一个女人结婚，当女孩到达时，为她的情敌买了三晚并赢回了她的丈夫。购买夜晚的原因无疑也是历史性的，但有关男子房屋的材料中没有包含可以准确解释的数据。我们只能说，我们在这里面临着女孩和幼鸟之间的一种禁忌关系，也就是说，带着面具，与已经超出了他家的范围的年轻人，在“另一个”王国里。女孩去找他的妻子。

Finist (Aph. 129) also belongs to the same group . In this tale, however, the arrangement of the characters is slightly different. The first marriage - which is a free marriage - does not take place in the forest or in the other kingdom, but in the hero's house; then he goes to the other kingdom in the guise of an animal and is about to marry (or marries) another woman, when the girl arrives, buys three nights from her rival and wins her husband back. The reason for the bought nights is undoubtedly also historical, but the materials on the houses of men do not contain data on the basis of which it can be explained exactly. One can only infer that we are here faced with a forbidden relationship between the girl and the young bird, that is, with the mask, with the young man who is already beyond the confines of his house, in the "other" kingdom where his bride goes to look for him.

13.肮脏的家伙。

13. The dirty old man .

“妻子在丈夫的婚礼上”的主题让人想起“丈夫在妻子的婚礼上”的主题。但在研究之前，有必要先考察一下主人公启蒙后回家的一些情况。

The motif of the "wife at the husband's wedding" recalls that of the "husband at the wife's wedding". But before studying it, it is necessary to examine some circumstances of the hero's return home, after the initiation.

在童话故事中，不被认可的英雄常常显得肮脏、沾满烟灰等。他就是那个“肮脏的家伙”。他与魔鬼结盟，魔鬼禁止他洗澡，作为交换，他给了他不成比例的财富，之后英雄结婚了。 “他不剪头发，不刮胡子，不清理鼻子，不换衣服”（Af. 150）。就这样，他持续了十四年（在德国童话故事中是七年），最后英雄说：“好了，我的服务结束了。” “然后魔鬼把它切成块，扔进锅里煮，煮好后，他把它洗净，一块一块地拼在一起，这是正当的。”魔鬼向他洒了活水和死水。肮脏的新郎的主题在德国童话故事中得到了进一步发展：“在未来的几年里，你将不必洗澡，也不必剃须或头发，也不必背诵我们的父亲”（格林，101）。同样：“你不能洗澡，你不能刮胡子，你不能擤鼻涕，你不能剪指甲，你不能清洁你的眼睛”（格林，100）。关于森林里的女孩也有同样的说法：“她把煤灰涂在脸上和手上”（格林，65）。她是Allerleirauh，也就是说，她穿着不同野兽的皮。男性童话故事中的英雄巴伦豪特 (Bärenhäuter ) 披着熊皮。英雄或女英雄的这种状况是他们在森林中停留或为魔鬼服务期间以及结婚之前的特征，但有时也会在其他情况下遇到。 “他喝醉了，把自己裹在泥里，然后用羽毛涂抹自己，到达了那艘看起来像怪物的船”（K.10）。

In the fairy tale the hero who has not been recognized often appears dirty, smeared with soot, etc. He is the "dirty old man." He has made an alliance with the devil, who forbids him to wash himself and, in exchange, gives him enormous riches, after which the hero takes a wife. "He does not cut his hair, he does not shave, he does not wipe his nose, he does not change his clothes" (Af. 150). Thus he drags out fourteen years (seven, in the German fairy tale), at the end of which the hero says: "Well, my service is done." "Then the devil cut him into little pieces, threw him into a cauldron and boiled him, when he was cooked he washed him and put him together piece by piece, as is proper." The devil sprinkles him with living and dead water. The motif of the dirty groom is further developed in the German fairy tale: "In the coming years you shall not wash yourself, nor shave your beard or hair, nor recite the Lord's Prayer" (Grimm, 101). Similarly: "You shall not wash yourself, nor shave, nor blow your nose, nor cut your nails, nor clean your eyes" (Grimm, 100). About the girl in the forest is said to be roughly the same: "She smeared her face and hands with soot" (Grimm, 65). She is Allerleirauh , that is to say, she is dressed in the skins of various beasts. The hero of the male fairy tale, Bärenhäuter , is covered with a bearskin. This condition of heroes or heroines is characteristic for the period of their stay in the forest or of their service to the devil and precedes marriage, but it is sometimes encountered in other situations as well. « He got drunk and wallowed in the mud, then he smeared himself with feathers and arrived on the ship, which looked like a monster » (K. 10).

不仅如此，禁止洗涤是仪式中经常遇到的，但它几乎是仪式中不可避免的一部分215。该禁令的长度各不相同。它可以持续整个圣地停留的时间，三十天，一百天，五个月等等。新手没洗，还抹了灰。这种涂抹是必要的：不洗就等于用烟灰或泥土涂抹自己，也就是把自己涂成黑色或白色。 “在最初的一百天里，他不洗澡，变得很脏，以至于当他出去时，人们不再认出他：据说他脏得看不见” 216。故不洗与隐身有关，涂白亦与此有关。 « 从头到脚都染成白色；因此，它们的外观令人厌恶，而且令人厌恶和肮脏，因为它们没有被清洗” 217。我们已经知道，变白与失明和隐形有关。黑死或许也有同样的起源。 “当它们出来时，它们是黑色的，沾满了污垢和烟灰，在它们被清洗之前人们无法看到它们” 218（“不被看见”也可以意味着“它们是看不见的”。但禁令本身无非是虚构的隐形的表达）。而且，这对我们来说也不是必要的，重要的是确立禁令的事实。但在这方面还可以添加一个特点。根据帕金森的说法，清洗的禁令延伸到山药成熟的整个时期，从播种到收获。允许清洗的时间与收获时间一致。在这里，我们发现自己处于最近农业代表的源头，代表着有利于生育的神降临到地球上。我们已经知道，仪式教导如何获得丰富的野味，它也延伸到农产品。除此之外，俄罗斯童话保留了对这一切的好奇回忆。在树林里的大房子里，女孩对英雄说：“站起来，小王子伊万，农民的儿子。麦子已入粮仓；我想到了一切。来吧，用烟灰涂抹你的脸，涂抹全身，然后到我父亲那里去”（《诗篇》126）。在这个童话故事中，女孩的父亲给英雄指派了播种、种植和收割小麦的任务。为什么英雄必须用烟灰涂抹自己，以表明他亲自完成了这一壮举？从给出的例子中可以清楚地看出原因：收获取决于保持在看不见、肮脏、黑暗的状态。

The prohibition to wash oneself is often encountered in the rite, and not only that, but it is an almost inevitable part of the ceremony 215 . The duration of this prohibition varies. It can last for the entire time of the stay in the sacred place, thirty days, a hundred days, five months, etc. The initiate does not wash himself, and in addition he smears himself with ashes. This smearing is essential: not washing is connected with smearing oneself with soot or clay, that is to say with painting oneself black or white. « During the first hundred days he does not wash himself, and becomes so dirty that he is no longer recognized when he goes out: it is said of him that he is so dirty as to be invisible » 216 . Therefore not washing is connected with invisibility, and painting one's body white is also connected to this. « From head to foot they are dyed white; for this reason they have a repulsive appearance, and also disgusting and dirty, because they do not wash themselves." 217 . We have already seen that dyeing oneself white is connected with blindness and invisibility. Dying oneself black probably also has the same origin. "When they come out they are black with dirt and soot, and one cannot look at them until they have washed themselves." 218 ( are not to be seen can also mean "they are invisible." But the prohibition itself is nothing but the expression of a fictitious invisibility). This is not even essential for us, what matters is to note the fact of the prohibition. But one can add a peculiarity in this regard. According to Parkinson, the prohibition to wash extends to the entire period of the ripening of the yam , from sowing to harvest. The permission to wash coincides with the harvest. Here we find ourselves at the sources of a more recent agricultural representation of the descent under the earth of the divinity who promotes fertility. We already know that the rite teaches how to obtain the abundance of game, it is also extended to the products of agriculture. Among other things, the Russian fairy tale has retained a curious reminiscence of all this. In the great house in the forest the girl says to the hero: "Get up, Prince Ivan, son of peasants. The grain is already in the granary; I have taken care of everything. Come, smear your face with soot, smear yourself all over, and go to my father" (Sm. 126). In this fairy tale the girl's father had assigned the hero the task of sowing, raising and harvesting the grain. Why must the hero smear himself with soot as a sign that he has personally accomplished the feat? The reason is clear from the examples given: the harvest depends on remaining in a state of invisibility, of dirt, of blackness.

不洗澡也是婚礼的一种准备：“他们把泥土涂在他的身上，并强迫他在村子里转了几天几夜，向妇女们扔泥土。最后他被交给了女人们，她们给他洗澡，涂了脸，并在他面前跳舞» 219回来后，年轻人就可以结婚了。将这段话与俄罗斯童话故事进行比较：“他们把他带到了他面前。一切都被青苔覆盖了。她亲手剪了他的头发，给他剃了胡子……现在我可以嫁给你的儿子了”（Chud.83）。

Not washing also constitutes a kind of preparation for marriage: "They smeared his body with mud and forced him to wander around the village for several days and nights throwing mud at the women. Finally he was handed over to the women, who washed him, painted his face and danced before him." 219 After his return, the young man can marry. Let us compare this passage with the Russian fairy tale: "They brought him before her. He was all covered with moss. She cut off his hair with her own hand, shaved him... Now I can marry your son." (Chud. 83).

禁止清洗构成了一个人种学问题，我们无法深入探讨其本质，因为它超出了我们的任务范围。在童话故事中，无法准确界定不洗澡的英雄和动物形态的英雄。可能是泥的涂抹与想象中的动物外貌有某种关系，它是一种面具。例如，女孩不仅不洗澡并沾上烟灰，她还用蜂蜜涂抹自己，然后用羽毛包裹自己（Grimm，46）。如果灌顶已经很长时间没有进行了，或者不再与青春期有关并且已经获得了另一种特征，那么涂抹和涂抹仍然存在。因此，在希腊神秘仪式中，启蒙者用粘土或粉笔涂抹自己，或者撒上面粉或麸皮。一些作者（萨姆特和其他人）希望在这个事实中看到让自己变得不被认出的愿望，实际上，正如我们很快就会看到的那样，不被认出是一个不可避免的特征，是英雄从森林归来的一个不可避免的条件。因此，不洗澡是一个非常复杂的现象，与隐形和失明、动物外观和不可识别性有关，也与死亡地区的永久有关。

The prohibition to wash is an ethnographic problem, the essence of which we cannot enter into, since it is beyond our task. In the fairy tale it is not possible to draw an exact boundary between the hero who does not wash and the hero in the guise of an animal. It may be that the smearing of mud has some connection with the imaginary animal appearance, is a kind of mask. The girl, for example, does not limit herself to not washing and smearing herself with soot, she also smears herself with honey and then wraps herself in feathers (Grimm, 46). Where initiation has not been practiced for a long time, or is no longer connected with puberty and has acquired another character, the smearing and the smearing remain. Thus in the Greek mysteries the initiate smeared himself with clay, chalk, or sprinkled himself with flour or bran. Some authors (Samter and others) want to see in this fact the desire to make oneself unrecognizable, and in fact, as we will see shortly, not being recognized is an inevitable characteristic, an inevitable condition for the hero's return from the forest. Not washing is therefore a very complex phenomenon, connected with invisibility and blindness, with the animal appearance and with unrecognizability, and it is also connected with the permanence in the regions of death.

萨姆特引用拉德洛夫的话指出，在带着死者的灵魂前往死者王国的过程中，西伯利亚萨满用烟灰涂抹了自己的脸220。根据这些材料，可以说英雄的乔装，在民间传说中经常出现，将衣服换成乞丐等等。这是与另一个世界的持久性相关的外观变化的特例。奇怪的是，在科尔古耶夫收集的童话故事中，我们不仅发现了伪装，而且还发现了对它的准确解释：“他走了他的路。但他的衣服，就像来自另一个世界的人一样，已经不同了，当然在他的背上写着：你将从另一个世界出来”（K.10）。

Quoting Radlov, Samter notes that in the act of leaving for the kingdom of the dead with the soul of the deceased, the Siberian shaman smears his face with soot 220 . In the light of these materials, it can be said that the hero's disguise, so frequent in folklore, exchanging his clothes for those of a beggar, etc., is a special case of the change of appearance connected with the stay in the other world. It is strange that in a fairy tale collected by Korgúev, we find not only the disguise, but also its interpretation in precisely this sense: "And he went on his way. But his clothes, like those of someone who comes from the other world, were already different and it was written, on the back of course: You will come out of the other world" (K.10).

14.“我不知道。”

14. " I don't know ."

“肮脏”主题与“我不知道”主题密切相关。这一主题的本质在于，英雄隐姓埋名地来到他的房子（或他未来妻子的王国），并假装不知道或不记得任何事情。 « 国王问他：“好吧，兄弟，你是什么出生的，你叫什么名字？ - 我不知道 ”。无论国王如何询问他，他仍然说：“我不知道我的名字”（ZP 2）。或者：“你是谁？ »——我不知道，我不知道我来自哪里，我什至不记得我属于哪个家庭。在最后一个故事中，英雄失去了一根手指（Chud.41）。马建议他：“去国王的花园，躺在犁沟里，遮住脸，不要表现出来（他是一个非常英俊的男孩）。无论谁问你，无论他们告诉你什么，总是回答“我不知道”（Z.St.，242）。这样的例子比比皆是。 « “你去了哪里，看到了什么？ ——我没去过任何地方，也没看到任何东西。”无论他们如何询问他，他还是什么都不记得”（《诗篇》5）。 “ “ 你叫什么名字？你从哪来？ ” 对于所有的问题他都回答：“我不知道”，因此他被昵称为“我不知道””（Sm. 305）。 “你是谁？ - 我不知道。 ——你是男人吗？ — 我不知道 »（七月 47）。另一方面，就连父母也认不出回家的儿子了。 “父亲只是认不出他”（Chud.1）。 « 他们只是认不出那是他们的儿子。他们失去了他。他在那里呆了很多年，衣衫褴褛，身体状况非常糟糕”（ZP 12）。同样，在维亚特卡童话故事中，父亲不认识他的儿子（ZV 85）。

The motif of the "dirty old man" is closely connected with that of the "I don't know". The essence of this motif consists in the fact that the hero arrives incognito in his own house (or in the kingdom of his future wife) and pretends not to know or remember anything.
