"The king asks him: 'Well, brother, what is your birthplace and what is your name? - I don't know.' However much the king questions him, he continues to say: 'I don't know my name.' " (ZP 2). Or: 'Who are you?' - I don't know, I don't know where I come from, I don't even remember what family I belong to.' In this last tale the hero is missing a finger (Chud. 41). The horse advises him: 'Go into the king's garden, lie down in a furrow, and cover your face, don't show it (he was a very handsome boy). Whoever questions you, whatever they say to you, always answer, “I do not know” » (Z.St., 242). Similar examples abound. « “Where have you been? What have you seen? — I have not been anywhere, I have seen nothing.” No matter how many times they questioned him, he remembered nothing » (Sm. 5). « “What is your name? Where do you come from?” To all questions he answered, “I do not know,” so that he was nicknamed “I do not know” » (Sm. 305). « Who are you? — I do not know. — Are you a man? — I do not know » (Sev. 47). On the other hand, not even the parents recognize their son when he returns home. « The father was simply unable to recognize him » (Chud. 1). « They simply could not recognize that it was their son. They had lost him. He had spent so many years there, he was dressed in rags, he was really in bad shape" (ZP 12). In the same way in a Vyatka fairy tale the father does not recognize his son (ZV 85).

无需证明，我们在这里也有回家的时刻之一的反映。在这些场合，原始的仪式要求退伍军人“忘记”他的名字、他的父母和他的家。他是一个新人，他是另一个人，他重生了，他是一个死了又以另一个名字复活的人。而父母也假装不认识自己的儿子，如果几年不见，也可能是真的不认识他了。

It is not necessary to demonstrate that here too we have the reflection of one of the moments of the return home. On these occasions an original ceremonial required that the veteran "had forgotten" his name, his parents, his home. He was a new man, he was another, he was reborn, he was a man who had died and was resurrected with another name. For their part, the parents also pretended not to recognize their son and if the absence had lasted several years, it could also be that they did not really recognize him.

15.秃头，裹着鞘。

15. Bald and covered in a sheath .

被遮盖的头部或相反，没有遮盖且没有头发的主题与未被认出的英雄的主题相关。在上面引用的例子中我们已经发现：“并且遮住你的脸，不要露出来。”英雄常常把膀胱、内脏或抹布放在头上。 “然后他取出内脏，取出内脏，彻底清洗，制成一顶帽子，并将内脏包裹在他的手上”（ZP 2，第16页）。或者：“伊万，商人的儿子，让他的马自由，穿上一张牛皮，把一个膀胱放在头上，然后去了海边”（Af. 165 a）。 « 她买了三张牛皮。他用它做了一个鞘，这样就看不出他是一个人，并在上面附上了一条两萨泽尼长的尾巴» 221 (Sev. 47)。

The motif of the unrecognized hero is connected to the motif of the covered head or, on the contrary, uncovered and without hair. In the example cited above we have already found: "And cover your face, do not show it." Often the hero puts a bladder, a gut or a rag on his head. "Then he took out the entrails, took out the guts, washed them thoroughly, made a hat out of them and wrapped the guts around his hands" (ZP 2, p. 16). Or: "Ivàn, the merchant's son, let his horse go free, dressed himself in an oxhide, put a bladder on his head and went to the seashore" (Af. 165 a). "She bought three oxhides. He made a sheath out of them, so that it was not visible that he was a man, and he attached a tail to it two saženi long " 221 (Sev. 47).

我们看到，在这些例子中，英雄隐藏了他的头发，出于某种原因隐藏了他的头。奇怪的是，蒙着头的这个主题常常与其对立面，即与不蒙蒙的、秃头的、秃头的主题联系在一起。它也经常与“我不知道”主题联系在一起。 « 他去了屠宰场，在那里杀牛，拿了一个膀胱，把它放在他的头上。他来到国王那里，向他请求施舍。国王问他： - 你叫什么名字？ — 普莱什！222 — 你的祖国是哪里？ ——普莱萨维尼扎！ ——你出生在哪里？ ——我是一个路人，我什至不知道我从哪里来？（Chud.4）。这里的英雄蒙着头，说他是秃头。显然，内脏或膀胱应该给人秃顶的印象。我们在邓甘童话故事中也发现了同样的事情。 « 从前有三个兄弟......最小的头上戴着一顶用公羊肠制成的帽子，因此他们称他为“秃子，223 ”。 “你为什么用手帕盖住它？ — 因为他是秃头，所以看到它会很糟糕“（Sev. 91）。

We see that in these examples the hero hides his hair, hides his head for some reason. It is strange that this motif of the covered head is often connected with its antithesis, that is, with the motif of the uncovered, bald, bald head. And it is also often connected with the motif of "I don't know". "He went to the slaughterhouse, where they slaughter cattle, took a bladder, put it on his head. He came to the king and asked him for alms. And the king asks him: - What is your name? - Pleš! 222 - What is your homeland? - Plesavniza! - And where were you born? - I am a passer-by, I don't even know where I come from" (Chud. 4). Here the hero, who has covered his head, says that he is bald. Apparently the intestines or the bladder were meant to give the impression of baldness. We find the same thing in a Dungan fairy tale. « Once upon a time there were three brothers… The youngest wore a cap made from a sheep's intestines on his head, and that's why they called him “the bald one,” 223. “Why did he cover him with a handkerchief? — Because he's bald, it would be a very ugly sight” » (Sev. 91).

另一方面，童话故事中的英雄通常被称为秃头。 « 无论他们问你什么，你总是回答：“秃头疥疮” » (Z. St. 334)。根据已经引用的材料，这个回应的意思是：“你从我的头饰上看不出我来自哪里并且我被禁止说话吗？ » 有时恰恰是一个光头男人解开了公主的谜题（同上，481） « 这个光头男人解开了我的三个谜语。即使他是秃头，我也会嫁给他。”乌兹别克童话中的公主说道。 “从前，有七个秃头傻瓜和一个狡猾的蓬头垢面的人”，蒙古童话由此开始224。这个“scarmiglio”让人想起德国人Grindkopf ， 225折 的英雄。这是关于什么的？这个细节的扩散和持久从何而来？226

On the other hand, the heroes of fairy tales are often called bald. "No matter what they ask you, you always answer: 'Bald-mangy'" (Z. St. 334). In the light of the materials already cited, this answer means: "Do you not see from my headdress where I come from and that I am forbidden to speak?" Sometimes it is precisely a bald man who solves the princess's riddle ( Ibid ., 481). "This bald man solved my three riddles. Although he is bald, I will marry him," says the princess in an Uzbek fairy tale. "Once upon a time there were seven stupid bald men and one crafty mangy," thus begins a Mongolian fairy tale 224 . This "mangy" reminds us of the German Grindkopf , the hero with the crease 225 . What is this about? Where does the diffusion, the persistence of this detail come from? 226

在入会仪式中，人体的所有部分也许都是被操纵的对象。正如我们所看到的，甚至内脏也被移除和更换。头部和头发是经过特殊处理的对象。头发有两种处理方式：要么被剪掉并烧掉，要么相反，让它继续生长，但在后一种情况下，它被隐藏在一顶特殊的帽子下，不能摘下来。

In the rite of initiation there was perhaps no part of the human body that was not the object of some manipulation. Even the innards, as we have seen, were, according to belief, removed and replaced. The head and hair were the object of special treatment. With the hair there were two ways: either they were cut and burned, or on the contrary they were allowed to grow, but in the latter case they were hidden under a special headdress that was not to be removed.

我们在各大洲都找到了这方面的证据，尤其是在太平洋岛屿上。在所罗门群岛，只有留长发并在青春期（即青春期）佩戴特殊类型圆锥形头饰的男性协会成员才能结婚。头发长在帽子里面，因此无法将其取下。内弗曼说：“他从来不被允许在没有戴“帽子”的情况下向女性展示自己，即使是在他头发还很短的一开始也是如此。那个女人看到他没戴帽子，立刻就会被镇压，就像她踏进了协会会议的地方一样” 227。在仪式和婚礼之间的时期，年轻人在那里被称为“matazezen”。随后他们将帽子连同头发一起脱掉228。因此，这顶帽子是未来新郎的标志。内弗曼认为毛发生长可以促进性能力的增强。 «通过长出头发，男孩成为男人，并通过使用“结婚帽”获得性能力» 229。这是数十种解释之一。力量源于头发；我们必须将自己限制在一个简单的提示上，只记住参孙和大利拉的故事。从引用的材料来看，并不清楚帽子是由内脏还是膀胱制成的，正如我们的童话故事所示。但这种形式显然存在于非洲。 « 在冈比亚，新割礼的人戴......一顶形状奇怪的帽子，上面有一对牛角 » 230。我们现在也明白了为什么在美国神话中那些被鲸鱼吞下然后打嗝的人从鲸鱼的肠子里出来时是无毛的。所有这些材料使我们能够确定入会仪式和新郎没有头发或隐藏头发的主题之间是否存在遗传联系。

We find evidence of this on all continents, but especially on the islands of the Pacific Ocean. In the Solomon Islands, only members of the male associations who have long hair and who have worn a special type of conical headdress during adolescence, that is, during puberty, may marry. The hair grows inside this cap, so that it cannot be removed. Nevermann says: "He is never allowed to show himself to women without a 'cap', not even at the beginning, when his hair is still short. Any woman who sees him without a cap would be immediately killed, just as if she had set foot in the meeting place of the association." 227 In the period between the rite and the wedding, the young people are called colà matazezen . Later they remove their caps together with their hair . 228 Therefore, this cap is the mark of the future husband. Nevermann is of the opinion that the growth of hair promotes an increase in sexual potency. "By growing hair, the boy becomes a man and through the use of the 'bridal cap' he acquires sexual potency." 229 This is one of dozens of explanations. Strength is attributed to hair; we must limit ourselves to a simple reference, recalling only the story of Samson and Delilah. From the materials cited it does not appear whether the cap was made of intestines or bladders, as our fairy tale shows. But this form apparently existed in Africa. "In Gambia the newly circumcised wear... a cap of strange shape, with a pair of ox horns." 230 Now we also understand why in American myths those who have been swallowed and then belched by the whale emerge without hair from the whale's intestine. All these materials allow us to establish the existence of a genetic connection between the initiation rite and the motif of the groom without hair or with hidden hair.

16.丈夫参加妻子的婚礼。

16. The husband at his wife's wedding .

这些细节为考察“丈夫在妻子的婚礼上”的母题提供了一些综合特征。然而，它与“妻子在丈夫的婚礼上”的主题有很大不同。在那里，英雄在国外遇见了他的女人，回到家，准备庆祝另一场婚礼，等等。这里的情况有所不同：主人公在故事开始时结婚了（或结婚了），然后他离开了，他得知他的妻子即将再婚“她想嫁给另一个人”（Sm.135），他赶紧去回来并及时赶到参加妻子的婚礼。

These details provide some additional features for the examination of the motif of the "husband at his wife's wedding". However, it differs substantially from the motif of the "wife at her husband's wedding". There the hero meets his wife outside his own country, returns home, prepares to celebrate another wedding, etc. Here things are different: the hero is married (or marries) at the beginning of the story, then he goes away, learns that his wife is getting ready to marry again "she wants to marry another" (Sm. 135), hurries back and arrives in time to attend his wife's wedding.

这里我们面对的是一场在结婚前就已经缔结的婚姻，此外还有丈夫前往“森林”、长期不在以及留在家里试图再婚的妻子。

Here we are dealing with a marriage already concluded before the initiation, furthermore there is the departure of the husband for "the forest", his prolonged absence and the attempt of the wife who remained at home to remarry.

但这一假设是否与缔结婚姻的方法相矛盾，根据结婚的方法，入会是结婚的条件之一？这并不矛盾，而是一种更新的形式。随着习俗的衰落，庆祝仪式的次数越来越少，有时每隔十年或更长时间。 Schurtz 和 Webster 也提供了这方面的例子。与此同时，年轻人长大了，没有等待他们回顾性经历的入会就结婚了。因此，有四十岁男子与刚进入青春期的男孩一起接受启蒙的案例231。

But does not this hypothesis contradict the manner of concluding marriage, according to which initiation was one of the conditions for taking a wife? This is not a contradiction, but a more recent form. As the custom declined, the rite was celebrated less and less frequently, sometimes at intervals of ten or more years. Examples of this can also be found in Schurtz and Webster. In the meantime, the young men grew up and married without waiting for the initiation to which they submitted themselves retrospectively; so that there were cases of men of forty years of age who underwent initiation together with boys who had just reached puberty 231 .

托尔斯泰二世研究了“丈夫在妻子婚礼上”的主题232。

The motif of the "husband at his wife's wedding" was studied by II Tolstoy 232 .

教授。托尔斯泰并没有给自己定下调查动机起源的目标。但在他的作品中，他收集的材料使我们能够回答一个非常重要的问题：当妻子在等他时，丈夫在哪里？托尔斯泰非常令人信服地证明了英雄“已经到了死亡的住所”。在维亚特卡童话故事中，与森林精灵的相处持续了十二年，转瞬即逝，就像十二天一样。 “通常童话故事的主题是死亡地区时间的转瞬即逝，在人的意识中，一年就像一天一样快”（第517页）。在阿尔汉格尔斯克的童话故事中，我们发现：“梭子鱼吞掉了伊凡；他把它带到岸上并吐了出来。伊万就走了”（托尔斯泰，第 517 页；翁奇，第 35 页）等等。我们已经知道动物体内的持久性作为一种起始模式。还有其他细节会导致相同的结果。 « 丈夫回来变了；他的妻子和家人都不认识他。”托尔斯泰的评论非常正确：“值得注意的是，只有丈夫改变了他的外貌；”童话故事从未提及妇女在与丈夫分居期间外貌发生的变化”（第 517 页）。

Professor Tolstoy does not set out to investigate the origin of the motif. But in his work he has collected material that allows us to answer a question that is very important to us: where is the husband while the wife waits for him? Tolstoy proves very convincingly that the hero "has gone to the abode of death." In a fairy tale from Vyatka, the stay with the forest spirit lasts twelve years that fly by like twelve days. "A common fairy-tale motif of the transience of time in the regions of death, where in the consciousness of man a year passes as quickly as a day" (p. 517). In an Arkhangelsk fairy tale we find: "The pike swallowed Ivan; it carried him to the shore and spat him out. And Ivan went away" (Tolstoy, p. 517; Onch., p. 35), and so on. The stay inside an animal, as a mode of initiation, is already known to us. And there are other details that lead to the same result. "The husband returns changed; neither the wife nor the relatives recognize him." Tolstoy very rightly observes: "It is noteworthy that only the husband changes his appearance; the fairy tale never speaks of a change in the woman's appearance during her separation from her husband" (p. 517).

最后，正如教授所观察到的那样。托尔斯泰“他满头头发地回家，蓬头垢面，脏兮兮的，就像一个衣衫褴褛的朝圣者”（第516页），在这里我们也有一个“从森林”返回的明确迹象。

Finally, if, as Professor Tolstoy observes, "he returns home covered in hair, unkempt and dirty like a ragged pilgrim" (p. 516), then in this too we have a sure indication of his return "from the forest".

17.禁止自吹自擂。

17. The prohibition on boasting .

上面列出的原因并没有穷尽童话故事和“大房子”之间的联系。在这里，我们只选择了最不假设和最明显的案例。在假设的层面上，还可以提出“房屋”综合体与其他一些禁令之间的联系问题，特别是禁止吹嘘的原因和禁止储藏室的原因。

The above-mentioned motifs do not exhaust the connections between the fairy tale and the "big house". Here we have chosen only the least hypothetical and most obvious cases. On the level of hypothesis, the question of the connection between the complex of the "house" and some other prohibitions can also be raised, in particular the motif of the prohibition of boasting and that of the forbidden closet.

回来的人必须对他所看到和听到的一切保持深深的沉默。 « 乔布森看到一个前一天晚上从“肚子”里出来的男孩。我无法以任何方式让他张开嘴，男孩的一根手指放在他的嘴唇上” 233。在这里，我们很容易认识到童话故事中普遍存在的“沉默症”。正如弗罗贝尼乌斯指出的那样，这种沉默有时会持续一段特定的时间：它持续的天数与仪式持续的天数一样多。

The one who returns must maintain a profound silence about all that he has seen and heard. "Jobson saw a boy who had come out of the 'womb' the night before. He could not in any way make him open his mouth, the boy held a finger to his lips" 233 . Here it is easy to recognize the "mutism" so widespread in fairy tales. As Frobenius points out, this muteness sometimes lasts for a certain time: it lasts as many days as the rite lasts.

在德国童话故事中，从树林里的房子回来的女孩直到某个时刻才说话或笑（格林，9）。即使在我们的材料中，我们也发现了同样的现象：“当男孩醒来并站起来时，发现他没有舌头，他什么也说不了”（ZP 107）。

In German fairy tales the girl who returns from the house in the forest does not speak or laugh until a certain point (Grimm, 9). We also find the same phenomenon in our materials: "When the boy awoke and stood up, it turned out that he had no tongue, he could not say anything" (ZP 107).

这项禁令涉及在森林中看到和学到的一切。犯罪将受到死刑的惩罚：“现在你会明白，每一个生物都会说话；但要小心不要告诉任何人，如果你告诉了，你就会死”（Af. 139）。

This prohibition concerns everything seen and learned in the forest. Transgression is punishable by death: "Now you will understand that every creature speaks; but be careful not to tell anyone, if you tell, you will die" (Af. 139).

特别是，拥有在森林中收到的助手、仙物或护身符都被一种特殊而深刻的神秘所包围。这就是为什么在英雄回家之前，帮助者禁止他夸口：“小心，不要向任何人夸口说你骑过我，如果你夸口，我会压碎你”（Af. 135）。 “骑着我”这个形式只是“占有我”的一种更艺术的表达方式。 “你所知道的，你不能告诉任何人，如果你告诉了它，两分钟都不会过去，你就会死”（Chud.38）。 “不要夸耀我，不要夸耀因为你和我在一夜之间建造了这座房子”（AF.178）。 “如果你夸耀我，我不会饶恕你，我会吃掉你”（ZP 13）。

In particular, the possession of a helper, a magical object or a talisman received in the forest is surrounded by a particular and profound mystery. And this is why the helper, before the hero returns home, forbids him to boast: "Be careful, do not boast to anyone that you have ridden me, if you boast about it, I will crush you" (Af. 135). The form "of having ridden me" is simply a more artistic expression for "of possessing me". "What you know, you must not tell anyone, if you do, in two minutes you will be dead" (Chud. 38). "Do not boast about me, do not boast because you and I built the house in a single night" (Af. 178). "If you boast about me, I will not spare you, I will eat you" (ZP 13).

将这些禁令与帮助者的神秘联系在一起的联系是非常明显的。然而，诸如“忠实的仆人”之类的童话故事的禁令似乎不太明确。 “如果有人听到或得知此事，他将被用石头打跪”（Af. 43）。对童话故事中的禁令的研究可以成为一项特别调查的主题。特别是，不仅有必要研究禁令，而且有必要研究它们的违规行为。

The connection between these prohibitions and the mystery of the helper is perfectly clear. The prohibitions in fairy tales of the "faithful servant" type appear less clear. "If anyone hears this, or learns of it, he will be turned to stone up to his knees" (Af. 43). The study of prohibitions in fairy tales could be the subject of a special investigation. In particular, it would be necessary to study not only the prohibitions, but their transgression.

18.禁止的壁橱。

18. The forbidden closet .

与“大房子”相关的另一个主题是“禁止壁橱”的主题。在童话《神奇的衬衫》（Af. 120 b）中，据说英雄最初住在树林里，以树根和浆果为食，然后最终住在一座配有森林房屋常见配件的房子里。我们找到房间、是否有人居住、场所设置等。三兄弟化身动物住在里面：一只老鹰、一只老鹰和一只麻雀，它们可以变成勇敢的年轻人；他们“像真正的兄弟一样”欢迎客人，并指派他照顾餐桌。老鹰“给了他钥匙，允许他去任何地方，查看一切，只命令他不要碰挂在墙上的钥匙”。伊万自然地用禁止的钥匙打开衣柜，看到门后有一匹马。然后他就睡着了，一睡就是整整一年不间断的睡眠。事情重复了三遍。第三次之后，兄弟们把马给了他，他就离开了。

Another motif that is connected to that of the "big house" is the motif of the "forbidden closet". In the fairy tale The Miraculous Shirt (Af. 120 b) it is said that the hero lives at first in the forest, feeding on roots and berries, then ends up in a house with the usual accessories of forest houses. There we find the rooms, the absence of inhabitants, the tableware, etc. Three brothers in the guise of animals live there: an eagle, a hawk and a sparrow who can transform themselves into bold young men; they welcome the guest "like a true brother" and assign him the task of looking after the table. The eagle "gave him the keys, allowed him to go everywhere, to look at everything, only ordered him not to touch a key hanging on the wall". Naturally Ivan opens the closet with the forbidden key and sees a horse behind the door. Then he falls asleep and sleeps for a whole year in uninterrupted sleep. The story repeats itself three times. After the third time the brothers give him the horse and he goes away.

在故事中，一切都是绝对清楚的，它向我们表明，在这种情况下，英雄未来的帮手就位于禁室里。这个童话故事也很有趣，因为违反禁令不会引起任何冲突。从历史上看，这正是应该发生的事情。帮助者固有的禁令仅在某一时刻有效，直到“不间断的睡眠”，之后禁止的事情对于入会者来说变得允许。

In the story everything is absolutely clear, and it shows us that in this case the hero's future helper is in the forbidden room. The tale is also interesting because the transgression of the prohibition does not cause any conflict. Historically, this was exactly what was supposed to happen. The prohibition concerning the helper remained in force only up to a certain point, until the "uninterrupted sleep", after which what was forbidden became permitted for the initiate.

禁止的壁橱已经被研究过好几次了。哈特兰诚实地承认，“对流行童话的研究还不够先进，无法为我们提供将这些神话追溯到共同来源并以令人满意的方式解释其含义的可能性” 234。卡比根据当地习俗做出了解释，理由是有时会在禁室里发现一名女性。他认为，“东方房屋的平屋顶以及对妇女的隔离肯定造成了这种情况，这在东方几乎是常见的” 235。这样的比较是非常危险的。

The forbidden closet has been studied many times. Hartland honestly admits that "the study of folk tales has not yet advanced so far as to enable us to trace these myths back to a common source and to explain their meaning satisfactorily." 234 Kirby gives an explanation drawn from local custom, basing it on the fact that a woman is sometimes found in the forbidden room. He believes that "the flat roofs of Oriental houses together with the segregation of the woman must have created this situation, almost usual for the East." 235 Such a comparison is more than risky.

然而，上面引用的材料让我们推测，禁止储藏室也可以追溯到“大房子”建筑群。要判断是否如此，我们必须弄清楚那些房子里是否有禁止的房间，我们还必须问自己那里存放着什么。将得到的结果与童话故事的材料进行比较，我们不得不问自己：首先，这些禁忌的壁橱是如何布置和布置的；第二，它们包含什么。

However, the materials cited above lead us to suppose that the forbidden storeroom also dates back to the complex of the "big house". To decide whether or not this is the case, we must clarify whether there were forbidden rooms in those houses and we must also ask ourselves what was kept there. Comparing the results obtained with the material of the fairy tale, we must ask ourselves: first, how these forbidden storerooms are arranged and furnished; second, what they contain.

但此时我们遇到了一个困难：民族志为我们提供的对这些房屋的描述不完整。尽管如此，一系列细节表明类似禁地的存在。例如，我们知道，在斐济岛上，围墙内还有另一个较小的围墙，其中包括至圣所（das Allerheiligste）236。不过，并没有说明其中包含什么内容。但我们知道，这些现象并非斐济独有。众所周知，部落的神圣物品是禁止非入会者进入的，它们被保存在男人的家里。帕金森对此表示：“在岛上的一个特定地点，有一个地方，严格禁止所有非入门者进入。在这禁地之中，有十二个部门，每个部门都有自己的圣所。其中两座房子是如此神圣，以至于没有人能够进入或接近它们。其中，鸟类、鱼类、鳄鱼、鲨鱼以及人类、太阳和月亮的图像都保存在木头上雕刻» 237。

But here we run into a difficulty: the incomplete description of these houses that ethnography offers us. Nevertheless, a whole series of details indicate the presence of such forbidden places. We know, for example, that in the island of Fiji within the enclosure there was another, smaller one, which enclosed the Sancta Sanctorum ( das Allerheiligste ) 236 . However, it is not said what it contained. But we know that these phenomena are not peculiar to the island of Fiji alone. It is known that in the houses for men the sacred things of the tribe were kept, forbidden to the uninitiated. Parkinson says in this regard: "In a certain point of the island there was a place, access to which was most strictly forbidden to all uninitiated. Inside this forbidden space ( district ) there were twelve departments, each of which had its own sanctuary. Two of these houses were so sacred that no one had access to them or could approach them. In them were preserved, carved in wood, birds, fish, crocodiles, sharks, as well as images of men, the sun and the moon" 237 .

因此，我们知道存在特殊和禁止的房间，其中发现了木头雕刻的动物。这一事实在某种程度上构成了通往童话故事禁柜中的辅助动物的桥梁。此外，这些房间里还保存着太阳和月亮的图像。我们必须关注最后一点。

We know, therefore, of the existence of special and forbidden rooms, in which animals carved in wood were found. This fact constitutes in a certain way a bridge to the animal helper that was found in the forbidden closet of the fairy tale. Moreover, in those rooms were preserved images of the sun and the moon. On this last point we must dwell.

博阿斯提到了会议室的秘密房间。在夸扣特尔人中，入会仪式是在男人家里的一个特殊的秘密房间里进行的。新手在这里停留了很长一段时间，并且可能在那里经历了所有的仪式操作238。 “你接近秘密房间，伟大的巫师，你已经在那个房间里了”，其中一位入会者如此唱道239。显然，呆在那个房间里会让你成为巫师。这一点也得到了其他消息的证实。在仪式期间，入会者学习跳舞的房子里会表演舞蹈。房子里有一个更秘密的房间，前面画着一只乌鸦。乌鸦张开嘴，将起始者扔进去，经过一定时间（没有更好的指定）后，他被吐出来240。这个消息表明，在某些情况下，我们没有像上面看到的小茅屋和大房子，而是有一个大房子，里面有一个房间供印心用。而这正是“密室”。 “密室”这个名字并不完全恰当：它在启蒙之前只是新手的秘密，之后就不再是秘密了。

The secret rooms of the meeting houses are mentioned by Boas. Among the Kwakiutl the initiation took place in a special secret room in the men's houses. The neophyte remained there for a long time, and probably underwent all the ritual operations there . 238 "You approach the secret room, great sorcerer, you have been inside that room," one of the initiates sings . 239 Evidently the stay in that room makes one a sorcerer. This is confirmed by other reports. During the rite in the house a dance is performed which the initiate learns to dance. In the house there is a more secret room, on the front of which a crow is depicted. The crow opens its beak into which the initiate is thrown and after a certain time (not better specified) is spat out . 240 This news shows that in some cases we do not have the hut and the big house, as we saw above, but a big house with a room reserved for initiation. And it is precisely the "secret room". The denomination "secret room" is not entirely appropriate: it is a secret only for the neophyte before initiation, after which it ceases to be such.

现在让我们转向童话故事，问问自己禁忌的壁橱在哪里。对此，可注意以下几点：

And now let us turn to the fairy tale and ask ourselves where the forbidden closet is located. The following can be noted in this regard:

1）绝大多数情况下它是在“大房子”中找到的，上面我们已经给出了一个例子。让我们报道一下其他人：“兄弟俩走啊走，走近了：他们看到了一栋很大很大的房子。”这所房子的主人是Voron 241。 “他立即杀了他们两个，把他们放进地窖埋了，让他们精神起来，他们看起来还活着。”几年后，三弟也来了。沃隆没有杀他。 “看，”他告诉他，“这是钥匙，你可以去任何地方，但不要去第一个马厩或楼上的后面的房间”（SM.11）。 « 森林里矗立着一座房子，一座非常大的房子。他进去，看到一些金钥匙，但有一个房间是锁着的”（《SM》316）。这里不可能提及所有案例。只要注意到这种现象存在于童话故事中并且发生得非常频繁就够了。它展示了禁忌壁橱和大房子之间的联系。

1) In the vast majority of cases it is found in the "big house", and we have already given an example of this above. Let us give some others: "The brothers walk, walk and come closer: they see a big, very big house". The owner of this house is Voron 241 . "He killed them both at once, lowered them into the cellar and buried them, put them in alcohol, so that they seemed alive". A few years later the third brother also arrives. Voron does not kill him. "Listen," he says to him, "here are the keys, you can go anywhere, but do not go to the first stable or to the back room on the upper floor" (Sm. 11). "In the forest stands a house, a very big house. He enters, sees certain golden keys, but one room is locked" (Sm. 316). It is not possible to cite all the cases here. Suffice it to note that this phenomenon exists in fairy tales and that it occurs very frequently. It demonstrates the connection between the forbidden closet and the large house.

2) 即使在强盗的家里也有禁止进入的壁橱。例如，在白湖童话中，英雄最终进了强盗之家。一位老妇人把他藏在一个特殊的小房间里。他感觉他们想吃掉他。在地板上，他看到一扇活板门并抬起它：他看到一个地窖，一个装满死人的地窖（Sk.15）。这里，说实话，并没有什么禁令，只是有一个特殊的房间，里面放着尸体。这种房间的一个有趣的例子可以在托博尔斯克童话故事中找到。女孩最终进了强盗的房子。一位老人将她带到了地牢。地板是水晶制成的，有三间牢房，第一间是金子，第二间是银子，第三间是尸体。 “你会在这里找到你的死亡”（《SM》334）。在这个童话故事中，强盗们有着绿色的面孔。我们已经看到，强盗之家是大房子的变种。因此，这些例子也证实了禁止或指定壁橱的主题与“大房子”的联系。

2) There is also a forbidden room in the house of robbers. For example, in a tale from White Lake the hero ends up in the house of robbers. An old woman hides him in a special cubbyhole. He senses that they want to eat him. In the floor he sees a trapdoor and lifts it: he sees a dungeon, a new dungeon full of dead people (Sk. 15). Here, to tell the truth, there is no prohibition, but there is a special room with dead bodies. An interesting example of such a room can be found in a tale from Tobolsk. The girl ends up in the house of robbers. An old man leads her into a dungeon. The floor is made of glass, there are three cells, the first is full of gold, the second of silver, the third of corpses. "Here you will find your death" (Sm. 334). In this tale the robbers have green faces. We have already seen that the robber's house is a variety of the large house. Therefore these examples also confirm the connection of the motif of the forbidden or special storage room with the "large house".

3）禁止的壁橱是蓝胡子类型童话故事中一个典型且不可或缺的主题。我们在佩罗身上发现的形象在俄罗斯民间传说中是未知的，森林里的新郎有着动物的外表。在维亚特卡童话故事中，他是一只熊，熊说：“你可以进入两个房间，但不能进入第三个房间，因为第三个房间是用石灰树皮封闭的”（ZV 16）。一般来说（在俄罗斯童话故事中）禁室里的沥青沸腾了。女孩将手指浸入其中，“手指就从她的手上脱落”（Chud.58）。俄罗斯的材料并没有提供任何可靠的推论来让我们对这个童话做出判断。但在 Hartland 和 Kretschmer 的材料中，人们也可以收集到大量细节，表明与上述例子中发现的相同联系。除了缺失的手指之外，我们还发现了女主人公鸟般的外表、沾满烟灰的脸、四分五裂的尸体、死人的复活。这个童话故事的另一个特点是新郎的家位于树林深处。在《蓝胡子》中，克莱奇默承认了死亡之王。

3) The forbidden closet appears as a characteristic and indispensable motif in fairy tales of the Bluebeard type . The form we find in Perrault is unknown in Russian folklore, where the forest groom has an animal appearance. In a Vyatka fairy tale he is a bear, who says: "You may enter two rooms, but do not go into the third, which is closed by a linden bark" (ZV 16). Generally (in Russian fairy tales) in the forbidden room there is boiling pitch. The girl dips her finger in it "and the finger falls off her hand" (Chud. 58). The Russian material does not offer any certain deductions that would allow us to pass judgment on this fairy tale. But for it too, in the materials of Hartland and Kretschmer, numerous details can be gathered that indicate the same connection as in the examples cited above. In addition to the missing finger, we also find the heroine's bird-like appearance, the face smeared with soot, the dismembered bodies, the revivification of the dead. Another characteristic of this tale is the groom's dwelling located in the depths of the forest. Kretschmer sees Bluebeard as the lord of death.

4）禁柜的主题在智能科学类型的故事中很少遇到。在彼尔姆的童话故事中，父亲带着儿子在一所五百岁老人居住的房子里接受训练。房子里有七个房间；男孩不得进入第七个，但违反了禁令（ZP 1）。我们上面谈到了聪明科学的原因（III，24）。

4) The motif of the forbidden closet is encountered more rarely in tales of the type The Sly Science . In a Perm tale the father takes his son to do his apprenticeship in a house inhabited by a five-hundred-year-old man. There are seven rooms in the house; the boy must not enter the seventh, but the prohibition is transgressed (ZP 1). We have spoken about the motif of the sly science above (III, 24).

5）在另一个世界经常会遇到禁止的壁橱（格林，3）。在具有传奇性质的德国童话故事中，另一个世界甚至被称为“天堂”，在俄罗斯童话故事中，英雄最终去了教堂或教父的大房子里，只有一点一点地，我们才清楚地知道他是在教父的房子里。上帝，他的教父统治着世界（《诗篇》28）。教父告诉他：“你可以去所有的房间，只有一间你连看都不用看。”

5) The forbidden closet is often encountered in the other world (Grimm, 3). In German fairy tales of a legendary nature the other world is even called "heaven", in Russian fairy tales the hero ends up in church or in the great house of his godfather, and only gradually does he discover that he is in the house of God, that his godfather rules the world (Sm. 28). The godfather tells him: "You may go into all the rooms, only you must not even look into one."

这五种类型显然彼此相关，并且可以以某种方式追溯到与大房子相关的一组现象。在天堂里，就像在土匪家里一样，失去了一根手指，更多的时候手指上沾满了金子。因违反禁令而从异世界返回地球的少女，会在一定时间内失去语言能力等。

These five types are all manifestly related to each other and can in one way or another be traced back to the group of phenomena connected with the great house. In heaven, just as in the house of robbers, a finger is lost, and more often the finger is covered with gold. The girl who returns to earth from the other world for having transgressed a prohibition, loses for a certain time the gift of speech, etc.

不过，这并不代表储藏室被禁止的原因就一定要追溯到林宅建筑群。有些形式显然与这个复合体无关。它们有以下几种形式：

However, this does not mean that the motif of the forbidden closet, as such, must be traced back to the complex of forest houses. There are forms that have manifestly nothing to do with this complex. They are the following forms:

6) 禁止的壁橱从故事一开始就出现在父亲的家里。房间的秘密一直保留到英雄的父亲去世为止。临死时，父亲将所有房间的钥匙托付给儿子或忠实的仆人，但禁止他们打开其中一间，英雄后来在其中发现了一位异常美丽的女人的肖像（格林，6）。

6) The forbidden closet appears at the very beginning of the story, in the father's house. The secret of the room is kept until the hero's father dies. When he dies, the father entrusts the keys to all the rooms to his son or to a faithful servant, but forbids opening one, in which the hero later finds the portrait of a woman of extraordinary beauty (Grimm, 6).

7) 有时，禁柜的原因是婚姻的原因；在这种情况下，壁橱里住着一条蛇或Košcej。他带着英雄的妻子飞走了（Af.94）。

7) Sometimes the motif of the forbidden closet follows that of marriage; in this case the closet is inhabited by a serpent or by Košcej. He flies away, taking the hero's wife with him (Af. 94).

我们只提到了最重要、最常出现的群体。一项特殊研究（特别是从俄罗斯材料开始）可以确定其他一些群体的存在。然而，情况开始变得光明。后两个案例的历史真实性暂时无法考证，只能假设它们是一种艺术创作的结果，通过将母题移至故事的开头，并以此为动机来表达。剧情：主人公看到肖像，开始寻找。故事的原理，特别是它的动机，是一个非常不稳定的部分。妻子宫殿里的房间也是如此：违反禁令释放了带走妻子的蛇，从而引发了英雄的搜索，也就是说，一个复杂的情况和一个新的情节被创造出来，妻子的失踪以及对她的搜寻。这里可能还隐藏着其他与婚姻禁令有关的东西，类似于丘比特和普赛克中发现的东西。

We have mentioned only the most important groups, those that recur most frequently. A special study (especially starting from Russian material) could establish the existence of some other groups. However, the picture is beginning to become clear. The historicity of the last two cases cannot yet be proved, and all that remains is to assume that they are the result of an artistic creation that manifests itself by transposing the motif to the beginning of the story, and using it as a motivation for the plot: seeing the portrait, the hero sets out on a search. The beginning of the story, and especially its motivation, is a very unstable part. The same applies to the room in the wife's palace: the transgression of the prohibition releases the serpent that carries off the wife, and thereby provokes the hero's search, that is, a complication and a new plot are created, the disappearance of the wife and her search are created. It may be that something else is hidden here, connected with marital prohibitions, similar to those found in Cupid and Psyche .

现在我们将简要研究问题的另一个方面，即房间的内容。从其位置和内容的角度来看，这间卧室的类型之间并不总是存在稳定的关系，这方面必须对其本身进行研究。使用哈特兰的材料，可以初步列出在小隔间中发现的物品。

We will now briefly examine another aspect of the problem, namely the contents of the rooms. There is not always a stable relationship between the type of this little room, in terms of its location, and its contents, and this aspect must be studied separately. Using Hartland's materials, it is possible to make a preliminary list of what is found in the cubbyhole.

除了动物帮手（通常是一匹马、一只狗、一只鹰、一只乌鸦）之外，储藏室里还有被链子锁着的蛇、各种恐怖的东西、四分五裂的尸体、半死不活的人（强盗的首领，他还没有完全康复）。被杀）、骨头、断手断脚、血、血盆、带斧头的木块等。在传奇童话中，这些恐怖被转化为对罪人的折磨（英雄看到他的母亲在火轮上等），或对神性的折磨（被活活钉在十字架上）。也许英雄有时看到的火、太阳、天体三位一体也是非常古老的：我们已经看到，在人类住宅的禁室中保存着太阳和月亮的图像。其他一切我们都已经知道了。我们已经研究过将入会仪式与分营主题联系起来的联系。在这方面，我们注意到，在这些情况下，被分遣的人往往会再次复活，因为储藏室里还有神奇的药膏。

In addition to the animal helper (usually a horse, a dog, an eagle, a crow), in the storeroom are found chained serpents, horrors of all kinds, quartered bodies, half-dead men (the leader of the robbers who was not completely killed), bones, amputated hands and feet, blood, a bloody basin, a block with an axe, etc. In the legendary tales these horrors are transformed into tortures of sinners (the hero sees his mother on a wheel of fire, etc.), or into tortures of the divinity (crucified alive). It may be that the fire, the sun, the celestial trinity which the hero sometimes sees, are also very ancient: we have seen that in the forbidden rooms of men's houses images of the sun and the moon were preserved. Everything else is already known to us. We have already examined the connection between the rite of initiation and the motif of quartering; We note in this regard that in these cases the quartered often come back to life, since there are also magic ointments in the storeroom.

最后，一个单独的组由包含女性的小房间组成（美丽的女孩被剥夺了翅膀或衣服，被绑着，口渴，或者只是美丽的女孩或肖像）。由于缺乏相应的民族志材料，目前不可能与男人的房屋建立任何直接联系。然而，让我们记住，根据弗雷泽的材料，在男人的房子里，女人住在特殊的房间里，男人不能进入。这里可能反映出尚未充分分析的婚姻禁令。一般来说，英雄发现禁柜里的女人后，就会娶她。暂时禁止结婚的规定随着结婚而结束。因此，虽然不能证实禁止壁橱的童话主题与男性家庭制度之间存在联系的假设，但本案并不与之相矛盾。

Finally, a separate group is formed by cubbyholes containing women (beautiful girls deprived of wings or clothes, tied up, thirsty, or simply beautiful girls or a portrait). At the moment it is not possible to establish any direct connection with the houses for men, in the absence of corresponding ethnographic materials. However, let us recall that, according to Frazer's materials, in the houses for men women lived in special rooms, where men did not enter. Here there could be a reflection of marital prohibitions that have not yet been fully analyzed. Usually after discovering the woman in the forbidden closet, the hero marries her. The temporary prohibition on marriage ends with the wedding. Therefore, although this case does not confirm the hypothesis of the connection between the fairy-tale motif of the forbidden closet and the institution of the houses for men, it does not contradict it.

19.结论。

19. Conclusion .

正如我们所看到的，一方面，入会仪式和在男人家里的住宿之间的巧合，另一方面，在树林里的小木屋和“大房子”中发生的事情，令人惊讶。将这个类比归因于我们的阐述，而不是一个实质性的类比，难道不合适吗？我们是否可能选择并掌握了入会仪式的一些特征，其主要目的是使它们类似于童话故事的主题？当类比过于完整时，这种怀疑是完全有道理的。但这里的对应不是细节，而是涉及入会仪式过程的本质及其外部属性和附件。

As we see, the coincidence between the rite of initiation and the stay in the men's house, on the one hand, and what happens in the little hut in the woods and in the "big house" on the other, is surprising. Would it not be appropriate to attribute this analogy to our exposition, rather than to a substantial analogy? Have we perhaps chosen and seized upon some characteristics of the rites of initiation with the specific aim of making them analogous to the motifs of the fairy tale? Such a suspicion is entirely justified when the analogy is too complete. But here the correspondence is not in the details, it concerns the very essence of the process of the rite of initiation and its external attributes and accessories.

但是，当然，童话故事和仪式并不完全一致。因此，举例来说，童话故事中有一些无法用仪式来解释的特殊之处：其中一个主题是英雄与女巫或食人魔的女儿交换位置，以便她受到原本打算的致命一击。飞行的英雄。另一个令人费解的细节是女孩沉默的原因，通过这个原因，英雄恢复了人类的外表。

But, of course, the fairy tale and the rite do not coincide completely. Thus, for example, there are certain peculiarities in the fairy tale that cannot be explained by the rite: among others, the motif of the hero who changes places with the daughter of the witch or the ogre, so that she receives the fatal blow intended for the hero, who takes flight. Another inexplicable detail is the motif of the girl's silence, through which the hero regains his human appearance.

另一方面，仪式自然比童话故事更广泛，而后者并没有反映全部。因此，举例来说，童话故事似乎没有包含任何对男性社会曾经施加的政治影响的回忆。然而，必须指出的是，在领袖形象已经形成的地方，男性社团仅代表官方的一部分，作为组织，他们没有权威。童话中，除了“兄弟”（政治无能）之外，还有“国王”，即历史上存在的一种情况。

On the other hand, the rite is, of course, broader than the fairy tale, and the latter does not reflect it entirely. Thus, for example, the fairy tale does not seem to contain any reminiscence of the political influence once exercised by male societies. However, it must be said that where the figure of the leader had already come into being, the male societies no longer represented anything more than an official part and, as organizations, had no authority. In the fairy tale, apart from the "brothers" (politically impotent), there is also the "king", that is to say, a situation that existed historically.

毫无疑问，并不是所有的联系都已经被发现，也不是所有的事情都已经被发现。但研究必须继续的方向已经找到了，而且这项研究可以产生显着的成果。

It is beyond doubt that not all connections have been found, not everything has been discovered. But the direction in which research must continue has been found, and this research can yield significant results.

二.来自坟墓之外的捐助者

II. Donors from beyond the grave

20.死去的父亲。

20. The dead father .

我们已经研究了与男性启蒙制度和住房有关的整个复杂现象。

We have examined the whole complex of phenomena connected with the institution of initiation and men's houses.

但是，当然，假设这个机构是童话故事产生的唯一基础是不准确的。研究所消亡了，主题却继续形成，历史气候的变化也带来了正在创建的主题生命的变化。

But, of course, it would be incorrect to believe that this institute is the sole basis from which the fairy tale was born. The institute has become extinct, while the theme continued to form and the changed historical climate introduced changes also in the life of the theme that was being created.

女巫是最古老的，但绝不是童话故事的唯一捐赠者。与捐赠者一起，礼物的对象也发生变化，交付礼物的环境也发生变化。但是，尽管如此，连接还没有完全丢失。这首先可以从新的捐赠者捐赠女巫捐赠的东西这一事实中看出：他们捐赠了一个帮手，不再是森林动物而是一匹马，同样的礼物也被追溯归属于女巫。其次，新的捐赠者也重新与死亡领域和祖先的世界建立联系。

The witch is the oldest, but by no means the only giver in the fairy tale. The object of the gift changes with the giver, and the circumstances in which it is given change. But the connection has not yet been completely lost. This is seen firstly from the fact that the new givers give what the witch gave: they give a helper, who is no longer a forest animal but a horse, and the same gift is retrospectively attributed to the witch as well. Secondly, the new givers also reconnect with the realm of death and the world of the ancestors.

作为森林精灵的捐赠者变得难以理解；他被一位男性捐赠者（祖先）取代。我们已经看到，女术士也与图腾祖先有联系，但是图腾祖先，正如我们所看到的，曾经与女性血统的继承联系在一起，随着向男性继承的过渡，被父亲、祖父和祖先所取代。曾祖父。因此，女巫被她死去的父亲取代，他把马交给英雄，不是在森林里，也不是在小屋里，而是从坟墓里。另一方面，送礼的对象也发生了变化。真正的女巫指挥着野生动物，她是狩猎习俗和制度的反映，我们在童话故事中看到了这一点：女巫召集了狼、熊、鸟，并将它们分配给英雄作为助手。野生动物被其他动物所取代，首先是被动物所取代，即使穿着服装，它也开始在武士的生活中扮演如此重要的角色，即马。因此，马的礼物被认为是女巫的礼物。但这匹马的历史不如女巫那么古老。它不是森林中的生物，而是乡村中的生物，在那里你不会从灌木丛后面射击敌人，而是英雄战士们手持剑进行公开战斗。

The donor as a forest spirit becomes incomprehensible; he is replaced by a male donor, an ancestor. We have already seen that the sorceress also connects herself to the totemic ancestors, but the totemic ancestor, once connected as we have seen with the succession in the female line, with the transition to the male succession is replaced by the father, the grandfather and the great-grandfather. Thus the sorceress is replaced by the dead father, who gives the horse to the hero not in the forest, nor in the hut, but from the grave. On the other hand, the object of the gift also changes. The true, authentic sorceress commands the wild animals, she is a reflection of the custom and the regime of hunting and we see this in the fairy tale: the sorceress calls together the wolves, the bears, the birds and assigns them to the hero as helpers. The wild animals are replaced by others, and first of all by the animal which also in the custom begins to play such an important part in the life of the warrior, namely the horse. Thus the gift of the horse is attributed to the sorceress. But the horse is less ancient than the sorceress. It is not a creature of the forest, it is a creature of the countryside, where one does not shoot the enemy from behind a bush, but where warrior-heroes meet in open combat with sword in hand.

你可能会发现父子之间有着深厚而神秘的联系。这种联系的神秘本质体现在伊万需要的不是与他活着的父母，而是与已故或垂死的父母之间的牢固联系。在童话故事中，活着的父母的形象相当可怜，他们的无能也迫使伊万离开。已故父亲的形象在故事中显得更加强大。

It can be discovered that there is a deep and mysterious connection between father and son. The mysterious nature of this connection is manifested by the fact that Ivan needs a strong bond not with his living parents, but with his dead or dying ones. In the fairy tale, the living parents cut a rather pitiful figure, their impotence is also what forces Ivan to leave. The figure of the dead father is all the more powerful in the tale.

这个数字最引人注目的例子可以在Sivko-Burko童话 242中找到，其中我们读到：“在临死之际，父亲说：“孩子们！我死后，轮流到我坟前睡三夜”而死。老人被埋葬了。夜幕降临，轮到哥哥睡在坟墓上，但半是出于懒惰，半是出于恐惧，他对弟弟说：“伊万-格鲁洛！去你父亲的坟墓，在我那里过夜。反正你也没什么事可做！ ”伊万·格鲁洛出发，到达坟墓并躺下：半夜，坟墓突然打开，老人出来问道：“谁在那儿？你是最大的孩子吗？ ——不，爸爸！我是伊万·格鲁洛。”老人认出了他，问道：“大儿子怎么没来？ ——他派我来的，父亲！ - 出色地。你的运气！ ” 老者吹着口哨，吹着响亮的口哨：“西夫科-布尔科，乌鸦-乌鸦！ “西夫科跑得快，让大地颤抖，他的眼睛里冒出火花，鼻孔里冒出一柱烟。 “我的儿子，你是一匹好马！而你，马，请像服务我一样服务他！ “说完这句话，老人就躺在坟墓里了”（Af. 105 a）。

The most striking example of this figure is found in the fairy tale Sivko-Burko 242 , where we read: "On his deathbed, the father said: 'Children! When I am dead, take turns to sleep on my grave for three nights in a row,' and he died. The old man was buried. Night comes: it is the elder brother's turn to sleep on the grave, but partly out of laziness and partly out of fear, he says to the younger one: 'Ivan-Silly! Go to your father's grave and spend the night in my place. You have nothing to do anyway!' Ivan-Silly set out, reached the grave and lay down. At midnight, suddenly the grave opens, the old man comes out and asks: 'Who is there? Are you the eldest son? — No, father! I am Ivan-Silly.' The old man recognizes him and asks: 'Why didn't the eldest son come?' — He sent me, father! — Well, your luck! „ The old man whistled, whistled with a loud whistle: “ Sivko-Burko, Raven-Raven! „ Sivko runs fast, makes the earth tremble, sparks fly from his eyes, a column of smoke comes from his nostrils. “ Here you are, my son, a good horse! And you, horse, serve him as you have served me! „ Having said this, the old man lay down in the grave » (Af. 105 a).

英雄的美德在于什么，或者为死者提供的服务在于什么？他为何捐献一匹马？很明显，童话故事在这里遗漏了一些东西，链条中缺少了一个环节，必须重新构建它才能充分理解这个主题。

In what does the virtue of the hero consist, or in what does the service rendered to the dead consist? Why does the latter give a horse? It is clear that here the fairy tale omits something, here a link in the chain is missing and it must be reconstituted to fully understand this motif.

在这方面可以提出两个假设，它们不是排他性的，而是相辅相成的。两者均已得到材料证实。当然，这并不是简单地“坐在”坟墓上的问题；而是一个简单的“坐”在坟墓上的问题。对于死者来说，这种崇拜行为太乏味了，不可能是原始的。在这种情况下，童话否定了最初庆祝的祭祀和安抚仪式。他确实否认了它们，但并非完全否认。因此，例如，我们在童话故事（Sm.306）中读到：“当他们的母亲去世时，兄弟俩各得到一头牛。伊万·格鲁洛牵着他的牛走进埋葬他母亲的树林。他牵着她说：“妈妈，你需要牛吗？ “是的，我需要它，”母亲回答道，“把它绑在这里！” „ » 显然，这是一个非常古老的案例。首先，森林仍然存在；其次，英雄去母亲的坟墓，这个古老的案例也为我们保留了他此行的目的：他带着牛去母亲的坟墓。

Two hypotheses can be formulated in this connection, which do not exclude each other, but complement each other. Both are confirmed by the materials. Here, of course, it is not a question of simply "sitting" on the grave; this is too insipid an act of the cult in suffrage of the dead to be primordial. In this case the fairy tale has repudiated the sacrificial and propitiatory rites that were originally celebrated; it has repudiated them, it is true, but not entirely. Thus, for example, we read in a fairy tale (Sm. 306): "When the mother died, each of the brothers was given a cow. Ivan-Grullo took his cow and led her into the forest where his mother was buried. He led her and said: 'Mother, do you need the cow? ' 'Yes, I do, ' replied the mother, 'tie her here! ' " This is clearly a very archaic case. In the first place, the forest still figures; secondly, the hero goes to his mother's grave, and this archaic case has also preserved for us the purpose of his journey: he takes the cow to his mother's grave.

根据这些材料和已经引用的其他材料，父亲的祈祷可以翻译如下：“到我的坟墓来做出必要的牺牲。”

In light of these materials and those already cited, the father's prayer can be translated as follows: "Come to my tomb to make the sacrifice due to you."

但这并不能说明或解释一切。死者为何需要祭品？如果不进行祭祀，即死者的饥饿没有得到满足，他就不得安宁，就会以鬼魂的形式回到人间。这就是生者和死者所恐惧的，这就是死者所激发的恐怖的基础。我们看到，哥哥们其实害怕上坟，他们害怕死人。由此产生了第二个假设：坐在坟墓上是一种辟邪行为。这个假设得到了一些童话故事和其他民族志材料的证实，非常接近我们的童话故事：“孩子们，如果我死了，请看守我的坟墓三个晚上。”父亲以一条可怕的蛇的形式从坟墓中出现，英雄杀死了他，挖掘了坟墓并发现了一匹马、一把剑和一支步枪243。

But this does not say or explain everything. Why does the dead need sacrifices? If the sacrifice is not made, if, that is, the dead man's hunger is not satisfied, he will have no peace and will return as a ghost to the world of the living. This is what the living and the dead fear, this is what the terror that the dead inspire is based on. We see that the older brothers are actually afraid of going to the grave, they are afraid of the dead. From this arises the second hypothesis: sitting on the grave is a form of apotropeic act. The hypothesis is confirmed by some fairy-tale and other ethnographic materials, very close to our fairy tale: "Children, if I die, watch over my grave for three nights." The father comes out of the grave in the form of a terrible serpent, the hero kills it, digs up the grave and finds a horse, a sword and a gun . 243

在俄罗斯童话剧目中，有一些案例，其中死者选举权仪式的誓言没有实现，死者又回来了（Onč.45）：“从前有一个农民，住在一个荒芜的地方。地点：他有两个小儿子，一个在婴儿床上，另一个是一岁的儿子和一个三岁的女孩。他对他的主妇说：“明天我就死了，你躺在圣像下给我上香三天。”丈夫死了，妻子称赞他两天，第三天就忘记了。三岁的小女孩走到妈妈跟前说：“妈妈，妈妈，爸爸又活过来了，他能坐起来了！ ——你在说什么，笨蛋？ “他坐着”，但他死了！ ” 家庭主妇一看：丈夫正坐在长凳上用磨刀石磨牙。女人抓住两个男孩，跳到炉子上，小女孩留在地板上。死者从婴儿床上撕下尿布并吞下它们，还吞下了婴儿。”

In the Russian fairy tale repertoire there are cases when the vow of the deceased's suffrage is not fulfilled, and the dead man returns (Onč. 45): « Once upon a time there was a peasant who lived in a deserted place: he had two little sons, one in the cradle, the other one year old, and a three-year-old girl. He said to his housewife: “Tomorrow I will die, lie me down under the holy image and incense me for three days”. The husband died, the wife incensed him for two days and forgot about it on the third day. And the three-year-old girl goes to her mother and says: “Mummy, mummy, father is alive again, he is sitting down! — What are you saying, stupid? 'He is sitting down', but he is dead! ' The housewife takes a look: the husband is sitting on the bench and sharpening his teeth with the whetstone. The woman grabbed the two boys and jumped on the stove, the baby girl remained on the floor. The deceased tore the diapers from the cradle and devoured them and also devoured the baby girl.

基督教为死者选举权的祈祷就是基于此。即使在童话故事中，死者也总是试图复活（参见Vij）。在我们的童话故事中，主人公经常去坟墓“背诵祈祷文”。

This is the basis of Christian prayer for the deceased. Even in fairy tales the dead always try to come back to life (cf. Vij ). In our fairy tale the hero often goes to the grave to "recite prayers".

民族志资料也得出同样的结果。我们去“坐在”坟墓上，迫使死者在他或她离开时回去。这个事实自古以来就已被观察到。例如，冯·登·斯坦宁讲述了在帕雷西印第安人中，当有人去世时，他们的亲戚会在他的坟墓前度过六天，并进行非常严格的禁食。 “如果在这六天内死者没有复活，他们就不再守夜，因为死者已经到达了另一个世界” 244。同样的事情也发生在巴布亚湾（新几内亚南部）。死者的大女婿在那里看守坟墓五天五夜。他时不时地站起来，在空中挥舞双手，尖叫着将死者的灵魂从尸体中驱逐出去。第五天结束时，亲戚们来了。如果相信鬼魂仍然存在，则通过一起喊叫将其赶走245。

Ethnographic materials also lead to the same conclusion. People go and "sit" on the grave to force the deceased to go back in if he comes out. This fact has been observed since the most remote times. Thus, for example, Von den Steinen tells that among the Paressi Indians when someone dies, the relatives spend six days on his grave, observing a very rigorous fast. "If within these six days the dead person has not returned to life, they cease to keep vigil, because the deceased has already arrived in the other world." 244 The same thing happens in the Gulf of Papua (Southern New Guinea). There the eldest son-in-law of the deceased keeps vigil at the grave for five days and five nights. From time to time he stands up, waves his hands in the air and shouts to expel the spirit of the deceased from the corpse. At the end of the fifth day the relatives arrive. If it is believed that the spirit is still present, they chase it away by shouting together . 245

这些“会议”的辟邪特征是显而易见的。从这个事实出发，我们可以假设，父亲提议去坟墓也是为了确保他来世的平安。

The apotropeic character of these "sessions" is clear. Starting from this fact, one can assume that the father's proposal to go to his grave also aims to ensure his peace in the afterlife.

最后，死者赠马的主题也有历史依据：祖先的代表，他们强大，因为他们在另一个世界，所有的原则都来自那里。生者不会像入会仪式那样尝试进入来世。神奇的帮手是死者的礼物。这种信念的种子在非常原始的阶段就已经存在。在上述新几内亚南部的例子中，尸体腐烂后，头骨被移走，涂上颜色，放在家里，并向它祈祷。在吉尔伯特群岛，当地人负责埋葬，但有时他们会移走骨头并用它们制作鱼钩和其他捕鱼工具246。为了强迫死去的母亲帮他钓鱼，印第安人躺在她的坟墓上，睡在那里，并禁食了几天247。在这些情况下，这些表述的经济基础是显而易见的。只要向前迈出一步，你就会看到死者给予仙物或直接帮助生者，正如我们稍后将在感恩的死者的主题中看到的那样。在北美，“在狩猎季节开始时，猎人会拜访他父亲或叔叔的坟墓，清除其中的杂草，并祈祷如下：‘我已经清理了你的坟墓。’”明天我要去森林，打猎……森林不是村庄，它是死亡之地。让他狩猎成功，或者平安归来”» 248 .

Finally, there is also a historical basis in the motif of the dead man giving the horse: the representation of the ancestors, who are strong because they are in the other world, from which all the principles come. The living man does not try to penetrate into the afterlife, as happens in the rite of initiation. The magical helper is a gift from the dead man. The germs of this belief already exist in very primitive stages. In the case of southern New Guinea mentioned by us, after the corpse has decomposed, the skull is removed, painted, kept in the house and prayers are addressed to it. In the Gilbert Islands the natives take care of the burials, but sometimes they remove the bones and make hooks and other fishing tools from them . 246 In order to force his dead mother to help him in fishing, the Indian lies down on her grave, sleeps there and fasts for a few days . 247 In these cases the economic basis of such representations is evident. One step further and one arrives at the deceased who gives a magical object or directly helps the living, as we will see later in the motif of the grateful dead. In North America, "at the beginning of the hunting season the hunter visits the grave of his father or of a paternal uncle, clears it of weeds and prays more or less in these terms: 'I have cleared your grave. Tomorrow I will go into the forest, to hunt... The forest is not a village, it is the place of death. May I be successful in the hunt, or may I return safe and sound.' " 248 .

我们分析了从坟墓中赐予一匹马的父亲。但可以看出，他并不是唯一的捐赠者。我们将研究其他类似的案例，最初仅参考童话故事材料，而不为每个单独的群体绘制历史相似之处，随后我们将尝试对整个死亡捐赠者群体做出一些解释。

We have analyzed the father who gives a horse from the grave. But it may be noted that he is not the only donor. We will examine other similar cases, referring at first only to the material of the fairy tale, without drawing historical parallels for each individual group, and in a second time we will try to give some explanation for the whole group of dead donors.

有时，将仙车交付给儿子的原因隐藏在真实的舞台中，以与服装保持一致。父亲给孩子们留下了遗产。 “当老人去世时，他把钱分给了他的孩子们：他给了最年长的一百卢布，中间的男人又给了一百卢布，他不想给这个白痴任何东西，这会钱被扔掉了”（AF.123）。但白痴索要他的份额，得到了它，并用这笔钱买了一只猫和一只狗，后来证明它们是神奇的帮手。通过这种方式，在垂死的父亲的帮助下，尽管是间接的，但神奇的帮手还是获得了。

Sometimes the reason for giving the half-fairy to the son is shrouded in a real, customary staging. The father leaves his sons an inheritance. "When the old man's time to die came, he divided the money among his sons: to the eldest he gave a hundred rubles, to the middle one another hundred rubles, to the simpleton he did not want to give anything, it would have been money thrown away" (Af. 123). But the simpleton asks for his share, gets it, and with this money he buys a cat and a dog, who later turn out to be magical helpers. In this way, here too, the magical helper is obtained, albeit indirectly, with the help of the dying father.

21.死去的母亲。

21. The dead mother .

同样，在以女孩为主角的童话故事中，母亲是为她提供帮助的人。 « 在临死之际，商人把女儿叫到身边，从毯子下拿出一个布娃娃，递给她，并说道：“听着，瓦西里苏斯卡！记住并按照我告诉你的去做。我死了，带着我母亲的祝福，我给你留下了这个娃娃；始终随身携带，不要让任何人看到；当你遇到任何麻烦时，请喂她并询问她的建议。她会吃东西并告诉你如何补救不幸”（Af. 59）。

Similarly, in fairy tales featuring a young girl, it is the mother who gives her the helper. "On the point of death, the merchant's wife called her daughter to her, took a doll from under the blanket, gave it to her and said: 'Listen, Vasilísuška! Remember and do what I tell you. I am dying and together with my motherly blessing I leave you this doll; keep it always with you and do not let anyone see it; and when you are in trouble, feed it and ask its advice. It will eat and tell you how to remedy the misfortune.' " (Af. 59).

这个雕像是女孩的神奇帮手。她的母亲经常把她从坟墓里救出来。在故事《猪鞘》中，父亲爱上了他的女儿并想娶她。 “她去了墓地，去了她母亲的坟墓，然后开始可怜兮兮地哭起来。”她妈妈对她说：“让我给你买一件镶满星星的衣服。”女孩服从了，但父亲却更加疯狂地爱着她。然后她妈妈建议她要一件有太阳和月亮的衣服。 “妈咪，爹地更爱我了。”然后她建议她要求为她做一个猪鞘。 “她的父亲向她脸上吐口水，并将她赶出家门”（AF. 161 a）。众所周知，即使在童话《Zoluška》中，母亲也将女儿从坟墓中救了出来。

This figure is the girl's magical helper. Very often the mother helps her from the grave. In the tale The Pig's Sheath the father falls in love with his daughter and wants to marry her. "She went to the cemetery, to her mother's grave, and began to cry piteously." The mother said to her: "Buy yourself a dress that is all embroidered with stars." The girl obeys, but the father falls even more madly in love with her. Then the mother suggests that she ask for a dress with the sun and the moon. "Mummy, daddy is even more in love with me." Then the mother suggests that she ask for a pig's sheath to be made for her. "The father spat in her face and threw her out of the house" (Af. 161 a). In the tale Zoluška , as is known, the mother also helps her daughter from the grave.

即使在斯温加德的歌曲《埃达》中，英雄也对他的母亲说道：

Even in Svingarde's song in the Edda , the hero addresses his mother:

格罗阿，醒来吧，亲爱的！

Groa, wake up. Wake up, beloved!

在死者的世界里听我说，母亲！

From the world of the dead, hear me, mother!

记住你命令我来

Remember that you ordered me to come

到埋葬你的土丘寻求帮助。

On the mound where you are buried to ask for help.

她给了她儿子十个咒语。

And she gives her son ten spells.

22.感恩的死者。

22. The grateful dead .

最后，每一个接受服务的死者都可以履行同样的功能。例如，在阿布哈兹童话故事中，讲述了英雄如何参加葬礼。 « 死者已经被带到墓地。他看到一些人用脖子上系着绳子拖着死者，而其他参加葬礼的人则用长长的干树枝殴打死者。”商人的儿子得知死者在没有偿还债务的情况下去世，他向债权人付款249。然而，这无疑是最近对主题处理的合理化。在俄罗斯童话中，英雄只是埋葬了死者，从而获得了死者的帮助。 Liljeblad 250研究了这个主题。但不幸的是，他的推论并不正确，首先是因为不存在“关于感恩的死者”的童话故事。 Liljeblad 将几种类型放在一起，并尝试从整体上研究这些材料。这个错误源于这样一个事实：他从一个错误的前提开始，即每个童话主题最初都与童话故事相关。实际上，具有相同形态意义的图案绝大多数是可以相互替换的，并且所有的供体也是可以相互替换的。利杰布拉德只发现了八个关于“感恩的死者”的俄罗斯童话，但感恩的死者在各种各样的童话故事中出现的频率要高得多。尽管我只报告了实际存在的材料的极小部分，但我将要引用的案例都没有被 Liljeblad 提及。此外，利杰布拉德仅限于比较文本，根本没有触及感恩的死者的问题。

And finally, every dead person to whom a service is rendered can fulfill the same function. In an Abkhazian tale, for example, it is told how the hero happens to be present at a funeral. "The dead person had already been carried to the cemetery. And then he sees some people dragging the dead person around with a rope tied around his neck, and others who had attended the funeral were beating the dead person with long dry branches." The merchant's son learns that the dead person died without having paid his debts, and he pays the creditors . 249 This is, however, undoubtedly a more recent rationalization than the treatment of the motif. In Russian tales the hero simply buries the dead person and thereby acquires a helper in the person of the dead person. This motif has been studied by Liljeblad . 250 Unfortunately, however, the conclusions he draws are not correct, first of all because there are no tales "about grateful dead people." Liljeblad puts together some types and tries to study this material as a whole. The mistake arises from the fact that he starts from the false premise that every fairy-tale motif is originally linked to a fairy tale. In reality, motifs having the same morphological meaning are in their overwhelming majority interchangeable, and all donors are also interchangeable. Liljeblad found only eight Russian fairy tales about the "grateful dead", but the grateful dead are encountered much more frequently and in the most varied fairy tales. None of the cases I am about to cite are mentioned by Liljeblad, although I report only a minimal part of the actually existing material. Furthermore, Liljeblad limits himself to comparing texts alone and does not touch on the problem of the grateful dead at all.

在返老还童的苹果故事的一个变体中，女术士建议英雄：“上路吧，伊凡国王！”这是一个村庄，村庄附近有一座山，山上有一个勇敢的人，像狗一样躺在地上；去询问牧师是否可以埋葬这个勇敢的人。他有一匹马锁在十二个铁门后面，十二个铜锁后面。”伊凡国王实际上埋葬了这位勇敢的人，并为他举办了豪华的葬礼。 « 死者对他说：“年轻的伊凡国王，我感谢您给了我一个体面的葬礼，我把我的马给了您”（Af. 104 f）。在童话故事中，掘墓人会争吵、互相侮辱，并且不想埋葬死者。这个死人后来成为英雄的助手（Sm.86）。在Sivko-Burko的变体中，三个勇敢的人代替了父亲。这些英雄都是伊万的前辈。他们未能跳到公主的窗户上，因此被斩首。伊凡埋葬了他们，并收到三匹马作为礼物：一匹是铜制的，另一匹是银制的，第三匹是金制的（《诗篇》9）。

In a variant of the tale of the rejuvenating apples, the sorceress advises the hero: "Set out, young King Ivan! Here is a village, near the village a mountain, on this mountain a brave man lies on the ground like a dog; go and ask the priests if you can bury this brave man. He has a horse locked behind twelve iron gates, behind twelve copper locks." Young King Ivan does indeed bury the brave man and orders a sumptuous funeral for him. "And the dead man says to him: 'I thank you, young King Ivan, for having given me an honorable burial, and I give you my horse' " (Af. 104 f). There are tales in which the gravediggers quarrel, insult each other and do not want to bury the dead man. This dead man later becomes the hero's helper (Sm. 86). In a variant of Sivko-Burko, three brave men appear instead of the father. These heroes are Ivan's predecessors. They failed to jump to the princess's window and were therefore beheaded. Ivan buries them and receives three horses as a gift from them: one of copper, one of silver, and the third of gold (Sm. 9).

23.死亡之头。

23. The death's head .

英雄埋葬死去的勇者头颅的事例也属于同一类。 « 走，走，被一个死人的头绊倒。他用脚将她推开，她说：“别撞到我，伊万！不如把我埋进沙子里吧！ „ » 伊万将头埋在沙子里，沙子告诉他在哪里可以找到他需要的仙浆果。 （悲伤。2）。这个案件或许可以让我们对鲁斯兰遭遇的死者头颅有一些了解。在民间故事中，它并不从地面伸出，而是躺在那里。 « 头颅就在地上，他向她弯下腰，坐在她旁边说：“这是什么样的头颅？ „ » 首领和鲁斯兰之间发生了一场奇怪的对话：“首领，我是否应该让你复活？ ” 她回答他：“如果我必须再次死亡，请不要让我再活一次，但如果我必须永远活着，请让我再活一次”（Sm.220）。在这里，伊万提供的服务不是埋葬头颅，而是让它复活。同样的事情也发生在沃古利童话251中。

To the same category belong the cases in which the hero buries the head of a dead hero. « He walks and walks, he stumbles over a dead man's head. He pushes it away with his foot, and it says: “Don't hurt me, Ivan! Bury me in the sand instead!” Ivan buries the head in the sand, and it shows him where he can find the fairy berries he needs. (Sad. 2). This case perhaps sheds some light on the death's head encountered by Ruslan. In folk tales it does not protrude from the ground, but lies there. « The head is there on the ground, he bends down to it, sits down beside it and says: “What kind of head is this?” » A curious dialogue takes place between the head and Ruslan: « Head, must I bring you back to life? "And she answers him: "If I must die again, do not revive me, but if I must live forever, revive me" (Sm. 220). Here the service rendered by Ivan is not in burying the head, but in bringing it back to life. And the same thing happens in a Vogul fairy tale 251 .

在埃鲁斯兰·拉萨雷维奇（Eruslan Lasàrevic）的童话故事中，头总是躺在地上。这是一个死人的头。但在流行的印刷品中，头从地下弹出。很难说这两种表示中哪一种是主要的。正如 Waser 252指出的那样，在古代宝石中，人们经常会遇到似乎从地下冒出来的胡须头像雕像。这些头像是预言性的，因为它们上方有一个弯曲的人物，头像的嘴半张着。作者将它们与蛇发女妖、带有翅膀的六翼天使和小天使以及其他材料进行了比较，得出的结论是它们象征着死者的灵魂，这是可能的，但尚未完全得到证实。在童话故事中，头是一个未埋葬的死人。头颅从地下冒出来的表现可能是一个焦躁不安的死人探出身子站起来或寻找人埋葬他的表现。被埋葬并心存感激的死者会成为捐赠者，赠送剑、马、仙浆果等，或者成为为英雄指路的顾问，甚至自己成为助手。这就是埃达中密米尔的头颅。瓦尼人杀死了密米尔并将他的头颅献给了众神。但奥丁用咒语保护了她免遭毁灭，并发表了演讲。此后，他曾多次与该机构进行协商。这个案例为解释保存头骨的习俗提供了桥梁。头骨上装饰着图画，被涂上颜色并保存在家里。自然地，这个头骨或头代表了死者。谁掌握了他的头脑，谁就掌握了他的整个生命：死者被迫帮助生者。

In the fairy tale of Eruslàn Lasàrevic the head always lies on the ground. It is the head of a dead man. But in popular prints the head emerges from the ground. It is difficult to say which of the two representations is the primary one. As Waser 252 points out , in ancient gems one often encounters effigies of bearded heads that seem to emerge from the ground. These heads prophesy, since a bowed figure is depicted above them and the mouth of the head appears half open. The author compares them with the Gorgon, with the winged heads of seraphim and cherubim and with other materials, reaching the conclusion that they symbolize the soul of the dead, which is probable, but not entirely proven. In the fairy tale the head is an unburied dead man. It may be that the representation of the head emerging from the ground is the representation of a restless dead man who leans forward to get up or to find someone to bury him. The buried and grateful dead man becomes a donor who gives a sword, a horse, fairy berries, etc., or an advisor who shows the hero the way, or even becomes a helper himself. Such is the head of Mimir in the Edda . The Vanir killed Mimir and sent his head to the gods. But Odin preserved it from destruction by means of a spell and gave it speech. From then on he consulted with it on many occasions. This case serves as a bridge to the custom of keeping heads or skulls. The skull was decorated with drawings, painted, and kept in the house. Naturally this skull or head represented the dead man. Whoever had the head in his power had the whole being in his power: the dead man was forced to help the living.

这解释了为什么某些民族，例如戴亚基人，特别试图占有头颅，因为正如伯格所说，“他们相信，拥有头颅的人的灵魂必须在生活中保卫他们，并在生活中服从他们。世界” 253 .但这种暴力形式很快就被其他形式的胁迫所取代。死者可以通过执行所有对他来说必要的行为来被迫服役。在美拉尼西亚的传说中，我们发现了一个奇怪的案例，女巫的形象、死者和头颅融合在一起。英雄逃跑，看到一间小屋并进入其中。在小屋里，他看到两具尸体。他取出头骨，清洗它们，并对它们进行其他处理。头骨建议他朝某个方向行走，也就是说，像女巫一样，它们向他展示了路径254。即使在俄罗斯童话故事中，我们也能找到履行同样职责的人头（Chud.13）。

This explains why certain peoples, such as the Daiaks, seek to take possession of heads in particular, because, as Burger says, "they believe that the souls of the men whose heads they possess must defend them in life and obey them in the other world." 253 But this violent form soon gives way to other forms of coercion. The dead can be forced to serve by performing all the acts that are necessary for him. In the legends of Melanesia we find a curious case in which the image of the sorceress, the dead man and the head are fused together. The hero flees, sees a hut and enters it. In the hut he sees two corpses. He takes the skulls, washes them and subjects them to other manipulations. The skulls advise him to walk in a certain direction, that is, like the sorceress, they show him the way . 254 In the Russian fairy tale too we find a human head that fulfills the same function (Chud. 13).

24.结论。

24. Conclusion .

我们注意到童话故事中存在一类我们称之为捐赠者的人物。其中我们可以区分出一个特定的群体，即死者群体。它包括女巫、已故的父母、死者和头颅。从功能上来说，它们都是相互关联的。但它们不仅在形态上相同，而且在历史上也相互联系。女巫已经以元素的女主人、人类必需的力量的女主人的身份出现在我们面前。除了这些体现在物体上的力量之外，人们会陷入黑暗的区域。这些表现形式披着仪式的外衣，主题也源于它们。

We have noted the presence in the fairy tale of a certain category of characters that we call donors. Among them we can distinguish a particular group, that of the dead. The witch, the deceased parents, the dead man and the head are part of it. Functionally they are all related to each other. But they are not only morphologically equivalent, they are also linked to each other historically. The witch has already appeared to us as the mistress of the elements, the lady of the forces necessary for man. Beyond these forces incarnated in objects, we descend into the region of darkness. These representations are cloaked in rites and from them the theme derives.

在这里，我们发现自己面对的是最古老的层。正如我们所见，女巫传递仙女的过程并不受任何外部动机的驱动。在仪式中，对象构成了目的；整个仪式的进行正是为了获得这个物品。在后期，功能本身被保留，伴随它的某些情况也被保留，但捐赠者的性格发生了变化，并引入了与这些变化相对应的动机。我们已经看到女巫与死者王国有关。随着农业的兴起和血统的男性继承，随着财产及其继承的出现，男性祖先出现，祖先崇拜诞生。这样就出现了父亲施主、父亲祖先，他在早期也以胚胎形式存在。

Here we are faced with the most ancient stratum. The delivery of the enchanted object by the sorceress is not externally motivated by anything, as we have seen. In the rite the object constitutes the aim; the whole rite is performed precisely to procure this object. In later times the function itself is preserved, certain circumstances that accompany it are preserved, but the donor character changes, and motivations corresponding to these changes are introduced. We have seen that the sorceress is connected with the realm of the dead. With the rise of agriculture and the male succession of the lineage, with the appearance of property and of its inheritance, the male ancestor appears and the cult of ancestors is born. Thus appears the father-donor, the father-ancestor, who in embryonic form also existed in earlier times.

所提供帮助的性质可能会随着各国人民的历史演变而改变。在威达人中，男人在打猎时会求助于他们的父亲捐助者255。在农业民族中，祖先赐予生育能力：他们在地球内部，从那里送出地球的果实256。在战争时期，他们通过介入战斗来提供帮助257。正如罗德指出的，这种对死者的崇拜维持了特别长的时间，因为死者是亲近而亲爱的神灵，比无所不能的官方神灵更容易对付258。他们的敬拜是狭隘而实际的。因此，我们可以理解为什么印度人必须去钓鱼时，会先躺在母亲的坟墓上，在那里睡觉并禁食几天，就像佐卢什卡（Zoluška）在发生不幸时前往母亲的坟墓一样。在一些变体中，他用眼泪沐浴它，或者根据其他变体，他用水浇灌它，也就是说，他做了奠酒。

The nature of the help given can change with the historical development of peoples. Among the Wedda, men turn to the father-giver when they go hunting . 255 Among agricultural peoples, the ancestors give fertility: they are in the interior of the earth, and from there they send up the fruits of the earth . 256 In times of war they help by intervening in battle . 257 As Rohde points out, this cult of the dead lasts a particularly long time because the dead are near and dear deities, easier to deal with than the omnipotent official deities . 258 Their cult is narrow and practical. Thus we understand why the Indian who has to go fishing first lies down on his mother's grave, sleeps there and fasts for a few days, just like Zoluška who goes to his mother's grave when some misfortune happens to her and, according to some variants, bathes it with his tears, or according to others sprinkles it with water, that is to say performs a libation.

当然，我们不能深入探讨祖先崇拜现象的实质，我们只能强调与童话故事的联系。随着祖先在崇拜中的出现，他成为主题的一部分，崇拜行为激发了所提供的帮助。给予西夫科-布尔科的父亲本质上也是一个感恩的死者，但为他提供的服务的特征并不能从童话故事中清楚地看出，而是从比较的非童话材料中清楚地看出。女术士是一位捐赠检查者，尽管当英雄提供服务时可以发现并指示案例，但称她为感激之情是很奇怪的。给予西夫科的父亲仍然以考官的身份出现，他奖励英雄是因为他通过了考验，而不是因为他为他提供了服务。在这种情况下，这种服务对于历史学家和学者来说已经是隐含的，但对于听众来说却不是。因此，这个主题被证明是非常古老的，尽管晚于女巫。

Of course, we cannot go into the substance of the phenomenon of ancestor worship; we can only point out the connection with the fairy tale. With the appearance of the ancestor in the cult, he becomes part of the theme, and the act of worship motivates the help given. The father who gives Sivko-Burko is also essentially a grateful dead man, but the nature of the service rendered to him does not emerge clearly from the fairy tale, but rather from non-fairy-tale comparative materials. The sorceress is a donor-examiner; it would be strange to call her grateful, although one can find and indicate cases in which the hero does her a service. The father who gives Sivko still presents himself as an examiner; he rewards the hero because he has passed the test and not because he has done him a service. In this case the service will already be implicit for the historian and the scholar, but not for the listener. In this way, this motif reveals itself to be very ancient, although later than the sorceress.

随着祖先崇拜的衰落，父亲消失了，死者依然如此。考试完全消失，提供的服务脱颖而出。由此诞生了“感恩的死者”的形象，他像他的父亲和女巫一样，给予一匹马或其他仙器。这是整个组中最古老的案例。

With the decline of the ancestor cult, the father disappears, the dead man remains as such. The examination disappears completely, the service rendered comes to the fore. Thus the image of the "grateful dead man" is born, who, just like the father and the witch, gives a horse or another enchanted means. This is the least ancient case of the whole group.

三．捐助者助手

III. Donors-helpers

25.感恩的动物。

25. Grateful animals .

考虑到这些因素，我们还可以理解另一种捐赠者，即感恩动物。

In light of these considerations, we can also understand another type of donor, namely grateful animals.

这是一个组合字符。这些感恩的动物在童话故事中以捐赠者的身份出现，并通过向英雄提供自己的帮助或为他提供召唤它们的公式来充当捐赠者。每个人都知道，英雄迷失在森林里，饱受饥饿之苦，看到小龙虾、刺猬或鸟，正准备射杀并吃掉它们，却遭到它们求饶。 « 突然一只雀鹰飞来；小国王伊万瞄准他：“我的雀鹰，我要杀了你，生吃你！ ——别吃我，伊凡国王！到时候，我会让你舒服„„（Af. 92）。公式“不要吃我”、“不要吃你遇到的东西”（Af. 103 a）等。反映了禁止食用可以成为帮助者的动物。英雄并不总是想吃动物；他总是想吃动物。有时它对他有帮助：鸟儿被雨淋湿了，鲸鱼被扔进了浅滩；英雄帮助他们，动物成为他隐形的帮手。可以肯定的是，这种对动物的同情心形式并不那么古老。童话一般不懂得慈悲的感觉。如果英雄释放了一只动物，那并不是出于同情心，而是因为他在按照一定的契约关系来规范自己。这在动物被网、陷阱或英雄的桶中捕获的情况下尤其明显，此时英雄在瞄准它后并没有射杀它，而是抓住了它，就像渔夫和渔夫的故事一样。小鱼或白痴埃梅利亚的。埃梅利亚犹豫了很久，他和梭子鱼展开了对话，埃梅利亚不相信梭子鱼，她不想让他自由，只有当装满水的水桶自己回到家时，埃梅尔贾相信这笔交易的好处，并释放了长矛（Af.100）。

This is a combined character. Grateful animals appear in the tale as donors and act as such by placing themselves at the hero's disposal or by providing him with the formula to call them. Everyone knows how the hero, lost in the forest, tormented by hunger, sees a crayfish, a hedgehog, or a bird, and is about to shoot to kill and eat them, when they beg him to spare them. "Suddenly a sparrowhawk flies by; King Ivan takes aim at it: 'My sparrowhawk, I will kill you and eat you raw! — Don't eat me, King Ivan! When the time comes, I will be useful to you' " (Af. 92). The formulas 'don't eat me', 'don't eat what comes your way' (Af. 103 a), etc. reflect the prohibition to eat an animal that can become a helper. The hero does not always want to eat the animal; sometimes it does them a service: the birds have been soaked by the rain, the whale has been thrown onto a shoal; the hero helps them and the animals become his invisible helpers. It is reasonable to suppose that this form, the form of compassion for an animal, is less ancient. The fairy tale, in general, does not know the feeling of compassion. If the hero lets an animal go free, it is not out of compassion but because he is acting according to certain contractual relationships. This is especially evident in cases where the animal gets caught in the net or the trap or the bucket of the hero, when the latter does not shoot at it after aiming at it, but catches it, as in the fairy tale of the fisherman and the little fish or in that of Yemelya the Simpleton. Emelja hesitates for a long time, a dialogue ensues between him and the pike, Emelja does not believe the pike, he does not want to let it go free, and only when the buckets full of water arrive home by themselves, Emelja is convinced of the advantage of the deal and releases the pike back into the wild (Af. 100).

可以证明，伊凡幸免而未吃的鱼或其他动物只不过是祖先动物，是不允许食用的动物，但因为它们是图腾祖先而有所帮助。安克曼说：“人死后，他的灵魂会转移到当时正在出生的图腾血统的个体中，反之亦然，图腾动物的灵魂在死亡时会转移到图腾血统的新生儿中。”以他的名字命名的家庭。因此，人们不得杀死或食用动物，否则就会杀死并吃掉其亲属” 259。

It can be demonstrated that the fish or other animals spared and not eaten by Ivan are nothing other than ancestor-animals, animals that it is not permitted to eat and that help because they are totemic ancestors. "At the death of a man," says Ankermann, "his soul passes into an individual of the totemic lineage who is being born at that moment, and, vice versa, the soul of a totemic animal at the point of death passes into a newborn of the family that bears its name. For this reason one must not kill an animal or eat it, because otherwise one would kill and eat a relative . " 259

随着向定居生活和农业的过渡，这种独特的图腾信仰呈现出不同的形式。人与动物之间的团结被友谊所取代，而且友谊是建立在一种契约的基础上的。关于图腾崇拜的灭绝，安克曼说260：“在许多其他部落中，这种观念占主导地位，根据这种观念，人与动物之间存在着友谊关系，这种关系表现为虔诚和互助。这种关系的起源归因于部落的创始人，通常是这样解释的：在远古时代，在极端需要的时刻，这位创始人得到了一种神圣品种的动物的帮助，或者被它从危险中拯救出来。 。这个主题是众所周知的传说的主题：这个谱系的祖先在森林里迷路了，快要饿死或渴死时，一只动物把他带到了泉水处，或者给他指明了回家的路；或者他被敌人追赶而逃跑，但被一条大河拦住，一条大鱼把他带到了对岸”，等等。

With the transition to a sedentary life and agriculture, this singular totemic faith takes on a different form. The solidarity between man and animal is replaced by friendship, which, moreover, is based on a kind of contract. Regarding the extinction of totemism, Ankermann says : "Among many other tribes the idea prevails that between man and animal there exists a relationship of friendship, which expresses itself in pity and mutual aid. The origin of this relationship is attributed to the founder of the tribe and is generally explained by the fact that in ancient times, in a moment of extreme need, this founder was helped by an animal of a sacred race or was saved by it from danger. This theme is the subject of universally known legends: the progenitor of the race has lost his way in the forest, is about to die of hunger or thirst, when an animal leads him to a spring or shows him the way home; or he flees pursued by enemies, but is stopped by a large river and a large fish ferries him to the other bank", etc.

如果我们检查一下这个与我们的童话故事非常接近但代表某个宗教阶段的材料，那么似乎有鉴赏能力的动物也是一个祖先；所缺少的只是怜悯的时刻，因为图腾教徒甚至不可能想到杀死他的图腾。自从图腾崇拜存在以来，人们就宣布“不要吃这种鱼”的禁令，但后来它变成了求饶的祈祷，归咎于同一种动物。这种演变可以在墨西哥的一个传说中看到：蜥蜴祈祷：“别打我！” » 并向英雄展示了他死去的父亲所在的地方261。我们理解它为什么会这样：它发现自己与已故祖先的世界有着非常密切的关系。如果蜥蜴向英雄表明的是人类的父亲，而不是图腾动物谱系的父亲，那么这是因为在特定的民族中，图腾崇拜正在衰落，而人类祖先也已经在神话中获得了自己的现实，但与动物祖先的联系尚未消失。显然，这种演变在全世界都呈现出或多或少相同的特征。例如，在祖鲁童话中，一只被捕获的野兽知道英雄的所有祖先：“野兽开始说话并说：某某的儿子，某某的儿子。他重复了祖父母的昵称，数到十，而这个人自己也不知道» 262。

If we examine this material, which is very close to our fairy tales but represents a certain religious stage, it seems very probable that the grateful animal is also an ancestor; only the moment of pity is missing, for it could not even occur to a totemist to kill his totem. As long as totemism existed, the prohibition "Do not eat this fish" was pronounced by men, but later it was transformed into a prayer for spared life, attributed to the animal itself. This development is evident, for example, in a Mexican legend: the lizard prays: "Do not hit me!" and shows the hero the place where his dead father is to be found . 261 We understand why it acts in this way: it is in the closest possible connection with the world of the dead ancestors. And if the lizard indicates to the hero the human father and not the father of the totemic animal lineage, this is due to the fact that among that particular people totemism is declining and the human ancestors have already acquired their reality also in myth, but the bond with the animal ancestor has not yet disappeared. It seems that this evolution presents more or less the same characteristics throughout the world. Thus, for example, in a Zulu tale a captured beast knows all the ancestors of the hero: "The beast began to speak and said: Son of such and such and such. And he repeated the nicknames of his grandfathers, and counted up to ten, which the man himself did not know" 262 .

此外，即使在我们这个时代的欧洲童话故事中，感恩的动物与人类祖先之间的联系也被保留下来。在故事《Burenuška》（Af. 56）中，继母下令宰杀她继女的牛。牛说：“但是你，美丽的女孩，不要吃我的肉。”在几个版本中，这头牛正是女孩死去的母亲：如果她吃了牛的肉，女孩就会用她母亲的身体的一部分来滋养自己。也许有人会反对，认为在这种情况下，牛并不是一种感恩的动物。但即使是感恩的动物，从狭义的意义上来说，也常常是英雄的亲戚。确实，在我们这个时代的俄罗斯童话中，动物不能说：“不要吃我，因为我是你的兄弟。”因此，这种情况发生了意义的转换：感恩的动物不是英雄的兄弟或父亲，而是变成这样：“不要吃我，我们将成为兄弟”，日本文本中的乌鸦说（Z圣475）。更重要的是，英雄和感恩的动物不再是兄弟（就像勇敢的骑士等童话故事中经常发生的那样），而是父子：“你将成为我的父亲，我将成为你的父亲。”儿子”（Onč.16）。 “他拿起一只起重机并对它说：“做我的儿子吧””（Af. 109）。 “不要吃我，我们是兄弟”这个公式必须从历史的角度理解为“不要吃我，因为我们是兄弟”含义的转置。与图腾祖先的联系还可以通过其他东西来证明：感恩的动物是动物之王（我是小龙虾之王等），或者用人种学的方式表达，他是一位大师，这一事实证明了这一点。我们在上面谈到了与女巫情妇有关的这一点。另一方面，还有另一种情况：有时，感恩的动物会被欢迎到家中并被喂养。我们稍后将在有关助手的章节中研究这种情况。

The connection between grateful animals and the human ancestor has been preserved even in the European fairy tale of our time. In the tale Burenuška (Aph. 56) the stepmother orders the slaughter of her stepdaughter's cow. The cow says: "But you, beautiful girl, do not eat my flesh." In several variants this cow is none other than the girl's dead mother: if she were to eat the cow's flesh, the girl would be eating a piece of her mother's body. It may be objected that in this case the cow is not a grateful animal. But even grateful animals, in the narrow sense of this term, are often relatives of the hero. It is true that in the Russian fairy tale of our time an animal cannot say: "Do not eat me, for I am your brother." This situation has therefore undergone a transposition of meaning: the grateful animal is not the brother or father of the hero, but becomes one: "Do not eat me, and we will be brothers," says the crow in a Yakut text (Z. St. 475). What is much more important is the fact that the hero and the grateful animal become not brothers (as happens very often in tales of brave knights, etc.), but father and son: "You will be my father, and I will be your son" (Onč. 16). "And he took a crane and said to it, 'Be my son'" (Af. 109). The formula "do not eat me, and we will be brothers" must be understood in the historical perspective as a transposition of meaning of "do not eat me, because we are brothers." The connection with totemic ancestors is proved by something else: it is proved by the fact that the grateful animal is a king of animals (I am the king of the crayfish, etc.) or, to express ourselves ethnographically, it is a master. We spoke about this above in connection with the witch-mistress. On the other hand, there is another probative circumstance: sometimes the grateful animal is welcomed into the house and fed. We will examine this case later, in the chapter on helpers.

DK Zelenin 在西伯利亚材料的基础上也得出了安克曼在非洲材料的基础上得出的相同推论。但后一种材料比非洲材料更困难，因为在西伯利亚图腾崇拜不再直接存在，只有痕迹，而在非洲它仍然是一种活生生的现象。我们的主题和图腾崇拜之间的联系对于 DK Zelenin 来说是如此明显，以至于他认为没有必要证明这一点。 “在图腾动物被描述为对人类有益的传说中，最古老的是那些关于感恩动物的传说”，Zelenin 263说。即使在这些传说中，他也看到了我们在童话故事中注意到的那些契约关系的存在。 “从我们的角度来看，这些故事特别有趣，因为它们概述了人与动物之间联盟的契约关系，我们认为这是图腾崇拜的核心” 264。

DK Zelenin also draws the same conclusions as Ankermann on the basis of the African material. But the latter material is more difficult than the African one, since in Siberia totemism no longer exists directly, only traces of it, while in Africa it is still a living phenomenon. The connection between our motif and totemism is so obvious to DK Zelenin that he does not consider it necessary to prove it. "Among the legends in which the totem animal is presented as a being beneficial to man, the oldest are considered to be those about grateful animals," says Zelenin . 263 In these legends too he sees the presence of those contractual relationships which we have noted in the fairy tale. "From our point of view these tales are particularly interesting, in that they outline the contractual relationships of alliance between man and animals, which we consider to be the core of totemism . " 264

所有这些类比都表明感恩动物应该包括在哪一组现象中，也表明科斯坎犯了一个错误，认为这个主题“纯粹是印度的想法” 265。

All these analogies show in what group of phenomena grateful animals must be included, and they also show that Cosquin made a blunder in considering this motif "a purely Indian idea . " 265

26.铜脸。

26. Copper-front .

作为各种感恩的动物，在童话故事中有时被称为“铜眉”。 《森林怪物》等“铜锋”是一个怪物，他发现自己成为了国王宫廷的囚犯。他请求国王释放他：“放我走，我会对你有用”（《SM》159）。 “国王之子，放我走吧，我会对你有用”（Af. 67 a）。 “让我走，你就会拥有你想要的一切”（Onč. 150）。这个角色属于捐赠者类别。 “我会对你有用”这句话与感恩的动物们的话语一模一样。英雄释放了他，随后被释放的囚犯本人或他的女儿们给了他自动填充的手帕（Chud. III. 44）、羽毛或仙女古筝（Chud. 115），或者铜线给了他力量或水生命的一部分（Af. 68）、一匹马等。或者，最后，他将自己置于英雄的支配之下，成为他的助手；只要提及他、呼唤他，让他出现就足够了。

As a variety of grateful animals can be considered the figure that in fairy tales is sometimes called "copper-faced", "wild monster", etc. "Copper-faced" is a monstrous being that is held prisoner at the king's court. He asks the little king to release him: "Let me go away, I will be useful to you" (Sm. 159). "Son of a king, let me go away, I will be useful to you" (Af. 67 a). "Let me go away, and you will have everything you desire" (Onč. 150). This character belongs to the category of donors. The formula "I will be useful to you" corresponds exactly to the words of grateful animals. The hero sets him free and then the liberated prisoner himself or his daughters give him the self-filling handkerchief (Chud. III. 44), feathers or fairy lyres (Chud. 115), or Copper-Forehead gives him strength or the water of life (Af. 68), a horse, etc. or, finally, he places himself at the hero's disposal and becomes his helper; it is enough to mention him and call him for him to appear.

在确定了感恩的动物和“铜脸”之间的亲缘关系后，让我们更仔细地研究一下这个人物。

Having established the relationship between the grateful animals and "Copper-Forehead", let us examine this figure a little more closely.

它在童话故事中是怎样出现的呢？最完整的案例发生在阿法纳西耶夫。童话故事一开始就讲述了一个贪婪贪婪的国王。 « 他的贪婪让他不得安宁，他从未停止增加利润和征收新税。有一天，他看到一位老人带着紫貂、貂、海狸和狐狸。 “站住，老头子，你是哪里人？ ——我出生在某某村庄，但现在我在森林小人身边服役。 - 你是如何捕捉动物的？ ——呃，森林小人设下陷阱，野兽们都傻了，上当了。 “听着，老伙计，我会给你很多酒喝，我会给你钱：让我看看你把陷阱放在哪里。”老人被引诱了，带他参观了那个地方。国王立即将森林人抓获并锁在铁柱中，然后为他的强盗设置陷阱”（Af. 67 a）。

How does he present himself in the fairy tale? The most complete case is in Afanasiev. The tale begins by telling of a greedy and gluttonous king. "His greed gave him no peace, he never stopped increasing his profits and imposing new taxes. One day he saw an old man with sables, martens, beavers, and foxes. 'Stop, old man, where do you come from? ' 'I was born in the village So-and-so, but now I am in service to the little woodman. ' 'And how do you catch the animals? ' 'Eh, the little woodman sets traps, the animals are stupid and fall for them. ' 'Listen, old man, I will give you plenty of wine to drink and I will give you money: show me where you set the traps. ' The old man let himself be seduced and showed him the place. The king immediately had the Silvanus captured and locked up in an iron pillar, then set traps for his bandits" (Af. 67 a).

随后的主题一般是这样发展的：囚犯请求国王释放他，国王偷了钥匙并释放了囚犯，国王成为他的帮助者或给他一个帮助者。

The theme then generally develops as follows: the prisoner begs the little king to release him, the king steals the keys and frees the prisoner, who becomes his assistant or gives him an assistant.

阿法纳西耶夫的版本清楚地展示了这个角色是如何融入到动作中的：他在森林里偶然被发现，被带回家，并被囚禁在那里。
