Suddenly some black ravens with iron feet came, seized the carcass, carried it up the mountain and began to peck at it. They ate the horse and were about to get to the merchant's son" (Aph. 136). "An eagle flew in, wrapped him in a rawhide and carried him to the mountain of gold" (Sm. 49). In the latter case we see that the hero does not just enter the corpse of an animal, but also wraps himself in its skin. In another tale Ivan finds himself in a pit where they are throwing away a carcass. "How can he escape? He sees a large bird dragging away a cow; at the same time they are throwing a dead cow into the pit. He tied it around his body. The bird comes, grabs the animal and carries it away, and the little king Ivan is swinging in the air and cannot free himself" (Af. 111 a).

将这种形式的渡轮与以前的形式进行比较，很容易得出这样的结论：我们现在面临着一种更新的形式，它已经取代了转变。古代用于渡船的古老动物，即鸟，至今仍未被遗忘，并充当运输工具。但是，除此之外，我们还找到了马、牛和牛。

Comparing this form of ferry with the preceding one, it is easy to come to the conclusion that we are here before a more recent form, which has replaced the transformation. The old animal, used in ancient times for the ferry, namely the bird, is not yet forgotten and serves as a transporter. But, together with this, we also find the horse, the cow and the ox.

这一猜想得到了材料的证实。入会仪式中会穿着动物的皮毛，象征着对动物的认同。入会者披着牛皮、熊皮和水牛皮跳舞，模仿它们的动作并代表一种图腾动物340。

This conjecture is confirmed by the materials. The covering of the skin of an animal is found in the rites of initiation and symbolizes the identity with the animal. The initiants danced, dressed in the skins of oxen, bears, buffaloes, imitating their movements and representing a totemic animal 340 .

同样的表现也出现在狩猎民族的丧葬仪式和神话中。斯滕伯格说：“既然人死后就变成了作为他的图腾的动物，这自然也会对埋葬仪式产生影响：死者被包裹在作为他的图腾的动物的皮里” 341。因此，在以水牛为图腾的奥瓦哈部落中，尸体被缝在水牛皮中342。南森观察到了爱斯基摩人的这种习俗：“尸体的腿通常被折叠在背后，并在这个位置被缝进皮肤中” 343。南森解释说，这种习俗的目的是确保尸体在坟墓中占据尽可能小的空间，但这可以解释折叠腿的原因，但不能解释将尸体缝入皮肤的行为。拉斯穆森指出，爱斯基摩人被扔进海里，缝在皮肤上344。因此，正如南森所认为的那样，缝合它们的行为与坑无关，南森没有告诉我们皮肤属于哪种动物。楚科奇人也有同样的习俗。

The same representation is also found in the burial rites and myths of hunting peoples. Sternberg says: "Since after death man becomes the animal that serves as his totem, it is natural that this also has repercussions on the burial rites: the deceased is wrapped in the skin of the animal that served as his totem." 341 Thus among the Owaha tribe, whose totem was a buffalo, the corpses were sewn into a buffalo skin . 342 Nansen observed this custom among the Eskimos: "The legs of the corpse are often folded onto the back and in this position it is sewn into a skin." 343 Nansen explains the custom with the aim of ensuring that the corpse takes up as little space as possible in the grave, but this would explain the folding of the legs but not the act of sewing the corpse into the skin. Rasmussen notes that the Eskimos are thrown into the sea, sewn into a skin 344 . Consequently, the act of sewing them is not connected with the pit, as Nansen believes, who does not tell us to which animal the skin belongs. The same custom is also observed among the Chukchi.

相应的主题也存在于神话中，在这里，皮肤的穿着或自我介绍作为一种身份形式，是非常明确的。在这些情况下，鸟类占主导地位。例如，英雄得到一只鹰。 « 他用力摇晃她，以至于所有的骨头和肉都脱落了……然后他披上了鹰皮，飞上了天空，进入了死者的国度 » 345。这些神话在美国非常普遍。 Ielch，特林基特部落的神，杀死了一只喜鹊，给它的羽毛穿上衣服，然后飞向天空，在那里他放置了太阳346。萨满服装常常描绘鸟，也可以用相应的方式来解释。

A corresponding motif also exists in myths, and here the putting on of the skin or entering into it, as a form of identity, is very clear. In these cases the bird predominates. The hero, for example, takes an eagle. "He shook it so hard that all the bones and flesh fell off... Then he put on the eagle's skin and flew to heaven, to the realm of the dead." 345 These myths are very widespread in America. Ielch, god of the Tlinkit tribe, kills a magpie, dresses in its feathers and flies to heaven, where he places the sun . 346 The shamanic clothing, which often depicts a bird, can also be interpreted in a corresponding way.

这种习俗在养牛民族中更为普遍，他们将尸体缝在公牛或母牛的皮上，就像童话故事中发生的那样。在非洲可以找到很多例子。 “当拥有牲畜的人死亡时，”Raum 在谈到 Dgiagga 部落时说道，“他的一只牲畜被杀死，尸体上覆盖着兽皮347。 “在瓦赫赫人中，”富勒伯恩说，“死者被缝在他死时所用的皮肤上。”他补充道：“对死者的哀悼持续了八天。但由于在炎热的气候下，尸体很快就会散发出强烈的恶臭，他们把它缝在一张牛皮上，当这还不够时，他们又缝了第二个、第三个、第四个、第四个。第五” 348 .当我们将此案例与其他案例进行比较时，这种机械理性主义解释的谬误就显而易见了。弗罗贝尼乌斯记载道：“这位伟大的国王去世后，按照先祖们的习俗，他们把他缝在一张牛皮里，然后在湖上漂了三天。”

This custom is much more widespread among cattle-breeding peoples, among whom the corpses are sewn into the hide of an ox or a cow, as in the fable. Many examples of it can be found in Africa. "When someone who owns cattle dies," says Raum, speaking of the Djagga tribe, "one of his animals is killed and the corpse is covered with the skin ." 347 "Among the Wahehe," says Fülleborn, "the deceased is sewn into the skin on which he died." And he adds: "The mourning for the dead lasted eight days. But since in that very hot climate the corpse very soon begins to give off a strong stench, they sewed it into an ox hide, and when that was no longer sufficient they sewed it into a second, a third, a fourth, a fifth." 348 The erroneousness of this mechanical-rationalistic explanation becomes evident when this case is compared with others. Frobenius reports: "When the great king died, according to the custom of the fathers they sewed him into a cowhide and made him float for three days on the lake."

遵守这种习俗的人通常根本不会激发这种习俗。学者们主动寻找原因：据他们说，这样做是为了避免恶臭或节省墓室空间等。所有这些动机自然都是错误的，必须从习俗的历史而不是其形式中寻找解释。

People who observe this custom usually do not give any reasons for it. Scholars seek the reasons on their own initiative: according to them, this is done to avoid the stench or to save space in the tomb, etc. All these reasons are of course wrong and the explanation must be sought in the history of the custom and not in its forms.

这些人以饲养牲畜为生。例如，这些人是吠陀时期的印度教徒，事实上，我们也发现了同样的习俗。值得关注这个事实。印度达到了很高的文明程度，却保留了将尸体缝成皮的古老习俗。但既然尸体是被烧毁的，那么将尸体缝在皮肤上的习俗一定是有特殊原因的。火葬死者前，先给死者穿上衣服或盖上牛身体的相应部位（即把牛头放在他的头上等）或将一只山羊与尸体一起焚烧。火神阿格尼在火焰中带走了死者349。这种习俗是如何产生的呢？这样做是为了让阿格尼燃烧，即吞噬动物而不是人。在《梨俱吠陀》中，我们读到：“为了保护自己免受烈火的伤害，请穿上由牛部件制成的覆盖物”（《梨俱吠陀》，X，16，7）。这种动机显然是最近才出现的。德国科学家创造了特殊术语“Umlegetier”（即用于覆盖尸体的动物）来表示用其皮肤覆盖尸体的牛。尸体上覆盖着兽皮，毛发外露，保留了头、腿和尾巴。

The peoples in question live by raising cattle. Such are, for example, the Hindus of the Vedic period, and indeed we find the same custom among them. This fact is worth dwelling on. India reached a very high level of civilization, and yet it retained the old custom of sewing the corpse into a skin. But since the corpses were burned, the custom of sewing them into the skin must have had a special reason. Before burning the deceased, he was dressed or covered with the corresponding parts of the body of a cow (that is, the head of the cow was placed on his head, etc.), or a goat was burned together with the corpse. The god of fire, Agni, carried the dead man away in the midst of the flames . 349 What is the reason for this custom? It is done so that Agni burns, that is, devours, the animal and not the man. In the Rigveda we read: "To protect yourself from Agni, put on a covering made of cow parts" ( Rigv ., X, 16, 7). This motivation is evidently more recent. German scientists have coined the special term Umlegetier (i.e. animal that serves for covering) to indicate the cow with whose skin the corpses were covered. The corpse was covered with the skin of an animal, with the hair facing outwards, preserving the head, the legs and the tail.

有趣的是，这种仪式或习俗也存在于古代农业文明中，但已经成为遗迹。

It is interesting that this rite or custom also exists in ancient agricultural civilizations, but already in a relic form.

在埃及，在最遥远的时代，尸体被裹着皮埋葬，挖掘工作已发现了350 具埋葬痕迹。巴奇认为这是木乃伊化的首次尝试。后来，当木乃伊化已经取得进展时，用皮包裹死者的习俗呈现出另一种形式，非常清楚地保留了原始的身份感。 “裹着皮的不再是死者，而是庆祝的牧师。” “在他躺在床上之前，”巴吉说，“他用一张牛皮或牛皮包裹自己，通过这一行为，他的目的是获得复活；但他的目的是让他复活。”人们相信，“穿过”牛人的皮肤就获得了新生的礼物……”人们想象众神也做了同样的事情：因此阿努比斯穿过了奥西里斯的皮肤。在这里我们看到动物变成了神，通过将死者缝进一张皮里，他将自己与动物联系起来并证实了他的不朽。同样的表现也反映在献祭中：“皮肤是献祭的典型代表，穿过它的人赋予了受害者的力量和生命，使他成为被杀动物的代表。正如牛是奥西里斯的象征，而奥西里斯又是“阿蒙提牛”，所以穿着牛皮的人代表奥西里斯» 351。

In Egypt in the most remote times corpses were buried wrapped in skins, and excavations have brought to light traces of such burial . 350 Budge believes that this was a first attempt at mummification. Later, when mummification had already advanced, the custom of wrapping the dead in a skin took another form, which has very clearly preserved the original sense of identity. "It is no longer the dead man who is wrapped in the skin, but the celebrating priest." "Before lying down on the bed," says Budge, "he wrapped himself in the skin of an ox or cow, and by this act he aimed at obtaining resurrection; it was believed that by 'passing' through the skin of the ox the man acquired the gift of a new birth..." It was imagined that the gods also did the same: thus Anubis had passed through the skin of Osiris. Here we see that the animal has become a god, and that by sewing the dead man into a skin he was identified with the animal and his immortality was confirmed. This same representation is also reflected in the sacrifices: "The skin was typical for sacrifices, passing through it gave the man the strength and life of the victim and made him become a representative of the killed animal. As the ox was the symbol of Osiris, who in turn was the "Amenti ox", so the man who wore its skin represented Osiris" 351 .

这里似乎缺少运动的表示。正如莫雷特所说，皮肤充当了“血腥裹尸布” 352。这是因为埃及人并没有想象死者的旅程是以飞行的形式，而是首先想象为乘船旅行，这对他们来说是最自然的交通工具。但牛在另一个世界作为伴侣的职责对于埃及来说也不陌生。

Here the representation of motion seems to be missing. As Moret says, the skin served as a "bloody shroud" 352 . This is due to the fact that the Egyptians did not imagine the journey of the deceased as a flight, but above all as a journey in a boat, which was for them the most natural means of transport. But the function of the ox as a companion in the other world is not foreign to Egypt either.

莫雷特说：“牛，塞特（奥西里斯的对手）的同谋，本身就被当作祭品；在他被杀后，他背着奥西里斯来到天堂，并用他的皮肤为神船制造了一张帆，人们乘着这艘船到达了天堂。”因此，皮肤被转变成帆353。

Moret says: «The ox, accomplice of Set (rival of Osiris) is, as such, offered in sacrifice; after being killed it accompanies Osiris to heaven carrying him on its back and gives its skin to be made into a sail for the divine vessel, with which one reaches paradise». The skin, therefore, was transformed into a sail 353 .

在希腊，让尸体穿皮的习俗被神穿皮的信仰所取代。我们已经讲过赫拉克勒斯，狄俄尼索斯披着牛皮、头角悬空的形象也广为人知。在这个阶段，人们常常相信，陪伴死者进入另一个世界的动物只是为他提供食物，我们在印度已经看到了这种信仰的雏形。因此，人与动物的表现被人+动物作为食物的表现所取代，或者正如斯坦格尔所认为的，动物作为另一个世界的仆人。 “可食用动物的皮被去除，尸体被脂肪包裹，动物的尸体与蜂蜜和肉罐一起在死者附近被焚烧” 354。然而，马匹不会失去皮肤，“它们必须跟随死者，在阴间​​为他服务”。

In Greece the custom of putting a skin on the corpse was replaced by the belief that the gods wore skins. We have already spoken of Heracles, and the image of Dionysus wearing an ox-skin with his head and horns hanging down is also well known. At this stage it was often believed that the animals which accompanied the deceased into the other world served him only as food, and we have seen the rudiments of this belief in India. The idea of ​​man-animal is therefore replaced by that of man + animal as food or, as Stengel believes, of the animal as a servant in the other world. "The skin is removed from edible animals, the body is wrapped in their fat, and the corpse of the animal is burned together with jars of honey and meat in the immediate vicinity of the deceased." 354 But the skin is not removed from horses. "They must follow the deceased, to serve him in Hades."

所有这些材料都清楚地表明，英雄爬入动物尸体或将自己缝在里面的母题的来源可以在丧葬仪式中找到，这种丧葬仪式曾经反映了动物死后的身份表征，并且已经过时了。通过养牛阶段。

All these materials clearly show that the source of the motif of the hero who creeps into the corpse of an animal or sews himself into it is to be found in funeral rites which once reflected the representation of identity with the animal after death and had passed through the stage of cattle breeding.

4.鸟。

4. The bird .

将英雄缝入皮肤的操作已经标志着原始身份表征的开始消失。同样的现象也出现在英雄的主题中，他没有变成动物，也没有被缝在动物身上，而是骑在动物身上。在这方面还可以注意到，最初被认为已死亡的动物，即鸟类，是被骑乘的，后来出现了真正的骑乘动物。童话里说：“坐在我的翅膀上。我会带你去我的国家……” 商人坐在机翼上；雄鹰飞向蓝色的大海，升得很高，很高”（Af. 125）。在同一故事的一个变体中，老鹰向英雄问了三遍他在下面看到的东西。 « 农夫坐在老鹰上；雄鹰展翅高飞，飞向蔚蓝的大海；他离开岸边，问农夫：“看看并告诉我我们后面、前面和下面是什么？ „ »（AF. 125 b）。农夫回答说：“我们后面是土地，前面是大海，上面是天空，下面是水。”随着飞行的进行，情况发生变化。

The operation of sewing the hero into the skin already marks the beginning of the disappearance of the original representation of identity. The same phenomenon is observed in the motif of the hero who does not transform himself into an animal or is not sewn into one, but rides it. Here too we can note that originally the animals that are believed to be dead, namely birds, are ridden, and later the real riding animals appear. The fairy tale says: "Sit on my wings. I will take you to my country..." The merchant sat on the wings; the eagle took flight towards the blue sea and soared high, high" (Af. 125). In a variant of the same story the eagle asks the hero three times what he sees beneath him. "The farmer sat on the eagle; the eagle rose and soared towards the blue sea; he moved away from the shore and asked the farmer: “Look and tell me what is behind us, in front of us and below us?” » (Af. 125 b). « Behind us, — the farmer replies, — is the earth, in front of us is the sea, above us is the sky, below us is the water ». As the flight progresses, the picture changes.

这些例子清楚地表明了鸟的图像与遥远的空间，尤其是海洋的表现之间的联系。正如我们所看到的，如果将尸体缝成皮的习俗在致力于养羊和养牛的人们中达到顶峰，那么这种鸟反而是沿海居民的特征。例如，在中部非洲，它几乎从未被发现，但另一方面，它在大洋洲岛屿和美洲海岸的居民中占主导地位。正如我们稍后将看到的，在鸟旁边或与鸟一起，在这些民族中还有船。按照他们的说法，亡者的王国并不在森林和山脉之外，甚至不在地下，而是在地平线之外，同时也是阳光和水的王国。在这些民族的形象艺术中，有船形的木制鸟像；死者通常坐在一只鸟上，根据弗罗贝尼乌斯的说法，这种表现是在乘船旅行的影响下诞生的。

These examples clearly show the connection between the image of the bird and the representation of distant space, especially the sea. If, as we have seen, the custom of sewing the corpse into a skin reaches its apogee among peoples dedicated to pastoralism and cattle breeding, the bird is instead characteristic of coastal dwellers. It is almost never found, for example, in Central Africa, but on the other hand it predominates on the islands of Oceania and among the inhabitants of the American coast. Alongside the bird or together with it, as we will see later, among these peoples there is the boat. According to them the realm of the dead is not beyond the forests and mountains or even underground, but beyond the horizon, it is at the same time the realm of the sun and the water. In the figurative art of these peoples there are wooden images of birds in the form of boats; the dead person generally sits on a bird, a representation which, according to Frobenius, arose under the influence of boat travel.

在童话故事中已经提到过伊万去见海王，而这位国王的形象常常与太阳联系在一起。在同一个故事的另一个版本中（Aph. 103），伊凡占有了海洋女士，然后前往遥远的地方，那里有太阳过夜。太阳王为失去海洋女士而悲伤。这类童话故事对于神话学家来说非常方便，因为他们想在童话故事中看到天象的反映。事实上，遥远的王国通常（但不总是）是太阳的王国，正如我们稍后在研究这个主题时会看到的那样。但事实并不重要，因为它反映了天空及其星星的表现，而是反映了死亡王国：鸟正是将死者运送到那里的典型动物。冯特说：“在大洋洲和美洲西北部，人们普遍认为祖先或最近去世的人的灵魂居住在某些鸟类体内，这与神话直接相关，根据神话，死者与太阳有关，太阳是他未来的家” 355。一段时间以来，人们都知道这只鸟是死者的灵魂，但学者们有时对这种代表的起源有相当模糊的看法。例如，冯特认为，灵魂鸟的表征源于尸体火化过程中灵魂化为烟雾的表征。 “灵魂进入烟雾，从烧焦的尸体升向天空，”他写道，“已经接近灵魂化身的另一种形式……确切地说，它转变为快速的动物、鸟类和物种。其他飞行生物。”然而，我们认为，这是航海民族或沿海居民所发展的转变表征的第二阶段。

In the already mentioned tale Ivan goes to the king of the sea, and the image of this king is often connected with the sun. In another version of the same tale (Af. 103) Ivan takes possession of the Lady of the Sea and then goes to the distant lands where the sun spends the night; the Sun King grieves over the loss of the Lady of the Sea. Tales of this kind are very convenient for mythologists, who want to see in them a reflection of celestial phenomena. In fact, the distant kingdom is often (but not always) the kingdom of the sun, as we will see later when the time comes to study this motif. But the fact is important not as a reflection of the representation of the sky and its stars, but as a reflection of the kingdom of the dead: the bird is precisely the characteristic animal that transports the dead there. "In Oceania and Northwest America," says Wundt, "the popular conception that the souls of ancestors or of recently deceased persons live in certain birds is directly connected with the myth that the soul of the deceased is related to the sun, its future home." 355 That the bird is the soul of the deceased has long been known, but scholars sometimes have rather vague opinions about the origin of this idea. Wundt, for example, believes that the idea of ​​the soul-bird arose from the idea that the soul went up in smoke during the cremation of corpses. "The passing of the soul into the smoke that rises to the sky from the burnt corpse," he writes, "already approaches another form of incarnation of the soul... namely, its transformation into swift animals, especially birds and other flying beings." In our opinion, this is, instead, the second phase of the representations of transformations, developed among the seafaring peoples or coastal inhabitants.

没有必要引用很多材料。我们将仅限于几个说明性案例。弗罗贝尼乌斯在​​他关于原始民族世界观的书中用了整整一章来讨论鸟类。在塔希提岛和汤加群岛，携带灵魂的鸟类的代表在上世纪末仍然存在。当人死后，一只鸟会接管他的灵魂。结果，这只鸟将灵魂运送到来世的境界。在运送死者的鸟类中，大洋洲的居民中有犀鸟，澳大利亚人中有乌鸦，努特卡部落中有乌鸦。在塔希提岛和汤加群岛，人们还相信这只鸟在等待并吞噬死者的灵魂。同样的犀牛鸟也出现在 Daiaki 中：它快速而可靠地将死者的灵魂运送到死者之城。

It is not necessary to cite many materials. We will limit ourselves to a few illustrative cases. In his book on the world view of primitive peoples, Frobenius devotes a whole chapter to the bird. In Tahiti and Tonga the idea of ​​soul-carrying birds still existed at the end of the last century. When a man dies, a bird takes possession of his soul. The bird then carries the soul to the realm of the afterlife. Among the birds that carry the dead, the inhabitants of Oceania include the rhinoceros bird, the Australians the crow, and the Nutka tribe the raven. In Tahiti and Tonga it is also believed that the bird lies in wait and swallows the soul of the deceased. The same rhinoceros bird also figures among the Daiaki: it carries the soul of the deceased quickly and safely to the city of the dead.

这种信仰也反映在神话和仪式中。在大明人中，死者的胸前拴着一只母鸡。鸡被带到婆罗洲作为祭品。在苏门答腊，棺材上喷有鸡血356。

This belief has also been reflected in myths and rites. Among the Daiaki, a hen is tied to the chest of the dead. In Borneo, hens are brought as sacrifices. In Sumatra, the coffin is sprinkled with hen's blood 356 .

大洋洲的神话中也有同样的表现。毛伊想要获得火种，骑着鸽子飞入地狱。在密克罗尼西亚的童话神话中，有这样一句话：“把食物放在鸟儿里，在上面放一些垫子，飞起来寻找你的妻子” 357。

The same representation is also found in the myths of Oceania. Maui, wishing to procure fire, flies to hell on the back of a dove. In a Micronesian myth-tale, it is said: "Put food in a bird, put some mats in it, fly and look for your wife" 357 .

在美国西北部的神话中，有伊尔奇的形象：“伊尔奇首先是死亡之鸟，灵魂的向导；他邀请死者的灵魂参加宴会，并邀请其他人与他一起为死者哭泣” 358。

In the mythology of Northwest America we have the figure of Ielch: «Ielch is first of all the bird of the dead, the guide of souls; he invites the spirits of the dead to a banquet and invites others to weep with him over the dead» 358 .

鸟灵魂或被鸟绑架的灵魂的表现在埃及、巴比伦和古典时期都被保存下来，所有这些形式都接近童话故事并解释它。在埃及，来世领域的渡口有多种，一般来说，埃及的表述既不统一也不连贯。莫雷特说，已故国王的尸体仍留在金字塔中，“但那些知道通往天堂的良善之路的灵魂，可以通过爬上地平线尽头升起的梯子来走向众神。 ，或乘船旅行，黑暗的卡戎在其中划行，要么融化成蒸汽，要么乘着神圣的朱鹭托特的翅膀升起» 359。稍后我们将分析梯子和船，现在我们对鸟感兴趣。鸟背上的飞行是在《亡灵书》中遇到的。 « 我站了起来，我站了起来，就像一只从蛋中孵化出来的强大的年轻雀鹰。我像一只鹰一样飞翔和下降，背部有四臂宽，翅膀像南方的翡翠”（《死者之书》，第二十七页，第248页）。

The representation of the bird-soul or of the soul kidnapped by the bird has been preserved in Egypt, in Babylon, in classical antiquity and all these forms are close to the fairy tale and explain it. In Egypt there are several kinds of ferry in the realm of the afterlife, and in general the Egyptian representations have no unity and no coherence. The bodies of the deceased kings, — says Moret, — remain in the pyramids, « but the souls who have known the paths of good that lead to paradise, transfer themselves to the gods either by climbing a ladder that rises at the edge of the horizon, or by making the journey in a boat rowed by the dark Charon, or by dissolving into vapor or by rising on the wings of Thoth, the sacred ibis » . 359 We will analyze the ladder and the boat later, here for now we are interested in the bird. The flight on the back of the bird is encountered in the Book of the Dead . « I rose, I rose like a mighty young hawk, hatched from its egg. I fly and descend like a hawk whose back is four arms wide and whose wings are like a southern emerald » ( Book of the Dead , XXVII, p. 248).

巴比伦也知道这种表示法。在吉尔伽美什的诗中，埃巴尼梦想被召唤到地狱（伊尔卡拉）“在那里他穿着羽毛连衣裙，像鸟一样” 360。因此，在巴比伦，死者被想象为鸟类的存在。希腊也存在类似的情况361。例如，伪卡利斯提尼的故事还讲述了亚历山大死后一只鹰飞走了。愤世嫉俗的Peregrino Proteus死后发生了地震，一只鹰飞向天空，用人的声音喊道：“我已经放弃了地球，登上了奥林匹斯山” 362。这种信念仍然反映在某些作品中，例如阿特米多鲁斯的《梦论》（ Oneirocriticon）。在其中，梦中看到的每只鸟都被解释为一个人，而每一次梦中的飞行都是灵魂对拒绝尘世外壳并以鸟类动物的外表飞翔在极乐世界的渴望363。在罗马，当皇帝去世时，一只鹰会被释放，这样它就可以将君主的灵魂带到天堂364。

Babylon also knows this representation. In the poem of Gilgamesh Eabani dreams of being called to hell (Irkalla) "where one wears a dress of feathers, like birds." 360 In Babylon, therefore, the dead were imagined in the guise of beings having the form of birds. A similar representation also existed in Greece . 361 The story of Pseudo-Callisthenes also narrates, for example, that at the death of Alexander an eagle took flight. At the death of the Cynic Peregrin Proteus there was an earthquake, an eagle flew up to the sky exclaiming in a human voice: "I have left the earth and ascended to Olympus." 362 This belief is still reflected in certain works such as the Oneirocriticon (Treatise on Dreams) of Artemidorus. In it, every bird seen in a dream is interpreted as a man, and every flight dreamed as the aspiration of the soul to repudiate the earthly envelope and fly to the Elysian Fields in the guise of an animal-bird 363 . In Rome, when emperors died, an eagle was released so that it could carry the soul of the sovereign to heaven 364 .

最后，在带翅膀的天使的形象中，我们在基督教中看到了这种信仰的最后残余。

And finally, in the image of the winged angels, we have in Christianity the last remnants of this belief.

5.在马背上。

5. On horseback .

马的起源肯定比鸟晚。我们已经展示了马是如何与鸟同化的，带翅膀的马本质上是马鸟。当人类开始驯养马时，虽然童话中也有个别变马的例子，但对马的转化的表现可能已经退居二线了。马在仪式中占有重要地位：它作为坐骑与死者一起埋葬。马尔滕在古希腊注意到了这种替代：“在希腊宗教（以及日耳曼宗教）中，死者以马的形式出现，但同时也以骑士或马主的形式出现。 ”我们已经研究过马的形象。因此，英雄的骑马飞行反映了鸟的旅程诞生的同一表征的另一个阶段：通往死亡王国的渡轮。这种情况是如此明显，以至于我们可以不报道材料，而是让读者参考已经引用的Anucin、Negelein、Malten等人的著作。

The horse is certainly of later origin than the bird. We have already shown how the horse resembles the bird, how the winged horse is essentially a bird-horse. When men began to domesticate horses, the representation of the transformation into an animal had probably already receded into the background, although individual cases of transformation into a horse are also encountered in the fairy tale. The horse figures in the rites: it is buried together with the deceased as a mount. Malten has noted this substitution in ancient Greece: "In the Hellenic religion (as well as in the Germanic one) the dead appear in the form of a horse, but at the same time also in the form of a rider or owner of a horse." We have already studied the image of the horse. Therefore, the flight of the hero on the horse reflects another phase of the same representations from which the journey on the bird arose: the ferry into the realm of the dead. This situation is so obvious that we can refrain from quoting material, referring the reader to the works already cited by Anucin, Negelein, Malten, etc.

6.在船上。

6. On the ship .

如果说作为运输工具的马不需要特别考察的话，上面已经对它的体型进行了整体分析，那么我们还没有触及船的话题，现在我们重点来详细讨论一下。英雄出发的船不是一艘完全普通的船：它是一艘飞行船：“你会看到一艘船在你面前，上船并飞到你需要去的地方”（Aph.83） 。 “突然，船升到空中，瞬间，就像离弦的箭一样，把他们引向一座巨大的石山”（Af 78）。但我们也会遇到常见的船或小船，比如我们提到的七个西蒙的船。

If the horse as a carrier does not require special consideration, since its character has already been analyzed above in its entirety, we have not yet touched on the subject of the boat and will now dwell on it in detail. The boat or ship on which the hero sets out is not a completely ordinary vessel: it is a flying vessel: "You will see a ship before you, climb aboard and fly where you need to go" (Aph. 83). "Suddenly the boat rose into the air and in an instant, like an arrow shot from the bow, it led them to a great rocky mountain" (Aph. 78). But we also encounter the usual ship or boat, such as the boat of the seven Simeons, which we have mentioned.

通过研究鸟类，我们已经表明飞行器是鸟类的进化，就像马一样。马继承了翅膀，船只只有战胜空气的能力。瓦瑟说，“人们也许无法找到不存在灵魂容器信仰的任何实体的居住区域” 365。在我看来，这是不正确的。马在印度、亚洲大草原、斯基泰人、希腊人、日耳曼人、斯拉夫人等人中占主导地位，船在大洋洲的岛屿民族中占主导地位，在欧洲则是船崇拜的经典国家。死者，或者更准确地说是船葬，是斯堪的纳维亚半岛。

In studying the bird we have already shown that the flying vessel is an evolution of it, like the horse. The horse has inherited its wings, the vessel only the ability to overcome the air. Waser says that "one cannot perhaps find a region inhabited by some entity, where there does not exist the belief in the vessel of souls." 365 In my opinion, this is not correct. The horse prevails in India, on the Asiatic steppes, among the Scythians, the Greeks, the Germans, the Slavs, etc., the boat predominates among the island peoples of Oceania, and in Europe the classic country of the cult of the boat of the dead, or more exactly of burial in a boat, is Scandinavia.

在整个大洋洲，各种形状的船只都被用作墓地。我们发现它们挂在树上366，放置在特殊的高平台367上，它们被简单地放入水中，或者被烧毁。从所有这些案例中，特别是从燃烧和平台上的展示来看，死者的空中旅程的表现清晰可见。

Throughout Oceania boats of all shapes and sizes serve as burial vessels. They are hung from trees 366 , placed on special high platforms 367 , simply lowered into the water, or burned. In all these cases, and particularly in the burning and display on platforms, the representation of the airborne journey of the deceased is clearly apparent.

这些表现显然源自鸟的表现，即使我们从雕刻的物体中不知道它，描绘了一只鸟形状的船，代表“灵魂的容器”。 “鸟形的船将灵魂运送到另一个世界，”弗罗贝尼乌斯说。如果在帝汶岛上人们相信，当他到达另一个世界时，船是全金的，这意味着死者已经到达了太阳的王国。

These manifestations evidently derive from the representation of the bird, even if we did not know it from the carved objects, representing a boat in the form of a bird, which represent the "vessel of souls". "The boat in the form of a bird transports the souls to the other world", says Frobenius. And if on the island of Timor it is believed that at the moment of his arrival in the other world the boat is all of gold, this means that the deceased has arrived in the realm of the sun.

在埃及，船与太阳融为一体：在这里，死者之船与太阳一起在水面上行驶368。在巴比伦，正如我们从吉尔伽美什神话中知道的那样，我们有过海的经历。

In Egypt the boat merged with the sun: here the vessel of the dead travels on the water together with the sun 368 . In Babylon, as we know from the myth of Gilgamesh, we have the crossing of the sea.

在希腊，不存在船葬仪式。正如博尔德列夫所说，“希腊人从来都不是天生的航海家”，他们害怕大海。 “在那片大海的波浪中冒险的船每次都可能在不知不觉中一点一点地进入那些童话般的地区，而普通的航行可能会转变为进入来世地区的朝圣” 369。对于希腊人来说，海洋是一种外来元素，埋葬在船上并不是一个有吸引力的前景，这与斯堪的纳维亚人的代表不同，正如阿努辛所证明的那样，在斯堪的纳维亚人中，埋葬在船上采取了庄严的形式，并在《埃达》中被铭记。 。

In Greece the rite of burial in a boat does not exist. As Boldyrèv says, "the Greeks were never born navigators", they were afraid of the sea. "The ship that ventured into the waves of that sea could penetrate every time without realizing it and little by little into those fairy-tale regions, and an ordinary navigation could transform itself into a pilgrimage to the regions of the afterlife" 369 . For the Greeks the sea was an alien element, being buried in a boat was not an attractive prospect, unlike the representation of the Scandinavians, among whom, as was demonstrated by Anucin, burial in a boat assumed solemn forms and is remembered in the Edda .

另一方面，在希腊的描述中，有黑暗舵手卡戎（Charon）渡河的故事，童话中也提到过。俄罗斯童话保留了老人向英雄发出的警告的细节：“在你的路上有三条宽阔的河流，这些河流上有三艘渡船：一开始他们会砍掉你的右手，第二次他们会砍掉你的右手。”第二个你左边，第三个他们就会砍下你的头。”撇开三重，我们在这里看到了在渡轮过程中手被截肢的表现（见Onč.3）。我们已经遇到过截手作为启蒙的典型元素。通过这一行动，舵手使自己成为死亡舵手。

On the other hand, in Greek representations we find the crossing of the river, with the dark ferryman Charon, also mentioned in the tale. The Russian tale has preserved the detail of the warning that the old man addresses to the hero: "On your path there are three wide rivers, on those rivers there are three ferries: on the first they will cut off your right hand, on the second your left, and on the third they will cut off your head." Leaving aside the triplication, we have here the representation of the amputation of the hand in the act of ferrying (cf. Onč. 3). We have already encountered the amputation of the hand as a typical element of initiation. With this operation the ferryman reveals himself as the ferryman of death.

7.树。

7. The tree .

通往天空的树的主题也有类似的起源。 « 他拿起麻袋，爬上了橡树。不断上升，他到达了天堂”（Af. 110）。在这里，俄罗斯童话反映了人们普遍持有的观念，即两个世界（有时甚至是地下、地上和天堂这三个世界）是通过树连接起来的。斯滕伯格关于西伯利亚人民对鹰的崇拜的书的第七章专门讨论了这种表现。最有趣的是中间树的表示与鸟的表示相关。在伊库蒂斯中，每个萨满都有一棵“萨满树”，即一根非常高的杆子，上面有像梯子一样的横杆，杆顶上有一只鹰的雕像。这棵树与萨满的入会有关。 “令人惊讶的是，”斯腾伯格写道，“在布里亚特人中，萨满入会的核心时刻是由一棵专门竖立的树的升天构成的；通过爬上这棵树，萨满通过与天上的处女的婚姻，达到了与神灵的最高交流……在萨满的小屋里，另一棵这样的树矗立着，但不那么高。奥罗科萨满的胸甲上描绘了上、中、下三个世界。萨满从这棵树上掉下来，就会带来整个世界的毁灭” 370。斯滕伯格调查了这棵树在西伯利亚各个民族中的名称，得出的结论是它的意思是“道路”。所有这些材料都非常有趣，但斯滕伯格的推论显得非常可疑。他将这棵树追溯到印度神圣之树的代表，“在那里，每一个佛陀（以及在他之前的每一个受启发的人），比如西伯利亚萨满，都有自己独特的树，他的美德与它联系在一起;这棵树被称为菩提塔鲁（bodhitaru），智慧树、知识树。通过树升天、与太阳之女的婚礼或第一个人从地狱升天这些主题不仅出现在亚洲，也出现在美国。

The motif of the tree by which one reaches heaven has a similar origin. "He took his sack and climbed up the oak. Climbing, climbing, he reached heaven" (Af. 110). Here the Russian tale reflects the widespread idea that the two worlds (and sometimes even the three, underground, terrestrial and celestial) are connected by the tree. The 7th chapter of Sternberg's book on the eagle cult among the Siberian peoples is devoted to this idea. What is most interesting is the fact that the idea of ​​the intermediary tree is connected with that of the bird. Among the Yakuts, every shaman has a "shamanic tree", that is, a very high pole with crossbars like a ladder and with the image of an eagle on the top. This tree is connected with the initiation of the shaman. "It is striking," writes Sternberg, "that among the Buryats the central moment of the shaman's initiation is constituted by the ascension of a specially erected tree; by climbing this tree the shaman reaches the supreme communion with the divinities, through his marriage with the celestial virgin... In the shaman's hut there stands another of these trees, but less tall. On the breastplate of the Oroco shaman the three worlds are depicted, the upper, the middle and the lower. A fall of the shaman from this tree brings with it the ruin of the whole world." 370 Sternberg investigates the name of this tree among the various Siberian peoples and comes to the conclusion that it means "road." All this material is very interesting, but Sternberg's deduction appears very doubtful. He traces this tree back to the representations of the sacred tree of India « where every Buddha (and before him every inspired person) had, like the Siberian shaman, his own particular tree to which his virtue was linked; this tree was called bodhitaru , tree of wisdom, of knowledge. The ascension to heaven by means of the tree, the marriage with the daughter of the sun or the ascension of the first men from hell, are subjects which are found not only in Asia, but also in America.

由此看来，无论是埋在树上还是埋在树干里，树与死者崇拜都没有什么关系。但中间树一方面与萨满仪式和鸟的形象有关系，另一方面，正如我们从阿努辛的材料中看到的那样，与死者被废黜的船和树干有关。所有这些联系都没有被民族志研究过。在菲尔波特和泽列宁对树的专门研究中，菲尔波特和泽列宁都没有提到树作为两个世界之间的中介371。但对于我们的目的来说，即使这些少数迹象也足够了。

Thus it is clear that, apart from burial in trees or in tree trunks, the tree has little connection with the cult of the dead. But the intermediary tree has a connection with shamanic initiation and with the image of the bird, on the one hand, and on the other, as we saw from Anucin's materials, with the boat and the trunk in which the deceased is laid. All these connections have not been studied by ethnography. In their special studies of the tree, both Philpot and Zelenin do not mention the tree as an intermediary between the two worlds . 371 But for our purposes even these few indications are sufficient.

8.梯子或带子。

8. The ladder or straps .

梯子的旅程与树紧密相连。从斯滕伯格的资料中我们已经看到萨满树的形状是梯子。在俄罗斯童话故事中，豌豆植物伸向天空。 “它就变成了梯子”（《SM》43）。这个天梯不仅可以用来登天，也可以用来登山。 “山上立刻出现了一个梯子”（Af. 93 a）。要进入地下世界，需要使用带子。 “然后他想到杀了他的马，剥了它们的皮，从它们的皮上切下丁字裤，把它们编成辫子，做成一个麻袋，然后下降到那里（即进入地下王国）”（Chud.2）。在由交织的马带制成的麻袋中，很容易辨认出包裹英雄的皮肤的变形。登山可以通过另一种有点出乎意料的方式来完成。英雄进入一个山洞：“他进入了山洞，手脚上套着铁爪，开始爬山”（Af.71）。鸟的爪子揭示了这一主题与鸟的形象之间的联系。

The journey with the ladder is closely connected with the tree. From Sternberg's materials we have already seen that the shamanic tree takes the form of a ladder. In the Russian fairy tale the pea plant reaches to the sky. "And it became a ladder" (Sm. 43). This ladder is not only used to climb to the sky, but also to climb the mountain. "And immediately a ladder appeared in the mountain" (Af. 93 a). To descend into the underworld, straps are used. "And it came into his mind to kill his horses, to flay them, and to cut straps from their hides, and to plait them and make a sack, and then to lower himself down there (that is, into the underworld)" (Chud. 2). In the sack made of plaited horse straps it is easy to recognize a deformation of the skin in which the hero wrapped himself. The ascent of the mountain can be accomplished in another, rather unexpected way. The hero enters a cave: "He entered it, attached to his hands and feet certain iron claws and began to climb the mountain" (Af. 71). The bird's claws reveal the connection between this motif and the image of the bird.

在这里，我们发现自己面临着由于上升和下降的原因而不同形式的同化。我们提到的所有形式都相对较新，并且很容易揭示它们从其他形式（特别是动物）的原始衍生。尽管众神沿着绳索从天而降的图像很早就出现过，但在坟墓用途中，梯子只有在与埃及相对应的阶段才会出现。在某些古埃及木乃伊附近发现了微型梯子，灵魂可以通过梯子升入天堂372。这天梯当然是仙梯，只有懂得魔法诀窍的人才能使用。 “塞特与太阳神和他的团体有联系，与此相对应，旧教义将他描述为监督死者可以爬向太阳神的梯子，塞特自己花了一段时间才爬上梯子。攀登 » 373。在《死者之书》（第 53 章）中，我们读到：“荣耀归于你，神之梯，荣耀归于你，赛特之梯，自首，神之梯，自首，赛特之梯……”

Here we are faced with the assimilation of different forms for the motif of ascent and for that of descent. All the forms we have mentioned are relatively more recent and easily reveal their original derivation from other forms, especially from animals. And although we meet with images of the gods descending from heaven along a rope quite early, ladders are only found in sepulchral usage at a stage corresponding to that of Egypt. Miniature ladders have been found among certain mummies of ancient Egypt, by which the souls could ascend to heaven . 372 This ladder is, of course, a fairy ladder, and can only be used by those who know the magic formulas. Set supervises it. "Set is connected with the sun-god and his group, and in accordance with this fact the old doctrine represents him as superintendent of the ladder by which the deceased can ascend to the sun-god, a ladder which Set himself once used to ascend . " 373 In the Book of the Dead (chap. 53) we read: "Glory to you, ladder of the god, glory to you, ladder of Set. Establish yourself, ladder of the god, establish yourself, ladder of Set..."

这些机械的渡轮手段（梯子、带子、绳索、链条、鱼叉等）是以前表现形式的变形。这种形式的渡轮（像以前的渡轮一样）表明我们正在处理渡轮在另一个世界的表征的反映。

These mechanical means of ferrying (ladders, straps, ropes, chains, harpoons, etc.) are a deformation of earlier representations. This form of ferry (like the previous ones) shows that we are dealing with a reflection of the representations of ferrying in the other world.

9.领导者。

9. The leader .

当英雄被带到另一个世界时，也可以说同样的事情。在这里，我们发现自己面对着灵魂领袖的大量代表。 “母狼开始奔跑，王也追赶她”（箴言 6）。 “向海而上，你会遇见一只金毛银鸟：它飞向哪里，你也去哪里”（Af. 71 c）。在这里，我们也有与其他形式相同的指南的动物方面。比较这三个案例——a ）英雄变成一只鸟飞走了；b ) 英雄骑在鸟身上飞走了；c ) 英雄发现了一只鸟并跟随它（Af. 96），——我们看到这里英雄发生了分裂、双重化。事实上，引导英雄是一种新的形式：例如，在美国神话中找不到它。在个人萨满教已经发展起来的地方，这个向导就是萨满。但他也采用了我们已知的运动方式。一位戈尔德人的萨满对斯滕伯格说：“不同的灵魂必须以不同的方式被引导：如果戈尔德是驯鹿牧民，他就必须被驯鹿牵引，如果他是狗牧民，他就必须被狗牵引；如果他是驯鹿牧民，他必须被驯鹿牵引；如果他是狗牧民，他必须被狗牵引；有些必须乘船前往» 374。

The same can be said when the hero is led into the other world. Here we are faced with the large group of representations of the leader of souls. "The she-wolf ran, and the little king galloped after her" (Aph. 6). "Go up to the sea, you will meet a silver bird with a golden crest: where it flies, go you too" (Aph. 71c). Here too we have the same animal aspect of the guide, exactly as in the other forms. Comparing these three cases - a ) the hero transforms himself into a bird and flies away; b ) the hero sits on a bird and flies away; c ) the hero sees a bird and follows it (Aph. 96) - we see that here a splitting, a doubling of the hero occurs. And, in fact, the guided hero is a recent form: it is not found, for example, in American myths. Where individual shamanism has already developed, this guide is the shaman. But he also uses the means of transport known to us. A shaman of the Golde people told Sternberg: "The different souls must be led differently: if the Golde was a reindeer breeder, he must be led on reindeer; if he was a dog breeder, he must be led with dogs; some must be led in boats . " 374

在狩猎不再是一种经济因素的地方，灵魂的引导者变得拟人化，但并没有失去他与动物的原始联系。例如，在埃及，在不太遥远的时代，奥西里斯就是这些向导之一。 “奥西里斯，众神的引导者，穿越杜阿特（地下世界），突破山脉，刺穿岩石，使每个库的心欢欣鼓舞”（《死亡之书》，XV，84）。但这无疑是最近才出现的现象。甲虫的形象似乎更加古老，死者有时会将自己变成甲虫，但后来成为他的向导。 “我通过一只甲虫进入了王宫”（同上，第 247 页）。

Where hunting has ceased to be an economic factor, the guide of souls becomes anthropomorphized, but does not lose his original link with animals. In Egypt, for example, in less remote times Osiris was one of these guides. "Osiris, guide of the gods, crosses the Duat (underworld), bursts through the mountains, pierces the rocks, gladdens the heart of every khu " ( Book of the Dead , XV, 84). But this is undoubtedly a more recent phenomenon. The representation of the scarab into which the deceased was sometimes transformed, but which later became his guide, appears more ancient. "I entered the king's house by means of a scarab which led me there" ( Ibid ., p. 247).

10.结论。

10. Conclusion .

从我们分析的形状中可以得出什么推论？第一个也是最根本的一点是，所有渡轮模式都有一个单一的起源：它们反映了死者在来世的漫游。

What deductions can be drawn from the forms we have analyzed? The first and fundamental one is that all modes of ferrying have a single origin: they reflect the representation of the deceased's wanderings in the afterlife.

第二个推论：形式的多样性通常可以被认为是后来的形式对更原始的形式的分层。这种变化源于生产方式的变化。最古老的形式是人转变为图腾动物的图腾表征。随着图腾崇拜的衰落，这些形式发生了变化。随着骑乘动物的出现和移动方式的改进，首先渡船的形式开始发生变化（人坐在鸟上），然后出现了动物本身：鹿和马。一开始，马与鸟同化，就像忽略马的民族中的船一样，从而产生了混合形式。死者的形象分为一背一身和一被背一身，或一牵一一被牵。随着农业的到来，向导变得拟人化和神化，但他的动物本性仍然从初级和相似之处清晰地闪耀出来。就连梯子、树、带子等形状，也通过比较揭示了它们最初的动物形态。

Second deduction: the diversity of forms can often be considered as a stratification of later forms on other more primitive ones. This change is caused by the change in the forms of production. The oldest form is the totemic representation of the transformation of man into his totemic animal. With the decline of totemism these forms change. With the appearance of saddle animals and the improvement of methods of locomotion, first the forms of the ferry begin to change (men sit on birds) and then the animals themselves: the deer and the horse appear. At first the horse is assimilated to the bird, as happens with the boat among peoples who are unaware of the horse, giving rise to hybrid forms. The figure of the deceased is split into the one who carries and the one who is carried, or into the one who leads and the one who is led. With the arrival of agriculture the guide is anthropomorphized and divinized, but his animal nature still shines through clearly from the rudiments and parallels. Even shapes such as the ladder, the tree and the straps reveal their original animal form through comparison.

第七章 火河之上

Chapter Seven On the River of Fire

一、童话中的蛇

I. The Serpent in the Fairy Tale

1.蛇的出现。

1. The appearance of the snake .

本章的关注中心将是蛇的形象，特别是我们将讨论与蛇的决斗。对于任何对蛇的材料了解甚少的人来说，很明显，它是世界各地民间传说和宗教中最复杂、最难以破译的人物之一。蛇的整体外观及其在童话中的角色由一系列细节组成。必须对每个细节进行解释。但没有整体就无法解释特殊，而整体又是由特殊组成的。展览程序可能有所不同；我们将按如下方式进行：首先，我们将揭露童话故事的材料，我们将根据这个故事给出蛇的特征，而不求助于比较材料，我们稍后才会使用比较材料，但是遵循另一个命令。我们将首先研究最古老和最古老的反应，然后研究最新的和最近的反应。

The focus of this chapter will be on the figure of the serpent, and in particular we will deal with the duel with the serpent. It is clear to anyone with even a superficial knowledge of the materials on the serpent that it is one of the most complicated and undeciphered figures in folklore and religion throughout the world. The whole appearance of the serpent and its part in the fairy tale consists of a series of particulars. Each of these particulars must be explained. But the particular cannot be explained without the whole, and the whole in turn is made up of particulars. The expository procedures may vary; we will proceed as follows: first we will set out the material of the fairy tale, we will give the characteristic of the serpent according to this tale, without resorting to comparative materials, to which we will resort only at a later time, but following another order. We will first study the most ancient and archaic correspondences, and then the newest and most recent.

对于故事的创作者或听者来说，蛇是怎样的？在童话故事中，在正宗的俄罗斯民间故事中，从来没有描述过蛇。我们知道他长什么样，但我们从童话里不知道。如果我们想只根据童话故事的素材来画蛇，那是很困难的。但是，尽管如此，还是可以勾勒出其外观的一些特征。

How does the snake appear to the creator or listener of the fairy tale? In the fairy tale, in the authentic Russian folk tale, the snake is never described. We know what it looks like, but we do not know it from the fairy tale. If we wanted to paint the snake only from the materials of the fairy tale, it would be difficult. But, nevertheless, some features of its external appearance can be outlined.

首先，蛇始终是一个有多个头的生物。头的数量各不相同，以3头、6头、9头、12头为主，但也可以有5头和7头。对于蛇来说，这是一个基本的、恒定的、不会失败的性格。

First of all, the snake is always a being with many heads. The number of heads varies, 3, 6, 9, 12 heads predominate, but there can also be 5 and 7. In the snake this is a fundamental, constant and unfailing characteristic.

所有其他角色都只是零星地被提及，有时甚至根本没有被提及。例如，并不总是说蛇是有翅膀的生物。他在空中飞翔：“忽然，距他们一俄里，他们看见一条蛇飞来”（《箴言》72）。 “蛇飞来，开始盘绕小女王”（Af. 104 a）。但是，尽管它的翅膀几乎从未被提及与飞行有关，但人们可能会认为它在没有翅膀的情况下在空中滑翔。童话故事甚至没有描述他的身体，我们不知道它是有鳞的、光滑的还是被皮肤覆盖的。一般来说，流行卡通中最喜欢的细节——unguirostra腿和长尖尾巴也不见了。蛇的飞行有时类似于女巫的飞行。 “猛烈的风暴爆发，雷霆隆隆，大地颤抖，茂密的森林俯首：那是飞翔的三头鹰”（Af.71b，V）。在阿法纳西耶夫的整个作品集中，翅膀只被提及一次：蛇“用火热的翅膀”带走了女王（Af.72）。

All other characters are mentioned only sporadically and sometimes not at all. For example, the serpent is not always said to be a winged creature. It flies through the air: "Suddenly, a verst away from them they see a flying serpent" (Aph. 72). "The serpent flew in and began to coil itself around the little queen" (Aph. 104 a). But, nevertheless, its wings are almost never mentioned in connection with flight; one might think that it glides through the air without wings. The tale does not even describe its body; we do not know whether it is scaly, smooth or covered with skin. Usually, the unguirostral legs and the long, pointed tail, a favourite feature of popular cartoons, are also missing. The flight of the serpent sometimes recalls that of the sorceress. « A violent storm breaks out, the thunder rumbles, the earth trembles, the thick forest bends: it is the three-headed eagle that flies » (Af. 71 b, V). In the whole of Afanasiev's collection wings are mentioned only once: the serpent carries the little queen away « on its fiery wings » (Af. 72).

也许缺乏描述证明了小说家对蛇的形象并不完全清楚。有时他与英雄形象同化，被表现为骑士；在他的领导下，马常常会绊倒。

The absence of description probably proves that the image of the serpent is not entirely clear to the storyteller. Sometimes it is assimilated to the figure of the hero and is represented as a knight; under him the horse usually stumbles.

蛇是一种炽热的生物。 “一条愤怒的蛇飞向他，喷出火焰，用死亡威胁他”（Af. 92）。以马为例，我们确切地知道火、火花和烟雾是从它的鼻孔和耳朵中发出的。这里没有什么类似的。尽管如此，可以说蛇与火的联系是其特征之一。 “蛇用火焰燃烧，用爪子撕裂”（Chud. 119）。蛇体内携带着这种火焰并将其喷出：“然后蛇喷出了熊熊的火焰，想要烧死公主们”（Af. 95 P）。 “我要用火焚烧你的王国，将其灰烬撒在风中”（弗 152）。这是蛇威胁的不变公式。只有一种情况下，火王与蛇相匹配：“在到达他的王国之前三十俄里，火已经在燃烧”（Af.119a）。

The serpent is a fiery being. "A ferocious serpent flies towards him, spurts fire, threatens him with death" (Aph. 92). Of the horse, for example, we know precisely that fire, sparks and smoke come out of its nostrils and ears. Here there is nothing similar. Nevertheless, it can be said that the serpent's connection with fire is one of its characteristics. "The serpent burns with flame, tears with its claws" (Chud. 119). The serpent carries this fire within itself and emits it: "Then the serpent put out a fiery flame and wanted to burn the princesses" (Aph. 95 P). "I will burn your kingdom with fire, and scatter its ashes to the wind" (Aph. 152). This is the constant formula of the serpent's threats. In only one case does the serpent correspond to the king of fire: "Thirty versts before reaching his kingdom the fire is already burning" (Af. 119 a).

2.童话中与水的联系。

2. The connection with water in the fairy tale .

但蛇还与另一种元素有关：这个元素就是水。他不仅是火王，也是水王。这两个角色并不互相排斥，他们经常合作。例如，水之王发出了一封带有三个黑色印章的信，要求交出女王玛法，并威胁要“杀死所有人，用火烧毁整个王国”（Af.68）。因此，水元素和火元素并不相互排斥。蛇的水生特性也从它的名字中可见一斑：它是“黑海蛇”，生活在水中。当他浮出水面时，水也在他下面上升。 “然后鸭子嘎嘎叫，河岸回响，大海移动，大海变得躁动，那个怪物犹大出来了”（Af.76）。 « 突然，蛇开始出现，在他身后，水涌出三岸高（Af. 68）。在童话故事中，蛇睡在海中央的一块石头上，打呼噜，“它打呼噜，七俄里外的波浪就升起来了”（Af.73）。

But there is another element with which the serpent is connected: this element is water. He is not only the king of fire, he is also the king of water. These two characteristics do not exclude each other, they often ally themselves. Thus, for example, the king of water sends a letter with three black seals and demands the handing over of Queen Martha, he threatens to "kill all the men and burn the whole kingdom with fire" (Aph. 68). Therefore the watery and fiery elements do not exclude each other. This aquatic nature of the serpent is also evident from his name: he is the "serpent of the black sea" and lives in the water. When he rises above the water, the water also rises beneath him. "Then the duck quacked, the banks resounded, the sea moved, the sea was agitated, that Judas monster sprang out" (Aph. 76). « Suddenly the serpent began to emerge, and behind it the water gushed up three arshins high (Af. 68). In one fairy tale the serpent sleeps on a stone in the middle of the sea, and snores, « snores so that the wave rises seven versts away » (Af. 73).

3、与山的联系。

3. The connection with the mountains .

但蛇还有另一个名字，叫做“山蛇”。他住在山里，但这居住地并不妨碍他同时也是海怪。 “突然，云移，风起，海涛汹涌，蛇从碧海中升起，升上山”（Af.92）。尽管“在山上”一词也可以简单地表示“在岸上”，但无法区分两种类型的蛇：水生蛇和山蛇。有时他住在山里，但当英雄走近他时，他就从水里出来了。 “他们走了一年、两年，跨越了三个境界，看到了远处的高山，山中的某些沙质草原，那是凶蛇的国度”（Af.74P）。居住在山间是蛇的一个共同特征。

But the serpent also has another name, it is called "Mountain-Serpent". It lives in the mountains, but this place of residence does not prevent it from being at the same time a sea monster. "Suddenly the clouds moved, the wind rose, the sea was agitated, from the blue sea arose the serpent and rose up on the mountain" (Aph. 92). And although the words "on the mountain" can also mean simply "on the shore", one cannot distinguish two types of serpent, the water one and the mountain one. Sometimes it lives in the mountains, but when the hero approaches it, it comes out of the water. "They walked a year, two years, they passed through three kingdoms and saw high mountains in the distance, between the mountains certain sandy steppes, that was the country of the fierce serpent" (Aph. 74 P). The dwelling in the mountains is a common characteristic of the serpent.

4.蛇绑匪。

4. The serpent-captor .

蛇的行为如何？从本质上讲，它有两个特有的功能：第一个是女绑匪的。通常，老鼠的速度快如闪电且突然。国王有三个女儿，她们正在一座美丽的花园里散步。 «看哪，黑海蛇开始飞到那里。有一次，国王的女儿们在花园里徘徊，看着花朵。突然，情况并非如此，黑海蛇来了，用它炽热的翅膀把他们带走了”（Af.72）。

How does the serpent behave? Basically, two functions are peculiar to it; the first is that of the kidnapper of women. Usually the kidnapping is lightning-fast and sudden. A king has three daughters, who are walking in a magnificent garden. "And behold, the Black Sea Serpent took the habit of flying there. One day the king's daughters were lingering in the garden to look at the flowers. Suddenly, who knows, the Black Sea Serpent arrived and carried them away on his fiery wings" (Af. 72).

但蛇并不是唯一的绑匪，不能从其他行为与它完全相同的绑匪中抽象地进行分析。例如，不朽的科什切伊可能会扮演绑匪的角色。 « 在某个王国，某个国家，曾经住着一位国王。这位国王有三个儿子。但有一天，不朽的科什切伊带走了他们的母亲»（Af. 93 a）。

But the serpent is not the only kidnapper and cannot be analyzed by abstracting it from some other kidnappers who act exactly like it. The role of kidnapper can be played, for example, by Košcej the Immortal. "In a certain kingdom, in a certain state, there once lived a king. This king had three sons. But one fine day Košcej the Immortal took their mother away" (Af. 93 a).

有时绑匪是一只鸟。 “就在那时，火鸟飞来，抓住了他们的母亲，带她越过遥远的土地，越过遥远的海洋，进入他的王国”（《诗篇》31）。

Sometimes the captor is a bird. "Then the firebird flew in, caught their mother, and carried her away to distant lands, to his kingdom, over the distant sea" (Sm. 31).

在空中绑架者的作用下，风或旋风以特定的频率出现。但类似案例的比较表明，旋风背后通常有一条蛇，或者科什切伊，或者一只鸟。旋风可以认为是失去了动物、蛇等形态的绑匪。绑架的是旋风，但当英雄寻找王后时，却发现她落入了蛇的手中（《SM.160》）。 “但这不是旋风，而是凶猛的蛇”，这是故事中公开的说法（Af. 74 P）。诸如“科什切伊从窗户飞进来，就像一阵可怕的旋风”（Af.94）这样的某些表达方式向我们展示了动物的一面是如何消失的。 “突然刮起了大风，沙尘暴起，风把小女孩从护士手中夺走了，不知把她带到了哪里”（Chud.53）。这里没有动物，但事实证明，女王掌握在老鹰的手中。

In the role of the aerial kidnapper, the wind or the whirlwind appears with particular frequency. But a comparison of similar cases shows that usually behind the whirlwind lies the serpent, or Košcej, or a bird. The whirlwind can be regarded as a kidnapper who has lost his animal, serpent, etc. form. It is the whirlwind that kidnaps, but when the hero searches for the little queen, it turns out that she is in the power of the serpent (Sm. 160). "But this is not the whirlwind, but the fierce serpent," as is openly stated in the tale (Af. 74 P). Certain expressions such as "Košcej flew in through the window, like a fearful whirlwind" (Af. 94) show us how the animal aspect has been lost. "Suddenly a strong wind arose, the sand and dust rose in clouds, the wind snatched the child from the nurse's hands and carried her off to who knows where" (Chud. 53). There is no animal here, but it turns out that the little queen is in the power of the eagle.

扮演绑匪角色的魔鬼、邪灵只不过是在小说家同时代的宗教表征影响下的进一步变形。

The devils, the evil spirits who play the part of the kidnapper, are nothing more than a further deformation under the influence of religious representations contemporary to the storyteller.

5.蛇的税收。

5. The snake's taxes .

蛇的作用不仅限于吞噬或绑架女孩，或者以邪灵的形式定居在活人身上并折磨他，或者在死人身上强迫他吞噬活人。有时他会表现出威胁性，围攻一座城市，并要求一名女子结婚或将其吞噬作为贡品。这个主题，可以简称为“蛇的税收”，非常普遍，其特征也相当统一。本质上，事情可以归结为：英雄最终来到了异国他乡，看到每个人都“如此担心”，并从他偶然遇到的人那里得知，蛇每年（或每个月）都需要一个女孩，并且现在轮到国王的女儿了。在这些情况下——必须强调的是——蛇总是扮演水生生物的角色。公主已经被带到了海边。 « 他们告诉他，她是国王唯一的女儿，美丽的帕柳莎公主，第二天他们会带她去蛇那里吃掉她；在那个王国里，每个月都会有一个女孩被送给七头蛇。轮到国王的女儿了”（Af. 104 a）。

The functions of the serpent are not limited to devouring or carrying off the maiden, or, in the form of an evil spirit, taking up residence in a living man and tormenting him, or in a dead man and forcing him to devour the living. Sometimes he appears threatening, besieges a city and demands as tribute a woman to marry or to devour. This motif, which can be called briefly "the serpent's taxes," is very widespread and its characteristics are fairly uniform. In essence the matter boils down to the following: the hero arrives in a foreign land, sees that everyone is "so angry," and from people he meets by chance learns that every year (or every month) the serpent demands a maiden, and now it is the king's daughter's turn. In these cases, it must be emphasized, the serpent always acts as an aquatic being. The princess has already been led to the seashore. « They told him that she was the king's only daughter, the beautiful princess Palyusha, and that tomorrow they would take her to the serpent to eat her; in that kingdom every month a girl was given to the seven-headed serpent; and it was the king's daughter's turn » (Af. 104 a).

6.守卫边境的蛇。

6. The serpent guarding the borders .

在这种情况下，蛇住在一条河边，而这条河通常是一条火河。河上有一座桥。这条河有自己的名字：它叫红醋栗河，桥总是用荚蒾搭建的。英雄站在桥下发现了蛇的到来。 “午夜来临，他们从荚蒾桥下经过，穿过火河”（Af. 74 b）。这条河是边境。你不能过桥：桥上有蛇把守，只有杀死蛇后才能过桥。 “他们一步一步地走到一座红桥，没有人可以越过它，他们不得不在那里过夜”（《SM.150》）。此时我们想起了女巫：她也是入口的守护者。女巫守护外围；巨蛇守卫着遥远王国的中心。一些配件特别清晰地回忆起女巫：“他们来到一条火河，河上有一座桥，河的周围是一片巨大的森林”（Af.78）。有时河边有一座小茅屋，但无人居住，行人也不在里面提问或吃点心。尽管如此，它有时被同化为女巫的小屋，有时它站在鱼尾纹上。没有栅栏，骨头没有固定在柱子上，而是散落在各处：“他们到达了红醋栗河；岸边到处都是人骨散落，一直到膝盖！他们看到一间小茅屋，就进去了：里面空无一人，他们想在那里停下来”（Af. 77）。只有在战斗结束后，才谈到这位英雄“他过了桥，到达了对岸”（Af. 95 P）。

In such cases the serpent dwells beside a river, which is often a river of fire. There is a bridge over the river. This river has its own name: it is called the Red Currant River, the bridge is always made of viburnum. The hero spies on the serpent's arrival by standing under the bridge. "Then midnight came, and they passed under the viburnum bridge, across the river of fire" (Aph. 74b). This river is a frontier. The bridge cannot be crossed: the bridge is guarded by the serpent and one can only cross it after killing the serpent. "They walked and walked, and came to a red bridge, which no one could cross, and there they had to spend the night" (Sm. 150). At this point the sorceress comes to mind: she too is the guardian of the entrance. The sorceress guards the outskirts; the serpent guards the very heart of the distant kingdom. Some accessories recall the sorceress with particular clarity: "They came to a river of fire, over the river there was a bridge, and all around the river an immense forest" (Af. 78). Sometimes next to the river there is a hut, but no one lives there, in it the traveler is not questioned or refreshed. Nevertheless it sometimes resembles the hut of the sorceress, sometimes it stands on chicken legs. There is no fence, the bones are not fixed on poles but are scattered around: "They come to the river of the Red Currant; all around on the bank are scattered human bones, they reach the knee! They see a hut, they go in: it was deserted and they decided to stop there" (Af. 77). And only after the fight is it said of the hero that "he crossed the bridge and reached the other bank" (Af. 95 P).

7.吞食蛇。

7. The swallowing serpent .

有时童话特别强调蛇的守护者角色：“那里有一条宽阔的河，河上有一座荚莲树桥，桥下有十二头蛇；”它不允许骑士或行人通过，它吞噬所有人”（Af. 95 P）。蛇比女巫更清楚地表达了自己的意图：它想吞掉并吃掉英雄。 “现在告别这个世界，独自滑入我的喉咙，这对你来说会更好”（Af.92）。 “我会把你们全吃掉，连肉带骨。”占据公主的蛇也想吞掉英雄，公主警告他：“他会吃掉你。”某些表达方式，例如“他想吞下一切”（Af. 95 P）。 “现在我要吃了你”（Af. 118 c）经常出现。即使在战斗之后，这种危险还没有完全消失，事实上，在战斗之后，它变得特别具有威胁性。蛇被杀死后，童话故事中会出现他的母亲或婆婆，这些人物的唯一作用就是威胁要吞下英雄；有时甚至会实施威胁。因此，蛇的形象是重复的：这里有雌性吞咽蛇。它追赶英雄，到达他身边，“在他身后，第三条蛇急忙张开血盆大口，从地面向天空……如何拯救自己？” » 他把三匹马扔进嘴里，然后又扔了三只猎鹰和三只灰狗；但蛇继续追捕他。然后他把两个同伴扔进了嘴里。最后他来到了铁匠那里，他们用烧红的钳子抓住了蛇的舌头，从而拯救了英雄（《箴言》74b）。

Sometimes the tale places special emphasis on the guardianship entrusted to the serpent: "There is a wide river over there, across the river is a bridge of viburnum, under the bridge stands the twelve-headed serpent; it allows neither riders nor pedestrians to pass, it devours everyone" (Aph. 95 P). The serpent expresses its intentions much more clearly than the witch: it wants to swallow up, to eat the hero. "And now say goodbye to the world and crawl down my throat alone, it will be better for you" (Aph. 92). "I will eat you all, flesh and bone." The serpent that has taken possession of the princess also aims to swallow the hero, and the princess warns it: "He will eat you up." Expressions such as "he wants to swallow him all up" (Aph. 95 P) and "now I will eat you up" (Aph. 118 c) occur very often. Even after the fight this danger has not yet completely disappeared; indeed, after the fight it becomes particularly threatening. After the serpent has been killed, the tale brings in its mother or mother-in-law, and the sole function of these figures is to threaten to swallow the hero; sometimes the threat is even carried out. Thus the image of the serpent is duplicated: here we have the female swallowing serpent. It pursues the hero, catches up with him, "behind it the third serpent hurries, opens its jaws from earth to heaven... how can one save oneself?" It throws three horses into its jaws, then three falcons and three greyhounds; but the serpent continues to hunt him. Then it throws its two companions into its jaws. Finally it reaches the blacksmiths, who seize the serpent by the tongue with their red-hot pincers and thus save the hero (Aph. 74b).

在另一个童话故事中，英雄将三块盐（375）扔进母 蛇的嘴里（Af.75）。有一个童话故事，说这条蛇变成了一头巨大的母猪，吞下了两兄弟和马。在这里，英雄也躲避了铁匠，铁匠们用钳子抓住蛇的舌头，然后用棍子殴打它。 « 母猪恳求道：“勇敢的布尔加！让我小小的灵魂忏悔吧！ “……”那你为什么要吞掉我两个兄弟？ ” “现在我马上还给你。布尔贾抓住了他的耳朵。母猪吐口水，两兄弟带着马跳了出来”（Af. 76）。

In another tale the hero throws three poods 375 of salt into the jaws of the female snake (Af. 75). There is a fairy tale in which this snake transforms itself into a huge sow and swallows two of the brothers together with the horses. Here too the hero takes refuge from the blacksmiths who seize the snake by the tongue with their pincers and beat it with rods. "And the sow begged: 'Brave Búrja! Let my little soul repent! '….. 'And why have you swallowed my two brothers? ' 'Now I will give them back to you at once. ' Búrja seized her by the ears; the sow spat and the two brothers jumped out with their horses. ' (Af. 76).

8.睡眠的危险。

8. The danger of sleep .

在与蛇的遭遇中，英雄受到了危险的威胁：睡眠的危险，入睡的危险。这与我们在与女巫会面时已经看到的危险是一样的。 « 走啊走，他们来到了一片荒芜茂密的森林。他们刚进去，就沉沉地睡着了。弗洛尔卡-西登从口袋里掏出鼻烟盒，打开，将一把烟草塞进鼻子里，然后开始喊道：“嘿，兄弟们，别睡着了，继续！ „ »（AF.72）。这次睡眠是一个建议。 « 小王子开始在桥上行走，用木槌敲击，然后一个小罐子跳了出来，开始在他面前跳舞；他盯着她看，然后就睡着了。”假英雄睡着了，真正的英雄永远不会睡着。 “勇敢的布尔贾向他脸上吐口水，并将他撕成碎片”（Af. 76）。在奥涅加的童话故事中，帮助英雄的蛇妈妈告诉他：“现在出发……但是不要睡在海边，否则我的儿子会飞起来看到马和你，你会睡觉，你会被他打败，但如果你不睡觉，他不会对你做任何事，他将无法对付你们两个”（Hon. Zav.，第 144 页） ）。在战斗中，英雄的兄弟们发现自己在小屋里，尽管英雄已经警告过，但他们总是睡着了。当英雄与蛇搏斗时，兄弟们前一天晚上喝醉了，睡着了，我们就扭曲了这个主题。

During the encounter with the serpent the hero is threatened by a danger: the danger of sleep, the danger of falling asleep. It is the same danger that we have already seen during the encounter with the sorceress. « They walked and walked, they came to a wild and thick forest. They had hardly entered it when a heavy sleep took hold of them. Frolka-Siden took her snuffbox from her pocket, opened it and stuck a handful of snuff in her nose, then she began to shout: “Hey, brothers, don't fall asleep, carry on! „ » (Af. 72). This sleep is a suggestion. « The little prince began to walk on the bridge, to tap with his mallet, then a little jug jumped out and began to dance in front of him; he stared at it and fell into a heavy sleep. » The false hero falls asleep, the true hero never falls asleep. "The brave Búrja spat in his face and tore him to pieces" (Af. 76). In a tale from Onega the mother of the serpents, who helps the hero, says to him: "Now set out... But don't go to sleep by the sea, otherwise my son will fly and see the horses and you, and you will sleep, you will be defeated by him, but if you don't sleep he won't do anything to you, he won't be able to deal with you two" (On. Zav., p. 144). During the fight the hero's brothers are in the hut and invariably fall asleep, despite having been warned by the hero. A distortion of this motif is when the brothers get drunk the night before and sleep while the hero fights the serpent.

9.原来的敌人。

9. The original enemy .

决斗之前通常会发生争吵和吹牛。蛇自吹自擂，但英雄也很放荡：“我会用一只手把你捧在手掌上，用另一只手给你很多打击，连你的骨头都找不到”（Af. 74 P） ）。

The duel is usually preceded by a fight and boasting. The serpent boasts, but the hero also has a loose tongue: "With one hand I will take you in the palm, and with the other I will give you such a beating that not even your bones will be found" (Af. 74 P).

然而，在这场争论中，一个非常重要的情况出现了：蛇有一个对手，而这个对手就是英雄。因此，巨蛇知道英雄的存在，不仅如此，它还知道自己将会灭亡在这个英雄的手中。或者，更准确地说：蛇不会死在任何人的手中，它是不朽的，所向无敌的。英雄和蛇之间存在着一种纽带，这种纽带的起源超出了故事的范围。 “除了小国王伊万，我在全世界没有其他对手……但他还年轻，连乌鸦都不会把他的骨头带到这里”（Af. 71 b V）。

During this quarrel, however, a very important circumstance comes to light: the serpent has an adversary and this adversary is the hero. Therefore the serpent knows of the existence of the hero, and not only that, but it knows that it will perish at the hands of this hero. Or, to put it more precisely: the serpent cannot perish at the hands of anyone else, it is immortal and invincible. There is a bond between the hero and the serpent that has its origin outside the scope of the story. "In the whole world I have no other adversary than the little king Ivan... but he is still young, not even the raven will bring his bones here" (Af. 71 b V).

10.决斗。

10. The duel .

我们希望对决作为整个故事的高潮，得到重点描述，细节突出英雄的力量和大胆。但这并不符合童话故事的风格。与许多民族的英雄史诗相反，在这些英雄史诗中，战斗和战斗是歌曲的中心，有时甚至描述得相当长，而童话故事则简单而简短。战斗本身没有详细描述。 “勇敢的布尔贾逃跑了，挥舞着他的棍棒，砍下了他的三个头”（Af.76）。不过，有一些细节需要特别注意。蛇从不试图用武器、爪子或牙齿杀死英雄：它试图让他沉入地下，从而杀死他。 “犹大怪物接管了并强迫他跪在潮湿的土地上。”在第二次决斗中，“他把他的腰部贴在潮湿的泥土里”。反过来，只有砍掉它所有的头才能杀死这条蛇，但这些头有一个神奇的特性：它们会重新长出来。 « 他从犹大怪物身上砍下了九个头；怪物把它们捡起来，用他炽热的手指做了一个手势，然后它们又粘在了他身上”（Af.77）。只有在砍掉了炽热的手指之后，英雄才设法砍掉了所有的头。

We would expect the duel, as the climax of the whole tale, to be described with emphasis, with details that would emphasize the hero's strength and courage. But this is not the style of the fairy tale. Unlike the heroic epic of many peoples, in which the fight and the battle are the center of the song and are sometimes even described at some length, the fairy tale is simple and brief. The fight itself is not described in detail. "The brave Búrja ran up, brandished his club and cut off three of his heads" (Af. 76). There are, however, some details that require special attention. The serpent never tries to kill the hero with a weapon or with its paws or with its teeth: it tries to make him sink into the ground and then kill him. "The Judas-monster gained the upper hand, forced him to kneel on the damp earth." In the second duel, "he stuck it up to the waist in the damp earth." The serpent, in turn, can only be killed by cutting off all its heads, but the heads have a miraculous peculiarity: they grow back again. "He cut off nine heads from the Judas monster; the monster picked them up, made a sign with his fiery finger, and they reattached themselves to him" (Af. 77). Only after cutting off the fiery finger does the hero manage to cut off all the heads.

第三次战斗是最可怕的。正如我们已经说过的，兄弟俩睡在拴着马的小屋里。在决定性的时刻，英雄将帽子或靴子扔进小屋。然后小屋倒塌了，马赶紧去救主人。这也是战斗描述中的一个不变特征：只有马（或其他助手，例如英雄的狼群）才能杀死蛇。 “小马驹跑上来，把蛇从马鞍上扔下来”（Af. 76）。 “马投入战斗，开始用牙齿咬蛇，用蹄踩碎它”（Af. 71 b V）。 “野兽冲向他，把他撕成碎片”（AF.117）。一匹马站起来，扑到蛇的肩膀上，另一匹马用蹄子踢它的两侧，蛇摔倒了，马用腿把它踩碎了。噢，多么聪明的马啊！ »（Zav 阁下，第 145 页）。

The third fight is the most terrible. The brothers, as we have already said, sleep in the hut to which the horse is tied. At the decisive moment the hero throws his hat or a boot into the hut. Then the hut falls apart and the horse rushes to the aid of its master. This too is a constant feature in the description of the fight: only the horse (or another helper, for example the hero's pack) can kill the snake. "The colts ran up and threw the snake from its saddle" (Aph. 76). "The horse rushed into the fray and began to gnaw the snake with his teeth and trample it with his hooves" (Aph. 71 b V). "The wild beasts rushed at him and tore him to pieces" (Aph. 117). « One horse reared up and threw itself on the serpent's shoulders, the other struck its sides with its hooves, and the serpent fell and the horses crushed it with their hooves. Oh, what good horses! » (On. Zav., p. 145).

当然，战斗以英雄的胜利而结束。但一旦战斗结束，最后一件事必须处理：必须彻底消灭这条蛇。蛇或其头必须被烧毁。 “他就把树干扔在火河里”（弗 74 b）。 “他收集了所有零件，将它们烧毁，并将灰烬撒在田野里”（Af. 73）。 “他点燃火，烧了蛇，并将其灰烬撒在风中”（《箴言》71 b V）。有时，蛇的遗骸会被扔进海里，或藏在桥下，或埋在石头下。

The fight ends, of course, with the victory of the hero. But once the battle is over, one last task must be taken care of: the serpent must be destroyed once and for all. The serpent or its heads must be burned. "And he threw the trunk into the river of fire" (Aph. 74 b). "He gathered all the parts, burned them, and scattered the ashes in the field" (Aph. 73). "He lit a pyre, burned the serpent, and scattered its ashes to the wind" (Aph. 71 b V). Sometimes the remains of the serpent are thrown into the sea, or hidden under the bridge, or buried under a stone.

略有不同的是，有一些偏差，战斗继续进行，蛇占据了一个女人，在决斗之前，英雄看到了公主并与她交谈。经常有三姐妹在蛇出现之前隐藏英雄。但更多时候公主住在一座非常奇怪的宫殿里。例如，她“在钻石宫殿中”（Af. 71 b V）。在这些情况下，英雄几乎总是在战斗前睡着，尤其是在公主被带到蛇那里被蛇吞掉的故事中。英雄睡得很香，头枕在公主腿上，很难叫醒他。通过这种方式，我们在童话故事中看到了睡眠的双重本质。一方面，虚假英雄在战斗前或战斗中睡觉。另一方面，是在战斗前睡觉的英雄。童话故事本身并不清楚这种睡眠的本质，需要专门研究。

A somewhat different and somewhat different course is followed by a fight in which the serpent has taken possession of a woman, and before the duel the hero sees the princess and speaks to her. Often it is three sisters who hide the hero before the serpent appears. But more often still the princess lives in a very strange palace. She, for example, lives "in a diamond palace" (Af. 71 b V). In these cases the hero almost always falls asleep before the fight, especially in the tales in which the princess has been led to the serpent to be devoured by it. The hero sleeps soundly, with his head on the princess's knees, and it is difficult to wake him. Thus we see in the fairy tale the double nature of sleep. On the one hand, the false heroes sleep before or during the fight. On the other hand, it is the hero himself who sleeps before the fight. The nature of this sleep is not clear from the fairy tale itself and requires special study.

这些就是蛇的基本特征和典型特征，现在让我们继续历史性地研究它。

These would be the fundamental and typical characteristics of the snake, and now let's move on to studying it historically.

11.关于蛇的参考书目。

11. The bibliography on the serpent .

关于蛇的参考书目浩如烟海，浩如烟海，我们不仅无法批判性地审视它，甚至无法一一列出；在这项研究中，我们必须限制自己只提及这些群体。但尽管如此，蛇形象的起源和争斗原因的问题还不能算是解决。所有这些研究都属于某些类别，而这些类别本身以及指导它们的原则和方法都注定了这些作品的失败。例如，有一组研究将蛇的形象视为对曾经存在的史前动物的回忆。这些作品本身就已经是错误的，因为正如已经精确确定的那样，人类是在这些动物灭绝之后才出现在地球上的。例如，Bölsche 并不否认这一事实，但相信人类已经根据这些动物的骨头重建了它们的表征376。这种说法本身是荒谬的，但它并不符合现实，还因为带翼蛇的形象是一个较新的现象：它是在我们眼前形成的，而且它形成的过程是可以追踪的。但这些研究仍然包含一种理论，试图从本质上解释这一现象。我们在另一个类别的作品中发现了同样的尝试，即神话尤其是太阳理论377的追随者的作品。与这个理论争论是没有用的。例如，西克指出，蛇是月亮的黑暗面，而英雄是光明面。然而，必须认识到，作者非常认真地使用和收集这些材料，没有歪曲它们或使它们适应他们的理论。因此，这些材料可以放心使用，并在一定程度上使我们免于收集材料的苦差事。

There is a vast bibliography on the serpent, so vast that we cannot even critically examine it, nor even list it; in this study we must limit ourselves to mentioning only the groups. But with all this the problem of the origin of the image of the serpent and of the motif of the fight cannot be considered solved. All these studies fall into certain categories and these categories, as such, as well as the principles and methods that inform them, condemn the works to failure. Thus, for example, there is a group of studies in which the figure of the serpent is studied as a reminiscence of prehistoric animals that once existed. Such works are already erroneous in themselves because, as has been precisely established, man appeared on earth only after these animals had become extinct. Bölsche, for example, does not deny the fact, but believes that man reconstructed the representation of these animals on the basis of their bones . 376 This statement is absurd in itself, but it does not correspond to reality also because the image of the winged serpent is a more recent phenomenon: it was formed before our eyes and the process of its formation can be followed. But these studies still contain a theory, an attempt to explain the phenomenon in its essence. We find the same attempt in the works of another category, namely that of the followers of the mythological and especially solar theory . 377 Polemicizing with this theory is useless. Siecke, for example, states that the serpent is the dark side of the moon, and the hero the light side. However, it must be recognized that the authors use and collect the materials very conscientiously, without distorting them or adapting them to their theory. Therefore such materials can be used without fear and, up to a certain point, they free us from the thankless work of collecting the material.

有了这两种理论，解释蛇现象的尝试就结束了。所有其他类别甚至都没有提出问题，他们在不同的范围内或在其某些联系中分析蛇：我们想谈论在某些领土边界内表征材料的作品；它们为我们提供了最宝贵的材料，因为虽然它们不声称进行一般扣除，但却为此类扣除奠定了坚实的基础。特别有价值的是汉布利对非洲蛇的研究和对澳大利亚蛇的一些研究378。与这个组非常相似的是另一个组，它在一个民族、一个民族或一个文明的背景下处理蛇。埃及和巴比伦有完整的关于蛇的参考书目，特别是与创世表格的发现有关，这为比较圣经和巴比伦材料提供了灵感。两本关于古典时期蛇的专着很重要，更不用说其他关于蛇的个别类型的著作了。第一个是 Mähly 的研究，虽然古老但非常认真和谨慎，第二个是更现代的 Küster 379研究。史密斯的作品则不然，它有着冠冕堂皇的标题《龙的进化》 ，但几乎完全局限于地中海材料，与其标题380不符。

With these two theories the attempts to explain the phenomenon of the serpent are exhausted. All the other categories do not even pose the problem, they analyze the serpent within different limits, or in certain of its connections: we want to talk about the works that characterize the material within the scope of certain territorial frontiers; they provide us with the most valuable material, because even if they do not claim to draw deductions of a general nature, they create a solid basis for such deductions. Particularly valuable are Hambly's studies on the serpent in Africa and some studies on the serpent in Australia 378 . Very similar to this group is the other that deals with the serpent in the context of a people, a nationality or a civilization. There is a whole bibliography on the serpent in Egypt and Babylon, especially in connection with the discovery of the tablets on the creation of the world that gave rise to the comparison of the biblical and Babylonian materials. On the serpent in classical antiquity two monographs are important, not to mention other works on the individual types of serpent. The first is the study by Mähly, old but very serious and prudent, the second is the more modern study by Küster 379 . The same cannot be said of Smith's work which bears the high-sounding title of Evolution of the Dragon , but is limited almost exclusively to Mediterranean material and does not correspond to its title 380 .

以下类别涵盖仅限于单一主题的研究。这首先包括哈特兰关于珀尔修斯的极其重要的工作381，以及兰克致力于对抗蛇的战士故事的研究382。艾·尼基福罗夫（AI Nikiforov）在其关于北方蛇征服者的材料中正确地评价了这部作品：“兰克的大书不能称为研究。它是变体的参考书目以及它们的示意性正式分类。”圣乔治的传说特别受青睐：关于它，我们有四部基本著作：基尔皮奇尼科夫的著作、维谢洛夫斯基的回应（构成一部新的独立著作）、雷斯滕科的研究和奥夫豪瑟的德国著作。作者得出了完全不同的结论，也不可能是其他情况，因为将与蛇决斗问题的表述仅限于传说，无论与一般的与蛇战斗问题的联系如何，都不能不导致尽管语言学工作非常准确，但还是有错误的推论。

The next category includes studies limited to a single subject. It includes first of all Hartland's major work on Perseus 381 , as well as Ranke's study of the tale of the serpent fighter 382 . In his materials on the conqueror of the serpent in the North, AI Nikiforov rightly says of this work: "Ranke's large book cannot be called a study. It is a bibliography of variants and a schematic formal classification of them." The legend of St. George met with particular favor: we have four fundamental works on it: Kirpíčnikov's, Veselovsky's answer which constitutes a new independent work, Rystenko's study, and the German one by Aufhauser. The authors come to completely different conclusions and it could not be otherwise since limiting the problem of the duel with the serpent to the legend alone, ignoring the connection with the problem of the fight against the serpent in general, cannot but lead to erroneous deductions despite all the accuracy of the philological work.

最后，人们对蛇的各种特定联系进行了研究（“蛇与树木崇拜”，“蛇与太阳”，“蛇与冶金”，“蛇与女人”等）。我们不会在这方面引用个别作品，因为我们不追求参考目的。

Finally, the serpent has been studied in various particular connections ("The serpent and the cult of trees", "The serpent and the sun", "The serpent and metallurgy", "The serpent and the woman", etc.). We will not cite individual works on the subject, because we do not pursue bibliographical purposes.

12.与蛇的决斗蔓延。

12. Spread of the duel with the snake .

既然我们给自己定下了研究蛇形象的历史联系和上述意义的任务，我们首先必须问自己，它是在哪里、在哪些民族中遇到的。学者们经常假设与蛇的战斗是一个非常古老的主题，反映了原始的表现形式。这是不准确的。埃伦赖希（Ehrenreich）观察到，与解放女孩有关的与蛇的决斗仅在“古代世界”遇到，也就是说在欧洲、亚洲和部分非洲383。但埃伦赖希提出的领土扩张原则实际上是体育场性质的历史现象。与进化形式的蛇的决斗存在于所有古代国家宗教中：在埃及、在巴比伦、在古典时期、在印度、在中国；在埃及、在巴比伦、在古典时期、在印度、在中国；他也皈依了基督教，正如奥夫豪瑟所证明的那样，天主教会封他为圣人并非没有反对384。但与蛇决斗的主题在尚未形成国家的民族中并不存在。

Since we have set ourselves the task of studying the serpent image in its historical connections and in the sense indicated above, we must first ask ourselves where and among what peoples it is encountered. Scholars very often start from the assumption that the fight with the serpent is a very archaic motif and reflects primitive ideas. This is not correct. Ehrenreich observed that the duel with the serpent in connection with the liberation of the maiden is encountered only "in the ancient world," that is, in Europe, Asia and partly in Africa . 383 But what Ehrenreich presents as a principle of territorial extension is in reality a historical phenomenon of a stage-like character. The duel with the serpent in a developed form is encountered in all the ancient state religions: in Egypt, Babylon, in classical antiquity, in India, in China; It also passed into Christianity and, as Aufhauser has shown, it is not without opposition that the Catholic Church canonized it . 384 But the motif of the duel with the serpent does not exist among peoples who have not yet formed a State.

由此我们立即可以推断，与蛇战斗的主题是与国家地位一起出现的。但这一推论仍然没有告诉我们这一动机的来源。抽象地推理，人们可以承认它第一次与国家地位一起出现，或者它作为其他预先存在的主题的变体出现。根据记录的各个民族的文明水平对材料进行比较，我们将看到，与蛇搏斗的主题并不是一下子诞生的，也不是一个新的主题，而是从其他主题发展而来的。预先存在的。

From this we can immediately deduce that the motif of the fight with the serpent arose together with the state. But this deduction tells us nothing about the sources of this motif. Reasoning abstractly, one might assume that it arose for the first time together with the state, or that it arose as a variant of other pre-existing motifs. A comparison of the materials, arranged according to the level of civilization of the peoples among whom they were recorded, will show us that the motif of the fight with the serpent did not arise all at once nor as a new motif, but developed from other pre-existing ones.

现在我们必须正面解决这个问题。

And now we must attack the problem head on.

二.吞食之蛇

II. The Swallowing Serpent

13.仪式性吞咽和打嗝。

13. Ritual swallowing and belching .

在俄罗斯童话中，整个战斗画面包括两个基本时刻，即两张王牌。第一个是战斗本身，另一个是对母蛇的追击，并试图吞噬英雄，杀死她的丈夫或儿子。在这种情况下，雌性蛇的出现对听者来说绝对是出乎意料的，她的出现对于动作的发展来说不是必要的，也没有动机，它很容易与动作分离，事实上，它经常失踪，而不影响动作的进展。故事。

In the Russian fairy tale the complete picture of the fight includes two fundamental moments, two axes. The first is the fight itself, the other is the pursuit of the female snake and its attempt to swallow the hero, the killer of her husband or son. In such cases the female snake appears completely unexpectedly for the listener, its appearance is not necessary for the development of the action and is not motivated, it can easily be separated from it and in fact it is often missing without any prejudice to the progress of the story.

我们在上面已经提出了这样的假设：与蛇决斗的母题并不是作为一个新的母题而出现的，而是源于其他已有的母题。这些材料表明，与蛇搏斗的主题源自吞咽的主题，并叠加在其之上。这使我们首先考察蛇最古老的形态，即吞咽蛇。

We have already formulated the hypothesis above that the motif of the duel with the serpent did not arise as a new motif, but arose from other pre-existing ones. The materials show that the motif of the fight with the serpent was derived from that of swallowing, was stratified upon it. This leads us to examine first of all the most archaic form of the serpent, namely the swallowing serpent.

我们已经知道，童话的关键并不在于童话本身。除了童话之外，我们还能在哪里遇到男人的吞咽和打嗝呢？我们已经注意到这个仪式是入会系统的一部分，但当时我们仅限于一个提示。到了这一步，如果我们想避免与蛇打斗的原因变得难以理解，我们就必须更仔细地处理这个问题。有必要确定这一仪式在实践中是如何进行的；然而，显然，这里不能是对仪式进行研究的问题，而只是呈现其特征的问题。

We already know that the key to the tale is not in the tale itself. Where else, apart from in the tale, does one encounter the swallowing and belching of a man? We have already noted that this rite was part of the initiation system, but then we limited ourselves to a brief reference. At this point we must deal with the problem a little more minutely, if we are to avoid leaving the motive for the fight with the serpent incomprehensible. It is necessary to establish how this rite was carried out in practice; it is obvious, however, that here there cannot be a question of proceeding to an investigation of the rite but only of presenting its characteristics.

这种仪式的形式虽有所变化，但仍具有某些不变的特征。我们通过那些遭受苦难和侵犯其秘密的人的故事、通过目击者、神话、从形象艺术中获得的数据以及通过妇女和外行人的故事来了解它。这些形式之一在于使起始物穿过具有动物形状的装置。在已经建造建筑物的地方，这种可怕的动物以特殊形状的小屋或房屋为代表。据想象，始祖被消化了，然后吐了出来，变成了一个新人。如果建筑物尚不存在，则使用其他方式。因此，在澳大利亚，蛇被代表为地球上蜿蜒的洞穴，或者干涸的河床，或者竖起一个避难所，在它前面放置一块劈开的树，这代表了下巴385。

The forms of this rite change, but they always have certain constant characteristics. We know it through the accounts of those who have undergone it and violated its secret, through eyewitnesses, myths, data derived from the figurative arts and through the stories of women and non-initiates. One of these forms consists in making the initiate pass through a device having the shape of an animal. Where buildings were already being constructed, this monstrous animal was represented by a hut or a house of a special shape. It was imagined that the initiate was digested and then vomited out as a new man. Where buildings do not yet exist, other means are used. Thus in Australia the serpent was represented by a sinuous cavity in the earth, or by the dry bed of a river, or a roof was erected, placing a piece of split tree in front of it, which represented the jaws . 385

这种仪式比大洋群岛的其他地方保存得更好。在前德属新几内亚，专门建造了一座专门用于割礼的房子。 « 它应该代表吞噬年轻人的怪物巴勒姆 » 386。从内弗曼的资料中我们知道，这个怪物名叫巴勒姆，有着蛇的形状。 « 巴勒姆吞下孩子的故事不仅仅是妇女讲述的寓言，新手必须真正经历它的象征性表现。这是割礼之家，贾比姆部落将其塑造成怪物的形状。”

This rite has been preserved better than anywhere else in the Oceanic Islands. In the former German New Guinea a special house was built for circumcision. "It was supposed to represent the monster Barlum, who swallows up the young boys." 386 From Nevermann's materials we know that this monster, called Barlum, has the form of a serpent. "The swallowing up of the boys by Barlum is not just a tale told by the women; the neophytes must actually pass through a symbolic representation of it. It is the house of circumcision, to which the Iabím tribe gives the form of a monster."

上梁由棕榈树形成，头发由头发或树叶代表。 « 小屋的入口或入口被涂有鲜艳颜色的椰子叶网格封闭。朝向“尾巴”，小屋变得更窄、更低。吞咽的象征是新手进入“子宫”，而巴勒姆的声音产生共鸣：在其他地方，新手单独进入。动物吞下它们然后吐掉它们。吞咽和呕吐的表现形式非常不同。例如，初学者必须自己从内部编织小屋。当他们完成后，他们被囚禁在里面，他们在胃里。或者搭建一个平台，在上面放置仪式的组织者。新手从他下面经过；当他们每个人靠近时，他都会表现出吞咽和窒息的样子。他喝了一口椰子制成的杯子，然后假装恶心，给孩子们洒水» 387。在塞拉姆岛（大洋洲），新手在夜间被扔进房子里，通过一个鳄鱼嘴或卡萨罗喙形状的开口。据说这个年轻人被魔鬼吞掉了388。 “在昆士兰州的某些地方，人们相信树蛙的咆哮是魔术师吞下儿童并将其吐出变成幼崽时发出的。” “昆士兰妇女相信，树蛙的声音是蜥蜴发出的，它们吞下孩子并拒绝他们变成幼崽” 389。在塞内冈比亚，内雷吞下孩子，将他们放在肚子里一段时间，然后将他们放回光明中390。在非洲（波罗斯群岛），外行人相信有一个巨大的怪物会吞掉孩子；那些因受伤而死亡的人仍留在怪物的胃里” 391。

The upper beam is formed by a palm tree, the hair is represented by hair or leaves. « The mouth or entrance to the hut is closed by a grid of brightly painted coconut leaves. Towards the “tail” the hut becomes narrower and lower. Swallowing is symbolized by the introduction of the neophytes into the “belly” while Barlum’s voice resounds: in other places the neophytes enter by themselves. The animal swallows them and then vomits them. Swallowing and vomiting are represented in very different forms. For example, the neophytes have to weave the hut themselves from the inside. When they have finished, they are imprisoned inside, they are in the stomach. Or a platform is erected on which the organizer of the rite stands. The neophytes pass under him; as each of them approaches he pretends to swallow and suffocate. He takes a sip from a cup made of a coconut, then pretends to be nauseous and sprinkles water on the children . 387 On the island of Ceram (Oceania) the neophyte is thrown into the house during the night, through an opening shaped like the jaws of a crocodile or the beak of a husky. The devil is said to have swallowed the young boy . 388 In certain parts of Queensland it is believed that the sound of tree frogs is produced by magicians in the act of swallowing children and vomiting them out transformed into young men. 389 The women of Queensland believe that the sound of tree frogs is produced by lizards swallowing children and vomiting them out transformed into young men . 390 In Senegambia it is Nerrey who swallows children, keeps them in his belly for a while and then releases them to the light . In Africa (among the Poro) "the uninitiated believe that a large monster swallows children; those who die of wounds remain in the monster's stomach" 391 .

我们还可以举出很多其他例子，但重要的不是数量。现象本身是明确的，其表现形式也是明确的。然而，其动机并不清楚，不清楚是什么引起了该仪式，人们通过执行该仪式向自己承诺了什么，其历史基础也不清楚。

We could give many more examples, but what matters is not the quantity. The phenomenon, as such, is clear, and the forms in which it manifests itself are clear. Its motives, however, are not clear, it is not clear what gave rise to the rite, what men intended to achieve by performing it, its historical foundations are not clear.

14.此礼的意义和基础。

14. The meaning and foundation of this rite .

对仪式本身的研究并没有给我们理解它的钥匙，而是由伴随它的神话给我们的。但问题在于，在举行这种仪式的地方，这些神话是在入会期间讲述的，构成了一个只有入会者才知道的深刻谜团，他们没有公开告诉他们，也没有将它们传达给欧洲人。只有当故事已经脱离了仪式时，转录才会发生：欧洲人在已经与仪式失去了生命联系的民族中，在美国在被迫搬到公园的人群中，以关于旧事的回忆，用英语等。换句话说，我们只有神话的碎片，它失去了神圣的特征，也已经开始失去了它的形式。然而，对这些神话的考察使我们得出以下结论：留在野兽胃里的人赋予了从里面出来的人神奇的能力，特别是对野兽的力量。这次留下来的老兵成为了一名伟大的猎人。这一事实揭示了仪式和神话的经济基础。心理学基础是史前的，它建立在食物赋予所吃之物同一性的信念之上。要加入图腾动物，成为图腾动物，从而进入图腾血统，就必须被该动物吃掉。进食可以是主动的，也可以是被动的（参见失明和隐形）。在提到的情况下，我们有被动进食，即吞咽。但我们知道，这种交流也可以以一种主动的形式进行：在仪式期间，图腾动物被吃掉。我们不知道进入动物体内的起始者是否吃了他吃过的同一动物的一块肉。正如我们将看到的，在神话中，这种情况几乎总是会发生。

The study of the rite itself does not give us the key to understanding it, the key is given to us, instead, by the myths that accompany it.
