But the trouble is that in the places where the rite was alive, the myths were told during the initiation and constituted a profound mystery known only to the initiates who did not tell them openly and did not communicate them to the Europeans. The transcription occurred only when the stories had already detached themselves from the rite: the Europeans recorded them late, among peoples who had already lost the living link with the rite, in America among peoples who had been forced to move to the parks, based on the reminiscences of the elders, in the English language, etc. In other words, we only have fragments of the myth, which, losing its sacred character, has already begun to lose its form. However, the examination of these myths authorizes us to formulate the following conclusion: the stay in the stomach of the beast gave those who emerged magical abilities, and in particular power over the beasts. The survivor of this stay became a great hunter. This fact reveals the economic basis of both the rite and the myth. The psychological basis is prehistoric, it is founded on the belief that food confers identity with the thing eaten. To unite with the totem animal, to become it and at the same time enter the totem lineage, one must be eaten by this animal. Eating can be active or passive (cf. blindness and invisibility). In the cases cited we have passive eating, that is, swallowing. But we know that this communion can also be accomplished in an active form: during the rite the totem animal is eaten. We do not know whether the initiate who entered the animal ate a piece of the same animal that he had eaten. In myths, as we will see, this almost always happens.

继续讨论神话，我们必须记住，神话不应被视为仪式的绝对精确说明。也许神话与仪式完全一致是不可能的。神话作为一个故事，比仪式的生命力更长久。正如我们所指出的，有时神话是在不再庆祝该仪式的地方被转录的。因此，这个神话包含了后来的特征，误解的特征，或者某种变形或外观变化的特征：因此，例如，胃中的持久性转化为巢穴或巢穴中的持久性，或者一条或多条蛇盘绕在周围的持久性。到男主角或女主角的身体。另一方面，蛇所带来的好处的形式也发生了变化。随着狩猎工具的改进，这种好处的神奇狩猎本质就消失了。通用的魔法能力仍然存在，其中两种以特别强大且经常重复出现的形式发展：治愈能力和理解动物语言的能力。

Turning to myths, we must bear in mind that the myth should not be considered as an absolutely exact illustration of the rite. Perhaps a complete coincidence of the myth with the rite is not possible. The myth, which is a story, lives longer than the rite. As we have noted, sometimes the myths were transcribed where the rite was no longer celebrated. Therefore the myth contains later traits, traits of incomprehension or of a certain deformation or change of aspect: thus, for example, the permanence in the stomach changes into permanence in the nest or in the lair, or in the coiling of the serpent or serpents around the body of the hero or heroine. On the other hand, the forms of the benefit conferred by the serpent also change. With the improvement of the instruments of hunting, the magical hunting character of this benefit disappears. The generic magical faculties remain, two of which develop in particularly marked and often recurring forms: the faculty of healing and that of understanding the language of animals.

让我们首先看看蛇所带来的狩猎好处。在北美神话中，英雄特洛梅纳佐（Tlomenatso）看到水面上漂浮着一团火，并意识到那是安戈斯（双头蛇）。他跟随巨蛇来到了它的巢穴，安戈斯给了他一块透明的石头，并引导他的灵魂穿越所有的土地。英雄回来了，第二天抓到一只海豹，第二天又抓到两只，等等。它们都是Angos 392的礼物。

Let us first examine the hunting benefit conferred by the serpent. In a North American myth the hero Tlomenatso sees a fire floating on the water and realizes that it is Angos (the two-headed serpent). He follows the serpent to its lair, where Angos gives him a small piece of transparent stone and guides his soul through all the lands. The hero returns and the next day catches a seal, the day after that two, etc. These are all gifts from Angos 392 .

这些表述可能基于这样的观点：猎人的艺术不在于杀死野兽（这并不困难），而在于将其置于他的力量之下，而这只能通过魔法来实现。自古以来，猎人的运气就与魔法运气、魔法美德的获得联系在一起。当农业开始时，人们在蛇的胃里找到了大地的果实。在金钟群岛有一个神话，其中包含以下情节：“蛇说：滑进我的肚子里。”龙开了，那人溜了进去。他去看火，他去看芋头，他去看甘蔗。他去看了所有的东西。”英雄收集了所有东西，然后出去了。在这里，很明显他把所有这些东西带给了人类。迈尔抄写了这个神话，并以原文和直译版出版，他补充道：“这个传说是金钟群岛所有居民的共同遗产” 393。从Nevermann-Thilenius的材料中我们知道，不仅从蛇的胃中提取了火和大地的果实，而且还提取了陶工的艺术394。

These representations are probably based on the opinion that the art of the hunter does not consist in killing the beast (which is not difficult) but in having it in his power, and this can be obtained only by magic. The luck of the hunter has been connected since the most remote times with magical luck in general, with the acquisition of magical virtues. When agriculture begins, men find the fruits of the earth in the stomach of the serpent. In the Admiralty Islands a myth was recorded which contains the following episode: "The serpent said: slip into my belly. The dragon opened and the man slipped in. He went to see the fire, he went to see the taro , he went to see the sugar cane. He went to see all things." The hero collects everything, then goes out. Here it is clear that he brings all these things to men. Meier, who transcribed this myth and published it in the original and in a literal translation, adds: "This legend is a common heritage to all the inhabitants of the Admiralty Islands" 393 . From the materials of Nevermann-Thilenius we know that not only fire and the fruits of the earth are extracted from the stomach of the serpent, but also the art of the potter 394 .

这些材料揭示了入会期间吞咽仪式以及一系列其他神话和仪式的经济基础，这些神话和仪式仅与第一个神话和仪式间接相关。因此，在澳大利亚，任何想成为女巫的人都会跳进池塘里，相信那里有某些可怕的蛇，并“杀死”他。他生病了，失去了理智，从而获得了他的魔力395。同样的情况也发生在美国：“那些希望变得强壮、健壮、刀枪不入的人会在夜间在蛇或雷霆栖息的池塘里游泳。如果他有足够的勇气容忍他们的存在，他就会从他们那里获得所需的力量” 396。在特林基特人中，一位希望获得“新灵魂”的巫师“让自己被大海吞没”，第四天他被发现倒挂在树上397。

These materials reveal the economic basis of the rite of swallowing during initiation and of a whole series of other myths and rites, only indirectly connected with the first. Thus in Australia the man who wishes to become a sorcerer throws himself into a pond where it is believed that certain monstrous serpents live and "kill" him. He becomes ill, loses his mind, and thus obtains his magical power . 395 The same happens in America: "The man who wishes to become strong, robust and invulnerable swims at night in ponds inhabited by serpents or thunderbolts. From them he receives the desired strength, if he has enough courage to endure their presence." 396 Among the Tlinkit the sorcerer who wished to procure a "new spirit" "had himself swallowed up by the sea," and on the fourth day he was found hanging upside down from a tree . 397

这些例子表明，动物的吞咽被水吞咽所取代，在蛇居住的池塘里洗澡，甚至被海水吞咽，然后将人扔到岸上。

These examples show that swallowing by an animal is replaced by swallowing by water, by bathing in a pond where snakes live, and even by swallowing by the sea which then throws the man onto the shore.

因此，让我们做出以下观察：仪式中的猎人是从蛇或其他动物中出来的，而神话中的伟大猎人、伟大的巫师。同样的起源有最初的火，随着农业的出现，地球上最初的果实，以及陶艺的出现。我们将会看到，伟大的领袖将遵循这一点，甚至后来的神也会遵循这一点。在祖鲁神话中，被吞下的孩子会回家。 « 然后全国充满了欢乐。孩子们回到了他们的祖父身边......他们被任命为领导者” 398。在相对文明的巴苏托部落的非洲神话中，英雄被怪物吞掉了。他回到家，但人们不认识他，并强迫他消失399。在这里，我们有了神化的雏形。在克洛诺斯吞噬他的孩子并返回并将他们吐出来的形象中，我们可能会想起同样的表现。克洛诺斯不是因为他是教父而吞噬了他的孩子，并通过这一行为赋予了他们神性吗？先知约拿被鲸鱼吞下并呕吐出来，也是同一个循环的一部分。难道他没有因为住在鲸鱼体内而拥有预言的恩赐吗？ Radermacher 专门写了一篇文章来讨论这个主题，他承认这个原因是完全不可理解的400，但根据这里引用的材料，其根源已经澄清。

Let us therefore make the following observation: from the serpent or another animal comes forth the hunter in the rite, and the great hunter, the great sorcerer in the myth. The first fire has the same origin, and with the appearance of agriculture the first fruits of the earth, as well as the art of the potter. We shall see that this will be followed by the great chief and still later by the god. In a Zulu myth the children who have been swallowed return home. "Then there was great joy in the country. The children returned to their grandfather... and they were created chiefs." 398 In an African myth of the relatively civilized Basuto tribe, the hero is swallowed by a monster. He returns home, but the people do not recognize him as a man and force him to disappear . 399 Here we have an embryonic form of deification. Perhaps in the image of Chronos devouring his children and belching them out again we have reminiscences of the same representation. And does not Chronos devour his children because he is the father-god and by this act confers divinity upon them? The prophet Jonah, swallowed and vomited out by the whale, belongs to the same cycle. Does he not have the gift of prophecy because he lived in the whale? Radermacher, who has devoted a special article to this subject, admits that this motif is completely incomprehensible , 400 but in the light of the materials cited here its roots become clear.

目前我们只观察到了一个时刻：吞咽仪式及其在神话中的反映或等同物。蛇或任何其他怪物到处都被表现为善良的存在。目前还不清楚如何发生一场斗争，但现在很清楚，当弗罗贝尼乌斯等学者声称好蛇是东亚特有的，而敌蛇是欧洲特有的时，他们犯了一个多么大的错误。 （《太阳神》，第 145 页）。善蛇、给予蛇是蛇的第一阶段，后来转变为它的对立面。欧洲和亚洲与我们无关。

So far we have only observed one moment: that of ritual swallowing and its reflection or equivalent in myths. The serpent or any other monster is everywhere presented as a good being. For the moment it is not at all clear how a fight could arise from this, but it is already clear what a huge mistake scholars like Frobenius make in affirming that the good serpent is peculiar to eastern Asia, and the enemy serpent to Europe ( The Sun God , p. 145). The good serpent, the donor serpent is the first phase of the serpent which later transforms into its opposite. Here Europe and Asia have nothing to do with us.

15.鸟类的语言。

15. The language of birds .

提到了恩人蛇，在继续研究与蛇的决斗之前，让我们先关注一个直接源自我们正在处理的这组现象的主题，而正是英雄获得知识的主题鸟类的语言。

Having mentioned the benefactor serpent, before moving on to the study of the duel with the serpent, let us dwell on a motif which derives immediately from the group of phenomena with which we are dealing, namely the motif of the hero who acquires knowledge of the language of birds.

在现代希腊童话中，蛇或龙吞下了小王子，教他鸟的语言，然后把他吐了401。在卡勒瓦拉（第十七符文）中，维纳莫伊宁被一个巨大的怪物吞下，学习了三个魔法词，点燃了里面的火焰，并开始敲击铁。怪物把他吐了出来，不仅教了他三个字，还告诉了他宇宙的历史，让他无所不知。

In a modern Greek fairy tale the serpent, or dragon, swallows the little prince to teach him the language of birds, then vomits him out 401 . In the Kalevala (XVII rune) Väinämoinen is swallowed by an enormous monster to learn three magic words, lights a fire inside it and begins to strike iron. The monster vomits him out and not only teaches him the three words, but tells him the history of the universe, and gives him omniscience.

在多尔干神话中，被英雄释放的女孩说道：“我该如何报答你救了我呢？”你若不怕我，我就将你缠上三圈，报答你的善行。他能做什么呢？同意。蛇绕了他的身体三圈后，吹进了他的左耳。”因此，英雄发现了鸟和鱼的语言。这两个案例的比较表明，将蛇缠绕在英雄的脖子上是一种后来的吞咽形式，从不再承认这是一种好处的时代开始。在维亚特卡童话故事中，蛇将自己缠绕在脖子上，“就其蜇人而言，它并没有蜇人，而是窒息而死”（ZV 106）。英雄获得了全知。我们上面已经提到，在仪式期间可以吃一小块图腾动物。从这个事实我们开始明白，英雄获得鸟类语言的知识不仅是通过被吞下然后呕吐，而且相反，因为他吃或舔了蛇的任何一块或颗粒，或者吃了一条蛇肉汤或汤等

In a Dolgan myth the girl freed by the hero says: "How shall I repay you for saving me? If you are not afraid of me, I will wrap myself around you three times and thus repay you for your good deed. What could he do? He agreed. After wrapping itself three times around his body, the serpent breathed into his left ear." Thus the hero discovers the language of birds and fish. A comparison of these two cases shows that the serpent's wrapping itself around the hero's neck is a later form of swallowing, from the times when it was no longer accepted as a benefit. In a Vyatka tale the serpent wraps itself around the neck and "as far as it stings, it does not sting, but suffocates" (ZV 106). The hero achieves omniscience. We have already mentioned above that during the rite one could eat a piece of the totem animal. From this fact we begin to understand that the hero acquires knowledge of the language of birds not only by being swallowed and then vomited, but also by, on the contrary, eating or licking a piece or a particle of the snake, or by eating a broth or soup made of snake meat, etc.

在萨马拉童话故事中，英雄（名叫 Sten'ka Razin）遇到了怪物 Volkodir。 « 怪物抬起头，看到了年轻人；他向他吹气，并开始向他移动……沃尔科迪尔拖着他，想咬他一口。”斯滕卡切开蛇，在它的胃里发现了一块石头，舔了舔它，“了解了世界上的一切”（悲伤。110）。在楚贾科夫的童话故事中，用蛇肉制成火腿，准备并食用汤，英雄获得了鸟类语言的知识（Chud.38）。被吃的蛇赋予鸟类、野生动物和鱼类语言知识的主题在世界各地的民间传说中非常普遍（参见格林，17，以及博尔特-波利夫卡的相似之处）。

In a Samara tale the hero (who is called Stenka Razin) encounters the monster Volkodir. "The monster raised its head and saw the boy; it hissed at him and began to move toward him... Volkodir drags him and wants to take a bite out of him." Stenka cuts open the snake and finds a stone in its stomach, licks it and "learns everything there is in the world" (Sad. 110). In a tale by Chudjakov the snake's meat is made into a ham, made into soup and eaten, and the hero gains knowledge of the language of birds (Chud. 38). The motif of the eaten snake conferring knowledge of the language of birds, wild beasts and fish is widespread in folklore throughout the world (cf. Grimm, 17, and the Bolte-Polivka parallels).

在这些情况下，吞咽与启蒙有关，这一点可以通过以下事实得到证明：鸟类的语言知识也可以通过其他程序获得，这些程序与启蒙的联系是毫无疑问的。例如，英雄最终来到了来自森林的老人或智者的房子里，他在大锅中煮了他（ZV 30），或者把他扔进炉子里三次（Sm. 72），或者干脆杀死了他。他（AF.140d）。

That in these cases swallowing is connected with initiation is demonstrated by the fact that knowledge of the language of birds is also acquired by other procedures whose connection with initiation is beyond any doubt. The hero, for example, ends up in the house of the old man of the forest or of a wise man who has him cooked in the cauldron (ZV 30) or throws him three times into the stove (Sm. 72), or simply kills him (Af. 140 d).

关于鸟类语言的原因，科学界存在一些混乱。博尔特将其与鸟类拥有预言天赋并参与人类命运、警告人类等事实联系起来。这种比较是错误的，因为英雄不仅学会了鸟类的语言，还学会了其他动物的语言。它甚至没有解释为什么为此目的必须吃蛇。韦克通过蛇是动物灵魂402这一事实来解释这一点。根据我们的材料，这个问题的呈现方式有所不同。我们可以提出这样的猜想：预言科学的原因，特别是鸟类语言的知识，源自于小男孩被吞咽和呕吐的仪式，或者他自己吞下动物的一块或一块碎片的仪式。 ，随后他获得了魔法能力。最初这些能力仅与狩猎有关，后来出现了与陶艺、农业等相关的能力。随着人类逐渐占有自然和生产，这些能力和艺术的神奇特征逐渐消失，但人类认为自己无法凭借自己的力量获得的能力继续（尽管在神话中）通过蛇的参与而获得（参见 Melampus 等）。其中一部分是理解鸟类和动物语言的能力，让人想起猎人曾经获得的对动物意志的绝对权力，通过仪式必须成为人类和动物手中的温顺工具。满足他的愿望。

There is much confusion in science about the reason for the language of birds. Bolte connects it with the fact that birds possess the gift of prophecy and participate in the destinies of man, warn him, etc. This connection is wrong, since the hero learns to understand the language not only of birds but also of other animals; and he does not even explain why it is necessary to eat a snake for this purpose. Weicker explains it by the fact that snakes are the souls of animals . 402 In the light of our materials the matter presents itself differently. We can formulate the conjecture that the reason for the science of prophecy and in particular for the knowledge of the language of birds derives from the rites during which the youth submitted to being swallowed and vomited or swallowed a piece or a particle of an animal himself, and as a result acquired magical powers. Originally these powers were connected only with hunting, later on powers connected with the art of the potter, with agriculture, etc. appear. As man takes possession of nature and production, the magical character of these abilities and arts vanishes, but the abilities that man feels he cannot acquire with his own strength continue (even if only in myth) to be acquired with the participation of the serpent (see Melampo, and others). Among these is also the ability to understand the language of birds and animals, a reminiscence of the absolute power that the hunter once acquired over the will of the animal, which through the rite was to become a docile instrument in the hands of man and serve his wishes.

为了赋予魔法美德而进行吞咽的痕迹不仅在童话文学中零星可见，而且在中世纪的传奇文学中也时有发现。例如，我们在有关所罗门的传说中找到了它们。在塔木德传说中，所罗门在阿斯莫迪斯的帮助下建造了神庙。 “聪明的国王很想向魔鬼学习一些东西，但他既没有时间也没有机会。”圣殿建造完成后，所罗门独自与阿斯摩蒂斯在一起，并开始质问他。 “把我身上的枷锁拿掉，”阿斯摩蒂尔斯说道，“那么我就会向你展示我所有的力量，并将你提升到高于所有人的程度。”所罗门服从了他。 “他吞下了所罗门，并将他吐出 400 帕拉桑” 403。再往后我们看到，说实话，所罗门因为一夫多妻制而受到了惩罚（在吐掉所罗门之后，阿斯摩蒂斯继位为王），但这是后世意义的转位，与所罗门的说法相矛盾。传奇的开始。所罗门为了得到阿斯摩蒂斯的智慧而被吞掉。

Traces of swallowing practiced with the aim of conferring magical virtues are encountered sporadically not only in fairy-tale literature, but also in the legendary literature of the Middle Ages. We find them, for example, in the legends of Solomon. In a Talmudic legend Solomon builds the temple with the help of Asmodeus. "The wise king wanted to learn something from the devil, but he found neither the time nor the opportunity." When the temple was finished, Solomon was left alone with Asmodeus and began to question him. "Take the fetters off me," says Asmodeus, "then I will show you all my power and exalt you above all men." Solomon obeys him. "He swallowed Solomon and vomited him out 400 parasangs away . " 403 Later we see, to be sure, that Solomon was punished for his polygamy (after having vomited Solomon, Asmodeus becomes king in his place), but this is a transposition of meaning from a later period, which contradicts the beginning of the legend. Solomon is swallowed in order to acquire the wisdom of Asmodeus.

16.钻石。

16. Diamonds .

童话故事有时会讲述英雄在蛇的胃或头中发现钻石或宝石，然后蛇给了他。 “他的头上有宝石” 404。 “渡过大海，到火蛇那里去寻找宝石”（《SM》362）。 “他开始吼叫，宝石就吼叫出来”（悲伤6）等。

The tale sometimes tells that in the stomach or head of the serpent the hero finds diamonds or precious stones, which the serpent gives him. "And the precious stones were in his head" 404 . "Go across the sea and go to the fiery serpent to seek the precious stones" (Sm. 362). "He began to roar and roared out a precious stone" (Sad. 6), etc.

我们在种姓之前的神话阶段就已经发现了这个细节。博阿斯引用了一个例子，其中蛇“给出了一块透明的石头” 405。俄罗斯童话保留了与吞咽和呕吐行为的联系，这使我们认为这里也与入会仪式有关。我们在上面已经看到晶体被引入到起始者的体内。水晶、石英在我们所知的最原始阶段的萨满教中具有非常重要的作用。拉德克利夫-布朗说：“石英晶体和虹彩蛇之间有着非常广泛的联系，在整个澳大利亚，这些晶体是巫师使用的最重要的魔法物质之一” 406。

We find this detail already in the phase of the myth before the castes. Boas cites a case in which the serpent "gives a piece of transparent stone." 405 The Russian tale retains the connection with swallowing and the act of vomiting, and this leads us to think that here too we are dealing with a connection with the rite of initiation. We have already seen above that crystals are introduced into the body of the initiate. Rock crystal, quartz, plays a very important part in the shamanism of the most primitive stages known to us. Radcliff-Brown says: "There is a very widespread connection between quartz crystals and the iridescent serpent, and throughout Australia these crystals are among the most important magical substances used by the sorcerer . " 406

这一事实一方面将童话中放置在水晶棺材中的女孩的形象（见第四章，第十章）与蛇居住的水晶山以及玻璃阁楼中的公主联系起来，其中英雄骑着一匹仙马绑架了她（见第八章，8）。

This fact is connected on the one hand with the image of the fairy-tale girl placed in a crystal coffin (see chap. IV, 10) and on the other with the crystal mountain where the serpent lives, and also with the princess in the glass attic, from where the hero abducts her on a magic horse (see chap. VIII, 8).

17.吞咽运输者。

17. The swallower-transporter .

在到目前为止提到的所有案例中，蛇始终是一个善良的存在，是科学和魔法力量的赋予者。在童话故事中，这条善良的蛇与人类的敌人、必须消灭的怪物并存。人们早就注意到蛇是双重存在。斯滕伯格多次谈到蛇形象中的二元论。这种“二元论”是蛇的表征进化过程的结果。它们不是两条不同的蛇，而是蛇进化的两个阶段。原本善良的蛇，后来变成了它的对立面，只有这时，蛇怪的表征才诞生，必须被杀死的坏蛇的表征才得以形成，与蛇战斗的主题才得以形成，这在历史上是没有的。人类自身的发展，既不是在进化过程中，也不是内在地发展，而是遵循其原始心理形式与新的社会及其文明形式相矛盾的事实。

In all the cases cited so far, the serpent was always a good being, a giver of knowledge and magical power. In the repertoire of the fairy tale, this good serpent coexists alongside the enemy of the human race, alongside the monster that must be destroyed. It has long been noted that the serpent is a double being. Sternberg speaks repeatedly of the dualism in the representations of the serpent. This "dualism" is the result of the process of evolution of the representations of the serpent. They are not two different serpents, but two phases of its evolution; the serpent, originally good, later transforms into its opposite, and only then does the representation of the serpent-monster arise, the bad serpent that must be killed, and the subject of the struggle with the serpent is formed, which in history does not develop by itself, neither in the process of evolution nor immanently, but as a result of the fact that its original psychological forms are in contradiction with the new forms of society and its civilization.

让我们首先观察到，在许多情况下，无论是在仪式还是在神话中，吞食者（怪物、蛇、野兽）保持静止，而被吞食的人在移动：因此，例如，孩子离开家，被吞食者吞下。怪物，然后吐了，然后回家。但也有不同性质的神话：英雄被吞下，然后被运送到吞下者胃中的另一个国家，然后他被呕吐或释放自己。这些神话在种姓形成之前就在各民族中广泛传播，必须更仔细地研究。

Let us begin by observing that in many cases, both in rites and in myth, the swallower (monster, serpent, wild beast) remains still, it is the swallowed that moves: thus, for example, children leave home, are swallowed by a monster, then vomited and then return home. But there are myths of a different nature: the hero is swallowed and then transported to another country in the stomach of the swallower, then he is vomited or frees himself. These myths, which are extraordinarily widespread among peoples of a stage prior to the formation of the castes, must be studied a little more closely.

将英雄传送到异界的吞食者形象到底是从哪里来的呢？可以说，我们在这里面临着仪式中固有的某些元素的演变。留在野兽的肚子里就被认为是在死亡的境界，在另一个世界。甚至那些接受过手术的人也相信：通过进入蛇的肚子，他进入了另一个世界。因此，在鞑靼童话中，英雄救了一个女孩，蛇的女儿。作为感激之情，她对他说：“不要被我父母（即蛇）的可怕外表吓到。要进入他的国度，我们必须先经过我母亲的子宫，然后再经过我父亲的子宫。在这段旅程中，可怕的黑暗将笼罩我们，这种奇观对于脆弱的心灵来说是难以忍受的，但这是到达我们王国的唯一途径。作为回报，蛇王将给予你尊贵和仁慈的欢迎，并奖励你的英勇行为” 407。

Where does the image of the swallower who carries the hero into the other world come from? It can be said that we are here faced with the evolution of certain elements embryonically inherent in the rite. The stay in the stomach of a wild beast was considered as a stay in the realm of death, in the other world; even those who had undergone the operation believed in it: by entering the belly of the serpent he entered the other world. Thus in a Tartar tale the hero has saved a girl, daughter of the serpent. In gratitude she says to him: "Do not be frightened by the terrible appearance of my father (i.e. the serpent). To enter his kingdom we must first pass through my mother's womb and then through my father's belly. During this journey a terrible darkness will envelop us and this spectacle would be unbearable for a weak heart, but it is the only way to reach our kingdom. In return, the king of the serpents will welcome you with honour and kindness and will reward you for your heroic action" 407 .

但是，显然，这些仪式的发起者和这些主体的意识中发生了一些不再符合原始形式的事情。这个神话清楚地表明了空间感和运动感的发展。空间表征的出现迫使吞噬者移动并进行遥远的旅程。兽形死亡王国的表现被死亡之地作为遥远国度的表现所取代。很明显，这种表述只能出现在那些已经通过哲学思考获得了空间概念并在经济上进行过实验的民族中，即那些进行过遥远旅行的民族中。事实上，吞咽运输船的神话主要是一个航海神话。英雄被装在肚子里渡过大海，吞咽者的形状像一条大鱼。此外，通过移动吞咽者，叙述者取消了吞咽的意义。 “森林”被海洋取代。这意味着森林狩猎不再是唯一的经济资源，相应的仪式也失去了意义。但是，尽管如此，这种变化并不构成一场彻底的革命，以至于取消并让我们忘记旧的仪式和旧的主题。学者们非常清楚地看到了这种联系，但神话的发起者已经忘记了它，尽管他仍然很大程度上保留了其古老的形式。原本不动的东西变成了可移动的东西，令人恐惧的东西变得冒险甚至滑稽，必要的东西变得无用且有害。在这些情况下，英雄不再获得任何魔法美德。相反，他视吞噬者为敌人，被他吞噬后杀死他，从他的胃里杀掉他，从里面打败他。这就是与蛇决斗的原则。

But evidently something has happened in the consciousness of the initiators of these rites and of these subjects that no longer corresponds to the original forms. The myth clearly shows that the sense of space and motion has developed. The appearance of spatial representations forces the swallower to move and to make a distant journey. The representation of a theriomorphic realm of death is replaced by the representation of the land of the dead as a distant land. It is quite obvious that such representations could arise only among peoples who had already reached the concept of space through philosophical speculation and had experienced it economically, that is, among peoples who had made distant journeys. And, in fact, the myth of the swallower-transporter is predominantly a maritime myth. The hero is transported by sea in the stomach and the swallower has the form of a large fish. Furthermore, by moving the swallower the narrator annuls the meaning of swallowing. "The forest" is replaced by the sea. This means that the game of the forest has ceased to be the only economic resource and that the corresponding rites have lost their meaning. But, with all this, this change does not constitute a revolution so radical as to cancel and make us forget the old rite and the old subject. The scholar perceives the connection very clearly, but the promoter of the myth has already forgotten it, while still preserving in large part its ancient forms. What was immobile becomes mobile, the frightening becomes adventurous and even comical, what was necessary becomes useless and harmful. In these cases the hero no longer acquires any magical virtue. On the contrary, he sees in the swallower his enemy and kills him after being swallowed by him, he kills him from his stomach, he defeats him from the inside. And here lies the principle of the duel with the serpent.

然后我们将提供一些例子：材料非常丰富，足以单独形成一本书。这本书是存在的：它是弗罗尼乌斯的《太阳神的时代》，他非常仔细地收集了这些神话。然而不幸的是，作者的努力一无所获，因为，从一开始，鲸鱼对他来说就是大海，被吞没的英雄就是夕阳，而初升的太阳就是从鲸鱼中走出来的英雄。

We will bring a selection of some examples later: the material is so abundant that it would be enough to form a book. And such a book exists: it is The Age of the Sun God by Frohenius, who has collected these myths quite carefully. Unfortunately, however, the author's efforts lead nowhere, because, from the beginning, the whale is for him the sea, the swallowed hero is the setting sun, and the rising sun is the hero who comes out of the whale.

作者没有提到与仪式、与人们的经济和社会生活的联系，也没有看到这种联系。

The author does not mention the connection with the rite, with the economic and social life of the people, and does not perceive this connection.

18.与鱼的决斗，如同与蛇决斗的第一阶段。

18. The fight with the fish , as the first phase of the duel with the snake .

毫无疑问，人被吞噬并被传送到另一个国家的神话是一个非常复杂的现象，因为它产生的原因及其联系的多方面性。我们不会在这里研究这个神话的整个复杂性，也不会研究运输的特定时刻，我们只会将注意力集中在导致与蛇决斗的各个方面。

There is no doubt that the myth of the man swallowed and transported to another country is a very complex phenomenon because of the causes that produced it and the multiformity of its connections. We will not study here the whole complex of this myth nor the particular moment of the transport, we will turn our attention only to the aspects that lead to the duel with the serpent.

让我们首先考察一些英雄的运输过程中没有任何挣扎的情况。在密克罗尼西亚有一个关于男孩是鳗鱼之子的神话。女人们取笑他，因为他没有父亲，他去找父亲，跳进水里，看到一条鳗鱼张着大嘴。他将两根光束扔进她的下巴，也就是说，他将它们放置在使嘴巴无法再次合上的位置，然后他跳入其中。一条鲨鱼把他带到了一个有很多海龟盾的岸边。沿着同一条路，他回到鲨鱼的嘴里，然后回到他的家，在那里他结婚了408。在这里我们看到被吞下的英雄被运送到另一个海岸。海龟盾显然已经取代了赋予魔法力量的水晶或石英。

Let us first examine some cases in which the hero is transported without any element of struggle. In Micronesia there is the myth of the boy son of the eel. The women make fun of him because he has no father, and he goes in search of his father and jumps into the water where he sees an eel with an enormous mouth wide open. He throws two beams into its jaws, that is, he places them so that the mouth cannot close, then he jumps in. A shark pulls him out and carries him to a bank where there are many turtle shields. By the same route he returns to the jaws of the shark and then to his home where he marries . 408 Here we see the swallowed hero being transported to another bank. The turtle shields have evidently replaced the crystal or quartz which confers magical power.

这个案例显示出明显的颓废症状：吞咽是没有任何必要的双重，龟盾没有神奇的德性，婚姻与先前的吞咽和英雄归来无关，这在仪式上是结婚的条件。现在让我们看看其他更典型和更广泛的案例。

This case shows clear symptoms of decadence: the swallowing is double without any necessity, the tortoise shields are devoid of magical virtue, the marriage is not linked to the previous swallowing and the return of the hero, which in the rite are a condition of marriage. Let us now move on to other more typical and widespread cases.

父亲委托给儿子一项任务；但他不服从，跑向大海，与同伴一起上了船。突然，船开始摇晃。不听话的男孩掉进水里，立刻被一条大鱼吞掉了。过了一会儿，他感到饿了，他环顾四周，看到鱼肝挂在他的上方，就开始用贝壳切它。鱼感觉不舒服，吐了409。

The father gives his boy an assignment, but he disobeys, runs away to the sea and sets off on a boat with his companions. Suddenly the boat begins to rock and sway. The disobedient boy falls into the water and is immediately swallowed by a large fish. After a while he feels hungry, looks around, sees the fish's liver hanging above him and begins to cut it with a shell. The fish feels sick and vomits him up . 409

在之前的案例中，吞咽对吞咽者没有任何后果。然而，在这里，英雄切开了鱼的肝脏并吃掉了它。很难说这是否是对仪式期间发生的事情的回忆，当时入会者吃了一块动物。无论如何，这是一个非常普遍的原因，这种吞咽动物的喂食行为以各种借口发生。鱼感觉不舒服，吐出了英雄。我们看到，在这些神话中，呕吐是需要一个理由的，其本身就已经是不可理解的了。请注意，鱼并没有死，也没有与饕餮者发生决斗。

In the previous case, the swallowing had no consequences for the swallower. Here, however, the hero cuts the liver of the fish and eats it. It is difficult to say whether or not this is a reminiscence of what happened during the rite, when the initiate ate a piece of the animal. In any case, it is a very common motif and this eating of the swallowing animal occurs under various pretexts. The fish feels ill and vomits the hero. We see that in these myths the vomiting requires a reason, in itself it is already incomprehensible. It is noteworthy that the fish does not die and that no duel with the swallower takes place yet.

有时，英雄会在鱼体内点燃火，以摆脱它，即对被吞下的反应。在鸟儿的帮助下，部落首领建造了一艘船，英雄要求进入其中。经过长时间的讨论后，它被接受了。在旅途中，一头鲸鱼吞噬了所有人，但英雄将两根长矛插入它的嘴里，使它无法再合上。在鲸鱼的胃里，他看到了死去的父母。为了释放自己，他点燃了一堆大火；鲸鱼痛苦地翻滚，游向浅滩。每个人都与船一起从张开的嘴里出来。他们最终来到了富饶的月之国，并同船回家。

Sometimes the hero lights a fire inside the fish, to get out, that is, to react to being swallowed. With the help of birds a tribal chief builds a boat, and the hero asks to get in. After long discussions he is accepted. During the voyage a whale swallows everyone, but the hero sticks two spears in its mouth, so that it can no longer close it. In the whale's stomach he sees his dead parents. To free himself he lights a great pyre; the whale writhes in pain and swims towards a shoal. Everyone comes out of the open mouth together with the boat. They have ended up in the land of the moon, where abundance reigns, and they return home in the same boat.

在这种情况下，英雄在鱼中看到了他死去的父母，这表明当他到达鱼中时，他已经在死者的住所了。一般来说，英雄有时会在鱼中遇到许多死人和活人，在他面前被吞掉，然后把他们带出来。这个原因我们不去研究；我们只注意到，即使在俄罗斯童话中，也有英雄进入鱼的内部并在那里点燃火焰的情况（Af.133 PV、Af.135 VP、ZV 138、134等） 。一般来说，鱼身上的火是一个广泛存在的主题，除非人们知道在仪式和神话中，所有基本必需品都是从吞咽者那里提取出来的，包括火，否则这是难以理解的。正如我们所知，在吞噬者内部，起始者有时会受到燃烧。这个怪物体内燃烧着可怕的火焰。因此，在神话中，从鱼里出来的男孩经常抱怨那里的酷热，或者，正如我们所看到的，他们自己生火来救自己。

In this case the hero sees his dead parents in the fish, which shows that upon entering the fish he is already in the abode of the dead. Usually the hero sometimes meets in the fish many dead and living people, swallowed before him, and leads them out. We will not study this motif; we will only note that even in the Russian fairy tale there is the case of the hero who moves into the inside of the fish and lights a fire there (Af. 133 PV, Af. 135 VP, ZV 138, 134, etc.). In general, fire in the fish is a widespread motif and is incomprehensible unless one knows that in the rite and myth all the essential things are taken out of the swallower, including fire. As we know, inside the swallower the initiate sometimes subjects himself to burning. Inside this monster burns a terrible fire. Therefore in the myth the boys who come out of the fish often complain about the great heat that reigns there, or, as we have seen, they light a fire themselves to save themselves.

所有这些都表明，仪式已经被遗忘，其组成元素被用于艺术创作。这些案例可以被认为是一种恶化、一种变形，但它们展示了主题的创造性阐述、旧的消亡和新的诞生。吞咽和嗳气不再符合生产形式，也不再符合人们的社会生活和意识形态：它们已接近衰落。我们已经在神话中看到了打嗝的动机：它是由疼痛引起的。在童话故事中，打嗝完全消失了，吞咽持续的时间更长，因为这是一个更加丰富多彩的艺术时刻。被吞下去的英雄不再被吐出来，而是把自己挖了出来。让我们举个例子：许多年前，一个叫穆图克的人正在一块岩石上钓鱼，突然他的鱼线缠结了，他跳进水里去解开它。就在这时，一条鲨鱼从他身边经过，把他吞掉了，但没有伤害他。鲨鱼向北移动。穆图克心里暖暖的，自言自语道：“现在我们正处于水深火热之中。”当鲨鱼再次潜入更深的水中时，穆图克感到寒冷，意识到他们已经潜到了很深的地方；最后鲨鱼到达了博伊古岛，退潮把它扔到了海滩上。穆图克感觉到阳光直射到鱼身上，发现鱼已经干了。然后他拿起一个锋利的贝壳，挂在耳后，开始刺穿鲨鱼的身体，直到刺出一个足够的开口。他溜出监狱，发现自己的头发全都掉光了。

All this shows that the rite is already forgotten and that its constituent elements are exploited for artistic creation. These cases can be considered as a deterioration, as a deformation, but they demonstrate the creative elaboration of the motif, the dying of the old and the birth of the new. Swallowing and belching no longer correspond to the forms of production or to those of the social life and ideology of peoples: they are about to decline. We have already seen how belching is motivated in myth: it is provoked by pain. In the fairy tale belching is completely missing, swallowing lasts longer, because it is a more colorful artistic moment. The swallowed hero is no longer vomited, but digs himself out. Let us cite an example: many years ago a man called Mutuk was fishing on a rock when suddenly his fishing line got tangled and he jumped into the water to untangle it. At that moment a shark passed by and swallowed him without harming him. The shark moved away to the north. Mutuk felt warm and said to himself, "Now we are in warm water." When the shark sank back into deeper water, Mutuk felt cold and realized that they had descended to a great depth; finally the shark reached the island of Boigu and the low tide threw him onto the beach. Mutuk felt that the rays of the sun were falling directly on the fish and realized that he was dry. Then he took a sharp shell that he carried behind his ear and began to pierce the shark's body until he had made a sufficient opening. He crawled out of his prison and noticed that all his hair had fallen out.

在这种情况下，我们所有的注意力都集中在脱发本身上。这也是这些神话的一个非常普遍的特征。对于弗罗贝尼乌斯来说，事情很清楚：脱发意味着黎明的太阳没有光线。另一方面，我们用以下事实来解释这一时刻：入会是一种“剃发”，在仪式期间，头发被剃光或烧焦，或隐藏在特殊的头饰下（关于童话故事中的秃头，请参阅第四章） ，15）。

In this case it is the loss of hair that attracts all our attention. This is also a very common feature of these myths. For Frobenius the matter is clear: the loss of hair means that the dawn sun has no rays. We, on the other hand, explain this moment by the fact that the initiation was a "tonsure", during the rite the hair was shaved or burned, or hidden under a special headdress (on bald men in fairy tales, see chap. IV, 15).

我们还观察到英雄被吞噬的原因多种多样。英雄跳入水中是因为有人嘲笑他，他违背父亲的禁令而上船，他乘船去旅行，或者他因为鱼线被缠住而跳入水中，或者钩子丢失等。 ETC。总之，叙述者不知道为什么英雄一定会落入水中并被吞没，每个人对这一事实的解释也不同。

We also observe the diversity of reasons why the hero is swallowed. The hero jumps into the water because someone is making fun of him, he sets off on a boat in disobedience to his father's prohibition, he sets off on a boat to go on a journey, or he jumps into the water because his fishing line has gotten tangled, or his hook has been lost, etc. etc. In a word, the narrator does not know why the hero must inevitably end up in the water and be swallowed, and everyone motivates this fact in a different way.

从下面的案例可以看出，英雄砍吞者的母题已经取代了嗳气：钓鱼的男孩向鱼王献上啄食。一条鱼把它和船一起吞掉了。为了逃脱，男孩撕下了鲸鱼的心脏，鲸鱼试图将其吐出来，但没有成功。然后男孩听到鱼的身体在沙滩上沙沙作响。海鸥出现，用喙撕开鱼的身体，鱼就出来了410。

That the motif of the hero cutting open the swallower to get out has replaced belching is seen from the following case: a boy fishing with a hook offers the king fish to catch. A fish swallows him together with the boat. To get out, the boy tears out the heart of the whale, which tries in vain to vomit it out. Then the boy hears the body of the fish rustling on the sand. Seagulls appear and tear the body of the fish with their beaks, and he comes out . 410

这个案例在很多方面对我们来说都非常重要。首先，我们看到打嗝仍然存在于意识中，但意识将其丢弃。前面的案例中对吞咽者心脏的折磨纯粹是出于功利的原因（英雄割肝养活自己），而在这里他的目的却是杀死吞咽者，也就是说，在这里我们也有反应的时刻，我们有杀死吞噬者。此外，这个案例很有趣，因为吞咽者的身体是从外面被开膛破肚的。大多数情况下是由动物来执行操作，这里是海鸥。可以观察吞食者是如何从内到外被击败的，以及重心是如何逐渐向从外击败的方向转移的。

This case is very important for us in many respects. First of all we see that the belching is still present in consciousness, but it is discarded. In the previous cases the heartbreak of the swallower has a purely utilitarian motive (the hero cuts out the liver to satisfy his hunger), here instead it aims to kill the swallower, that is, here too we have the moment of reaction, we have the killing of the swallower. Furthermore, this case is interesting because the body of the swallower is disemboweled from the outside. In most cases it is animals that perform this operation, here it is seagulls. We can observe how the swallower is defeated from within and from without and how the center of gravity gradually shifts towards defeat from the outside.

让我们再举一个类似的例子，吞咽者被人开膛破肚。两兄弟在海边，一头鲸鱼出现，他们被吞没了。他们在鲸鱼的肚子里看到了心脏并将其切掉。鲸鱼死了，被推向海滩。人们出现并开始屠杀她，兄弟们从她身上出现。 “当他们看到对方时，他们开始互相嘲笑：在鲸鱼的肚子里，他们失去了头发，那里太热了” 411。

Let us give another similar example in which the swallower is disemboweled by men. Two brothers are on the seashore, a whale appears and they are swallowed. In the belly of the whale they see the heart and cut it out. The whale dies and is driven towards the beach. People appear and begin to cut its throat and from it the brothers emerge. "When they saw each other, they began to laugh at each other: in the belly of the whale they had lost their hair, so great was the heat that reigned there" 411 .

在这个例子中，在查阅了资料之后，一切就都清楚了。但有一个奇怪、非常有趣的细节：当两个男孩从鲸鱼中出来时，他们笑了。我们在一项专门研究中对仪式稻米进行了分析412。

In this example, after the materials already examined, everything is completely clear. But there is a strange and very interesting detail: when they come out of the whale, the two boys laugh. Ritual laughter was analyzed by us in a special study 412 .

所引用的案例可能会给人这样的印象：这个神话完全是海洋和水生的。确实，它主要是一个水生神话。正如我们稍后将看到的，它与蛇的水生特性有关。生活在森林深处的人们，与世隔绝，不知道如何旅行和贸易，发展得更慢。但即使在它们之中，也有类似的、尽管较慢的演变。关于这个主题的现有材料要少得多，而且情况也不太清楚。然而，下面的例子也必须提及：英雄离家出走，父亲警告他，他会遇到狼，狼会杀死或吸吮他。英雄真的遇见了狼，并开始嘲笑他：“你真是太伟大了！你真的会吸我的！ » 英雄假装抵抗，违背自己的意愿接近虎口并跳了进去。他发现里面有很多人；有的还活着，有的几乎已经死了，还有的只剩下骨头了。他看到头顶上有一颗悬垂的心。然后他说：“我想跳舞！”唱歌我会跳舞！ » 人们开始唱歌。他把刀放在头上，开始跳舞。他用这把刀击中了狼的心脏，杀死了他，将他分尸，释放了所有与他在一起的人，然后离开了413。如果说以前的英雄是被吞噬的人，那么现在的英雄就是消灭吞噬者的人。如果在前面的例子中，吞咽者被开膛破肚是因为他吞下了英雄，那么这里发生了相反的情况：为了杀死吞咽者，英雄进入了他的体内。如果说在仪式中，英雄是被吞下并呕吐的人，并且仅仅因为这一事实而成为英雄，那么在这个神话中，英雄就是杀死吞食者的人。显然，神话中发生的转折反映了人们社会生活的转折。英雄嘲笑狼，跳进狼的嘴里；之前我们也见过其他英雄嘲讽的案例。此外，我们还在这里看到，在吞食者的肚子里，英雄遇见了死者。怪物中躺着的死者、尸体、骨头的存在以及吞咽者或死亡小屋中死亡的其他属性，构成了我们从仪式的特征中所了解的画面。所缺少的只是英雄复活死者，我们就会看到典型的暂时死亡的画面。在这里，复活被合理化，并采取了解放那些发现自己处于狼中的人的形式。同样有趣的是，狼体内正在跳舞。

The cases cited might give the impression that this myth is exclusively maritime and aquatic. It is true that it is predominantly an aquatic myth; as we shall see later, it is connected with the aquatic nature of the serpent. The peoples who lived in the thick of the forests, separated from the world without knowing about travel and trade, developed more slowly. But there is a similar, albeit slower, evolution among them too. The material available on this subject is much scarcer and the picture is less clear. However, the following case must also be mentioned: the hero goes away from home, his father warns him that he will meet the wolf who will kill him or suck him. The hero actually meets the wolf and begins to mock him: "You are really magnificent! You will really suck me!" The hero pretends to resist, to approach the jaws in spite of himself and jumps in. Inside he finds a large crowd; some were alive, some were almost dead, and some had nothing left but bones. Above his head he saw a heart hanging. Then he said: "I want to dance! Sing and I will dance!" And the people began to sing. He fixed a knife to his head and began to dance. With this knife he struck the wolf's heart, killed him, cut him open, freed all those who were with him, and came out . 413 If before the hero was the one who had been swallowed, now the hero is the one who annihilates the swallower. If in the previous cases the swallower was disemboweled because he had swallowed the hero, here the opposite happens: to kill the swallower the hero enters into him. If in the rite the hero was the one who had been swallowed and vomited out and was a hero only because of this fact, in this myth the hero is the one who killed the swallower. It is clear that the turn that has taken place in the myth reflects a turn in the social life of the people. The hero mocks the wolf and leaps into its jaws; we have seen other cases in which the hero mocks. We also see here that in the belly of the swallower the hero encounters the dead. The dead lying in the monster, the corpses, the presence of bones and other attributes of death in the interior of the swallower or in the hut of death form a picture that is familiar to us from the characteristic of the rite. All that is missing is for the hero to resurrect the dead and we would have the typical picture of temporary death. Here the resurrection is rationalized and has taken the form of liberation of the men who were in the wolf. It is also interesting that a dance takes place inside the wolf.

英雄主义重心的转移预示着这些神话历史上极其重要的创新。迄今为止所审查的所有案例都有一个特点：故事都是围绕一个角色展开的。神奇的英雄主义被个人的勇气和英勇所取代。被吞没已经没有什么英雄气概了。可以看出，重心的转移创造了一个新的角色：神话是建立在两个人的基础上的：一个被吞没，另一个释放了第一个。英雄不再是被吞噬的人，而是释放他的人。在美洲的努特卡部落中，有这样一个神话：“在地狱之门，住着一条巨大的鲸鱼，被称为“绑船吞噬者”。每个人经过那个地点时都非常小心。有一次，英雄的母亲乘着小船经过。船被拖离岸边，鲸鱼出现，把船和女人一起吞掉了。当英雄得知母亲的遭遇后，他决定报仇。他和他的兄弟们一起跳入河对岸的大海中，开始唱歌。当他们唱完两遍之后，海水分开了，鲸鱼吞掉了小船。英雄向他的兄弟们大声喊叫，让船径直驶向腹部。他们在肚子里切出了肠子和心脏。鲸鱼死了并被冲上岸。海滩上的动物（鸟、蜗牛、鱼等）打开了鲸鱼的身体，大家都出来了。鲸鱼肚子里的温度太高了，以至于其中一个兄弟的头发都掉光了414。

The shifting of the center of gravity of heroism heralds an extremely important innovation in the history of these myths. All the cases examined so far had one characteristic: the story was built on a single character. Magical heroism is replaced by courage and individual valor. There is no longer anything heroic about being swallowed. It can be observed that the shifting of the center of gravity creates a new character: the myth is built on two people: one who is swallowed and the other who frees the first. The hero becomes not the one who is swallowed, but the one who frees him. In America, the following myth was recorded among the Nutka tribe: "In Hellgate there lived an enormous whale called the 'devourer of boats tied together'. Everyone passed by that place with great caution. Once the hero's mother passed by in a small boat. The boat was dragged far from the shore, the whale appeared and swallowed the boat together with the woman. When the hero learned what had happened to his mother, he decided to take revenge. Together with his brothers, he went down the river into the sea and began to sing a song. When they had sung it twice, the waters parted and the whale swallowed the boat. The hero shouted to his brothers to direct the boat right into the belly. In the belly they cut out the intestines and the heart. The whale died and was carried to the shore. On the beach, the animals (birds, snails, fish, etc.) cut open the whale's body and they all came out. In the belly of the whale it was so hot that one of the brothers lost all his hair . 414

这个故事的主题是在种姓形成之前的社会阶段与蛇的战斗。一方面，这个主题已经接近童话故事：我们有一个女人被吞噬（在童话故事中是一只老鼠），与怪物的战斗以及女人的解放。但与此同时，斗争仍然保留着它的旧形式：要杀死吞食者，必须冲进他的肚子，被它吞掉。

This tale contains the motif of the fight with the serpent in the phase of a society prior to the formation of castes. On the one hand the subject is already close to the fairy tale: we have the swallowing of a woman (in the fairy tale it is a rat), the fight with the monster and the liberation of the woman. But, together with this, the fight still retains the old forms: to kill the swallower one must throw oneself into its belly, be swallowed by it.

源自仪式并仍保留在神话中的吞咽行为很自然地被其他形式的斗争所取代。事实上，人们可以观察到吞咽如何被吞噬的替代形式所取代，以及吞咽者如何不再从内部而是从外部被杀死：这是这一主题的进化的又一步。举个例子，从内部的吞杀到外部的失败的转变尤为明显。

It is quite natural that the swallowing that comes from the ritual and is still maintained in the myth, has been replaced by other forms of struggle. And, in fact, one can observe how swallowing is replaced by the substitute forms of devouring, and how the swallower is no longer killed from the inside but from the outside: it is another step forward in the evolution of this subject. Let us cite a case in which the transition from swallowing and killing from the inside to defeat from the outside is particularly evident.

怪物 Tsekis 吞噬了所有人，只剩下一位老人和他的孙女。英雄陌生人得知这一事实，让女孩戴上一条由西休特尔蛇制成的腰带，并派她去取水：泽基斯将女孩与仙女腰带一起吞下。当女孩在怪物的肚子里时，英雄唱起了一首神奇的歌曲：“西休特尔，活过来，醒来并杀死他！” » 怪物浮出水面，在痛苦的抽搐中翻滚。英雄用箭射杀了她，并把女孩带了出去415。

The monster Tsekis devours all the people, only an old man and his granddaughter remain alive. The foreign hero is informed of this fact, makes the girl wear a belt made of Sisiutl snakes and sends her to fetch water: Tsekis swallows the girl together with the magic belt. While the girl is in the monster's stomach, the hero sings a magic song: "Sisiutl, revive, wake up and kill him!" The monster comes to the surface, writhes in the convulsions of agony. The hero kills it with his arrows and pulls the girl out 415 .

女孩被送入蛇腹的目的是什么，从神话本身并不清楚，但从她的故事中似乎很清楚：在这里，我们发现自己面临着杀死吞噬者的传统的反映一定在他体内。而吞噬者虽然是从外部击败的，但蛇体内也一定有一个人。还有一个特点是，内部使用魔法手段，外部使用非常常见的理性手段，即弓箭。

For what purpose the girl is sent into the stomach of the serpent, it is not clear from the myth itself, but it is clear from its history: we are here faced with a reflection of the tradition according to which in order to kill the devourer one must be inside it. And although the devourer is defeated from the outside, a person must also be inside the serpent. It is also characteristic that inside a magical means is used and outside a very common rational means, the bow and arrow.

内部杀戮的弱化和外部杀戮的加强，使这一主题更接近当代的童话形式。替换更进一步：要击败蛇，你必须将一些东西扔进它的嘴里，但它并不总是一个人：烧红的石头也被扔进它的嘴里。举个例子：湖里住着一只怪物，它会吞噬所有去湖里打水的人。英雄（外国人）将石头烧红，扔进怪物的嘴里，然后把他切成碎片，这些碎片变成了可食用的鱼416。在这里，良好和基本必需品的吞噬者的主题并没有完全消失：他身体的各个部分都变成了可食用的鱼。又如：一条蛇吞食了所有的人；只剩下一名孕妇，她生下了双胞胎。童子奉蛇西米酒；他张开他的下巴，他们把烧红的石头扔进去417。

The weakening of killing from within and the strengthening of killing from without bring this motif closer to contemporary fairy-tale forms. The substitution goes further: to defeat the serpent, something must be thrown into its jaws, but it does not always have to be a man: burning stones are also thrown into its jaws. Here is an example: a monster lives in the lake and devours all those who go to draw water from it. The (foreigner) hero makes some stones red hot and throws them into the monster's jaws, then he cuts it into pieces and these pieces are transformed into edible fish . 416 Here the motif of the devourer from whom good, essential things come has not completely disappeared: parts of its body are transformed into edible fish. Another example: a serpent devours all the people; only a pregnant woman remains and gives birth to twins. The boys offer the serpent sago wine; he opens his jaws wide and they throw red-hot stones into them 417 .

最后，一旦将魔法物品或烧红的石头扔进嘴里的权宜之计消失了，剩下的就是与蛇的真正决斗。两个女人去洗澡。两个怪物（库特雷亚，弗罗贝尼乌斯所说的鳄鱼）吞下了它们。蛇爬到一个洞穴，将水注入河流，收集，即吞下所有的水，河流就干涸了。被吞下的妇女的丈夫追踪蛇的踪迹，用长矛将她们杀死。水又开始流动。他射中了怪物的腹部并释放了他的妻子418。

Finally, once the expedient of throwing magical objects or red-hot stones into the jaws has disappeared, the actual duel with the serpent remains. Two women go to bathe. Two monsters ( kutrea , alligators according to Frobenius) swallow them. The serpents crawl to a cave that feeds the river with its waters, collect, that is, swallow all the water and the river dries up. The husband of the swallowed women follows the trail of the serpents and kills them with spears. The water begins to flow again. He shoots the bellies of the monsters and frees his wives 418 .

在这种情况下，受害者仍然总是被吞下去。这条蛇是水生生物，我们稍后会谈到。当吞咽完全消失时，我们发现自己面临着与我们已知的蛇的决斗。然而，正如我们可以遵循吞食英雄的替代形式一样，我们也可以遵循吞食女人的替代形式。这里有一个不再包含任何吞咽的例子，但还没有完全脱离它：两个女人去洗澡，她们被一条鳐鱼发现，鳐鱼把她们背在背上走开了。两个英雄用长矛与她搏斗并杀死了她，然后点燃火来救活妇女，让她们被蚂蚁蜇伤，她们苏醒过来419。背着女人的种族显然是把女人装在肚子里的怪物的替代品。与火的联系并没有被遗忘，但它被扭曲了：使死者复活的火是对暂时死亡的最后回忆。随着这些细节的消失，我们发现自己面临着与目前形式的蛇的战斗。我们举两个例子。首先：一个英雄陌生人遇到一个女孩，她给一条井蛇带来煮熟的米饭和肉。英雄用他的剑420砍下了蛇的头。另一个例子：沼泽蛇每年都会夺走一个受害者。 “这是一项没有人知道其基础和起源的法律。”一个女孩被带到怪物面前：英雄在适当的时候出现在马背上并击倒了蛇421。

In this case the victim is still swallowed. This snake is an aquatic creature that we will discuss later. When the swallowing disappears completely, we are faced with the duel with the snake in the forms known to us. However, just as one can follow the substitution of the swallowing of the hero, one can also follow the substitute forms of the swallowing of the woman. Here is an example that no longer contains any swallowing, but has not yet completely separated from it: two women go to bathe, they are spotted by a ray that takes them on its back and moves away. Two heroes fight with spears against it and kill it, then they light a fire to revive the women, have them stung by ants and they revive . 419 The ray that carries the women on its back is an obvious substitution for the monster that carries them in its stomach. The connection with fire is not forgotten, but it is distorted: the fire that serves to revive the dead is a last reminiscence of temporary death. Once these details have disappeared, we find ourselves faced with the fight with the serpent in its present form. Let us give two examples. First: a hero-foreigner meets a girl who brings cooked rice and meat to a well snake. The hero cuts off the snake's heads with his sword 420 . Another example: a swamp snake demands a victim every year. "This was a law whose foundation and origin no one knew." A girl is led to the monster: at the right moment the hero appears on horseback and knocks the snake down 421 .

至此，我们暂时中断我们的审查。我们试图勾勒出主体进化的方案，以跟踪如何在一个主题（吞咽）的基础上发展另一个主题（与蛇决斗）。但我们只发现了其中的原因之一。为什么蛇被杀的问题还不能给出详尽的答案，但有一件事已经很清楚了：蛇被杀是因为人们的生活发生了变化，使旧的主题变得难以理解，并使其与新的主题相一致。思想。应该指出的是，在最原始的民族中并不总是能发现古老的形式。例如，即使是俄罗斯童话故事也包含了将鱼运送到内地、点燃火和呕吐的英雄，其形式与美国材料有着惊人的相似之处。因此，最古老的案例不一定是在最原始的民族中记录的。但相反的关系是不可能的：只有当有相应的基础时，创新才会被引入。简而言之，进化与人类的文明程度相对应。我们已经说过是什么造成了瞬间的位移。这里另一个细节的演变是有特色的：蛇或吞噬者最初被箭击倒，然后用长矛，最后用剑。显然，只有懂得冶金学和炼铁技术的人才能用剑将其落地。最后引用的两个例子是在卡比勒人中记录的，我们对他们感兴趣的不是卡比勒人，而是从他们的经济发展阶段的角度来看。他们不再是游牧民族，他们种植橄榄树和果树，非常认真地耕种田地，很早就懂得制陶和打铁的艺术，而且也是勇敢的战士。正是在这样的阶段，剑和马出现了。后来，封建政权用披着骑士盔甲的蛇来掩盖决斗。随着斗争形式的变化，在卡比勒人中，蛇的性格也发生了变化，呈现出农业特征：每年都有一个女孩被牺牲——上面已经研究过这个例子。卡比勒人也使用大米和肉类。因此，主体的演化并不是自身完成的，而是各国人民经济生活和社会制度变化的产物。

At this point we will interrupt our review for the moment. We have attempted to outline the scheme of the evolution of the subject, to follow how on the basis of one motive (swallowing) another (duel with the snake) develops. But we have only identified one of the roots of the motif. The question of why the snake is killed cannot yet be answered exhaustively, but one thing is clear from now on: it is killed because changes have occurred in the life of peoples which have made the old subject incomprehensible and have modified it in accordance with the new ideology. It should be noted that archaic forms are not always found among the most primitive peoples. Thus, for example, even the Russian fairy tale contains the carrying inside of the fish, the lighting of the fire and the vomited hero, in forms which present a striking analogy with American materials. Therefore the most archaic cases have not necessarily been recorded among the most primitive peoples. But the opposite relationship is impossible: an innovation is introduced only when there is a corresponding basis for it. In short, evolution corresponds to the degrees of civilization of peoples. We have already said what the moment of displacement originated from. Here the evolution of another detail is characteristic: the serpent, or swallower, is killed first with arrows, then with spears and finally with the sword. It is clear that it can be killed with the sword only among a people who know metallurgy and the art of working iron. The last two examples cited were recorded among the Kabyles, who do not interest us as Kabyles, but from the point of view of the stage of their economic evolution. They are a people no longer nomadic, who cultivate olives and fruit trees, work their fields very carefully, have long known the art of the potter and that of working iron, and are also courageous and warlike. It is precisely at such a stage that the sword and the horse appear. Later, the feudal regime cloaks the duel with the serpent in knightly armor. With the changing forms of struggle, the character of the serpent also changes among the Kabyles, which takes on agricultural characteristics: every year a girl is sacrificed to it - a case, this, already studied above. The Kabyles also make use of rice and meat. Therefore, the evolution of the subject does not complete itself, but is the product of changes in the economic life and social regime of the peoples.

19.与蛇决斗后期的吞咽痕迹。

19. Traces of swallowing in late cases of snake fight .

与蛇决斗的母题源于吞咽母题的基本论点可以通过对一些已实现阶级发展的民族中与蛇决斗的案例的分析来证实。如果说，一方面，未来与蛇的斗争可以在阶级形成之前阶段的人们的材料中找到，另一方面，吞咽的痕迹可以在某些更近期的材料中找到。必须承认，在俄罗斯剧目中，没有英雄在战斗中跳入蛇口的例子，但一般来说这样的例子并不少见。

The basic thesis that the motif of the duel with the serpent is derived from the motif of swallowing can be confirmed by the analysis of some cases of duel with the serpent among peoples who have reached the stage of class development. If, on the one hand, one can find the future fight with the serpent in the materials of peoples of a stage prior to the formation of classes, on the other hand, one can find traces of swallowing in certain more recent materials. It must be recognized that in the Russian repertoire one does not find examples in which the hero leaps into the jaws of the serpent during the fight, but in general such cases are not very rare.

在关于世界创造的巴比伦神话中，我们读到第 422 章：“当提亚马特张开双唇时，他（即马杜克）让伊姆胡鲁进入双唇，这样她就无法再合上双唇了。”随着这个动作，战斗开始了。格雷斯曼将“Imhullu”解释为“邪恶的风”。那么，为什么风会阻止你闭上嘴还不清楚。通常龙会产生风来吸走英雄。另一方面，在类似的情况下，会使用矛来防止蛇的嘴巴再次闭合。这里也有矛：“他把矛插进去，把他的身体切成碎片，撕开他的内脏，挖出他的心脏。”我们必须想象马杜克将长矛刺入龙的下颌并刺入龙的腹部，在那里他撕出内脏，挖出心脏，将身体切成四半，然后退出。事实上，没有任何地方说马杜克进入了龙的腹部，但可以推断，这就是格雷斯曼的理解，并做出了以下注释：“他与其他风一起进入了龙的腹部。”为大英博物馆编辑和翻译该文本的巴奇也是如此解读这段文字的。 “在第七块石碑中，据说马杜克进入了‘提亚马特的中部’，因此被称为尼比姆，即‘进入的人’和‘抓住中心的人’（即内脏）” 423 .

In the Babylonian myth of the creation of the world we read 422 : "When Tiamat had opened her lips as wide as she could open them, he (i.e. Marduk) made Imhullu enter them, so that she could not close them again." With this act the fight begins. Gressmann interprets "Imhullu" as "evil wind." Why the wind prevents the closing of the mouth is not clear; usually the dragon produces the wind to suck the hero. On the other hand, in similar cases a spear is inserted to prevent the serpent's jaws from closing. Here too there is a spear: "He put a spear in it, tore its body to pieces, tore out its entrails and cut out its heart." We must imagine that Marduk thrusts a spear into the dragon's jaws and penetrates the belly, where he tears out its entrails, cuts out its heart, dismembers its body and then exits. It is not said anywhere that Marduk enters the belly of the dragon, but it can be inferred, and this is how Gressmann understands it when he adds the following comment: "Together with the other twenty he enters into her belly." This is also how Budge, who edited and translated the text for the British Museum, interprets this passage. "In the seventh tablet it is said of Marduk that he entered 'into the midst of Tiamat' and for having done this he was called Nibim , that is, 'he who entered' and 'he who has grasped the centre' (that is, the entrails)" 423 .

英雄进入龙腹的情节在这里显得不够令人信服；然而，从古典文献中却可以看出这一点。根据他的神话的一个版本，赫拉克勒斯为了拯救赫西俄涅而跳入蛇口，在那里度过了三天，期间他的头发由于肠子里的高温而全部脱落，并从内部撕裂了他的头发。打开怪物的肚子424。类似的还有一个关于伊阿宋的神话，根据该神话（从图像资料来看），在《科尔基斯》中，伊阿宋为了得到金羊毛而跳进了守护蛇的嘴里，从而杀死了他。这个版本是通过阁楼花瓶425的绘画为我们所知的。 《格萨尔》史诗为我们提供了一幅非常清晰的巨蛇内心斗争的图景。老虎大如山，“见人一日路，半日吞人”，就是像前面提到的美洲狼一样，把人吸进去。 « 格萨尔……奇迹般地刺入了虎口之间，到达那里后，他采取了以下姿势：他用双脚支撑在虎的下獠牙上，用头抵住上颚，用肘部抵住虎口。下巴»。他的朋友兼同伴这样评价他：“我仁慈的可汗被一只山一样大的黑斑虎吞掉了。”维蒂亚西（圣骑士）从外部攻击他，格萨尔从内部杀死他426。这里吞咽和打斗的主题仍然有着非常清晰的联系。俾路支童话故事也是如此：“龙向 Djanghet 吹气，将他吞下；但他把剑举在额前。这条龙接近了 Djanghet，但当它到达并吞噬了他时，它就分裂成了两半 » 427。让我们记住，即使在《埃达》中，奥丁也是如何投入狼芬里斯的口中的。

The hero's entry into the belly of the dragon does not seem convincing enough here; however, it is very clear from the materials of classical antiquity. According to one version of his myth, Heracles leaped into the serpent's mouth to save Hesione, spent three days there, during which all his hair fell out because of the great heat that reigned in the entrails, and from the inside he tore open the monster's belly . 424 A similar myth about Jason is also told, according to which (judging from the iconographic materials) in Colchis Jason threw himself into the jaws of the guardian serpent in order to seize the Golden Fleece and thus killed it. This version is known to us from the paintings on an Attic vase . 425 A very clear picture of the struggle inside the serpent is given to us by the epic of Gesar. A tiger, as big as a mountain, "sees a man when he is a day's journey away and swallows him when he is half a day's journey away," that is, it sucks him in like the American wolf mentioned above. "Gesar... miraculously enters the jaws of the tiger and, having arrived there, assumes the following attitude: he braces himself with both feet against the tiger's lower teeth, with his head he touches the roof of his mouth and with his elbows the jaws." His friend and companion says of him: "My pretty khan has been swallowed up by a black-spotted tiger, as big as a mountain." The vitiasis (paladins) attack him from without and Gesar kills him from within . 426 Here the motives of swallowing and fighting are again very clearly connected. The same applies to a Baluchi fable: "The dragon blew the air towards Djanghet to swallow him; but the man held his sword before his forehead. The dragon approached Djanghet, but as soon as it reached him and swallowed him, it split in two" 427 . Let us remember how in the Edda Odin also throws himself into the jaws of the wolf Fenris.

20.结论。

20. Conclusion .

所有这些材料使我们可以得出以下结论：

All these materials allow us to formulate the following conclusion:

与蛇决斗的主题是从吞咽的主题发展而来的。吞咽最初是入会时庆祝的仪式。这个仪式赋予年轻人或未来的萨满巫师魔法能力。这些表现一方面体现在童话故事中，体现在蛇头或蛇腹中发现的宝石，另一方面体现在获得动物语言知识。后来这些原因消失了，它们不再发展，吞咽不再被认为是一种好处，而是一个偶然的事实；与仪式的联系消失了，引入了一个新的时刻，即英雄转移到吞咽者胃中的时刻。在这个阶段，功利主义时刻出现了：贪食者的心脏或肝脏被切开并用作食物。后来，随着新角色的出现，神话变得更加复杂：第一个角色被吞噬，第二个角色将自己投入到同一个角色的嘴里，并将吞噬者从内部撕开，从而释放了他。在这个阶段，英雄在蛇体内的移动不再可能，并且出现了替代形式：英雄不再将自己扔进蛇的下颚，而是将烧红的石头或仙术扔进蛇中，导致吞噬者从内部死亡，同时杀死它是从外面来的。这种杀戮的形式正在一点点地改变。吞者被箭杀死，被矛杀死，被刀杀死，被骑马的英雄分尸。从这里我们直接进入童话故事中与蛇决斗的形式。随着种姓社会秩序的出现，斗争的形式并没有发生实质性的变化。在某些情况下，即使在最近与蛇的决斗中，仍然可以检测到吞咽的痕迹。

The motif of the duel with the snake developed from that of swallowing. Originally, swallowing was a rite that was celebrated during initiation. This rite conferred magical powers on the young man or the future shaman. These representations are reflected in the fairy tale on the one hand with the precious stones found in the head or belly of the snake, on the other with the acquisition of knowledge of the language of animals. Later these motifs die out, they do not develop, swallowing is no longer felt as a benefit, but is a casual fact; the link with the rites is lost, a new moment is introduced, that of the hero moving into the stomach of the swallower. At this stage, utilitarian moments appear: the heart or liver of the swallower are cut out and used for food. Later the myths become more complicated with the introduction of a new character: the first is swallowed, the second frees him by throwing himself into the same jaws and tearing the swallower apart from the inside. At this stage the hero's movement inside the serpent is lost and substitute forms appear: instead of throwing himself into the jaws, the hero throws red-hot stones or fairy godmothers into it which kill the swallower from the inside, while he kills it from the outside. The forms of this killing gradually change. The swallower is killed with arrows, with a spear, with a sabre, and is quartered by the hero on horseback. From here we move directly to the forms of dueling with the serpent existing in the fairy tale. With the appearance of the social order by castes, the forms of struggle do not change substantially. In certain cases traces of swallowing can still be found even in more recent forms of dueling with the serpent.

这种演变是经济生活和社会制度变化的产物。一旦仪式失败，吞咽嗳气的感觉就消失了，取而代之的是各种短暂的形式，从而完全消失。英雄主义的重心从吞食转移到杀死吞食者。形式和工具根据人们实际使用的工具而变化。人们的文化水平越高，斗争的形式就越接近我们在当代童话故事中看到的形式。随着游牧生活的结束，畜牧业和农业的出现，这个过程也就结束了。

This evolution is a product of changes in economic life and in the social regime. With the disappearance of the ritual, the meaning of the act of swallowing and belching is lost, replaced by various transitory forms and then disappears altogether. The center of gravity of heroism is transferred from swallowing to the killing of the swallower. The forms and instruments change according to the instruments actually used by the people. The higher the culture of the people, the more the forms of struggle come closer to those found in contemporary fairy tales. With the cessation of nomadism, with the appearance of cattle breeding and agriculture, this process ends.

三．桶里的英雄

III. The Hero in the Barrel

21.运输飞船。

21. The transport vessel .

在继续对蛇的分析之前，我们必须停下来，在我们的研究中纳入另一个主题，该主题已部分地由已经引用的材料阐明：我们想谈论桶中、篮子或栅栏中的英雄的主题放入水中。

Before continuing the analysis of the serpent we must stop and include in our study another motif that is partly illuminated by the materials already cited: we want to talk about the motif of the hero in the barrel, in the basket or in the pole lowered into the water.

桶中英雄的主题与鱼内英雄的主题相似，是由它衍生而来的。让我们举一个维亚特卡童话故事中的例子。 « 他们抓住了我，把我放进一个桶里，用铁环将其封闭，然后将其放入水中。六个月来我在里面既不生也不死。然后，对我来说幸运的是，木桶停在海滩上，洞朝上。”一只狼出现了。 « 我一点一点地抓住他的尾巴，把小刀插在他的屁股上。然后他就离开了，拖着我的桶走过树桩和树根。他打碎了整个木桶，让我回家，奇迹般地活了下来”（ZV 34）。在狼闻到桶的味道并打破它的时候，我们很容易就能认出那些将被困在鱼里的英雄从外面释放出来的动物。在磨刀器中，我们认识到从内部切鱼的刀。在彼尔姆的童话故事中，是牛打破了木桶（ZP 57）。即使在更简单的情况下，我们也能发现这种类比：某些嫉妒的人把英雄放在救生艇上； “过了一会儿，云层变厚，暴风雨咆哮，海浪上涨，把不知道在哪里的救生艇带到了很远的地方，扔到了一个岛上”（Af.130）。将英雄扔到海滩上的救生艇让我们想起了呕吐他的鱼。

The motif of the hero in the barrel is similar to that of the hero in the fish and is a derivation of it. Let us cite a case taken from a Vyatka fairy tale. "They caught me, put me in a barrel, closed it with iron hoops and lowered it into the water. For six months I remained in there, neither dead nor alive. Then, luckily for me, the barrel stopped on the beach with the hole facing upwards." A wolf appears. "I gently tied him by the tail and stuck my penknife in his behind. And he went off, dragging my barrel over stumps and roots. And he smashed the whole barrel and let me go home, miraculously alive" (ZV 34). In the wolf who comes to sniff the barrel and breaks it open we easily recognize the animals who free the hero from the outside who is locked in the fish. In the penknife we ​​recognize the knife with which the fish is cut from the inside. In a Perm fairy tale it is the ox that breaks the barrel (ZP 57). Even in simpler cases we detect the analogy: some envious people put the hero in a boat; "after a while the clouds gathered, the storm roared, the waves rose and carried the boat who knows where, carried it far away and cast it on an island" (Af. 130). The boat that casts the hero on the beach reminds us of the fish that vomits him out.

但这些对外部类比的考虑本身并不足以建立有效的亲属关系。对不同顺序的考虑导致我们将这两个原因结合起来。坠入木桶的动机有多种，但它有机地进入了一个情结：这个情结是由国王将死于一个孩子手中的预测而形成的；这个情结是由国王将死于一个孩子手中的预测而形成的；这个情结是由国王将死于一个孩子手中的预测而形成的；这个情结是由一个孩子的死亡而形成的。他被放入水中，由牧羊人或园丁秘密教育，通常与其他男孩一起，后来登上王位。

But these considerations of external analogy would not be sufficient in themselves to establish an effective relationship. There are considerations of another order that lead us to the comparison of these two motifs. The lowering into the barrel is motivated in various ways, but there is a complex into which it enters organically: this complex is formed by the prediction that the king will perish at the hands of a child; this child is lowered into the water, educated in secret by a shepherd or a gardener, often together with other children, and later ascends to the throne.

如果我们的猜想正确的话，在桶中的停留对应于在鱼腹中的停留，与其他男孩一起的秘密教育对应于入修者在长辈指导下的共同生活时期，而整个复合体构成了获得领导者所必需的能力的条件，即登上王位的条件。兰克是第一个认识到桶肚的人，但他给出的动机是弗洛伊德式的428。木桶实际上是子宫，但不是母体：它是赋予神奇力量的动物的子宫。

If our conjecture is correct, the stay in the barrel corresponds to the stay in the belly of the fish, the secret education together with other boys corresponds to the period of life in common of the initiates under the guidance of an elder, and the whole complex constitutes the condition for the acquisition of the faculties necessary for a leader, the condition, that is, for the accession to the throne. Rank was the first to recognize the belly in the barrel, but the reason he gives is Freudian 428 . The barrel is indeed the belly, but not the mother's: it is the belly of an animal that confers the magical power.

然而，我们提出的考虑因素并没有穷尽这个问题。我们知道吞咽和打嗝的仪式和主题具有图腾起源。然而，不仅动物，树木也可以充当图腾。树的传统也可以在桶中得到体现，这两种传统可能融合在桶中英雄的主题中。在密克罗尼西亚神话中，四个人去拜访太阳。过了一会儿，他们意识到他们的船被拿走了。 « 然后，太阳将他们包裹在一根大竹子里，这在当时的贝利群岛上还不为人知，在这根竹子里，他们被运送到了祖国的海岸。此后他们成为四大领导人” 429。关于第一个人也存在同样的神话。在美国西北部，有一个神话讲述了一些妇女如何制作一个大篮子，与丈夫和孩子一起爬进篮子，关上篮子，然后把自己扔进水里。海浪和风推动着篮子，最终落在了皮克纳科特尔。然后他们打开篮子，出来了，这就是波特梅兹人的祖先。

However, the considerations we have presented do not exhaust the matter. We know that the rite and the motif of swallowing and belching have a totemic origin. However, not only animals but also trees could serve as totems. The tradition of the tree can also be seen in the barrel, and it may be that these two traditions merged in the motif of the hero in the barrel. In a Micronesian myth, four men go to visit the sun. After a while they notice that their boat has been carried away. "Then the sun enclosed them in a large bamboo, which was not yet known in the Pelée Islands at that time, and in this bamboo they were transported to the shore of their homeland. After this they became the four chiefs." 429 The same myths exist about the first men. In Northwest America, a myth tells how some women made a large basket, climbed into it with their husbands and children, closed it, and had themselves thrown into the water. The waves and the wind pushed the basket and it finally landed at Piknakotl. Then they opened the basket, stepped out and were the ancestors of the Potemeizi.

诺亚很可能也有同样的起源，他进入了一艘大船或方舟，被锁在里面，出来时是人类的祖先。 Userer 已经进行了这种比较。埃及（奥西里斯）也遵守这种树的传统，我们也在俄罗斯童话故事中找到它。在彭萨的一篇故事中，女孩为了躲避父亲的迫害而躲在一根木柱里。这根柱子被扔进水里，飘到了另一个境界。国王找到了她，并把她带到了他的房间（就像仙女镜子的故事一样），然后娶了这个女孩（Sm.252）。在这里，这棵树与玻璃棺材起到了同样的作用。在森林里，国王经常在树上发现一个沉默的女孩；通常它是赤身裸体的，它用毛发覆盖自己，让人想起一只鸟，它也经常被羽毛覆盖。这一切都指向了这个主题的来源。树上或树上的女孩与棺材里的女孩一样，处于暂时死亡状态的女孩：她的状态对应于她在动物体内的永久状态。让我们记住，这种持久性是婚姻的一个条件，而且往往也是权力的一个条件。

It is probable that Noah, who entered a large boat or ark, had himself enclosed in it and emerged as the progenitor of men, also has the same origin. This comparison was already made by Usener. The tradition of the tree is also observed in Egypt (Osiris) and we also find it in Russian fairy tales. In a story by Pensa the girl takes refuge in a wooden pillar to escape her father's persecution. This pillar is thrown into the water and floats to another kingdom. The little king finds it and has it carried to his room (exactly as in the story of the enchanted mirror), then marries the girl (Sm. 252). Here the tree fulfills the same function as the glass coffin. In the forest the little king often discovers a mute girl in a tree; usually she is naked, covers herself with her hair and resembles a bird, often she is also smeared with feathers. All this indicates the source of this motif. The girl in the tree or on the tree is the same as the girl in the coffin, the girl in a state of temporary death: her state corresponds to the permanence inside the animal. Let us remember that such permanence is a condition of marriage and often also of power.

从这个角度来看，重新审视摩西在浮篮中的停留（他后来成为他的人民的领袖和救世主）以及萨尔贡国王的著名自传（公元前2600年）是很有趣的。在格雷斯曼的版本中，表格的主旨如下：“我是萨尔贡，强大的国王，阿卡迪亚的国王。我的母亲很穷（维斯塔？），我不认识我的父亲，我父亲的兄弟住在山里。我的城市阿苏皮拉努位于幼发拉底河畔。我可怜的（？）母亲生下了我，秘密生下了我，把我放在一个柳条盒子里，用焦油把门关上，把我托付给了河……然后河把我举了起来，带我去了阿基，饮水者。阿基，饮水者，带我穿过……（间隙）。浇水者阿基把我当作他的儿子并教育我。浇水工阿基让我成为他的园丁。当我还是一名园丁时，伊什塔尔喜欢我，我统治了四年» 430。接下来是国王所有伟大事迹和战役的夸耀清单。但如果说整桌都是夸，故事的开头也是或许当时的听者没有察觉的自焚。萨尔贡的伟大始于他在包厢里的就职。他夸耀它就像夸耀他的战役一样，因为它证明了他的统治权利，并且像军事战役一样，证明了他是一位伟大的国王。

In this respect it is interesting to re-examine Moses' stay in the floating basket (he later becomes the leader and savior of his people) as well as the famous autobiography of King Sargon (2600 BC). In Gressmann's version the tablet has the following tenor: "I am Sargon, mighty king, king of Akkadia. My mother was poor (vestal?), I did not know my father, my father's brother lives in the mountains. My city, Asupiranu, is located on the banks of the Euphrates. My poor (?) mother bore me, she gave birth to me in secret, she placed me in a wicker box, closed the doors with tar, and entrusted me to the river... Then the river lifted me up and brought me to Akki, the waterer. Akki, the waterer, took me out by means of... (gap). Akki, the waterer, took me instead of a son and educated me. Akki, the waterer, made me his gardener. While I was gardener, Ishtar took a liking to me and I reigned four years . 430 Then follows the boastful list of all the king's great deeds and campaigns. But if the whole table is a boast, even the beginning of the story is a self-praise that perhaps the listener of that time did not perceive. Sargon's greatness begins with his deposition in the box; he boasts of it as he boasts of his campaigns, since it proves his right to reign and, like the military campaigns, proves that he is a great king.

四．绑架蛇

IV. The Captive Serpent

22.蛇的出现。

22. The appearance of the serpent .

我们已经开始研究童话故事中的蛇，但到目前为止我们还没有见过它，除了后期的案例（马杜克、赫拉克勒斯、伊阿宋等）。这意味着蛇是一种晚期现象，其外观的发展晚于其功能的发展。事实上，到目前为止我们见过谁扮演吞咽者的角色？在仪式中，我们有各种各样的动物；蛇占主导地位，有时像在澳大利亚那样被描绘得很梦幻，但我们也遇到了鸟和狼。跨海的运输者自然以鱼的形式出现。后来所有这些动物都进入了蛇、龙的构成。在种姓形成之前的阶段，没有一个民族认识龙。有（例如在澳大利亚）巨大的蛇，有具有奇妙色彩的蛇的代表，但不存在龙作为其中一部分的混合生物。事实上，双头蛇在北美也有踪迹，但它并不是杂交生物。头部不是彼此相邻排列，而是排列在颈部和尾部。在这种情况下，尾部与代表第二个头的刺相关联。龙是一个较新的现象。这些奇妙的动物是晚期甚至城市文化的产物，当时人类已经开始失去与动物的亲密和有机联系，尽管复合动物的胚胎形式甚至可以更早地发现，例如在墨西哥或爱斯基摩人中。这些生物最辉煌的时代是古代国家的时代，埃及、巴比伦、古印度、希腊、中国，蛇也出现在纹章中，象征着国家。相反，它在真正的原始民族中并不存在。

We have begun to study the serpent of the fairy tale, but we have not yet seen it, except in late cases (Marduk, Heracles, Jason, etc.). This means that the serpent is a late phenomenon, that its appearance is developed later than its functions. And who have we actually seen in the role of swallower up to now? In the ritual we have the most varied animals; the serpent predominates, sometimes fantastically depicted as in Australia, but we have also encountered the bird and the wolf. The transporters across the sea naturally take the form of fish. Later all these animals enter into the composition of the serpent, the dragon. None of the peoples in the stage before the formation of the castes knows the dragon. There are (e.g. in Australia) enormous serpents, there is the representation of serpents with fantastic coloring, but there are no hybrid beings of which the dragon is a part. To be sure, in North America the two-headed serpent is known, but it is not a hybrid being. The heads are not placed next to each other, but on the neck and tail. In this case the tail is associated with the stinger, hence the representation of the second head. The dragon is a more recent phenomenon. These fantastic animals are the product of a late and even urban culture, when man had begun to lose the intimate and organic bond with animals, although embryonic forms of composite animals can be found even earlier, for example in Mexico or among the Eskimos. The era of greatest splendor of these beings is that of the ancient States, Egypt, Babylon, ancient India, Greece, China, where the serpent also appears in the coat of arms, symbolizing the State. On the contrary, it does not exist among truly primitive peoples.

蛇是一些动物的机械组合，与埃及的狮身人面像、古典的半人马等是相同的现象。蛇的艺术表现表明，除了其基本方面（爬行动物+鸟类）之外，它还可以由非常不同的动物组成，并且其构成不仅包括鳄鱼或蜥蜴和鸟类，还包括豹，狮子、山羊等动物，由二、三、四动物组成。

The serpent is a mechanical combination of some animals, it is a phenomenon identical to the Egyptian sphinxes, the classical centaurs, etc. The artistic representations of the serpent show that in addition to its fundamental aspect (reptile + bird) it can be formed of very different animals, and that in its composition enter not only the crocodile or the lizard and the bird, but also the panther, the lion, the goat and other animals, that it consists of two, three, four animals.

此时可以观察到另一个现象。蛇，龙，或多或少与拟人化的神一起出现。这不是一个绝对精确的规律，而是一种趋势。在宗教史上如何理解“神”这个词的问题是非常复杂的，我们不会在本书中解决这个问题。动物型图腾祖先并不是拟人化的宙斯或无形的基督教圣灵那样意义上的神。神性是从动物发展而来的。随着农业和城市的出现，图腾起源的多彩动物世界开始失去其真实性。一个拟人化的过程发生了。动物获得了人的身体；在某些情况下，最后消失的是动物的口鼻。狼头阿努比斯、鹰头奥罗斯等神灵就这样诞生了。另一方面，死者的灵魂在鸟身上获得了人头。就这样，人逐渐在动物身上成形。某些神的形象的拟人化过程几乎已经完成，例如赫耳墨斯，他的脚后跟下面有非常小的翅膀，直到最后，这种动物转变为神的属性：宙斯被描绘成与一只鹰在一起。

At this point another phenomenon can be observed. The serpent, the dragon, appears more or less together with the anthropomorphic gods. This is not an absolutely exact law, it is a tendency. The problem of how the word "god" is to be understood in the history of religions is very complex and we will not resolve it in this book. The totemic ancestor of the animal type is not a god in the sense in which the anthropomorphic Zeus or the amorphous Christian Holy Spirit is a god. The divinity develops from the animal. With the appearance of agriculture and cities the colorful animal world of totemic origin begins to lose its reality. A process of anthropomorphization takes place. The animal acquires the body of a man; in some cases the last to disappear is the animal's muzzle. Thus divinities such as Anubis with the head of a wolf, Oros with the head of a falcon, and so on arise. On the other hand, the souls of the deceased acquire a human head on the body of a bird. Thus, little by little, man emerges from the animal. The process of anthropomorphization is almost complete in the figure of certain gods, such as Hermes with tiny wings under his heels, until finally the animal becomes an attribute of the god: Zeus is depicted together with an eagle.

这是一条线。另一方面，动物不是城里人能对付的，它是另一种，它是死者变成的动物（蛇、虫、鸟），它不是日常生活的一部分，它是实体化的，神秘：随着它的意义，它也开始失去它的外观。正如动物与人类融合一样，动物也开始相互融合。他们是从未见过的人，但却被赋予了一种神秘、超凡脱俗的非凡力量。由此形成了混合生物，龙就是其中之一。

This is a line. On the other hand, the animal is not the one that the man of the city can deal with, it is another, it is the one that the deceased transforms into (snake, worm, bird), it is not part of everyday life, it is hypostatized and mysterious: together with its meaning it also begins to lose its appearance. Just as the animal merges with man, animals begin to merge with each other. They are the ones that no one has ever seen, but who are invested with a mysterious, otherworldly and extraordinary power. This is how hybrid beings are formed, one of which is the dragon.

如果我们现在仔细观察龙的形象（本质上是由蛇+鸟组成），并将其与之前所说的所有内容进行比较，我们可以得出这样的结论：蛇是由两种代表动物组成的。灵魂，即来自鸟和蛇的灵魂。最初，垂死的人可以变成任何动物，正如大量文献所证明的那样。但是，当死亡之国的表征出现时，这个国家开始将自己定位在地球之上，或者地平线之外，或者相反，在地下，正如我们在谈论遥远王国时将更详细地看到的那样。与此相对应的是，死者能变形成的动物数量是有限的。遥远的国度诞生了鸟类，地下的国度则诞生了蛇、蠕虫和爬行动物，它们之间似乎没有什么特别的区别。鸟和蛇是最常见、分布最广的代表灵魂的动物，它们融合在龙的形象中。这也是冯特的观点：“有可能，”他说，“在带翅膀的形象（蛇）中，确实存在着早已被遗忘的代表灵魂的鸟，在蛇的蛇形树干中，也有可能。”龙代表虫，代表灵魂？431。这也解释了蛇的翅膀、蛇爪和鳞片，以及带有毒刺的尾巴等。我们很快就会看到，这也解释了其基本职能之一，即绑架妇女。

If we now look closely at the figure of the dragon (which is essentially made up of the serpent + the bird) and compare it with everything that has been said before, we can come to the conclusion that the serpent is made up of two animals that represent the soul, namely the bird and the serpent. Originally, the dying man could transform himself into any animal, as is proven by numerous documents. But when the representations of the land of death appear, this land begins to be located either high above the earth, or beyond the horizon, or, on the contrary, underground, as we will see in more detail when we speak of the distant realm. Correspondingly, the number of animals into which the deceased can transform himself narrows. For the distant realms, birds are born, for the underground realm, snakes, worms and reptiles, between which, it seems, no particular distinction is made. The bird and the serpent are the most common and widespread animals that represent the soul and they have merged into the figure of the dragon. This is also Wundt's opinion: "It may be," he says, "that in the winged figure (serpent) lies hidden the long-forgotten representation of the bird representing the soul, and in the serpentine trunk of the dragon the representation of the worm representing the soul." 431 This also explains the wings, the claws of the serpent and its scaliness, as well as the tail with the sting, etc. We will see shortly that this also explains one of its fundamental functions, namely the abduction of the woman.

然而，这仍然没有阐明蛇的另一个不变的特性，即它的许多头。正如它由多种动物组成一样，它也有几个头。这该如何解释呢？这个问题可以类比马的许多头和翅膀来解决。八足马在民间传说中广为人知。例如，奥丁的坐骑斯莱普尼尔有八条腿，而且绝不是唯一的例子。许多头只不过是以图像的形式表达了比赛的速度，这也是我们马的许多翅膀。它的四个、六个、八个翅膀象征着它飞行的速度。这也是蛇的多头畸形：它的许多下巴是一个肥大的吞噬形象。集约化通过数量的增加进行，通过数量体现质量。这是一个较晚的现象，正如定义数量的范畴一般是较晚的范畴一样。

But this does not yet clarify another constant peculiarity of the serpent, namely its many heads. Just as it consists of several animals, it has several heads. How is this to be explained? The problem can be solved by analogy with the many heads and many wings of the horse. The eight-legged horse is known in folklore. Thus, for example, Sleipnir, Odin's steed, has eight legs, and he is by no means the only example. The many heads are nothing but the rapidity of running expressed in image form, and such are also the many wings of our horse. Its four, six, eight wings are an image of the rapidity of its flight. Such is also the many-headedness of the serpent: its many jaws are a hypertrophied image of devouring. Intensification proceeds by means of an increase in number, the expression of quality by quantity. This is a late phenomenon, just as the category of definite quantity is generally a late category.

在到目前为止提到的案例中，许多头并没有出现，但它们存在于卡比勒人中，例如，我们观察到的马。另一种创造吞噬形象的系统不是通过数量而是通过增加下巴的大小来进行的：在俄罗斯童话中，它们从地面延伸到天空，但嘴只有一个，并且许多头都不见了，因为它们迄今为止引用的材料中缺失。其中的鱼通常是常见的鱼之一，但空间可以容纳数千人，有时甚至可以容纳整个国家。狼的肚子里还躺着许多活人和死人。在这个阶段，没有人会因为这种不成比例而停下脚步。鲸鱼形式的鱼的表现包含着重新建立比例的尝试，而张开的嘴则是将比例艺术夸张地插入到吞噬的画面中，也是一种晚期现象。

In the cases mentioned so far, the many heads do not appear, but they do exist among the Kabyles, for example, where we observed the horse. Another system of creating the image of devouring proceeds not by quantity but by increasing the size of the jaws: in the Russian fairy tale they extend from the earth to the sky, but there is only one mouth and the many heads are missing, as they are missing in the materials mentioned so far. In them the fish is usually an ordinary fish, and yet thousands of people and sometimes a whole country find room in it. In the stomach of the wolf, too, lie many living and dead men. At this stage no one is stopped by such disproportion. The representation of the fish in the form of a whale contains an attempt to re-establish the proportions, and the gaping mouth is the artistically exaggerated insertion of the proportions into the picture of devouring, and is also a late phenomenon.

23.死亡绑匪。

23. The Death-Captor .

对吞噬蛇及其外观的分析都得出一个结果：从基因上来说，蛇与死亡的表征重新联系起来，并且可以在其中识别出两条交替的线：一条更古老，仍然与仪式和死亡联系在一起。其他的，最近的，纯粹是推测。

The analysis of the devouring serpent and that of its appearance both lead to the same result: genetically the serpent is reconnected with the representations of death, and one can discern in them two alternating lines: one, more ancient, still linked to the rite and the other, more recent, purely speculative.

死亡表征与相应仪式之间的这种联系解释了蛇的另一个方面，即绑架蛇。

This link between the representations of death and the corresponding rites explains another aspect of the serpent, namely the captive serpent.

现在我们可以讨论死亡表征的历史了。然而，这种表征的早期形式并没有反映在蛇的形象中：蛇反映了死亡表征的后来形式，即作为老鼠的死亡。死亡的发生是因为有人绑架了死者的灵魂或其中一个灵魂。与此相对应的是，人们想象死者的重新整合：需要将灵魂再次绑架并放回原处。有些童话故事完全建立在绑架和反绑架的基础上。

At this point we could turn to the history of representations of death. However, the earliest forms of this representation are not reflected in the image of the serpent: the serpent reflects a later form of representations of death, namely death as abduction. Death comes because someone has kidnapped the soul or one of the souls of the deceased. In accordance with this, people imagine the reintegration of the deceased: the soul must be kidnapped again and put back in its place. There are fairy tales that are built entirely on abduction and counter-abduction.

但绑匪是谁？我们很快就会看到，绑架者往往是死者本人，死者会带走活人。死者（通常以动物的形式）绑架灵魂的表征的形成过程，与另一个过程，即灵魂的客体化过程密不可分。让我们举个例子。达科他人想象有四个灵魂：身体的灵魂，与身体一起死亡；身体的灵魂，它与身体一起死亡；始终与身体同在或在身体附近的精神；灵魂对身体的动作做出反应，根据一些人的说法，灵魂向南移动，根据另一些人的说法，灵魂向西移动；最后是第四个：它始终保留在死者亲属保留的一簇头发中，直到有机会将他扔到敌国，在那里这个灵魂开始以传播死亡和疾病的幻象的形式徘徊432。

But who is the kidnapper? We will see shortly that the kidnapper is often the deceased himself, that the dead drag the living with them. The process of forming the representation according to which it is the deceased (usually in the form of an animal) who kidnaps the soul is inseparable from another process, namely the process of objectification of the soul. Let us give an example. The Dakota imagine that there are four souls: the soul of the body, which dies together with it; the spirit which always remains with the body or is found in its vicinity; the soul which answers for the actions of the body and which heads south, according to some, or west, according to others; and finally the fourth: it always remains in the tuft of hair of the deceased which the relatives keep until the opportunity arises to throw it into an enemy country where this soul begins to wander in the form of a vision which sows death and disease . 432

在后一种情况下，有趣的是，从死者中释放的灵魂或其中一个灵魂反过来又成为其他灵魂的死亡原因。换句话说，其中一个灵魂客观化了自己，成为一个独立而可怕的存在，失去了与主人的联系并导致死亡。
