In this last case it is interesting that the soul or one of the souls that comes out of the dead becomes in turn the cause of death for the others. In other words one of the souls objectifies itself, becomes an independent and fearsome being, loses the bond with its master and causes death.

我们所说的客观化是指相信灵魂是一个独立的存在，能够生活在人之外。为了这个目的并不总是需要死亡；即使是活着的人也可以在自己之外拥有灵魂或灵魂之一。就是所谓的外在灵魂，灌木灵魂。科什切伊就有这样的灵魂。

Objectification means the belief that the soul is an independent being capable of living outside of man. For this purpose it is not always necessary to die; even a living man can have a soul or one of his souls outside himself. This is the so-called external soul, bush-soul . Košcej has such a soul.

在班图人中，人有四个灵魂，其中一个是外在的，以动物的形式与人的身体以最亲密的方式联系在一起。这种动物是豹子、乌龟、鱼或任何其他动物。

Among the Bantu, man has four souls, one of which is external, in the form of an animal connected in the most intimate way with the body of man. This animal is a leopard, a tortoise, a fish or any other.

当我们得知动物绑架了生者的灵魂时，我们总是想知道这种动物是否不是从死去的动物身上衍生出来的。因此，在特林吉特部落的印第安人中，水獭被赋予了一种特殊的、超自然的美德，其中还有偷偷绑架人类并将他们转化为水獭人的热情433。即使死者早已失去了动物的外表，人们仍然会感到恐惧，就是基于这个事实。因此，在社会群岛，人们相信“死者的灵魂拥有绑架生者灵魂的力量” 434。在弗雷泽身上可以找到很多这种现象的例子。例如，塔拉努马雷部落（墨西哥）认为，尽管萨满尽了一切努力来挽救病人的生命，但死亡还是发生了，其原因是“那些在他之前死去的人打电话给他或把他拖走” » 435 .死者拖着生者一起走。英属新几内亚的巴布亚人相信“死者的灵魂带走了生者的灵魂” 436。特殊的神灵出现，其任务是拯救灵魂。毛利学者之一埃尔德森·贝斯特说：“蜥蜴代表死亡：这解释了毛利人对蜥蜴的巨大恐惧，以及为什么看到蜥蜴是一个非常不祥的预兆。她是维罗（邪恶神灵）的使者，也是死亡的使者……维罗派蜥蜴来带走这个人。”并进一步说：“现在你知道为什么维罗被称为小偷了，因为他是小偷的保护者，自古以来他就到处潜入绑架人类的灵魂” 437。

When we are told that animals carry off the souls of the living, we can always ask ourselves whether this animal is not derived from a zoomorphic dead person. Thus, among the Indians of the Tlingit tribe, a special and supernatural virtue is attributed to the otter, among other things the passion for stealthily carrying off men and transforming them into otter-men . 433 This fact is generally the basis of the fear that the dead inspire even when they have long since lost their animal form. Thus in the Society Islands it is believed that "the souls of the dead possess the power to carry off the souls of the living." 434 In Frazer one can find numerous examples of this phenomenon. The Taranumare tribe (Mexico), for example, believe that death, which comes in spite of all the efforts of the shaman to save the life of the sick person, is caused by the fact that "those who died before him have called him or dragged him away." 435 The dead drag the living with them. The Papuans of British New Guinea are convinced that "the spirits of the dead carry away the souls of the living." 436 Special deities arise whose task it is to save souls. Eldson Best, one of the Maori scholars, says: "The lizard represents death: this explains the great fear which lizards inspire in the Maori people and why the sight of a lizard is a very bad omen. It is the messenger of Viro (an evil deity) and the announcer of death. . . Viro sends the lizard to fetch the man." And further on: «Now you see why Viro is called a thief, because he is the protector of thieves, since time immemorial he has intruded everywhere to steal the souls of men» 437 .

上述案例说明了一种观念的存在，根据这种观念，死亡的发生是因为死者以动物的形式绑架了灵魂，而其中的一种动物正是蛇。

The above cases illustrate the existence of a conception according to which death occurs because a dead person, in the form of an animal, has kidnapped the soul, and one of these animals is precisely the serpent.

例如，在他的古代东图拉耶夫的历史中，他说：“还有一种特殊的死亡灵魂的代表，埃克穆（ekimmu），他到处传播疾病。这些巴比伦恶魔的形象被保留下来，它们大多是有翅膀的人物，类似于野兽” 438。类似的现象在埃及也有发生。第27章。 《死亡之书》向夺走心灵的诸神祈祷。但在埃及，吞噬死者的人（而不是绑架者）的外表略有不同：他在火湖附近被发现，死者击败了他，我们稍后会看到。说到这里，值得一提的是7世纪科普特圣人皮森齐奥 (Pisenzio) 的一生。皮森齐奥描述了木乃伊遭受的折磨；对他来说，木乃伊是一个过着罪恶和不诚实生活的人。木乃伊说道：“当我陷入浓浓的黑暗中时，我看到一个200多噚大的湖，里面满是爬行动物；每只爬行动物都有七个头，身体类似于蝎子。巨虫也住在那里，光是看到它的人都会感到恐惧。它的嘴里长着一些类似于铁矛的牙齿。一只（这些爬行动物）抓住了我，把我扔到了那只不停吃东西的蠕虫那里；突然，所有其他爬行动物都聚集在他周围，当他用我的肉填满他的嘴后，所有这些爬行动物聚集在他周围，也填满了他们的嘴。”并进一步说：“当我睁开眼睛时，我看到死亡在多个方面在空气中漫游，在那一刻，无视仁慈的天使走近，将我不幸的灵魂从身体中带走，然后将其绑在一个绳索的形式上。”黑马，他们带我去了阿蒙提。”这些素材包含了许多童话的配件：火湖、多头蛇、空中传送的人，甚至还有马，当然，它们也让我们更加了解童话的起源。这个类比是相当完整的：抹去死亡的那一刻就足以衍生出一种纯粹的“幻想”，没有宗教基础。我们在童话故事中也看到了同样的“奇幻”。这些案例以非常清晰的形式包含了死亡时刻。唯一被遗忘的元素是捕获者源自代表灵魂的动物。在更原始的情况下（非常罕见），这个元素仍然很明显。因此，例如，爱斯基摩人的托纳苏克（Tornasuk），萨满灵魂的绑架者，可以被认为是先于蛇的。它看起来像一头有吸盘的海象。分析tornasuk Nansen这个词得出的结论是它的意思是“去除灵魂” 439。厄里涅斯也与灵魂相连。这种联系对于学者来说是显而易见的，但对于相信这种存在的人来说却并非总是如此。

In his history of the ancient East, Turaev, for example, says: "There was also a representation of a special spirit of death, ekimmu , which roamed everywhere spreading disease. Images of these Babylonian devils have been preserved, mostly winged figures, similar to wild beasts." 438 Similar phenomena are also found in Egypt. The 27th chapter of the Book of the Dead addresses a prayer to the gods who carry away hearts. But in Egypt the devourer (and not the kidnapper) of the dead has a somewhat different appearance: he is found near the lake of fire, and the dead defeat him, as we will see later. At this point it is interesting to cite the life of Pizentius, a Coptic saint of the seventh century . Pizentius describes the torments inflicted on the mummy; for him the mummy is a man who led a sinful and dishonest existence. Here is the mummy speaking: "And it happened that when I was thrown into the thick darkness, I saw a lake more than 200 fathoms in size and it was full of reptiles; each reptile had seven heads and its body resembled that of scorpions. There also lived the Great Worm, the mere sight of which terrified those who looked at it. It had in its mouth certain teeth similar to iron spears. And one (of these reptiles) grabbed me and threw me to that worm that never stopped eating; and suddenly all the other reptiles gathered around it and after it had filled its mouth with my flesh all these reptiles, gathered around it, also filled their mouths." And further on: "When my eyes were opened I saw death in many forms, and at that moment the angels who know nothing of mercy came and took my wretched soul from my body, and, having bound it in the form of a black horse, bore me to Amenti." These materials contain many fairy-tale accessories: the lake of fire, the many-headed serpent, the man carried through the air, and even the horse, and, of course, they bring us closer to understanding the origin of the fairy tale. The analogy is complete enough: it is enough to erase the moment of death to obtain a pure "fantasy," without any religious foundation. We also see the same "fantasy" in the fairy tale. These cases contain the moment of death in a very clear form. The only element forgotten is the derivation of the kidnapper from the animals that represent the soul. This element is still clear in more primitive cases (which are very rare). Thus, for example, the tornasuk of the Eskimos, the snatcher of the souls of shamans, can be considered as anterior to the serpent; it has the appearance of a walrus with suckers. Analyzing the word tornasuk Nansen comes to the conclusion that it means "removing soul" 439. The Erinyes are also connected with the soul. This connection is obvious to the scholar, but it is not always so to the people who believe in such beings.

但为了更准确地理解，仍然缺少一个要素。到目前为止，我们的注意力都集中在绑匪的身上。被绑架者的形象，即童话故事中一般的公主或女人的形象，一直在我们的视野之外；在引用的材料中，我们尚未遇到作为绑架对象的妇女。现在我们必须开始研究这个元素。

But for a more precise understanding there is still one element missing. Up to now we have turned our attention exclusively to the figure of the kidnapper. The figure of the kidnapped, that is, of the princess or of the woman in general in the fairy tale, has remained outside our field of vision; in the materials cited we have not yet encountered the woman as the object of the kidnapping. And now we must undertake the study of this element.

24.插入色情时刻。

24. Inserting the erotic moment .

死者有两种非常强烈的本能，他们凭借灵魂的客体化而作为自主存在而存在：对食物的饥饿和性欲。在早期，对食物的饥饿是第一位的：吞噬死亡比所有其他类型的死亡都更古老。从这个角度来看，埃及的死者吞噬者应该被认为是非常古老的。在埃及和巴比伦，我们发现的在希腊如此发达的色情时刻仍然完全缺失。

Two very strong instincts were attributed to the dead who, by virtue of the objectification of the soul, existed as autonomous beings: hunger for food and sexual appetite. In the earliest times, hunger for food is in first place: devouring death is older than all other types of death. From this point of view, the Egyptian devourers of the dead are to be considered very archaic. In Egypt, as well as in Babylon, the erotic moment which we find, for example, so luxuriantly developed in Greece, is still completely lacking.

随着社会的进步，性感觉的满足逐渐凸显出来。有时，这两种形式的食欲会被同化，就像俄罗斯童话中发生的那样：“蛇抓住了公主，把她拖到巢穴里，但没有吃掉她；蛇抓住了公主，把她拖到了巢穴里，但没有吃掉她；蛇抓住了公主，把她拖到了巢穴里，但没有吃掉她；蛇抓住了公主，把她拖到了自己的巢穴里，但没有吃掉她。”她是如此美丽，以至于他娶了她为妻子”（Af. 85）。在原始社会中，没有个人色情表现的空间。这种色情出现得相对较晚，并被插入到先前存在的宗教表征中，特别是被插入到绑架死亡的表征中。神在凡人中选择一个情人或情人。死亡的发生是因为绑灵者爱上了一个活人，并将他传送到亡灵国度与他结婚。在个体之爱还没有发展起来的地方，绑匪的欲望只是对异性的欲望，但后来变成了对这个性别中特定的、被选择的个性的欲望。因此，帕金森告诉我们有关新梅克伦堡岛的以下内容：“死者的灵魂，即那些埋在地下的人的灵魂，被称为tangou或kenit。白天它们是看不见的，晚上它们以炽热的火花或小火的形式出现在世人面前。死去的男人的灵魂会跟踪女人，死去的女人的灵魂也会悄悄接近男人。所有活着的人都会在灵魂接近时逃离，因为它们带来疾病、折磨和死亡” 440。还有其他地方：未出生的孩子或死于分娩的妇女的灵魂被称为geges……他们也在白天以男人或女人的形式四处游荡，他们用某些非常芬芳的草药装饰自己，因此从远处就可以辨认出来；他们试图引诱活生生的男人和女人，并诱导他们与自己发生性关系；他们特别迫害那些与同一图腾成员有关系的人。这些geges生活在峡谷和石地中。

As social development progresses, the satisfaction of sexual feeling comes to the fore. Sometimes these two forms of appetite become assimilated, as in the Russian fairy tale: "The serpent seized the princess and dragged her to his lair, but did not eat her; she was so beautiful that he took her for his wife" (Aph. 85). In primitive society there is no room for manifestations of individual eroticism. This eroticism appears relatively late and is inserted into pre-existing religious representations and in particular into the representation of death as abduction. The deity chooses a lover from among the mortals. Death occurs because the spirit abductor has fallen in love with a living person and has transported him to the realm of the dead in order to marry him. Where individual love has not yet developed, the desire of the abductor is simply desire for the other sex, but later it becomes desire for a specific and chosen individual of this sex. Parkinson tells us the following about the island of New Mecklenburg: "The spirits of the dead, that is, of those who were buried underground, are called tangou or kenit . By day they are invisible, by night they appear to the living in the form of fiery sparks or small fires. The spirits of dead men pursue women, the spirits of dead women approach men furtively. All the living flee at the approach of the spirits, for they bring sickness, torment and death." 440 And elsewhere: the spirits of unborn children or of women who died in childbirth are called gesges... They also wander around during the day in the form of men or women, adorn themselves with certain very fragrant herbs and are therefore recognizable from afar; they try to seduce living men and women and induce them to unite sexually with them; they persecute in particular those who have had relations with members of the same totem. These gesges live in ravines and stone-heaps.

对死亡的描绘的色情色彩越来越强烈。斯滕伯格将这种现象称为“选择性”。 “神灵或其他生物选择了一个情人，并将她传送到死亡的境界。”斯滕伯格写道：“这种观念在原始人的智力中得到了巩固，甚至个人生活中的许多悲剧事件也被归因于选择性。例如，闪电或随机火灾造成的死亡，掠食性动物、老虎、熊、鳄鱼等造成的死亡。这是由于这个或那个灵魂爱上了这个或那个人，杀死了他以在精神世界中拥有他» 441。

The erotic coloration of the representations of death becomes more and more intense. Sternberg has called this phenomenon "electivity." "The deity or another being chooses a lover and transports her to the realm of death." Sternberg writes: "This idea has become so firmly established in the intellect of primitive man that even many tragic events in the life of the individual are ascribed to electivity. Thus, for example, death by lightning or by chance fire, death by a predatory animal, tiger, bear, crocodile, etc., is attributed to the fact that this or that spirit, having fallen in love with this or that individual, kills him in order to possess him in the world of spirits . " 441

它是一种晚期现象，从它在古希腊特别普遍的事实就可以看出，而在其演变的最原始阶段，它仍然呈现出非常普遍和无差别的特征。在希腊人中，为爱而强奸被认为是死亡形式之一。阿特米多洛斯的格言是众所周知的：“如果病人梦想与神或女神结合，这意味着死亡” 442。在443 座坟墓中发现了一些石板，上面描绘了一名妇女被一位美丽的长着翅膀的年轻人从哭泣的亲戚中绑架的故事。 “在古代宗教中，死亡被理解为与死亡神性的结合，死者与之庆祝婚礼” 444。这也体现在婚礼仪式上。 « 婚礼是典型的石棺造型；处女膜之神是死亡之神；送葬队伍与婚礼队伍相同；新娘在晚上由火把引导，床铺得像临终床，围绕祭坛的游行类似于葬礼” 445。没有必要报告所有导致古典学者得出这样结论的材料。

That this is a late phenomenon is evident from the fact that it is particularly widespread in ancient Greece, while in the most primitive phases of its evolution it still presents a very generic and undifferentiated character. Among the Greeks, abduction for love was known as one of the forms of death. Artemidorus's maxim is well known: "If the sick person dreams of uniting with a god or a goddess, it means death." 442 In tombs, tablets were found depicting a woman being abducted from the circle of her weeping relatives by a beautiful winged youth . 443 "In the religion of antiquity, death was understood as a union with the divinity of death; the deceased celebrated the wedding with it." 444 This is also evident in wedding rituals. "Wedding is a typical representation of the sarcophagi; the gods of the hymen are the gods of death; the funeral procession is the same as the wedding procession; the bride is led at night by torchlight, the bridal chamber is made to resemble a deathbed, and the procession around the altar is analogous to the funeral ceremonial" 445 . It is not necessary to report all the materials that have led scholars of classical antiquity to such conclusions.

25.神话中的老鼠。

25. The Abduction in Myths .

从这些一般性观察中，我们现在转向神话。就他们而言，我们可以在这里引用来自各个原始民族的一系列关于这种或那种动物强奸人类的传说。随着宗教的演变，动物被神所取代，但这些神仍然保留着兽形：冥王普鲁托在他的战车上绑架了得墨忒耳的女儿科尔；珀罗普斯用一辆神奇的战车载着希波达弥亚横渡大海。空中飞行的战车取代了预先存在的动物。希腊神话中从人类手中绑架爱人的众神名单令人瞩目。马尔滕专门研究了可拉的绑架，他得出的结论是，这个主题源于对死亡绑架人的表现。色情时刻是后来添加的446。童话比这些神话更古老：童话中的绑匪还没有人类的外表，他保留着吞噬动物的本性，而这种本性几乎在神话中消失了。另一方面，波瑞阿斯（Boreas）的神话与童话故事有非常相似的地方，即波瑞阿斯（Boreas）在伊利苏斯河岸绑架了奥里提亚（Oritia），当时奥里提亚正与朋友仙女法玛塞亚（Farmacea）玩耍，并将她带到萨佩多涅悬崖上的色雷斯（Thrace）。女孩在花园里散步，被旋风卷走。

From these general remarks we now pass to myths. In so far as they are concerned we could cite here a whole series of legends of various primitive peoples about the abduction of a man by this or that animal. With the development of religion the animal is replaced by the god, but these gods still retain their zoomorphism: Pluto, god of the underworld, abducts Kore, daughter of Demeter, in his chariot; Pelops carries Hippodameia across the sea in a miraculous chariot; the chariot flying through the air replaces a pre-existing animal. The list of gods of Greek mythology who have abducted their lovers from the human race is considerable. Malten, who has studied especially the abduction of Kore, comes to the conclusion that this motif is derived from the representation of the abduction of men by Death. The erotic moment is added later . The fairy tale is more archaic than these myths: in fairy tales the kidnapper does not yet have a human appearance, he retains his nature as a devouring animal, which in myths has almost been lost. On the other hand, the myth of Boreas who kidnaps Orithyia from the banks of the Ilissus while she is playing with a friend, the nymph Pharmacea, and takes her to Thrace on the Sarpedon rock, has a very close parallel in fairy tales in which the girl who is walking in a garden is carried away by a whirlwind.

除此之外，还有希腊绑架死亡事件的再现，但已经不明确了。例如，在欧里庇得斯的《阿尔赛斯特》中，主人公被塔纳托斯（Thanatos）绑架，塔纳托斯是一位无面且苍白的神，其名字的意思是死亡。或者，正如迪特里希所说，吞噬人类的欲望归因于哈迪斯本人447。鹰身女妖只捕猎雄性。

In addition, there were representations of the abducting death in Greece, but already amorphous. Thus, for example, in Euripides' Alceste the protagonist is abducted by Thanatos, a faceless and pale divinity, whose name means death. Or, as Dieterich says, the desire to devour men is attributed to Hades himself 447 . The Harpies hunt only males.

因此，如果美丽绑架的原因在基因上变得清晰，但这并不意味着一切都已经明确了。有人可能会反对公主被“死亡”以龙的形式绑架等等。永远不会死。她的命运是双重的：在最原始的材料中，丈夫将她从蛇手中救了回来，这样她就可以庆祝两段婚姻，其中一场是被迫的，与一只动物（她与动物的婚姻生活在爱情童话中讲述）类型和普赛克），另一个与一个男人，即与小王子。但也有不存在两个配偶的情况：蛇没有被丈夫取代，而是变成了美丽的王子，就像《丘比特与普赛克》中所发生的那样。后来，美丽被神绑架，仍然是神的妻子。科什切伊、鸟类、熊等与蛇一起出现在童话故事中并非巧合。被绑架公主的命运将我们带回到森林房屋建筑群，在那里她接受了科什切伊的婚礼仪式，然后交到了人类新郎手中。当我们分析国王和公主的新婚之夜时，我们将研究这一时刻的进一步发展。

If, therefore, the motif of the kidnapped beauty is clarified genetically, this does not mean that everything is already definitively clear. One might object that the princess kidnapped by "death" in the form of a dragon, etc., never dies. Her fate is twofold: in the most primitive materials the groom takes her back from the serpent, and in this way she would celebrate two marriages, one, forced, with an animal (her married life with the animal is narrated in fairy tales of the type of Cupid and Psyche ) and the other with a man, that is, with the little prince. But there are also cases in which there are not two spouses: the serpent is not replaced by the groom, but is transformed into a handsome prince, as happens in Cupid and Psyche . Later, kidnapped by a god, the beauty remains the wife of this god. It is no coincidence that in the fairy tale Košcej, birds, bears, etc. appear alongside the serpent. The fate of the kidnapped princess leads us back to the forest house complex, where she receives the nuptial initiation from Košcej and then passes into the hands of the human groom. We will study the further development of this moment when we analyze the wedding night of the little king and the princess.

五、水蛇

V. The Water Serpent

26.蛇的水生特性。

26. The aquatic nature of the snake .

在引用的例子中我们已经发现，鱼、鲨鱼、鲸鱼、蛇、木桶总是与水有关。蛇的这一方面也需要研究；即使在童话故事中，蛇也是水生生物。

In the examples cited we already find that the fish, the shark, the whale, the snake, the barrel are always connected with water. This aspect of the snake must also be studied; even in the fairy tale the snake is an aquatic being.

我们必须确定蛇的水生特性是否是后来插入的元素，或者这方面是否也是它最初固有的。上面，当我们谈到“主人”时，我们已经遇到了童话故事中的水生生物：我们看到了元素之王，其中也包括水。说到这里，我想起了那位一直抬起膝盖的老人；只要他让它们升起，湖里的水就很高，一旦他把它们放下，湖里的水就会降低。蛇正是这些生物之一。蛇从水中上升，必然伴随着水的上升。

We must decide whether the aquatic nature of the serpent is a later element, or whether this aspect is its own from the beginning. We have already met the aquatic beings in the fairy tale above, when we spoke of the "masters": we have seen the lords of the elements, and among them also the lord of water. I remember in this connection the old man who holds his knees up; as long as he holds them up, the water of the lake is high; as soon as he lowers them, the water also lowers. The serpent is precisely one of these beings. The rising of the serpent from the water invariably involves the rising of the water.

迄今为止分析的蛇的所有功能都与其外观没有紧密的联系。鱼、蜥蜴和鸟这些构成蛇的动物也能吞咽和呕吐。对水域的守护与最初的蛇的出现以及后来的蛇龙的出现有着更紧密的联系。在最原始的民族中，例如澳大利亚人中，已经发现了水蛇守护者的形象。 “距离爱丽丝泉约五十米——斯宾塞和吉伦指出——有一个峡谷，据说里面住着一条大蛇的灵魂，还有许多活蛇，即它的后代” 448。这种雄性（甚至雌性）蛇在澳大利亚很常见。个案描述呈现出三个共同特点：蛇体形大、造型奇特、生活在水里，能吞、存于体内、能吐；吞噬人类，人类要么死亡，要么获得健康和魔法美德。在澳大利亚西南部，人们相信蛇“生活在深邃且常年的盆地中，代表水元素，这对整个澳大利亚的居民至关重要”。这条蛇被称为 Kurreja，被描述为“体型巨大的怪物，类似蛇”。其他人被称为卡里亚（Karia）并“将受害者整个吞下” 449。在其他地方，这种怪物被称为“Iero”，被描述为“一条巨大的鳗鱼或蛇……它有一个红头发的大头和巨大的下巴，据说，水从其中流淌。”它的身体毛茸茸的，颜色各异，对于居住在这个地区的人来说，它具有治愈的能力。病人可以在水中游泳并恢复健康” 450。

All the functions of the serpent so far analyzed are not firmly connected with its appearance. Even the fish, the lizard, and the bird, animals that constitute the serpent, can swallow and vomit. The guardianship of waters is more firmly connected with the aspect of the serpent at first, and of the dragon-serpent at a later time. The representation of the serpent as guardian of waters is already encountered among the most primitive peoples, for example among the Australians. "About fifty meters from the Alice Springs," Spencer and Gillen note, "there is a gorge where it is said that the spirit of a large dead serpent dwells, together with a multitude of living serpents, its descendants." 448 This male (or female) serpent is widespread in Australia. The descriptions of individual cases present three common characteristics: the serpent is of large size and of a fantastic appearance, it lives in water which it can swallow, keep in its body and vomit again; devours men, who either perish or gain health and magical powers. In south-western Australia there is a belief in a serpent which 'lives in deep and everlasting pools and represents the element of water, which is of vital importance to the inhabitants of all Australia'. The serpent, called Kurreja, is described as 'a monster of enormous size, resembling a serpent'. Others are called Karia and 'they swallow their victims whole' . 449 In other places this monster is called Iero and is described as 'an enormous eel or serpent... it has a large head with red hair and enormous jaws, from which, so it is said, rapid waters flow. Its body is hairy and of various colours, and to the inhabitants of this locality it has healing powers. The sick can swim in the water and recover health' . 450

这些材料表明，水蛇的存在是在我们所知的社会进化的最原始阶段就被确定的。这种表述自然也有它的史前史，我们缺乏史前的材料，我们不会假设地深入到更遥远的距离。我们注意到的第二件事是，吞蛇和水蛇是同一个存在。这解释了为什么当神话中出现被吞者运动的原因时，这种运动通常发生在水上或通过水。澳大利亚人在入会仪式上会画出张着嘴的蛇。因此，吞蛇无非是水蛇，但在某些情况下，蛇的某一方面较发达，在其他情况下，另一方面较发达。

These materials demonstrate that the presence of the water serpent is established in the most primitive stages of social evolution known to us. This representation naturally also has its prehistory, for which we lack the materials, and we will not hypothetically delve into a more remote distance. The second thing we note is that the swallowing serpent and the water serpent are one and the same being. This explains why when the motif of the swallowed being's movement arises in myths, this movement usually occurs on water or through water. During the initiation rite, the Australians make a figure of the serpent with its mouth open. Therefore, the swallowing serpent is nothing other than the water serpent, but in some cases one aspect of the serpent is more developed, in other cases the other aspect is developed.

这些蛇继续统治着世界各地人民的水域，并处于进一步的进化阶段。根据尼亚萨（大洋洲）居民的说法，“一只可怕的螃蟹覆盖了蛇的下颚，导致潮起潮落” 451。在没有潮汐的地方，蛇只是让海水移动。艾诺人说，“湖里住着一条鳟鱼，它非常强壮，当它用胸鳍撞击岸边时，它的尾巴就会把对岸的水抬高” 452。在多尔加尼童话故事中，英雄遇到了猛犸象。 « 猛犸象走过的地方，就形成河流；第453章在阿玛祖鲁人中，人们害怕使用某个湖的水，因为蛇 Umugarna 生活在其中454。在穆伊斯卡印第安人中，人们祭祀生活在湖中的蛇或龙455。

These serpents continue to rule the waters among the peoples of the whole world and in further stages of evolution. According to the inhabitants of Niassa (Oceania) "a horrible crab covers the jaws of the serpent, causing the ebb and flow." 451 Where there is no tide the serpent simply causes the water to move. The Ainos tell that "in a lake there lived a trout, so strong that when it struck the shore with its pectoral fins, it raised the waters with its tail on the opposite shore." 452 In a Dolgani tale the hero meets a mammoth. "Where the mammoth walks, rivers are formed; where it lies down, lakes are formed." 453 Among the Ama-Zulú people are afraid to use the water of a certain lake, because the serpent Umugarna lives in it . 454 Among the Muiska Indians sacrifices are made to the serpent or dragon that lives in lake 455 .

在致力于农业和畜牧业的非洲人民中，可以特别清楚地观察到蛇与土壤肥力的联系。 « 人们相信，蛇会带来幸运的捕获；他拥有这条河流以及其中的一切。”因此，这里的施主蛇也是水蛇。它与仪式的联系也广泛建立。在非洲，蛇崇拜的阳具方面尤其发达（有关文件，请参见Hambly 456）。

Among the African peoples devoted to agriculture and pastoralism, the connection between the serpent and the fertility of the soil can be observed with particular clarity. "The serpent, so it is believed, gives a lucky catch; it has in its power the river and all that is in it." Therefore here too the donor-serpent is the water serpent. Its connection with the rites is also largely established; in Africa the phallic aspect of the serpent cult is particularly developed (for documents, see Hambly 456 ).

就像吞咽蛇一样，水生生物最初是一种可怕但最终有益的生物：它提供水，后来成为地球和人类肥沃的创造者。

Like the swallowing serpent, the aquatic one was originally a fearsome but ultimately beneficial being: it is the one who gives water, later it becomes the creator of the fertility of both the earth and men.

与蛇打斗的原因是怎样产生的呢？从外部来看，就主题而言，蛇滥用权力的原因是：作为水生生物，它保留了水分并导致干旱，或者相反，它吐出的量足以导致干旱。洪水。

How does the motif of the fight against the serpent arise? Externally, as far as the subject is concerned, the motif of the abuse of power by the serpent appears: in his quality of being aquatic he retains water and causes drought, or, on the contrary, vomits such a quantity of it as to cause a flood.

在乔皮印第安人中，一条蛇从池塘上升到天空，并抬高了后面的水位，引发了洪水457。在印加印第安人中，洪水是由于“第一个人或称为帕查的神的三个儿子，没有人可以与之战斗，开始与一条大蛇战斗;他通过吐出大量的水来报复，以至于整个地球都被淹没了”（Krickeberg，第279页）。在最后一个例子中，关系是相反的：蛇喷水是因为有人开始对抗它。在像红皮人那样的文明阶段，这样的例子是很少见的。更常见的是，蛇被杀死是因为它是吞食者，而不是因为它是水生生物。

Among the Chopi Indians a serpent rose up from a pool to the sky and raised the waters behind it, causing a flood . 457 Among the Inca Indians the flood is caused by the fact that "the three sons of the first man or of a god called Pacha, having no one to fight with, began to wrestle with a large serpent; this took revenge by spitting out such a mass of water that the whole earth was flooded" (Krickeberg, p. 279). In this last example the relationship is reversed: the serpent emits the water because someone has begun to fight it. Examples of this kind are rarely met with in the stage of civilization corresponding to that of the Redskins; more often the serpent is killed because it is a swallower and not because it is an aquatic being.

但随着向常规农业的过渡、牲畜饲养和原始状态的形成，情况发生了变化。这个阶段创造了拟人化的神。对于农民来说，他的神掌管着水域是很重要的。它的神具有人类的外表。曾经被视为神圣的神灵，如今却有着凶猛的外表。随着神性从兽转移到神，神杀死了兽，推翻了它们，剥夺了它们对水域的统治权，并开始按照农民和牲畜饲养者的需要来统治它们。

But with the transition to regular agriculture, to the breeding of livestock and the formation of the primitive State, things change. This phase creates anthropomorphic gods. For the farmer it is important that his gods govern the waters; his gods have a human appearance. The divine beings, once considered sacred, have a wild appearance. With the transition of divinity from the beast to the god, the gods kill the beasts, dethrone them, take away their government of the waters and begin to govern them as is necessary for the farmer and the livestock breeder.

这一阶段在印度表现得尤为清晰，在希腊和中国也表现得尤为明显。

This stage is represented with particular prominence in India, and appears clearly in Greece and China.

《梨俱吠陀》中关于太阳和月球神话中与蛇的战斗已经说了很多。被强大的因陀罗神征服的蛇弗利多（Vritra）的含义之一是绝对明确的：他阻止了河流。河流之所以流动，只是因为因陀罗杀死了弗栗多并释放了他们。以下是458条引言：

Much has been said about the fight with the serpent in the Rigveda in connection with solar and lunar mythology; one of the meanings of the serpent Vritra, defeated by the powerful god Indra, is absolutely clear: it is he who holds back the rivers. The rivers flow only because Indra killed Vritra and freed them. Here are some quotes 458 :

III-33：《河流说：我们的河床是因陀罗为我们挖掘的。谁手里拿着霹雳；他移走了并杀死了阻挡水流的弗栗多。” IV-17（对因陀罗）：“在用力量和力量杀死弗利多之后，你释放了被龙吞没的河流”。 I-32：“你让七条河流流动。” I-52：“因陀罗杀死了阻止河流的维梨陀”（参见整首赞美诗 1-32，以及 I-51-4、I-51-5、I-52-2-6、I-121 -11、II-11-5、VIII-12-26、VIII-851-18 等）。

III-33: « The rivers say: our riverbed was dug for us by Indra, who had the thunderbolt in his hand; he removed and killed Vritra, who was holding back the waters ». IV-17 (addressing Indra): « Having killed Vritra with power and strength, you freed the rivers, swallowed up by the dragon ». I-32: « You made the seven rivers flow ». I-52: « Indra killed Vritra, who was holding back the rivers » (cf. the entire hymn 1-32, as well as I-51-4, I-51-5, I-52-2-6, I-121-11, II-11-5, VIII-12-26, VIII-851-18, etc.).

即使在中国，蛇也是水生生物，它是海洋和湖泊生物，也生活在井里。海蛇生活在海底一座由透明石头和水晶门组成的宫殿里。清晨，如果海面平静，无论谁在水面上弯腰都可以看到这座宫殿459。换句话说，他从元素之主转变为元素之王或皇帝，具有中国皇帝的形象和相似性。说到这里，值得一提的是北京460成立的传奇故事。北京是由蛋白石王子建立的。城市繁荣，商人出现，贸易繁荣，城市供应充足，王子以正义治理，但发生干旱。城门外就是蛇洞。几千年来没有人见过他，但众所周知他住在那里。挖掘机在挖地筑墙的同时，也触及了那个山洞，没有考虑可能产生的后果。蛇很恼怒，决定搬到别处去，但蛇却说：“我们在这里生活了几千年，难道能容忍燕王赶走我们吗？”如果我们必须离开，我们会带走阴阳缸（用来盛水的浴缸）中的所有水箱，并在午夜时分出现在王子的梦中，请求他允许我们离开。如果他同意我们并允许我们随身携带浴缸，他就会落入陷阱，因为我们会在他自己的允许下接管水。”事情就是这样发生的。蛇在梦中以一老一老的形象出现在王子面前，请求他允许离开北京。于是发生了严重的干旱，所有的水都消失了。梦解了，王子急忙去追两位老人，用长矛在浴缸上戳了个洞，洪水泛滥。佛教僧侣的祈祷使水减少，形成了一个池塘，后来在池塘旁边建立了一座寺庙。据说，朝廷的水就是从这个池塘汲取的。

In China, too, the serpent is an aquatic being, a marine and lake creature, and it also lives in wells. The sea serpent lives at the bottom of the sea in a palace of transparent stones with crystal doors. In the early hours of the morning, if the sea is calm, anyone who bends over the water can see this palace . 459 In other words, from lord of the elements he transforms himself into king or emperor of the elements, in the image and likeness of the Chinese emperor. In this connection it is interesting to cite the legend of the founding of Beijing . 460 Beijing was founded by the prince of opal. The city prospers, merchants appear, trade flourishes, the city is sufficiently supplied, the prince governs with justice, but drought comes. Outside the gates of the city there was the cave of the serpent. For many thousands of years no one had seen him, but it was well known that he lived there. While they were digging the ground to build the walls, the excavators also touched that cave, without thinking of the consequences that could arise. The snake was very angry and decided to move elsewhere, but his female said: "We have lived here for thousands of years, will we tolerate Prince Yen chasing us away? If we have to leave, we will take all the reservoirs in our yin-yang tubs (tubs used to carry water) and at midnight we will appear in the prince's dream and ask his permission to leave. If he grants us this and allows us to take the tubs with us, he will fall into a trap, because we will take possession of the water with his permission." And so it happens. The snakes appear in the prince's dream in the form of an old man and an old woman and ask him for permission to leave Beijing. Then a terrible drought comes, all the water has disappeared. The dream is deciphered, the prince hurries after the two old men, makes a hole in a tub with his spear and a flood arises. A Buddhist monk's prayer causes the water to subside, a pond is formed, next to which a temple later rises. It is said that the water for the imperial court is drawn from this pond.

这个流行的神话被佛教僧侣用于他们的特定目的，就像基督教利用与蛇的决斗来达到其目的一样，导致圣乔治杀死了龙并将他释放的人们皈依了基督教。

This popular myth has been exploited by Buddhist monks for their own purposes, just as the Christian religion has exploited the duel with the serpent for its own purposes, by having St. George kill the dragon and convert the people he freed to Christianity.

所有这些例子都表明，水蛇（以其纯粹的形式，没有任何我们稍后将讨论的其他表征的聚合）被杀死，没有人知道确切的原因，或者被指责造成干旱，滞留水，以及这激发了战斗。

All these examples show that the water serpent (in its pure form, without any aggregate of other representations which we will discuss later) is killed for some unknown reason, or is blamed for causing the drought, for holding back the waters, and this is the reason for the fight.

在古希腊，这些生物之一是九头蛇或勒奈蛇。在形象艺术中，九头蛇被描绘成一条多头蛇，其头的数量在三到九之间。根据阿波罗多洛斯的说法，八个头是凡人，中间的一个是不朽的。人们相信躺在地上的蛇可以盛水。在勒纳，这种表示可能已经扩展和改变，因为当干旱发生时，人们相信蛇吞没了该国所有的水域，因此蛇居住的勒纳地区是如此沼泽461。正如我们之前在中国和其他民族的神话中看到的那样，蛇吞噬或夺走国家所有的水和丰富的水（洪水、涨潮、河流，或更准确地说是沼泽）的表现取决于蛇根本不是古典时期所特有的，更不用说勒纳了。勒奈蛇是水蛇世界形象的特例。

In ancient Greece one of these beings is the hydra or Lernaean serpent. In figurative art the hydra is represented as a multi-headed serpent, the number of its heads varies between three and nine. According to Apollodorus, eight heads were mortal, the middle one was immortal. People believed that the serpent stretched out on the ground held back water. In Lerna this representation had probably been extended and altered in the sense that when drought came, people believed that the serpent swallowed up all the water in the country, and for this reason the place of Lerna, where the serpent lived, was so marshy . 461 As we have seen above in the myths of China and other peoples, the representation according to which the serpent swallows up or carries away all the water in the country and the abundance of water (flood, high tide, river, or more precisely marsh) depends on the serpent, is not at all peculiar to classical antiquity nor even less to Lerna. The Lernaean serpent is a special case of the world image of the water serpent.

另一个特殊的例子是童话故事中的“黑海蛇”，“水中之王”，其背后“水涌三岸高”。

Another such special case is the "Black Sea Serpent" from the fairy tale, "the King of the Waters", behind which "the water gushed three aršinas high ".

但这只是蛇的一个方面，一般来说，它不适合一个统一的解释。其意义是多方面的、多边的；正如弗罗贝尼乌斯、西克和其他人所做的那样，所有将蛇复合体简化为单一整体的尝试都注定会失败。

But this is only one aspect of the serpent, which, in general, does not lend itself to a unitary explanation. Its meaning is multiform and many-sided; all attempts to reduce the serpent complex to a single whole, such as Frobenius, Siecke and others make, are doomed in advance to failure.

在俄罗斯童话中，蛇并不是作为阻挡水流的蛇出现的，斗争也不是从这一动机出发的，但在其他民族的童话中，这种非常古老的动机显然被保留了下来。在普萨维亚童话故事中，英雄“发生在一座恶魔统治水的城市，要求以女孩的形式向它进贡” 462。在俾路支童话中，女​​主人公说：“今天轮到我被国王派去见龙，让他放一点水进入运河，因为这座城市快要渴死了” 463。在蒙古童话中，龙王赐予水，被人类受害者驯服464。在《纳尔蒂》史诗中，七头蛇变成了狗，不允许汲水465。这些材料表明，自古以来，蛇的水生本性就是与生俱来的。在它的起源中，它并没有提供与蛇决斗的机会，蛇为了人类的利益而管理着水源，但在农业中，这一功能传递给了众神，他们杀死了蛇，并给了人类它所保留的水和河流。这一传统独立于与吞噬者战斗的传统而发展。在俄罗斯童话中它不是体现在功能上，而是体现在蛇的水生属性上。

In the Russian fairy tale the serpent does not appear as the one who holds back the water, and the fight does not proceed from this motive, but in the fairy tales of other peoples this very ancient motivation has been clearly preserved. In a Psavian fairy tale the hero "came to a city where a devil ruled the water, demanding tribute for it in the form of maidens." 462 In a Baluchi fairy tale the heroine says: "Today it is my turn to be sent by the king to the dragon, so that he may let some water into the canals, because the city is fainting from thirst." 463 In a Mongolian fairy tale the king of dragons grants water, tamed by a human victim . 464 In the Nart epic the seven-headed serpent, transformed into a dog, does not allow the water to be drawn . 465 These materials prove that the aquatic nature has been inherent in the serpent from time immemorial. Originally it did not provide the occasion for a duel with the serpent that administers the waters for the benefit of men, but with agriculture this function passed to the gods who killed the serpent and gave men the waters and rivers it retained. This tradition developed independently of the tradition of the fight with the swallower. In the Russian fairy tale it is not reflected functionally, but is reflected in the aquatic attributes of the serpent.

27.蛇的税。

27. The Serpent's Taxes .

对蛇的水生性质的研究使我们更接近它的农业概念。我们在我们已经称之为“蛇的税收”的主题中找到了这个农业概念。

The study of the aquatic nature of the serpent has brought us closer to its agricultural conception. This agricultural conception is found in the motif we have already called "the serpent's taxes".

我们一开始所说的关于蛇的一切都与作为基本经济基础的狩猎密切相关，由此产生了这个主题：绑匪带走了被绑架的人。然而，在这里，它被带到了他面前。这种情况发生的方式与女孩向水魔和众神的介绍仪式相对应，目的是影响国家的生育力。

Everything we said about the snake at the beginning is closely connected with hunting as a fundamental economic basis, from which this motif arises: the kidnapper took away the kidnapped girl. Here, instead, she is brought to him. The forms in which this occurs correspond to the rite of the presentation of girls to the water demons and to the gods with the aim of influencing the fertility of the country.

对它的传播的分析使我们想到了上述主题的农业起源：我们在古典农业国家、古代墨西哥、埃及、印度、中国以及在较小程度上也在希腊发现了它。它反映了通过牺牲将女孩强行交付给神的仪式。在胚胎阶段，它也会在更原始的阶段遇到，例如在北美，那里既没有农作物，也没有农业，仪式必须确保丰富的捕鱼。但是，正如我们所说，这种仪式和与之相应的神话只有在拥有原始农业制度的国家才能得到充分发展。

The analysis of its diffusion leads us to the idea of ​​the agricultural origin of the above motif: we find it in the classical agricultural countries, in ancient Mexico, in Egypt, in India, in China, and to a lesser extent also in Greece. It is a reflection of the rite of the forced delivery of a girl to the god, through her sacrifice. In embryo it is also encountered in more primitive stages, as for example in North America where there are neither crops nor agriculture and the rite must ensure abundant fishing. But, as we have said, this rite and the myths corresponding to it reach their full development only in countries with a primitive agricultural regime.

弗雷泽和斯滕伯格都相当令人信服地证明，人与神之间的性关系必须增加土地的产量：这首先可以从这样的事实中看出：这种求婚婚姻是在播种前举行的，其次可以从它们在不同地点的特殊传播中看出。例如，农业依赖河流的地方。在尼罗河、恒河、幼发拉底河、底格里斯河和黄河的山谷中。在那些地方，女孩被献祭给生活在水中的生物。斯腾伯格写道：“由于生育之神被认为是特别贪欲的神，而另一方面，这种贪欲对于男人的福祉是不可或缺的，因此祭祀的习俗就出现了，特别是女孩和男孩，这取决于性别这个或那个神性» 466。这些牺牲可以有多种形式，但对我们来说，只有那些与水重新联系的牺牲才是重要的。在斯滕伯格的描述中，这个仪式的一般特征在于，女孩必须穿上结婚礼服，用鲜花装饰，喷上香水，然后放在一块特殊的岩石或神圣的石头上带到水边，“然后鳄鱼将她拖入水中”。水和人们绝对相信这个女孩已经成为鳄鱼的妻子，如果事实证明她不再是处女，鳄鱼会把她送回来。”

Both Frazer and Sternberg demonstrate quite convincingly that sexual relations between a man and a deity were intended to increase the yield of the land: this is seen firstly from the fact that such offertory marriages were celebrated before sowing, and secondly from their particular diffusion in places where agriculture depends on rivers, such as the valleys of the Nile, the Ganges, the Euphrates and the Tigris, and the Yellow River. In those places the girl was sacrificed to a being who lived in the water. Sternberg writes: "Since the gods of fertility were considered to be particularly lustful deities and, on the other hand, this lust was indispensable for the well-being of men, the custom of sacrificing, especially of girls and boys, according to the sex of this or that deity arose from this." 466 These sacrifices could have various forms, but for us only those that are connected with water are important. In Sternberg's description the general characteristic of this ceremony consists in the fact that the girl must wear the wedding garments, is adorned with flowers, perfumed and carried to the water's edge on a special rock or sacred stone, "after which a crocodile drags her into the water and the people are absolutely convinced that the girl has become the crocodile's wife, who would send her back if it turned out that she was no longer a virgin."

此类牺牲旨在影响收成，以及总体上植被的增加。在致力于捕鱼的民族中，这些仪式旨在增加水中的水量。这种仪式总是与神话密切相关，神话解释了为什么牺牲是必要的以及它的起源。因此，据说在阿尔冈金人和休伦人中，曾经没有鱼，人们面临饥饿的威胁。不料，一位美丽的年轻人（水神）在梦中向酋长显现，并对他说：“我失去了我的妻子，我找不到在我之前没有遇到过男人的女人。这就是为什么你没有鱼，这就是为什么你在这件事上没有让我满意之前，你就不会有鱼。”为了让他相信他的妻子是贞洁的，他们把他嫁给了一个小女孩，而这个小女孩自然不认识任何男人。在仪式中，女孩嫁给了渔网，也就是说，她被扔进水里467。

Sacrifices of this kind were intended to influence the harvest and, in general, the increase of vegetation. Among fishing peoples, such rites were intended to increase the fishiness of the water. The rite is always closely connected with a myth that explains why the sacrifice is necessary and where it originated. Thus, among the Algonquins and Hurons it is told how once there were no fish and the people were threatened with starvation. And behold, a very beautiful youth (the god of water) appeared to the chief in a dream and said to him: "I have lost my wife and I cannot find any woman who has not known a man before me. That is why you have no fish, and that is why you will not have any until you satisfy me in this respect." And to convince him that his wife is chaste, they marry him off to a little girl, who, of course, had never known a man. In the rite the girl is given in marriage to a fishing net, that is, she is thrown into the water 467 .

迪塞尔多夫说，玛雅部落的生活完全依赖于玉米。在奇切尼察市，人们发现了女孩的骨头和头骨，以及属于女孩的珍珠项链和其他女性装饰品，根据编年史家的说法，这些女孩被活活扔进了那个池塘。正如作者所说，由此可见，自愿赠送生命、鲜血和财产可以使众神满意，因此他们没有理由迫害人类。即使在今天，印第安人仍然相信，只有有人被淹死，干旱才会结束468。在美国的收藏中我们找到了相应的神话。

The life of the Maya tribe, says Dieseldorf, depends entirely on corn. In the city of Chichenitza, bones and skulls of girls were found, as well as pearl necklaces and other feminine ornaments belonging to girls who, according to the chroniclers, were thrown alive into that pond. From this, as the author says, it follows that the voluntary gift of life, blood and possessions could satisfy the gods, so that they had no reason to persecute men. Even today the Indians believe that the drought will cease only when someone drowns . 468 In American collections we find corresponding myths.

这组表述在非洲更为普遍。那里的人们相信，一个叫做穆鲁维亚的大草原湖，每年都需要牺牲一个皮肤光滑、没有任何疤痕的孩子（这一要求可能是为了取代贞操）。每年都会征收贡品，按照规定，孩子会被活活扔进湖里……如果没有这种祭品，湖水就会干涸。在踏上长途旅行之前，巴甘迪人试图向维多利亚湖之神穆卡萨献上注定成为他妻子的处女来安抚他。英属东非的阿基库朱人崇拜一条蛇，据他们说，这条蛇生活在他们的一条河流中，每隔几年，他们就把女人，尤其是女孩嫁给这条蛇神。阿拉伯旅行家伊本·白图塔（Ibn Batuta）回忆道，有人向他保证，在岛上（马尔代夫群岛）的人们崇拜偶像的时代，每个月都会有一个邪灵以船只的形式出现在当地人面前。挂满了灯笼。每当居民们看到那艘船时，他们都会带上一个女孩，把她打扮得像新娘一样，把她带到岸边的一座异教寺庙，然后把她遗弃在俯瞰大海的露台上。女孩在这里过夜，第二天早上她被发现死亡并被剥夺了贞操。每个月，当幽灵出现时，居民们都会掷骰子。最后一位被牺牲的处女被一位虔诚的柏柏尔人救了，他通过向海怪背诵《古兰经》来吓跑海怪（469）。

This group of representations is even more widespread in Africa. There the people believed that a certain large lake in the steppe, called Mruvia, annually demanded the sacrifice of a child who had to have smooth skin, without any scars (a requirement which was probably intended to replace chastity). Every year the tribute was collected and, according to the prescriptions, the child was thrown alive into the lake… Without this sacrifice the lake would have dried up. Before undertaking a long journey the Bagandi tried to propitiate Mukasa, the god of Lake Victoria Nyanza, by dedicating to him virgins who were destined to serve as his wives. The Akikuju natives of British East Africa venerate a serpent which, they say, lives in one of their rivers, and every few years they give women, and especially girls, in marriage to this serpent-god. The Arab traveler Ibn Batuta tells that some people assured him that at the time when the population of the island (the Maldives) were idolaters, every month an evil spirit appeared to the natives, emerging from the sea in the form of a vessel covered with lanterns. Every time the inhabitants saw that vessel they took a girl, adorned her like a bride, led her to a pagan temple that stood on the shore and abandoned her on a terrace overlooking the sea. There the girl spent the night and in the morning was found dead and deflowered. Every month, when the spirit appeared, the inhabitants threw dice. The last virgin thus sacrificed was saved by a pious Berber, who managed to put the sea monster to flight by reciting the Koran to it .

在这种情况下，有趣的不仅是带有灯笼和烟雾的欧洲船只被误认为是怪物。还有更多需要注意的地方：这些牺牲无疑很快就会与已经发展起来的农业形式以及与之相对应的社会生活和家庭关系形式以及已经开始创造的宗教形式发生冲突。众神。随着土地所有权的出现，一种新形式的家庭关系诞生了。父母的爱巩固和增长，不再允许孩子做出牺牲。最初对给人类带来丰收的强大神灵的同情转移到了不幸的受害者身上。如果这个受害者是从被征收贡品的敌人队伍中带走的，这就是对受害者开始同情的征兆。但是，尽管如此，有时会出现在很长一段时间内仪式无法从内部破坏的情况。然后一个陌生人出现并释放了女孩。当仪式进行得最激烈的时候，他会被当作一个亵渎神明的人而被杀，因为他的行为会危及人民最切身的利益，因为他的行为会危及收成。相反，在童话故事中，他是人人尊敬的英雄。有趣的是，即使在童话故事中，英雄也常常来自外国。这种同情心的转变也解释了替换的原因，例如，用一个洋娃娃代替了女人。泽列宁在他的《言语禁忌》中引用了一个非常重要的可以解释为非完全替代的案例。松特湖的底部住着塞德神，她是女人的情人。在捕鱼季节开始时，男人们向他扔了一个布娃娃，之后做出这一牺牲的渔夫的妻子去世了：塞德将她作为他的妻子470。在埃及，每年播种前，女孩都会穿上婚纱并扔进尼罗河，以确保河水饱满并获得丰收471。值得注意的是，这种习俗随着阿拉伯人的占领而终止。中国也有同样的习俗，每年都会有一个年轻的女孩被嫁给黄河，也就是说，她被淹死在河里，为此目的，选出最美丽的女孩472。

It is not only the fact that European ships with lanterns and smoke were mistaken for monsters that is interesting here. There is still more to note: these sacrifices undoubtedly soon come into conflict with the forms of agriculture that have developed and with the forms of social life and family relations corresponding to them, as well as with the forms of religion that has already begun to create gods. With the appearance of land ownership a new form of family relations arises. Parental love consolidates and increases and no longer permits the sacrifice of a child. The sympathies that originally went to the mighty spirit who sent the crops to men are transferred to the unfortunate victim. If this victim is taken from the number of enemies on whom a tribute has been imposed, this is a symptom of the beginning of compassion for the victim. But with all this, it sometimes happens that for a long time the rite cannot be destroyed from within. And then a stranger appears and frees the girl. When the rite was at its height he would have been killed as a sacrilegious person who attacks the most vital interests of the people because his action would have jeopardized the harvest. Instead, in the fairy tale he is the hero that everyone honors. It is interesting that even in the fairy tale the hero very often comes from a foreign country. This shifting of sympathies also explains the substitutions, for example, whereby a doll is thrown in place of the woman. A very important case that can be interpreted as a non-total substitution is cited by Zelenin in his Taboo of Words . At the bottom of Lake Sont lives the spirit Seid, a lover of women. At the beginning of the fishing season the men throw him a rag doll, after which the wife of the fisherman who has performed this sacrifice dies: Seid takes her as his wife . 470 In Egypt, every year before sowing, a girl was dressed in a wedding dress and thrown into the Nile to ensure that it would fill up and obtain a good harvest . 471 It is characteristic that this custom ceased with the Arab occupation. The same custom also existed in China where every year a young girl was given in marriage to the Yellow River, that is, she was drowned in it, and for this purpose the most beautiful girls were chosen 472 .

28.神话。

28. The myths .

在仪式不再存在的地方，不同性质的故事往往仍然存在。有时讲述真实发生的案件，或经过艺术修饰，具有童话色彩，出现在“原始童话”集中；他们常常失去了与生育力和繁殖力的原始联系。在墨西哥的一个传说中，人们遭受饥饿；作为玉米的交换，诸神需要一个女孩。 «它必须被引向Pontitlan漩涡» 473。这里与收获的联系非常清楚，反对的因素消失了。瓦德沙加黑人说，有一次，河口的鬼魂绑架了一个正在妇女中间行走的女孩，并将她带到了他们的城市，那里回响着死者迎接新来者的胜利欢呼声。第二天，居民们带来了神灵所希望和指示的祭品，第二天，女孩的尸体在海岸上被发现474。在这种情况下，与生育观念的联系不再被保留，但另一方面，另一种联系显得清晰：灵魂被称为死亡。有时，牺牲的动机仅仅是因为需要安抚水生动物所带来的危险。弗雷泽报道说，东印度群岛的一个岛屿上的居民被一群鳄鱼的出现吓坏了，他们将这种不幸归咎于鳄鱼之王对一个女孩的热情。因此，他们强迫女孩的父亲把她打扮成新娘，并将她投入鳄鱼崇拜者的怀抱475。在后一种情况下，纯粹的色情动机掩盖了古老的宗教动机，与收获的联系已经消失。

Where the rite no longer exists, there are often still tales of a different nature. Sometimes they relate an event which is supposed to have actually happened, or they are artistically embellished, have the character of a fairy tale and figure in collections of "primitive fairy tales"; very often they have lost their original connection with fertility and fecundity. In a Mexican legend the people are starving; in exchange for corn the gods demand a girl. "She must be led to the Pontitlan whirlpool. " 473 Here the connection with the harvest is very clear; the element of opposition is missing. The Wadschagga Negroes relate that once the spirits of the river inlet abducted a girl as she was walking among the women and carried her to their city, from where the cries of triumph with which the dead welcome the newcomer resounded. The next day the inhabitants brought the sacrifices desired and indicated by the spirit, and the next day the girl's body was found on the shore . 474 In this case the connection with the idea of ​​fertility has no longer been preserved, but on the other hand another connection appears clear: the spirits are called dead. Sometimes the sacrifice is motivated simply by the danger represented by the aquatic animals which must be propitiated. Frazer reports that the inhabitants of an island in the East Indies, frightened by the appearance of a herd of crocodiles, attributed this misfortune to the passion which the king of the crocodiles had for a girl. They therefore forced the girl's father to dress her as a bride and to throw her into the arms of her crocodile worshipper . 475 In this last case the purely erotic motivation has obscured the older religious motivation, the connection with the harvest has disappeared.

我们还在希腊神话中发现了类似的动机替代，例如被锁在岩石上的珀尔修斯和安德洛墨达。她为何被锁链锁住？有一次，她的母亲在海女们面前夸耀自己的美丽，引起了海女们的嫉妒。海神带来了可怕的洪水和吞噬一切的鲨鱼。神谕许诺，如果国王的女儿吃了这种可怕的鱼，国家就会得救。在赫拉克勒斯神话中，流浪的英雄在特洛伊海岸遇到了一个被锁在海边岩石上的女孩：她就是拉俄墨冬的女儿赫西俄涅。他的父亲曾经欺骗了建造特洛伊城墙的波塞冬，但没有收到承诺的赔偿。然后波塞冬派出一只海怪摧毁了特洛伊地区，直到绝望中的拉俄墨冬将自己的女儿交给了他。赫拉克勒斯与怪物战斗并释放了赫西俄涅。

A similar substitution of motivations is also found in Greek myths, such as that of Perseus and Andromeda chained to the rock. Why is she chained? Once her mother boasted of her beauty in the presence of the Nereids and aroused their jealousy. The god of the sea sent a terrible flood and a shark that devoured everything. The oracle promised that the country would be saved if the king's daughter was fed to the terrible fish. In the myth of Heracles the wandering hero comes across a girl chained to a rock on the seashore of Troy: it is Hesione, daughter of Laomedon. Once her father had deceived Poseidon who had built the walls of Troy but had not received the promised reward. Then Poseidon sends a sea monster that devastates the Trojan region, until Laomedon, in despair, gives him his daughter. Heracles fights with the monster and frees Hesione.

在牛头怪的传说中，以活人祭祀的形式向被征服的血统征收的贡品被保留了下来。每隔七年，希腊就会派遣九个男孩和九个女孩去见牛头怪，牛头怪在迷宫中将其吞噬。但在牛头怪循环中，提到了袭击该国的干旱和众神带来的流行病。

In the legend of the Minotaur, the tribute imposed on the conquered race in the form of human sacrifices has been preserved; every seven years Greece sent the Minotaur nine young men and nine young women whom he devoured in his labyrinth. But in the Minotaur cycle, reference is made to the drought that had struck the country and to the epidemics sent by the gods.

所有这些案例都将我们直接带入童话故事。发展或证明童话故事可以追溯到上述仪式的论点也许是多余的：这个过程本身是显而易见的。神的名字从神话中消失，动机发生变化（正如我们所见，在比较仪式时，神话的动机已经不同），叙事风格发生变化，神话在童话中重生。

All these cases lead us fully to the fairy tale. It is perhaps superfluous to develop or prove the thesis that the fairy tale goes back to the rite described above: the process itself is evident. From the myths the names of the gods evaporate, the motivations change (as we saw, in the comparison of the rites the motivations of the myths are already different), the style of the narration changes, and the myth is reborn in the fairy tale.

一方面将绑架的母题与相应的神话（宙斯绑架欧罗巴等）进行比较，另一方面将贡品的母题与相应的神话进行比较，我们发现关于绑架的神话并不那么古老。童话故事；在后者中，动物绑架者变成了动物神，但珀尔修斯和安德洛墨达类型的神话比童话故事更古老。由此可见，神话与童话的关系并不总是相同的，这个问题不能像冯特、潘泽尔等人那样一概而论。

If we compare the motif of the abduction with corresponding myths (the abduction of Europa by Zeus, etc.) on the one hand, and the motif of tributes with corresponding myths on the other, we see that the myths of the abduction are less archaic than the fairy tale; in the latter the animal-abductor has been transfigured into an animal-god, but the myth of the Perseus and Andromeda type is older than the fairy tale. From this we see that the relationship between myth and fairy tale is not always the same, and the question cannot be resolved summarily as Wundt, Panzer and many others do.

宗教表现可以产生宗教神话，从中可以发展出已经剥离了任何宗教色彩的童话故事。

Religious representations can produce a religious myth, from which a fairy tale can be developed, already stripped of any religious coloration.

l 这个概念表达得非常清楚和简洁。 M. Tronskij 在研究古典古代神话和我们这个时代的童话故事中，主要致力于波吕斐摩斯的形象：“失去其社会意义的神话变成了童话故事” 476。事实上，珀尔修斯和安德洛墨达的神话与俄罗斯童话完全对应。

This concept is expressed very clearly and briefly by L. M. Tronsky in his study The Myth of Classical Antiquity and the Fairy Tale of Our Time , devoted mainly to the figure of Polyphemus: «The myth that has lost its social significance becomes a fairy tale» 476 . And, in fact, the myth of Perseus and Andromeda corresponds exactly to Russian fairy tales.

我们可以不在这里对这个问题进行更详细的研究，因为它具有普遍性，不能通过引用单一原因来解决。但在提出童话与神话的联系这一论点时，有必要指出神话并不是童话的动力原因。

We need not go into a more detailed examination of the question here, since it is of a general nature and cannot be resolved by citing a single motive. But in presenting the thesis of the connection between the fairy tale and the myth, it must be observed that the myth is not the efficient cause of the fairy tale.

童话也可以直接源自宗教，而不是神话。

The fairy tale can also derive immediately from religion, overlooking the myth.

因此，例如，在希腊神话中，没有龙绑架女孩的情况。这种表现形式能够存在于民间，而没有在希腊文学中找到任何证据，我们通过希腊文学了解了这个神话。他还不如不进入文学界。相反，将女孩交给海怪的做法被保留下来，因为这是一个农业传说，而希腊是一个农业国家，可能在更古老的时期，希腊也庆祝过相应的仪式，但没有在《希腊神话》中得到体现。文学。

Thus, for example, in Greek myth there is no account of the kidnapping of the girl by the dragon. This representation could have existed among the people without any evidence of it being found in Greek literature, through which we know the myth; it could also not have entered literature. Instead, the delivery of the girl to the sea monster has been preserved because it is an agrarian legend and Greece is an agrarian country and it may be that the corresponding rites were also celebrated in Greece in more ancient times, without having been reflected in literature.

然而，有一件事是明确的：同一主题的童话故事和神话不能同时共存。在希腊，还不可能有关于珀尔修斯和安德洛墨达的童话故事，只能有一个神话。在古典时期，童话故事只能在后来才出现。然而，可能存在细菌，特别是在所谓的下层人民中。

One thing, however, is clear: the fairy tale and the myth on the same subject cannot coexist simultaneously. In Greece there could not yet be a fairy tale about Perseus and Andromeda, there could only be a myth. In classical antiquity the fairy tale could appear only later. However, there could have been some germs, and precisely in the so-called lower classes of the people.

你。蛇与死者王国

VI. The Serpent and the Realm of the Dead

29.守护蛇。

29. The Guardian Serpent .

通过研究入会仪式，我们已经看到它们与死者王国中寄居的表现是如何密切相关的。启蒙者经历死亡，反之亦然，死亡是一种启蒙。这向我们解释了为什么后来，当入会仪式已经被遗忘很长一段时间时，下降到死亡领域（katabasis）是英雄化的一个条件，也解释了为什么吞咽者在英雄化的表现中扮演着如此重要的角色。死亡。 。

In studying the rites of initiation we have already seen how closely they are connected with the representation of the sojourn in the realm of the dead. The initiate experiences death and, vice versa, death is a kind of initiation. This explains why later, when initiation had long been forgotten, the descent into the realm of death, the catabasis, is a condition of heroization and also explains why in the representations of death the swallower plays such an important role.

水蛇被想象为池塘、水库、河流、海洋以及陆地上的生物。但这些盆地也是通往另一个领域的入口。通往另一个王国的路要经过蛇的嘴，然后穿过水，先穿过水，然后穿过水。这让我们审视蛇作为守护者的地位。水蛇的守护职责是显而易见的：它站在水边、水里守护着水。但即使是山蛇，最终也不是与高地相连，而是与洞穴相连，因为人们相信，就像盆地一样，洞穴是通往另一个王国的通道。因此，蛇住在山洞里。

The water serpent was imagined as living in ponds and basins, in rivers, in seas and also on land. But these basins also serve as entrances to the other realm. The road to the other realm leads through the serpent's jaws and through the water, first through the water and then on the water. This brings us to consider the serpent as a guardian. The guardianship of the water serpent is obvious: it stands beside the water and in the water and guards it. But the mountain serpent is also connected, ultimately, not with heights but with caves because it was believed that, like the basins, caves were an entrance to the other realm. That is why the serpent lives in caves.

我们可以观察到人们想象中生活在地球水中的蛇是如何开始移动到或多或少令人难以置信的距离的。这种转变与空间表征的出现以及死者旅程表征的出现重新联系起来。原来生活在某些池塘和湖泊中的蛇（以至于人们甚至不敢从它们旁边经过）后来从死者旅程的起点移动到了旅程的终点​​。这种运动可以有两种类型：蛇在精神上向地球内部移动，也就是说，它变成了地狱生物，或者相反，它向天高地转移，变成了天体、太阳和火体。存在。蛇的地底本质更为古老，但这两种现象发生的时间都相对较晚。从广义上讲，我们可以确定永久居住在森林某一点的吞食者（在与世隔绝和与世隔绝的民族中）和在广阔的空间中旅行的吞食者（在达到更高文明程度的民族中，知道运输工具并且不完全依靠狩猎的产品生活），生活在地下的吞食者（原始农业）和生活在天空的吞食者（先进农业，国家）。

We can observe how the serpent that people imagined living in the water on earth, begins to move into a more or less fantastic distance. This displacement is connected with the appearance of spatial representations, with the appearance of representations about the journey of the deceased. The serpent that originally lived in certain ponds and lakes (so much so that people were even afraid to pass by them) later moves from the beginning of the journey of the deceased to the end of this journey. This displacement can be of two kinds: the serpent is mentally moved towards the interior of the earth, that is, it becomes a chthonic being, or on the contrary, it is moved towards the celestial heights and becomes a celestial, solar and fiery being. The chthonic nature of the serpent is older, but both phenomena occur relatively late. In broad outline, it is possible to determine the evolutionary stages of the swallower who resides permanently in one point of the forest (among peoples who live in isolation and seclusion), of the swallower who travels over large spaces (among peoples who have reached a higher level of civilization, know means of transport and do not live exclusively on the products of hunting), of the swallower who lives underground (primitive agriculture) and of the swallower who lives in the sky (advanced agriculture, statehood).

我们将首先检查冥蛇，然后检查太阳蛇。在这两种情况下，我们已经注意到的路线都会发展，即对蛇的敌对行为路线；但值得注意的是，正如对冥府塞伯鲁斯的分析将向我们展示的那样，冥府之蛇在某种程度上仍然是必要和有用的，而天界之蛇始终且只是一个敌人。冥蛇与死者的国度有关。这不是印度的天蛇，他是一条升到天上的水蛇。然而，在埃及，冥蛇似乎是升入天堂的蛇：死者会遇到它。童话故事反映了蛇进化的所有阶段。

We shall first examine the chthonic serpent and then the solar serpent. In both cases the line that we have already noted develops, the line of hostile attitude towards the serpent; but it is to be noted, as the analysis of the chthonic Cerberus will show us, that the chthonic serpent is still to a certain extent necessary and useful while the celestial serpent is always and only an enemy. The chthonic serpent is connected with the realm of the dead. In India the celestial serpent is not such; it is a water serpent raised to the sky. In Egypt, on the other hand, the chthonic serpent seems to be the one that rises to the sky: the deceased meets it. The fairy tale reflects all the stages of the evolution of the serpent.

被吞噬，是与异界沟通的首要条件。但曾经使这种共融成为可能的东西却变成了它的对立面，即变成了到达这个王国必须克服的障碍。吞咽不再被练习，它只是一种威胁。这是这种表征的最后进化阶段，在童话故事中也有所体现。

Being swallowed was the first condition for entering into communion with the other realm. But what once made this communion possible is transformed into its antithesis, that is, into an obstacle that must be overcome to reach this realm. Swallowing is no longer practiced, it is only a threat. This is the last evolutionary stage of this representation, and it too is reflected in the fairy tale.

30.地狱犬。

30. Cerberus .

在尚未建国的民族中，关于冥蛇的材料如此稀缺，这并非巧合。在这些民族中，冥蛇还不存在；水蛇占主导地位，但转移到了很远的地方。在某些民族中，例如贾加人，我们发现了一种从水蛇到冥蛇的明显过渡形式477。

It is no accident that materials on the chthonic serpent are so extraordinarily scarce among peoples who have not yet reached statehood. Among these peoples the chthonic serpent does not yet exist; the water serpent predominates, but transferred to a fantastic remoteness. Among certain peoples, such as the Djagga, we find a clear form of transition from the water serpent to the chthonic one 477 .

但是，正如我们所指出的，死者王国的地下守护者的代表只有在农业民族中才能获得真正的发展。这个守护者的典型代表是刻耳柏洛斯，我们应该把注意力集中在他身上，因为他的形象解释了童话故事中蛇所代表的守护者的角色。

But, as we have noted, the representation of the underground guardian of the kingdom of the dead acquires its true development only among agricultural peoples. A typical representative of this guardian is Cerberus, on whom it will be appropriate to dwell, because his figure explains the role of guardian also represented by the serpent in the fairy tale.

在希腊，盆地、河流、池塘、湖泊是死亡王国的众多入口的说法仍然非常牢固。 “海洋是进入来世王国的第一个入口”，- Ganscinietz 478说，并进一步说：“例如在沼泽中消失并从地下流出的流动的水被认为是进入来世的入口。地下世界，还有矿井隧道？479．居住在那些水域中的生物具有龙或牛的外观。例如，阿克洛斯（Achelous）就是这样的人，他向得伊阿尼拉（Deianira）求婚，然后被赫拉克勒斯（Heracles）杀死。 Cerberus 也属于同一类别。

The idea that the basin, the river, the pond, the lake are all entrances to the realm of the dead still holds very firmly in Greece. "The ocean is the first entrance to the realm of the underworld," says Ganscinietz, 478 and further on: "The running waters which, for example, disappear in marshes and emerge from the ground, were said to be an entrance to the underworld, as were the galleries of mines." 479 The beings who dwelt in these waters had the appearance of dragons or oxen. Such, for example, was Achelous, who asked for Deianira as his wife and was then killed by Heracles. Cerberus also belongs to the same category.

刻耳柏洛斯居住在赫拉克勒斯发现他的阿刻戎河口附近，揭示了他古老的水生本性。在这里，蛇向水中的另一个点（即到达点）的移动尤其明显。在阶级形成之前的社会中，蛇居住在水的源头，即河流的源头，而居住在河流末端的刻耳柏洛斯证实了龙的运动是从离开人间，进入地狱。即使在外表和功能上，他也与我们童话故事中的蛇相似：他有三个狗头，从嘴里流出有毒的粘液，他有一条蛇尾巴，在他的尾巴上有一个头，他用这条尾巴蜇人。

Cerberus reveals his ancient aquatic nature by residing at the mouth of the Acheron, where Heracles finds him. Here the displacement of the serpent to another point in the water, to the point of arrival, is particularly evident. In the society before the formation of classes, the serpent resides at the source of the waters, that is, at the beginning of the river, while Cerberus residing at the end of the river confirms the assumption of the dragon's displacement from the exit from the earth to the entrance into hell. Even externally and functionally he is similar to the serpent of our fairy tale: he has three dog heads, from whose jaws a poisonous slime drips, he has a serpent's tail, on the tail he has a head and with this tail he stings.

双头畸形或双额头部是一个非常古老的特征。这是美国的典型特征，那里的蛇几乎总是在身体的两端都有一个头。这种表述是基于这样的事实：蛇的尾巴感觉或感觉像被蜇，是与多头畸形不同的现象。 Cerberus 将这两个方面结合在一个图中。

Bicephaly or bifrontality of the heads is a very ancient character; it is typical for America, where the snake almost always has a head at both ends of the body. This representation is based on the fact that the tail of the snake is felt or considered as a sting and is a phenomenon different from pluricephaly. Cerberus unites the two aspects in a single figure.

当赫拉克勒斯听从欧律斯透斯的命令，将刻耳柏洛斯带到地面时，他用尾巴蜇了他。地狱犬头和背上的头发和毛发都是由蛇制成的。正如 Küster 指出的那样，Cerberus 以前简称为 Dragon 480。根据赫西奥德（ Theog . 769）的说法，他摇尾巴欢迎新来者，但不会让任何人回去。埃涅阿斯不能进入塔耳塔洛斯，因为塞伯鲁斯不让他通过，为了安抚他，他向他扔了一个魔法咒语，让他睡着了（En ., VI, 419）。将物体扔进守护者的嘴里取代了英雄本人进入怪物的嘴里。在我看来，从这些暗示中可以看出，刻耳柏洛斯高兴地摇着尾巴，让死者进来，却攻击活人，正如我们从《埃涅阿斯纪》中看到的那样。因此，古代蛇作为通道辅助者的作用还没有完全消失，其守护者的作用也尚未完全阐明。刻耳柏洛斯与童话故事中的蛇的不同之处在于他的狗头，这是希腊人添加的，与他作为守护者的职责有关。古典语言学学者会反对，认为向塞伯鲁斯扔奥法的行为纯粹是希腊现象，不能被解释为吞咽的替代品。但即使在童话故事中，英雄也会扔掉五彩纸屑、盐等。到那条想要吞掉他的蛇那里。

When Heracles, obeying Eurystheus' orders, brings Cerberus to the surface, Cerberus stings him with his tail. The hair and fur on Cerberus' head and back are made of snakes. As Küster notes, Cerberus was formerly simply called a dragon . 480 According to Hesiod ( Theog . 769), he wags his tail to welcome the newcomer, but does not let anyone go back. Aeneas cannot enter Tartarus because Cerberus does not let him pass, and to appease him he throws him a magic ointment that puts him to sleep ( En ., VI, 419). This throwing of an object into the mouth of the keeper replaces the hero's own entry into the monster's jaws. It seems to me that from these references it is quite clear that Cerberus lets those who are dead enter, wagging his tail joyfully, but attacks the living, as we see in the Aeneid . Thus the ancient office of the serpent, an auxiliary of the passage, has not entirely disappeared, while its role as guardian is not yet fully developed. Cerberus differs from the serpent of the fable by his dog heads, which are a Greek addition connected with his duties as guardian. Classical philologists will object that the act of throwing the offering to Cerberus is a purely Greek phenomenon and cannot be interpreted as a substitute for swallowing. But even in the fairy tale the hero throws sweets, salt, etc. to the serpent that would swallow him.

根据比较材料对 Cerberus 的这种解释不同于 Dieterich 在他的Nekyia中的解释。迪特里希认为，塞伯鲁斯是大地的化身，在埋葬尸体时，它会吞噬尸体，为此，他提到了塞伯鲁斯吞食尸体的事实。按照他的说法，刻耳柏洛斯是“大地深处，它张开的血盆大口吞下死者，吞噬他们，也就是腐烂肉体，只留下骨头”。在我们看来，吞噬尸体是吞噬的合理化阶段，即死亡。

This interpretation of Cerberus in the light of comparative materials differs from that of Dieterich in his Nekyia . Dieterich believes that Cerberus is the personification of the earth that swallows up the corpses when they are buried and for this purpose he refers to the fact that Cerberus devours a carcass. According to him Cerberus is "the depth of the earth, whose gaping jaws swallow the dead, devour them, that is, they rot the flesh leaving only the bones". In our opinion, this devouring of the carcass is a rationalized phase of devouring, that is, of death.

所有这些材料都足以解释蛇作为遥远王国入口的守护者。

All these materials sufficiently explain the serpent as the guardian of the entrance to the distant realm.

希腊材料非常有趣：它们描绘了水蛇转变为冥蛇以及好蛇转变为坏蛇的进一步阶段。蛇不再吞噬，它只是威胁要吞噬，而且战斗并不总是发生。赫拉克勒斯击败了他，但让他活着。尽管塞伯鲁斯的性格令人厌恶，但他仍然被认为是人类不可或缺的存在。他是哈迪斯的守护者。

The Greek materials are very interesting: they portray a further stage of the transformation of the aquatic serpent into the chthonic one and of the good serpent into the bad one. The serpent no longer devours, it only threatens to devour, and the fight does not always take place. Heracles defeats it, but leaves it alive. Despite all his repugnant characteristics, Cerberus is still felt as a being indispensable to men. He is the guardian of Hades.

31.蛇升天。

31. The serpent moves to heaven .

正如我们提到的，蛇不仅移动到地底深处，而且还移动到天空。然而，我们不可能准确地确定吞食者和水蛇的这种转变发生在社会进化的时间和阶段。

As we have already mentioned, the serpent moves not only into the depths of the earth, but also into the sky. It is not possible, however, to determine exactly when and at what stage of social evolution this displacement of the swallower and the water serpent occurs.

那些了解太阳蛇的民族都比那些不了解太阳蛇的民族更加文明。例如，在澳大利亚大陆，天蛇的形象还不存在。我们在大洋岛屿和非洲，即了解农业基础知识的人们中，发现了它的萌芽状态。我们在亚库蒂人（Iacuti）（即饲养牲畜的民族）中发现了它的一种非常完整的形式。它也在吠陀印度发展起来，但其最明显的形式出现在埃及。

The peoples who know the solar serpent are all more civilized than those who do not know it. The representation of the celestial serpent does not yet exist, for example, on the Australian continent. In an embryonic state we find it on the Oceanic islands and in Africa, that is, among the peoples who know the rudiments of agriculture. In a very complete form we find it among the Yakuts, that is, among a people who practice cattle breeding. It is also developed in Vedic India, but its most marked forms are found in Egypt.

此举产生了许多后果。首先，吞咽的对象发生了变化。蛇不再吞噬人类，它吞噬太阳，并作为太阳吞噬者被杀死。另一方面，有时他自己就是太阳。

This transfer had a number of consequences. First of all, the object of swallowing changed. The serpent no longer swallows men, it swallows the sun and is killed as a swallower of the sun. On the other hand, sometimes it is the sun itself.

第二个结果：他从地上水域的管理者转变为天界水域的管理者：他显现为阻挡水、雨水的云。杀死蛇就会下雨。

Second consequence: from administrator of the earthly waters he converts into administrator of the celestial waters: he appears as a cloud that holds back the water, the rain. The killing of the serpent causes the rain.

第三个结果：在死者的太阳区域的表征特别发达的地方，在人们的生活中占有重要地位的地方，蛇就成为守护死者天国的存在。埃及为我们提供了一个典型的例子。

Third consequence: where representations of the solar region of the dead are particularly developed, where they play an important role in the life of the people, the serpent becomes a being that guards the celestial abodes of the dead. The typical example is offered to us by Egypt.

最后，这是这种转移的第四个结果：所有围绕蛇的人和蛇本身都呈现出火热的性质和颜色。这条河成为生者领域和死者领域之间的边界，并与此一起成为一条炽热的河流；甚至连湖也变成火岩，蛇本身也变成火岩。

And finally, here is the fourth consequence of this transfer: all those who surround the serpent and the serpent itself take on a fiery nature and color. The river becomes the boundary between the realm of the living and that of the dead and with that becomes a fiery river; the lake also becomes fiery, and the serpent itself becomes fiery.

作为吞咽蛇神话的萌芽状态的一个例子，我们可以指出在佩利群岛的广泛信仰，根据这种信仰，“太阳之屋位于海面上方的西方，那里生长着登格斯树，形成了该国海岸有茂密的森林。当傍晚太阳接近树时，它会摇动树枝上的果实并将它们扔进海里；守卫这片太阳土地入口的鲨鱼贪婪地潜入水果中，没有注意到太阳已经淹没到它的家了。”在这里，我们看到了后来在农业民族中发展起来的想法的种子，根据这个想法，蛇是太阳的吞噬者。太阳神话的支持者认为这种表现非常古老和原始。这是不正确的：对于猎人来说，太阳的重要性微乎其微。

As an example of the embryonic state of the myth of the swallowing serpent we may point to the belief widespread in the Pelée Islands according to which "the house of the sun is in the west above the sea, where grows the denges tree which forms dense forests on the coasts of that country. When in the evening the sun approaches the tree, it shakes the fruit which grows on the branches and throws it into the sea; the sharks which guard the entrance to this solar land greedily pounce on the fruit and do not notice that the sun has submerged itself in order to reach its home." Here we have the germs of the idea which developed later among agricultural peoples, according to which the serpent is the swallower of the sun. The supporters of solar mythology consider this idea to be very old, primitive. This is not true: among hunters the sun has very little importance.

毛伊岛的神话也有同样的表现。毛伊岛是天与地交汇的地方；在那儿，祖先奇内努伊·特波张开了可怕的嘴巴。毛伊想杀了她；他警告鸟儿，他的旅伴，当他进入他的嘴时不要笑。如果他们笑，他就会死，如果他们不笑，怪物就会灭亡。小鸟提瓦卡瓦卡笑了，怪物醒了，毛伊死了。如果他成功杀死了他，这些人就不会再死了481。

The same representation is found in the myth of Maui. Maui goes to where heaven and earth meet; there the fearful jaws of the progenitor Chinenui-te-po open. Maui wants to kill her; he warns the birds, his traveling companions, not to laugh while he enters her jaws. If they laugh he will die, if they do not laugh the monster will perish. The little bird Tivakavaka begins to laugh, the monster wakes up and Maui dies. If he had succeeded in killing it, men would no longer be dead . 481

我们在其他地方研究过大米禁令482。在这里，我们想分别研究以下元素：张开的下巴从地面到地平线的转移以及与死亡表征的联系。对于生活在盆地中并吞噬行人的蛇来说，这种情况是晚期的，而对于埃及蛇来说，它是原始的、胚胎的，埃及蛇在死者走向太阳、走向拉哈的旅程中威胁要吞噬死者。神话的这种短暂性特征与人们从狩猎过渡到农业的短暂性特征相对应。

Elsewhere we have studied the prohibition of laughter 482 . Here we would like to study the following elements separately: the transfer of the gaping jaws from the earth to the horizon and the connection with the representation of death. This case is late in comparison with the serpent that lives in basins and swallows travellers, and it is primitive, embryonic, in comparison with the Egyptian serpent, which threatens to devour the deceased during its journey towards the sun, towards Rha. This transitory character of the myth corresponds to the transitory character of the people who pass from hunting to agriculture.

蛇作为太阳吞噬者的形象在印度吠陀中得到了明确的发展。因此，蛇代表着双重角色：一方面，它是陆地生物，并且阻止河流流动，正如我们已经说过的，这是它最古老的形式。另一方面，它就像仙人一样，挡住了雨水，同时也通过吞噬来挡住太阳的辐射。

The representation of the serpent as a swallower of the sun is clearly developed in Vedic India. Accordingly, the serpent plays a double role: on the one hand, it is an earthly being and holds back the flow of rivers, as we have already said, and this is its most ancient form. On the other hand, as a celestial being, it holds back the rain, but it also holds back the radiation of the sun by swallowing it.

梨俱吠陀I-32,4。 “当你，因陀罗，杀死​​了原始巨蛇并摧毁了坏巫师的迷惑艺术时，你就没有敌人了，因为你发现了太阳、天空和黎明。”

Rigveda I-32,4. « When you, Indra, killed the primeval serpent and destroyed the enchanting arts of the evil sorcerers, then you had no enemies, because you discovered the sun, the sky, the dawn ».

I-52,4。 “当你用与白马结合的精神力量杀死弗利多之后，因陀罗啊，你将太阳举在天空中，让所有人都看到。”

I-52,4. « After you killed Vritra with the strength of the spirit in union with the white horses, O Indra, you held the sun in the sky, so that all might see it ».

II-19.3。 “这位强大的因陀罗掀起了汹涌的波浪，平静了大海，并与蛇战斗，使太阳可见。”

II-19,3. « This mighty Indra raised the troubled waves, settled the sea, and, fighting against the serpent, made the sun visible ».

在这些情况下，我们谈论的不是蛇，而是因陀罗杀死了蛇，从而释放了太阳并将其展示给人类。蛇的本性退居次要地位，在前台我们看到的是胜利的蛇神。

In these cases, it is not so much the serpent that is spoken of as Indra who killed the serpent and thus freed the sun and showed it to humanity. The nature of the serpent itself takes a back seat; in the foreground we have the god who conquered the serpent.

因陀罗借助马杀死蛇的细节很有趣。印度是马匹繁育的经典之地，也是马匹训练艺术的发源地。在这里，吞噬太阳的蛇的本性非常明显。

The detail of Indra killing the serpent already availing himself of the help of the horse is interesting. India is the classical land of horse breeding, it is the homeland of the art of training them. Here the nature of the serpent, swallower of the sun, is very evident.

老实说，蛇在童话故事中以完全相同的方式出现，尽管很少见。 “在伊凡居住的王国里，没有白天，总是黑夜”（Af. 75）。 “他们杀了那条蛇，取下它的头，把它固定在女巫的小屋上，然后把它撕成碎片，光明出现在整个王国”（同上）。杀死蛇导致降雨的说法（“杀死蛇后，因陀罗从天上降下创造生命的水”）在童话故事中没有反映。

In the fairy tale the serpent appears in exactly the same way, although rarely, to be honest. "In the kingdom where Ivan lived there was no day, it was always night" (Af. 75). "They killed that serpent, took its head and, having attached it to the hut of the witch, tore it to pieces and light appeared throughout the kingdom" ( Ibid .). The representation according to which the killing of the serpent causes rain ("after killing the serpent, Indra sends down from the sky the life-giving water") has no reflection in the fairy tale.

蛇身上发生的变化是很容易解释的。如果说没有技术手段的猎人首先需要的是驾驭动物意志的力量，那么按照自己的意愿来统治动物的饲养员则根本没有这样的愿望；他需要阳光、雨水和河流，《梨俱吠陀》忠实地反映了这些利益。

The change that has taken place in the serpent is quite explicable. If the hunter without technical means needed first of all power over the will of the animal, the cattle breeder who governed the animals according to his will knew no such aspiration at all; he needed the sun, the rain and the rivers, and the Rigveda faithfully reflects these interests.

这些考虑表明神话学家认为吠陀宗教是最古老的宗教形式是错误的。吠陀印度是一个种姓国家，其宗教是一种晚期的祭司宗教，然而，它反映了从其他更原始和更古老的表现形式发展而来的大众表现形式。

These considerations demonstrate how mistaken were the mythologists for whom Vedic religion would be the most ancient form of religion. Vedic India is a caste state, its religion is late, priestly, which however reflects popular representations developed from other more primitive and more ancient representations.

32、天蛇担任守护者的角色；亚库蒂.

32. The celestial serpent in the role of guardian; the Yakuts .

在印度，蛇作为守护者的地位已经完全消失：它只是一种水生生物。

In India the serpent as a guardian has been completely lost: it is only an aquatic being.

为了研究以天蛇为代表的守护者的角色，我们将转向印度更原始的民族，他们为这位边疆的天体守护者提供了非常清晰的形象：我们想谈谈亚库蒂人。这是一个饲养牲畜，特别是牛和马的民族，但他们还没有广泛发展的祭司种姓，他们没有文学，而将神推到前台的祭司自负还没有玷污他们的形象。蛇的。

In order to study the role of guardian represented by the celestial serpent, we will turn to a more primitive people of India, who offer a very clear image of this celestial guardian of the frontiers: we want to speak of the Yakuts. They are a people who breed livestock, especially cattle and horses, but they do not yet have a widely developed priestly caste, they have no literature, and the priestly pedantry, which pushes the gods to the fore, has not yet obscured the image of the serpent.

在 Iacuti 中，蛇的形象非常清晰，而且异常丰富和有趣。表现形式并不是赞美诗的形式，而是神话的叙事形式，在形式上与童话故事非常接近。在亚库蒂神话中，两个领域有着明显的对比，蛇统治着与人类领域隔着一条河的领域。 « 他驰骋了不知多久，突然气势汹汹地爬上了一座高山；当他到达天地交接处，距离另一边的圣地（即人类）与魔地的边界时，一股致命的火焰伴随着巨大的轰鸣而来。 ，谁爬行嘶嘶； 15俄里外，各种爬行动物和蠕虫正在爬行，完全覆盖了地面” 483。

Among the Yakuts the figure of the serpent is very clear and extraordinarily rich and interesting. The representation does not take the form of a hymn, but the narrative form of a myth, which in form is so close to a fairy tale. In the Yakut myths two realms are clearly opposed, and the serpent reigns in the one that is separated from the realm of men by a river. "He galloped I know not how far, and suddenly he rushed up a high mountain; when he came to where heaven and earth meet, where is the boundary between the holy (i.e. human) land and that of the devils, on the other side, a day and a half's journey away, a deadly fire advanced with a great roar, which crawled and hissed; at a distance of 15 versts crawled reptiles, worms of all kinds, which completely covered the ground . " 483

这个案例很有趣，因为蛇和爬行动物不仅仅存在于天空中，而且存在于“圣地的边界”；因此，我们将蛇转移到死者的超凡领域。

This case is interesting because serpents and reptiles are not simply found in heaven, but there "where the border of the sacred land is"; we therefore have the transfer of the serpent to the supernal realm of the dead.

在印度，我们既没有遇到天河，也没有遇到火湖；在 Jacuti 中，我们两者皆有。在这方面，我们可以观察到这个湖，曾经是蛇的家园，在具体意义上是人们不敢经过它的标志，当它升入天空时，它是如何呈现出太阳的颜色的。 « 飞了足够长的距离后，他（英雄）飞过一片熊熊燃烧的大海，然后降落在埃克休丘海岸的一座冰冻山峰上。到达那里后，过了一段时间，Eksiukiu 从南方吵闹地飞来，雷鸣般，模糊不清，爪子里抓着什么东西» 484。

In India we do not encounter either the celestial river or the fiery lake; among the Yakuts we find both. In this connection it may be noted how the lake, once the abode of the serpent in the concrete sense, so that people were afraid to pass by it, by moving to the sky takes on the color of the sun. "After having flown for quite a long time, he (the hero) flew over a flaming and burning sea, then he lowered himself to the shore of Eksiukiu, on an icy peak. Having arrived there, after some time from the south Eksiukiu came flying noisily, thunderous, darkening, and holding something in his claws" 484 .

这条蛇与死者有联系：“所以他活了一段时间，有一天早上，照亮他的天空没有像平常那样亮起来，他的太阳也没有像平常那样升起。当他沉思地坐在那里，对这个事实感到恐惧、恐惧时，突然，大地受到了巨大漩涡的攻击，攻击者是一个像一岁黑牛犊那么大的恶魔。他把所有干土都举起来，就像举起头发一样，使之像翅膀一样旋转；雨夹雪，暴风雨爆发，红色的火焰开始闪烁。随后一大片黑色云朵冲天而起，似乎有手有脚。有一天晚上，午夜时分，似乎乌云破灭，天摇地动。发出巨大的噪音，就好像它的拱顶被分成两半，好像有什么东西撞击地板，声音比任何其他噪音都大。” （怪物的详细描述如下，铁头发，肿眼睛，装备铃铛和棍子）。 « 我是来带你走的。不管你愿不愿意，我都会带你走。我姑姑叫你，太阳之王的女儿，女巫凯格贾里克（她慢慢地转身）……上你的灵马，穿上你的死衣服，吃你的葬礼食物……来吧，我们走吧。”英雄辱骂他，骂他是“飞云虫”，打了他一下，太阳就出现了，天亮了。与此同时，一条河流出现，“在营地的地方形成了一股大流水” 485。

This serpent has a connection with the dead: « Thus he lived for a while, and one morning the sky that illuminated him did not brighten at the usual hour, his sun did not rise at the usual hour. While he was sitting there, lost in thought, frightened, terrified by this fact, suddenly the earth was attacked by a tremendous whirlwind, by a demon, as big as black yearling calves. He lifted up all the dry earth as if it were hair, and made it whirl like a wing; rain fell mixed with snow, a storm broke out, red flaming fires began to flash. Then a great black cloud rose into the sky, and it seemed as if it had hands and feet. And one night, just at midnight, it seemed as if the clouds were rent or the sky was shaking; there was a great crash as if its vault were split in two, and as if something was hitting its floor louder than any other noise. » (The detailed description of the monster follows, with iron hair, swollen eyes, equipped with bells and a staff.) « I have come to take you away. Whether you like it or not I will take you away. My aunt, daughter of the lord of the sun, the sorceress Kegjallik (she who turns slowly) calls you… Mount your funeral horse, put on your dead man's clothes, eat your funeral food… Come on, let's go ». The hero insults him, calls him « a flying cloud worm », strikes him and the sun appears, the sky brightens. At the same time a river appears and « in place of the field a wide flowing water has formed » 485 .

这个案例以罕见的完整性向我们展示了一条蛇的形象，它既是吞噬太阳的天蛇，也是阻挡河流的陆地蛇，还有将人类送往死亡王国的绑架蛇。

This case shows us with rare completeness in the image of a single serpent both the celestial serpent, swallowing the sun, the terrestrial one that holds back the rivers and also the abducting serpent that transports man to the realm of the dead.

然而，作为太阳死者王国的守护者的巨蛇在这里仍然发育不良。只有随着农业的进步，太阳死亡王国的蛇才能完全发展，具有观察太阳的能力，依赖太阳，依赖它的季节回归和收获。这些条件在吠陀印度、雅库特人或非洲养牛人中都不存在。然而，它们存在于古埃及，古埃及可能为我们提供了除了降雨蛇之外最完整的蛇形态，因为在埃及，收成并不取决于雨水，而是取决于尼罗河的洪水季节。 。

But the serpent as the guardian of the solar realm of the dead is still little developed here. The serpent of the solar realm of the dead reaches its full development only with the advance of agriculture, with the ability to observe the sun, with dependence on the sun, on its seasonal return and on the harvest. These conditions do not exist in Vedic India, nor among the cattle-breeding Yakuts or Africans. They do exist in ancient Egypt, and ancient Egypt offers us perhaps the most complete form of the serpent, except that of the rain-giving serpent, for in Egypt the harvest does not depend on rain, but on the seasonal flooding of the Nile.

埃及宗教也缺乏水域的蛇守护者，而且该湖已经完全是火成湖了。只有蛇，太阳的敌人和死者王国的守护者，这是致力于农业的先进民族的特有概念。相反，在《梨俱吠陀》中，蛇完全是一种水生生物（陆地和天体），并且缺少死亡王国，就像缺少旅行和运动一样。吠陀经是一个致力于养牛的民族的创造。根据路德维希的说法，《梨俱吠陀》中从未遇到过“小麦”这个词。因此，不可能有太阳的宗教，也不可能观察到太阳的运动和太阳回归的不变性。

In the Egyptian religion, the serpent guardian of the waters is also missing and the lake is already exclusively fiery. There is only the serpent enemy of the sun and guardian of the realm of the dead, a characteristic conception of a progressive people dedicated to agriculture. On the contrary, in the Rigveda the serpent is exclusively an aquatic being (terrestrial and celestial) and the realm of the dead is missing, as are travel and movement. The Vedas are the creation of a people dedicated to cattle breeding. According to Ludwig, the word "grain" is never found in the Rigveda . For this reason there could not have been a religion of the sun, nor the observation of its movement and the invariability of its return.

尽管埃及的表现在连贯性和统一性方面均不出色，但可以说埃及人想象的是死者王国中的一艘船上的太阳落山。死者自己变成了太阳。因此，太阳的吞噬者（被吞噬是一种永久的威胁，但从未付诸行动）同时也是到达死者王国的死者的吞噬者。吞噬从未发生，而只是一种威胁，因为新来者凭借其魔法武器降落并杀死了巨蛇阿波菲斯，从而进入了应许的王国。

Although the Egyptian representations are not outstanding for their coherence or their uniformity, it can nevertheless be said that the Egyptians imagined the sun descending in a little ship into the realm of the dead. The dead man himself became the sun. Thus the devourer of the sun (being devoured is a permanent threat which, however, is never carried out) is at the same time the devourer of the dead who comes to the realm of the dead. The devouring never occurs and is only a threat, because the newcomer knocks down and kills the serpent Apophis with his magical armament, and thus enters the promised realm.

33.埃及的蛇。

33. The Serpent in Egypt .

在与蛇决斗的各种形式中（在原始民族中、在《梨俱吠陀》中、在古典时期、在埃及、中国），俄罗斯童话在内容和细节上与埃及童话有着最接近的相似之处（除了蛇的形象）。马）在《亡灵书》中描述。这并不意味着埃及是俄罗斯童话的故乡，也不意味着这一主题从埃及传到了欧洲。它的含义完全不同，即童话反映了这种晚期的农业神话概念。正是在这个阶段之后，在多元化和多样性的意义上，解体开始了，本地邪教的多元化（例如我们在希腊发现的九头蛇、蛇发女妖、美杜莎、蟒蛇）开始解体。 、勒奈蛇、拉冬、塞伯鲁斯等）。典型性让位给个性化，另一方面，发生了化石化，或者更准确地说，是僵化，骨骼被创造出来，几个世纪以来都保持完整，并被完全不同的形态的活生生的肉体所覆盖，仙女的活生生的肉体故事。鉴于这一事实，我们必须对埃及材料多花一些时间。
