Despite all the specific and peculiar characteristics of each people, one can detect very clear common traits that are also found in the fairy tale. First of all, as we have said, the old representations do not disappear, but continue to exist and new ones are stratified upon them. So far we have seen that peoples attribute to the kingdom of the afterlife the life and forms of production of the material existence that they know. The world of the afterlife repeats this world; the hunter populates it with animals, the horticulturist with gardens. But with the transition to agriculture this process is interrupted. In the other world one does not plow, sow or reap. And even in the distant kingdom of the fairy tale no agricultural work is ever carried out. The animals, the gardens, the islands have been preserved in all religions, but a new element has appeared: the deities who bestow fertility have appeared. As we have seen, traces of these deities have also been preserved in the fairy tale. And this is the first observation. Now here is the second: in Egypt the solar conception of the other realm reaches its full development, gradually evolving and assuming symbolic forms. The oldest pyramids "still lie almost entirely within the orbit of the religion of Rha and the solar-celestial abode of the dead, the later ones turn more and more towards Osiris." 508 We will not stop to study the Egyptian representations in detail. In our opinion they essentially contain three strata: the animal, the horticultural and the solar-agricultural, markedly monarchical. It is known that the other world is full of animals and that the Egyptians could not explain the motives of the animal cult to Herodotus, who could not explain it either. Trees and gardens were also an essential part of this belief. Breasted says of this: "One of the most important resources, if not perhaps the most important of the many resources by which the Pharaoh hoped to maintain himself in the kingdom of Rha, was the tree of life on the mysterious island in the midst of the Field of Offerings; he went in search of it accompanied by the morning star." 509. Incidentally, this morning star is also at the same time a green falcon. And this is what the coconut tree, which perpetually drops its fruit, has transformed into under agrarianism: this palm is hypostatized into the tree of life that grows in the realm of the dead. Whoever reaches this tree achieves immortality. The old ideas that a stay in the other realm confers magical power and that whoever succeeds in returning becomes a magician and an enchanter, do not die. "The magic crystal" that we encountered in America is not forgotten. But "the crystal mountain" or "the crystal rain" here takes the form of the "crystal sky", already deprived of its magical functions. "Ptah has covered his sky with crystal" ( Book of the Dead , XIV). For the first time in the history of the world, the magical function passes to another object, full of mystery and power, namely, to the book. Egypt was the first to create the "fairy book" which in the fairy tale is also found in the hands of the princess or her father. These representations predominate both in the official religion of the court and the priests and among the people, who tell wonderful stories of the way in which this book was brought from the realm of the dead. Reitzenstein says: "Let us cast another glance at the representation of the island of the dead, guarded by an enormous serpent. It is not essential for us whether fantasy places it downstream of the river, as for example in the delta, or upstream... or in the Red Sea, it matters little whether that island is one or whether there are many, as in the subdivision of the Book of the Dead . What is most important is the conferring of the fairy-tale form precisely to these representations which are repeated in a series of prophetic and magical tales. The basis of these is the purely Egyptian idea that whoever wants to acquire the highest knowledge and with it the highest power must become a god, and he becomes one by means of a wandering through the world of the dead or through the sky. This "purely Egyptian idea" is already known to us from Australian and American materials and also forms the basis of the fairy tale. The "tales" to which the author refers are the story of the adventures of Satna-Chamoens with the mummies, and the story of his shipwreck . 510

还需要提及黄金在埃及葬礼崇拜中的重要性。因此，例如，在挽回经文中提到了“金屋”。巴奇解释说，这些是“石棺，或者也许是墓穴的前室，甚至可能是墓穴前面的地方”。 “黄金屋的大厅”将是地下室的主要房间。因此，墓穴被认为是由黄金511制成的。

It is also necessary to mention the importance of gold in the Egyptian funerary cult. Thus, for example, in the propitiatory texts a "golden house" is mentioned. Budge explains that it refers to the "sarcophagi or, perhaps, the front room of the crypt, or perhaps also the place in front of the crypt". The "halls of the golden house" would be the main room of the crypt. Therefore the crypt was imagined to be made of gold 511 .

即使在亚述，我们也有同样的多重分层。我们将只关注对理解童话故事很重要的材料。巴比伦引入的新元素是城市的代表，而且是要塞城市的代表。 « 尽管保留了来世世界古老而原始的表现形式，但已经达到较高文明水平的亚述人将一些特征转移到了来世王国：他们想象它是一座大城市的形式，巨大的宫殿是死者王国的女神阿拉图居住的地方。七堵墙围绕着这座巨大的监狱，死者被剥夺了光明，生活在其中” 512。巴比伦风格的花园显得更加古老。经过二十四小时的朝圣，吉尔伽美什到达了大海，神女坐在海中王座上，旁边有一个美丽的花园，里面长满了神树，其中一棵特别引起了吉尔伽美什的热情，他很快就接近了他。 «它的果实是Samtu石头，它的顶峰产生晶体，它结出的果实看起来很美丽» 513。我们已经知道，这里的晶体生长在树上，但即使是最古老的兽形表征也没有被遗忘，然而，这些表征并没有随着埃及的多样性而保存下来。我们已经注意到，死者王国的居民像鸟一样浑身覆盖着羽毛。

In Assyria we also have the same multiple stratification. We will only dwell on the materials that are important for understanding the fairy tale. The new element introduced by Babylon is the representation of the city and moreover of the fortress city. "Although they had retained the old and primitive representations of the world of the underworld, the Assyrians, who had reached a high level of civilization, transferred some of their characteristics to the kingdom of the underworld: they imagine it in the form of a great city with an immense palace in which lives the goddess Allatu, mistress of the kingdom of the dead. Seven walls surround that vast prison in which the dead, deprived of light, are kept." 512 The Babylonian representation of the garden appears to be older. After a pilgrimage of twenty-four hours Gilgamesh arrives at the sea where the divine girl sits on the sea throne, next to a marvelous garden with divine trees, one of which particularly arouses the enthusiasm of Gilgamesh who hastens to approach it. "Its fruits are the Samtu stones, its summit produces crystals, it bears fruits beautiful to look at." 513 Here the crystals, which we already know, grow on the trees, but the most ancient theriomorphic representations are not forgotten either, which, however, have not been preserved with the multiformity of Egypt. We have already noted that the inhabitants of the kingdom of the dead are covered with feathers like birds.

11.古典古代。

11. Classical antiquity .

到目前为止，我们已经研究了个别案例的材料，从最先出现的案例开始，到后来出现的案例结束。我们将研究又一个复杂而复杂的表征的例子，而不将它们分成各自的组成部分，为此我们将选择古典。我们将看到这些再现的个别元素也出现在童话故事中，这将是支持童话再现的历史性的又一论据。不仅每个元素都有其自身的历史性，而且它们的色彩对比、逻辑上的不相容性和矛盾性也是历史性的。

So far we have studied our material in individual cases, beginning with those that appeared earlier and ending with those that appeared later. We will study one more example of complex and complicated representations, without separating them into their constituent parts, and for this purpose we will choose classical antiquity. We will see that the individual elements of these representations are also found in fairy tales, and this will be one more argument in favor of the historicity of fairy tale representations. Not only is each element taken by itself historical, but also the contrast of their hues, their logical incompatibility and their contradiction.

希腊代表的多样性近乎混乱。到目前为止，它们还没有成为严格的、基于历史的研究的主题。这种混乱多次助长了古代怀疑精神的讽刺，在这方面，记住阿里斯托芬的《青蛙》就足够了，其中代表了一个绝对不可能的来世世界，由舵手卡戎;那些根据青蛙的叫声有节奏地摆渡的人。拉德马赫试图从喜剧中排除这个世界的确切地形及其所有的荒谬514。在希腊的描述中，民俗学家发现了一些对他来说是新鲜的东西：有山脉，即奥林匹斯山，有地下王国，即哈迪斯，有受祝福的岛屿和波塞冬的水下王国，还有花园赫斯珀里得斯与金苹果。谈到格鲁佩时，拉德马赫认为苹果的金色证明了赫斯珀里得斯的花园曾经位于地下；他个人倾向于相信，在这种情况下，黄金是巨额财富的象征515。根据我们的比较材料，这两种解释都是不正确的。我们必须考虑另一个得到证实的观点，即迪特里希的观点：“人们总是认为花园与太阳和太阳神有关；人们总是认为花园与太阳和太阳神有关。”它位于太阳升起的地方，或者根据更广泛的说法，位于太阳落下的地方，即在遥远的西方” 516。

The multiformity of Greek representations borders on chaos; up to now they have not been the object of a rigorous historically grounded study. This chaos has often fed the irony of the skeptical spirits of antiquity, and it is enough to recall in this connection Aristophanes' The Frogs , in which an absolutely impossible world of the afterlife is represented, with the helmsman Charon; the ferrymen row in cadence according to the croaking of the frogs. Radermacher has tried to exclude from comedy the exact topography of this world and all its absurdity . 514 In Greek representations the folklorist finds little that is new to him: there are the mountains, that is, Olympus, there is the subterranean kingdom, that is, Hades, there are the islands of the blessed and the underwater kingdom of Poseidon, and the garden of the Hesperides with the golden apples. Referring to Gruppe, Radermacher believes that the golden color of the apples proves that the Garden of the Hesperides was once underground; he is personally inclined to believe that in this case the gold is an indication of fabulous wealth . 515 In the light of our comparative materials, both explanations are erroneous. We must consider another opinion confirmed, namely that of Dieterich: "The garden is always thought of in connection with the sun and the sun god; it was located at the point where the sun rises, or, according to more widespread representations, at the point where it sets, that is, in the extreme West . " 516

这种多元化本身就已经是一种颓废、瓦解的原则，而这种瓦解为童话的诞生创造了有利的土壤。赫拉克勒斯得到赫斯珀里得斯的苹果的整个神话与返老还童的苹果的童话故事非常接近，事实上，童话故事更加古老，保留了苹果的神奇功效，而在赫拉克勒斯的神话中，他们都是一种“稀有”。人们不能不注意到一些希腊表现形式的美丽和生动的魅力。希腊人也许是第一个将音乐引入另一个世界的人，不是笛子和鼓的神奇音乐，而是普通的人类音乐，这种创新随后传播到整个欧洲，从阿伦卡的小花到音乐家天使他们在玛丽脚边拉中提琴和吹小号。 Dieterich 517说，死亡之岛充满了声音。在那座城市里，“大多数居民都会演奏竖琴……即使在卢西恩的祝福之岛上，也可以听到弦乐器和长笛的演奏，可以听到歌曲，甚至可以听到被风吹动的树叶，轻声吟唱赞美诗……守护花园的赫斯珀里得斯自古以来就被称为闪亮的眼睛、歌手。”此时我们想起了童话故事中的“唱歌树”（Af.166）。

This plurality is in itself a principle of decadence, of disintegration, and this disintegration creates a favorable terrain for the birth of the fairy tale. The whole myth of Heracles who procures the apples of the Hesperides is very close to the tale of the apples that rejuvenate; indeed, the tale is even more archaic, having preserved the magical effect of the apples, while in the myth of Hercules they are a kind of "rarity." One cannot fail to note the beauty and lively charm of some Greek representations. The Greeks were perhaps the first to introduce music into the other world, and not the magical music of flutes and drums, but ordinary human music, and this innovation then spread throughout Europe, from Alenka's Little Flower to the musician angels who play the viola and the trumpet at Mary's feet. The island of the dead is full of sounds, says Dieterich 517 . In that city "most of the inhabitants play the lyre... Even in Lucian's island of the blessed, one can hear the playing of stringed instruments, flutes, one can hear songs and even the leaves of the trees, moved by the wind, whisper hymns... The Hesperides, who guard the garden, have been called the bright-eyed, the singers since time immemorial". At this point we are reminded of the "singing tree" of our fairy tales (Af. 166).

从整个希腊表现形式中，我们只会分离出一个细节：金色。说到这里，我首先想到的是赫利俄斯宫殿：它被描述为矗立在美丽的柱子上，闪烁着黄金和宝石的光芒。它的顶部覆盖着象牙，门闪闪发光。有趣的是，这座宫殿像俄罗斯童话故事中一样矗立在柱子上。显然，它们是支撑天穹的柱子：我们记得赫拉克勒斯将天球扛在肩上。正如迪特里希所观察到的，赫利俄斯的整个血统“很容易通过从脸上放射出金色光芒的眼睛的光彩来识别”。当然这已经是后来的合理化了。这种金色是众神、死者和入会者所固有的。作为他的启蒙和神性的证明，毕达哥拉斯声称拥有金色的四肢，并且在必要时还展示了金色的大腿518。在这方面，我们的英雄浮现在脑海中“金腿到膝盖，银臂到肘部”（Af.159）。金色的面容、金色的皇冠、灵气、光环，这一切，都源自这里。这也解释了为什么黄金不仅在希腊而且在其他国家也被用于死者崇拜。例如，道生主义者声称，吞下黄金或珍珠的人不仅可以延长寿命，而且可以保证死后身体的存在，防止其腐烂。斯滕伯格指出，中国人把金子放进了死去的人嘴里519。回到古典时代，我们记得罗马皇帝在脸上撒上金粉520；这也解释了迈锡尼的金色葬礼面具。在中国，黄金被放入每个人的嘴里，而在罗马，皇帝将金粉撒在脸上，这一事实表明这些表现形式发生了演变。我们已经在希腊找到了正义与不诚实世界的代表。黄金是只有正义之人的遗产。因此，在《启示录》中，死者之地被详细描述为黄金城521。

From the whole complex of Greek representations we will single out only one detail: the golden color. In this connection the memory of the palace of Helios comes to mind first: it is described as rising on beautiful columns, shining with gold and precious stones. Its tops are covered with ivory, the doors shine with silver. It is interesting that the palace stands on columns just as in the Russian fairy tale. Evidently it is the columns that support the celestial vault: we remember Heracles carrying the celestial sphere on his shoulders. The whole lineage of Helios, as Dieterich observes, "is easily recognized by the splendor of the eyes that radiates from the face like a ray of gold." Naturally this is already a later rationalization. This golden color is inherent in the gods, the dead and the initiated. As proof of his initiation and his divinity Pythagoras claimed to have golden extremities and also showed, when necessary, a golden thigh . 518 In this connection we are reminded of our hero "with legs of gold up to the knee, with arms of silver up to the elbow" (Af. 159). The golden face, the golden crown, the halo, the halo, all have their origins here. And this also explains why gold was used in the cult in suffrage of the dead not only in Greece but also in other countries. Thus, for example, the Daosistes affirm that whoever swallows gold or pearls not only prolongs his life but also guarantees the existence of the body after death, protecting it from decomposition. Sternberg points out that the Chinese put gold in the mouths of their dead . 519 To return to classical antiquity, we recall that the Roman emperors sprinkled their faces with gold dust . 520 This also explains the golden funeral masks of Mycenae. The fact that in China gold is put in everyone's mouth, while in Rome the emperors sprinkle their faces with gold dust indicates the evolution that has taken place in such representations. Already in Greece we find representations of the world of the just and the dishonest. Gold is the patrimony of the just alone. Thus, in the Apocalypse the place of the dead is minutely described as a golden city 521 .

这一切都足以说明人们对稀有金器的渴望从何而来。它们是失去了作为来自另一个世界的东西并确保长寿和不朽的神奇功能的物体。然而，苹果保留了这种功能，而各种“金毛鸭”却失去了它。

All this explains sufficiently where the motive for the desire to possess rare gold objects comes from. These are objects that have lost their magical function as things from the other world and ensuring longevity and immortality. Apples, on the other hand, have retained this function, while the various "golden-crested ducks" have lost it.

因此，我们看到童话故事保留了对遥远王国的表征的各个层次和各种沉积物：在其中我们还发现了与狩猎有关的最古老的元素，与原始和更先进的农业有关的元素，以及与狩猎有关的元素。相应形式的社会制度和习俗。

We see, therefore, that the fairy tale has preserved the various layers, the various sediments of the representations of the distant kingdom: in it we also find the most ancient elements pertaining to hunting, those pertaining to primitive and more advanced agriculture, as well as the corresponding forms of the social regime and customs.

第九章 新娘

Chapter NineThe Bride

一、公主的印章

I. The Princess's Seal

1.公主的两种类型。

1. The two types of princess .

那些把童话里的公主想象成“美丽的女孩”、“无价之宝”、“无法用童话来讲述、无法用笔来描述”的人是在自欺欺人。一方面，她实际上是一位忠实的未婚妻，等待着她的未婚夫，并拒绝所有在未婚夫不在的情况下向她求婚的人。但另一方面，她又是一个阴险、复仇心强、邪恶的存在，随时准备杀死、淹死、残害、抢劫她的未婚夫，而成功或几乎成功占有她的英雄的基本任务是来驯服她。他用一种非常简单的方式做到了这一点：他用三种棍子殴打她，直到她死了而不是活了，之后幸福就来了。

Those who imagine the princess of the fairy tale only as "a very beautiful girl", a "priceless beauty", such that "she cannot be told in a fairy tale or described with a pen" are mistaken. On the one hand, she is, in truth, a faithful bride who awaits her betrothed and refuses all those who solicit her hand in the absence of her fiancé. But on the other hand, she is an insidious, vengeful and evil being, always ready to kill, drown, maim, rob her fiancé, and the essential task of the hero who has succeeded or almost succeeded in taking possession of her consists in taming her. This he does in the simplest way: he beats her with three kinds of rods until she is more dead than alive, after which happiness takes over.

有时，公主被表现为女英雄、战士、射箭高手、跑马高手，对未婚夫的敌意可以表现为与男主角公开竞争的形式。

Sometimes the princess is presented as a heroine, a warrior, a master of shooting arrows, running, and horse riding, and the hostility towards her fiancé can take the form of open competition with the hero.

公主的这两个方面并不是由她的个人品质决定的，而是由行动的流畅性决定的。英雄将她从毒蛇手中解救出来，他是她的救世主：这就是温顺女友的类型。另一个则被暴力夺走，被一个狡猾的人绑架或违背她的意愿带走，这个狡猾的人已经完成了任务或解决了谜语，而没有被他不幸的前任的头颅固定在宫殿周围的柱子上这一事实吓到。公主。

The two aspects of the princess are determined not so much by her personal qualities as by the course of the action. The hero frees her from the serpent, he is her savior: this is the type of the gentle bride. The other is taken by force, is kidnapped or taken against her will by a crafty man who has accomplished the deeds or solved the riddles, without being frightened by the fact that the heads of his unfortunate predecessors are fixed on the stakes around the princess's palace.

这一事实有时不仅决定了与未婚夫的关系，也决定了与父亲的关系。研究公主就不能把她和她的父亲分开，研究婚礼的时刻就不能不考虑英雄登基的时刻。

This fact sometimes determines not only the relationship with the fiancé but also with the father; the princess cannot be studied by separating her from her father, the moment of the wedding cannot be studied without considering the moment of the hero's accession to the throne.

公主、她的父亲和她的未婚夫可以形成不同的“力量三角”。通过暴力征服或获得的公主与父亲一致对英雄采取行动，并试图消灭他。

The princess, her father and her fiancé can form different "triangles of power". The princess, conquered or obtained by violence, acts against the hero in agreement with her father and tries to eliminate him.

但也可以有另一种组合：公主与英雄一起对抗她的父亲，有时是她杀死了老国王。

But there can also be another combination: the princess acts against her father together with the hero and sometimes it is she who kills the old king.

作为一个女人，她从来没有被准确地描述过：在这一点上，俄罗斯童话故事与《一千零一夜》不同，在《一千零一夜》中，发展了某种尽管原始的女性美标准。俄罗斯童话中唯一提到的身体特征是金色的头发，我们已经讨论过这一点。由此可见，研究公主不能只看她的外表，而要看她的行为。他的品质在他的表演方式中逐渐显露出来。

As a woman she is never described exactly: in this the Russian fairy tale differs, for example, from the Thousand and One Nights , in which a certain, albeit primitive, canon of female beauty was developed. The only physical characteristic mentioned in the Russian fairy tale is that of golden hair, and we have already spoken about this. From this we see that the princess must be studied not on the basis of her external features but on the basis of her actions. Her qualities are revealed little by little by her way of acting.

2.英雄的烙印。

2. The branding of the hero .

在研究与蛇战斗的画面时，我们忽略了战斗中公主的部分；现在必须填补这一空白。决斗前，英雄睡着了，公主无法叫醒他。 « 她摇晃他，摇晃他，他就是不醒！他开始哭泣，一滴灼热的泪水落在他的脸颊上”（Af. 92）。因此，泪水唤醒了他。在这个和其他类似的案例中，眼泪只能唤醒英雄。但事情的结果往往不同。 « 蛇已经爬近了，正要抓住小国王伊万，而他却继续睡觉。玛法公主有一把小刀，她用它在伊凡国王的脸颊上划了一道口子。然后他醒了，跳起来，与蛇搏斗。”在这里，英雄身上所受的伤还有另一种意义：以后，正是伤疤让英雄被认出来。 “这就是父亲，他把我从蛇的手中救了出来，我不知道他是谁，但现在我通过他脸颊上的伤疤认出了他”（Af. 68）。因此，英雄被赋予了一定的印记，一个印记，一个血淋淋的印记，英雄通过伤疤认出了自己。就连战斗中所受的伤口也具有同样的意义：它代表着血迹。公主拿起手帕包扎伤口。英雄通过伤口和手帕认出了自己。

In studying the picture of the fight with the serpent, we have left out the part of the princess during the fight; now this gap must be filled. Before the duel the hero is asleep and the princess cannot wake him. "She shook him and shook him, and he would not wake! He began to cry and a burning tear fell on his cheek" (Aph. 92). The tears therefore wake him. In this and similar cases the function of tears is only to wake the hero. But often things go differently. "The serpent has already crept up close, it is about to seize the little King Ivan, and he continues to sleep. Princess Martha had a penknife, and with it she made a cut in the cheek of the little King Ivan; then he awoke, jumped up, and fought with the serpent." Here the wound inflicted on the hero has yet another meaning: later it will be the scar that will reveal the hero. "Here, father, is the one who saved me from the snakes. I did not know who it was, but now I recognize him by the scar on his cheek" (Af. 68). Therefore, a certain mark is impressed on the hero, a brand, and a bloody brand at that, and the hero recognizes himself by the scar. The wound received during the fight also has the same meaning: it represents a bloody brand. The princess takes a handkerchief and bandages the wound. The hero recognizes himself by the wound and the handkerchief.

英雄的这种烙印不仅仅在决斗中进行。这里重要的不是环境，而是婚礼前不久烙印的品牌。

This branding of the hero is not practiced only during the duel. What matters here is not the setting, but the fact that the brand is impressed shortly before the wedding.

我们在Sivko-Burko童话故事中也有类似的情况。这里没有战斗，但英雄的烙印以更清晰的形式表达出来。英雄骑着 Sivko-Burko 飞到公主的窗前并亲吻了她。 « 他飞向国王的宫殿，打碎了所有十二块玻璃，并亲吻了无价之美的公主，她在他的额头中央留下了一个印记 » (Af. 106 b)，或者： « 她在他的额头上打了一个标记额上戴着金戒指”（《箴言》106a）。 « 然后她用手指敲击他的额头。他的额头上亮起一道光»（Sev.8）。这个标记不仅出现在西夫科-布尔科类型的故事中，而且还出现在其他故事中。因此，举例来说，注定要嫁给公主的新郎是一个聪明的男孩。 “她把金戒指印在他的额头上，把他带到法庭并嫁给了他”（Af. 114 a）。有时，这个主题会经历一种奇怪的变形，但这证明了它在大众意识中的牢固地位，因此即使在不合适的地方也会使用它。举例来说，童话故事一开始就讲述了主人公事业不走运，一事无成。国王得知此事后怜悯他：“宣布他无产，并下令在他额头中央印上印章，这样就没有人向他索要贡赋或赋税”（Af. 122 d）。

A similar case is found in the fairy tale Sivko-Burko . There is no fight here, but nevertheless the branding of the hero is expressed in a much clearer form. On Sivko-Burko's horse the hero flies up to the princess's window and kisses her. "He flew up to the king's palace, broke all twelve panes of glass and kissed the princess Priceless Beauty, and she put a brand on him right in the middle of his forehead" (Af. 106 b), or: "she struck him on the forehead with her golden ring" (Af. 106 a). "And she struck him on the forehead with her finger. A light came on in his forehead" (Sev. 8). This branding is found not only in tales of the Sivko-Burko type , but also in others. For example, the princess's intended groom is a wise boy. "She stamped her golden ring on his forehead, took him to court and married him" (Aph. 114 a). Sometimes this motif undergoes a bizarre distortion which, however, proves how firmly it has settled in the popular consciousness, so that it is used even where it is not appropriate. Thus, for example, the tale begins by telling how the hero is unlucky in his trade, how he succeeds in nothing. The king hears of this and takes pity on him: "he declared him penniless and ordered a seal to be stamped on the middle of his forehead, so that no one would exact tribute or taxes from him" (Aph. 122 d).

除了在皮肤上印记的各种方式外，还有另一种方式来标记英雄：例如，他以鹿的形式将头放在公主的膝盖上，公主“拿起剪刀剪了一个鹿头上的一簇毛”（Af. 145）。另一种形式的品牌推广涉及剪掉一绺头发。通常，品牌的功能是公主和英雄之间存在团结的标志。但邪恶的公主也用同样的手段杀死了英雄。例如，他解决了难题。 « 谁知，夜里，当大家都已经熟睡的时候，她拿着童话书走到他们面前，看了一眼书，立刻就认出了罪魁祸首；拿起剪刀，把他的太阳穴剃光了。” “有了这个标志，我明天就会认出他并处决他”（AF.133）。

In addition to the various ways of impressing a brand on the skin, there is another means of marking the hero: for example, in the form of a deer, he places his head on the knees of the princess, who "took the scissors and cut a tuft of hair from the deer's head" (Aph. 145). Another form of branding consists in cutting a lock of hair. Usually the function of branding is a sign of solidarity existing between the princess and the hero. But the wicked princess also uses the same means to kill the hero. He, for example, has solved the riddles. "And behold, during the night, when everyone was already sound asleep, she came to them with her magic book, looked into the book and immediately recognized the culprit; she took the scissors and shaved his temples." "By this sign I will recognize him tomorrow and have him executed" (Aph. 133).

所举的例子足以让我们了解俄罗斯童话中公主的作用。俄罗斯童话故事为这一主题提供了相当完整、丰富和多样的画面，但它并没有包含可以阐明其历史的某些细节。烙印总是与随后对隐藏的英雄的认识联系在一起，也就是说，它已经转变为纯粹诗意的权宜之计。在属于其他民族的材料中，这种联系不是强制性的，它们包含一些对我们来说很重要的细节。因此，例如，在拉普神话中，女孩对向她求婚的太阳之子做出了以下反应：“让我们混合我们的血液，让我们团结我们的心，无论痛苦还是快乐...... ”（Charuzin，《拉普斯》，第 347 页）。所以在婚礼之前，血统是混合的；不过，并没有说是喝醉了。故事继续叙述，女孩的父亲割破了两个年轻人的小指，混合了他们的血液。

The examples cited are enough to give us an idea of ​​the role of the princess in the Russian fairy tale. The Russian fairy tale provides a fairly complete, rich and varied picture of this motif, but nevertheless it does not contain certain details that could shed light on its history. The branding is always connected with the subsequent recognition of the hidden hero, that is, it has turned into a purely poetic device. In the materials of other peoples this connection is not obligatory, and they contain some details that are important to us. Thus, for example, in a Laplander myth the maiden answers the son of the sun who has asked for her hand in marriage in the following way: "Let us mix our blood, let us unite our hearts for sorrow and for joy..." (Charuzin, The Laplanders , p. 347). Thus before the wedding the blood is mixed; however, it is not said that it is drunk. The tale continues by telling how the maiden's father cuts off the little fingers of the two young people and mixes their blood.

俄罗斯童话可以与这个神话相比较吗？如果比较正确的话，同样的现象也会在这里反映出来，这意味着童话在保留了自身的烙印行为之后，其意义发生了变化，转变为一种认可的符号；标记的血腥特征会在决斗过程中以伤口的形式出现，而混合血液的行为则完全消失。

Can the Russian fairy tale be compared with this myth? If the comparison is correct, the same phenomenon would be reflected here, which would mean that, after having preserved the act of branding itself, the fairy tale changed its meaning by transforming it into a sign of recognition; and the bloody character of the brand would have taken the form of a wound during the duel while the act of mixing the blood has disappeared altogether.

拉普人的神话比其他任何仪式都更好地保留了这一仪式的形式和意义。抽出的鲜血、痕迹和伤痕是加入氏族协会、氏族联盟的标志。因此，我们发现他们已经在入会仪式中，在联盟新成员的接纳仪式中。但它们在仪式之外也广泛传播。这并不是他们唯一的形式。在澳大利亚人中，老人和年轻人，以及年轻人，当他们是亲戚时，都会喝血，以巩固这种血缘关系，当两个部落缔结和平时也会这样做522。对于原始人来说，血统身份是亲属关系的唯一标志”，Lippert 523说道。因此，任何人为的血统混合都必须创造血缘关系。哈特兰、维塞洛夫斯基在他的《诗学》中，以及查鲁津、斯滕伯格和其他作者在一项具体研究中报告了一长串民族，他们在加入家族联盟的仪式上或为了加强家族联盟的目的而混合和饮用血液。 Schweinfurth 在 Niam-Niam 中发现了这一事实，Wellhausen 在阿拉伯人中发现了这一事实，他们总是伴随着宴会参加仪式，Achelis 在 Lidî 524中发现了这一事实。血液从身体的哪个部位抽取并不重要，但自然地，在穿衣服的人中，是暴露的部位，额头、脸颊、手，就像我们在童话故事中看到的那样。查鲁津写道：“加入这个氏族的人的血统必须与这个血统的儿子的血统混合在一起。”这些习俗“既有法律意义，也有宗教意义；它们构成了合法接纳外国人加入家庭群体的制度，并且也是结合的神圣象征" 525。

The myth of the Lapps has preserved the forms and the meaning of this rite better than any other. The blood drawn, the brands and the scars are signs of admission into the clan association, into the clan union. Therefore we find them already in the rite of initiation, in the rite of admission of a new member to the alliance. But they are also widespread outside this rite. And this is not their only form. Among the Australians, old and young men drink blood, as well as young men, when they are related, in order to consolidate this kinship, and the same is done when two tribes conclude peace . 522 For primitive man, blood identity was the only sign of kinship, says Lippert . 523 Therefore every artificial mixture of blood was supposed to create kinship. Hartland, Veselovskij in his Poetics and in a special study, Charuzin, Sternberg and other authors report a long list of peoples among whom blood was mixed and drunk during the ceremony of admission to the family alliance or for the purpose of strengthening it. Schweinfurth has noted this fact among the Niam-Niam, Wellhausen among the Arabs who always accompany the ceremony with a banquet, Achelis among the Lydians . 524 The part of the body from which the blood is extracted is of no importance, but naturally, among peoples who wear clothes it is the uncovered parts, the forehead, cheeks, hands, as we also see in the fairy tale. "The blood of one who enters the clan association," writes Charuzin, "must be mixed with the blood of a son of the lineage." These customs "have both a juridical and a religious significance; they constitute a system for the legal admission of an alien into the family group and also function as a sacred symbol of union" 525 .

结婚后，妻子成为丈夫血统的一部分，反之亦然，丈夫进入妻子血统。在童话故事中，我们总是有最后一种情况，它反映了母系关系。维谢洛夫斯基也许是唯一一个明确指出这种“血缘关系向婚姻关系的转移”的人526。在分析哈特兰收集的材料时，他写道：“在孟加拉的一些原住民中，新郎用红铅笔标记他的妻子。在比尔戈里人中，婚礼仪式是让新郎和新娘的小指流血，然后互相涂抹。在凯瓦提人和拉吉普提人中，这种血液与配偶的食物混合在一起。在乌卡斯（新几内亚），婚礼开始时，新娘和新郎逃跑，被追赶并重新抓获。关于新娘的售价的争论随之而来。当这个问题解决后，丈夫和妻子互相割伤对方的额头，直到血流出来。两个家族的其他成员也这样做，这一行为巩固了他们的联盟。”后来作者提到了一些童话故事（安南语、挪威语、芬兰语）。

At the time of marriage the wife becomes part of the husband's lineage or, vice versa, the husband becomes part of the wife's lineage. In the fairy tale we always have this latter case which is a reflection of matriarchal relations. Veselovsky is perhaps the only one who has clearly pointed out this "transfer of the community of blood to conjugal relations" 526 . In analyzing the materials collected by Hartland he writes: "Among some aborigines of Bengal the groom marks his wife with a red pencil. Among the Birgori the wedding rite consists in the blood flowing from the little fingers of the groom and the bride, who smear it on each other. Among the Kevati and the Radjputi this blood is mixed with the food of the bride and groom. Among the Wukas (New Guinea) at the beginning of the wedding ceremony the bride and groom run away, are chased and recaptured. There follows a debate about the price of the bride. When this has been fixed, the husband and wife carve each other's foreheads until blood flows. The other members of the two families do the same and this act consolidates their alliance. "The author then quotes some fairy tales (Annamite, Norwegian, Finnish).

这种习俗的传播及其形式的多样性使得我们不可能概括地描绘出其演变的完整图景，但这对于我们的目的而言甚至没有必要，因为与童话故事的联系是显而易见的。楚科奇童话甚至还保留了用鲜血涂抹自己的行为。婚礼前，“年轻人首先下令杀死驯鹿来喂养客人，并杀死一头驯鹿，将其血涂在自己身上”。其中一个女孩喊道：“快点散开，血都凉了！” »（Ziv.St.501-502）。关于这个主题的许多材料可以在 Samter 的著作527中找到。在这方面我们也记住特里斯坦和伊索尔德。对于 OM Freidenberg 来说，伊索尔德的杯子是“受精的仪式饮料” 528。根据卡桑斯基的说法，它被简化为“一种纯粹具有神奇意义的饮料”。对我们来说，葡萄酒是血液的替代品：特里斯坦和伊索尔德庆祝婚礼。这种饮料的业余特征是中世纪的转变，受到当时使用的过滤器的影响。特里斯坦和伊索尔德偷偷地说着拉普人神话中恋人所说的话：“让我们混合我们的血液，让我们团结我们的心” 529。

The spread of this custom and the variety of its forms make it impossible to sketch a complete picture of its evolution, but this is not even necessary for our purposes, since the connection with the fairy tale is obvious. A Chukchi fairy tale has even preserved the act of smearing oneself with blood. Before the wedding, "the young man first ordered that reindeer be killed to feed the guests and one to be killed in order to smear himself with its blood." One of the girls shouts: "Hurry up and smear yourselves, the blood is getting cold!" (Ziv. St. 501-502). In Samter's work one can find a lot of material on this subject . 527 In this connection we also recall Tristan and Isolde . For OM Freidenberg, Isolde's cup is "the ritual drink of fertilization." 528 According to Kasansky, it is reduced to "a drink of purely magical significance." For us, wine is a surrogate for blood: Tristan and Isolde celebrate a wedding rite. The amorous character of the drink is a medieval transposition influenced by the preparation of filters, as was customary in those times. Tristan and Isolde say in a veiled way what the lovers say in the myth of the Lapps: "Let us mix our blood, let us unite our hearts" 529 .

但这个话题还没有完全说完。在童话故事中，公主还剪掉了新郎的头发，以示纪念。

But the topic is not yet completely exhausted. In the fairy tale the princess also marks the groom by cutting his hair.

作为婚礼上的用法，这一事实并不经常成立。查鲁津说，“兄弟般的联盟不仅是通过血统的混合而缔结的，而且还通过交换人不可分割的一部分的东西来缔结，例如头发、衣服的一部分等。 ” 530。除此之外，即使在童话故事中，公主不仅剪掉头发，还剪掉新郎长袍的一角（Sm.85等）。

As a nuptial custom, this fact has not been ascertained very often. "The fraternal alliance," says Charuzin, "is concluded not only by mixing blood, but also by exchanging something that is an inseparable part of the person, such as hair, parts of clothing, etc." 530 . By the way, even in the fairy tale the princess cuts off not only the hair, but also a piece of the groom's caftan (Sm. 85, etc.).

作为加入氏族的标志，这种习俗是经常遇到的。在澳大利亚人中，当年轻人在割礼后返回营地时，妇女们正在等待他，她们会剪掉他的一些头发531。剪发的习俗可以说是一种国际现象，一直延续至今，其最初的基础、最初的含义在很大程度上是显而易见的。在洗礼、奉献神职和修道时，要剪掉一绺头发。在所有这些情况下，人成为新社区的一部分；在所有这些情况下，我们也有一种“启蒙”，这种习俗与启蒙的联系是毫无疑问的。在这里，我们发现自己面临着头发处理的特殊情况，我们已经讨论过（第四章，第 15 节）。如果在某些忏悔中牧师没有剃发，那么在这里我们也可以看到与头发生长的联系，头发的生长赋予了一种特殊的力量（另见维谢洛夫斯基，《主体诗学》，第 125 页）。

As a sign of admission to the clan, this custom is met with frequently. Among the Australians, when the boy returns after circumcision to the camp where the women await him, they cut off a few locks of his hair . 531 The custom of cutting hair can be called an international phenomenon, which has lasted to the present day, and its original basis, its original meaning, are largely evident. At baptism, at consecration to the priesthood and at taking the monastic vows, a lock of hair is cut off. In all these cases the man enters a new community; in all these cases we also have a kind of "initiation," and the connection of this custom with initiation is undoubted. We are here faced with a special case of those manipulations with the hair, of which we have already spoken (chap. IV, § 15). And if in some confessions priests are not tonsured, here too we can detect a connection with the growth of hair which gives a particular strength (see also Veselovskij, Poetics of Subjects , p. 125).

正如我们所知，启蒙感觉就像暂时的死亡。因此，当有人死亡时，如何以各种形式剪断头发或放血是可以理解的。一名年轻的苏族印第安人去世后，他的父母剪掉了他额头上的一绺头发532。这必定意味着他与死者的聚会相交流，他进入他们的家庭。根据古希腊人的说法，地狱和死亡之王塔纳托斯剪下了新来者的一绺头发。后来，当人们不再明白这些行为的意义和意义时，剪发就从死者身上转移到了还活着的亲人身上，于是普遍流传的剪发以示哀悼的习俗就诞生了。这种对习俗的解释使我们不同意杰文斯和罗伯逊·史密斯的理论，根据该理论，剪发构成了向死者提供珍贵的礼物和为他带来的牺牲533。在童话故事中，这是妻子去世和加入氏族的标志。正是由于这个原因，妻子，而不是其他人，才留下了这个印记。我们很快就会看到为什么新娘的父亲不能执行此操作。

As we already know, initiation was felt as a temporary death. It is therefore understandable why the cutting of a lock of hair or bloodletting were practiced in various forms when someone died. At the death of a young Sioux Indian, his parents cut a lock of hair from his forehead . 532 This must signify his communion with the assembly of the dead, his entry into their family. Thanatos, king of hell and death, according to a representation of the ancient Greeks, cuts a lock of hair from the newcomer. Later, when men no longer understand the sense and meaning of these acts, the cutting of the hair is transferred from the dead to the living relatives, and the widespread custom of cutting one's hair as a sign of mourning is born. Our explanation of the custom allows us not to agree with the theory of Jevons and Robertson Smith according to which the cutting of the hair constitutes the offering to the deceased of a precious gift and a sacrifice which is brought to him . 533 In the fairy tale it is the sign of the wife's passing and admission to the clan. Precisely for this reason the wife, and no one else, imprints the mark. We will see shortly why this act cannot be performed by the father of the bride.

二.艰难的事业

II. Difficult undertakings

一）环境

A) The environment

3、事业困难。

3. Difficult enterprises .

现在让我们转到公主的另一个功能。结婚前，她会委托新郎完成各种艰巨的任务来考验他。 “艰难的事业”的主题是童话故事中最普遍的主题之一。但必须指出的是，在科学文献中，还没有绝对清楚地知道这项“艰巨的任务”是什么。如果女巫交给女孩从地里采集罂粟种子的任务，这也可以被认为是一项艰巨的任务。为了避免术语上的混乱，有必要明确指出，我们这里所说的“艰难的事业”仅指那些与结婚请求有关的事业，而不是与提供魔法手段有关的事业。有时，即使与结婚请求没有直接联系，也会分配困难的任务，但通过比较可以很容易地确定这种联系。在这里我们也将研究这些案例。

Let us now turn to another function of the princess. Before she marries, she tests the groom by giving him various difficult tasks. The motif of "difficult tasks" is one of the most widespread in fairy tales. But it must be said that in scientific literature it is not yet completely clear what this "difficult task" is. If the witch gives the girl the task of picking poppy seeds from the ground, this too can be called a difficult task. In order to avoid confusion in terminology, it must be made clear that by "difficult tasks" we mean here only those that are connected with the request for marriage, and not with the delivery of a fairy means. There are cases in which difficult tasks are assigned even though there is no immediate connection with the request for marriage, but this connection can easily be ascertained by comparisons. We will also study these cases here.

“艰难的事业”呈现出一幅非常多样化的景象。通过比较这些材料，我们将尽力让您清楚一些。

The "difficult undertakings" present a very varied picture. By comparing the materials we will try to bring you some clarity.

通过研究这些公司，我们将研究两个问题。第一：在什么条件、什么情况下以及为什么分配困难的任务。第二：这些企业的内容是什么，由什么组成。这两个方面并不总是一致的；在不同的情况下可以作出相同的承诺，反之亦然。最后，我们要从整体上解决困难事业的历史基础问题。

In studying these enterprises we will examine two problems. First: under what conditions, in what circumstances and why are difficult enterprises assigned. Second: what is the content of these enterprises, of what do they consist. These two aspects do not always coincide; the same enterprise can be imposed in different circumstances, and vice versa. Finally we will address the problem of the historical foundations of difficult enterprises, considered as a whole.

那么，什么情况下布置困难任务呢？

So, under what circumstances are difficult tasks assigned?

4、公告。

4. The announcement .

有时，可以从故事一开始就强加这一承诺。童话故事开始于一位国王希望与他的女儿结婚，并发布了一份公告，其中他公开了他将与公主结婚的条件。在这种情况下，结婚请求源于承诺：首先我们有承诺，然后是试图履行承诺的结婚请求。一个典型的例子是Sivko-Burko。 “美好的一天”，“那些日子”，国王向各地发送了“一张卡片”，其中他表示，他会将自己的女儿送给任何亲吻她的人，骑着他的马飞翔，而公主将在阳台上或在塔上（AF.105）。这是最著名的壮举，但它绝不是在这种情况下获得的唯一一项壮举。例如：“他们听说国王颁布了一份特许状：谁建造了一艘可以飞的船，谁就娶公主为妻”（AF.83）。其中一些案例可以列出，其中包含各种类型的业务。从来没有说过是什么导致国王分配了这项任务。换句话说，企业没有动力。目前还不清楚另一个情况：这项工作是如此艰巨，以至于其实施似乎是不可能的。英雄之所以这么做是因为他有一位仙女帮手。目前还不清楚这些活动是为了吸引还是吓唬有抱负的人，还是为了帮助找到唯一有价值的丈夫。

Sometimes the task may be imposed from the beginning of the tale. The tale begins with the story of a king who wishes to marry his daughter and publishes a proclamation in which he makes known the conditions under which he will grant the princess's hand. In such cases the request for marriage originates from the task: first of all we have the task and then the request for marriage which consists in the attempt to accomplish the task. A typical case is that of Sivko-Burko . "One fine day", "in those times" the king sends around "a letter" in which he lets it be known that he will give his daughter to whoever kisses her, flying on his horse, while the princess is on the balcony or in the tower (Af. 105). This is the best-known task, but it is by no means the only one assigned in this circumstance. For example: "They heard that a letter from the king had arrived: to whoever built a ship that could fly he would give the princess in marriage" (Af. 83). We can list some of these cases, containing tasks of various kinds. It is never said what induces the king to assign this task. In other words, the enterprises are not motivated. Another circumstance is also unclear for the moment: the enterprises are so arduous that their implementation must appear impossible. The hero accomplishes them because he has a magical helper. For the moment it is not at all clear whether these enterprises aim to entice or frighten the aspirants, or whether they are meant to help find the only worthy husband.

目前，我们仅限于记录故事一开始的业务转让事实以及源于业务本身的婚姻请求，然后我们继续看看其他形式的业务转让所呈现的情况。

For the moment we limit ourselves to recording the fact of the assignment of the companies from the beginning of the story as well as the request for marriage originated by the companies themselves, and we move on to see what picture the other forms of assignment of companies present.

5.企业作为对结婚请求的回应。

5. Businesses as a response to the request for marriage .

上述案件的特点是，承诺先于结婚请求，并导致结婚。但童话故事也呈现了相反的情况：英雄向公主求婚，却被迫先解开新娘的谜语。正如我们所看到的，第一个案例不包含任何动机，但在第二个案例中，动机是存在的。 “我们首先必须检验求婚者的实力”（Af. 116 c）。 « 如果老太婆的儿子做到了这一切，小王后也可以嫁给他为妻；说明他确实有智慧；如果他不这样做，他和老妇人的头就会因为所犯的罪行而被砍掉”（Af. 112）。

The above case is characterized by the fact that the enterprise precedes the request for marriage, it provokes it. But the tale also presents the opposite case: the hero asks for the princess's hand, but is ordered to solve the bride's riddles first. As we have seen, the first case does not contain any motivation, in the second, however, there is motivation. "First of all, the suitor's strength must be tested" (Af. 116 c). "If the old woman's son does all this, the little queen can also be given to him in marriage; it means that he is truly wise; and if he does not do so, for the crime committed, both his and the old woman's heads will be cut off" (Af. 112).

这项壮举被要求作为对追求者的考验。我们所说的“力”并不是指物理力，而是另一种力。从整个先前的行动过程中可以清楚地看出它是什么力量，并且从对任务的分析中也可以清楚地看出：传统上我们称之为神奇的力量，它体现在帮助者身上，受到了考验。

The feat is requested as a test for the suitor. By "strength" is meant not physical strength, but strength of another kind. What kind of strength is involved is clear from the whole preceding course of the action, and becomes clear from the analysis of the feat: the strength that we conventionally call magical and that is embodied in the helper is put to the test.

但这些事业从另一个方面也很有趣：它们包含着威胁的时刻：“如果他不这样做，他的头就会因所犯罪行而被砍掉。”这种威胁暴露了另一个动机。从这些功绩和威胁中，不仅表现出为公主找到最好的新郎的愿望，而且还隐秘地希望新郎不会被发现。 “对我来说，我同意，但首先你必须完成三项任务”（Af. 133），这句话充满了危险：求婚者被送去死。说到这里，我们想起姐姐为了取悦情人而急于除掉哥哥，还派哥哥去寻找狼奶。在这种情况下，公司的要求是对追求者的敌对行为。有时，这种敌意会表现得很明显；有时，这种敌意会表现得非常明显。当一项任务已经完成而需要其他越来越危险的任务时，它就会表现出来。

But these enterprises are also interesting from another point of view: they contain the moment of threat: "If he does not do it, his head will be cut off for the crime he has committed." This threat betrays another motivation. From the enterprises and threats emerges not only the desire to find the best husband for the princess, but also the secret and unconfessed hope that this husband will not be found. The words "I agree, but first you must perform three enterprises" (Af. 133), are full of insidiousness: the suitor is sent to his death. In this connection we are reminded of how the sister, also eager to get rid of her brother in order to please her lover, sends him to fetch wolf's milk. In this case the request for the enterprise is an act of hostility towards the suitor. Sometimes this hostility is expressed very clearly; it manifests itself when an enterprise has already been accomplished and others, increasingly dangerous, are requested.

因此，我们可以发现第二类承诺，即为响应婚姻要求而要求的承诺。它们表明，企业被指派来测试追求者，同时也含有对追求者的敌意和恐吓的成分。

Consequently, we can detect a second category of undertakings, those that are requested in response to the request for marriage. They demonstrate that the undertakings are assigned to test the suitor and, at the same time, also contain an element of hostility towards the suitor and aim to intimidate him.

6.逃脱并重新发现的公主布置的任务。

6. Enterprises imposed by the escaped and found princess .

前一个案例中提到的敌意特征，在以下情况下明显表现出来：公主逃离她的男朋友或丈夫，使用飞毯或通过欺骗恢复翅膀。丈夫寻找她并找到了她，但她不放弃并强迫他执行某些任务。例如，它要求英雄躲起来。在追求他的过程中，她表现出了极大的执着。当英雄变成一根别针，躲在镜子后面，她找不到他，魔法书也给她答案时，出于愤怒，她烧毁了书并打碎了镜子。由此我们看出公主并不想嫁给英雄（Sm.355）。但我们也看到了其他一些东西：企业具有神奇的竞争特征。公主也是女巫，但英雄超越了她。毕竟，即使是国王发布公告或强加商业以回应结婚请求的情况也不能免除这一性质。例如，当公主用十二根柱子和十二根梁建造寺庙时，或者当她坐在玻璃山上时，她就展示了她的神奇力量。

The character of hostility, just hinted at in the previous case, is clearly manifested in the situations characterized as follows: the princess runs away from her fiancé or husband, using the flying carpet or recovering her wings by deception. The husband searches for her and finds her, but she does not give up and forces him to perform certain tasks. Thus, for example, she demands that the hero hide. In pursuing him she shows great persistence. When the hero, transformed into a pin, hides behind the mirror and she cannot find him nor do the magic books give her an answer, in her anger she burns the book and breaks the mirror. From this we see that the princess does not want to marry the hero (Sm. 355). But we also see something else: the tasks have a character of magical competition. The princess is also a magician, but the hero surpasses her. After all, even the cases in which the king issues a proclamation or the enterprises are imposed in response to the request for marriage are not exempt from this character. When, for example, the princess builds the temple on twelve columns and twelve beams or when she sits on the glass mountain, by doing so she gives proof of her magical power.

从所有这些情况都可以清楚地看出公主不想结婚。有时甚至公开地说。她向她的祖父（水之精灵）寻求建议：“伊凡国王向我求婚：我不想嫁给他，但我们的整个军队都被击溃了”（Af. 76）。艰巨的任务随之而来。所有这些案例尚未完全澄清问题，但它们揭示了公主对求婚者的敌对态度，并表明事业中可能存在竞争性。那么，对于为什么公主对她的追求者怀有敌意的问题，我们没有得到答案。

In all these cases it is clear that the princess does not wish to take a husband. Sometimes it is even said openly. She asks her grandfather, the spirit of the waters, for advice: "King Ivan has asked me to marry him. I do not want to marry him, but our entire army has been routed" (Af. 76). The difficult enterprises follow. All these cases do not yet completely clarify the problem, but they reveal the princess's hostile attitude towards the suitor and show that a competitive character may be inherent in the enterprises. To the question why, then, the princess is hostile to her suitor, we get no answer.

7.被假英雄绑架的公主强加的任务。

7. Enterprises imposed by the princess kidnapped by false heroes .

在公主被哥哥从英雄身边绑架的情况下，这些功绩的动机有所不同，而真正的英雄被他们扔下悬崖，隐姓埋名地回到了自己的国家，并躲在一些鞋匠或裁缝身边。在同意嫁给假英雄之前，公主强迫他完成各种壮举。

The deeds are motivated differently in cases where the princess has been kidnapped from the hero by her elder brothers, while the true hero, thrown by them into a precipice, has returned incognito to his country and is hiding with some shoemaker or tailor. Before consenting to the marriage with the false hero, the princess forces him to perform different deeds.

有时，回到故乡的英雄会通过人们的谣言得知这一点：“这些国王带来了一位国王的女儿，长子想娶她，但首先她派人去拿结婚戒指，或者他想要它制成。“一”（Af. 93 a）。

Sometimes the hero who has returned home is informed of this by the gossip of the people: "And these little kings have brought here a king's daughter, the eldest wants to marry her, but first she sends for a wedding ring, or wants one to be made" (Aph. 93 a).

这里很明显，强加承诺是为了找到真正的男朋友，在这些情况下，对男朋友的敌意因素通常对应于对假男友的敌意。真正的男朋友正在被提供服务：他有机会展示他的能力。

Here it is clear that the undertaking is imposed in order to have the opportunity to find the real fiancé, and in these cases the element of hostility towards the fiancé generally corresponds to the hostility towards the false fiancé. The authentic fiancé is rendered a service: he is given the opportunity to show what he can do.

在所有这些情况下，新娘和她的父亲都对真实或虚假的未婚夫抱有敌意。国王本人，即未来的岳父强加的承诺，或者订婚的公主强加的，都没有关系。主动权有时来自父亲，有时来自公主。但情况并不总是这样：可以发现一定的区别：只有公主的父亲，未来的岳父，对英雄有敌意，而公主则通过欺骗自己的父亲来帮助英雄。

In all these cases the bride and her father are united in their enmity towards the true or false fiancé. The king himself, that is, the future father-in-law, imposes the enterprise, or the fiancée princess imposes it, it does not matter. Sometimes the initiative comes from the father, sometimes from the princess. But it is not always like this: a certain differentiation can be noted: only the princess's father, the future father-in-law, is hostile to the hero, while the princess helps the hero, deceiving her own father.

8.水灵的功绩。

8. The exploits of the Water Spirit .

这是典型的童话故事，主人公被卖给了水精灵。她去找他，但在路上，在见到他之前，她就与他的女儿订婚了。英雄一出现在他面前，水生精灵就强迫他做一些他根本不鼓励的事情，或者以这种方式激励他：“这是对你拖延这么久的惩罚：给我建造一个谷仓夜”（AF. 125 d）。有时，完成这一壮举被视为解放的条件：“认出哪个是我最小的女儿；”如果你认识到这一点，我会让你去任何你想去的地方，但如果你不认识到这一点，对你来说就更糟了”（Af. 125 b）。

This case is typical of fairy tales in which the hero has been sold to the Water Spirit; he goes to him, but on the way, even before meeting him, he becomes engaged to his daughter. As soon as the hero appears before him, the Water Spirit forces him to carry out certain deeds which he does not motivate at all or motivates in this way: "This is to punish you for having delayed so long: build me a barn in one night" (Aph. 125 d). Sometimes the completion of the deed is made a condition of liberation: "Recognize who my youngest daughter is; if you recognize her I will let you go where you wish, but if you do not recognize her, so much the worse for you" (Aph. 125 b).

在这里，叙述者不知道是什么迫使水神强加这些壮举，他设计了一个理由。然而，这些事业之后总是伴随着与精神之女的婚姻，在这里我们只是看到了童话经典的反映；婚姻+生意+婚姻的要求。对婚姻的要求已经消失，困难的事业必须以某种方式激发，婚姻甚至不是以一种非常令人信服的形式从事业的执行中衍生出来的。另一方面，这些案例很有趣，因为新娘的父亲明显对英雄怀有敌意。婚礼结束后，逃亡者逃亡，水灵试图接近并杀死逃亡者。公主与新郎结盟对抗自己的父亲。

Here the narrator does not know what compels the Water Spirit to impose the deeds, and he invents a reason. These deeds, however, are always followed by marriage to the spirit's daughter, and here we simply have a reflection of the fairy-tale canon: request for marriage + deeds + marriage. The request for marriage has disappeared, the difficult deeds must be motivated in some way, and the marriage does not result in a very convincing form from the execution of the deeds either. On the other hand, these cases are interesting because the father of the bride is manifestly hostile to the hero. The marriage is followed by the escape and the attempt of the Water Spirit to catch up with and kill the fugitives. The princess joins forces with the groom against her own father.

可以指出一些案例，其中实施困难承诺与结婚请求没有直接关系。例如，七个西蒙斯就是这种情况。在这里，国王“命令七个西蒙展示他们知道如何实践什么艺术”（AF.84）。然而，即使在这里，婚姻也伴随着企业的执行。事业与婚姻之间的因果联系已经转变为机械联系。

Several cases can be pointed out in which the imposition of difficult undertakings is not directly connected with the request for marriage. This is the case, for example, of the Seven Simeons . Here the king "orders the Seven Simeons to demonstrate what arts they can practice" (Aph. 84). However, here too, marriage follows the execution of the undertakings. The causal link between the undertakings and the marriage has been transformed into a mechanical connection.

在故事《青蛙公主》（Af. 150）中，国王在孩子们的婚礼后突然宣布：“我希望你们的妻子们为我明天烤软白面包”（Af. 150 c）。但从故事的继续来看，我们可以清楚地看出，青蛙新娘的地位高于其他人，也就是说，与其他情况一样，强加的承诺导致了魔法手段的拥有者与普通凡人的区别。 。

In the tale The Frog Princess (Aph. 150), after the marriage of his children the king declares out of the blue: "I want each of your wives to bake me a soft white loaf of bread tomorrow" (Aph. 150c). But from the continuation of the tale it becomes clear that with this fact the frog bride is exalted above the others, that is to say that the imposition of the deeds leads, as in other cases, to the differentiation of the possessor of magical means from ordinary mortals.

9.魔法大师的任务。

9. Master-Sorcerer's Deeds .

但既然我们已经提到了与求婚没有直接关系的事业，我们就不能抛开那些关于狡猾的科学的童话故事（Af.140）。在这些故事中，英雄也被卖掉或落入巫师手中，而巫师则教他技艺。但英雄是巫师的囚犯，他的父亲来接他回来，巫师给他布置了一系列谜题，他在与儿子达成一致后解决了这些谜题，就像小国王伊万执行分配给他的任务一样与女儿订下约定后，被水生精灵所左右。在这些情况下，甚至任务也常常是一致的：它涉及在十二个平等者中承认儿子或妻子。 “好吧，老人，”巫师说，“我已经教了你儿子所有的技巧，但如果你不认识他，他将永远和我在一起”（Af. 140 a）。这个童话故事与英雄与水生精灵的童话故事相似，不仅因为其功绩的主题，而且因为它包含了逃生的内容。但是，正如我们将看到的，这种逃脱具有与巫师进行魔法竞争的特征。我们在这里既没有找到敌对的岳父，也没有找到公主。从功能上来说，敌对的魔法师、巫师，对应于敌对的岳父。

But now that we have touched on the feats not directly connected with the marriage proposal, we cannot leave aside the tales of the Crafty Science (Aph. 140). In these too the hero has been sold or has fallen into the hands of a sorcerer who teaches him his art; but the hero is the sorcerer's prisoner, his father comes to take him back and the sorcerer gives him a series of riddles which he solves after having previously agreed with his son, just as the little king Ivan performs the feats assigned to him by the Water Spirit after having agreed with the latter's daughter. In these cases, too, the feats often coincide: it is a question of recognizing the son or the bride among twelve equals. "Well, old man," says the sorcerer, "I have taught your son all the tricks, but if you do not recognize him, he will remain with me forever and ever" (Aph. 140a). This tale is similar to that of the hero and the Water Spirit, not only for the motif of the enterprises but also because it contains the escape. But, as we will see, this escape has the character of a magical competition with the sorcerer; we do not find here either the hostile father-in-law or the princess. Functionally, the hostile father-in-law corresponds to the hostile magician, the sorcerer.

这个案例在某种程度上与其他案例有些孤立。上面我们同意仅将那些与结婚请求直接或间接相关的事情称为“困难的事情”。在这里，这个要求不存在：任务不是强加给英雄的，而是强加给他的父亲的，直到那一刻为止，女人根本没有出现在故事​​中。从这一点来说，这个案例不属于我们研究的范围，甚至可以抛开。但是，另一方面，这里谜题的解决方案也与婚姻有关，新娘似乎是机械人，或者是巫师本人的女儿；因此，我们有时会遇到与水神和他的女儿的童话故事相同的情况，因此不能排除这些童话故事；此外，这些公司也很有趣，我们稍后会分析其内容。

This case is somewhat isolated from all the others. We agreed above to call "difficult deeds" only those which are directly or indirectly connected with the request for marriage. Here there is no such request: the deeds are imposed not on the hero, but on his father, and up to that point the woman does not figure at all in the story. In this respect the case does not fall into the category we have studied and we could just as well leave it aside. But, on the other hand, here too the solution of the riddles is followed by marriage, and the bride appears ex machina or is the daughter of the sorcerer himself; so we are sometimes faced with the same situation as in the tales about the Water Spirit and his daughter, so that these tales cannot be excluded; furthermore, the deeds are also interesting, the content of which we will analyse later.

10.充满敌意的岳父。

10. The hostile father-in-law .

至此，我们已经穷尽了俄罗斯童话中出现困难任务的情况。他们的比较特征并没有给我们理解他们的钥匙：我们面临着一个相当多样化甚至矛盾的画面：一方面新郎被吸引和渴望，我们希望新娘有最好的未婚夫，另一方面我们你害怕他，你不想要他，你试图消灭他，你用死亡威胁他，你对他表现出明显或潜在的敌意。为了更清楚起见，在这一点上，我们想强调岳父对未来丈夫表现出的敌意的一些特征，无论在何种情况下施加承诺。这将有助于我们以后了解主人公登基的情况，而且由于童话故事常常淡化岳父和女婿之间的冲突，因此更有必要，因为它不了解根本不是由行动产生的敌意的原因，并因此将其最小化。

We have thus exhausted the situations in which difficult undertakings are imposed in the Russian fairy tale. Their comparative characterization does not give us the key to understanding them: we are faced with a rather varied and even contradictory picture: on the one hand the groom is attracted and desired, people want the bride to have the best fiancé, on the other hand people are afraid of him, they do not want him, they try to eliminate him, they threaten him with death, they manifest an open or latent hostility towards him. For greater clarity we would like at this point to highlight some characteristics of the hostility that the father-in-law shows towards the future groom independently of the situation in which the undertaking is imposed. This will help us later to understand the circumstances of the hero's accession to the throne, and it is all the more necessary since the fairy tale very often attenuates the conflict between father-in-law and son-in-law, because it does not understand the reasons for an enmity that does not arise from the action at all and for this reason it minimizes it.

减少敌意的方法之一是：不是把仇恨归咎于岳父本人，而是归咎于嫉妒的人、恶毒的舌头或诽谤者。例如，主人公成为了一名富商，其他商人都羡慕他。 “他们很生气，并向国王报告说，他吹嘘在一夜之间为皇宫的房间制作了地毯”（《SM》310）。各公司纷纷效仿。最后：“国王没有继承人，收养了商人的儿子。”我们在这里看到那些有功绩的人占据了国王的位置，这一次是和平发生的。

One way to minimize enmity is as follows: it is attributed not to the father-in-law himself, but to envious people, evil tongues, or slanderers. The hero, for example, becomes a rich merchant and the other merchants envy him. "They were angry and told the king that he had boasted that he could make the carpets for the halls of the king's palace in one night" (Sm. 310). This is followed by various deeds. And finally: "The king had no heirs and adopted the merchant's son." Here we see that he who has accomplished deeds takes the place of the king, which this time happens peacefully.

在分配任务的公主背后，有时还有另一个角色，即情人，她害怕自己的竞争对手，因此迫使公主将困难的任务强加给英雄，从而成为对男友的敌意的始作俑者。然而，敌人往往是国王本人，正如我们所说，即使在完成事迹之后甚至在结婚之后，他仍然充满敌意。有时，童话故事会激发这种行为，因为英雄是士兵或农民，而且他配不上公主。 « 国王认为将女儿嫁给一个普通农民是不对的，并开始考虑如何除掉这样的女婿。这就是他的想法：“我会给他一些艰巨的任务来完成”（Af. 83）。就连富人马尔科也给他邪恶的女婿分配了一项必定会导致他垮台的任务。 « 马科和他的女婿住了一个月，然后是一个月，第三个月；一个晴朗的日子，他打电话给他说：“这是我的朋友蛇王写给你的一封信，请前往遥远的王国，向他索要十二年的贡品”（Af. 173）。另一方面，女婿有时也会伸出指甲。当他听到委托给他的任务时，他说：“好吧！但如果国王继续寻找借口，我将征服他的整个王国，并用武力将公主据为己有”（Af. 83）。如果国王本人是一位伟大的魔法师，他就会用他的魔法摧毁英雄。最常见的典型壮举之一就是驯服一匹马。 « 现在我委托给你一项艰巨的任务，一项劳累的工作：同样的未受洗礼国王将成为你的小马驹，他将把你带得比静止的森林更高，比移动的云更低，他会把你所有的骨头分散到所有的地方。风 » (AF. 125 P)。

Behind the princess who assigns the tasks there is sometimes another character, namely the lover, who fears his rival suitors and therefore pushes the princess to impose difficult tasks on the hero, thus becoming the initiator of the enmity towards her fiancé. Often, however, the enemy is the king himself and, as we have said, he remains hostile even after the completion of the tasks and even after the marriage. Sometimes the fairy tale justifies this behavior by the fact that the hero is a soldier or a peasant and is not a worthy match for the princess. "The king judged that it was not right to marry his daughter to a simple peasant and began to think about how to get rid of such a son-in-law. And this is what he came up with: 'I will give him several difficult tasks to perform' " (Af. 83). Marko the Rich also assigns his unwelcome son-in-law a task that is to be his downfall. "Marko lived with his son-in-law for a month, then another and a third; one day he called him and said: "Here is a letter for you, go with it to the distant kingdom, to my friend the Serpent King, demand from him a tribute for twelve years" (Aph. 173). On the other hand, the son-in-law also shows his claws sometimes. When he hears the task entrusted to him, he says: "All right! But if even after this the king continues to look for pretexts, I will conquer his entire kingdom and take the princess by force" (Aph. 83). In cases where the king himself is a great magician, he uses his art to destroy the hero. One of the typical feats that most often recurs consists in taming a horse. « Now I entrust you with a difficult mission, a tiring task: King Unbaptized Forehead himself will be your colt, he will carry you higher than the motionless forest, lower than the moving cloud, and he will scatter all your bones to all the winds » (Af. 125 P).

11.老国王的任务。

11. Enterprises imposed on the old king .

未来女婿也表现出敌意。当所有的事情都完成后，他们的矛头转向了国王。车轮转动：未来的新国王总是执行强加给他的一切，而老国王总是灭亡。在这些壮举中，我们可以提到的是在沸腾的牛奶中沐浴，以及过过一根细如发丝的桥。

The future son-in-law also shows his hostility. After all the deeds have been accomplished, their tip turns against the king. The wheel turns: while the future new king always carries out everything that is imposed on him, the old king invariably perishes. Among these deeds we can mention that of bathing in boiling milk, and that of crossing a bridge as thin as a hair.

这种情况发生在当英雄被派去寻找一些神奇的物体时，却带着国王想要娶的公主回来，或者当他被派去寻找国王的新娘时，她与她的绑架者英雄达成协议，或者当哥哥们把伊万扔下悬崖后，把三位公主带进屋里。铜银王国的公主们嫁给了英雄的兄弟，但他注定的新娘却没有嫁给任何人。

This case occurs when the hero, sent to fetch some miraculous object, returns instead with the princess the king wanted to make his own, or when he is sent to fetch the king's bride and she has an understanding with her hero-captor, or when the elder brothers, after throwing Ivan off a cliff, bring three princesses home. The princesses of the kingdom of copper and silver marry the hero's brothers, but the bride destined for him does not marry anyone.

“然后老父亲就产生了亲自娶她的想法。”他问黄金王国的公主：“你愿意嫁给我吗？ “当你不给我量尺寸就给我做一双鞋时，我就嫁给你。”微服归来的英雄代替老人完成了这一壮举。接下来是其他任务，最后是最后一个：“煮沸牛奶，然后潜入其中”（Af. 71 c，103 b）。国王自然自焚而死。

« And then the old father thought of marrying her himself ». He asks the princess of the golden kingdom: « Will you marry me? - I will marry you when you make me a pair of shoes without taking my measurements ». The hero who has returned incognito performs this feat in place of the old man. The other feats follow and, finally, the last one: « Boil this milk and dive into it » (Af. 71 c, 103 b). The king naturally gets burned and dies.

B)公司内容

B) Content of the companies

分析完它们被命令的情况之后，我们现在来分析一下这些公司本身；只有在此之后我们才能进行一些扣除。

After having analyzed the circumstances in which they are ordered, let us now analyze the enterprises themselves; only after that will we be able to draw some deductions.

企业并不总是与它们所处的环境联系在一起，我们必须独立于该环境来研究它们。

Businesses are not always tied to the situation in which they are imposed, and we must study them independently of that situation.

这些事业虽然数量众多，但往往是重复的，而且其基本路线是可以确定的。

These enterprises are very numerous, but they are often repeated and their fundamental lines can be defined.

12.研究型企业。

12. Research enterprises .

绝大多数任务都是为了将​​英雄送到遥远的王国。他必须证明他在那里，他有能力去那里并返回，否则就会死。他预计会采购只能在那里找到的物品或稀有物品。这些物体的独特之处始终是金色。但我们已经知道，物体的金色是其属于来世境界的标志。因此，当英雄被要求获得火鸟、金鬃猪、金毛鸭、金角鹿或山羊时，这总是意味着英雄必须寄居在来世。有时，这一壮举可以简单地表述如下：“从前，有一位国王发出公告，要寻找一个愿意前往遥远王国的人”（《诗篇》12）。 “获得太阳、月亮和星星”（圣条 249）、“获得太阳和月亮的钥匙”（圣条 304）以及其他与太阳有关的事业，也旨在相同的目的。有时，童话故事甚至清楚地讲到堕入地狱：“给我地狱的钥匙”（Sm.353）。英雄被要求在铅王国呆七年（Af. 151）并获取可以治愈和赋予生命的水（Af. 83）。在非俄罗斯童话中，这一要求表达得更加清晰：“我要求你在两天内给我带来我已故七代人的消息”（《俾路支故事》，第 46, 32, 194 页）。

The vast majority of quests are aimed at sending the hero to the far-off realm. He must prove that he has been there, that he is capable of going there and returning, or else he must die. He is required to procure objects or rarities that can only be found there. The peculiarity of these objects is always their golden color. But we already know that the golden color of an object is a sign that it belongs to the realm of the afterlife. Therefore, when the hero is required to procure a firebird, a pig with golden bristles, a duck with a golden tuft, a deer or a goat with golden horns, this always means that the hero must sojourn in the realm of the afterlife. Sometimes the quest is simply formulated as follows: "Once upon a time there was a king who sent word to find someone who would go to the far-off realm" (Sm. 12). The same goal is also pursued by the enterprise of "procuring the sun, the moon and the stars" (Sm. 249), "procuring the keys of the sun and the moon" (Sm. 304) and other tales connected with the sun. Sometimes the tale even speaks clearly of a descent into hell: "Bring me the keys of hell" (Sm. 353). The hero is asked to stay for seven years in the kingdom of lead (Af. 151) and to procure healing and life-giving water (Af. 83). In non-Russian tales this request is expressed even more clearly: "I demand of you that within two days you bring me news of seven generations of my dead" ( Beluch Tales , pp. 46, 32, 194).

其中，最值得关注的就是获取金枝。从本质上讲，它与获取金苹果、金角鹿、火鸟等的事业没有任何区别。 « 某界有金橡银枝；我希望你把橡树从那个领域连根拔起，把它们带到这里”（Chud.85）。在有关“金毛猪”的童话故事的一个版本中，阿法纳西耶夫的抄本写道：“之后，傻瓜得到了一头金毛猪，它带着十二只小猪，还有一根生长在遥远王国的金松树枝。空气状况 » (Af. 106 P)。

Among these feats, the feat of procuring a golden bough deserves special attention. It essentially differs in no way from the feats of procuring golden apples, a golden-antlered deer, a firebird, etc. "In a certain kingdom there is a golden oak with silver branches; I want you to uproot the oak from that kingdom and bring it here" (Chud. 85). In one version of the tale about the "golden-bristled pig", in Afanasiev's transcription we read: "After that the simpleton procured a golden-bristled pig with twelve piglets and a branch of the golden pine that grows in the distant kingdom, in the state of air" (Af. 106 P).

众所周知，弗雷泽的宏伟研究致力于“金枝”。从内米戴安娜圣殿撕下金枝的人可能会成为大祭司的继承人：这里我们遇到了与童话故事中相同的情况。正如我们将看到的，征服稀有事物或一般来说完成一项艰巨的任务与英雄登上王位有关，并且常常与杀死老国王有关，就像《内米》中发生的那样。但童话故事表明，弗雷泽在关注树枝时是错误的：它不是关于树枝，而是关于它的金色，弗雷泽非常天真地将这种颜色解释为槲寄生的黄色色调。弗雷泽的整个调查是在错误的方向上倾斜进行的。借助对树木和森林的崇拜来解释这一习俗是错误的，就好像我们将猪或鸟作为仪式动物来研究以解释获得金毛猪或火鸟的壮举一样。不是这个，而是王位觊觎者必须接受一项实验，证明他去过另一个世界。与森林的联系并不是弗雷泽所寻求的。

Frazer's great study is, as is well known, devoted to the "golden bough." He who plucked the golden bough from the sanctuary of Diana in Nemi could become the successor of the priest: here we have the same case as in the tale. As we shall see, the conquest of a rarity or in general the accomplishment of a difficult enterprise is connected with the hero's accession to the throne and often with the killing of the old king, as also happens at Nemi. But the tale shows that Frazer is wrong when he focuses on the branch: it is not the branch, but its golden color, and Frazer explains this color very naively as the yellow hue of mistletoe. Frazer's whole investigation proceeds obliquely, in the wrong direction. To resort to the cult of trees and the forest to explain this custom is false, as if we were to study the pig or the bird as ritual animals to explain the feat of procuring the golden-bristled pig or the firebird. It is not that, but rather that the pretender to the throne must undergo an experiment proving that he has been in the other world. The connection with the forest is not where Frazer seeks it.

我们所列举的功绩的比较给出了这个问题的答案：通过要求英雄完成困难的功绩，我们本质上想从他那里知道什么？到目前为止我们分析的企业让我们可以给出一个准确的答案：企业背后有证据；企业背后有证据；企业背后有证据。我们想从英雄那里知道他是否曾在地狱、在阳光的国度、在另一个世界。只有去过那里的人，才有权利握在公主的手上。

The comparison of the deeds we have listed gives an answer to the question: what do we essentially want to know from the hero by imposing on him the difficult deeds? The deeds we have analyzed so far allow us to give a precise answer: behind the deeds there is a proof; we want to know from the hero whether he has been in hell, in the realm of the sun, in the other world. Only he who has been there has the right to the hand of the princess.

现在我们仅限于观察这一事实。作为英雄化条件的卡塔巴西斯已经在上文中进行了分析，不再重复所引用的材料或引用新的材料。艰辛事业的图景及其历史根源逐渐展现在我们眼前。

For now we limit ourselves to the observation of this fact. The catabasis as a condition of heroification has already been analyzed above and there is no need to repeat the cited materials or to cite new ones. The picture of difficult enterprises and their historical roots are gradually revealed before our eyes.

我们尚未分析该组中的所有公司。上面我们将公主分配的一组任务与其他任务分开，这些任务是哥哥们从她的未婚夫那里偷来的。这些兄弟为了得到她的手而战斗，但公主通过向他们施加艰巨的任务来阻止他们。这些业务是什么？它们有一个特定的特点：在这种情况下，公主要求提供与婚礼相关的物品：鞋子、婚纱、结婚戒指、马车等。但更仔细的检查表明，这些企业与那些已经分析过的企业的区别并不在于其本质，而仅在于其目的或目标。 “首先，她派人去寻找结婚戒指，或者想要制作一枚”（Af. 93 a）。因此，即使在这种情况下，主人公也被送到了某个地方：从童话故事的整个进程中就可以看出他被送到了哪里，有时我们甚至发现它有明确的表述：“她想要为她缝制婚纱，就像她在童话故事中那样。另一个世界，并且没有采取措施”（Af. 73）。 “我会嫁给一个能为我制作和我在黄金王国里穿的鞋子一样的人”（Sev. 41）。 “我需要一件像我在玻璃山上穿的那样的衣服”（ZP 59）。这里表达得很清楚的是送入另一个领域。甚至借口的特征也特别明显：当然，这不是关于鞋子或马车，而是关于对英雄的考验。没有去过来世的兄弟无法完成这一壮举。英雄这样做是因为他曾经在那里。

We have not yet analyzed all the enterprises that are part of this group. Above we separated from the others the group of enterprises assigned by the princess that the older brothers stole from her fiancé. These brothers plot to obtain her hand, but the princess keeps them at bay by imposing difficult enterprises on them. What are these enterprises? They have a specific character: in such cases the princess asks that an object pertaining to the wedding be procured for her: the shoes, the wedding dress, the wedding ring, a carriage, etc. But a more careful examination shows that these enterprises are distinguished from those already analyzed not by their essence, but only by their object or objective. "She first sends for the wedding ring or wants one to be made" (Af. 93 a). So here too the hero is sent somewhere: where he is sent is evident from the whole course of the tale and sometimes it is even formulated clearly: "She wants wedding clothes to be sewn for her just as she had them in the other world, and without taking her measurements" (Af. 73). "I will marry the man who can make me the same slippers that I wore in the realm of gold" (Sev. 41). "I need a dress just like the one I wore on the glass mountain" (ZP 59). Here the sending to the other realm is expressed very clearly. The nature of the pretext is also particularly clear: it is not, of course, a question of the slippers or the carriage, but of testing the hero. The brothers who have not been to the other world cannot accomplish the feat. The hero accomplishes it because he has been there.

在这种情况下，英雄不会第二次踏上旅程；通常他不会去寻找所请求的对象（尽管有时也会发生这种情况），但他会制造它们，并将它们打包。由此，困难事业的另一个方面就暴露出来了。谁能完成壮举？这些事业本身是不可行的。英雄执行这些任务只是因为他有一个帮手。由此可见，功绩不仅要证明英雄是否到过来世的国度，还要证明他是否在那里得到了助手；事实上，我们可以观察到许多任务公开倾向于检查英雄是否有帮助者。例如，这也可以从某些表述中看出：“谁帮助他？”或“神灵肯定会为伊凡国王做这件事。”在有关助手的章节中，我们已经了解了马的职责是什么以及英雄如何获得它。许多任务的目的是发现英雄是否拥有一匹仙马并知道如何使用它。例如，该组包括训练（Af. 116 c）或驯服马（Af. 125 P）、驯服小马驹（Af. 125）或获得七十七匹母马（Af. 103）的壮举，以及它还可以包括骑马时亲吻公主（Af.105）。这最后一项任务的表述方式绝非巧合：《美丽的海伦下令为她建造一座十二根柱子和十二根横梁的神庙； ...新郎会在那里等待，这位大胆的年轻人坐在飞马上，会立即亲吻她的嘴唇”（Af. 105 b）。这是一个常见的、非随机的承诺公式：“无论谁亲吻我的女儿，贝尔维塞托公主，骑马飞到三楼，我都会嫁给她”（Af. 106 a）。在这些情况下，英雄展示了他拥有并非每个人都拥有的手段：他展示了他的魔法装备。 “去我不知道的地方，给我带来我不知道的东西”的企业也是同一团体的一部分（Af. 122）。英雄被派遣的国家是遥远的王国，“我不知道的事情”是一个已经成为禁忌的名字，它不是公开发音的，而是隐喻性的。这个隐喻对于英雄来说仍然难以理解，直到他找到了一个帮手。

In such cases the hero does not set out on a second journey; usually he does not go looking for the objects required (although this sometimes happens), but he makes them, he makes them. Thus another aspect of difficult tasks comes to light. Who can accomplish the task? These tasks are not feasible in themselves. The hero does them only because he has a helper. From this we see that tasks must prove not only whether the hero has been in the realm of the afterlife, but also whether he has acquired a helper there; and, in fact, we can observe that many tasks openly aim to verify whether the hero has a helper. This can be seen, for example, also from certain formulations: "Who helps him?" or "Surely the spirits will do this for King Ivan." In the chapter on helpers we have already seen what the horse's function is and how the hero procures it. Many tasks aim to discover whether the hero possesses a magic horse and whether he knows how to use it. This group includes, for example, the feat of training (Af. 116 c) or taming a horse (Af. 125 P), of chasing a colt (Af. 125) or of procuring seventy-seven mares (Af. 103), and one can also include that of kissing the princess while riding a horse (Af. 105). It is no coincidence that this last feat is formulated in the following way: « Helen the Beautiful ordered that a temple be built for her on twelve columns and twelve beams; … there she will await her husband, the bold young man who, riding a flying horse, will kiss her on the lips at first sight » (Af. 105 b). This is a common, not casual, formula of the quest: "To whoever kisses my daughter, Princess Bel Visetto, flying on a horse to the third floor, I will give her as a wife" (Af. 106 a). In these cases the hero demonstrates that he possesses means that not everyone possesses: he demonstrates his magical equipment. The quest "Go where I do not know, bring me what I do not know" (Af. 122) also belongs to the same group. The country where the hero is sent is the distant kingdom and "what I do not know" is a name that has become taboo, which is not pronounced openly, but metaphorically. This metaphor remains incomprehensible to the hero until he has acquired a helper.

13.宫殿、花园、桥梁。

13. The palace , the garden , the bridge .

我们常常会遇到一个由三项不同的工作组合而成的团体：一夜之间种园、播种、种植和磨粮，一夜之间建造一座金色宫殿和一座通向它的桥梁。这些壮举有时与已知的训练或驯服马匹以及其他壮举相结合。

Very often one comes across a group of three differently combined enterprises: planting a garden, sowing, growing and grinding wheat in one night, building a golden palace and a bridge to it in one night. These enterprises are sometimes combined with the already known one of training or taming a horse and also with others.

我们先来分析一下这座建筑。有时，它不是一座宫殿，而是一座教堂（《诗篇》35），而且必须用纯蜡建造（《诗篇》1），或者它是一座房屋（《诗篇》34），甚至是一个粮仓（《AF》199）。 126）等都是金殿的变形，最后这一种形态，也是出现频率最高的一种。有时，三项任务（宫殿、桥梁、花园）被总结为一项任务：“确保明天黎明时分，距离大海七俄里的地方，黄金王国崛起，并在它和我们的宫殿之间架起一座桥梁。 “黄金，那座桥用昂贵的天鹅绒装饰，栏杆两侧生长着奇妙的树木，鸟儿用不同的声音歌唱。如果明天你不这样做，我就会命令你分尸”（《箴言》71）。

Let us first analyze the palace. Sometimes it is not a palace, but a church (Sm. 35) that must be built, and, what's more, of pure wax (Sev. 1), or it is a house (Sm. 34), or again a granary (Aph. 126), etc. These are all deformations of the golden palace, and this last form is also the one that occurs most frequently. Sometimes the three enterprises (palace, bridge, garden) are summarized in one: "See that tomorrow at dawn, at the seventh verst from the sea, the kingdom of gold arises, and that between it and our palace a golden bridge is erected, that this bridge is covered with costly velvet, and that on both sides of the parapet beautiful trees grow, and that birds sing in different voices. If you do not do this by tomorrow, I will give orders to quarter you" (Aph. 71).

一夜之间建造一座宫殿的壮举本身就令人难以理解。这个主题本身无法被理解：但金色宫殿的主题可以通过矗立在遥远王国的金色宫殿来理解。这是同一栋楼。我们在上一章中对其进行了分析，认识到了“大房子”的特征。因此可以推断，建造宫殿的工程与“大房子”有某种联系，但目前尚不清楚这种联系具体是什么。这里可能发生了意义的转换；为了解决这个问题，我们要回到“大房子”历史存在阶段的资料。在海洋神话中，女孩被神灵带走，与他同住，生下一个儿子，并带着孩子回家；他的同龄人嘲笑他的出身，并指责他没有父亲。女孩把儿子送到他父亲那里。 （在这一切中，很容易看出女孩住在树林里的房子里，在那里她生了孩子，然后又回到了家）。 « 他开始住在精灵的房子里，当他长大后，精灵对他说：“现在我们去找你的母亲吧”。他们来到一个非常热的地方，男孩拒绝继续前进。神魂拉着他的手，开始吹气。他们继续走，来到一个地方，天气很冷，男孩再次拒绝继续前进。神灵把它放在腋下，温暖起来。终于，他们来到了灵母的住所。他宣称他来是为了让男孩拥有该地点两栋房屋之一的所有权。灵母说：“好吧”【即她同意赠予两栋房子中的一间】。房子建在七块石头上，周围有七道栅栏，并配有各种王冠。 “现在去那栋房子里睡觉吧，”鬼魂说道。 “半夜我会来叫醒你；然后你必须决定你想让我把你的房子搬到哪里“。当男孩睡觉的时候，房子从地里升起，来到了地表。”后来这个男孩成为部落的首领。他的脚一踏上梯子的台阶，雷声就隆隆作响534。

The undertaking of building a palace in one night is, in itself, incomprehensible. This motif cannot be understood by itself; but the motif of the golden palace can be understood through the golden palace that stands in the distant kingdom. It is the same palace. We have analyzed it in the preceding chapter and have recognized in it the characteristics of the "great house." We can therefore deduce that the undertaking of building the palace is connected in some way with the "great house," but at present it is not clear what the connection consists of. Here probably a transposition of meaning has taken place; to solve this problem let us turn to the materials concerning the "great house" at the stage of its historical existence. In an Oceanic myth the girl is carried away by the spirit, lives with him, gives birth to a son and returns home with her child; his peers mock him because of his origin, and reproach him for having no father. The girl sends her son to the father. (In all this it is easy to recognize the girl's stay in the house in the woods where she gives birth to a son, and her return home.) « He began to live in the house of the spirit and, when he was quite grown up, the spirit said to him: “Now let's go to your mother”. They came to a place where it was terribly hot and the boy refused to go any further. The spirit took him by the hand and began to blow. They continued walking and came to a place where it was very cold and the boy again refused to go any further. The spirit put him under her armpits and warmed him. Finally they came to the home of the mother of the spirit. The spirit declared that he had come to give the boy ownership of one of the two houses that stood on that site. The mother of the spirit said: “All right” [that is, she agrees to give one of the two houses]. The house stood on seven stone squares and was surrounded by seven fences and furnished with crowns of all kinds. “Now go and sleep in that house,” said the spirit. “At midnight I will come to wake you; then you must decide where you would like me to move your house.” While the boy slept the house rose up through the earth and came to the surface. Later the boy becomes the chief of the tribe. As he sets foot on the steps of the ladder the thunder rumbles . 534

我们试着分析一下这个例子：有一点是明确无疑的，那就是居住在“大房子”里；在这里，孩子学会控制元素。当他被热和冷引导时，他不仅保持麻木不仁，而且成为这些元素的主宰。说实话，这并没有公开表达，但另一方面，据说男孩回来后就掌管了雷霆。所以，在成为部落首领之前，男孩就带着这个能力，也带着整个房子。在这个男孩身上，我们可以认出世界的秩序者。是他给人类带来了雷霆，也给了他们“房子”，即社会秩序，正如在其他文本中他给人类带来了舞蹈和图画，并教导他们神圣的习俗一样。我们可以相信，这是在仪式期间向新入会者讲述的一个神话，向他们解释他们所遭受的行为。

Let us try to analyze this example: one thing is clear and indubitable, namely the dwelling in the "great house"; there the boy learns to govern the elements. When he is led through the heat and the cold, not only does he remain insensitive, but he becomes the master of these elements. To tell the truth, this is not expressed openly, but on the other hand it is said that on his return the boy governs the thunder. So, before becoming the chief of the tribe, the boy brings this ability with him, and he also brings the whole house with him. In this boy we can recognize the organizer of the world. It is he who gives thunder to men and also gives them the "house", that is, the social order, just as in other texts he brings dances and drawings to men and teaches them sacred customs. We can assume that it is a myth that was told to the newly initiated during the rite, to explain to them the acts to which they were subjected.

我们相信，在世界上完全不同的地方，即北美，记录的文本有可能做出这样的解释。在其中一个故事中，男孩九次升入天空，每次都带回一些东西：鸟、浆果、动物等，也就是说，他将这些东西带给人类，他将它们建立在地球上。他第十次失踪，再也没有回来。每个人都在哀悼他，他的母亲做了一个梦：“她似乎在梦中看到了一栋宏伟的房子，但当她醒来时，她发现她以为的梦是现实。房子就在那里，她的儿子梅莉亚坐在她面前。”女人叫醒了她的丈夫，他们看着房子，跑向它，但当他们靠近时，房子就移开了，“最后他们意识到自己在高高的天空中。然后他们坐下来，哭着开始唱：“我们的儿子在天堂，正在玩月亮。”孙女建议他出现在我们的舞蹈中。从那时起，梅利亚之舞就开始了” 535。

The possibility of such an interpretation is convinced by texts recorded in a completely different part of the world, namely North America. In one of them the boy ascends to heaven nine times and each time brings back something: a bird, berries, animals, etc., that is, he brings these things to men, establishes them on earth. The tenth time he disappears and never comes back. Everyone mourns him and his mother has a dream: "She thought she saw in her dream a magnificent house, but when she awoke she realized that what she had thought was a dream was reality. The house was there and her son Melia was sitting in front of her." The woman wakes her husband, they look at the house, run toward it, but as they get closer it moves away "and finally they realized they were up high in the sky. Then they sat down, cried and began to sing: 'Our son is in heaven, playing with the moon.'" The granddaughter suggests that we make him appear in our dances. Since that time the dance of Melia has been danced » 535 .

在本文中，我们更加清楚地认识到世界、社会组织和人类习俗的秩序者。英雄给人类带来了房子，但他是“隐形的”，他是“在天上”的，也就是说，他是被保密的，被禁忌的，他是“在另一个世界的”。博阿斯注意到了这个传说与仪式（即部落的社会生活）之间的联系，并且从传说的尾声中可以明显看出。我们报告了一个类似的案例，记录在同一个部落。英雄去河里钓鲑鱼，但一条鱼也没找到。他陷入昏迷，看到了一个美丽的男人：他就是那个发出雷声的人，“他从世界的一端轰鸣到另一端”。英雄向他索要一件神奇的宝藏，对方回答说：“建造一座房子，并邀请所有部落。”他向他展示了双腿张开的雷鸟雕刻图像，并说道：“他的腿是房子的门”；然后他向他展示了他父亲的雕刻肖像。 “明天晚上，这一切都会发生在你的村子里。”他还赐给他生命水和其他东西。

In this text we perceive with even greater clarity the organizer of the world, of the social organization and of the customs of men. The hero brings the house to men, but he is "invisible", he is "in the heavens", that is, he is kept secret, made taboo, he is "in the other world". The connection between this legend and the rites, that is, the social life of the tribe, is highlighted by Boas and is evident from the epilogue of the legend. We report a similar case, recorded in the same tribe. The hero goes fishing for salmon up the river, but does not find a single fish. He falls into a swoon and sees a very beautiful man: he is the one who produces the thunder, "the one who resounds from one end of the world to the other". The hero asks him for a magic treasure, and the other answers: "Build a house and invite all the tribes". He shows him a carved image of the thunderbird with its legs spread apart and says, "Its legs are the door of the house." He then shows him a carved image of his father. "Next night all this will be in your village." He also gives him the water of life and other things.

在所有这些情况下，宫殿与雕刻图像和护身符一起奇迹般地转移到英雄的村庄，即建立了崇拜。在上面的例子中，房子是由产生雷声的人或“精灵”的意志转移的，在童话故事中，这是通过帮助者发生的。在童话故事中，宫殿的转移不仅是一件困难的事情。主角把它放在一个鸡蛋里随身携带。 “最后他们从桌子上站起来，她把他带到了一片美丽的空地，她打破了鸡蛋，一座宫殿形成了，在那座宫殿里，一切都像以前一样，就像在那座山上一样”（K.12）。所引用的材料使我们有可能确认，通过要求带人参观房子，国王隐喻地要求英雄提供他知道这所房子的证据。另一方面，这里的童话故事反映了世界秩序者赋予人类所拥有的一切的故事。随后，我们将反复认识到英雄是世界的秩序者，特别是在这项事业的后半部分，在要求种植花园或犁地和播种田地时。

In all these cases the palace is miraculously transferred to the hero's village together with carved images and amulets, that is, a cult is established. In the above-mentioned examples the house is transferred by the will of the thunderer or a "spirit", in the fairy tale it happens by virtue of the helper. In the fairy tale the transfer of the palace is not only seen as a difficult undertaking. The hero takes it with him in an egg. "And finally they rose from the table, and she led him to a beautiful clearing, and broke the egg, and a palace was formed, and in that palace everything was as before, as on that mountain" (K. 12). The materials cited enable us to assert that, by asking to be shown the house, the king metaphorically asks the hero for proof that he knows it. On the other hand, here the fairy tale is a reflection of the stories about the orderers of the world who have given man everything he has. Later we will repeatedly recognize in the hero an orderer of the world, and in particular in the second half of this enterprise, in the request to plant a garden or to plough and sow a field.

在上述文本中，我们看到神话英雄不仅是地球上房屋的建立者，而且还为人类带来浆果和动物。在童话故事中，宫殿的建造几乎总是与统治自然的能力联系在一起，但这种能力已经呈现出农业的特征。 “一夜之间，犁地、分选种子、播种小麦、收割、研磨并放入粮仓”（Af. 125 克）。 “他必须在一夜之间犁地，分选种子，播种，让一切生长，让它成熟，磨碎谷物，制作面包”（Sev.1）。这一壮举在许多版本中都有体现。在其他地方，英雄也受到考验，看看他是否具有催收的美德。这正是农业初期对巫师的要求。 «在雅浦岛上，当地人相信神圣树林的牧师或魔法师拥有影响大地某些果实生产的神奇美德，因此直接为人类的维持做出贡献。例如，托米的大祭司或大巫师被认为能够加速芋头的收获和整个岛上面包果种植园的生长。在《Ologi》和《Pernogo》中，牧师或魔术师知道甘薯的魔力；在马基，他是椰子和棕榈树魔法方面的专家。这些祭司还可以使太阳落在大地上” 536。让我们看看未来的领袖和国王会带来什么技能。即使是童话故事也没有完全忘记指挥太阳和天体元素的能力。 “我不会嫁给他……先向他要红日白月，半夜浓星。”英雄“制造”了这一切，并“交付”了这一切，即他就地建立了这一切。

In the above texts we have seen that the mythical hero is not only the founder of the house on earth, but also brings berries and animals to men. In the fairy tale, the building of the palace is almost always associated with the ability to govern nature, but this ability has taken on an agricultural character. "In a single night he must plough and sort the seed, sow the wheat, reap it, grind it and store it in the granary" (Af. 125 g).
