But since this case contradicts social morality, the involuntary nature of the action is inserted and the old order of things is also preserved, according to which the successor is a foreigner. In order for him to remain a foreigner, he must be separated from his father, and here the oracle comes into play. It is appropriate to point out at this point that the difficult undertaking has also been preserved; Oedipus solves the riddle of the Sphinx. But the undertaking, originally a demonstration of magical power, has transformed itself into the liberation of the people from a calamity. The right to the throne is conditioned by this liberation and not by magical power. When power passed from father-in-law to son-in-law, the death of the old king was a pre-established fact and did not require any oracle. But when power passes from father to son, the death of the king (father) at the hands of his successor (son) becomes something unnatural or dishonest and is motivated complementarily by the will of the gods and by fate. This is also seen from the fact that oracles more often concern grandchildren and sons than sons-in-law. Perseus' grandfather had been foretold that he would lose his throne at the hands of a grandson, Laius that he would perish at the hands of his son, Pelias that he would yield the kingdom to a hero with only one sandal: in this hero he recognizes a grandson, that is, a representative of his lineage.

这些案件后来在童话故事中的反映非常微弱，童话故事反而保留了古老的情况：英雄杀死了他的岳父，结婚并在没有任何神谕的情况下掌权。如果预言不是指父子，而是指岳父和女婿，那么这个童话故事就包含了一些不太古老的特征。这就是富人马克的故事，它与其说是童话，不如说是传奇。在这个故事的一个版本中，我们读到：“他取代了这个庄园的主人”（Sm.242），但对于民俗学者来说，这意味着：“他取代了这个领域的国王。”在德国民间传说中，童话的主角不是商人，而是国王。 “从前，有一个贫穷的女人生了一个儿子，自从他出生时就穿着一件衬衫，他们就向他预言，他十四岁时会娶国王的女儿”（格林，23）。国王想尽一切办法消灭英雄。这些案例表明，国王死于其继任者之手是事先已知的，而在童话故事中，就像在历史现实中一样，这种情况是通过神谕之口表达的；当人们开始不再清楚这种形式的国王更替的必要性时，神谕就出现了。

These later cases have very weak repercussions in the fairy tale, which instead preserves the archaic situation: the hero kills his father-in-law, marries and assumes power without any oracle. If the prophecy refers not to father and son, but to father-in-law and son-in-law, the fairy tale contains traits of less ancient origin. Such is the fairy tale of Mark the Rich, which has the character of a legend rather than a fairy tale. In one version of this story we read: "He replaces the master on this estate" (Sm. 242), but for the folklore scholar this means: "He replaces the king on this realm". In German folklore the protagonist of the fairy tale is not a merchant, but a king. "Once upon a time there was a poor woman who gave birth to a son, and because he was born with a caul it was foretold to him that at the age of fourteen he would marry the king's daughter" (Grimm, 23). The king tries in every way to eliminate the hero. These cases illustrate the observation that the death of the king at the hands of his successor was known from beforehand and that in the fairy tale, as in historical reality, this situation was expressed by the mouth of oracles; the oracle appears when the necessity of this form of replacement of the king begins to be no longer clear in the conscience of men.

25.童话中国王被杀。

25. The killing of the king in the fairy tale .

但童话里真的有老国王死后把权力交给女婿的事吗？乍一看，事情似乎并不完全是这样：冲突是和平解决的；国王将一半的王国交给了他的女婿，他们继续统治，没有人被杀。或者，在娶了国王的女儿之后，英雄平静地等待着他的岳父的死亡，只有在他登上王位之后。或者英雄继续作为一种寄生虫生活在国王身边。还有其他形式可以避免或减弱这种冲突，但它们都无法向我们隐藏事实的真相。首先，英雄获得了整个王国，其次，当这种情况发生时，老国王被杀了。

But does it really happen in the fairy tale that the old king dies and hands over power to his son-in-law? At first glance it seems that this is not the case: the conflict is settled peacefully; the king hands over half of the kingdom to his son-in-law and both continue to reign, no one is killed. Or, after marrying the king's daughter, the hero calmly awaits the death of his father-in-law, and only then does he ascend to the throne. Or again, the hero continues to live with the king as a kind of parasite. There are other ways in which this conflict is avoided or attenuated, but none of them can hide the true state of affairs from us. First, the hero gets the entire kingdom; second, when this happens, the old king is killed.

在童话故事中，英雄得到整个王国，而不仅仅是一半，这是一个很常见的事实，不需要证明。以下是一些例子：“他将自己的女儿赐给了伊凡·格鲁鲁斯，并把他的全部王国也赐给了他”（《诗篇》221）。 “他把他的全部王国都赐给了他”（Chud.1）。 “他会将他的整个王国赐给任何为他提供王国的人”（ZV 114）。 “神将他的天下都赐给他”（弗 107），等等。这些例子保留了原始的和历史证明的形式，而“半王国”是后来童话故事的替代品。

That in the fairy tale the hero receives the whole kingdom and not only half of it is such a common fact that it does not need to be proved. Here are some examples: "And to Ivan the Dummling he gave his daughter, and he gave him also all his kingdom" (Sm. 221). "And he gave him all his kingdom" (Chud. 1). "To him who gets it for him he will give all his kingdom" (ZV 114). "He gave him all his kingdom" (Af. 107), etc. These examples retain the original and historically attested form, while the "half kingdom" is a later fairy-tale substitution.

杀死国王也是如此。童话故事试图掩盖或淡化这种情况，但并没有完全成功。童话里的国王是怎么被杀的？有时他会被魔法物品杀死：在这种情况下，英雄的魔法武器就是国王死亡的原因。 “自弹古筝”可以用于此目的。 « 格鲁洛人用一朵花堵住了他的耳朵，走向国王并弹奏了他的七弦琴。奏乐一开始，国王、他的贵族和宫廷侍卫就都睡着了。格鲁洛人从墙上拔下一把大马士革剑并杀死了国王”（Af. 123 B/2）。 « “嘿，俱乐部，击败，击败！ „ 棍棒击中了一两次，杀死了坏国王。愚者成为国王并长期仁慈地统治”（Af. 123）。国王因为不好而被淘汰的事实并没有改变。在同一个童话故事的一个变体中，吞食之狼突然出现并吞噬了国王。这只狼是英雄的帮手，在功能上相当于仙女的物品：棍棒、烟斗等。 “格鲁洛成为了国王，并与他美丽的王后和狼幸福地生活在一起。”阿法纳西耶夫的童话《第 122 章》为我们提供了一个特别有趣的案例。其中老国王死于敌军之手：“国王看到他的军队逃跑，急忙去阻止，但他能做什么呢？不到半个小时，他们也杀了他。战斗结束后，人们聚集在一起，开始乞求弓箭手接管整个国家。他同意了，成为国王，他的妻子成为王后。”这个案子的有趣之处在于，将国王交给敌军来杀害国王，在现实中也遇到过：这是杀害国王的形式之一，虽然出现得很晚，但已经构成了向各种妥协的过渡。这种习俗在安哥拉中部实行，那里的国王有马蒂亚姆沃的头衔。一支葡萄牙探险队报道了一位土著人的以下故事：“我们有这样的习俗：我们的马蒂亚姆沃死于战争或暴力死亡；我们现在的马蒂亚姆沃将不得不以第二种方式死去，因为他已经活得够久了。当我们决定必须杀死马蒂亚姆沃时，我们建议他向我们的敌人宣战，我们和他的家人一起陪他参加战争......如果马蒂亚姆沃没有受到伤害，我们就回去战争并为之而战三四天，然后我们突然抛弃了马蒂亚姆沃和他的家人，将他们留在敌人手中» 563。在这些情况下，国王和他的部下一起自杀。即使童话与现实之间没有直接的依赖关系，这个案例也展示了现在与新事实相矛盾的习俗（或主题）如何根据这些事实改变外观。童话和故事都导致国王在战争中丧生，这种形式取代了通过勒死或其他方式杀死国王的旧形式。

The same can be said of the killing of the king. The fairy tale tries to hide or to tone down this circumstance, but it does not succeed entirely. How is the king killed in the fairy tale? Sometimes he is killed by means of magical objects: in this case the hero's magic weapon is the cause of the king's death. Self-playing lyres can be used for this purpose. "The Simpleton stopped his ears with a flower, went to the king and made his lyre play. As soon as he began to play, the king and his boyars and the court guards all fell asleep; the Simpleton took a damask sword from the wall and killed the king" (Af. 123 B/2). "'Hey, cudgel, strike, beat!' The cudgel swung, struck once or twice and killed the wicked king. And the Simpleton became king and reigned long and benignly" (Af. 123). The fact that the king is eliminated here because he is evil does not change anything. In a variant of this same tale, the All-Swallowing Wolf suddenly appears and devours the king. This wolf is the hero's assistant and is functionally equivalent to fairy objects: clubs, fifes, etc. "The Simpleton became king and lived a long and happy life together with his beautiful queen and the wolf." A particularly interesting case is offered by Afanasiev's tale 122a. In it, the old king perishes at the hands of the enemy army: "The king saw that his army was fleeing and rushed to stop it, but what was to be done? Not half an hour had passed when they killed him too. At the end of the battle, the people gathered and began to beg the archer to take over the entire state. He agreed, became king, and his wife became queen." The case is interesting because the killing of the king by handing him over to the enemy army is also encountered in reality: it is one of the forms of killing the king, it appears late and already constitutes a transition to compromises of all kinds. This custom was practiced in central Angola where the king has the title of matiamvo . A Portuguese expedition reports the following story of a native: «We have the custom that our matiamvo die in war or by a violent death; our current matiamvo will have to die in the second way, because he has already lived enough. When we decide that the matiamvo must be killed, we propose to him to declare war on our enemies, and we all accompany him to war together with his family… If the matiamvo remains unharmed, we go back to war and fight for three or four days, then suddenly we abandon the matiamvo and his family and leave them in the hands of the enemy» 563. In these cases the king kills himself and his followers. Although there is no direct relationship of dependence between fairy tale and reality, this case shows how a custom (or a motif) that is now in contradiction with new facts, changes aspect in accordance with these facts. Both fairy tale and history have the king perish in war, and this form replaces the older one of killing the king by strangulation or other means.

但这些减弱的妥协形式并不是强制性的。也有公开杀害老国王的情况。 “父亲说：‘现在砍下我的头吧。’但士兵回答说：“我不能砍下你的头。”国王的女儿抓起剑说道：“国王的话永不改变！ “然后他砍下了自己的头”（ZV 105）。 « 然后她拿起军刀砍下了国王的头，然后抓住牧童的耳朵，吻了他的嘴唇。 “你将成为我的丈夫，我将成为你的妻子”（《SM》30）。

But these attenuated forms of compromise are not obligatory. There are also cases in which the old king is killed openly. «The father said: “Now cut off my head”. But the little soldier answered: “I cannot cut off your head”. The king’s daughter seized her sword and said: “A king’s word never changes!” And she cut off his head» (ZV 105). «And she took her sword and cut off the king’s head, then she took the shepherd boy by the ear and kissed him on the lips. “You shall be my husband and I will be your wife” » (Sm. 30).

26.假英雄。

26. The false hero .

由此可见，老国王的死绝不是一个例外。然而，这个案件与既定的父子继承制相矛盾，这也许可以解释为什么试图避免老国王的死亡。另一方面，在童话故事中还有另一种方式来解决这种情况，这种方式在历史上不再符合叙述者本人所生活的时代的现实。在英雄登上王位之前不久，在故事的结尾处插入了一个意想不到的新角色：一位将军，一位普通的领导者，在与蛇的决斗中隐藏在灌木丛后面，后来获得了所有胜利的功劳。无论是在历史现实中，还是在信仰、仪式和神话领域，我们都找不到这个形象，因此我们必须将其视为纯粹的童话形式，是在童话本身的基础上产生的。在我们看来，这个形象是一种“替罪羊”，它是根据相同的原则创造的，在此基础上，在仪式和民间传说领域也出现了类似的替代人物。这个角色的作用在于承担起国王从一开始就注定的死亡、惩罚和谋杀。登上王位、婚姻、某人的死亡、某人的杀戮的复杂性，通过将杀戮从一个角色转移到另一个角色而被保留下来，这是专门创造的。

We see, therefore, that the death of the old king is by no means an exception. However, this case contradicts the succession from father to son that has now been established and this may explain the attempts to avoid the death of the old king. On the other hand, in the fairy tale there is another way of getting around this situation that no longer corresponds historically to the reality of the time in which the narrator himself lives. A little before the hero ascends to the throne, at the very end of the tale a new and unexpected character is introduced: a general, an ordinary leader who hides behind a bush during the duel with the snake and later takes all the credit for the victory. We do not find this image either in historical reality or in the field of beliefs, rites and myths, so we must consider it a purely fairy-tale formation that arose on the terrain of the fairy tale itself. It seems to us that this image is a kind of "scapegoat" and that it was created according to the same principles on the basis of which similar substitute characters also arose in the field of rites and folklore. The function of this character is to take upon himself the death, punishment, and murder that were originally intended for the king. The complex of the accession to the throne, of marriage, of someone's death, of someone's killing, is preserved here by transferring the killing from one character to another, created for this purpose.

27.索桥。

27. The rope bridge .

有时国王会以不同的方式死去：他被要求用绳子或杆子穿过一个坑，然后他就会跌倒。通常此案与英雄带美人入国的主题有关。国王想娶她，但英雄不同意，说道：“我挖了一个深坑，用一根杆子穿过；谁过去了，谁就带走公主。” “好吧，瓦尼莎！你开始吧！ “英雄越过深渊，老王却掉进深渊”（AF.77）。

Sometimes the king dies in a different way: he is asked to cross a pit by a rope or a pole, and he falls. Usually this case is connected with the motif of the hero who brings a beautiful woman into the kingdom. The king wants to marry her, but the hero does not consent and says: “I have dug a deep pit, crossed by a pole; whoever steps over it will take the princess.” “All right, Vaniusa! You go first!” The hero crosses the pit, but the old king falls into it” (Af. 77).

在这里，我们需要研究薄桥本身的原因及其在本案例中的应用。这个主题的起源并不难发现。大量的材料证明，它源自这样一种表述，根据这种表述，死者的王国与生者的王国被一座细桥分开，有时是用头发制成的，死者或死者的灵魂可以通过这座桥。谢夫特洛维茨（ARW，XIV）在这座“地狱桥”上收集了特别丰富的材料。在印加印第安人中，死者前往“哑巴之地”，必须在狗的帮助下通过发桥过河564。在北美，有一座桥搁在水牛头上565。有趣的是，无论如何，桥的主题几乎总是包含一种动物。即使在爱斯基摩人中，我们也发现了一座像刀片一样薄的桥，穿过深渊到达死亡之地566。这种表述非常普遍567。这个形象在帕斯主义中特别突出。 « 死后第四天日出时，灵魂到达钦瓦特桥附近的审判地点。在它传到另一边之前，邪灵就提出了他们的控告。善行和恶行都有精确的天平衡量，灵魂才能跨过那座危险的桥……正义的灵魂在体现善行的美丽女孩的带领下，在守桥的好狗的陪伴下，快乐地过桥。 。然后它进入了天堂，最后到达了阿胡拉-马自达的金色王座……但是邪恶的灵魂找不到任何人来帮助他们，他们在桥上绊了一跤，掉进了深渊，邪恶的恶魔抓住了他们，将他们带到黑暗的地方» 568。

Here we must examine the motif of the thin bridge as such and its application to the case in question. The origin of this motif is not difficult to discover; a considerable amount of material proves that it derives from the idea that the realm of the dead is separated from that of the living by a thin bridge, sometimes made of hair, across which the dead or the souls of the dead pass. Particularly abundant material on this "infernal bridge" has been collected by Scheftelowitz (ARW, XIV). Among the Inca Indians the dead go to the "land of the mute" and have to cross a river on a bridge of hair, with the help of a dog . 564 In North America there is a representation of the bridge resting on the head of a buffalo . 565 It is interesting to note that, in one way or another, the motif of the bridge almost always contains an animal. Among the Eskimos, too, we find a bridge as thin as a blade leading across an abyss to the land of the dead . 566 Such representations are very widespread 567 . This image has a particular prominence in Parsism. « On the fourth day after death at sunrise the soul reaches the place of judgment at the Tschinvat bridge. Before it crosses to the other side the evil spirits present their accusations. The good and evil deeds are weighed on exact scales, then the soul can cross the dangerous bridge… The righteous soul crosses it happily, led by a beautiful girl who embodies its good deeds and accompanied by the good dogs that guard the bridge. Then it enters paradise and finally reaches the golden throne of Ahura-Mazda… But the evil souls find no one to help them, they stumble on the hair-thin bridge and fall into the abyss where an evil demon seizes them and carries them to a place of darkness » 568 .

甚至童话故事中的桥也是这些相同表征的反映：它很薄，由头发制成，很滑，下面有一个深渊。

Even the bridge in the fairy tale is a reflection of these same representations: it is thin, made of hair, it is slippery, and underneath it there is an abyss.

但这种表现与国王被杀有什么关系呢？在我们看来，所引用的材料使我们能够得出以下结论：通过微妙桥梁的通道发生在死后。其次，没有帮助者，最初是畜生性，后来是善行化身，就会堕入深渊。在宗教表述中是死亡的结果，在童话故事中则是死亡的原因。可以认为，国王被杀了，也可能认为，由于他缺乏魔法力量（正是因为这个原因，他被杀了），所以他无法过桥，掉进了深渊。

But how is this representation connected with the murder of the king? It seems to us that the materials cited allow us to formulate the following conclusion: the passage across the thin bridge takes place after death. Secondly, those who fall into the abyss are those who are deprived of helpers, who at first have an animal character and later assume the form of an incarnation of good deeds. What in religious representations is the consequence of death, in the fairy tale appears as the cause of death. One can believe that the king was killed, and probably it was believed that, since he was devoid of magical power (he was killed for this very reason), he could not cross the bridge and fell into the abyss.

童话故事将这一时刻转移到生活的背景中，并将死亡的后果转化为死亡的原因。从艺术上来说，这种转移是完全合理的，因为它包含了对老国王的谴责，它展示了他的弱点，他缺乏敏捷性，这是他魔法弱点的回声。

The tale transfers this moment into the sphere of life and transforms the consequences of death into the cause of death. Artistically speaking, this transfer is fully justified, since it contains the condemnation of the old king, demonstrates his weakness, his lack of agility, is an echo of his magical weakness.

28.煮牛奶。

28. Boiling milk .

除了桥上的考验之外，童话故事还呈现了另一种将老国王引向死亡的考验。我们想谈谈煮牛奶测试。 « “我们还不能结婚：你老了，我还年轻；我知道一个可以让你年轻的办法：叫人把两只大锅搬到院子里，一只盛满羊奶，一只盛满水，准备好今晚的一切。”伊凡沐浴在牛奶中，变得美丽而健壮，无法形容，但国王却在锅炉里被烫伤了”（《圣训》321）。

In addition to the test of the bridge, the tale presents another that leads the old king to death; we want to talk about the test of the boiling milk. "We cannot yet marry: you are old and I am young; I know a way that will make you young: have two cauldrons brought into the courtyard, one full of goat's milk and the other of water, and let everything be ready by this evening". Ivan bathed in the milk and became beautiful and strong beyond description, but the king ended up scalded in the cauldrons" (Sm. 321).

这个主题看起来不如吊桥那么清晰。首先，有隐秘的迹象表明国王在被杀之前接受了沐浴仪式。例如，在奎拉卡尔省（印度南部），祭司国王统治十二年，之后举行盛宴。 “国王下令搭建一个覆盖着丝绸的木平台，然后在音乐和豪华的游行的陪伴下在浴缸中沐浴”。仪式结束时，国王在平台上自杀，割掉了自己的鼻子、耳朵、嘴唇和身体的肉，然后将其扔向人群，仿佛将自己作为祭品，最后，第569章他割断了喉咙然而，这可能是当地的习俗，而洗澡或多或少是一个偶然的事实。另一方面，我们有资料表明，死者的灵魂在地狱中要接受一次沐浴（准确地说是两次沐浴，就像童话故事中那样）。例如，根据印第安人的说法，地狱之王卡蒂奥斯有两个桶：一个装满开水，另一个装满冷水。如果“黑魂”（即罪魂）经过两次浴后变成白色，就可以进入天堂；否则，她将被判处多年辛苦工作570。

This motif seems less clear than that of the suspension bridge. First of all, there are veiled indications that before being killed the king was subjected to a ritual bath. Thus, for example, in the province of Kwilakar (southern India) the priest-king reigns for twelve years, after which a feast is given. "The king gives the order to prepare a wooden platform covered with silk, then he goes to bathe in a tub, accompanied by music and a sumptuous procession." At the end of this ceremony the king kills himself on the platform by cutting off his nose, ears, lips and the fleshy parts of his body, which he throws to the crowd as if to offer himself as a sacrifice and, finally, he cuts his throat . 569 However, it may be that this is a local custom and that the bath is a more or less accidental fact. On the other hand, we have materials according to which in hell the soul of the dead was subjected to a bath (and precisely to two baths, as in the tale). Thus, for example, according to the representations of the Indians, the king of hell Katios had two buckets: one full of boiling water, the other of cold water. If the "black soul" (that is, the sinful soul) after passing through the two baths became white, it could enter heaven; otherwise it was condemned to hard labor for many years 570 .

这些材料将我们带回到微妙桥梁所属的同一表征循环。但这些证言和童话故事还是有区别的：这里有水，而童话里大部分是牛奶。上面提到的情况是羊奶，有时是马奶，有时没有指定奶的质量。谁喝了这乳，谁就变美丽；英雄出来很漂亮。但经过马耳时也变得美丽起来。在这里，我们展示了一种可以恢复活力和净化的沐浴，但与此同时，我们还看到了这种沐浴与通过动物的通道之间的联系。在俄罗斯童话中，英雄穿过马的耳朵，而在格鲁吉亚童话中，他必须沐浴在海底的马奶中571。在同一个童话故事中，老国王在大锅里被烫伤，但当英雄把自己浸入牛奶中时，马从耳朵里吸出雪，撒到牛奶中，使牛奶冷却。因此我们不得不得出这样的结论：这个母题的基础是英雄的变形、神化。老国王的死因被人为地与他联系在一起。众所周知，凡是到达死者王国的人都会经历变形，在这里我们有这种表现的反映。

These materials bring us back to the same cycle of representations to which the thin bridge belongs. But there is still a difference between these testimonies and the fairy tale: here we have water, while in the fairy tale it is mostly milk. In the case cited above it is goat's milk, sometimes it is mare's milk, sometimes the quality of the milk is not specified. Whoever passes through this milk becomes beautiful; the hero emerges from it beautiful. But he also becomes beautiful when he passes through the horse's ears. Here we have the representation of a bath that rejuvenates and purifies, but at the same time we also see a connection between this bath and the passage through an animal. In the Russian fairy tale the hero passes through the horse's ears, while in a Georgian fairy tale he has to bathe in the milk of horses that live at the bottom of the sea . 571 In the same fairy tale the old king is scalded in the cauldron, but when the hero immerses himself in the milk, the horse draws snow from its ears and sprinkles it into the milk, cooling it. We are therefore forced to conclude that the basis of this motif is the transfiguration, the apotheosis of the hero. The motif of the death of the old king has been artificially associated with him. It is well known that those who arrive in the realm of the dead undergo a transfiguration and here we have a reflection of this representation.

29.结论。

29. Conclusion .

从我们的解释中可以得出哪些推论？不能说所有的细节都完全清楚，但无论如何，有一件事是明确的：英雄与老国王之间的王位之争完全是历史现象。这个童话故事反映了权力通过一个女人、通过她的女儿从岳父到女婿的转移。他还向我们展示了其他东西：在获得公主的手和王位之前，女婿经历了一项实验，必须证明他已经完成了所有的训练。这个实验具有婚前性质，也必须表明英雄是否能够指挥自然。童话故事还保留了向新事物秩序过渡的痕迹。新的政权影响旧的形式，其结果是诸如俄狄浦斯王登基之类的现象，或者童话故事中的新秩序适应旧秩序，通过将一半王国交给英雄来和平解决冲突等等。 .从内容上看，这些现象本身并不是历史性的，只能从历史上解释为一种社会秩序更替另一种社会秩序以及由此产生的不一致和矛盾的结果。

What conclusions can we draw from what we have said? It cannot be said that all the details are completely clear, but one thing is clear: the struggle for the throne between the hero and the old king is a completely historical phenomenon. The tale reflects the transfer of power from the father-in-law to the son-in-law through a woman, through the daughter. And it shows us something else too: before the son-in-law wins the hand of the princess, and with it the throne, he undergoes an experiment which is supposed to prove that he has completed his apprenticeship. This experiment has a prenuptial character and is also supposed to show whether the hero is capable of commanding nature. The tale has also retained traces of the transition to a new order of things; the new regime influences the old forms and phenomena such as Oedipus' accession to the throne result, or the tale adapts the new order of things to the old, peacefully settling the conflict by ceding half the kingdom to the hero, etc. From the point of view of their content, these phenomena are not in themselves historical, but can only be explained historically as the result of the replacement of one social order by another and of the inconsistencies and contradictions that result from this.

四．神奇的逃脱

IV. The Magical Escape

30.童话里的逃脱。

30. The escape in the fairy tale .

随着婚礼和英雄登基，童话故事结束了。但是，如果我们不进一步考察一个在童话故事中没有固定地位的主题，我们的评论就是不完整的：它就是被称为“神奇逃脱”的主题。

With the marriage and the hero's accession to the throne, the fairy tale ends. But our review would be incomplete if we did not examine a motif that does not have a fixed place in the fairy tale: it is the motif called "the magical escape."

就其背后的原因而言，逃跑并没有特定的地点，但一般我们会在童话故事的结尾，有时甚至在婚礼之后找到它。故事可以在与女巫或其他捐赠者在一起之后、在发现所需物品之后、在与蛇决斗之后、在婚礼之后等结束。逃脱和追捕可以遵循上述任何阶段，并且存在一种趋势（但这不是定律），根据逃脱发生的阶段，给予逃脱和追捕特定的形式。例如，英雄在遇到女巫后可以逃脱；在这些情况下，他几乎总是通过在身后扔一把梳子变成森林、一块石头变成一座山、一条毛巾变成一条河流来拯救自己。或者他躲在一棵树上，从一棵树跳到另一棵树，女巫咬树干。有时，女孩会在炉子附近、苹果树或隐藏她的小溪附近找到保护。如果她从树林里的强盗房子里逃出来，她就会躲在沿途遇到的一辆马车里，车上装满干草、花瓶或兽皮。男孩为了躲避巫师的迫害，先后将自己变成了鲈鱼、一粒麦子、戒指等。与此相对应，巫师会变成鱼、熊、雀鹰、公鸡等。被绑架的公主依次变成鱼、天鹅、星星；它是由“大师”采取的。与蛇决斗后，雌性有时会追赶英雄：她和她的女儿们化身为讨人喜欢的井、床、苹果树，雌蛇追捕英雄，想要吞掉他。在他找到少女国王并拿到返老还童的苹果后，英雄骑着马飞走了，公主也跟着他飞走了，但女巫给了他另一匹马，他设法溜走了。科什切伊也骑马加入了英雄的行列。与水精灵的女儿结婚后，英雄和他的妻子通过变成一座教堂及其流行音乐、一口带有水桶的井等来拯救自己。最后，有时英雄在船上避难，但追击者却用火从天上击中他，或者相反，英雄放火药，烧伤了落下的追击者的翅膀。

In relation to the motives behind it, escape does not have a specific place, but we generally find it at the end of the tale, sometimes even after the wedding. The story may end after the stay with the witch or with some other donor, after the discovery of the sought object, after the duel with the serpent, after the wedding, etc. Escape and pursuit may follow each of the above-mentioned phases, and there is a tendency (which, however, is not a law) to give escape and pursuit certain forms depending on the phase in which the escape occurs. Thus, for example, the hero may escape after having been to the witch; in these cases he almost always saves himself by throwing behind him a comb which turns into a forest, a stone which becomes a mountain, a towel which forms a river. Or he takes refuge in a tree, jumps from one tree to another, and the witch gnaws at the trunk. Sometimes the girl finds protection near the stove or near an apple tree or a stream which hides her. If she flees from the house of the robbers in the woods, she hides in a wagon she meets on the way, loaded with hay or vases or skins. The boy saves himself from the sorcerer's persecutions by transforming himself successively into a perch, a grain of wheat, a little ring, etc. Correspondingly, the sorcerer transforms himself into a fish, a bear, a sparrowhawk, a cock, etc. The kidnapped princess in turn transforms herself into a fish, a swan, a star; she is taken by the "masters". After the duel with the serpent, the female sometimes pursues the hero: she and her daughters transform themselves into flattering wells, beds, apple trees; the female serpent hunts the hero and wants to swallow him. After he has been to the maiden king and has taken possession of the rejuvenating apples, the hero flies away on horseback and the princess flies after him, but the sorceress gives him another horse and he manages to escape. Košcej also catches up with the hero on horseback. After marrying the daughter of the Water Spirit, the hero and his woman save themselves by transforming themselves into a church and its pope , into a well with a bucket, etc. Finally, sometimes the hero takes refuge on a ship, but the pursuer strikes him down from the sky with fire, or, on the contrary, the hero sets fire to gunpowder and burns the wings of the pursuing man who falls.

我们列出了十种追捕和救援。专门研究逃逸的阿恩只考虑了两种形式，而伊切尔森在他的逃逸研究中根本没有区分逃逸和追击的形式572。

We have listed ten types of pursuit and rescue. Aarne, who specifically studied escape, takes into consideration only two forms, while Iochelson, in his study of escape, does not differentiate at all between the forms of escape and pursuit 572 .

这里的问题是双重的：第一是逃避主题本身的起源问题，第二是其形式的多样性问题。在这里，我们不能专门研究赋格曲的所有变体，我们将把自己限制在对赋格曲总体有所了解的形式上。

Here the problem is twofold: the first is that of the origin of the motif of the fugue as such, the second is that of the multiplicity of its forms. Here we cannot study in particular all the varieties of fugue, we will limit ourselves to the forms that shed some light on fugue in general.

31.英雄通过扔梳子等逃脱。

31. The hero escapes throwing a comb, etc.

在这些情况下，孩子们经常（但并非总是）逃离女巫的房子，并向身后扔一块燧石或卵石，这些石子或卵石变成了一座山。或者他们扔一把梳子或毛巾。这些仙女物品是英雄从女巫那里偷走的，或者，如果逃亡者骑马逃跑，他们会从马耳中取出它们（Af. 117 V。他们还会从马耳中取出一块木头或一个小瓶） ）。

In such cases the children often (but not always) run away from the witch's house and throw a flint or a pebble behind them, which turns into a mountain. Or they throw a comb or a towel. These fairy objects have been stolen from the witch by the hero, or, if the fugitives escape on horseback, they take them out of the horse's ear (Af. 117 V. From the horse's ear they also take out a splinter of wood or a phial).

我们不会提及 Aarne 和 Iochelson 作品中大量发现的变体；无论我们如何比较这些变体，解决问题的并不是它们的数量。我们只注意到，这种形式不仅与女巫有关：同样，英雄也以同样的方式逃离了芬尼斯特故事中的熊王（ZP 66），逃离了美丽的埃琳娜（Af.104）等。 ;我们必须从它与整个童话故事的关系以及一些历史相似之处来理解它。

We will not cite variants which are found in great numbers in the works of Aarne and Iochelson; however much we compare these variants, it is not their number that solves the problem. We note only that this form is not encountered only in connection with the sorceress: in the same way the hero also escapes from the bear-king in the tale of Finist (ZP 66), from Helen the Beautiful (Af. 104), etc.; we must understand it from its relations to the whole tale and from certain historical parallels.

我们首先分析一些相似之处。美国的比喻具有以下特点：英雄常常偷的不是能将他从追逐中解救出来的物品（就像俄罗斯童话中的布被偷一样），而是火。这是一个本质的区别。英雄给人类带来火，他是火的创造者。但他不仅是火的创造者，他也是森林、河流和山脉的创造者，这些森林、河流和山脉是他通过在身后扔一些物体而产生的。这是另一个本质区别。反过来，他扔在身后的物体与童话故事中扔的物体不同：它们是动物的一部分。例如，森林由头发产生，湖泊由鱼的液体脂肪产生，等等。这就解释了为什么在俄罗斯童话中，英雄有时会从马耳中取出一小块木头，然后这块木头就会变成一片森林。所以我们看到，森林、山川、河流都是凭借帮助者而形成的。我们已经看到了帮助者如何获得自己，我们知道他是英雄神奇力量的体现者。还有另一个区别：在俄罗斯童话中，扔一个物体就足够了，而在美国神话中，在类似的情况下，英雄有时会唱一首歌并标记节奏573。这些材料表明，投掷梳子的主题恰恰起源于世界创造者的神话。

Let us first analyze some parallels. The American parallels have the following characteristics: often the hero steals not the object that will save him from the chase (as in the Russian tale a cloth is stolen) but fire. This is an essential difference. The hero brings fire to men, he is the initiator of fire. But he is not only the initiator of fire, he is also the initiator of forests, rivers and mountains that he causes to arise by throwing certain objects behind him. And this is another essential difference. In turn, the objects that he throws behind him differ from those that are thrown in the tale: they are parts of animals. Thus, for example, the forest arises from hair, the lake from the liquid fat of fish, etc. This explains why in the Russian tale the hero sometimes takes a small splinter of wood from the horse's ear and this splinter turns into a forest. We see, therefore, that forests, mountains and rivers are formed by virtue of the helper. We have already seen how the helper is procured, we know that he is the one who embodies the hero's magical powers. There is yet another difference: in the Russian fairy tale it is enough to throw an object, whereas in American myths in similar cases the hero sometimes sings a song and marks the cadence 573 . These materials suggest that the motif of the thrown comb was born precisely as a myth of the creator of the world.

但这个事实是否可能与故事的整个流程以及我们对英雄的了解相矛盾？不，这并不矛盾。相反，它向我们解释了童话故事中的某种矛盾：在童话故事中，英雄偷走了使他免于追捕的物体。对比发现，这里之前曾出现过另一个物体。此外，甚至在我们认识到英雄是世界的秩序者之前，我们就看到他将太阳放置在正确的位置，他加速了收割，并且他从另一个世界带来了这些能力。在这里，我们看到了相同表示的褪色残留物。英雄从另一个世界带来了战胜元素的力量。

But does not this fact contradict the whole course of the story, everything we know about the hero? No, there is no contradiction. On the contrary, it explains a certain incongruity in the fairy tale: in the fairy tale the hero steals the object that saves him from the pursuit. The comparison shows that another object figured here previously. Moreover, we have already recognized in the hero the orderer of the world, we have seen that he puts the sun in its right place, that he hastens the harvest and that he has brought these abilities from the other world. Here we have the faded remnants of this same representation. From the other world the hero brings power over the elements.

在美国神话中，土狼和狐狸偷火；他们“从一侧跑到另一侧，追赶者在他们后面疾驰，呈之字形，这就是约古姆河河道蜿蜒的原因”。在这种情况下，逃亡者，同时也是火灾的俘获者，为人类创造了一条河流，从而拯救了自己。同样，英雄创造了森林、山脉和河流，从历史的角度来看，这整个神话就是自然创造者的神话。

In an American myth the coyote and the fox steal the fire; they run away "from one side to the other, and their pursuers gallop after them, zigzagging and that is why the course of the Yoagum River is winding." In this case the fugitives, who are also the stealers of the fire, create a river for the men, saving themselves. In the same way the hero creates the forests, the mountains and the rivers, and in the historical perspective this whole myth is the myth of the creator of nature.

必须指出的是，学者们在这个话题上存在一些混乱。遵循纯粹描述性程序的伊切尔森承认他无法破译这个主题。目前，这里提出的假设只是一个假设，仅此而已。 Bogoraz 574提出了另一个假设。 « 这个神话的构造本身就符合弗洛伊德学派关于视觉与神话之间的亲缘关系的理论，因为通过三重重复以及突破障碍并占有逃亡受害者的持续倾向，这个神话让人想起强迫症一种在梦中诞生并发展的迫害形式。”因此我们看到，即使像博戈拉兹这样的伟大学者也没有超越弗洛伊德主义。稍后我们将简要讨论阿恩的理论。为了找到通用解决方案，我们必须将此形式与其他形式进行比较。

It must be said that there is some confusion among scholars on this subject. Iochelson, who follows a purely descriptive procedure, admits that he is unable to decipher this motif. For the time being the hypothesis advanced here is only a hypothesis, and nothing more. Another hypothesis is formulated by Bogoraz 574 . "The very construction of this myth corresponds to the theories of the Freudian school regarding the relationship between vision and myth, since with the triple repetition and with the persistent tendency to break through the barrier and to take possession of the fleeing victim, this myth recalls the obsessive form of persecution that arises and develops in the dream." We see therefore that even great scholars like Bogoraz do not go beyond Freudianism. We will speak briefly of Aarne's theory later. In order to find a general solution we must compare this form with the others.

32.通过转变来逃避。

32. The escape with transformations .

这种形式主要适用于《海王》和《智者瓦西里莎》 (Af. 125) 类型的童话故事。在这些故事中，被水之灵绑架的女孩拥有神奇的能力。 “她把马变成了井，把自己变成了水桶，把小国王变成了老人。”第二次“她把小国王变成了老流行，而她自己变成了一座破败的教堂”，第三次“她把马变成了一条蜂蜜河，基塞尔河岸，小王子变成了男性”。一只鸭子和她自己在一只灰鸭子里。水之王扑倒在基塞尔上；他吃了，吃得太饱，以至于死了。他就死在这里！ »（AF.125a）。

This form is characteristic mainly for fairy tales of the type The Sea King and Vasilissa the Wise (Aph. 125). In them the girl abducted by the Water Spirit possesses magical powers. "She changed the horses into a well, herself into a bucket, and the little king into an old man." The second time, "she changed the little king into an old pope , and herself into a ruined church," and the third time, "she changed the horses into a river of honey, with banks of kisél , the little prince into a male duck, and herself into a grey duck. The Water King threw himself into the kisél ; he ate, he gorged himself so much that he died. And there he breathed his last!" (Aph. 125 a).

阿尔恩专门研究赋格，他知道欧洲以外只有六例这种形式的录音，而欧洲发现的赋格形式数量众多，他没有数过。我们将阿恩的地理原则转化为历史原则。美洲、非洲、波利尼西亚和亚洲的神话对我们来说是童话研究的来源之一，它们为我们提供了童话演变的较早阶段。如果这种形式在美洲、非洲等地不存在，那就意味着它是一种晚期形式，是在童话故事本身的基础上产生的，而不是在某些原始关系的基础上产生的。逃亡者所转化的典型物体也证​​明了这一点：井和水桶、教堂和流行音乐。如果这些形式出现在种姓形成之前的人们的神话中，我们就必须证明教会取代了其他一些预先存在的物体。但这些材料并不存在，我们所能做的就是假设这个母题是在教堂和流行音乐已经存在的时候诞生的，也就是童话故事也已经存在的时候，也就是在一个相对很晚的时代。只有湖泊或河流才可能存在，而且以前确实存在过，作为逃亡和追捕的最后一环。我们还有以前形式的这枚戒指。

Aarne, who has studied the escape in particular, knows of only six cases of this form recorded outside Europe, while the forms found in Europe are so numerous that he has not counted them. We convert Aarne's geographical principle into a historical principle. The myths of America, Africa, Polynesia and Asia are for us one of the sources of study of the fairy tale; they give us the fairy tale in an earlier stage of its evolution. If this form does not exist in America, Africa, etc., it means that it is a late form, born on the ground of the fairy tale itself and not on that of certain primitive relationships. Proof of this is also the object-types into which the fugitives are transformed: well and bucket, church and pop . If these forms were found in the myths of peoples prior to the formation of the castes, we would have had to show that the church replaced some other pre-existing object. But these materials do not exist and we can only suppose that the motif was born when churches and popes already existed , that is, when fairy tales also already existed, that is, in a relatively very late period. Only the lake or the river could exist, and did exist even before, as the final link in the escape and pursuit. We also have this link in the previous form.

而教堂、树木等。它们是欺骗追击者的手段，水对他来说是一种障碍，就像以前的森林、山脉和河流一样。因此，该形状的第三环完全对应于前一形状的第三环。它完全取自这种旧形式。阿恩认为，一般来说，整个形式（以及逃亡者的转变）是通过修改从第一个形式衍生出来的。在根据芬兰学派的方法研究了这两个变体并将它们各自还原为原型后，他写道：“毫无疑问，这个版本是另一个版本的转变。在我看来，很容易得出这个结论：为此目的，比较这两个版本的传播就足够了» 575。因此，如果一种形式很少出现而另一种形式经常出现，那么一种形式就派生于另一种形式。这种说法听起来很天真。为了证明这一点，有必要在材料上显示过渡形式，有必要显示从一种形式到另一种形式的过渡阶段。但是，阿恩收集的非常丰富的材料并非有意为之，他确信所有案例都属于一种或另一种，而他本人构建了两种原型，而不仅仅是一种。因此，更正确的说法是，到目前为止我们还不知道这种变种是如何产生的，我们只能以某种可能性确定其中一种先出现，另一种后来出现，甚至更晚出现。但不能说一个是从另一个生出来的。

While the church, the tree, etc. are a means of deceiving the pursuer, the water is an obstacle to him, just as the forest, the mountains, and the river were in the previous form. Therefore the third ring of this form corresponds fully to the third ring of the previous form. It has been taken entirely from this older form. Aarne believes that in general this whole form (with the transformation of the fugitives) is derived from the first by way of modifications. After having investigated these two varieties according to the methods of the Finnish school and after having reduced each of them to its archetype, he writes: "There is no doubt that this version is a transformation of the other. In my opinion it is very easy to come to this conclusion: it is enough to compare the diffusion of these two versions." 575 Thus, if one form is rarely encountered and the other frequently, one derives from the other. This statement sounds naive. To prove it, it would be necessary to show the transitional forms on the material, it would be necessary to show the phases of transition from one form to another. But, as if on purpose, the very rich material collected by Aarne leads to the affirmation that all the cases belong to one variety or the other, and he himself constructs two archetypes, and not just one. Therefore it would be more correct to say that up to now we do not know how this variety arose, we can only establish with some probability that one arose first and the other later, indeed even late. But that one arose from the other, cannot be affirmed.

33、蛇变水井、苹果树等。

33. Transformation of snakes into wells , apple trees , etc.

另一方面，也有一些事情是可以坚定地说出来的。有时候，改变的不是逃亡者，而是追捕者。与蛇决斗后，他的亲戚（婆婆、姐姐等）追捕逃亡者。为了导致死亡，他们将自己变成了其他童话故事中逃亡者所变成的物体，即变成一棵苹果树和一口带水桶的井。如果英雄吃了一个苹果或喝了一些水，苹果或水就会把他撕成碎片。在这些情况下，只有教会缺失，这是完全可以理解的，因为蛇和它的雌性与魔鬼有关，不能将自己转变为教会。这些物体与逃亡者所转变的物体之间的类比表明，一种形式直接源自另一种形式。但不能说哪个是最古老的。与前一个例子一样，这种追求和救赎形式的第三个环节是非常古老的。在对蛇的追捕毫无结果之后（童话故事在这一集之前从未提到过它们，它们是临时插入的），蛇的母亲开始追捕并试图吞掉逃亡者，我们已经审查过这一案件。

On the other hand, there is something that can be stated unequivocally. Sometimes it is not the fugitive but the pursuer who is transformed. After the duel with the serpent, his female relatives (mother-in-law, sister, etc.) chase the fugitives. In order to cause their death, they transform themselves into the same objects into which, in other fairy tales, the fugitives transform themselves, namely into an apple tree and a well with a bucket. If the hero eats an apple or drinks a little water, the apple or the water tears him to pieces. In these cases, only the church is missing, which is quite understandable since the serpent and its female are related to the devil and cannot transform themselves into a church. The analogy between these objects and those into which the fugitives transform themselves suggests that one form is derived immediately from the other. But it cannot be said which is the oldest. As in the previous case, the third link in this form of pursuit and salvation is very old. After the pursuit of the snakes has been unsuccessful (the tale never mentions them before this episode, and they were inserted ad hoc ), the snake's mother launches into the chase and tries to swallow the fugitives, a case we have already examined.

34.逃脱与追击以及随后的转变。

34. Escape and pursuit with successive transformations .

这种追捕救援有三种类型或三种形式。在《七个西蒙》的故事（AF.84）中，逃亡者的角色是由被绑架的公主扮演，公主被英雄或更准确地说是被七位英雄追赶。 “公主变成了一只白天鹅，从船上飞走了。”弓箭手追赶她，游泳者到达她身边，但医生治愈了她。最完整的形式给了我们一系列的转变。 “他摔倒了，撞到了船，变成了鸭子飞走了……” “它撞到了船，变成了一颗小星星，然后升上了天空。”弓箭手向她射了一箭，星星落在船上（Sm. 304）。

There are three varieties or forms of this type of pursuit and rescue. In the tale of the Seven Simeons (Aph. 84) the part of the fugitive is played by the kidnapped princess who is pursued by the hero, or more precisely, by the seven heroes. "The princess changed herself into a white swan and flew away from the ship." The archer chases her, the swimmer overtakes her, but the doctor heals her. The most complete form gives us a series of transformations. "She fell, hit the ship, changed herself into a duck and flew away..." "She hit the ship and changed herself into a little star, then rose up to the sky." The archer shoots an arrow at her, the star falls on the ship (Sm. 304).

在这些例子中，逃亡与追捕的表达非常清楚：逃亡者和追捕者都发生了转变。在童话故事中，逃跑的特征显得不太明显，在童话故事中，国王的妻子变成了鸟、鸭子等。后来国王试图让她恢复人形，但她变成了一系列动物。另一方面，从一种动物转变为另一种动物的速度似乎更加明显。 “他抓住了玛丽亚公主；它变成了一只蚱蜢，然后变成了蜥蜴和其他各种爬行动物，最后变成了纺锤体”（Af. 57）。 « 当它飞到你附近时，尝试抓住它的头，当你抓住它时，它会变成青蛙、蟾蜍、蛇和其他爬行动物，最后变成箭。拿起这支箭头并将其分成两部分»（Af. 150 P）。

In these cases, flight and pursuit are expressed very clearly: both the fugitive and the pursuer are transformed. The nature of the flight appears less clear in the fairy tales in which the wife of the little king is transformed into a bird, a duck, etc. and the little king then tries to give her back her human form, but she changes into a series of animals. On the other hand, the rapidity of the transformation from one animal into another appears more evident. "He seized Princess Marya; she changed into a grasshopper, then into a lizard and into all sorts of other reptiles and, finally, into a spindle" (Af. 57). "As soon as she flies near you, try to catch her by the head, and when you have caught her, she will change into a frog, a toad, a snake and other reptiles, and finally into an arrow. Take this arrow and break it into two pieces" (Af. 150 P).

在这两种情况下，被征服或重新征服的公主都会变成一系列动物，反对她从一个王国返回或运送到另一个王国。

In both cases, the princess, conquered or reconquered, transforms into a series of animals, opposing her return or her transport from one kingdom to another.

这些连续转变的第三个例子可以在“聪明的科学”类型的童话故事中找到（Af.140）。其中，男学生逃离巫师的家，将自己变成一匹马、一只鲈鱼、一枚戒指、一粒麦子、一只雀鹰，而追赶的巫师则变成水、一条梭子鱼、一个人、一只公鸡。雀鹰将公鸡撕成碎片（Af. 140 a）。

The third case of these successive transformations is found in fairy tales of the type The Clever Science (Af. 140). In them the pupil escapes from the sorcerer's house, transforming himself into a horse, a perch, a ring, a grain of wheat, a sparrowhawk, while in turn the pursuing sorcerer transforms himself into water, a pike, a man, a rooster. The sparrowhawk tears the rooster to pieces (Af. 140 a).

所有这些品种都可以一起研究。但这个主题的来源应该从什么方向寻找呢？按照类似情况下通常使用的描述性程序，我们不会得出任何结果。然而，如果我们从女孩变成动物的假设出发，源于对人在死亡时刻变成动物的再现，我们就找到了一个让我们前进的方向。我们观察到公主变成了一只鸭子，而国王又让她恢复了人类的外表。鸭子是最常见的动物之一，其形象与死亡有关。相反的转变为人则体现了生命的回归。我们尝试寻找一下这个方向的对比资料，看看它们能否给我们提供一些解释。

All these varieties can be studied together. But in what direction should the sources of this motif be sought? By following the descriptive procedure generally used in such cases, we will not arrive at any result. If, on the other hand, we start from the assumption that the transformation of the girl into an animal derives from the representation of the transformation of the man into an animal at the moment of death, we hit upon a direction that allows us to go forward. We observe that the princess is transformed into a duck and that the little king restores her human appearance. The duck is one of the most widespread animals whose image is connected with death. The opposite transformation into a man reflects the representation of the return to life. Let us try to look for comparative materials in this direction and see if they cannot provide us with some explanation.

从死者之地返回生者之地伴随着转变为动物。在非洲，约鲁巴人和波波人相信，好人死后会花时间转变成不同的动物，或者更准确地说，灵魂会根据自己的意愿物质化为动物576。在埃及也有类似的表述：“如果死者不再喜欢留在那里，他可以返回地球并参观他所珍视的地方，他可以在他的坟墓前停下来并在那里接受牺牲。或者他可以将自己变成苍鹭、燕子、蛇、鳄鱼、神，呈现出他想要的所有方面» 577。

The return from the land of the dead to that of the living is accompanied by the transformation into an animal. In Africa the Ioruba and the Popo believe that after death good men pass the time by transforming themselves into various animals, or more exactly, the spirits materialize of their own free will into animals 576 . Similar representations are also found in Egypt: « If the dead man no longer likes to remain there, he can return to earth and visit the places that were dear to him, he can stop at his tomb and accept sacrifices there. Or he can transform himself into a heron, a swallow, a snake, a crocodile, a god, assume all the aspects he wants » 577 .

这些材料说明了什么？它们证明了这种再现的历史性，根据这种再现，死者的外貌并不被认为与单一动物有关：死者可以随意变成不同的动物。我们还看到，这种表征与返回地球的表征是相伴的。死者返回地球后变成了不同的动物。这种表现无疑是相对较新的：我们稍后会看到古典时期的这种表现尤其丰富。但它也存在于社会进化的最原始阶段，确实更罕见，但另一方面又具有原始的清晰度和纯粹性。如果我们加上第二个角色，即追赶者的角色，这种转变就会变得迅速，而且转变会相继发生。因此，例如，在海洋神话中，我们发现一个男人的例子“他想把他的妻子从死亡的世界带回来，但她逃脱了他，总是采取新的鸟类形式” 578 ​。这里清楚地表达了童话故事中已经隐秘出现的内容：当被迫返回地球时，这种转变就会发生。死者抵抗并试图通过不断新的转变来避免回归。

What do these materials indicate? They attest to the historicity of the representation according to which the appearance of the deceased is not thought of in connection with a single animal: the dead man can transform himself into different animals, at will. We also see that this representation is concomitant with that of the return to earth. Returning to earth the deceased transforms himself into different animals. This representation is undoubtedly relatively recent: we will see later that classical antiquity is particularly rich in it. But it also exists in the most primitive stages of social evolution, more rarely, it is true, but in compensation with the original clarity and purity. If to this is added the second character, that of the pursuer, this transformation acquires rapidity, the transformations follow one another. Thus, for example, in the Oceanic myths we find the case of the man "who wants to bring his wife back from the world of the dead, but she eludes him, always assuming new bird forms" 578 ​​. Here is clearly expressed what already appears in a veiled way in the fairy tale: this transformation occurs when the return to earth is forced. The deceased resists and tries to avoid the return by ever new transformations.

在灵魂的表征已经形成的地方，动物化身的表征不再能出现在整个个体，而只能出现在他的灵魂中，轮回学说就会出现，其经典形式在《轮回》中是已知的。印度。因此，在藏族关于“智慧科学”的传说中，逃亡和追捕的情节是这样叙述的：“国王的灵魂从鱼身上跳到了附近飞翔的鸽子身上”（Z.Star.419）。在西伯利亚萨满教中，我们发现了相同的灵魂狩猎现象。在布里亚特人中，萨满在树林、草原、水下寻找病人的灵魂，就像巫师寻找逃离他的男孩一样。如果他找不到这个灵魂，他就必须去死界。有时，这个王国的统治者同意让灵魂被寻找只是为了换取另一个灵魂。 « 如果病人同意这种替代，萨满就会变成一只雀鹰，在他的朋友（即替代病人的人）的灵魂以云雀的形式从沉睡的身体中出现的那一刻扑向他的灵魂并将其交付给死亡的黑暗领主，让其颤抖和不情愿，而死亡领主随后将让死者的灵魂获得自由” 579。

Where the idea of ​​the soul had already been formed, the idea of ​​the incarnation in animals no longer of the whole individual, but only of his soul, could arise; the doctrine of metempsychosis, the classical form of which is known in India, could arise. Thus in a Tibetan legend about "the crafty science" the episode of flight and pursuit is narrated as follows: "The soul of the king jumped from the fish into a dove that was flying nearby" (Z. Star. 419). In Siberian shamanism we find the same phenomenon of the hunting of souls. Among the Buryats the shaman searches for the soul of the sick person in the woods, on the steppes, under water, just as the sorcerer searches for the boy who has run away from him. If he cannot find this soul, he must go to the realm of the dead. Sometimes the ruler of this realm agrees to let the sought-after soul escape only in exchange for another soul. « If the patient consents to this substitution, the shaman transforms himself into a sparrowhawk, throws himself on the soul of the friend (that is, of the one who replaces the sick person) at the moment in which he emerges in the form of a lark from his sleeping body and delivers this trembling and reluctant being to the dark lord of death, who, following this, releases the soul of the dead person » 579 .

在这里，我们看到了与童话故事中相同的情况：逃亡者变成天鹅，而追捕者则以猛禽的形式攻击他（Af. 140 c）。一般来说，在西伯利亚人民中，这一主题经常被描述为萨满教对死者灵魂的狩猎。 « 老人看着死者的脸。事实上，他是她的儿子。他勃然大怒，扑向儿子，儿子为了躲避他，变成一只秋沙鸭逃跑了。老人开始以雀鹰的形式追赶他” 580。因此，在这里我们也看到，当死者被迫从另一个世界回到生者的境界时，随后就会转变为各种动物。

Here we see the same thing that occurs in the fairy tale when the fugitive changes into a swan and the pursuer springs upon him in the form of a bird of prey (Aph. 140 c). In general, among the Siberian peoples this motif is very often told as a shamanic hunt for the soul of the deceased. "The old man looked into the face of the deceased. And, indeed, it was his son. He flew into a rage and threw himself upon his son, who, to escape him, changed into a merganser and took flight. The old man began to chase him in the form of a sparrowhawk." 580 Here, too, we see that the successive transformation into various animals occurs when the deceased is forced by force to return from the other world to the realm of the living.

如果这些观察和推论是正确的，它们可以向我们解释许多古典时期的材料。这种表现形式的经典版本和形式通常与童话故事相似，但它们本身就像童话故事本身一样神秘，并被所引用的材料所阐明。

If these observations and inferences are correct, they can explain much of the material of classical antiquity. The classical versions and forms of this representation are often paralleled with the fairy tale, but they are in themselves as enigmatic as the fairy tale itself and are illuminated by the materials cited.

在我的怀抱里她改变了

And in my embraces she transformed

在狮子和蛇中，在火和水中，

in lion and in serpent and in fire and in water,

忒提斯的珀琉斯在索福克勒斯的悲剧《亚该亚人的聚会》 581中这样说道。忒提斯，海神涅柔斯的女儿，海神涅柔斯，居住在水下王国的不朽女神，“按照宙斯的命令，勉强嫁给了凡人” 582。她被预言，她的儿子将比他的父亲更伟大。因此，众神不愿意娶她为妻，她被迫嫁给凡人。她转变的时刻就是她从地下或水下王国进入人类王国的时刻。在这里，反对派的性质非常明显。同样，涅柔斯通过连续的转变，抵御了赫拉克勒斯的攻击。同样，在与赫拉克勒斯的战斗中，河神阿克洛斯进行了一系列的转变：他变成了蛇和牛，直到赫拉克勒斯折断了他的一只角后，他才放弃。在所有这些情况下，它们都是正在经历转变的水生生物。同样在童话故事中，公主在船上变成了几种动物，但灰鸭子来自河里。

says Peleus of Thetis in Sophocles' tragedy The Gathering of the Achaeans . 581 Thetis, daughter of Nereus, a Nereid, an immortal goddess who lives in the underwater kingdom, "unwillingly marries a mortal by order of Zeus." 582 It has been predicted to her that her son will be greater than his father; for this reason the gods do not want her as a wife and she is forced to marry a mortal. The moment of her transformation is the moment in which she is led from the subterranean or underwater kingdom into that of men. Here the character of the opposition is very clear. In the same way, by means of successive transformations, Nereus defends himself from Heracles; in the same way, in fighting against Heracles, the river deity Achelous undergoes a series of transformations: she changes into a serpent and an ox, and only after Heracles has broken one of her horns does she give up. In all these cases it is aquatic beings who undergo the transformation. In the fairy tale, too, the princess transforms into several animals while on the ship, but the grey duck comes from the river.

纺锤是女孩转变链条中的最后一环：它必须被打破并扔到肩上。作为链条中的最后一环，古典时期的材料为我们提供了破损的号角。从动物到物体的转变必须被视为后来的形成。折断的角与撕裂的头发是相同的现象：它表明力量的丧失。人死后折断物品的做法很普遍，并保留在死刑犯头上折断刀或结婚时折断棍子的习俗中。这种破裂伴随着从一种状况到另一种状况的转变。

The spindle is the last link in the chain of the girl's transformations: it must be broken and thrown over the shoulder. As the last link in the chain, the material of classical antiquity gives us the broken horn. The transformation from animal to object must be considered as a later formation. The broken horn is a phenomenon identical to the torn hair: it indicates the loss of strength. The breaking of objects at the death of a man was widely practiced and was preserved in the custom of breaking the sabre over the head of those condemned to death, or of breaking a stick at the moment of marriage. This breaking accompanied the transition from one condition to another.

因此，即使是古典世界也仍然保留着两个世界之间的这种联系，尽管这种联系并非始终如一，而这种联系与随后的转变的主题相关。在提到Radermacher时，Malten引用了Thanatos呈现不同方面的案例，并且这一观察也可以扩展到Empusa 583。地下和水下生物都拥有这种能力。 “地下王国佩里克利墨尼斯的领主从波塞冬那里得到了改变外表的礼物，新希腊死神查罗斯也拥有这份礼物”。著名的变形杆菌也是同一组的一部分。拉德马赫引用了一些材料。在其中，他只注意到一个事实：这种转变与水元素之间存在某种连续性的联系（礼物是波塞冬等人赐予的），从中他得出结论，主题本身是作为对水元素的观察而诞生的。水域的变化、波浪的变化等水生物就像水本身一样多变，这里所研究的转变无非是“水生神的顿悟” 584。根据我们所报告的材料，情况显得非常不同，拉德马赫的观点必须被认为是不正确的。当以纯粹描述性的方式孤立地研究材料时，这种错误是不可避免的。

Therefore, even the classical world still retains, even if not constantly, this connection between the two worlds associated with the motif of successive transformations. Referring to Radermacher, Malten cites the case in which Thanatos takes on different aspects and this observation can also be extended to Empusa 583 . This ability is precisely possessed by subterranean and underwater beings. « The lord of the subterranean kingdom Periclimene receives from Poseidon the gift of changing his appearance, a gift also possessed by Charos, the neo-Greek god of death ». The well-known Proteus also belongs to the same group. Radermacher cites several materials. In them he notes only one fact: a certain continuity of connection between this kind of transformation and the element of water (the gift is given by Poseidon, etc.), from which he concludes that the motif itself was born as an observation of the mutability of the waters, of the play of the waves, etc. Aquatic beings are as changeable as water itself and the transformations studied here are nothing but "an epiphany of the aquatic deities" 584 . In the light of the materials we have reported, things appear quite different and Radermacher's opinion must be recognized as erroneous. Such an error is inevitable when the material is studied in isolation and in a purely descriptive way.

35.决定性的障碍。

35. The decisive impediment .

我们不会研究其他形式的追求，因为我们已经研究了最重要和最经典的形式。我们绘制了这样的图景：从历史的角度来看，逃避和追寻的基本类型就摆在我们面前，仿佛建立在从死国到生国的回归之上。阿恩也赞成这种解释，尽管它并非来自他引用的材料。阿恩没有警告说，最后一个障碍往往是由水、河流构成的，他顺便将这条河与分隔生者王国和死者王国的河流进行了比较。事实上，河流作为最后的障碍，有其特殊的意义。追赶者继续穿过山脉和树林，但河流最终阻止了他。前两个障碍是机械障碍，最后一个是魔法障碍。说实话，童话里也机械地处理了这个障碍：追赶者试图喝水。但它是次要形式，可以从以下事实看出：我们常常没有河流，而是湖泊，而追赶者从不试图绕过它。正是水将其阻挡为边界线。另一方面，这条河经常是火成岩的。 « “牙刷，化为火河！ “没有什么可做的，他们就回去了”（Chud.1）。 “Snòdati，火河”（Af. 104）。 “她挥动布，形成一条火河”（ZP 55）。 “伊凡国王在身后挥动毛巾，突然形成了一个火湖”（Af. 117）。

We will not examine the other varieties of pursuit because we have studied the most important and classical forms. We have drawn the following picture: the basic types of flight and pursuit stand before us in their historical perspective, as if built on the return from the realm of the dead to the realm of the living. Aarne also leans toward this explanation, although it does not arise from the materials he cites. Aarne has not noticed that the last obstacle is often constituted by water, by the river, and he has fleetingly compared this river with the one that divides the realm of the living from the realm of the dead. In fact the river, as the last obstacle, has a special significance; the pursuer presses on through mountains and forests, but the river stops him definitively. The first two obstacles are mechanical, the last is a magical obstacle. To tell the truth, in the tale this obstacle too is treated mechanically: the pursuer tries to drink the water. But that this is a secondary form is evident from the fact that we often have not a river, but a lake, and the pursuer never tries to go around it. It is precisely the water that stops him as a frontier line. On the other hand, this river is very often fiery. "“ Little brush, turn into a river of fire! „ There was nothing more to be done and they turned back " (Chud. 1). " Unwind, river of fire " (Af. 104). " She waved the cloth and a river of fire was formed " (ZP 55). " Little King Ivan waved the towel behind him and suddenly a lake of fire was formed " (Af. 117).

我们在上面已经看到，火河将两个王国分开，但是，即使没有这条河，魔法边界的感觉有时也会以非常清晰的形式表达出来：“但英雄已经到达了他的土地，不再有更多的东西了。”害怕她：她不敢跳到这边，只能盯着他»(Af. 104 a)。现在我们明白了为什么追捕者无法跨越边界：他的力量不会延伸到生者的领域。

We have already seen above that the fiery river divides the two realms, but, even when the river is missing, the sense of a magical frontier is sometimes expressed very clearly: "But the hero had already reached his land and was no longer afraid of her: she did not dare jump to this side and simply kept an eye on him" (Aph. 104 a). Now we understand why the pursuer cannot cross the frontier: his power does not extend to the realm of the living.

在另一个童话故事中，也表达了同样的事情，但叙述者不自觉地为这种现象的不可理解性添加了自己的轻微色彩：“他追他，追他，只差了大约十个萨赞：她乘飞机飞往俄罗斯。地毯，但由于他不能去俄罗斯，所以他就回去了”（Af. 150 a）。我们听说叙述者不由自主地想知道为什么追击者不能进入“俄罗斯”。

In another fairy tale the same thing is expressed, but the narrator has involuntarily added a slight colouring of his own, the incomprehensibility of this phenomenon: "He chased and chased her, and only missed her by about ten sazhens : she flew to Russia on the carpet, but since he could not go to Russia, he turned back" (Af. 150 a). One feels that the narrator has involuntarily asked himself why the pursuer could not enter "Russia".

这一推论完全符合童话故事整体动作演变所呈现的全貌。我们已经知道主人公进入了“异界”。在其中，我们认识到了死亡王国，既存在于遥远的王国中，又以特定的形式存在于森林中，特别是存在于魔法师大师居住的森林中。他以活物、绑匪和罪犯的身份来到这个王国，引起了该国领主的愤怒和追捕。

This deduction fully accords with the whole picture presented by the evolution of the action of the fairy tale as a whole. We already know that the hero enters the "other kingdom". In it we have recognized the kingdom of the dead both in the distant kingdom and, in specific forms, in the forest, and in particular in the forest where the master-sorcerer lives. In this kingdom he arrives as a living creature, as a kidnapper and as a transgressor, arousing the wrath and pursuit of the lords of that land.

我们所解释的一切都揭示了逃避的本质和某些形式，但尚未解释逃避本身的事实。阿恩的理论得到了许多他没有引用的材料的证实。回归是从异世界回归，但目前还不清楚为什么这种回归会采取逃避的形式。无论是入会后的回归，还是萨满从另一个世界的回归，都不代表仪式中的逃离，但它却出现在世界各地的神话、传说和童话故事中。

All of this sheds some light on the essence of flight and on certain of its forms, but it does not yet explain the fact of flight itself. Aarne's theory is confirmed by numerous materials that he does not cite. The return is the return from the other world, but it is not yet clear why this return takes the form of flight. Neither the return after initiation nor the return of the shaman from the other world reflects a flight in the rite, yet it figures in the myths, legends and fairy tales of the entire world.

我们只能假设这是从另一个世界带来的物品被盗的后果。逃亡原因的问题归结为盗窃原因的问题。盗窃的概念出现较晚，是随着私有财产的出现而出现的，并且先于简单的占有。在经济演化的最原始阶段，人类几乎什么也不生产，而是从自然中索取，他的经济纯粹是一种猎物和消费的经济。因此，最初的事情，即导致文化的事情，不能想象为由某人完成，而只能通过暴力来获取。第一把火被偷走了，第一支箭、第一粒种子也被偷到了天堂并带给了人类，等等。

We can only assume that it is the consequence of the theft of an object brought from the other world. The question of the cause of the flight is reduced to the question of the cause of the theft. The concept of theft appears late, with the beginning of private property, and is preceded by the simple taking of possession. In the most primitive stages of economic evolution, man still produces almost nothing, but takes from nature; his economy is purely one of prey and consumption. Therefore the first things, the things that lead to culture, he does not imagine as having been made by anyone, but only taken by force. The first fire is stolen, the first arrows, the first seeds, are also stolen from heaven and brought to men, etc.

因此，盗窃在民间传说中始终具有重要意义。在仪式中，仙媒的捐赠和归还都是和平进行的；在神话中，它经常被盗，而回归则以逃跑的形式出现。神话比仪式更长久，并在童话故事中重生。盗窃而不是奖励或礼物表明财产关系已经与原始共产主义发生了矛盾，因为没有财产。英雄从它们的主人（来自来世的存在，后来成为神）那里拿走东西，并将它们带给成为它们主人的人。赫尔墨斯作为两个世界的中介，也是一个小偷，后来成为贸易的保护者，这并非没有道理。

Hence the great importance that theft always has in folklore. In the rite the enchanted vehicle is given away and the return takes place peacefully; in the myth it is already often stolen and the return takes the form of escape. The myth lives longer than the rite and is reborn in the fairy tale. Theft as a substitute for the reward or the gift shows that property relations have come into contradiction with original communism, with the absence of property. The hero takes things from their owner, who is a being from the afterlife and later a god, and brings them to men who become their owners. It is not for nothing that Hermes, the intermediary between the two worlds, is also a thief and later becomes the protector of trade.

但除了与逃跑相关的盗窃之外，童话故事还保留了女巫和平地交付仙女物品并在没有任何逃跑的情况下返回，非常准确地反映了仪式。

But alongside this theft connected with the escape, the fairy tale preserves the peaceful delivery of the enchanted object by the witch and the return without any escape, reflecting the rite quite exactly.

第十章 童话作为一个复杂的故事

Chapter Ten The Fairy Tale as a Complex

1.童话的统一性。

1. The unity of the fairy tale .

我们已经研究了童话故事的后续组成部分。这些部分对于不同的主体来说都是相同的，它们依次产生并构成一个整体。由于每一个原因，我们都研究了来源，但我们还没有比较这些来源之间的关系。换句话说，我们知道各个主题的来源，但我们还不知道它们在动作进展中的连续性的来源，我们不知道整个童话故事的来源。

We have examined the fairy tale in the successive constituent parts of its composition. These parts are the same for the different subjects, they spring successively from one another and constitute a whole. For each of these motifs we have studied the sources, but we have not yet compared these sources in their mutual relations. In other words, we know the sources of the individual motifs, but we do not yet know the source of their succession in the course of the action, we do not know the source of the fairy tale as a whole.

对所审查的资料进行短暂的回顾表明，许多童话主题可以追溯到各种社会制度，其中入会仪式占有特殊的地位。我们也意识到来世和前往另一个世界的旅程的表现所发挥的重要作用。这两个循环定量地提供了大部分主题，但有些主题有另一个起源。

A quick retrospective glance at the sources examined shows that many of the fairy-tale motifs go back to various social institutions, among which the initiation rite occupies a special place. We are also aware of the important role played by representations of the afterlife, of journeys to the other world. These two cycles quantitatively provide the majority of the motifs, but some motifs have another origin.

如果我们按照来源或者历史对应关系排列得到的结果，我们得到下图。以下主题可以追溯到启蒙情结：将孩子们驱逐或转移到森林中或被森林精灵绑架，小茅屋，出售的承诺，被女巫殴打的英雄，截肢，向幸存者展示的想象中的死亡迹象、女巫的火炉、四分和复活、吞咽和打嗝、仙女的礼物或者是仙女帮手、易装癖、森林大师和“智能科学”。接下来的婚礼前的时期和返回的时刻都反映在大房子的主题中，里面的桌子，猎人，强盗，小妹妹，美丽的女人的主题中。棺材，魔法花园和宫殿（普赛克）中的美丽女人，以不洗澡的男人、妻子婚礼上的丈夫、丈夫婚礼上的妻子、禁忌的壁橱和其他一些。

If we list the results obtained by arranging them according to the sources or their historical correspondences, we obtain the following picture. The following motifs are traced back to the initiation complex: the expulsion or removal of the children into the forest or their abduction by the sylvan spirit, the little hut, the promise of sale, the heroes beaten by the sorceress, the amputation of the finger, the imaginary signs of death shown to the survivors, the sorceress' stove, the quartering and resurrection, the swallowing and belching, the gift of the enchanted object or the enchanted helper, the disguise, the master of the forest and the "crafty science". The period that follows, up to the wedding and the moment of the return, are reflected in the motifs of the large house, of the table that is set in it, of the hunters, of the robbers, of the little sister, of the beautiful woman in the coffin, of the beautiful woman in the enchanted garden and in the palace (Psyche), in the motifs of the man who does not wash, of the husband at his wife's wedding, of the wife at her husband's wedding, of the forbidden closet and some others.

这些对应关系使我们能够确认起始周期是童话故事最古老的基础。所有这些主题加在一起，可以组成无数个不同的童话故事。

These correspondences allow us to affirm that the cycle of initiation is the most ancient basis of the fairy tale. All these motifs, taken together, can be composed in an infinite number of different fairy tales.

另一个揭示其与童话故事对应的循环是死亡的表征。少女被大蛇掳走、各种神奇的诞生、死者归来、穿着铁鞋的英雄离去等等、森林作为异国的入口、气味英雄的形象、茅屋门的洒水、女巫家的宴会、摆渡人的形象、鹰上、马背上、船上的长途旅行等等，与看门人吞噬陌生人的入口，天平上的称重，到达另一个王国及其所有附属物。

Another cycle which reveals its correspondence with the fairy tale is that of the representations of death; these include the kidnapping of the girl by the serpent, the various types of miraculous birth, as well as the return of the deceased, the departure of the hero equipped with iron shoes, etc., the forest as the entrance to the other kingdom, the smell of the hero, the sprinkling of the door of the hut, the banquet in the house of the witch, the figure of the ferryman-guide, the long journey on the eagle, on horseback, in a boat, etc., the duel with the guardian of the entrance who would like to devour the stranger, the weighing on the scales, the arrival in the other kingdom and all its accessories.

这两个周期的总和已经为我们提供了童话故事的几乎所有（但不是全部）基本补充。不可能在它们之间划出确切的界限。我们知道，整个入会仪式感觉就像是在死亡之地的寄居，反之亦然，死者经历了入会者所经历的一切：他得到了一个帮助者，他遇到了吞噬者，等等。

The sum of these two cycles already provides us with almost all (but not all) of the basic elements of the tale. It is not possible to draw an exact limit between them. We know that the entire rite of initiation was experienced as a sojourn in the land of death and, vice versa, that the dead man experienced everything that the initiate experienced: he was given an assistant, he came across the swallower, etc.

如果我们想象初学者身上发生的一切并连续讲述，童话故事所编织的情节就会出现。如果我们连续讲述死者身上发生的所有事情，这次也会出现同样的痕迹，但增加了上述仪式中缺失的元素。这两个周期加在一起已经为我们提供了童话故事几乎所有基本的建设性元素。

If we imagine everything that happened to the initiate and tell it consecutively, the plot emerges on which the fairy tale is woven. If we tell consecutively everything that was believed to happen to the deceased, the same outline emerges again, but with the addition of the elements that are missing in the line of the rites indicated above. The two cycles put together already give us almost all the fundamental constructive elements of the fairy tale.

我们发现了什么？我们发现，童话故事的构成的统一性并不在于人类心灵的某些特殊性，也不在于艺术创作的特殊性，而在于过去的历史现实。今天所说的都是曾经做过和再现的，而没有做过的则是想象的。在这两个周期中，第一个周期（仪式周期）先于另一个周期结束。仪式不再被庆祝，死亡的表征继续存在、发展、变化，不再与仪式本身有任何联系。仪式的消失与作为唯一或基本生存资源的狩猎的消失重新联系在一起。

What have we found? We have found that the compositional unity of the fairy tale is not to be found in certain particularities of the human psyche, nor in a particularity of artistic creation, but it lies in the historical reality of the past. What is told today, was once done, represented, and what was not done, was imagined. Of these two cycles, the first (that of the rites) dies out before the other. The rite is no longer celebrated, the representations of death continue to live, develop, and change without having any connection with the rite itself. The disappearance of the rite is reconnected with the disappearance of the hunt as the only or fundamental resource of existence.

关于主体的进一步形成，基于已经说过的内容，我们必须想象，一旦形成，这条痕迹就会吸收来自新的和后来的现实的一些新的特殊性或复杂性。另一方面，新的生活创造了新的文学体裁（长篇童话），它的生长环境已经不同于童话的创作和主题。换句话说，进化是通过分层、替代、意义调换等方式进行的。另一方面，通过新的阵型。

As for the further formation of the subject, based on what has been said we must imagine that, once formed, this trace absorbs into itself some new particularities or complications derived from a new and later reality. On the other hand, the new life creates new literary genres (the novelistic fairy tale), grown on a terrain already different from the terrain of the composition and subjects of the fairy tale. In other words, evolution proceeds by means of stratifications, substitutions, transpositions of meaning, etc. and, on the other hand, by means of neo-formations.

例如，国王的儿子被关在监狱里的主题就源于隔离国王、牧师、魔术师及其儿子的习俗；这是一个分层。死去的父亲或感恩的死者将马送给英雄的主题在功能上对应于女巫，即马的捐赠者。在对祖先的崇拜，即后来的现象的影响下，我们在这里看到了意义的转换和捐赠者形象的变形，同时保留了礼物的功能。因此，与前述循环无关的已经提到的原因的问题必须针对每种情况单独解决。例如，英雄结婚和继承王位的原因也是如此。在公主的形象中，我们一方面认识到独立的女性，血统和图腾魔法的持有者。她是“少女国王”，但她也可以与萨满的天妻相比，也可以与被继任者杀死和消灭的国王的遗孀或女儿相比。

Thus, for example, the motif of the sons of kings locked up in prison proceeds from the custom of isolating kings, priests, magicians and their sons; this is a stratification. The motif of the dead father or the grateful dead man who gives a horse to the hero, corresponds functionally to the sorceress, the giver of the horse. Under the influence of the ancestor cult, that is, of a later phenomenon, we have here a transposition of meaning and a deformation of the figure of the donor, while retaining the functions of the gift. Consequently, the problem of the motifs already mentioned, which are not connected with the above-mentioned cycles, must be solved individually for each case. The same applies, for example, to the motif of marriage and the hero's accession to the throne. In the image of the princess we recognize on the one hand the independent woman, holder of the lineage and of totemic magic. She is the "maiden king", but she can also be compared to the shaman's celestial wife and furthermore she can be compared to the widow or daughter of the king killed and eliminated by his successor.

与困难事业相关的整组原因似乎很难分析。无法确切地证明童话故事在这一领域保留了继承者魔法力量实验的习俗，但根据一系列间接线索，可以以合理的概率来说明。

The whole group of motives that are connected with difficult undertakings appears very difficult to analyze. It cannot be demonstrated exactly that in this field the fairy tale has preserved the custom of experimenting with the magical forces of the successor, but on the basis of a series of indirect indications it can be affirmed with a fair amount of probability.

此外，这种通过更换操作角色而构成的守恒定律仍然没有争议，并且童话故事的后续演变也沿着这条线进行。习俗和生活条件的变化是替代材料的来源。因此我们看到，在乞丐女人的下面，我们可以认出女巫，在带阳台的两层楼的房子下面，我们可以认出“男人的房子”，等等。

Furthermore, this law of the preservation of the composition with a substitution of the operative characters remains unshaken and the subsequent evolution of the fairy tale proceeds along this line. The customs, the changed conditions of life are the source from which the material for the substitution is drawn. Thus we see that under the beggar woman we can discern the sorceress, under the two-story house with a balcony the "house for men", etc.

这种推论与人们对童话故事的普遍看法并不相符。人们通常认为，史前时期的个别元素已经渗透到童话故事中，但作为一个整体，它是“自由”艺术创作的产物。相反，我们看到童话故事的元素可以追溯到种姓之前的社会中存在的现象和表征。

This deduction does not coincide with the commonly professed opinions on fairy tales; it is usually believed that individual elements of prehistory have crept into the fairy tale, but that as a whole it is the product of a "free" artistic creation. We see instead that the fairy tale consists of elements which go back to phenomena and representations existing in pre-caste society.

2.童话作为一种体裁。

2. The fairy tale as a genre .

我们已经明确了各个主题的来源；我们已经明确表示，它们的联系、它们的继承也不是随机现象。但这仍然不能解释童话本身出现的事实。

We have made clear the sources of the individual motifs; we have made clear that their connection, their sequence, is not a casual phenomenon either. But this does not yet explain the fact of the emergence of the fairy tale as such.

最古老的叙事阶段是什么？从前面的内容我们已经知道，在启蒙期间，一些事情被告知了年轻人。但什么东西呢？

What is the oldest stage of narration? From the above we already know that during initiation certain things were told to the young men. But what things?

神话和童话的结构与入会期间发生的一系列事件的巧合表明，长辈告诉年轻人发生在他们身上的事情，但他们是通过参考建立血统和习俗的祖先来讲述的。 ，从他在熊、狼等王国的寄居中奇迹般诞生的。他带来了火、魔法舞蹈（和教给年轻人的舞蹈一样）等等。起初，这些事件以传统的戏剧形式呈现，而不是叙述。它们是形象艺术的主题：如果不了解许多民族的传说和“童话”，就无法理解他们的雕刻和装饰设计。这些故事向初学者揭示了他作为对象的行为的意义，使他与主角相似。他们是邪教的一部分，受到禁令的约束。这些禁令构成了支持该论点的第二种情况，根据该论点，所讲述的事情与仪式有直接关系。

The coincidence of the structure of myths and fairy tales with the sequence of events that took place during the initiation suggests that the elders told the young people what was happening to them, but they told it in reference to the founding ancestor of the lineage and customs, who, born miraculously, from his stay in the kingdom of bears, wolves, etc. had brought fire, magic dances (the same ones that were taught to the young people), etc. At the beginning, these events were represented in a conventionally dramatic form rather than narrated. They served as subjects for the figurative arts: one cannot understand the carvings and ornamental designs of many peoples if one does not know their legends and their "fairy tales". The stories revealed to the initiate the meaning of the acts of which he was the object, made him similar to the one who was the protagonist; they were part of the cult and were subject to prohibition. These prohibitions constitute the second circumstance in favor of the thesis according to which things were told that had a direct relationship with the rite.

不幸的是，绝大多数所谓原始民族的故事集仅由文本组成。我们对讲述这些故事的环境以及伴随这些故事的环境一无所知。但也有例外；在某些情况下，收藏家不仅限于报道文本，还向我们提供了一些有关叙述展开方式的细节。

Unfortunately, the vast majority of collections of tales of so-called primitive peoples consist only of texts. We know nothing about the environment in which these tales were told, nor about the circumstances that accompanied them. But there are also exceptions; in some cases the collectors did not limit themselves to reporting the texts, but also provide us with some details on the way in which the narration unfolds.

多尔西在他的集《斯基迪波尼传统》的介绍中向我们提供了关于如何考虑此类故事的非常完整的指示。他谈到了大量的仪式和舞蹈，包括赠送圣袋（束）（即一种护身符）的仪式；它们被保存在家里，构成了家里最神圣的东西。所有的物品、狩猎的运气等等都取决于它们。其内容各异：笔、麦粒、烟叶等。简而言之，我们在其中认识到了我们的“童话礼物”的原型。 “每个仪式和每个舞蹈不仅伴随着其仪式，而且还伴随着其起源的叙述，”多尔西说。正如该系列的作者所展示的那样，对这些护身符起源的叙述必须被理解为对这种方式的叙述，例如，这个袋子的第一个主人进入森林，在那里遇到了一头水牛，带领他进入水牛王国，在那里他收到了这个袋子作为礼物，他学会了舞蹈，回来后他把这一切都教给了人们，并成为了他们的领袖。这些故事“通常是袋子或舞蹈的持有者或拥有者的私有财产，通常是在庆祝仪式之后或在袋子或仪式的所有权转移给下一个所有者期间立即讲述的。”因此，这个故事是仪式的一部分，是仪式的一部分，它与仪式以及获得护身符的人息息相关。它是一种言语护身符，一种对周围世界产生神奇作用的手段。 “因此，这些故事中的每一个都是深奥的……这就是为什么需要付出如此多的努力才能从它们中得出一些在复杂性上类似于病因学故事（起源神话）的东西”。

A very complete indication of how to regard such tales is given by Dorsey in the introduction to his collection Traditions of the Skidi-Pawnee . He speaks of the great number of ceremonies and dances, among which is the rite of the delivery of the sacred bags ( bundles ), that is, of a kind of amulets; they are kept in the house and constitute the most sacred thing. All goods, luck in hunting, etc. depend on them. Their contents vary: feathers, grains of corn, tobacco leaves, etc. In short, we recognize in them the prototype of our "fairy gifts". "Each ceremony and each dance was accompanied not only by its ritual, but also by the narrative of its origin", says Dorsey. The story of the origin of these amulets should be understood, as the author of the collection shows, as a story of how, for example, the first owner of this bag went into the forest, met a buffalo there, which led him to the kingdom of the buffalo, where he received the bag as a gift, learned the dances, and on his return taught all this to the people and became their leader. These stories "were usually the private property of the holder or possessor of the bag or the dance and, as a rule, were told immediately after the celebration of the rite or during the transmission of ownership of the bag or the ceremony to the next owner." Therefore, the story is part of the ceremony, of the rite, is linked to it and to the person who comes into possession of the amulet; it is a kind of verbal amulet, a means of acting magically on the surrounding world. "Therefore, each of these stories was esoteric... And that is why it is so difficult to derive from them something that resembles, in its complexity, an etiological story ( origin-myth )."

在这一观察中，有两个方面很重要。首先，正如已经指出的，故事是与仪式一起发生的，并且构成了仪式中不可限制的部分。其次，我们发现自己正处于迄今为止所观察到的一种现象的根源，即禁止讲述。禁令的颁布和遵守并不是出于礼节的原因，而是因为故事和讲述本身的行为所固有的神奇功能。 « 在讲述这些故事时，叙述者牺牲了自己生命的一部分，从而加速了生命的终结。因此，一位中年男子曾感叹道：“我无法告诉你我所知道的一切，因为我还没有死。”或者，正如一位老牧师所说：“我知道我的日子屈指可数了。我的生命现在已经毫无用处了。我没有理由不说出我所知道的一切。”

Two aspects are important in this observation. First, as has already been noted, the stories are performed together with the ritual and constitute its imprescriptible part. Second, we find ourselves here at the sources of a phenomenon that has been observed up to the present day, namely the prohibition of storytelling. The prohibition was issued and observed not for reasons of etiquette, but for the magical functions inherent in the story and in the act of storytelling itself. "In telling them, the narrator sacrifices a part of his life, thereby hastening its end. Thus a middle-aged man once exclaimed: 'I cannot tell you everything I know, because I am not yet about to die.' Or, as an old priest put it: 'I know that my days are numbered. My life is now useless. There is no reason why I should not tell you everything I know.'

我们将回到禁令，但现在让我们研究一下这些故事和仪式之间的联系。可以反驳的是，多尔西所说的现象是一个特定的、局部的事实：例如，多尔西本人就是这样理解的，因为他没有引用比较材料。但事情并非如此。说实话，这里的故事与仪式之间的联系无法严格证明，但可以根据非常丰富的材料来表明。对此，我们可以参考博阿斯的《印第安传说集》以及他对夸扣特尔部落社会组织和秘密结社的调查。该集合仅包含歌词。从传统民间传说的角度来看，这些只是欧洲已知的许多童话故事和主题的“印度版本”或“变体”，给人的印象是它们只是艺术叙事而不是其他。但一旦人们不仅开始熟悉文本，而且开始熟悉社会组织，甚至是单个部落的社会组织，事情就会完全改变。这些文本突然以全新的视角呈现在我们面前。我们看到它们与这个部落的一切、生活方式有多么紧密的联系，因此，如果没有故事或博阿斯所说的“传说”，部落的仪式和制度就无法理解。反之亦然：故事只有通过对社会生活的分析才能被理解，它们不仅作为社会生活的组成部分进入社会，而且在部落眼中它们是生活的条件之一，就像工具和护身符一样，它们被保存和守护作为最神圣的东西。 « 从字面上看，神话构成了部落最珍贵的财富。它们与部落所尊崇的最神圣事物的精髓息息相关。最重要的神话只有那些小心翼翼地保守秘密的老人才知道……这些神秘知识的老守护者居住在村庄里，像狮身人面像一样沉默，并决定在多大程度上他们可以安全地向他们的父亲透露科学。年轻的一代，在什么时候，这种神秘的传承才能更加富有成效……» 585。神话不仅是生活的组成部分，而且是每个人的一部分。夺走一个人的神话，就等于夺走他的生命。经济和社会功能是神话所固有的，这不是一种特殊现象，而是一种规律。神话的传播会剥夺其神圣的特征，同时也会剥夺其神奇的美德，或者如列维-布留尔所说，剥夺其“神秘的美德”。如果他们失去了神话，部落将不再能够生存。

We will return to the prohibitions, but for now let us examine the connection between these stories and the ceremonial. It may be objected that the phenomenon Dorsey speaks of is a particular, local fact: this is, for example, what Dorsey himself means by not citing comparative material. But things are not like this. To tell the truth, the connection between story and rite cannot be rigorously proved here, but it can be indicated on the basis of very abundant material. One can refer in this regard to Boas's collection of Indian legends and his investigation of the social organization and secret societies of the Kwakiutl tribe. The collection contains only the texts. From the point of view of traditional folklore, these are only "Indian versions" or "variants" of many fairy tales and motifs known in Europe; one gets the impression that these are merely artistic narratives and nothing else. But things change completely as soon as we begin to familiarize ourselves not only with the texts but also with the social organization, even if it is that of a single tribe. These texts suddenly appear to us in a completely new light. We see how closely connected they are with everything, the way of life of this tribe, so that neither its rites nor its institutions are comprehensible without the stories or "legends," as Boas calls them. And vice versa: the stories are understood only by analyzing social life, they enter into it not only as constituent parts, but in the eyes of the tribe they are one of the conditions of life on a par with tools and amulets, they are preserved and guarded like the most sacred things. "The myths constitute, literally, the most precious treasure of the tribe. They are related to the very marrow of what the tribe venerates as its most sacred thing. The most important myths are known only to the old people who jealously guard their secret… The old custodians of this mysterious knowledge reside in the villages, silent as sphinxes, and decide to what extent they can safely entrust the knowledge of the fathers to the young generation and at what time this transmission of the mysteries can be most fruitful… » 585 . Myths are not only constitutive parts of life, they are part of every single individual. To take away the myth from a man is the same as taking away his life. Economic and social functions are inherent in myth, and this is not a special phenomenon, it is a law. The dissemination of the myth would strip it of its sacred character and, at the same time, also of its magical virtue or, as Lévy-Bruhl says, of its « mystical virtue ». If it lost the myths the tribe would no longer be able to maintain itself alive.

与因其主题内容而成为遗物的童话故事不同，在这里，我们与人民的整个现实、他们的经济、他们的社会制度和他们的信仰有着鲜活的联系。英雄或入会者的祖先遇到的动物被描绘在柱子上；这些传说中提到的物品在舞蹈中被携带和佩戴，舞蹈中出现了熊、猫头鹰、乌鸦和其他动物，这些动物赋予了入会者神奇的美德等。

Unlike the fairy tale, which is a relic in terms of the content of its subject, here we have a living link with the whole reality of the people, with its economy, with its social system and with its beliefs. The animals encountered by the hero or the ancestor of the initiate were depicted on columns; the objects mentioned in these legends were carried and worn during the dances; in the dances, bears, owls, crows and other animals were represented that conferred magical virtue to the initiate, etc.

这里引用的材料和我们的考虑告诉我们特定类别的神话是如何诞生的，但它们还没有告诉我们童话故事是如何诞生的。

The materials cited here and our considerations tell us how the myth of a certain category was born, but they do not yet tell us how the fairy tale was born.

在第一章中，我们确定童话故事不是它所存在的社会制度的产物。现在我们可以澄清这个概念。童话的主题和构成是氏族政权进化阶段的产物，例如多尔西、博阿斯等人所研究的美洲部落。在这里我们看到基础和上层建筑之间的直接对应关系。主体的新社会功能及其纯粹的艺术用途与创造该主体的政权的消失有关。这个过程、童话故事中神话重生过程的外在起点，表现为主体的脱离以及叙事行为与仪式的分离。脱离仪式的时刻也是童话历史的开始，而它与仪式的融合则构成了童话的史前史。这种分离可以作为历史的必然而自然发生，也可以通过欧洲人的出现、印第安人的基督教化、整个部落被迫移居到更恶劣的土地、生活方式的改变而人为地加速。 ，通过生产方法的改变等。多尔西此前也观察到了这一差距。我们不要忘记，欧洲人在美洲已经当了500多年的主人，而在这里，我们常常只能看到原始情况的反映，我们有它的解体、它的碎片，或多或少清晰的痕迹。 « 当然，这些关于袋子和舞蹈起源的神话并不总是祭司的专有财产；它们在普通人中间传播，在那种环境下讲述，失去了很多原来的意义。因此，随着逐渐恶化的过程，我们最终不再赋予它们任何意义，它们就像童话故事一样被讲述” 586。多西称脱离神话是“恶化”。但童话故事已经被剥夺了宗教功能，其本身所代表的东西并不逊色于它所源自的神话。相反，它摆脱了宗教传统的束缚，逃入艺术创作的自由氛围中，从不同的社会因素中获得动力，开始蓬勃发展。

In the first chapter we established that the fairy tale is not a product of the social regime in which it exists. Now we can clarify this concept. The subject and the composition of the fairy tale are a product of the clan regime at the stage of evolution represented, for example, by the American tribes studied by Dorsey, Boas and others. Here we see the direct correspondence between base and superstructure. The new social function of the subject, its purely artistic use are connected with the disappearance of the regime that created this subject. The external beginning of this process, of the process of the rebirth of the myth in the fairy tale, is manifested in the detachment of the subject and of the act of narration from the ritual. The moment of detachment from the ritual is also the beginning of the history of the fairy tale, while its syncretism with the ritual constitutes its prehistory. This detachment can occur naturally, as a historical necessity, or it can be hastened artificially by the appearance of the Europeans, by the Christianization of the Indians and by the forced emigration of entire tribes to worse lands, by the change in the way of life, by the change in the methods of production, etc. Dorsey had already observed this detachment. Let us not forget that in America the Europeans have been masters for more than 500 years and that there we often have only a reflection of the original situation, we have its disintegration, its fragments, more or less clear traces. "Of course these myths about the origin of the bags and the dances do not always remain the exclusive property of the priests; they make their way among the common people and, told in that environment, lose much of their original meaning.
