Thus, through a gradual process of deterioration, one ends up not attributing any meaning to them any more and they are told like fairy tales." 586 Dorsey gives the detachment from the myth the name of "deterioration." But the fairy tale, already stripped of religious functions, does not in itself represent anything inferior to the myth from which it is derived. On the contrary, freed from religious conventionalisms, it escapes into the free atmosphere of artistic creation that receives its impulse from already different social factors, and begins to live a luxuriant life.

这不仅从内容的角度解释了这一主题的起源，而且也解释了童话作为一种艺术叙事的起源。

This explains the origin not only of the subject from the point of view of its content, but also the origin of the fairy tale as an artistic narration.

我们再说一遍，这个论点无法得到真正的证明，只能在大量材料上指出，这是不可能的。但尽管如此，仍然存在疑问。在这本书中，我们只讨论童话故事，我们相信可以将它们与其他童话故事分开并单独研究它们。既然我们已经完成了工作，打破了这种联系，我们必须重新连接它，因为对其他类型的研究可能会改变我们对童话故事形成方式的看法。

We repeat that this thesis cannot be truly proven, it can only be pointed out on a considerable amount of material, which is not possible here. But, nevertheless, a doubt still remains. In this book we have spoken only of fairy tales, we have believed it possible to separate them from other fairy tales and study them separately. Having broken the contact, now that we have reached the end of our work, we must reconnect, since the study of other genres could modify our idea about the way in which the fairy tale was formed.

我们研究了所谓原始民族的仪式和神话，并将它们与当代童话故事重新联系起来，但我们没有研究那些民族的童话故事，我们没有考虑到艺术传统从一开始就存在的可能性。

We have examined the rites and myths of the so-called primitive peoples and connected them with contemporary fairy tales, but we have not studied the fairy tales of those peoples, we have not taken into consideration the possibility of an artistic tradition existing from the very beginning.

虽然我们在本书中没有考察与童话故事无关的主题，但我们可以相信，不仅是童话故事，还有许多其他童话故事（例如有关动物的童话故事）都有相同的渊源。这一事实可以通过专门针对这些流派的专着来证明；在这里无法证明这一点。对印度童话集的研究得出的结论是，它完全是仪式材料，也就是说，我们赋予这个词的意义上的童话故事在印度人中仍然是未知的。这种观点对民俗学家来说似乎无法令人信服，但不仅了解文本的民族志学者却很倾向于承认这种情况的可能性。诺伊豪斯在前德国殖民地新几内亚观察到了这一现象。当地人“只知道传说；他们不知道童话故事和寓言。对我们来说看似童话的故事对他们来说就像其他故事一样是传奇” 587。 Lévy-Bruhl 也认为这是既定情况，并引用这些迹象作为证据588。通过对动物童话的分析也可以证实这一点。例如，在北美就有一组特殊的关于郊狼的童话故事。这些是关于郊狼的威力的喜剧故事。斯基迪印第安人这样评价他：“郊狼是一个聪明的家伙。他什么都知道，想要杀他是绝对不可能的。而且他充满了奇怪的幻想，而且非常狡猾，很难战胜他，很少让自己被彻底击败。”但这些“童话故事”是在需要完成某些任务并且必须将郊狼的技能转移给叙述者时讲述的。博戈拉兹在 koreko-kamciadalo 民间传说中发现了我们对美国民间传说的肯定：“koreko-kamciadalo 民间传说以其欢快和滑稽的特征而著称。关于乌鸦库赫特，有许多奇怪而有趣的故事，比如他如何与顽皮的老鼠作战，烧毁自己的房子等等。库赫特既以人的形象出现，又以乌鸦的形象出现。民间传说对他非常不敬，但同时库赫特也是乌鸦造物主，他创造了天地，创造了人类，给了他火，然后给了他狩猎的野兽。” 589。正如多尔西指出的那样，博戈拉兹认为的不敬实际上可能是对乌鸦狡猾的钦佩。无论如何，如果讲述了这么多有趣的事情的乌鸦是天空和大地的创造者，并且如果故事是在狩猎之前讲述的，那么即使在这种情况下，故事的神圣性也是毫无疑问的，因此认为神圣人物不仅仅局限于童话故事。入会仪式绝不是唯一的仪式，还有季节性的狩猎仪式和农业仪式，以及一系列其他仪式，每一个仪式都可能有自己的起源神话。这些仪式和神话之间的联系以及两者与童话故事的联系尚未被研究过。为了澄清这个问题，有必要仔细调查种姓之前的民族民间传说的一致性。这会让我们走得太远，而我们的目的并不意味着立即需要这样做。

Although we have not investigated in this book subjects which are not connected with fairy tales, we may assume that not only fairy tales but also many other fairy tales (for example, those about animals) have the same origin. This fact can be proved by special monographs devoted to these kinds of tales; it cannot be proved here. The study of collections of Indian fairy tales leads to the conclusion that they are exclusively ritual material, that is to say, that fairy tales in the sense we give to this word are still unknown among the Indians. This view seems unconvincing to the student of folklore, but ethnographers, who are familiar with more than the texts, are rather inclined to admit the probability of this situation. Neuhaus observed it in the former German colony of New Guinea. The natives "knew only legends; fairy tales and fables were unknown to them. The tales which seem to us to be fairy tales are to them legends like any other. " 587 Lévy-Bruhl also believes that this is a proven situation and cites the following indications as proof . 588 This can also be confirmed by the analysis of animal tales. Thus, for example, there is a special group of tales about the coyote in North America; these are comical stories about the exploits of the coyote. The Skidi Indians say of him: "The coyote is a clever fellow. He knows everything and it is absolutely impossible to kill him. Moreover, he is full of strange fantasies and is very cunning; he can only be overcome with the greatest difficulty and he rarely lets himself be defeated completely." But these "tales" are told when some feat has to be accomplished and the skill of the coyote must be transferred to the narrator. What we say about American folklore, Bogoraz notes about Koreko-Kamchadalo folklore: "Koreko-Kamchadalo folklore is distinguished by its cheerful and burlesque character. Many strange and funny stories are told about the raven Kucht, how he made war on the mouse-nurses, burned down his own house, etc. Kucht appears both in the guise of a man and in the guise of a raven. Folklore treats him with much irreverence, but at the same time Kucht is also the Raven-Creator, he who created heaven and earth, created man, provided him with fire and then gave him wild beasts for hunting. » 589. What Bogoraz considers irreverence may actually be a feeling of admiration for the crow's cunning, as Dorsey points out. In any case, if the crow about whom so many funny things are told is the creator of heaven and earth and if the stories are told before the hunt, even in this case the sacred character of the story is undoubted and with this the idea is reaffirmed that the sacred character is not limited to fairy tales alone. Initiation is by no means the only rite, there were also seasonal hunting and agricultural rites, as well as a whole series of other rites and each of them may have its origin-myth . The connection between these rites and myths and the connection that unites both to the fairy tale has not yet been studied at all. To clarify this problem, it is necessary to investigate minutely the consistency of folklore in pre-caste peoples. This would take us too far and our purposes do not imply an immediate necessity.

从我们所说的一切来看，对神圣主体的“亵渎”似乎很早就开始了，“亵渎”的意思是将神圣主体转变为亵渎主体，即非宗教的，不是“深奥的”，而是艺术性的。而这也是童话诞生的时刻。但无法确定神圣故事在哪里结束、童话故事从哪里开始。正如 DK Zelenin 在他的研究《童话的魔法宗教功能 590》中所证明的那样，即使在文明国家中，禁止讲述童话故事以及将童话故事归因于狩猎的魔法影响的禁令至今仍然存在。我们从沃古利人、马里人等的童话故事中也知道同样的事情。但这些童话故事都是遗迹、残留物。相反，印度童话几乎完全是一个神圣的故事、一个神话，但它也开始脱离仪式，我们可以看到像当代童话这样的纯粹艺术故事的种子。

From all that we have said it follows that the "profanation" of the sacred subject begins very early, meaning by "profanation" the transformation of the sacred subject into the profane, that is, not religious, not "esoteric", but artistic. And this is also the moment when the fairy tale is born. But it is impossible to determine where the sacred tale ends and where the fairy tale begins. As DK Zelenin demonstrated in his study The Magic-Religious Function of Fairy Tales , 590 the prohibition on telling fairy tales and the attribution to them of a magical influence on hunting has remained up to the present day even among civilized peoples. We know the same thing about the fairy tales of the Voguls, the Mari, etc. But these fairy tales are all relics, residues. On the other hand, the fairy tale of the Indians is almost entirely a sacred tale, a myth, but it too begins to detach itself from the rite and one can see in it the seeds of a purely artistic tale such as the contemporary fairy tale.

因此，童话继承了远古时代的社会文化和思想文化。但如果说它是宗教的唯一继承人，那就错了。宗教本身也发生了变化，并包含了非常遥远的遗迹。在埃及、希腊以及后来的基督教中发展起来的所有对来世和死者命运的描述，都出现得更早。这里不能不提萨满教，它也继承了童话故事中保存的史前时代的很多东西。

Thus the fairy tale has inherited from the most remote epochs their social and ideological culture. But it would be wrong to say that it is the sole heir of religion. Religion, as such, has also changed and contains in itself very remote relics. All the representations of the afterlife and of the fate of the dead, which developed in Egypt, Greece and later in Christianity, arose much earlier. Here we cannot omit a reference to shamanism, which has also inherited much from the prehistoric epochs preserved in the fairy tale.

如果我们把萨满巫师驱魔的故事、他们去另一个世界寻找灵魂的方式、帮助他们的人、他们的旅程等等结合起来。我们将它们与童话英雄的流浪或飞行进行比较，我们得到了对应关系。我们对单个元素做到了这一点，但对于复合体也存在巧合。这就解释了神话、来世之旅故事、萨满故事、童话故事以及后来的诗歌、英雄传说和史诗的统一性。随着封建文化的诞生，民间传说的成分成为统治阶级的遗产；在这一民间传说的基础上，诞生了诸如《特里斯坦与伊索尔德》、《尼伯龙根之歌》等英雄传说的循环。换句话说，运动是自下而上进行的，而不是像反动理论家所说的自上而下进行的。

If we put together the shamans' tales of their exorcisms, of the way they go to the other world in search of their souls, of the beings who help them in their enterprise, of their journey, etc., and compare them with the wanderings or the flight of the fairy-tale hero, we obtain a correspondence. We have done this for individual elements, but the coincidence also exists for the complex. This explains the unity of composition of the myth, of the tale of the journey to the afterlife, of the shaman's tale, of the fairy tale, and later of the poem, of the heroic legend and of the epic. With the birth of feudal culture, the elements of folklore become the heritage of the ruling class; on the basis of this folklore arise the cycles of heroic legends such as Tristan and Isolde, the Song of the Nibelungs, etc. In other words, the movement proceeds from the bottom upwards, and not from the top downwards, as the reactionary theorists claim.

这就是对这一一直被认为难以解释的现象的历史解释，即民俗主体的普遍类比现象。这个类比比肉眼所看到的要广泛得多、深刻得多。无论是移民理论，还是人类学派所倡导的人类心灵统一理论，都无法解决这个问题。这个问题可以通过对民俗学与物质生活经济的联系进行历史调查来解决。

Here lies the historical explanation of that phenomenon which has always been considered difficult to explain, namely the phenomenon of the universal analogy of folkloric subjects. This analogy is much broader and deeper than it appears to the naked eye. Neither the theory of migrations nor that of the unity of the human psyche, advocated by the anthropological school, can resolve this problem. It is resolved by the historical investigation of folklore in its connection with the economy of material life.

这个被认为如此困难的问题因此是可以解决的。但每个解决的问题都会立即引发其他问题。民俗学的研究可以遵循两个方向：现象的类比研究和差异研究。民间传说，尤其是童话故事，不仅是统一的，而且尽管具有统一性，但它却异常丰富和多面。对这种多样性的研究，对个别主题的研究，似乎比对构成的类比的研究更加困难。如果这里提出的解决方案是正确的，我们就可以继续研究各个主题、它们的解释问题及其历史。

The problem, thought so difficult, is therefore soluble. But every solved problem immediately gives rise to others. The study of folklore can follow two directions: that of the study of the analogy of phenomena and that of the study of differences. Folklore, and the fairy tale in particular, is not only uniform, but for all its uniformity, it is extraordinarily rich and multiform. The study of this multiformity, the study of individual subjects appears more difficult than that of the analogy of composition. If the solution proposed here proves correct, we can proceed to the study of individual subjects, to the problem of their interpretation and their history.

22俄语单词jagà（女巫、女巫、befana）被翻译为“maga”，因为作者对jagà和ved'ma（特别是“女巫”）进行了区分。 [编辑。 T. ]。

22 The Russian word jagà (witch, witch, befana) was translated « witch » because the author makes a distinction between jagà and ved'ma (specifically « witch »). [ N. d. T .].

"The life of a book does not end with the last page"
